Vietnam is tipped to lead the trade recovery, followed by Malaysia, with Singapore benefiting from its outsized external sector. The report attributes this growth to short-term demand for semiconductors and pandemic-related medical products, as well as supply-side factors. However, economies more exposed to South Asia and South-east Asia, such as Indonesia and the Philippines, may lose out on manufacturing competitiveness due to weak infrastructure and business conditions.

site_title: Malaysia's Axiata, RHB Bank to jointly bid for digital bank licence
summary: Malaysian telecoms firm Axiata Group and RHB Bank have teamed up to jointly bid for a digital bank licence in Malaysia, with the central bank aiming to issue up to five online-only bank licences by June 30. This move follows the trend of regulators opening up banking for digital players in Asia, driven by mobile connectivity and the need for low-cost financial services. The partnership aims to expand collaborations between the two companies, but neither has commented on the application.

site_title: Living with endemic Covid-19 also means Singapore does not completely close its borders: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced the country will not completely close its borders due to endemic Covid-19. Effective safeguards and border restrictions will remain in place to allow for the flow of food, essential supplies, workers, and travellers. With increased vaccination rates and booster shots, Singapore aims to keep the community safe while accepting some cases. The government will re-open borders safely, resume pre-pandemic activities, and eventually lift mask mandates outdoors. Countries that implement sensible safeguards will be able to reopen their economies and reconnect to the world.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher; post seventh monthly gain
summary: South Korean stocks ended higher on Monday, marking their seventh consecutive monthly gain, as foreign investors bought shares worth 520.9 billion won. The Kospi index rose 0.48% to 3,203.92, driven by gains from chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix. The won also rose, while May exports are expected to have risen at their quickest pace in over three decades, driven by strong global demand for semiconductors, cars, and petroleum products.

site_title: CIMB Group profits boosted by one-off gain
summary: CIMB Group Holdings reported a 384% increase in first-quarter earnings, driven by a one-off gain of RM1.16 billion from an investment in its e-wallet business, TNG Digital. The bank's net profit rose to RM2.46 billion, with revenue increasing 4% to RM5.96 billion. Higher income, improved net interest margins, and lower provisions contributed to the boost. CIMB's stock exchange filing also showed a 33% decrease in provisions and the absence of large impairments, further improving underlying profitability.

site_title: Japan's consumer confidence eases in May: government
summary: Japan's consumer confidence eased in May, reaching 34.1, down from 34.7 in April, according to a Cabinet Office survey. The slowdown in the sentiment index was attributed to prolonged lockdown measures to curb coronavirus infections. The government downgraded its view on the pace of recovery, indicating a slower pace of economic growth.

site_title: Malaysia says WTO agreed to establish panel to examine EU palm oil rules
summary: Malaysia's government announced that the World Trade Organisation (WTO) has agreed to establish a panel to examine the European Union's (EU) rules restricting the use of palm oil-based biofuels. The EU's renewable energy directive aims to phase out palm oil-based fuels by 2030 due to concerns over deforestation. Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, has launched a WTO case against the EU, claiming the measures are discriminatory. A WTO panel will now examine the EU's rules, with Malaysia committed to pursuing legal action if necessary.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip from record high, Deutsche Bank drags
summary: European stocks slipped 0.1% on Monday due to subdued trading caused by holidays in major markets. Despite this, the pan-European Stoxx 600 index is on track for a fourth consecutive month of gains. The index rose 2.6% in May as economies reopened after lockdowns, with governments and central banks reiterating support for the recovery. Deutsche Bank fell 1.7% after the US Federal Reserve expressed concerns over its anti-money-laundering controls.

site_title: Thai April factory output posts biggest rise in more than 8 years
summary: Thailand's manufacturing production index (MPI) in April rose 18.46% from a year earlier, the fastest pace in over 8 years, driven by increased production of automobiles, beer, and air conditioners. The MPI beat forecasts, with capacity utilisation at 59.58% in April, down from 70.65% in March due to extended holidays. The country's current COVID-19 wave is expected to have a limited impact on overall output, with infections mainly affecting certain groups.

site_title: China limits travel in most populous province over Covid-19 cases
summary: China has imposed travel limits and cancelled flights in Guangdong province, the country's most populous region, due to the reported Indian variant of the coronavirus. Residents leaving Guangzhou must show negative Covid-19 test results from the past 72 hours. Authorities have ordered mass testing in several districts and cancelled hundreds of flights. The province reported 18 new local cases, with patients infected with the fast-spreading Indian variant. China has largely brought domestic transmission under control, but tightened quarantine rules amid concerns over overseas variants.

site_title: H&M's online second-hand shop Sellpy launches in 20 more countries
summary: H&M's online second-hand shop Sellpy is expanding into 20 more European countries, taking its total markets to 24. The platform, majority-owned by H&M, offers a sustainable alternative to traditional fast fashion. Sellpy handles the sales process from pickup to shipping, with over 9 million garments sold since its 2014 launch in Sweden. The expansion aims to capitalize on growing demand for sustainable fashion, with the company's head of expansion stating that "every garment bought pre-owned saves resources for our planet."

site_title: Nestle, under fire over unhealthy products, working on new strategy
summary: Nestle is working on updating its nutrition and health strategy after an internal document revealed that over 60% of its mainstream food and drinks portfolio is considered unhealthy. The assessment, which excludes certain categories, would reduce the proportion to around 28% if including medical nutrition, pet food, and other excluded categories. Nestle has reduced sugars and sodium in its products by 14-15% in the past seven years and plans to continue making its products healthier. The company is working on a "company-wide project" to ensure its products meet nutritional needs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Monday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.48% at 29,008.44, and the Topix index down 0.42% at 1,939.27. Investors are awaiting economic indicators due this week at home and abroad, following a rally in last week's session.

site_title: CNMC to cease Kelantan operations in first phase of Malaysia's 'total lockdown'
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings announced it will temporarily cease all on-site operations in Kelantan, Malaysia, from June 1 to 14, as part of the country's two-week lockdown. The company aims to seek clarification on whether its operations are considered "essential" during this period. If successful in reducing daily Covid-19 cases, certain economic sectors may resume operations in a subsequent four-week lockdown. CNMC shares fell 2.1% after the announcement.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders await fresh catalysts
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day, with investors awaiting the release of key US jobs data and the impact of inflation on the economy. Despite a forecast-beating jump in US inflation, benchmark 10-year Treasury yields edged down slightly. Asian markets fluctuated, with gains in Seoul, Taipei, Jakarta, and Wellington, while Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Singapore dipped. The focus now shifts to the upcoming US jobs data, which will provide a fresh update on the state of the world's top economy.

site_title: Activists launch action against 'cookie banner terror'
summary: A Vienna-based group, NOYB, is taking action against hundreds of websites for their use of pop-up banners asking users to consent to cookies, which track online activity. The group claims these banners do not conform to EU laws, including GDPR, and are designed to be frustrating for users. NOYB will lodge over 500 draft complaints with companies in 33 countries if they don't comply with privacy laws. The group aims to simplify cookie consent processes and give users a clear "yes or no" option.

site_title: Indian economy faces resilience test amid risks from virus
summary: The Indian economy is set to test its resilience as it faces challenges from the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Despite forecasts of a 10% growth rate this year, economists warn that the economy's recovery is uncertain due to ongoing restrictions and low consumer spending. The country's vaccination pace is also a concern, with a potential third wave of infections expected to weigh on growth. The Reserve Bank of India has kept monetary policy loose, but experts predict the economy could slow down to 7.7% if hit by a third wave.

site_title: New rule on Covid-19 test for returning Singaporeans, PRs not a straightforward matter: experts
summary: Singapore has introduced a new requirement for citizens and permanent residents to test negative for COVID-19 before returning home from high-risk countries. Starting May 31, 2021, they must present a valid negative PCR test taken within 72 hours before departure. The measure aims to protect front-line staff at the airport and ease the load on Singapore's healthcare system, which has seen a spike in community cases. However, experts note that the measure has limitations, including the difficulty in accessing tests in some countries and the potential for false negatives. The government has also raised concerns about the constitutionality of the new requirement, with at least one legal expert questioning its constitutionality.

site_title: Hot stock: Union Gas rises as much as 7.4%, prompting SGX query
summary: Union Gas shares surged 7.4% on Monday, prompting a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query about "unusual price movements". The fuel provider's shares rose to 94 cents before easing to 90.5 cents, with the company attributing the trading to no new information. Union Gas confirmed its compliance with listing rules and stated it is not aware of any information that could explain the trading. The SGX is investigating the unusual price movements.

site_title: China to allow couples to have three children to boost birthrate
summary: China has decided to allow all couples to have a third child in an effort to boost its shrinking birthrate and aging population. The decision was made at a Politburo meeting, which also discussed implementing support policies and lifting the retirement age in a phased manner. The move aims to improve the population's structure, but experts warn that it may not lead to a sustained increase in birthrate, as previous relaxations have had limited effect. China's declining birthrate has raised concerns about the country's long-term economic prospects, with estimates suggesting the population may peak before 2025.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as virus cluster hits risk appetite
summary: Australian shares ended lower on Monday after hitting a record high, as the country's Covid-19 cluster in Victoria continued to swell, with 11 new cases reported. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.3% lower at 7,161.6, securing an eighth straight monthly gain in May. The central bank is expected to hold interest rates steady on Tuesday, but investors are awaiting signs of hawkishness. Energy stocks were the worst performers, with the sub-index closing 1.6% lower.

site_title: Australian dollar edges up as data-packed week starts, kiwi also higher
summary: The Australian dollar rose 0.19% to US$0.7723, on track for its second consecutive month of gains, ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's monetary policy-setting meeting. The New Zealand dollar also gained 0.12% to US$0.7257, as investors await the RBA's stance on interest rates and economic output figures for the first quarter of 2021. The RBA is expected to reaffirm its guidance of keeping the cash rate at record lows "until 2024 at the earliest", highlighting the divergence with global peers.

site_title: Australia's carbon emissions drop 5% in 2020
summary: Australia's carbon emissions decreased by 5% in 2020, falling to 499 million tonnes of CO2-e, 20% below 2005 levels. The drop was attributed to growth in wind and solar energy, a decline in transport emissions due to COVID-19 lockdowns, and increased carbon capture at the Gorgon LNG project. The country is on track to meet its 2030 Paris target, but has refused to set a more ambitious target, differing from other nations.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip downgrades Sembcorp to 'neutral', says positives priced in
summary: Phillip Securities has downgraded its call on Sembcorp Industries to "neutral" from "accumulate" due to the pricing of its positive aspects. Despite maintaining a higher target price of S$2.07, the research house believes the group's transformation plan and improving operating metrics are already reflected in the stock price. Analysts expect Sembcorp to achieve its sustainability goals, but remain cautious due to uncertainties surrounding the pandemic recovery and intense competition in the utility sector.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee outlined plans to tackle COVID-19, including faster testing, contact-tracing, and vaccinations. The government aims to ease curbs if the situation improves by June 13. Residents can get vaccinated from 39 and below by mid-June, and students can book vaccination slots starting June 1. Singapore will also allow private clinics to offer a wider range of COVID-19 vaccines, but at individual cost and risk. Additionally, the country is ramping up testing and DBS has issued its first tokenized bond on a digital exchange.

site_title: China reports 20 new local coronavirus cases in Guangdong province
summary: China reported 20 new local Covid-19 cases in Guangdong province on May 30, with 18 in Guangzhou and two in Foshan. Authorities locked down areas and suspended non-essential activities, while entertainment venues and markets were closed. The new cases were attributed to a fast-spreading virus strain detected in India. China's total confirmed cases rose to 91,099, with its death toll remaining unchanged at 4,636. The country also reported 19 new asymptomatic infections.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close down on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed down 0.99% on Monday due to profit-taking following last week's rally. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index fell 289.33 points to 28,860.08, while the Topix index slipped 24.46 points to 1,922.98. Investors are awaiting global economic indicators set to be released this week.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 21.06 points, or 1.32%, to 1,573.38, on Monday, with 844 losers beating 78 gainers. The market opened lower amidst global market fluctuations.

site_title: IRAS withholds S$85m in JSS, JGI payouts to 2,600 employers, pending checks
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) has withheld S$85 million in Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) and Jobs Growth Incentive (JGI) payouts to 2,600 employers, pending checks on gaming and employer claims. This is part of IRAS's efforts to ensure fair payouts and has resulted in the denial of over S$16 million in payouts. Whistleblower reports have contributed to the investigation, with 500 tip-offs made to IRAS, and employers found to have made false claims face severe penalties, including up to 10 years in prison.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street higher, bullion shines
summary: Australian stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by Wall Street's higher finish and strong commodity prices. Gold stocks led gains, with gold prices surging above the US$1,900 mark after a stronger-than-expected inflation reading in the US. Mining stocks added 0.7%, while banking stocks rose 0.2%. Energy stocks, however, lost nearly 1.3% despite oil prices reaching two-year peaks.

site_title: Cities across China's industrial heartland now rationing power
summary: Cities across Guangdong province in China are rationing electricity to businesses due to high demand from the global economic recovery and hot summer weather. 21 municipalities in the province are limiting power use, primarily affecting factories and businesses, with some shutting down several days a week. Power supplies for homes and public utilities remain unaffected. The rationing is a result of a surge in electricity consumption, driven by increased activity from businesses and factories, and boosted by high temperatures and low rainfall.

site_title: Taiwan's new Covid-19 cases slow but restrictions to stay in coming weeks
summary: Taiwan reported 347 domestic Covid-19 cases on Monday, marking the second consecutive day with new cases below 400. Health Minister Chen Shih-chung stated that the pandemic is heading towards a stage where it can be controlled, and restrictions will remain in place for the next one to two weeks. Measures include fines for not wearing face masks, a halt to wedding banquets, and the setup of rapid Covid-19 test stations in outlying islands. The government also approved an additional T$420 billion in stimulus spending to help the economy.

site_title: Cauayan City navigates typhoon damage with help of Singapore startup Graffiquo
summary: Cauayan City in the Philippines has successfully navigated typhoon damage with the help of Singapore startup Graffiquo, a digital twin software and service provider. Graffiquo built an integrated digital twin system for disaster resiliency, enabling the city to assess damage and rebuild in just one day. The system uses aerial photos and data to predict flooding, identify areas of need, and dispatch emergency resources. The partnership has created new jobs and increased skill levels, and Graffiquo and Cauayan City recently won The Gamechangers Award for their innovative use of cloud technology to improve disaster response.

site_title: Addvalue unit bags contract to supply connectivity solutions to Chinese fishing ships
summary: Addvalue Tech's subsidiary has secured a contract with CTTIC Shanghai to supply satellite-communication solutions to over 1,000 Chinese fishing vessels. The deal includes the provision of Addvalue iFleetONE-VMS Terminals to the ships, aimed at helping them comply with regulatory requirements and transform their operations digitally. This follows an earlier agreement signed in August 2020. The contract is expected to contribute to Addvalue's growth and expand its presence in the maritime industry.

site_title: Portfolio of 29 cloud kitchen units at Lavender Street served up for sale
summary: Design and construction firm Chiu Teng Group is selling its portfolio of 29 ground-floor cloud kitchen units at Lavender Street in Singapore. The units, ranging from 26 to 42 square meters, are fully leased to popular food delivery tenants, including Mos Burger and Pho Stop. The site, approved for food & beverage use, is a three-minute walk from Bendemeer MRT station. The sale is seen as an opportunity for investors to generate immediate income with potential for future rental appreciation, amid a growing demand for cloud kitchens in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Design and construction firm Chiu Teng Group is understood to be selling its portfolio of 29 ground-floor cloud kitchen units at CT Hub 2 via expression of interest.

site_title: Covid-19 vaccination to be offered to those 39 and below by mid-June; deemed safe for pregnant women
summary: Singapore's expert committee on Covid-19 vaccination has revised its guidance, allowing pregnant women to receive the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines, deemed safe for them and their babies. Vaccination will also be available to those 39 and below by mid-June. Additionally, cancer patients on active treatment, persons with Severe Cutaneous Adverse Reactions, and those with a history of anaphylaxis (excluding mRNA vaccine reactions) can now receive the vaccines with proper assessment and guidelines.

site_title: Australia's Victoria Covid-19 cluster swells to 51, next few days 'critical'
summary: Australia's Victoria state reported 11 new cases of community transmission of COVID-19, swelling the current cluster to 51. The state went into a seven-day lockdown after a three-month run of zero community cases. Authorities warn the next few days will be critical, with the possibility of the outbreak worsening before it improves. The latest variant, detected in India, is considered more virulent, with a faster infection rate. The situation raises concerns about a larger outbreak in aged care homes, where two workers and one resident tested positive.

site_title: NTUC Foodfare cluster grows to nine, Hong Ye Group cluster up to 21
summary: Two more Covid-19 patients have been linked to the NTUC Foodfare cluster, bringing the total to nine, while four new cases have been linked to the Hong Ye Group cluster, increasing the total to 21. Additionally, 16 community cases and seven imported cases have been reported, adding to Singapore's total of 62,051 coronavirus cases.

site_title: Australia clears A$2.28b power line to boost renewable energy
summary: Australia's energy market operator has approved a $2.28 billion project to build the country's longest power transmission line, EnergyConnect, between South Australia and New South Wales. The 900km line, developed by TransGrid and ElectraNet, will help connect customers with renewable energy and prevent blackouts. The project was delayed due to cost recovery rules, but secured $295 million in hybrid debt funding from the national government's Clean Energy Finance Corp. The line is expected to facilitate up to 1,800 megawatts of low-cost renewable energy generation in South Australia, New South Wales, and Victoria.

site_title: Growth in China's services sector accelerates in May: official PMI
summary: China's services sector activity accelerated in May, with the official non-manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 55.2 from 54.9 in April. This marked a faster pace of growth compared to the previous month. The improvement in domestic consumption has stimulated activity in China's services sector, which includes many smaller and private companies. Despite slower growth compared to manufacturing, the gradual improvement in consumption has provided a boost to the services sector.

site_title: Japan's April factory output extends gains, retail sales jump
summary: Japan's industrial output rose 2.5% in April, driven by production of general-purpose and electrical machinery, despite a slower-than-expected growth pace due to ongoing coronavirus measures. Retail sales surged 12.0% in April, mainly due to statistical base effects, but consumer sentiment remains a concern. The government expects the economy to grow at a slower pace than initially thought, with manufacturers forecasting a 1.7% decline in May and a 5.0% rebound in June.

site_title: Beijing's Hong Kong office slams intimidation of judge in tycoon Jimmy Lai's case
summary: Beijing's Hong Kong office has condemned threats made to a judge who sentenced media tycoon Jimmy Lai and other democracy activists for their roles in an unauthorized assembly on October 1, 2019. The presiding judge received threatening phone calls, prompting the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office to warn of the threat to judges' safety. The sentencing was part of the aftermath of 2019's anti-government protests, which led to the imposition of a national security law by Beijing. The law has led to over 100 arrests, including Lai, and has drawn criticism from Western governments and international rights groups.

site_title: PropertyGuru to acquire REA Group's Malaysia, Thailand units
summary: Singapore real estate startup PropertyGuru has agreed to acquire REA Group's operating entities in Malaysia and Thailand, marking its largest acquisition in 14 years. The deal, valued at no price disclosed, will give PropertyGuru an 18% equity interest in the company and appoint a director to its board. The acquisition is expected to reduce competition in Malaysia and Thailand, where PropertyGuru has been competing against REA's affiliates, and will allow the company to invest in its existing brands.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.3% or 9.64 points to 3,188.19. The gains followed Wall Street's increase, despite data showing increased inflation. Addvalue Technologies and Chasen led the gains, with their shares rising 7.8% and 1%, respectively. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also rose, with UOB leading the pack. The market's positive sentiment was also influenced by European stocks reaching a new high and the US economy showing solid earnings.

site_title: GIC plans to open new Australian office to focus on investment opportunities
summary: Singapore's Government Investment Corporation (GIC) plans to open its 11th worldwide office in Sydney, Australia, to focus on investment opportunities in the country. The new office will support the management of existing assets and increase interaction with local partners to generate value-add. GIC currently holds an Australian portfolio with steady growth across various sectors, including real estate and logistics. The move aims to capitalize on private market capabilities to generate good, risk-adjusted returns for the overall portfolio.

site_title: Vaccination slots for students open for booking from June 1
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Education will start booking vaccination slots for eligible students on June 1, with priority given to those sitting national examinations. Students under 18 will receive the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, while those 18 and above can choose between the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines. Vaccination centers will be set up in community centers and dedicated MOE centers, with mobile teams to reach SPED schools. Parents or guardians must consent for students under 18, who may not need accompaniment for those aged 13 and above.

site_title: Crypto traders defy China's crackdown with secretive bets
summary: Chinese investors are continuing to defy the government's crackdown on cryptocurrency trading by secretly using over-the-counter (OTC) platforms and peer-to-peer networks. Despite a warning from the government earlier this month, the yuan exchange rate against the stablecoin Tether has largely recovered. Chinese investors remain a significant presence in the global crypto market, with estimates suggesting they owned 7% of the world's Bitcoin before the 2017 exchange ban. The government's efforts to enforce a wholesale ban will be challenging due to the hard-to-trace nature of transactions on these platforms.

site_title: Temasek-backed Sprinklr reveals 19% jump in revenue in IPO filing
summary: Sprinklr, a marketing software startup backed by Temasek, reported a 19.3% increase in annual revenue to $386.9 million, despite an annual net attributable loss of $41.2 million. The company, which counts Microsoft and McDonald's as customers, confidentially submitted IPO paperwork in March and plans to list on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol "CXM". This comes as the US IPO market is experiencing a bull run, with technology stocks seeing high investor demand.

site_title: Singapore can ease curbs after June 13, if situation improves and community cases fall: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced that the country may ease curbs after June 13 if the Covid-19 situation improves and community cases fall further. The government aims to relax restrictions, including a ban on dining-in, if the outbreak is brought under control. As of May 30, Singapore has 62,028 cases and 33 deaths. Lee emphasized the importance of continued efforts to stay home, work from home, and seek medical attention if unwell, with the goal of testing, contact-tracing, and vaccination becoming more widespread and effective.

site_title: South Korea's April factory output unexpectedly declines from March
summary: South Korea's factory output declined 1.6% seasonally adjusted from March, missing a 1.5% forecast gain, but surged 12.4% year-over-year, the fastest growth since October 2018. This was due to sluggish production in the second quarter of last year due to the pandemic. The unexpected decline in April's factory output was the biggest since May last year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Addvalue, Mapletree NAC Trust, Keppel, Lian Beng, KSH, mm2 Asia
summary: Several Singapore companies saw developments that may impact trading. Addvalue secured a contract with CTTIC Shanghai to supply satellite communication solutions to over 1,000 Chinese fishing vessels. RW0U, a real estate investment trust, bought a Tokyo office building for S$467.3 million. Keppel Land's unit VN Prosperity is buying a Vietnamese housing project for S$21.6 million. Lian Beng requested an extension to sell assets, and ER0 reported a loss of S$3.8 million for FY2021. mm2 Asia posted a net loss of S$92.7 million for FY2021, while Valuetronics reported a 4.6% year-on-year increase in net profit.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened Monday slightly higher, building on last week's gains as fears over inflation give way to optimism over economic recovery. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.35% to 29,225.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat. The Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange gained 0.12%. The gains come despite US trade uncertainty and a split Federal Reserve view, as investors focus on the economic recovery.

site_title: Goodyear faces allegations of labour abuse in Malaysia
summary: American tire manufacturer Goodyear is facing allegations of unpaid wages, unlawful overtime, and threats to foreign workers at its Malaysian factory. Court documents and complaints filed by six current and former foreign workers claim the company made wrongful salary deductions, required excessive hours, and denied workers full access to their passports. The allegations come after a court ruled in favor of the foreign workers in two cases, ordering Goodyear to pay back wages and comply with a collective labor agreement.

site_title: Qantas offers unlimited flights in biggest vaccine incentive
summary: Qantas Airways is offering 10 "mega prizes" of unlimited flights for a year to fully vaccinated individuals, as part of a vaccination incentive program. The prizes include free travel for families of four with Qantas and Jetstar, and come as Australia struggles to overcome vaccine hesitancy. Only about 4.2 million people in a nation of 26 million have received their first shot, prompting calls from Qantas CEO Alan Joyce for other Australian companies to offer similar incentives.

site_title: UK vaccine passport plans to be scrapped: The Telegraph
summary: The UK plans to drop Covid-19 vaccine passport requirements for large events, with officials stating there's no chance the law will be changed. The decision comes amid concerns from the Conservative Party, opposition lawmakers, and civil rights groups. Prime Minister Boris Johnson previously signaled the ethical issues with vaccine certification. A government review into Covid-19 status certificates is ongoing, with no decision yet made.

site_title: Gold set for best month since July 2020 on softer dollar, inflation woes
summary: Gold prices are set for their best monthly jump since July 2020, driven by a weaker US dollar and lower bond yields. Spot gold rose 0.4% to $1,909.81 per ounce, with a nearly 8% gain this month. Inflationary pressure and a softer dollar are fueling demand for gold as a hedge. Investors are also eyeing US payrolls data this week, with a target of $1,950.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with gains on easing concerns about rising inflation, driven by focus on the global economic recovery. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.09%, while the Shanghai Composite Index advanced 0.41%. The Shenzhen Composite Index climbed 1.10%. These gains come amid global economic recovery optimism, despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says stimulus still needed amid pandemic uncertainties
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) has reaffirmed its preference for maintaining monetary stimulus for a longer period than withdrawing it, citing ongoing pandemic uncertainties. Assistant Governor Christian Hawkesby stated that the bank would rather keep stimulus in place for too long than take it away too quickly. This stance is conditional on various assumptions falling into place by the end of next year, allowing for the removal of some stimulus.

site_title: Rich China tycoons park family offices in S'pore
summary: Wealthy Chinese families are increasingly setting up family offices in Singapore to manage their offshore assets, drawn by the city-state's favorable tax regime and legal environment. With over 400 single family offices (SFOs) now operating in Singapore, the country has become a popular base for Chinese high-net-worth individuals. The surge in SFOs is attributed to Singapore's transparent and stable judiciary, as well as its tax exemption schemes. This trend is expected to continue, with banks and wealth management firms reporting significant growth in clients from the Greater China region, and experts predicting a five-year upward trend.

images.alt_text: From left: Ms Zhao set up a single family office in Singapore; DBS Private Bank's Mr Lee says in the past three years, there has been double-digit growth in clients from the Greater China region; and Bank of Singapore's Ms Ho says the number of new clients incorporating family offices in 2020 was at least three times that of 2019.

site_title: One of world's top ports expects delays on China covid outbreak
summary: China's Yantian Port, one of the world's busiest ports, expects delays due to a recent Covid-19 outbreak. All shipments leaving the port require reservations, and stricter virus-control measures may cause delays for imports. The port, which handles about 100 ships a week, has strengthened its testing program and may interrupt vessels arriving at the port. This disruption is expected to continue into the coming week, adding pressure to already high shipping costs from China, which could fuel global inflation. The port's operator shares have fallen 1.8% on the news.

site_title: Faster, more extensive testing, contact-tracing and vaccinations will help Singapore tackle Covid-19: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for faster and more extensive testing, contact-tracing, and vaccinations to tackle the Covid-19 pandemic. The government plans to increase testing, including the use of breathalyser tests and do-it-yourself tests, and will expand contact-tracing to include close contacts of infected individuals. Vaccinations will also be accelerated, with faster deliveries expected over the next two months, and priority given to certain groups, including students and young adults. The goal is to have two-thirds of the population vaccinated by early July and reach herd immunity.

site_title: Sakae attempts to defend the indefensible after humiliating query from SGX RegCo
summary: Sakae Holdings faced criticism after attempting to justify its interactions with SGX RegCo, citing a dictionary definition of "close collaboration". The company had reportedly used the term to describe its relationship with the regulator, despite SGX RegCo stating it had not collaborated. This incident highlights concerns about corporate governance standards in Singapore, with the Corporate Governance Watch report suggesting that listed companies are a major weakness. The report notes that regulators are taking steps to enhance the regulatory landscape, but that the support of investors is also necessary to effect change.

site_title: Apple to open more stores even as pandemic drives online sales
summary: Apple plans to expand its global retail presence despite the pandemic's shift to online sales, aiming to add more stores. The company operates around 500 stores globally, including 100 in Europe, and sees retail locations as a key opportunity for customers to experience products and attend workshops. Apple's senior vice-president of retail and people, Deirdre O'Brien, stated that online learning can't replace the in-store experience, and the company intends to add more stores. This move counters the trend of many retailers cutting store locations amid the pandemic.

site_title: Late arrival of monsoon rains in India may delay sowing of crops
summary: India's southwest monsoon, which waters over half of the country's farmland, is expected to arrive two days late, potentially delaying the sowing of major crops such as rice, corn, and soybeans. The monsoon's delayed arrival may impact crop output and economic growth, particularly in rural areas where about 70% of the population lives. This delay could also reduce harvests if the monsoon gathers pace later. The India Meteorological Department had initially predicted the monsoon's onset date to be May 31, but it is now expected to arrive in Kerala on June 3.

site_title: Australian farmer counts the cost of mouse plague after drought
summary: Australian farmer Norman Moeris is dealing with a severe mouse plague that has ravaged crops, damaged equipment, and invaded homes. The infestation, fueled by recent heavy rains, has cost Moeris around $130,000 in lost grain. Despite efforts to control the population with bait and traps, the mice continue to multiply, posing a significant threat to the country's agricultural industry. The New South Wales state government has offered free bait, but some farmers and environmentalists oppose the use of a banned poison due to its potential impact on native animals.

site_title: Kuwaiti breeder hopes superworms will become new superfood
summary: Kuwaiti businessman Jassem Buabbas is breeding "superworms" for animal feed, aiming to eventually market them as a human food alternative. The darkling beetle larvae, high in protein, have been gaining popularity in the pet trade and could potentially become the first edible insect species to be sold in Gulf restaurants. Buabbas has created three sauces for the superworms and is awaiting permission from Kuwaiti authorities to serve them to humans. The European Commission has approved dried mealworms for human consumption, paving the way for the insect farming industry.

site_title: Moya unit's water supply system in Indonesia commences operations
summary: Moya Holdings Asia's subsidiary, Air Semarang Barat, successfully achieved the commercial operation date (COD) of its 25-year water treatment supply system project in West Semarang, Indonesia on May 22. The project has a water treatment capacity of up to 1,000 litres per second and aims to increase the reliability of clean water supply to customers in Semarang City. The project's on-time completion brings positive impacts to the community, despite the current Covid-19 pandemic situation. Moya's shares rose 1.5% after the announcement.

site_title: Hong Kong's 'Grandma Wong' arrested for solo Tiananmen protest
summary: Hong Kong police arrested 65-year-old Alexandra "Grandma Wong" for participating in a solo protest against China's Tiananmen crackdown near Beijing's Liaison Office. Wong, a democracy activist, waved a Union Jack flag and chanted slogans despite being denied permission for a Tiananmen-themed march. She was detained on suspicion of taking part in an unlawful assembly and faces charges related to inciting others to join an unauthorized assembly. This arrest marks a zero-tolerance approach to protests in Hong Kong, where the democracy movement has been severely suppressed.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong police have arrested an elderly democracy activist as she made a solo demonstration over China's deadly Tiananmen crackdown in a vivid illustration of the zero protest tolerance now wielded by authorities in the financial hub.

site_title: PM Lee to address nation live at 4pm, May 31 on Covid-19 plans
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will address the nation live on May 31, sharing plans to control Covid-19 and progressively reopen the country. The address comes after the number of new community cases has stabilized, and the government is preparing for a future where the coronavirus becomes endemic. Lee will discuss measures such as vaccinations, booster jabs, and improved hygiene standards. The address will be live-streamed on Facebook and televised on MediaCorp channels at 4pm.

site_title: US spied on Merkel, European allies with Danish help: media
summary: The US National Security Agency (NSA) spied on top European politicians, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel, from 2012 to 2014 with Danish help. The spying was done through a collaboration with Denmark's military intelligence unit FE and involved eavesdropping on Danish internet cables. The US accessed SMS text messages, telephone calls, and internet traffic, including searches and chats. Danish Defence Minister Trine Bramsen stated that systematic eavesdropping of close allies is unacceptable. The information was revealed through an investigation by Danish broadcaster Danmarks Radio.

site_title: Boris Johnson urges G-7 accord on Covid-19 'passports'
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is urging the G-7 nations to reach an agreement on Covid-19 vaccine passports and to discuss a "world treaty" to prepare for future pandemics. Johnson, who will host the G-7 summit in Cornwall, emphasizes the need for global cooperation in addressing the pandemic, citing the need for vaccination to be a global enterprise and for developing countries to receive vaccine supplies quickly. He also expresses concern over the spread of misinformation and the origins of the pandemic, while setting an ambitious target to vaccinate the world by the end of next year.

site_title: Renault-Nissan's south India plant staff to stay away on Monday
summary: Workers at Renault-Nissan's plant in southern India will not report for work on Monday due to coronavirus-related safety concerns. The union, citing hundreds of workers falling ill and dozens dying from Covid-19, is demanding adequate social distancing measures, rehabilitation of families of deceased workers, and medical treatment for affected workers. Renault-Nissan has only vaccinated 200 workers with a first dose, despite the plant having a workforce of over 8,000. The state government has urged companies to follow social distancing protocols and vaccinate all employees within a month.

site_title: Monde Nissin's IPO has top funds ditching blue chip stocks
summary: Monde Nissin's record-breaking initial public offering (IPO) in the Philippines has led to a shift in investor funds, with top funds ditching blue-chip stocks to invest in the food giant. The 48.6 billion peso IPO, the largest ever in the South-east Asian country, has attracted overseas investors, including Singapore's GIC and Hong Kong's AIA Group. The company's strong brands, market leadership, and growth prospects have made it an attractive investment opportunity, driving a 6.5% decline in the Philippine Stock Exchange Index this year.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Raffles Medical to 'add' with higher S$1.22 target price
summary: CGS-CIMB upgraded Raffles Medical Group to 'add' with a target price of S$1.22, citing its key role in Covid-19 testing, particularly at Changi Airport. Analyst Cezzane See forecasts a threefold increase in testing to 6,000 tests per day in FY2021, driving revenue growth and net profit. The company's mass-testing capabilities will lift earnings and net profit from FY2021 to FY2023, with higher EPS estimates.

site_title: China wrecks IPO plans for high-flying online education startups
summary: China's government is cracking down on its online education sector, forcing high-flying startups to put off plans for multi-billion-dollar initial public offerings. The crackdown, led by President Xi Jinping, aims to curb predatory practices and excessive spending on after-school tutoring. The education ministry plans to create a dedicated division to oversee private education platforms, and several potential mega-IPOs, including those backed by Alibaba and Tencent, have been halted. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to regulate the growing industry, which has attracted billions of dollars in funding and raised concerns about unequal access to education.

site_title: Intel reiterates chip supply shortages could last several years
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger says the global semiconductor shortage could last several years, citing a "cycle of explosive growth" during the pandemic that strained supply chains. The company plans to expand its manufacturing capacity with a $20 billion investment, aiming to produce chips within 6-9 months to address shortages at US car plants. This move could challenge TSMC and Samsung, which have dominated the semiconductor business, shifting the industry's center of gravity to Asia. The shortage has affected auto production and consumer electronics, with a resolution expected in 1-2 years.

site_title: Bond traders look to job figures for taper clues as cash glut grows
summary: US bond traders are monitoring the Federal Reserve's tapering plans amid a growing cash glut in dollar funding markets. The Fed's reverse repo facility has seen a buildup of US dollars, sparking debate about the pace of tapering. Investors will be closely watching the upcoming US jobs data, which may influence the Fed's decisions on policy tightening. The next central bank policy meeting is scheduled for June 15-16, and traders are pricing in a 72% chance of a 25 basis-point rate hike by the end of 2022.

site_title: Singapore bank lending up 0.1% in April: MAS data
summary: Singapore bank lending rose 0.1% in April, with total business loans remaining near flat at S$427.69 billion, according to Monetary Authority of Singapore data. Loan demand from manufacturing, transport, and communication industries declined, while consumer loans, particularly housing loans, continued to grow. The economy's recovery remains "very mixed," with the COVID-19 recovery story exhibiting a K-shaped nature. Total bank lending is up 0.4% year-on-year, marking the first step into positive growth territory since May 2020.

site_title: Chelsea wins Champions League, its chaos killing City's plans
summary: Manchester City's players were left stunned and heartbroken after Chelsea won the Champions League final, 1-0, with Kai Havertz's 42nd-minute goal. The team's inability to cope with Chelsea's chaotic playing style, led by coach Thomas Tuchel, ultimately led to their defeat. In contrast, Chelsea's victory marked the latest chapter in Roman Abramovich's chaotic reign at the club, which has won the Champions League twice under his ownership. The loss marked a crushing end to City's Champions League dreams, with their players visibly distraught as they left the stadium.

site_title: Israel inches closer to government without Netanyahu
summary: Israel is on the cusp of a new government without Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who faces trial on corruption charges. Opposition leader Yair Lapid has until Wednesday to form a coalition with nationalist hardliner Naftali Bennett, who could serve as the first term's prime minister in a rotating premiership. The proposed government would include centrist parties and Arab-Israeli lawmakers, but faces opposition from some right-wing lawmakers and the need for Arab support to pass a confirmation vote in parliament. Netanyahu's Likud party won the most seats in March's elections but failed to form a government due to his far-right partners' refusal to work with Arab factions.

site_title: Giving broad, equitable access to vaccines
summary: A temporary waiver of patent rights for Covid-19 vaccines is being advocated for, with some arguing it would increase global access to the life-saving treatment. Jeffery Tan, General Counsel of Jardine Cycle & Carriage, strongly supports the idea, emphasizing its potential to benefit low-income communities. The push for patent waiver aims to address the issue of unequal vaccine distribution, particularly in developing countries, and accelerate the global fight against the pandemic.

site_title: Putin betting coal still has a future
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's government is investing over $10 billion in railroad upgrades to boost coal exports to Asia, despite international efforts to phase out the commodity. The project aims to increase cargo capacity to 182 million tons per year by 2024, with plans to use prisoners to speed up the work. Putin bets that coal demand will continue to rise in big Asian markets like China, but the plan is fraught with risk, as the UN recommends phasing out coal to avoid catastrophic global warming and the IEA calls for phasing out all coal power plants without carbon capture by 2040.

site_title: North Korea slams end to US guidelines limiting South Korea missile range
summary: North Korea has criticized the US and South Korea for ending a pact limiting South Korea's development of ballistic missiles, calling it a sign of Washington's "shameful double-dealing." The US and South Korea announced the abolishment of the guidelines after a summit between US President Joe Biden and South Korean President Moon Jae In. North Korea's state media accused the US of applying a double standard and vowed to counter the US on "the principle of strength for strength." The move has been described as a sign of North Korea's determination to bolster its capabilities for self-defence.

site_title: Dollar gives up gains on economic data
summary: The US dollar gave up gains from early Friday as traders adjusted positions ahead of a month-end and holiday weekend, despite new economic data confirming US inflation and the recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. The dollar index rose 0.4% before falling back to flat for the day, ending its three-month downtrend. The euro and British pound were also relatively unchanged, while the Japanese yen and Chinese yuan were affected by the dollar's performance, with the yen losing against the dollar and the yuan reaching a three-year high.

site_title: HK tycoons offer apartment to boost vaccine take-up rate
summary: Hong Kong property tycoons have donated a one-bedroom apartment worth HK$10.8 million (S$1.8 million) as the grand prize in a vaccine lottery to boost inoculation rates in the city. Eligible residents aged 18 and above who have received both Covid-19 vaccine doses can register until Sept 1. The move aims to increase Hong Kong's vaccination rate, which currently stands at less than 20% of the population. This initiative follows a similar trend seen in other countries, including the US, where vaccine lotteries have been used to encourage inoculation.

site_title: 95-year-old dies of Covid; 5 new cases linked to NTUC Foodfare
summary: A 95-year-old Singaporean woman died from Covid-19 complications on May 30, bringing the country's death toll to 33. There were 25 new cases, including 19 in the community, and five linked to a new cluster at NTUC Foodfare. The coffee shop was closed and will reopen on June 13 for deep cleaning. The Ministry of Health is investigating cases and offering free Covid-19 testing for those who visited the coffee shop from May 13 to May 30.

site_title: Deliveries surge, but F&B orders diluted as more players crowd market, takeaway fatigue sets in
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) industry has seen a surge in deliveries but slower demand for takeaways and dining-in due to increased competition and consumer fatigue. Despite the government's efforts to support the industry, some firms have reported slower sales, with gelato supplier Momolato seeing a 50-70% decline in average daily sales compared to last year's circuit breaker period. The industry's recoveries have been mixed, with some firms recovering sales but others barely breaking even due to reduced seating capacity and increased competition.

images.alt_text: A deserted street in the eatery-lined Boat Quay area on May 19 after the current ban on dining in took effect. Some players say customers are spending less as the pandemic drags on.

site_title: Dubai property booms as wealthy buyers escape lockdowns
summary: Dubai's property market is experiencing a boom, driven by wealthy international buyers, particularly Europeans, seeking luxury villas on Palm Jumeirah and golf course estates. Transaction volumes have increased, with record month-on-month gains, and sales of properties above 10 million dirhams rose 6.7% in April. The market's recovery is attributed to Dubai's reopening to visitors, relaxed residency rules, and full foreign ownership of firms, which have regenerated the tourism industry and boosted business activity.

site_title: Britain to build new flagship to promote post-Brexit trade
summary: The UK government plans to build a new flagship to promote post-Brexit trade and boost the shipbuilding industry. The ship will host high-level trade negotiations and trade shows, and its cost will be confirmed once manufacturing contracts are tendered. The project is seen as a response to critics who point to disruptions in trade with the EU, Britain's largest export market, since Brexit. The ship's name will be announced in due course, reportedly after Queen Elizabeth's late husband Prince Philip.

site_title: India extends loan offer of 3t rupees to airlines, hospitals to cushion Covid-19 impact
summary: India has extended an emergency credit program to airlines and hospitals to mitigate the impact of the Covid-19 wave, with a focus on protecting the economy. The program, which was initially intended for small borrowers, has already disbursed 2.5 trillion rupees and can be expanded to a total of 3 trillion rupees. The loans, capped at 7.5% interest, will provide 20 million rupees to hospitals for on-site oxygen generation plants and offer additional credit to small companies and eligible borrowers. The move aims to cushion the sectors from the economic impact of the pandemic surge.

site_title: Food giant's Philippine IPO sends market into a frenzy
summary: Monde Nissin Corp, a Philippine food giant, has made a record-breaking debut on the stock market with a $1.35 billion initial public offering, sending shockwaves through the nation's consumer sector and driving investors to reallocate funds. The company's dominant position in the Philippines for basic foods and its prospects in the global market for meat alternatives are attracting foreign investors, despite the country's struggles with a large COVID-19 outbreak. The IPO has pushed up the benchmark stock index and has led to selling in other companies, including Monde's competitors and blue-chip stocks.

site_title: StanChart aims to double its consumer client base by 2025, says top executive
summary: Standard Chartered aims to double its global mass banking and affluent clients by 2025, targeting 20 million consumer clients. The bank views retail banking as critical as serving the high net worth, focusing on personalization and wealth advice. StanChart's focus on the full spectrum of banking services sets it apart from other international banks. The bank is evaluating assets up for sale from Citi and is also on the lookout for "great talent" in consumer banking.

images.alt_text: StanChart's Judy Hsu says: "Most banks are really focused on the upper end (of the wealth continuum). The mass affluent clients are still quite underserved..."

site_title: Finnish startup targeting car addiction
summary: A Finnish startup, MaaS Global Oy, has developed an app called Whim that aims to reduce car addiction and urban congestion. The app, which offers a range of transportation services such as electric scooters, city bikes, and public transport, has already prompted 12% of users in Helsinki to give up their cars. The company, backed by investors including BP and Toyota, claims its app can fix urban congestion and reduce pollution. Whim is available in several European cities and Tokyo, with plans to expand to Switzerland and other countries.

site_title: US government seeks to dismiss suit against Trump: Washington Post
summary: The US Justice Department has asked a federal judge to dismiss a lawsuit against former President Donald Trump, former Attorney General William Barr, and other officials over the forceful pushing back of peaceful protesters at a White House demonstration last year. The lawsuit, filed by the American Civil Liberties Union, sought to declare that Trump, Barr, and other officials violated the constitutional rights of demonstrators. The Justice Department argued that Trump and other officials should be considered immune from civil lawsuits due to their official duties and protection under the US Constitution.

site_title: The upstarts ready to ascend the throne
summary: Rafael Nadal is expected to dominate the Roland-Garros men's singles tournament, having achieved a 13-0 record in finals at the tournament. However, young players such as 19-year-old Jannik Sinner and 22-year-old Casper Ruud are emerging as contenders, with Sinner boasting a powerful forehand and Ruud showing he can perform at the highest level. Other notable players, including Novak Djokovic, Alexander Zverev, and Stefanos Tsitsipas, will also be vying for the trophy.

images.alt_text: Rolex Testimonee Jannik Sinner at Roland-Garros, 2020.

site_title: Malaysia to ramp up Covid-19 vaccinations as new infections surge
summary: Malaysia is ramping up Covid-19 vaccinations as the country faces a surge in new infections. The government plans to set up five new mega vaccination centers and train private doctors to administer vaccines. This move aims to increase daily vaccinations to 150,000 doses, up from 107,000 doses per day. The country has reported 6,999 new cases, bringing the total to 565,533, and has nearly 6% of its population vaccinated. A nationwide lockdown is in effect from June 1-14 to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Five months on, Brexit hurting both UK and EU businesses
summary: The UK and EU are experiencing a 23.1% decline in trade between them, with the UK's imports from the EU falling 12.3% and exports down 8.7% compared to the same quarter last year. The Brexit transition period has led to customs disruptions and a slowdown in the global economy, affecting trade statistics. Despite this, the EU remains the UK's largest trading partner, and the UK is seeking to boost trade elsewhere, including a £5 billion investment and trade deal with the Gulf Cooperation Council.

site_title: Global tax ambiguity will not stunt mergers and acquisitions: analysts
summary: Global tax ambiguity is unlikely to hinder mergers and acquisitions, despite new challenges, according to experts. Record capital deployment and geographical expansion opportunities are driving deal activity. Tax due diligence will become crucial, focusing on deal structure, tax rates, and protections in transaction documents. The potential onset of a global minimum corporate tax rate may impact valuation multiples and after-tax cash flows for investors. Tax liability insurance can help mitigate risk and speed up deal execution. Despite uncertainty, cross-border M&A activity is expected to continue, with strategic and commercial objectives driving acquisitions.

site_title: US to re-impose sanctions on Belarus firms over plane incident
summary: The Biden administration plans to re-impose sanctions on nine Belarusian state-owned businesses in response to Belarus' forced landing of a passenger jet and the subsequent arrest of a journalist on board. The sanctions target Belarusian firms, with the US calling for a credible international investigation into the events of May 23. The move aims to hold Belarus accountable for the incident.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong play complementary roles in wealth management
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong are playing complementary roles in wealth management, with Hong Kong being the top capital market for Chinese enterprises venturing abroad. Hong Kong's H-share and red-chip companies have a combined market value of over HK$12 trillion, making up 23% of the total market value. In terms of wealth management, Singapore and Hong Kong are on par, with no clear ranking. This suggests a balanced ecosystem between the two financial hubs, with each contributing to the overall wealth management landscape.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is the top capital market for Chinese enterprises venturing abroad. Data from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange (HKSE) showed that as at end-March this year, H-share and red-chip companies have a combined market value of over HK$12 trillion (S$2 trillion), making up 23 per cent of the total market value of all companies listed on the HKSE.

site_title: BT Explains: Global minimum corporate tax
summary: Singapore is set to implement a global minimum corporate tax rate, a move aimed at reducing tax ambiguity worldwide. The new tax rate, to be implemented by countries with a GDP of over $1 trillion, will help prevent multinational corporations from shifting profits to low-tax jurisdictions. The move is seen as a step towards global tax cooperation and aims to promote fair competition among businesses. The implementation of this tax rate is expected to be a significant development in the global economy, with Singapore poised to become a key player in the implementation of the new tax standard.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange reported a dismal week for Capesize earnings due to disrupted global public holidays. The Transpacific C10 route opened at $40,246 but plateaued and dropped to $30,976 by the end of the week. This decline was attributed to softening routes across the board.

site_title: Meltdown? Turmoil at UK empire Liberty Steel stokes job fears
summary: Liberty Steel, a UK-based steel empire, is facing an uncertain future after announcing plans to sell three UK plants, plunging 1,500 jobs into uncertainty. The company, owned by Indian-British billionaire Sanjeev Gupta, is struggling after the collapse of its main lender Greensill Capital and fraud allegations. Gupta's company has 35,000 employees worldwide and is trying to sell its most liquid assets to keep the company alive. The UK government has rebuffed a bailout request, and negotiations with Swiss banking giant Credit Suisse continue.

site_title: Possible S&P 500 correction as sustained bull run not viable
summary: The S&P 500 index has risen over 11% year-to-date in 2021, fueled by vaccination progress, strong economic data, and optimism in the fight against the pandemic. However, a prolonged bull run may not be sustainable due to factors such as low interest rates and potential inflationary pressures. A correction is possible, with a resistance zone between 4,195 and 4,236, and a potential support level at 4,065. Alternatively, the index may continue to rise if it breaks above 4,236 and forms new highs.

site_title: All about legacy giving
summary: The Community Foundation of Singapore (CFS) is launching the Legacy Giving Initiative, a campaign to encourage Singaporeans to make planned donations to charities over a period of years. The initiative aims to break the misconception that legacy giving is only for the ultra-wealthy. CFS chairperson Christine Ong emphasizes that giving is not about the amount, and individuals can start at any stage of life. The foundation has already reached over 33,000 page views and 19,000 visitors on its microsite, and plans to engage with prospects and partners to build formal alliances.

site_title: Q&M Dental ends JV plan to make surgical masks
summary: Q&M Dental Group has ended its joint venture plan to manufacture surgical masks with partners Hubei Aishubao Living Supplies and Guangzhou Pharmasen, after failing to meet definitive terms under a non-binding memorandum of understanding. The MOU was due to terminate if definitive agreements were not entered into within a year. As a result, the MOU is now terminated, and no party has further obligation or liability. This decision comes after the company's shares closed at S$0.675, down half a cent, on Friday.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng, Ho Bee Land chairs up stakes
summary: Singapore stocks experienced a 1.7% gain over the four trading sessions from May 21 to 27, bringing the 2021 year-to-date return to 13.0%. OCBC, DBS, and Singapore Telecommunications received the highest net institutional inflows, while Nanofilm Technologies International, Haw Par Corporation, and Olam International received the highest inflows outside the Straits Times Index.

site_title: Europe: Shares at record high on gains in financials, US spending plan
summary: European shares rose to a record high on Friday, driven by gains in financial stocks following a hawkish comment from a Bank of England official and optimism over US fiscal spending. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6% to a record high, with bank stocks and insurance services sectors leading the gains. Economic growth optimism and easing pandemic restrictions also supported the markets.

site_title: Canadian MP caught naked during telework for second time in a month
summary: Canadian MP William Amos has stepped down from some parliamentary duties after being caught on camera urinating during a virtual House of Commons session. This is the second time Amos has been caught exposing himself in a virtual setting, following a previous incident in April where he appeared naked while connected to a video conference. Amos apologized for his actions, saying they were "completely unacceptable" and claimed he was seeking "assistance." Conservative MPs criticized Trudeau's Liberals for failing to ensure a safe work environment following the first incident.

site_title: PM Lee to address nation on how Singapore will progressively open up again
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong will deliver a live address on Monday to share the nation's plan to balance COVID-19 control with gradual reopening. The solution involves accelerated testing, contact tracing, and vaccination, as well as improved hygiene standards. The government is planning for a future where the virus becomes endemic, with measures including vaccinations and booster shots, and improved ventilation systems. This follows a recent stabilization of new community cases and a S$800 million support package for affected businesses.

site_title: Philippines protests China's 'illegal' South China Sea presence
summary: The Philippines has protested China's "illegal presence and activities" near Thitu island in the South China Sea, demanding China withdraw its maritime assets and fishing vessels. This protest marks the 84th since 2016, amid escalating tensions over hundreds of Chinese boats in the Philippines' exclusive economic zone. The Philippines asserts sovereignty and jurisdiction over the island, which is part of the Spratly archipelago. China claims the area, citing a mini-city built on the Subi Reef, despite an international tribunal ruling invalidating China's expansive claim in 2016.

images.alt_text: The Philippines has protested China's continuing "illegal presence and activities" near an island in the South China Sea held by the Southeast Asian nation, the foreign ministry said on Saturday.

site_title: Investors continue to favour Reit ETFs
summary: Reit ETFs have seen significant growth, with assets under management (AUM) exceeding $40 billion globally, driven by the ascent of passive investing. The top-performing Reit ETF, Phillip SGX APAC Dividend Leaders Reit ETF, generated 5.8% total returns in 2021, with the NikkoAM-StraitsTrading Asia ex-Japan Reit ETF being the highest-yielding, offering a 4.7% 12-month gross dividend yield. Despite lagging behind the top-performing ETF, the NikkoAM-StraitsTrading Asia ex-Japan Reit ETF and Lion-Phillip S-Reit ETF still recorded net inflows of $108.7 million, reflecting investor demand for diversified Reit exposure.

site_title: Nasdaq-beating multiples threaten to cool Europe's luxury sizzle
summary: Europe's luxury sector is experiencing record-high valuations, with shares of companies like LVMH and Hermes International reaching all-time highs, boasting a 29% premium to the Nasdaq 100. The sector's growth is driven by post-lockdown demand and affluent Chinese clients, but investors are concerned about the high multiples, with some analysts warning of a potential correction. The luxury sector's valuation premium has reached historic highs, with Barclays strategists labeling it as the "very-expensive category."

site_title: Keppel unit to develop landed housing project in Ho Chi Minh City district
summary: Keppel Land's unit, VN Prosperity, is acquiring 60% of Phuoc Kien Construction Investment Joint Stock Company for approximately S$21.6 million to develop a landed housing project in Nha Be District, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. The project has received master plan approval, and VN Prosperity will jointly develop the project with Phu Long Real Estate Joint Stock Company, which will hold 40% of the shares. The acquisition is expected to proceed once approvals from relevant authorities are obtained.

site_title: Chasen reverses losses, posts net profit of S$1.7m by seizing opportunities amid Covid-19
summary: Chasen Holdings, a logistics firm, has posted a net profit of S$1.7 million for its FY2021, reversing a net loss of S$15.5 million in the previous year. The company attributes its gains to stronger performances by its specialist relocation and third-party logistics segments, which captured fresh opportunities amid the Covid-19 pandemic. Revenue rose 29% to S$130.7 million, up from S$101 million in the previous year.

site_title: China's banking regulator warns of global asset bubble risks
summary: China's banking regulator, Liang Tao, warns that recent interest rate hikes by emerging economies could lead to a bursting of global financial asset bubbles. The regulator attributes this to unprecedented pandemic easing measures by developed countries, which have enlarged asset bubbles. Liang calls for coordinated financial regulation, improved cross-border fund flow monitoring, and measures to prevent "hot money" risks. China has managed risks from local government debt and property finance bubbles, and the financial sector's leverage has declined. Liang also advocates for better representation of developing countries in global economic governance systems.

site_title: mm2 Asia reports net loss of S$92.7m for FY2021 due to Covid-19
summary: mm2 Asia reported a net loss of S$92.7 million for FY2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic affecting its movie-making, film distributions, and live entertainment businesses. Revenue fell 68.1% year-over-year to S$75.2 million. This is a significant decline from the net profit of S$3.3 million in FY2020. The pandemic's impact has severely impacted mm2's businesses since January 2021.

site_title: Valuetronics reports 4.6% increase in net profit to HK$187.1m for FY2021
summary: Valuetronics reported a 4.6% increase in net profit to HK$187.1 million for FY2021, driven by a 11.3% growth in its industrial and commercial electronics segment. Revenue fell 3.1% to HK$2.28 billion, with gross profit rising 6.5%. The company recommended a final dividend of 16 HK cents per share, totaling 21 HK cents per share. Despite a stable revenue and profit, chairman Ricky Tse expects FY2022 results to be "significantly lower" due to US-China trade tensions and global component shortages.

site_title: Vietnam May trade deficit seen at US$2b; CPI up 2.9%
summary: Vietnam estimated a trade deficit of US$2 billion for May, driven by a 35.6% increase in exports to US$26 billion and a 56.4% increase in imports to US$28 billion. Consumer prices rose 2.9% from a year earlier, with average prices increasing 1.29% in the first five months of the year. The country's trade deficit for the first five months of the year was US$369 million.

site_title: Apple to delay launch of podcast subscription service until June
summary: Apple is delaying the launch of its podcast subscription service until June, citing issues with some podcast creators experiencing delays in their shows appearing after uploading them. The service, which was originally set to launch this month, will allow podcast creators to charge for their shows with Apple keeping a 30% commission in the first year and 15% thereafter. The delay is a setback for Apple, which had touted the service as a way to monetize its massive podcast audience. The exact cause of the delay is not specified.

site_title: Sembcorp spruces up portfolio with green courage
summary: Sembcorp Industries, a majority-owned firm by Temasek Holdings, has unveiled a roadmap to invest S$5.5 billion to enhance its pro-climate aspect, aiming to quadruple its gross installed renewable energy capacity to 10 GW by 2025. Under the plan, the company aims to triple its urban business' land sales to 500 hectares and increase its contribution from sustainable solutions to 70% of group net profit. Sembcorp also pledges to halve greenhouse gas emissions by 2030 and achieve net-zero by 2050, marking a shift from its traditional focus on energy and marine businesses.

site_title: US probes two Malaysian glove makers over forced labour allegations: report
summary: The US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) is investigating Malaysian glove makers Hartalega Holdings and Supermax Corp over allegations of forced labor. The probe follows a petition by labor rights activist Andy Hall, who claimed the firms employed migrant workers under coercive conditions. The CBP confirmed it has sufficient information to investigate, and Hartalega Holdings stated it adheres to labor laws and regulations. This comes after the US previously banned imports from Top Glove, the world's largest latex glove manufacturer, due to similar allegations.

site_title: In US, tipped workers still feel the pandemic crunch
summary: US restaurant workers continue to protest low pay, citing health risks and the pandemic's economic impact. Hundreds participated in "wage strikes" nationwide, demanding fair pay for tipped workers. The industry has seen over 2.5 million job losses and 110,000 restaurant closures since the pandemic. Many workers, like Tizoc Zarate, have struggled to make ends meet, with some reporting they're considering leaving their jobs due to low wages and health concerns. Activists argue that the US unemployment benefit of $300 a week is not the cause of the shortage, but rather a wage shortage.

site_title: Federal Reserve admonishes Deutsche Bank for ongoing compliance failures
summary: The Federal Reserve has privately warned Deutsche Bank that its compliance programs are not meeting expectations, citing ongoing failures in risk management practices despite past agreements. The bank's leaders are bracing for potential sanctions, including a large fine. This comes after a tumultuous period for the lender, which has faced multiple crises and regulatory issues, including foreign-exchange violations and ties to money-laundering cases. The Fed's warning is a setback for CEO Christian Sewing, who has been working to repair the bank's relations with regulators.

site_title: Vietnam detects hybrid of Indian and UK Covid-19 variant
summary: Vietnam has detected a new hybrid Covid-19 variant, a mix of the Indian and UK variants, which spreads quickly by air and online. The variant has led to a surge in infections, with nearly 3,600 cases reported in 31 cities and provinces since late April, accounting for more than half of the country's total infections. Vietnam has registered 6,396 coronavirus cases and 47 deaths, and the new variant is more transmissible than previously known types, replicating itself quickly and causing rapid spread.

site_title: Covid-19 origins search 'being poisoned by politics': WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) warned that efforts to uncover the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic are being hindered by politics, with the agency calling for a "proper, positive atmosphere" to focus on science. Despite US President Joe Biden's order to investigate whether the virus emerged from a lab accident, the WHO has yet to provide a timeline for its next steps. The organization's report on the pandemic's origins, released in March, ranked a lab leak as "extremely unlikely" and instead suggested the virus jumped from bats to humans via an intermediate animal.

site_title: Metal recycler says it's boom time for scraps
summary: Hong Kong-based metal recycler Chiho Environmental Group expects a surge in demand for scrap materials as governments and corporations set net-zero targets to combat climate change. The company predicts steel scrap volumes and aluminum recycling rates will double in China over the next 5-10 years. Rising metal prices from the industrial rebound from the pandemic, combined with restrictions relaxed in China, are driving the demand boost. Chiho aims to improve its EV battery recovery rate to 90% and is in discussions with industry partners to develop recycling partnerships.

site_title: Lian Beng seeks third extension for disposal of assets competing with SLB unit
summary: Lian Beng Group has requested a third extension to dispose of its assets, competing with its spin-off SLB Development, due to dampened demand caused by the pandemic. The extension would be granted subject to SLB's announcement of the new deadline and Lian Beng's plans to fulfill the disposal. The original deadline was set in 2018, but was extended multiple times due to unfavourable market conditions, and Lian Beng now expects to sell the remaining units by April 19, 2023, or face potential losses and negative impact on shareholder value.

site_title: Tourists scarce as travel bubbles fail to inflate
summary: New Zealand's quarantine-free travel bubbles, hailed as a tourism "godsend" earlier this year, have failed to attract tourists due to ongoing pandemic concerns. The bubbles between New Zealand, Australia, and other countries have been suspended or cancelled multiple times, with recent scares in Australia and Taiwan causing disruptions. Despite strong domestic tourism in Australia and New Zealand, international bookings remain low, with data showing bookings to New Zealand from Australia were less than a quarter of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher ahead of holiday weekend
