summary: US stocks ended higher on Friday, despite a 3.6% inflation rate in April, the largest jump since 2008. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes added 0.1% each. Salesforce jumped 5.5% after reporting higher earnings, while Boeing fell 1.5% due to halted 787 Dreamliner deliveries. The market is set to close on Monday for the Memorial Day holiday.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks finished modestly higher on Friday, shrugging off data showing increased inflation following solid earnings from Salesforce and others.

site_title: Neymar says Nike claim of split over sex assault probe a 'lie'
summary: Brazilian football star Neymar has denied Nike's claim that it ended its sponsorship deal with him due to his refusal to cooperate with an internal investigation into an employee's accusation of sexual assault. Neymar claims the claim is an "absurd lie" and that he was not given the opportunity to defend himself. The alleged assault occurred in 2016, but was only reported to Nike in 2018, leading Neymar's father to accuse the company of "blackmail."

images.alt_text: Neymar said on Friday Nike's claim that it parted ways with him last year because he refused to cooperate with its internal investigation into an employee's accusation he sexually assaulted her was an "absurd lie."

site_title: Biden budget shifts funds from corporate taxes to social programmes
summary: US President Joe Biden's budget proposal allocates $6 trillion over 15 years to boost economic resilience and competitiveness, funded by increased taxes on big businesses and the rich. The plan includes $2 trillion for infrastructure spending, $1.8 trillion for education and social services, and $14 billion to combat climate change. The proposal also aims to combat homelessness, address health crises, and expand broadband internet access. The budget projects 5.2% GDP growth this year and lower the budget deficit to $1.8 trillion in 2022.

site_title: EU backs Pfizer jab for 12 to 15-year- olds
summary: The European Union's drug watchdog has approved the Pfizer/BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine for 12 to 15-year-olds, allowing the vaccine to be administered to children in the bloc. The vaccine was found to be "well tolerated" with no major side effects, according to the European Medicines Agency. Germany and Austria have announced plans to start vaccinating children over 12, with Moderna also expected to seek authorization for its vaccine in early June. The approval is seen as a boost to Europe's vaccination program and a step closer to ending the pandemic.

site_title: JD Logistics shares lose steam to close 3.3% higher
summary: JD Logistics Inc shares rose 3.3% in their first session on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, closing at HK$41.70 after pricing at $HK40.36. The company, spun out from Chinese e-commerce firm JD.com, had trading volumes up to 18.3%. This marked a successful debut for the stock, following its separation from JD.com.

site_title: Credit Suisse cuts risk as defections mount in wake of scandals
summary: Credit Suisse is taking steps to reduce risk amid a series of scandals, including the collapse of supply-chain finance firm Lex Greensill and Archegos Capital Management. The bank is cutting ties with SoftBank Group, barring clients from withdrawing cash from a Renaissance Technologies fund, and considering retention bonuses for top performers. Senior bankers are fleeing to competitors, with several departing for Jefferies Financial Group and others joining Barclays, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs. Chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio is conducting a wide-ranging review to recover from the scandals, which have led to a 14% decline in the bank's shares this year.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse Group AG is grappling with how to keep top bankers from fleeing to competitors and drastically reducing risk as new Chairman Antonio Horta-Osorio seeks to recover from a series of scandals.

site_title: Likely no tightening of Covid-19 restrictions for now with cases stabilising: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong said there's no need to tighten Covid-19 restrictions as cases stabilize. The current measures appear to be effective in controlling the spread of the virus, according to Wong. This decision comes as the country's economy continues to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: 15 new Covid-19 community cases, including 4 unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 30 new coronavirus cases, bringing the total to 61,970. 15 cases are community cases, with 4 unlinked, and 11 linked to previous cases. 15 imported cases are on stay-home notice or isolated, with 8 returning Singaporeans or permanent residents. No new cases were reported in migrant workers' dormitories.

site_title: My phone, my life
summary: A writer recounts a bus ride without their phone, highlighting the device's impact on daily life and mental well-being. According to a psychology lecturer, people feel out of place without their phones due to their need for affiliation and work-life integration. Studies show a shift in consumer behavior, with increased phone usage for non-social media activities. Experts warn of unhealthy attachment to phones, citing red flags such as withdrawal, persistence, and escape. A writer reflects on the experience, suggesting that excessive phone use may contribute to hostility in reality, and that putting down the phone is necessary to engage with the world.

site_title: Crypto versus gold debate rages on Wall Street as flows reverse
summary: Gold prices surge to nearly $1,900 an ounce, driven by weaker dollar and falling inflation-adjusted yields, while Bitcoin plummets 40% from its peak. The reversal of flows between the two assets suggests market psychology may be at play, rather than real-money flows. The decline in Bitcoin's price is attributed to volatility sparked by Elon Musk, undermining its appeal to institutional investors. This shift highlights the ongoing debate between gold and Bitcoin as potential hedging assets.

site_title: Brent ends at two-year high as demand outlook counters supply fears
summary: Oil prices rose 5% for the week, with global benchmark Brent reaching a two-year high at $69.63 a barrel, settling 17 cents higher. Strong US economic data and expectations of a global demand rebound outweighed supply concerns, particularly from Iran. Analysts attribute the surge to risk appetite among investors and boosted by good economic data. Brent is now making a renewed bid for the $70 per barrel mark, with US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $66.32 a barrel.

site_title: Malaysia PM orders nationwide 'total lockdown' amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin has announced a nationwide "total lockdown" starting June 1 to combat a surge in coronavirus infections, with the aim of reducing cases and increasing vaccination efforts. The lockdown will last for two phases, with the first phase lasting 14 days and the second phase lasting four weeks. Essential services will remain operational, and the government will provide aid to affected companies and individuals. The move comes amid strained hospital capacity and rising daily fatalities.

site_title: S$800m Covid-19 aid package for firms and individuals
summary: Singapore's government has announced an S$800 million aid package to support companies and individuals during Phase 2 (Heightened Alert). The package includes an extension of the Jobs Support Scheme wage subsidy to more sectors, such as gyms and cinemas, as well as support for rental costs and one-off assistance for lower-income employees and self-employed individuals. The measures aim to provide short-term relief and help businesses and individuals adapt to the ongoing pandemic, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stating that Singapore must be prepared to tighten restrictions if needed.

site_title: Canada probes forced labour claims in Malaysian palm oil, glove-making industries
summary: Canada is investigating allegations of forced labour in Malaysia's palm oil and glove manufacturing industries, including companies like Top Glove, Sime Darby Plantation, and FGV Holdings. The US has banned imports from these companies due to suspected forced labour practices, including excessive hours, debt bondage, and physical violence. Canada's Labour Programme is "actively researching" the allegations, but declined to provide further details or name specific companies being probed.

site_title: Gold flirts with US$1,900 on talk of tapering amid inflationary pressures
summary: Gold prices closed the week around US$1,900 an ounce, driven by inflationary pressures and expectations of tapering by the Federal Reserve, despite rising bond yields and a stronger dollar. A weekly market summary saw benchmark gold futures settle above US$1,900 for the first time in four and a half months, following Japan's April Producers Price Index increase. Analysts predict gold could reach US$2,000, but the Federal Reserve's monetary policy stance remains uncertain, with some central banks considering rate hikes.

site_title: Hong Kong's digital bank upstarts years away from profits
summary: Hong Kong's digital banks, Mox Bank and ZA Bank, are expected to break even by 2024, despite facing years of red ink. The two virtual banks have made limited inroads against brick-and-mortar rivals, with Standard Chartered-backed Mox Bank and China's ZhongAn Online P&C Insurance-backed ZA Bank continuing to build operations and launch new products. Despite gaining traction, they are yet to pose a serious threat to incumbent banks, highlighting the challenges of scaling up in the financial hub.

site_title: Jaguar F-Pace review: Jaguar keeps the F-Pace up
summary: Jaguar has released a facelift for its best-selling F-Pace SUV, addressing its need for a redesign. The updated model features a more refined interior, improved handling, and enhanced performance. The revised design keeps the original's sporty appeal while addressing its previous limitations. The F-Pace is now more agile and responsive, making it a more enjoyable drive. This facelift aims to reignite the F-Pace's excitement and appeal to potential buyers.

site_title: Big tech drawn to new Singapore carbon offset trading market
summary: Singapore is set to launch a new carbon offset trading market, Climate Impact X, backed by the Singapore Exchange. Tech giants such as Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are in talks to use the platform, aiming to meet ambitious net-zero targets. The platform will host an exchange for carbon offset trading and a marketplace for nature conservation projects, with a rating system and verification technology to ensure project integrity. The move follows growing pressure on private companies to reduce their carbon footprint, with Singapore aiming to become a global hub for sustainable finance.

site_title: No timeline yet for new Covid-19 origins probe: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has not set a timeline for a new, more in-depth investigation into the origins of the Covid-19 pandemic, despite growing pressure from countries such as the US and the European Union. The US has ordered an intelligence community investigation into whether the virus emerged from an animal source or a laboratory accident in China. The WHO is awaiting expert guidance before moving forward with further studies, which will need to be carried out to determine the pandemic's origins.

site_title: Covid-19 pandemic sparks French rush for country homes
summary: France saw a record 111,930 country home purchases in 2020 by non-farmers, a 6.6% increase from the previous year, totaling 23.5 billion euros. This surge is attributed to city dwellers fleeing cramped apartments due to Covid-19 restrictions. The increase in sales is notable, with 2020 transactions involving homes with at least 5 ha of land attached. This trend suggests a shift in consumer preference towards rural properties.

site_title: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong appointed to MAS board; Ong Ye Kung to step down
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced changes to its board, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong appointed as deputy chairman for a three-year term. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung will step down on May 31, while Lim Hng Kiang will remain on the board as a member. Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam was re-appointed as chairman, and Ravi Menon was re-appointed as managing director. Other members, including Heng Swee Keat, Peter Ong, and Tan Chorh Chuan, were also re-appointed for further terms.

images.alt_text: Minister of Finance Lawrence Wong has been appointed deputy chairman of the board of directors in the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), in a slew of changes announced on Friday.

site_title: Having occasional flare-ups might be the new normal to be faced
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong has warned that the COVID-19 situation may become a new normal, with occasional outbreaks and flare-ups requiring temporary tightening of curbs. The government has allocated S$800 million in support for businesses and individuals, which will be funded via reallocation of development expenditure. Wong suggests that Singapore must prepare for a future of living with the virus and that firms should adapt to this long-haul possibility. The government will need to provide ad hoc support without dipping into past reserves.

images.alt_text: Lawrence Wong says when fresh outbreaks happen, "we have to deal with them to the best of our abilities".

site_title: US: Stocks rise, shrugging off inflation data
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, shrugging off data showing a 3.6% inflation increase in April, the largest jump since 2008. Despite accelerating inflation, the market remained optimistic, with the Dow Jones up 0.4%, the S&P 500 gaining 0.3%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.5%. Investors appear to believe that the high inflation prints will be transient, as suggested by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: China's power crunch forces factories to use portable generators
summary: China is experiencing a power crunch, forcing factories to use portable generators due to a sudden and unreliable power grid. The electricity shortage is attributed to high industrial use, constrained supply, and high temperatures. Guangdong province, a key industrial hub, has seen a surge in electricity consumption, with some factories limited to operating just three days a week. Similar issues are affecting Japan and Taiwan, with Japan expecting its tightest summer electricity supply in years and Taiwan struggling with a water shortage.

site_title: Macy's needs another Miracle on 34th Street
summary: Macy's CEO Jeff Gennette is pushing forward with plans to build a multi-billion-dollar skyscraper atop the company's Herald Square flagship in New York City, despite concerns about the city's recovery from the pandemic. The project aims to revitalize the area and generate significant tax revenue, but faces hurdles including rezoning red tape and community opposition. Gennette believes the project is crucial for Macy's survival and the city's economic comeback, citing the company's long history in New York and its potential to attract thousands of workers to the department store. The project's success will depend on the city's rebound and the demand for office space.

site_title: MC Payment to convene EGM requisitioned by controlling shareholder over boardroom tussle
summary: MC Payment, a digital payments services firm, is convening an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) in response to a requisition notice from controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong. Kwong had requested the appointment of five new directors, including himself, to the board. The company has only five directors and has denied any board disagreements. Shareholders will vote on the appointment of the five nominees on June 30. Ching Chiat Kwong owns 27.1% of the company and had previously asked the board to consider his appointment as a non-independent director.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: BLACKROCK has become a substantial shareholder of ComfortDelGro after purchasing 5.2 million shares, increasing its shareholding to 5%. KSH Holdings reported a loss of S$3.8 million for FY2021 due to a 30% drop in construction business and impairment losses. Tung Lok Restaurants posted a net profit of S$800,000 for the six months ended March 31, reversing a loss a year ago, while also reducing casual labor and staff pay to cut administrative costs.

site_title: US consumer inflation surges in April
summary: US consumer prices surged in April, exceeding the Federal Reserve's 2% target, with the core PCE price index rising 3.1% year-over-year. This followed a 1.9% gain in March. Economists had forecast a 0.6% rise in April. The unexpected increase reflects pent-up demand and supply constraints as the economy reopens.

site_title: WTO says goods trade accelerating, with regional gaps
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) reported that global goods trade is accelerating, with a goods trade barometer of 109.7 points in May, surpassing the baseline of 100. The recovery is driven by export orders, air freight, electronic components, and robust container shipping. However, regional disparities and uneven vaccination timetables, particularly in poor countries, mar the improvement. The WTO forecasts an 8% pick-up in merchandise trade volume this year, but notes that the outlook is marred by continued weakness in services trade and lagging vaccination progress.

images.alt_text: The WTO said its goods trade barometer had surged to 109.7 points in May, well above the baseline of 100, from 103.9 in February and the low of 88.1 in the second quarter of 2020, when global goods trade volume fell 15.5 per cent.

site_title: Johnson acted unwisely over flat refurbishment but no conflict of interest, says report
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson was criticized for allowing the refurbishment of his flat to proceed without rigorous consideration of funding. An independent adviser on ministers' interests, Christopher Geidt, found no conflict of interest but deemed Johnson's actions "unwisely" driven. The refurbishment, estimated at hundreds of thousands of pounds, was partially funded by a Conservative Party donor. The Electoral Commission has launched an investigation into the funding of the work.

site_title: The super rich are choosing Singapore as the world's safest haven
summary: Singapore is becoming a popular safe haven for the world's super rich due to its economic stability and low risk. The city is seeing a surge in luxury sales, including Bentley cars and high-end real estate, as wealthy individuals and families diversify their assets during the pandemic and amid political turmoil in other regions. This trend is expected to continue, with some predicting a significant influx of foreign capital into the country's financial sector.

site_title: Art is sometimes in the eye of the accountant
summary: A Singaporean company, MYP Ltd, has been investing in art pieces, including a Jeff Koons work, worth S$5.7 million, which was initially recorded as "plant and equipment" in its accounts. The move sparked questions from shareholders and regulators, with some calling for better disclosure and expertise in art investments. An independent appraisal valued the art investments at S$1.1 million higher than initially recorded, leading to a 19% increase in the art's fair value. The incident highlights the challenges of valuing art and the importance of proper disclosure and expertise in such investments.

site_title: Morgan Stanley nears full ownership of China ventures with stake buys
summary: Morgan Stanley is nearing full ownership of its China ventures after buying stakes from its partner Shanghai Chinafortune for approximately $150 million. The deal, pending regulatory approval, would give Morgan Stanley 90% ownership of its mainland investment banking and trading businesses and 85% ownership of its funds business. This move follows Beijing's removal of foreign ownership limits in the securities and mutual fund industry last year, allowing foreign banks to expand their operations in China's multitrillion-dollar financial sector.

site_title: Have vaccination, will travel
summary: A global divide on international travel has emerged, with 60% demanding full vaccinations for travelers, while 40% resist, citing access issues or distrust of governments. The "no" vote comes from regions with diverse challenges, including Indonesia, Hong Kong, and Australia, while those in favor tend to be from India, Thailand, and the US. Vaccination is seen as a life-saving decision, not a lifestyle choice, and education is key to overcoming misinformation and fear. Experts emphasize the importance of stepping out of online echo chambers and engaging with reality to make informed decisions about travel and vaccination.

site_title: German Parliament to clear way for women quota on some company boards
summary: Germany's Parliament is expected to pass a law requiring some listed companies to have a minimum number of women on their boards, aiming to increase gender equality in the workplace. The law affects around 70 companies and will require at least one woman on boards with more than three members. Firms that fail to meet the quota will risk fines. The legislation also introduces parental leave rights for board members. The move follows a study showing that women's representation on German boards is still low, with many large firms having no women on their management teams.

site_title: McDonald's delivery rider, NParks employee among 15 Covid-19 community cases
summary: A delivery rider for McDonald's, a NParks employee, and two pupils are among 15 new Covid-19 community cases reported in Singapore. The cases, linked to various clusters, include a 28-year-old man who developed symptoms after testing at a McDonald's outlet and a 55-year-old senior officer at NParks who tested positive after being quarantined at home. The number of new cases in the community has decreased from 196 two weeks ago to 137 in the past week, with unlinked cases dropping from 46 to 23 over the same period.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 3.27 points lower at 1,590.63 on Friday, with 520 losers outnumbering 414 gainers. Volume was 5.430 billion lots worth RM2.260 billion.

site_title: Four front-runners ready to light up Euro 2020
summary: Four top contenders, Belgium, France, England, and Portugal, are expected to excel in the Euro 2020 football tournament. Belgium boasts a deep and talented squad under coach Roberto Martinez, led by Romelu Lukaku and Eden Hazard. France, the reigning World Cup champions, has a lethal attack with Kylian Mbappe and Antoine Griezmann, but faces a tough Group of Death. England, with a youthful side led by Harry Kane and exciting prospects like Phil Foden, hopes to finally win a major international trophy. Portugal, with stars like Cristiano Ronaldo and Bruno Fernandes, aims to repeat their Euro 2016 surprise win.

site_title: Malaysia to go into total lockdown amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin announced a nationwide total lockdown starting June 1 to 14 due to a surge in coronavirus infections, with record levels of 8,290 new cases reported. The lockdown will affect all social and economic sectors, with only essential services remaining operational. The move comes as hospitals are strained and the number of daily fatalities has been rising. This is the fourth consecutive day of record infections, bringing the total number of cases to 549,514 and 61 deaths.

site_title: Being a jack-of-all-trades pays off for Black Dot's Nicholas Fang
summary: Nicholas Fang, managing director of Black Dot, emphasizes the importance of a balanced lifestyle, particularly incorporating physical activity into daily routines. As a multi-sport enthusiast, Fang has represented Singapore in various sports, including fencing, triathlons, and modern pentathlons. He attributes his ability to excel in multiple areas to his diverse skillset, which he believes has also shaped his career in strategic communications and sports consultancy. Fang believes that staying physically active and mentally focused is crucial for personal and professional success.

site_title: Philippine reports highest daily Covid-19 cases in 4 weeks
summary: The Philippines reported its highest daily Covid-19 cases in 4 weeks, with 8,748 new infections and 187 deaths, bringing the total to 1.2 million cases. This surge is attributed to a rise in cases outside the capital region and increased healthcare facility usage.

site_title: Malaysia reports 8,290 new coronavirus cases on Friday, another record
summary: Malaysia reported a record 8,290 new coronavirus cases on Friday, bringing the total cumulative cases to 549,514. This marks the fourth consecutive day of record infections, with daily cases more than doubling since the country declared a state of emergency in January. The nation's vaccination efforts have failed to pick up, straining hospital resources, particularly ICU beds. Criticism of the government's handling of the pandemic has fueled public anger on social media.

site_title: Sri Lanka battles waves of plastic waste from burning ship
summary: Sri Lanka is battling waves of plastic waste from a burning ship, the MV X-Press Pearl, which has swamped the west coast. A ban on fishing has been imposed in an 80km coastal area, including Colombo, due to concerns over contamination and pollution. The ship's cargo, including 28 containers of plastic pellets, has caused extensive damage to the environment, with millions of granules washing up on beaches. International efforts to salvage the vessel are ongoing, with a possible oil leak being the biggest threat, while harm to marine wildlife and birds is being assessed.

site_title: Singapore planning for possibility that Covid-19 becomes endemic here
summary: Singapore is planning for the possibility that Covid-19 may become endemic, requiring booster jabs and basic precautions. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that scientists may conclude the virus won't be eradicated, and the country must learn to live with it. A new $800 million support package will help individuals and businesses impacted by tightened measures. Wong emphasized that the current restrictions are working to curb the virus spread, and no further tightening is needed, with a fuller update to come at the next press conference.

site_title: Boeing halts deliveries of 787 again, works with FAA on fix
summary: Boeing has halted deliveries of its 787 Dreamliner, just two months after restarting them, due to regulatory issues. The company is working with the US Federal Aviation Administration to resolve previously disclosed quality issues, providing added analysis and documentation of proposed fixes. The FAA has not yet approved Boeing's proposed inspection method, prompting the halt in shipments. The issue is related to manufacturing flaws in the carbon-fiber shell of the aircraft, and deliveries are expected to resume once the FAA approves the fixes.

site_title: Blackrock now a substantial shareholder of ComfortDelGro
summary: Blackrock has become a substantial shareholder of ComfortDelGro after purchasing 5.2 million shares, increasing its shareholding from 4.76% to 5%. The US-based asset manager now holds 108.4 million shares, up from 103.2 million previously. This change in position came from an increase in shares held as collateral. ComfortDelGro's shares closed at S$1.680, up 1.21% on the day.

site_title: No easy way to sustainable weight loss
summary: Weight loss is not a straightforward process, and sustainable weight loss requires a comprehensive lifestyle approach, including a reduced calorie diet and regular physical exercise. The American Heart Association recommends that individuals with a BMI of 30 or higher, or those with a BMI of 25-29 with at least one risk factor for heart disease, benefit from weight loss. However, even with a comprehensive lifestyle program, some individuals may require additional measures, such as medication or surgery. Ultimately, weight loss is a matter of willpower, and there is no easy way to achieve sustainable weight loss without making lifestyle changes.

site_title: MC Payment to convene EGM requisitioned by controlling shareholder over boardroom tussle
summary: MC Payments, a digital payments firm, is convening an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) in response to a requisition notice from controlling shareholder Ching Chiat Kwong. Kwong, who owns 27.1% of the company, has requested the appointment of five new directors, including himself, to the board. The meeting will vote on the appointment of these nominees, who include two former directors of the company. The move comes after the company previously noted that it may not require a total of 10 directors on its board.

site_title: Greenwashing and how it can be avoided
summary: Greenwashing in investing refers to the practice of making false or misleading claims about a fund's environmental, social, or governance (ESG) impact. To avoid greenwashing, investors should ask the right questions and conduct thorough research, as there are no standardized definitions of "green" or "sustainable" globally. Lack of transparency and communication can be a deliberate attempt to misrepresent a fund's characteristics. Investors must be cautious and verify information to ensure they are investing in funds that genuinely align with their values and goals.

site_title: KSH reports FY2021 loss of S$3.8m on dip in construction, impairment loss
summary: KSH Holdings, a mainboard-listed property firm, reported a loss of S$3.8 million for FY2021 due to a 30% drop in its construction business and impairment losses on hotels and investment properties. Revenue declined 32.3% to S$153.1 million, mainly attributed to the pandemic-induced slowdown. Excluding impairments, the company would have reported a net profit of S$9 million. The firm's order book for construction business stood at S$620 million, and it proposed a final dividend of one Singapore cent per share.

site_title: Retailers welcome rental, wage relief, as Heightened Alert 'almost like a circuit breaker'
summary: Retailers in Singapore have welcomed the government's S$800 million support package, including rental relief and enhanced wage subsidies, amid the Heightened Alert period. The measures aim to cushion businesses affected by the 80% drop in sales. Founders and owners expressed relief, with one stating that the rental relief came as a "pleasant surprise." The support package aims to help businesses and workers cope with the economic impact of the restrictions.

site_title: Malaysia to escalate EU palm oil dispute at WTO
summary: Malaysia is set to escalate a trade dispute with the European Union at the World Trade Organization (WTO) over the EU's restriction on palm oil-based biofuels. The EU's renewable energy directive, which bans palm oil-based diesel, is being contested by Malaysia and Indonesia, citing "unfair benefits" for local producers. Malaysia has requested a WTO panel to adjudicate on the case, which could lead to trade sanctions. The dispute centers on the EU's stance that palm oil cultivation results in excessive deforestation and should not count towards renewable energy targets.

site_title: Japan extends virus emergency until month before Games
summary: Japan has extended its coronavirus emergency until June 20, just a month before the Olympics, amid concerns about the safety of the Games. The emergency measures, which include limiting alcohol sales and encouraging telework, will be in place in 10 regions, including Tokyo, until the end of June. The decision has raised doubts about the prospects for the pandemic-postponed Olympics, with some experts warning that lifting restrictions too soon could lead to a surge in cases. The government will reassess the decision on local fans after the emergency ends.

site_title: Chinese companies look to Malaysia for expansion plans: Standard Chartered
summary: Chinese companies are expanding plans in Malaysia, citing the country as the best opportunity for sales and production growth in the Asean region, according to a Standard Chartered survey. 65% of respondents preferred Malaysia, followed by Singapore and Thailand. Most are increasing investments in the region, with 88% planning to increase investments by at least 25% after the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) is ratified. However, the executives also identified risks, including the pandemic, geopolitical uncertainty, and trade conflicts, which may require adapting Chinese business models to local contexts through partnerships with Asean actors.

site_title: TikTok given EU ultimatum over child safety concerns
summary: The European Union has given TikTok, a Chinese-owned video-sharing app, a one-month deadline to address concerns over the safety of children's data on the platform. The EU has prohibited targeted advertising to minors and is working with national consumer organizations to support TikTok in complying with EU rules. The move follows complaints by a European consumer campaign group that TikTok is breaching users' rights on a massive scale.

images.alt_text: TikTok, the Chinese-owned video-sharing app, was given one month by European Union regulators and consumer protection watchdogs to address concerns over the safety of children's data on the platform.

site_title: Singapore stocks end week higher alongside regional markets; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to close at 3,178.55 on Friday, ending the week higher alongside regional markets. The news of an S$800 million support package for firms and individuals affected by Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) boosted investor sentiment. Across the region, markets such as the KLCI, Nikkei 225, and Hang Seng Index also gained. Analysts attributed the positive sentiment to US President Joe Biden's planned $1.8 trillion deficit, which may benefit Asian equity markets.

site_title: Tung Lok in the black from government Covid reliefs and own cost control moves
summary: Tung Lok Restaurants has regained profitability after posting net earnings of about S$800,000 for the six months ended March 31, driven by government reliefs and cost-control measures. The restaurant group's business was impacted by the pandemic, with a 6.9% year-on-year decline in sales and a net loss of S$2.6 million in the previous year. Efforts to reduce costs and receive S$5 million in financial support helped the group turn profitable. Earnings per share increased to 0.37 Singapore cents, compared to a loss of 0.94 cents a year ago.

site_title: Sterling on track for fourth consecutive weekly gains
summary: Sterling is on track for its fourth consecutive weekly gain against the dollar and euro, despite a 0.1% decline against the dollar and euro on Friday. The Bank of England's comments on rate hike timing, particularly from policymaker Gertjan Vlieghe, are credited with providing support. Sterling has risen around 4% year-to-date, driven by optimism over Britain's speedy Covid-19 vaccination and reopening of its economy. Analysts note that positive news has been already priced in, and a potential re-opening in June may hold sterling back temporarily.

site_title: Malaysia's FGV posts Q1 loss, warns pandemic challenges to persist
summary: Malaysia's palm oil giant FGV Holdings reported a Q1 net loss of RM35.4 million, compared to a RM142.3 million loss in the same period last year. Revenue rose 21.9% to RM3.39 billion, driven by higher crude palm oil prices. The company expects crude palm oil prices to remain high but warns of ongoing challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic and labor shortages in the plantation sector.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish flat
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day marginally higher on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 11.21 points to 29,124.41. The global recovery outlook remained a positive factor for traders, despite earlier gains being given up. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.22%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.24%.

site_title: 15 new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore, including four unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 30 new COVID-19 cases, with 15 in the community, including four unlinked cases. The total number of cases reached 61,970. 11 cases were linked to previous cases, while 15 imported cases were placed on stay-home notice or isolated upon arrival. The Ministry of Health will announce more details on Friday night.

site_title: 1,000-year-old 'stolen' artefacts to return to Thailand from US
summary: Two 1,000-year-old sandstone artefacts believed to have been stolen from Thailand during the Vietnam War are set to return from the US to Thailand. The temple support beams, featuring carvings of Hindu deities, were on display at the San Francisco Asian Art Museum and will be put on display at the National Museum in Bangkok for three months. The return follows a three-year US investigation and a handover ceremony between US authorities and the Royal Thai Consulate General in Los Angeles. The artefacts' return holds significant importance for Thai history, archaeology, and culture.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Friday, driven by gains in Tokyo and overnight on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 gained 0.3%, and the Paris CAC 40 rose 0.2%. The gains were attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, as well as US-EU trade talks in focus.

site_title: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust to buy building housing HP Japan HQ for 38.8b yen
summary: Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust has agreed to purchase a 98.47% stake in a Tokyo office building, previously used as Hewlett-Packard Japan's headquarters, for 38.8 billion yen (S$467.3 million). The deal marks a significant investment in the Japanese market. The building's remaining 1.53% stake will be held by Mapletree's Japanese subsidiary. This purchase is part of the trust's strategy to expand its portfolio in Asia.

site_title: Taiwan targets Covid-19 vaccination for 60% of population by Oct
summary: Taiwan aims to vaccinate 60% of its population with at least one dose of coronavirus vaccine by October, according to Health Minister Chen Shih-chung. The move comes as the island battles a spike in domestic cases, with 555 new infections reported on Friday. Taiwan has called its second-highest alert to limit gatherings and shut entertainment venues. The goal is to utilize the full vaccination capacity to reach the 60% target, indicating a need for increased vaccination efforts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher following Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on Friday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street and a rise in the dollar's value against the yen. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index jumped 2.10% to 29,149.41, while the broader Topix index rose 1.91% to 1,947.44. Investors cheered the US jobs environment and a cheaper yen, driving up Japanese exporter shares. Major automakers and retailers, including Toyota and SoftBank, also saw significant gains.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore has introduced an $800 million Covid-19 support package, increasing the Jobs Support Scheme to 50% for affected businesses, including gyms and arts organizations. The package is funded by reallocation from development expenditure. Meanwhile, a US judge ruled that there is no sufficient irreparable harm to freeze funds of ex-EHT directors, and DBS and StanChart executed Singapore's first Sora-referenced interbank option trade. Additionally, Lawrence Wong was appointed to the MAS board, and corporate earnings rose, with Econ Healthcare posting a 41.2% increase in full-year net profit.

site_title: Nike says split with Neymar over refusal to cooperate with sex assault probe
summary: Nike has ended its partnership with Brazilian soccer star Neymar after he refused to cooperate with an investigation into a sex assault claim made by an employee in 2016. The investigation, which began in 2019, was inconclusive and did not provide sufficient facts to make an accusatory statement. Neymar's team denies the allegations, calling them "baseless." The split occurred last year, with Nike citing the refusal to cooperate as the reason for the end of their relationship.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post 1% weekly gain
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1% for the week, their biggest gain in three weeks, driven by tech heavyweights and upbeat US data. The Kospi index ended at 3,188.73, rebounding from a 0.1% decline on Thursday. Hyundai Motor and Kia Corp led the gains, while foreign investors bought US$125.62 million worth of shares. Strong global demand for South Korea's products, including semiconductors, cars, and petroleum, is expected to boost May exports, the fastest pace in over three decades.

site_title: No risk of sufficient irreparable harm to immediately freeze funds of ex-EHT directors: US judge
summary: A US bankruptcy judge has declined to freeze funds of former Eagle Hospitality Trust (EHT) directors Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, citing no "irreparable harm". The directors were accused of misusing a $2.4 million loan under the US Cares Act's Paycheck Protection Programme. The judge allowed the directors to participate in the sale of several hotels, but noted that if there's a risk of insolvency, the issue could be revisited. The judge also considers referring the matter to federal prosecutors for further investigation into "possible criminal conduct".

site_title: Bogus 'law firms' and lawyer impersonation scams on the rise, cautions Singapore's LawSoc
summary: Singapore's Law Society has seen a rise in bogus "law firms" and lawyer impersonation scams, with five cases of phishing, one case of impersonation, and two cases of bogus law firms reported since 2019. Scammers have become more sophisticated, using fake websites and email addresses to dupe unsuspecting clients. The Law Society is cautioning the public to verify emails and identities of lawyers and law firms, and has reported similar scams to the police.

site_title: Europe has passed turning point but still needs ECB support: Schnabel
summary: The euro zone economy has reached a turning point, with growth expected to surpass 4% this year, but still requires ECB support. ECB board member Isabel Schnabel played down concerns over rising borrowing costs, citing improved fundamentals and favorable financing conditions. Despite a two-year high in 10-year German bond yields, Schnabel argued that the rise is expected and reflects investors' growing optimism. The ECB must decide on its emergency bond buys at the June 10 meeting, with policymakers calling for continued stimulus to avoid a potential growth slowdown.

site_title: S$800m Covid-19 support package for affected firms and individuals, no draw on past reserves
summary: Singapore is rolling out an S$800 million support package for firms and individuals affected by Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) measures, including enhanced Jobs Support Scheme payouts for certain sectors. The package will be funded by reallocation from development expenditure and will provide rental relief, one-off support for lower- to middle-income employees and self-employed persons, and increased support for sectors significantly affected. The government will review support measures if measures are extended beyond June 13, and no draw on past reserves will be made for this package.

images.alt_text: The S$800 million support package includes enhanced Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payouts for certain sectors.

site_title: Jobs Support Scheme raised from 10% to 50% for those affected by tighter Covid-19 rules
summary: The Singapore government is increasing the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) wage support for employers in sectors significantly affected by tightened Covid-19 measures, from 10% to 50% from May 16 to June 13. This applies to gyms, fitness studios, and other affected businesses. The government will also provide rental relief and a new Covid-19 Recovery Grant (Temporary) scheme to support individuals financially impacted by the tightened measures.

site_title: Three crew missing after collision of Japanese cargo ship and tanker
summary: A Japanese cargo ship, the Byakko, sank after colliding with a Marshall Islands-registered tanker in the Seto Inland Sea. Three crew members are missing, with nine rescued by the Japanese coast guard and nearby ships. There were no injuries on the tanker crew, and no leakage or floating objects at the site. A search operation involving 14 patrol ships and three aircraft is underway.

site_title: Australia: Shares scale over three-month high on mining, energy boost
summary: Australian shares rose 1.2% on Friday, posting a 2.1% weekly gain, as mining and energy stocks jumped 2% and 1.7% respectively. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index reached its highest level since February 20. Strong US data boosted global sentiment, while iron ore futures rose after China planned to curb steel output. Energy stocks, including Santos and Oil Search, advanced 2.3% and 2.2% respectively. Financial stocks also rose over 1%, with the "Big Four" Australian banks gaining between 1.1% and 1.4%.

site_title: France fell into recession in Q1, revised GDP data shows
summary: France's economy contracted by 0.1% in Q1 2021, revised from an initial +0.4% growth, according to the INSEE statistics office. This follows a 1.5% contraction in Q4 2020. Household spending, a key driver of France's economic activity, fell 8.3% in Q2 after a third national Covid-19 lockdown. The public deficit stood at 9.2% of GDP in 2020. Despite a revised GDP growth forecast of 5% for 2021, Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire acknowledged the crisis is "moving behind us, though we must remain cautious."

site_title: Lawrence Wong appointed to MAS board; Ong Ye Kung to step down
summary: Lawrence Wong has been appointed deputy chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) board for a three-year term starting June 1, 2021. Ong Ye Kung, who has served on the board since 2016, will step down on May 31, 2021. Lim Hng Kiang will step down as deputy chairman but remain a member, while Tharman Shanmugaratnam will be re-appointed as chairman. Other MAS board members, including Ravi Menon and Heng Swee Keat, have also been re-appointed for various terms.

site_title: Big Tech drawn to new Singapore carbon offset trading market
summary: Big Tech companies such as Google, Microsoft, and Amazon are in talks with Singapore's Climate Impact X, a new carbon offset trading platform backed by the Singapore Exchange. The platform aims to provide transparency and assurance for companies to meet ambitious net-zero targets. Grab Holdings, a ride-hailing firm, also supports the platform, and companies like DBS Group Holdings are backing Climate Impact X. The platform will use blockchain technology and satellite verification to ensure the integrity of projects, and will be launched this year.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise Sembcorp target price on sustainability-focused strategic plan
summary: Analysts have raised their target prices for Sembcorp Industries, citing the company's strategic plan to focus on renewable energy and sustainable urban development. The group plans to grow its sustainable-solutions portfolio to 70% of its profit contribution in the next four years. UOB Kay Hian and DBS Group Research have increased their target prices, with UOBKH setting its target price at S$2.59 and DBS at S$2.40. Analysts believe the company's growth potential and ESG focus could lead to a market premium, but also note concerns over high gearing and potential equity-raising needs.

site_title: Gates divorce forces US$50b foundation to weigh changes
summary: Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates' divorce after 27 years of marriage has led the US$50 billion Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation to consider changes. Three weeks after the split, CEO Mark Suzman has initiated talks to strengthen the foundation's long-term sustainability. The move comes amid revelations of Melinda French Gates' earlier consideration of divorce due to Bill's ties to Jeffrey Epstein and reports of his behavior at Microsoft.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Friday, driven by fresh optimism about the global recovery outlook. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.05% to 29,127.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.07% to 3,606.48. This follows a positive lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: ecoWise Holdings halts trading after share surge, SGX query
summary: Ecowise Holdings, a CATALIST-listed environmental solutions provider, halted trading after receiving a Singapore Exchange (SGX) query regarding "unusual price and volume movements". The company's share price surged 41% to 5.5 cents before paring some gains, trading 35.9% higher at 5.3 cents. The trading halt was triggered after the SGX query, with no married deals recorded in early trade.

site_title: DBS, StanChart execute Singapore's first Sora-referenced interbank option trade
summary: DBS and Standard Chartered (StanChart) have successfully executed Singapore's first interbank option trade referencing the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (Sora). The trade was done on behalf of an undisclosed global real estate group to manage market risk from a Sora interest rate option. This marks a significant milestone in the transition from SOR and Sibor to Sora, with DBS and StanChart committed to developing more Sora derivatives to support clients' transition to the new benchmark.

site_title: China to limit daily price swings in national emissions trading to 10%
summary: China's national emission trading scheme will initially limit daily price swings at 10% when it launches in late June. The scheme, covering 2,225 power plants responsible for 4 billion tonnes of carbon emissions annually, aims to achieve the country's net-zero emission pledge. Limits for block deals will be set at 30% of price moves, with adjustments based on market movements. The move is seen as a key policy lever for China's climate goals.

site_title: Digital bank upstarts are years away from profits in Hong Kong
summary: Hong Kong's digital banks, Mox Bank and ZA Bank, are years away from profitability. Despite gaining traction, they face stiff competition from traditional banks and are still building operations. Mox predicts breaking even by 2024, while ZA Bank expects the same. To become profitable, digital banks will need to roll out more banking products and services, such as insurance and wealth management. The two digital banks are hiring staff and expanding their offerings, but their progress is slower than expected, with many customers also holding accounts with traditional lenders.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks set for 1% weekly gain as US data supports
summary: South Korea's stocks are poised for a 1% weekly gain, driven by Hyundai Motor's investment in electric vehicles and upbeat US jobless claims data. The Kospi index rose 0.6% to 3,184.34, with Hyundai Motor and Kia Corp jumping 4.3% each. The won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield rose 3.6 basis points to 1.2%. Foreigners were net buyers of 53.5 billion won worth of shares, and the 10-year yield rose 4.2 basis points to 2.154%.

site_title: Gold flat as dollar, yields firm ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,896.71 per ounce, as the dollar strengthened and US Treasury yields rose ahead of Friday's inflation data. The dollar index increased 0.1% against rivals, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. US gold futures edged 0.1% higher to $1,899.50 per ounce. Investors await the monthly US personal consumption report to gauge inflationary pressure, despite Fed officials downplaying rising price pressures and affirming support for accommodative monetary policy.

site_title: Qantas dangles free trips for people who have been vaccinated
summary: Qantas is considering offering free flight vouchers or air miles to fully vaccinated individuals, as part of a global trend of businesses incentivizing travel amid the pandemic. The program, set to run until the end of 2021, aims to boost vaccination rates and kick-start international travel. Other companies, including United Airlines, Tinder, and Uber, are also offering vaccination incentives. The move is seen as crucial for Australia's domestic and international travel, with only 3.7 million people vaccinated out of 26 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,186.46 points at Friday's open, following gains on Wall Street. Local stocks such as BlackGold Natural Resources, Suntec Reit, and Ascendas Reit saw brisk trading. UOB rose 1.5%, while OCBC and DBS followed with gains of 1.4% and 0.7%, respectively. This comes after solid US labour data and a proposed infrastructure package on Wall Street.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher following Wall Street gain
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday, following overnight gains on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.6% to 29,012.95 and the Topix index adding 1.5% to 1,938.83. The dollar's rise also contributed to the gains.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday, tracking overnight gains on Wall Street with investors also cheering the dollar's rise.

site_title: Econ Healthcare posts 41.2% rise in full-year net profit to S$5.7m
summary: Econ Healthcare Group posted a 41.2% rise in full-year net profit to S$5.7 million, driven by a 13.9% increase in operating subvention grants and other income. Revenue dropped 7.1% to S$20.4 million, but the company remains optimistic with plans to expand its nursing home operations in Singapore and China. The board recommended a final dividend of 0.78 Singapore cents per share.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit record high on Airbus boost, Bayer hurt by Roundup ruling
summary: European shares closed at a record high, boosted by Airbus's 9.2% jump after increasing jet output targets. German shares weakened due to Bayer's 5.0% drop after a US judge rejected its class action plan related to Roundup weedkillers. Investors moved into cyclical sectors for protection from rising inflation, with European banks and basic resources rising 1.9% and 3.0% respectively.

site_title: Thai Airways says court hearing on business restructuring moved to mid-June
summary: Thai Airways International has postponed its court hearing on its business restructuring proposal to June 15, following complaints filed by creditors. The airline's restructuring plan aims to restructure 245 billion baht (S$10.37 billion) of debt through payment extensions, interest waivers, and debt-to-equity conversions. The Central Bankruptcy Court will review the plan, which was previously approved by creditors. This move allows planners and creditors to clarify issues before the court's decision.

images.alt_text: Thai Airways International said that a court will decide on its restructuring proposal on June 15, after Friday's hearing was postponed to allow for the assessment of complaints filed by creditors against the plan.

site_title: Gold at Bank of England commands high premium, signalling Central Bank buying
summary: The Bank of England's gold reserves, stored and sold on behalf of other central and commercial banks, have been trading at unusually high premiums, signaling central bank buying. The premiums, which have reached as high as 50 US cents above benchmark London prices, are being driven by the Bank for International Settlements' recent purchases of up to 1 million ounces of gold. This buying may indicate that one or several central banks are increasing their gold reserves, potentially supporting a gold rally amid inflation concerns.

site_title: Brent nudges towards US$70 on rosy US data, oil demand outlook
summary: Oil prices surged on Friday, with Brent crude futures rising 16 cents to US$69.62 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude gaining 32 cents to US$67.17 a barrel. Strong US economic data and expectations of a rebound in global fuel demand in the third quarter supported the price increase. Analysts expect a 5-6% weekly gain for Brent and WTI, driven by summer travel in Europe and the US, while concerns about Iranian supplies eased. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) is likely to maintain its existing oil supply curbs at a meeting on Tuesday.

site_title: Daring to be different
summary: RHTLaw Asia, a Singapore-headquartered law firm, celebrates its 10th anniversary with a decade of success in delivering value to clients by being more than just a local law firm. Founded in 2011, the firm has grown to offer over 2,000 lawyers in 14 jurisdictions, driven by its willingness to take the road less traveled, embracing technology, and providing complementary professional services. RHTLaw's commitment to sustainability and CSR initiatives has also been key to its growth, with initiatives such as the RHT Rajan Menon Foundation and Greening Asean programme.

site_title: Credit Suisse scandals prompt Switzerland to think unthinkable: punish bankers
summary: Credit Suisse scandals have sparked a debate in Switzerland about punishing bankers, a rare discussion about banking reform. The bank's heavy losses from the collapse of family offices Archegos and Greensill have angered regulators. This has led to a discussion about ending the laissez-faire regime, where fines on bankers are not possible, and adopting Britain's stricter rule book. Lawmakers are considering fining bankers, a move that would be unprecedented in Switzerland. The debate centers on ending the current system and implementing stricter regulations.

images.alt_text: Exasperation with Credit Suisse following a string of scandals is prompting Switzerland to rethink a system in which top bankers have been largely untouchable.

site_title: New car launches in May and upcoming launches
summary: Several new car launches are expected in May, including the upcoming release of the new car models. Additionally, there are upcoming car launches, although the specific models and release dates are not mentioned.

site_title: Japan's jobless rate rises, prices fall as pandemic pain persists
summary: Japan's unemployment rate rose to 2.8% in April, exceeding forecasts, as the country continues to battle the pandemic's economic impact. Core consumer prices in Tokyo fell 0.2% in May, indicating inflation will remain below the central bank's 2% target. The government is considering extending state of emergency curbs until June 20, which could further hinder the economy's recovery. Economists expect employment and labor force to return to pre-virus levels in the second half of the year as vaccines allow the economy to recover.

site_title: JD Logistics soars in Hong Kong debut, valuing it at US$34b
summary: JD Logistics, a Chinese delivery and warehousing firm spun out from JD.com, made its Hong Kong debut with a stock market value of US$34 billion, soaring 9% on its first day. The company priced its US$3.2 billion IPO closer to the lower end of an indicated range, beating expectations. CEO Yu Rui said the funds raised will be used to improve networks and infrastructure in China and overseas markets, despite regulatory scrutiny. The IPO is the second-largest in Hong Kong this year, following Kuaishou Technology's debut in January.

site_title: Japan to extend virus emergency until a month before Olympics
summary: Japan's state of emergency, currently set to end on May 31, has been extended to June 20, a month before the Tokyo Olympics, in an effort to control coronavirus infections. The decision was made by Economy Minister Yasutoshi Nishimura, with the International Olympic Committee's deadline for a decision looming by the end of June. The move aims to mitigate concerns that the Olympics could turn into a superspreader event, despite Japan's lower infection rates compared to the US.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Econ Healthcare, SATS, Boustead, Lendlease Reit, SIA
summary: Econ Healthcare posted a 41.2% rise in full-year net profit, while SATS reported its first net profit in five quarters, with a net profit of S$8,000,000. Boustead's second-half net profit more than quadrupled to S$91.3 million, and Lendlease Global Reit issued S$200 million in perpetual securities. SIA was questioned by the Securities Investors Association about potential privatization and its business and shareholder interests. The Singapore stock market notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly gain on improving labour data
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday as solid labor data and a Republican infrastructure proposal boosted sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 added 0.4% and 0.1%, respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index remained flat. Key highlights include lower US unemployment benefits, a 1.3% drop in big-ticket manufactured goods orders, and a 2.9% jump in General Motors following car production restoration plans. The Republican infrastructure offer narrowed the spending gap with the White House, but significant differences remain between the parties.

site_title: Maybank posts higher Q1 profit on loan growth
summary: Maybank, Malaysia's largest lender by assets, reported a higher net profit of RM2.39 billion in Q1, beating analysts' forecast, driven by 7% rise in net fund-based income and 3.1% growth in group gross loans. Despite a 7.7% drop in revenue, the bank's Islamic banking income rose 16.3% and net earned insurance premiums grew 30%. The bank remains cautious due to ongoing loan repayment assistance for customers affected by coronavirus restrictions. Net interest margin expanded to 2.31%, with loan demand picking up pace as the economic outlook improved.

site_title: Central banks signalling policy shifts
summary: Central banks are signaling a shift away from emergency monetary settings, with South Korea following New Zealand and Canada in flagging potential interest-rate increases. As economies reopen and vaccines roll out, markets are adjusting to a tightening narrative, with bond yields and currencies fluctuating. The Bank of Korea, New Zealand, and Bank of Canada have all signaled a potential exit from record-low interest rates, while the Federal Reserve has seen its first rate hike priced forward by almost a year.

site_title: US judge denies Bayer's request to settle future Roundup weedkiller claims
summary: A US judge has rejected Bayer's proposal to pay up to $2 billion to settle future claims that its Roundup weedkiller causes cancer, calling the agreement "clearly unreasonable" for consumers exposed but not yet diagnosed. The decision compounds Bayer's struggles to wrap up litigation inherited from its acquisition of Monsanto in 2018. The company will reassess its US lawn care market and review its US residential lawn and garden business, potentially phasing out glyphosate in its products.

site_title: Air freight market becomes a bright spot for Boeing in China
summary: Boeing is optimistic about its freighter plane sales in China, where e-commerce demand has led to a boom in air freight. Despite a three-year deadlock, China Cargo Airlines placed an order for two 777 freighters last May, and Boeing has delivered 24 of the type to China. Boeing forecasts China will need 750 more freighters over the next 20 years, driven by pandemic-induced online shopping growth. The company's dominance of the freighter market makes it harder for rival Airbus to bypass, and air freight rates are forecast to stay strong due to reduced capacity.

site_title: Finding beauty in everyday materials
summary: The Loewe Foundation Craft Prize, established by creative director Jonathan Anderson, celebrates young artists and artisans creating works from everyday materials. This year, Chinese artist FangLu Lin won the top prize of 50,000 euros for her massive, intricately detailed cloth piece inspired by traditional Bai tie-dyeing techniques from China's Yunnan province. The prize recognizes practices often neglected in contemporary art, with past winners including Chilean artist David Corvalán and Japanese artist Takayuki Sakiyama. The prize's online exhibition showcases all 115 finalists' works.

site_title: GIC-backed Klarna seeking new funds at close to US$50b valuation: sources
summary: Klarna, a Swedish payments firm backed by GIC, is seeking a new round of funding valued at around US$50 billion, close to its estimated valuation. The latest fundraising, expected to be its final private round, would lift the company's valuation and make it Sweden's largest financial company. Klarna has already raised US$1 billion this year, tripling its valuation to US$31 billion, and plans to consider a direct listing or initial public offering early next year. The company's investor slate includes SoftBank, rapper Snoop Dogg, and BlackRock.

site_title: Commodity boom slams Malaysia builders already hurt by Covid-19
summary: Malaysia's builders are struggling due to the commodity boom, which has led to a surge in building material prices. The Master Builders Association Malaysia is seeking government help to shield builders from the risk of price increases. Prices of materials such as steel have jumped 30% since 2020, causing firms to suffer losses. The industry is already reeling from the COVID-19 pandemic, and the government's efforts to revive the economy are being hindered by the rising costs.

site_title: US luxury home builder raises profit forecasts despite higher costs all round
summary: Toll Brothers, a US luxury home builder, raised its profit forecasts despite higher costs, as the company pushes prices to record heights amid a booming housing market. The company's shares rose 5.3% after the announcement, with the stock gaining almost 50% this year. Toll's average contract price increased 6.3% to $875,500, and the company expects gross profit margins to jump to 24.6% this year, significantly exceeding earlier forecasts. The strategy, which involves raising prices to compensate for escalating costs, is working, according to analysts, but may eventually lead to a downward cycle if prices become too high.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Boustead Singapore's second-half net profit more than quadrupled to S$91.3 million, driven by its real estate division's successful launch of the Boustead Industrial Fund (BIF). The company proposed a final ordinary dividend of three Singapore cents and a special dividend of four Singapore cents per share. Meanwhile, Old Chang Kee reported a H2 profit of S$2.6 million, reversing its loss the previous year, and Sunpower Group completed the construction of a steam distribution pipeline in China.

site_title: URA, HDB release Jalan Tembusu, Tampines Street 62 residential sites for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and the Housing & Development Board (HDB) released 99-year leasehold residential sites in Jalan Tembusu and Tampines Street 62 for sale. The Jalan Tembusu site, yielding 640 units, and the Tampines Street 62 site, yielding 700 executive condominium units, are on the reserve list in the first half 2021 government land sales programme. Analysts predict high bids for both sites, with estimates ranging from S$1,100 to S$1,500 psf ppr for Jalan Tembusu and S$550 to S$620 psf ppr for Tampines Street 62.

site_title: GovTech employee, 4 cleaners among 14 Covid-19 community cases
summary: A GovTech employee and four cleaners are among 14 community cases of Covid-19 reported by the Ministry of Health in Singapore on May 27, 2021. The GovTech employee, who was last at work on May 7, developed symptoms on Monday and sought medical treatment. This brings the total community cases to 14, with three unlinked cases.

site_title: Hyundai to slash combustion engine line-up, invest in EVs
summary: Hyundai Motor Group plans to slash its combustion engine lineup by 50% to focus on electric vehicles, including hydrogen fuel cell and battery EVs. The move aims to free up resources for research and development on electric motors and batteries. Hyundai aims to sell 1 million EVs per year by 2025 and achieve a 10% global EV market share by 2040. The company will finalize its all-electric strategy within the next six months.

site_title: Eco-friendly watches take the stage
summary: Luxury watch brands are embracing eco-friendliness with the launch of sustainable timepieces. Cartier, Panerai, and Ulysse Nardin unveiled watches made from recycled materials and powered by renewable energy sources. Cartier's new Tank Must line features a strap made from nearly half vegetable waste and a solar-powered movement. Brands aim to reduce their environmental footprint through sustainable practices, marking a shift in the luxury watch industry towards eco-conscious design.

site_title: Bank watchdogs resist EU industry push to derail stricter rules
summary: European Union banking watchdogs are warning lenders to stop resisting stricter global capital rules, known as Basel III, or risk weakening the financial system. The EU is gearing up to propose implementing the new standards in the autumn, with a slated start in 2023. Banks, particularly those in the EU, are concerned that the rules will hit them harder than US lenders, who are recovering from the pandemic crisis. However, regulators argue that delaying or weakening the rules would undermine the EU's reputation as a defender of multilateral agreements and contradict the push for global convergence on climate risk.

site_title: US mid-term polls could decide GOP's future
summary: The US Republican Party is facing an existential crisis, with next year's mid-term elections potentially determining its future. The party has adopted a two-pronged opposition strategy, combining Trump loyaltyism with fiscal conservatism, as led by former President Donald Trump. The replacement of Liz Cheney with Elise Stefanik has been seen as a calculated move to appease the party's base. Analysts warn that Trumpism is a "losing horse" for the Republicans, but may still drive turnout in the mid-term elections. The party's strategy may also lead to a formal schism or the formation of a new party by Trump if the GOP breaks with him.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 14.5 points, or 0.9%, to 1,586.3, driven by a higher volume of 169.9 million lots worth RM68.1 million. Gainers outpaced losers 221 to 111.

site_title: HSBC withdraws from loss-making US retail banking
summary: HSBC is withdrawing from its loss-making US retail banking business by selling and winding down parts of the operation. This move marks a shift in focus towards Asia, the bank's largest market. HSBC has been trying to reduce its presence in European and North American markets where it faces intense competition. The bank's decision comes as Europe's largest bank steps up efforts to restructure and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Sharing Spaces
summary: The Singapore Pavilion at the Venice Biennale's Architecture Exhibition highlights unique Singaporean living spaces, addressing the question of "How Will We Live Together" in the post-pandemic world. Curated by Hashim Sarkis, the exhibition brings together 112 architects from 46 countries to present inspiring answers to the theme. Sarkis believes his contemporaries have the ability to offer more inspiring solutions than politics, showcasing the world's most prestigious architecture platform. The exhibition is considered timely, as many have been living under imposed isolation due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: When a summer day calls for a beer
summary: A warm summer day in New York City has led to a collective softening of the pandemic's grip, prompting a desire for outdoor gatherings and refreshing beers. The author, a beer enthusiast, advocates for pilsners, a style of lager that originated in the Czech Republic, due to its pale color, pronounced hop character, and dry, floral bitterness. Classic Old World pilsners, such as Pilsner Urquell, are preferred over mass-market beers, and local brands like Sixpoint's German-style pilsner and Reissdorf's Kölsch are also praised. The author concludes that pilsners and Kölsch are ideal summer beers, offering a refreshing and balanced taste experience.

site_title: When corporates binge on debt
summary: Companies are taking advantage of historically low interest rates to binge on debt, with record volumes of corporate bond issuance. While cheap borrowing costs benefit businesses, concerns arise about whether companies are using the capital for operational financing, hoarding cash, or repaying debt and paying shareholders. Rising inflation and diminishing central bank support may prompt a sell-off in corporate debt markets, prompting investors to reevaluate their strategies and scrutinize corporate purpose.

site_title: China tech giants spend billions to fuel growth after crackdown
summary: China's largest tech giants, including Alibaba, Tencent Holdings, and Meituan, are investing billions of dollars to expand into fundamental technology and infrastructure amid a crackdown on their lucrative businesses. The companies are pouring capital into cloud computing, autonomous driving, and artificial intelligence to meet Beijing's priority areas and tech self-sufficiency goals. Despite antitrust fines and regulatory scrutiny, the tech giants are committed to investing heavily in these areas, with Meituan raising $10 billion to develop autonomous delivery vehicles and robotics. The increased spending is seen as a response to Beijing's efforts to drive the tech industry towards innovation and self-reliance.

site_title: Edmund Tie appoints Desmond Sim as deputy CEO
summary: Edmund Tie & Company (SEA) announced that Desmond Sim will become deputy CEO on June 1, succeeding Ong Choon Fah, who has been CEO since 2015. Sim, a veteran with over 20 years of experience in the industry, left CBRE in February. He will take over as CEO in July, focusing on talent cultivation and management, and leveraging his global exposure and local market expertise.

site_title: Foxconn in talks to buy stake in Malaysian chipmaker DNeX
summary: Foxconn Technology Group is in talks to acquire a stake in Malaysian chipmaker Dagang NeXchange (DNeX), following its loss to DNeX in bidding for SilTerra Malaysia, a semiconductor company. DNeX won the deal in February, and the talks are ongoing with no certainty of a deal. A stake sale would expand DNeX's business and help SilTerra, with shares in DNeX rising 13.6% following the report.

site_title: A 120% loss on Vegas mall spells jackpot for Icahn's big short
summary: A commercial mortgage-backed conduit loan, worth $62.2 million, was written down to $0 after the Prizm Outlets mall in Las Vegas was sold for $400,000. This represents a 120% loss, the largest since the 2008 financial crisis. Billionaire investor Carl Icahn, who bet against retail, has received his first payout. The loan's failure is attributed to the pandemic's lockdown orders, which led to a decline in shopper traffic and a shift to online shopping. The sale of the mall is seen as vindication for those who shorted the commercial real estate credit derivatives index, CMBX 6.

site_title: Sats posts profit for Q4, but is in the red for full year
summary: Sats, a Singaporean ground-handler and in-flight caterer, reported its first net profit in five quarters for Q4, driven by year-on-year revenue growth from non-travel-related businesses and a smaller cost base. The company attributed the improvement to significant cost cuts and growth in non-aviation food orders. Despite a net loss of S$78.9 million for the full year, Sats expects to generate fast-paced growth in its non-travel-related business segment.

site_title: Disorganised rollout of new technologies hinders banks and regulators
summary: Banks have seen a 50% rise in digital services use during the Covid-19 pandemic, with 71% of consumers using digital services weekly. However, the pressure to innovate has led to disjointed digitalization, causing banks' IT landscapes to become complex and disconnected from operational processes. This has hindered the industry's ability to effectively implement new technologies, ultimately affecting regulators and banks alike. The issue highlights the need for more cohesive digitalization strategies to support the evolving needs of the financial sector.

site_title: US unemployment filings reach new pandemic low
summary: US unemployment filings reached a new pandemic low, with 406,000 new claims filed last week, 38,000 fewer than expected. The insured unemployment rate decreased slightly to 2.6%, with 3.6 million people receiving regular aid. Despite improvements, over 15.8 million people were receiving benefits under all programs. The decline in unemployment claims indicates ongoing progress in the labor market recovery, according to economists.

site_title: Travellers from Australia's Victoria state must serve 7-day stay-home notice
summary: Travellers from Victoria state in Australia must serve a 7-day stay-home notice in Singapore due to the increase in Covid-19 cases in the state. The rules will take effect from May 29, as part of tightened border control measures.

site_title: Warming planet revolutionises how banks define risk
summary: European banks are facing new capital requirements that will reflect the climate change risk in their loan books, according to Fitch Ratings. The European Central Bank's guidelines instruct banks to consider their sensitivity to climate risk when determining their capital needs. However, ensuring that banks have the necessary data from companies to assess their climate risks remains a challenge. Regulators are urging the non-financial sector to deliver the information needed, as the financial sector demands. This new requirement marks a significant expansion of new rules aimed at forcing banks to channel money away from polluting industries and towards businesses with lower carbon emissions.

site_title: Michelin meals to go
summary: Singapore's Michelin-starred restaurants are now offering affordable takeaway options, with set menus starting from S$138 for two people. Basque Kitchen by Aitor, Buona Terra, Candlenut, and Summer Pavilion are among the establishments participating in this initiative. Prices vary, but most menus include a range of dishes, from comfort food to high-end Peranakan cuisine. The takeaway options are available for a limited time, offering diners a chance to enjoy Michelin-starred meals at home.

images.alt_text: Basque Kitchen by Aitor wagyu txuleta burger - pricey but perfect.
Buona Terra's takeaway five-course tasting menu for one that's enough for two.
New dishes at Candlenut: Sayur lodeh with otah and mackerel (above) and an inventive lemongrass pandan sponge.
New dishes at Candlenut: Sayur lodeh with otah and mackerel and an inventive lemongrass pandan sponge (above).
