Summer Pavilion's marinated signature duck and steamed prawn and vegetable dumpling (above).
Summer Pavilion's marinated signature duck (above) and steamed prawn and vegetable dumpling.

site_title: Nvidia forecast beats expectations but crypto mining's role still unclear
summary: Nvidia forecasted second-quarter revenue above analysts' expectations, reaching $6.3 billion, with its data centre business and gaming chip segment driving growth. However, the company's crypto mining business remains unclear, with revenue from these chips expected to rise to $400 million in the second quarter. Nvidia's chief executive Jensen Huang stated that the company's efforts to make gaming chips less suitable for miners will help maintain supply and increase production. The company still expects to close its $40 billion deal to purchase Arm Ltd by March 2022.

site_title: Fall in Singapore's services revenue eases further to -1.5% in Q1
summary: Singapore's services revenue declined 1.5% year-on-year in Q1, easing further from a 7.6% decline in the previous quarter. The information and communications industry saw a 21% increase in turnover, driven by game publishers and online marketplaces. The administrative and support services industry was the worst hit, with a 19.9% decline, while the recreation and personal services industry fell 18.8%. The education sector, however, saw a 7.5% growth in revenue. Economists predict further declines in Q2 due to tightened Covid-19 restrictions, but a potential rebound in the second half of the year.

site_title: US dollar steadies, yuan hits new 3-year high
summary: The US dollar struggled to hold gains as investors weighed the possibility of the Federal Reserve tapering its asset purchases, while China's yuan reached a three-year high. The euro rose 0.1% to $1.2203, and the yen fell to a one-week low at 109.17 per dollar. Sterling dipped to a week-low before recovering, and other currencies remained in recent ranges. Despite Fed officials downplaying concerns about inflation, analysts believe the US central bank will give ample notice before changing policy, limiting any rebound in the US dollar.

site_title: Pandemic batters football clubs' valuations
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has significantly impacted European football clubs' valuations, with the top 32 clubs experiencing a 15% decline in aggregate enterprise value, marking the first decline in years. The pandemic has also exacerbated underlying issues in the industry, including declining broadcasting and match-day revenues, and deteriorating profitability. Only 7 of the 32 clubs reported a net profit, and the top division clubs are expected to see aggregate operating revenue losses of 11%. KPMG's report emphasizes the need for reforms, including a holistic approach to governance, redistribution of power, and more stringent cost-control mechanisms, to ensure the long-term sustainability of European football.

site_title: Singapore tightens travel rules following Melbourne case surge
summary: Singapore has tightened travel rules following a surge in COVID-19 cases in Melbourne, Australia's second-largest city. Travellers from Victoria will be required to serve a 7-day stay-home notice (SHN) and undergo a PCR test upon arrival. Short-term travellers with a history of visiting Victoria within the last 21 days will not be allowed to enter Singapore. The measures come after Melbourne was ordered into a 7-day lockdown due to a highly infectious variant of the virus.

site_title: KPMG managers back liquidating Envy group of companies: document
summary: Singaporean authorities should liquidate Envy Group of companies, accused of a $1.1-billion nickel trading scheme, due to insufficient assets to meet creditor claims. Interim judicial managers at KPMG report that funds were raised from nearly 1,000 investors, but no actual nickel trades were conducted. Documents were forged to convince investors, and returns likely came from investor funds. Ng Yu Zhi, a former managing director, faces multiple charges of cheating and fraud, with potential jail terms of up to 17 years if convicted.

images.alt_text: Ng Yu Zhi faces more than a dozen charges of cheating and fraud brought by prosecutors over the bogus nickel trading scheme.

site_title: The rise of data sharing and the 'intelligent edge'
summary: Singapore's Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) has emphasized the importance of data sharing and collaboration in driving innovation and revenue growth. As data generation and replication accelerate globally, with 64.2 Zettabytes created in 2020 alone, businesses must leverage frameworks and infrastructure to value and share data effectively. The "intelligent edge" concept, where data analysis is done near the source to reduce latency and costs, is becoming increasingly important. By combining disparate data sets and creating actionable insights, businesses can unlock new revenue drivers and differentiate themselves in a rapidly digitizing world.

site_title: Pandemic puts Malaysia's underemployment problem under the spotlight
summary: Malaysia's jobless rate reached a 27-year high in 2020, with 711,000 people underemployed due to structural issues in the economy. The tourism and agriculture sectors were most affected, with many jobs shed. Analysts warn that underemployment, defined as workers taking jobs below their qualifications or working fewer hours, could worsen, particularly among younger workers. Experts attribute the issue to the country's reliance on low-skilled foreign workers, lack of high-skilled jobs, and skills mismatch between workers and employers. To address the problem, Malaysia needs to rethink its economic model, recalibrate its wage structure, and invest in automation to create more high-skilled jobs.

site_title: UOB keeps finance tailored for women
summary: UOB, a Singaporean bank, continues to offer tailored financial products to women, including the Lady's Card, which was introduced three decades ago. The bank's strategy is to hyper-personalise its services to respond to the changing needs of its female customers, who make up half of Singapore's population. Data analytics shows that women tend to be less insured, save more, and invest more in sustainable funds than men. UOB has revamped its offerings to include insurance coverage, free health screenings, and lower medical consultation rates, with the Lady's Savings Account being a recent launch. The bank's approach aims to cater to women's diverse roles and spending habits, and its strategy is expected to reach one in three Singaporean women by 2024.

site_title: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit issues S$200m in perpetual securities at 4.2% per annum
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit issued S$200 million in perpetual securities at 4.20% per annum for financing potential investment opportunities and general working capital. The issuance was oversubscribed, and the proceeds will help reduce the Reit's aggregate leverage ratio to 31.3% from 35.4% as of March 31. The securities will bear an initial distribution rate of 4.20% for the first five years, with subsequent resets every five years. DBS and OCBC were the joint lead managers for the offering.

site_title: US Republicans unveil US$928b infrastructure counteroffer
summary: US Senate Republicans unveiled a new infrastructure offer worth $928 billion over eight years, significantly lower than President Joe Biden's $1.7 trillion proposal. The plan, led by Senator Shelley Moore Capito, includes $506 billion for roads and bridges and $98 billion for public transit. The White House has expressed willingness to negotiate, but wants a large package with expanded definition of infrastructure, while Republicans want to limit the scope and pay for it with unspent Covid-19 relief money. A bipartisan agreement remains elusive, with a deadline imposed by President Biden.

site_title: US: Dow rallies as jobless claims hit new pandemic low
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rallied 0.7% to 34,565.05, driven by gains in industrial equities such as Boeing, Caterpillar, and Honeywell International, as US jobless claims fell to a new pandemic low of 406,000. The S&P 500 gained 0.3%, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.2%. The jobless claims data marked the fourth consecutive week of decline, and orders of big-ticket US manufactured goods dropped 1.3% in April, the first decline in 11 months.

site_title: Orders for US business equipment rise most in eight months
summary: US orders for business equipment rose 2.3% in April, the largest increase in eight months, driven by robust capital investment and a broader economy reopening. Core capital goods orders, excluding aircraft and military hardware, rose 2.3%, while durable goods orders unexpectedly decreased 1.3%. The surge in business spending on equipment helped the economy grow at a 6.4% pace in the first quarter.

site_title: The pandemic and statistics that reflect it
summary: A recent article highlights the misuse of statistics in the Covid-19 pandemic, leading to downplaying of the crisis and millions of deaths. The article emphasizes that data should be used critically and not manipulated for political gain. It notes that companies are increasingly laying off employees, and the global economy is facing various challenges. The article also touches upon international relations, including US foreign policy under Donald Trump and China's competitiveness in the AI talent war.

site_title: Boeing to pay US$17m to settle FAA enforcement cases
summary: Boeing has agreed to pay at least $17 million to settle enforcement cases with the FAA over the installation of unapproved equipment on hundreds of 737 aircraft. The violations involved Head-up Guidance Systems and devices on the wing that didn't comply with federal standards. The settlement comes after intense scrutiny following two MAX crashes that killed 346 people. Boeing must also pay an additional $10.1 million if it doesn't improve its procedures, and has already paid $2.5 billion in penalties and compensation in a separate federal criminal charges case.

site_title: Rolls-Royce creates 'most refined picnic facility on Earth'
summary: Rolls-Royce has unveiled a bespoke convertible car called the "Boat Tail", which features a rear deck with cocktail tables, fridges for champagne, and a parasol matching the vehicle's baby blue color scheme. The car was hand-built over four years according to the client's specifications and is considered a masterpiece of art. The vehicle's price tag and buyer's identity remain unknown, but it marks the first project of Rolls-Royce's new "Coachbuild" division, which offers bespoke services to ultra-wealthy clients.

site_title: Ready, set, restructure: Singapore large caps clean house to woo investors
summary: Singapore's corporate stalwarts are undergoing restructuring efforts to stay relevant amid changing business dynamics, driven by trends such as clean energy, digitalization, and the appeal of the asset-light model. Companies like Sembcorp Industries, Singtel, and Keppel Corp are retooling and repackaging themselves to unlock value and attract investors. The trend is expected to continue, with analysts attributing it to the need to adapt to pandemic-led structural changes and capitalize on new opportunities.

images.alt_text: Conglomerates Keppel Corp and Sembcorp have trained their sights on green-energy and urban solutions since freeing themselves from the sickly rig building business.

site_title: Airbus sets ambitious goal to lift output above 2019 levels
summary: Airbus sets ambitious production goal to lift output above 2019 levels, aiming to reach 64 A320-series jets per month by Q2 2023, and 75 by 2025. The move comes as global aviation recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic, with vaccine rollout and airline confidence contributing to the optimism. Airbus shares jumped 5.3% following the announcement, while suppliers like Safran and Rolls-Royce rose. The plan aims to avoid delays and secure necessary capabilities for the industry, signaling a positive outlook for the global aviation market.

site_title: The pandemic-era audience has to work harder
summary: A recent staging of Chekhov's Three Sisters at the Singapore International Festival of Arts polarized the audience due to the unique production constraints. The American cast, unable to fly into Singapore, had their performances projected onto the backdrop while only one actress, Irina, appeared on stage. Co-directors Nelson Chia and Darron L West creatively reimagined the play to make the most of the limitations, leveraging the script's existential themes about the tragedy of living. The unconventional approach was praised for its artistry.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 16.08 points to 1,593.90, with 8.613 billion lots traded worth RM7.339 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 555 to 491, closing higher on Thursday.

site_title: Sanofi, GSK kick off Phase Three trial for Covid-19 shot
summary: Sanofi and GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) launched a Phase Three trial for a Covid-19 vaccine candidate, which combines tests for boosters and variants. The study, involving over 35,000 adults in the US, Asia, Africa, and Latin America, aims to get approved by the end of 2021. The trial follows positive interim results reported earlier this month, as the two drugmakers adapt to an evolving coronavirus.

site_title: EU, Japan throw support behind Olympics, with aid of vaccines from Europe
summary: The European Union and Japan have expressed support for Tokyo's hosting of the 2020 Olympic Games, citing EU-produced vaccines as a factor in Japan's efforts to combat a fourth wave of COVID-19. Despite Japan's slow vaccination rate, with only 5% of the population vaccinated, the EU and Japan reaffirmed their commitment to holding the Games in a safe and secure manner. This move comes as public opinion in Japan remains divided on hosting the event.

site_title: US pending home sales decline unexpectedly on lean inventory
summary: US pending home sales declined 4.4% in April to 106.2, the lowest reading since May last year, due to a lack of affordable properties. Elevated asking prices and limited inventory are making homes less affordable, despite a 53.5% increase in contract signings on existing properties. The National Association of Realtors expects supply to improve by this fall, but some experts, including JPMorgan's Jamie Dimon, warn of a housing bubble.

site_title: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala sells US$1.5b two-tranche bonds
summary: Abu Dhabi's Mubadala sold $1.5 billion in two-tranche bonds, including 10-year and 30-year Formosa bonds. The 10-year bonds offered an interest rate of 95 basis points over mid-swaps, while the 30-year bonds offered a 3.4% rate. This sale comes after Mubadala raised $1.1 billion in bonds less than three months ago, and follows a $2 billion bond sale by the Abu Dhabi government this week. The issuance is seen as a market return rather than a response to budgetary needs, which have been reduced due to rising oil prices.

site_title: Booming Danish housing market raises concerns over credit risks
summary: Denmark's central bank expresses concerns over the booming housing market, citing high mortgage debt levels and rapidly rising house prices. The country's homeowners are among the most indebted globally, and the central bank recommends tightening lending rules to limit vulnerability to a potential house price drop. The housing market has reached levels above those before the 2008 financial crisis, with prices expected to rise by over 11% this year. The government is awaiting recommendations from the Systemic Risk Council to limit continued risk build-up in the housing market.

site_title: US judge denies injunction to freeze funds of ex-EHT directors, may refer case to federal prosecutors
summary: A US bankruptcy judge has denied a preliminary injunction to freeze funds of former Eagle Hospitality Trust directors Howard Wu and Taylor Woods, allowing them to recover $2.4 million. The judge may refer the case to federal prosecutors for further investigation, according to sources. The move comes as part of Urban Commons Queensway's bankruptcy proceedings, which owns the iconic floating hotel The Queen Mary in Long Beach, California.

site_title: Sats swings into the black for Q4, but group still clocks net loss for full year
summary: Sats, a ground-handler and in-flight caterer, reported a net profit of S$800,000 in Q4, driven by revenue growth from non-travel related businesses. The group swung into a net loss of S$78.9 million for the full year, due to the impact of the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic on air travel demand. Sats aims to transform its aviation services businesses while expanding non-travel related businesses, and no final dividend was declared to preserve jobs and capabilities.

site_title: Muhyiddin faces renewed pressure as anger builds on Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faces renewed pressure to allow Parliament to reconvene amid rising public anger over the Covid-19 surge, with daily infections more than doubling since January's state of emergency declaration. Critics accuse the government of handling the pandemic poorly and enforcing virus rules inconsistently. Deputy Speaker Azalina Othman Said calls for public debate through Parliament to regain public trust, while opposition leaders welcome her proposal for an interim emergency government. The situation has strained resources of large hospitals and fueled public mistrust in the government.

images.alt_text: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin is facing renewed pressure to allow Parliament to reconvene, as his move to suspend democracy in January is failing to contain the Covid-19 outbreak amid rising public anger.

site_title: Edmund Tie appoints Desmond Sim as deputy CEO
summary: Edmund Tie & Company has appointed Desmond Sim as deputy CEO, effective June 1. Sim, with over 20 years of experience in the industry, will take over from Ong Choon Fah, who has been CEO since May 2015. Sim's expertise includes research, consulting, valuation, fund management, and business development. The company believes Sim's global exposure and market knowledge will drive the company's next phase of growth.

site_title: Thai princess allows new vaccine imports as slow rollout prompts anger
summary: Thailand's Princess Chulabhorn has approved the importation of alternative coronavirus vaccines by the Chulabhorn Royal Academy, bypassing the government amid a slow rollout and growing public anger. The move comes as Thailand struggles with its most severe Covid-19 outbreak yet, with over 920 deaths and less than 1 million people fully vaccinated. The decision allows the royal academy to supplement the government's vaccine campaign until domestic production can meet demand. The government is set to launch its mass immunization drive next month.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains on Thursday, STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.6% to 3,164.82, driven by a decline in receipts for Singapore's services industry easing to 1.5% year-over-year. Tech names and Jardine Matheson Holdings were among the top gainers. The global market's optimism on Covid-19 vaccine emergence is tempered by concerns about new strains and economy reopening hindrances.

site_title: UK details plan to scrap 15-year voting cap for expats
summary: The UK government plans to scrap a 15-year voting cap for expats, allowing them to vote in UK elections "for life." This change, part of forthcoming legislation, also introduces voter identification for the first time. Expats will need to show proof of their last UK address and can apply for an absentee ballot once every three years. The move aims to support a "truly global Britain" and give expats a greater voice in Parliament.

site_title: Sias raises privatisation idea for SIA; questions S$6.2b MC bond issue
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) is being questioned by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) about its intentions for privatisation and the recent issuance of $6.2 billion mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs). The investor watchdog has asked SIA about the factors leading to the MCB issuance, how the funds will be used, and whether the airline group needs further fund-raising. SIA shares were trading higher after the market closed, with some shareholders expressing uncertainty about the airline's intentions.

images.alt_text: Sias has written a letter to SIA, posing a string of questions triggered by the airline's recent announcement of the issuance of mandatory convertible bonds to raise a further S$6.2 billion.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.18% to 29,113.20, amid profit-taking after a strong previous day. The Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.43% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.79%. The decline was seen as traders waiting for US data later in the day.

site_title: Indonesian state utility to retire coal power plants gradually
summary: Indonesia's state utility, Perusahaan Listrik Negara (PLN), plans to retire its coal-fired power plants gradually, aiming to achieve carbon neutrality by 2060. The first phase will close three power plants by 2030, followed by the retirement of conventional power plants by 2035 and "supercritical" coal-based power plants by 2040. The final phase will see the closure of "ultra supercritical" coal power plants by 2056, marking the country's transition towards a greener energy mix, with over 400 gigawatts of renewable energy potential.

images.alt_text: Top thermal coal exporter Indonesia is planning to retire its coal-fired power plants gradually, in a phased move towards becoming carbon neutral.

site_title: 14 new Covid-19 community cases and one in workers' dorm in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 24 new COVID-19 cases, bringing the total to 61,940. 14 cases are community cases, with 3 unlinked, while 12 linked cases have been quarantined. 9 imported cases have been isolated or placed on Stay-Home Notice, with 7 being returning Singaporeans or permanent residents.

site_title: India scraps local trials for Covid-19 shots as it battles second wave
summary: India has scrapped local trials for "well-established" foreign Covid-19 vaccines to accelerate the vaccination rollout amid the country's second wave. The decision comes as India records its highest Covid-19 death toll since the pandemic began, with only 3% of its 1.3 billion population fully vaccinated. This move aims to counter the surge in infections, which accounts for over a third of the global total.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore companies made headlines today. Esco Lifesciences secured a US$200m Series A round, valuing the company at over US$800m, ahead of its Hong Kong IPO. Singapore services industries reported a Q1 revenue decline of -1.5%, while Sias raised questions about SIA's MC bond issue. BYD's stock surge led to the permanent suspension of SocGen's DLCs. CapitaLand acquired a stake in DLSP-Ascendas Co for 501m yuan, and Singtel posted a 93% lower H2 net profit. The STI rose 0.6% to finish the day at 3,164.82.

site_title: Singapore's Covid-19 testing labs operating at over 80% capacity amid surge
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 testing labs are operating at over 80% capacity amid a surge in testing demand. As of May 25, 27 labs can conduct up to 70,000 tests daily. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has ramped up lab capacity from 2,900 tests per day in early-April 2020 to 60,000-70,000 tests daily since January 2021. While some tests may take longer due to capacity constraints, MOH has implemented measures to prioritize result turnaround times for those testing positive or with symptoms.

images.alt_text: There are 27 testing laboratories that conduct Covid-19 tests in Singapore as of May 25, 2021.

site_title: Europe: Shares hover below record highs, HSBC edges lower
summary: European shares opened flat on Thursday, hovering just below a record high of 447.15 points. Energy stocks fell 0.3% due to declining oil prices, while mining stocks rose 0.8% on better metal prices. HSBC fell 0.2% after exiting US retail banking, and Puma dropped 1.1% after Kering announced a stake sale. The Stoxx 600 index remained almost unchanged at 445.34 points.

site_title: AirAsia Q1 loss narrows, weighed by asset depreciation
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia Group reported a 4.5% narrower net loss of RM767.4 million in its first quarter, primarily due to depreciation in leased assets and interest on lease liabilities. Revenue plummeted 87% to RM298.2 million, and passengers carried dropped 90% to 976,968. Despite this, the airline focused on domestic operations and expects improved stability as vaccinations continue and travel bubbles may be introduced. AirAsia has raised RM336.5 million through private placements and aims to secure RM1 billion in loans pending regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: A first-quarter net loss at Malaysian flagship budget airline AirAsia Group narrowed 4.5 per cent, primarily dragged down by depreciation in leased assets and interest on lease liabilities, a stock exchange filing on Thursday showed.

site_title: SoftBank shifts to foreign banks as borrowing soars
summary: SoftBank Group's bank borrowing rose 42% to 4.98 trillion yen (S$60.38 billion) in the last business year, with foreign lenders such as Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase & Co contributing significantly. Japanese lender Mizuho Financial Group is the only remaining top three backer. The increase comes as SoftBank expands its technology investing operations globally, with a recently completed share buyback driving its stock price recovery.

site_title: KPMG managers back liquidating Envy group of companies: document
summary: KPMG interim judicial managers recommend liquidating Envy Group of companies due to insufficient assets to meet creditor claims. The firms, accused of a $1.1 billion bogus nickel trading scheme, raised $1.5 billion from 1,000 investors, with $731 million withdrawn. Funds were allegedly used for personal transactions, not nickel trades. Documents were forged to convince investors of the scheme's existence. Ng Yu Zhi, a former managing director, faces multiple charges of cheating and fraud. The companies have not been charged, but liquidation is recommended to recover assets.

site_title: Taiwan says request to drop word 'country' preceded BioNTech vaccine deal collapse
summary: Taiwan's health minister said the collapse of a BioNTech vaccine deal was due to the German company's request to remove the word "country" from the announcement, which China objects to as implying Taiwan is a separate nation. Taiwan had signed and sent back a "final contract" after months of negotiations, but BioNTech delayed the completion of the deal citing a "revaluation of global vaccine supply and adjusted timelines". The deal's collapse has heightened tensions between Taiwan and China, with Taiwan's president accusing China of blocking the deal.

site_title: Australia: Shares close higher on mining boost
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% higher at 7,109.70, driven by gains in mining and tech stocks. Despite Chinese iron ore futures slumping, miners like Rio Tinto and BHP Group rose 3.8% and 1.2%, respectively. Tech stocks advanced 1.6%, led by Xero's 1.7% gain. Gold stocks fell 1.2% after bullion prices declined. Investors remain cautious ahead of US inflation data due Friday, which could revive concerns of early Fed tapering.

site_title: IFC and Mitsui invest US$60m in MiCare HealthTec Holdings
summary: International Finance Corporation (IFC) and Mitsui & Co (Asia Pacific) have invested US$60 million in MiCare HealthTec Holdings, a healthcare administration company in South-east Asia. MiCare will use the investment to expand into key markets, including Indonesia and Vietnam, and set up a new regional headquarters in Singapore. The company aims to improve healthcare affordability and outcomes for patients by enhancing its digital capabilities and introducing innovative solutions. IFC's investment marks its first in the managed-care organisations sector, with the goal of supporting insurers and providers with technological tools for efficient healthcare delivery.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slip; retail, institutional investors guard foreign sell-off
summary: South Korean shares closed marginally lower on Thursday, down 0.08% at 3,165.84, due to foreign investors' sell-off and concerns about central banks winding back emergency stimulus. Key stocks fell, including LG Chem (-3.49%), Samsung Electronics (-0.25%), and Hyundai Motor (-1.34%). The won ended 0.11% lower at 1,118.1 per dollar. Despite this, institutional investors guarded declines, and the central bank upgraded its economic outlook, signaling a potential shift towards tightening interest rates.

site_title: France, Germany push for 'historic agreement' on global corporate tax rate
summary: France and Germany pushed for a "historic" agreement on a global corporate tax rate, aiming to achieve a 15% minimum tax rate for multinational corporations. The proposal, spearheaded by US President Joe Biden, has faced opposition from European countries, including Ireland's finance minister who expressed significant reservations. French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire emphasized the need to seize opportunities and act now to secure support for the plan.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on profit-taking
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on profit-taking, snapping a five-day winning streak, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.33% to 28,549.01 and the Topix index falling 0.50% to 1,911.02. The market was weighed down by profit-taking after modest Wall Street rallies, with investors cautious about recovery in major economies.

site_title: Singapore services industries see revenue decline ease in Q1 to -1.5%
summary: Singapore's services industries saw a 1.5% year-on-year decline in revenue in Q1, easing from a revised 7.6% decline in Q4. The information and communications industry was a standout, with a 21% year-on-year increase, driven by game publishers and online marketplaces. The administrative and support services industry suffered the most, with a 19.9% year-on-year decline, due to weaker demand for rental and leasing services. The education sector, however, saw a 7.5% growth in takings.

site_title: Airbus sets higher jet output targets as recovery looms
summary: Airbus sets ambitious production targets for its jetliners, aiming to increase A320neo output to 45 aircraft per month by year-end and 64 per month by Q2 2023. The company also plans to boost A350 production to six aircraft per month by autumn 2022 and A220 production to six per month in early 2022, with a goal of 14 per month by the middle of the decade. The wide-bodied A330 family will remain at a production rate of two aircraft per month. These targets come as the aviation industry recovers from the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: 'Patriots rule Hong Kong' as sweeping pro-Beijing electoral rules passed
summary: Hong Kong's legislature has approved sweeping pro-Beijing electoral rules, reducing the proportion of seats filled by direct elections from half to less than a quarter. The changes, announced by China in March, aim to vet candidates and bar those deemed insufficiently patriotic towards China from standing. The measures were passed with 40 votes in favor and two against, further consolidating Beijing's authority over the autonomous city. The changes will increase the legislature's size to 90 seats and reduce direct election seats to 20, with the new vetting committee empowered to disqualify candidates deemed loyal to Beijing.

site_title: Boustead Singapore H2 net profit more than quadruples, proposes special dividend
summary: Boustead Singapore's second-half net profit more than quadrupled to S$91.3 million, driven by the successful launch of the Boustead Industrial Fund (BIF). The real estate division divested 14 leasehold properties, unlocking value and increasing earnings per share to 18.8 cents. This is a significant improvement from the preceding year's 3.8 cents. The company proposes a special dividend, indicating a strong financial performance.

site_title: Muhyiddin under pressure as anger builds on Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin faces growing pressure to allow Parliament to reconvene as the country grapples with a worsening Covid-19 pandemic. The government's decision to suspend Parliament has sparked widespread public anger and mistrust, with daily infections more than doubling since January. Critics argue that the move has crippled democracy and the government's ability to respond to concerns. Deputy Speaker Azalina Othman Said calls for a public debate through Parliament to address the crisis, while opposition leaders welcome her suggestions for an interim emergency government.

site_title: Lenovo's Q4 profit growth of 512% beats estimates
summary: Lenovo's Q4 profit surged 512% to $260 million, beating estimates. Revenue rose 48% to $15.63 billion, driven by pandemic-fueled demand for laptops and personal gadgets. The company strengthened its PC market lead, with a quarter share, ahead of HP and Dell. Worldwide PC shipments rose nearly a third in the March quarter, the fastest year-over-year growth since Gartner began tracking the market.

site_title: Aviva sees steady Q1, cash for shareholders on track
summary: Aviva reported steady Q1 sales, with life insurance premiums at £8.3 billion and a 4% rise in general insurance net written premiums to £2 billion. The company reiterated its plan to return capital to shareholders, with a "substantial" return expected in 2022. The combined operating ratio for general insurance strengthened to 90.6%, driven by relatively benign weather. JPMorgan analysts described the update as "strong," maintaining their "overweight" rating on the stock. Aviva has sold £7.5 billion worth of businesses in the past year to focus on key markets.

images.alt_text: British insurer Aviva recorded steady sales performance in its life insurance business and a 4 per cent rise in general insurance on Thursday as it repeated its promise to give cash back to shareholders.

site_title: SocGen permanently suspends DLCs of BYD Electronic after airbag trigger
summary: Societe Generale (SocGen) permanently suspended trading of BYD Electronic's 5x Short daily leveraged certificates (DLCs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) after the stock rose 15% and triggered the airbag mechanism, resulting in a 100% loss of value. The DLCs were listed on Dec 21, 2020, and were designated as a complex investment product. The suspension took effect at 9am on Thursday, May 27, 2021, and may prevent SocGen from providing quotations if the DLCs remain valueless.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to close Indonesian onshore equities business
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to close its Indonesian onshore institutional equities trading business, citing a desire to focus on global clients through local brokerage partners. The move will result in approximately 10 job losses. The firm remains committed to Indonesia and will continue to provide access to the equity market.

site_title: HSBC to exit loss-making US retail banking as part of Asia pivot
summary: HSBC is exiting its loss-making US retail banking business, selling parts and winding down others, as part of its Asia pivot. The bank will retain a small presence to serve international affluent clients. This move follows efforts to shrink its presence in European and North American markets where it faces competition from larger domestic players. HSBC aims to focus on its largest market, Asia, where it has struggled in the past.

site_title: Apec economic recovery hampered by Covid-19 vaccine availability: report
summary: A report by the Apec Regional Trends Analysis found that the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation countries' economic recovery is hindered by varying Covid-19 vaccine availability across member economies. Lower-income economies face significant challenges due to limited access to vaccines. Despite effective pandemic management policies, the region's economic growth is expected to be 6.3% in 2021. However, uncertainties remain due to evolving pandemic conditions, job losses, and inflation concerns, which may impact consumer spending and economic recovery.

site_title: Australia's Q1 business investment booms in boost to economy
summary: Australian business investment surged 6.3% in Q1, exceeding market forecasts, driven by tax breaks and spending on plant and machinery. Investment in buildings rose 3.8%, while firms planned to invest A$113.6 billion in the next fiscal year. This boost suggests economic growth could exceed forecasts, providing a positive outlook for the Australian economy.

site_title: URA, HDB release Jalan Tembusu, Tampines Street 62 residential sites for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) and Housing & Development Board (HDB) released two residential land parcels in Singapore, Jalan Tembusu and Tampines Street 62, for sale. The sites, with a 99-year lease, can yield approximately 1,340 residential units. The Jalan Tembusu site is expected to yield 640 units, while the Tampines Street 62 site is expected to yield 700 EC units. Analysts project top bids of around S$1,100 to S$1,500 psf ppr for the Jalan Tembusu site and S$550 to S$620 psf ppr for the Tampines Street 62 site, with 10-15 bidders expected for the Jalan Tembusu site.

site_title: Women can add US$280b to e-commerce in South-east Asia: report
summary: A report by the International Finance Corporation (IFC) predicts that South-east Asia's e-commerce market could grow by over US$280 billion between 2025 and 2030 if women's sales are brought to parity with men's. Currently, women comprise half of active e-commerce vendors but tend to run smaller businesses. The report highlights the pandemic's impact on women's sales, which have been more severely affected, and suggests that platforms can support female entrepreneurs by providing better training and financial support.

site_title: Aztech Global says MCO to reduce Malaysia production for two weeks by 30%
summary: Aztech Global, a technology unit of Aztech Group, estimates a 30% reduction in production output in Malaysia for two weeks due to the latest movement control order (MCO). The MCO requires 40% of the workforce to work from home, affecting the company's 20% Malaysian plant output. Operations in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Shenzhen remain unaffected. The company expects minimal impact on overall production output and will continue to monitor Covid-19 developments.

site_title: Q1 Apac fintech funding data signals improving appetite for digital lending: S&P
summary: S&P Global Market Intelligence reported that digital lending in the Asia-Pacific region saw a significant increase in the first quarter of 2021, with US$548 million in funding across 38 transactions. This represents more than half of the total funding raised by the sector in 2020. South-east Asia led the region, accounting for 44% of total Apac fintech funding, with ride-hailing firms like Grab and Gojek receiving significant investments. The report suggests that investor appetite for digital lending is returning, driven by the growth of digital financial services post-pandemic.

site_title: Millions in Melbourne ordered into snap Covid lockdown
summary: Millions in Melbourne, Australia were ordered into a 7-day snap lockdown due to a highly infectious Covid-19 variant. The lockdown affects over 5 million people and is the city's fourth since the pandemic began. Officials blame a sluggish vaccine rollout and hotel quarantine failures for the outbreak. Acting state Premier James Merlino said the lockdown aims to contain the spread of the virus and that more people being vaccinated could have prevented the situation.

site_title: Johnson faces challenge to authority after Cummings salvo
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces a major challenge to his authority after former chief adviser Dominic Cummings declared him unfit to lead the country due to his poor pandemic leadership, which Cummings claims led to thousands of unnecessary deaths. Cummings's testimony in Parliament detailed the government's "disastrous" pandemic failures and criticized Johnson's leadership, saying he made "very bad misjudgments" and is "overly obsessed" with media coverage. The attack on Johnson's authority threatens to damage his standing among Tory members of Parliament and his ability to stay in power.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is battling a major attack on his authority after the controversial strategist who masterminded his rise to power declared he is unfit to hold the job.

site_title: Singaporeans, PRs from higher-risk countries must test negative before returning
summary: Singapore will require Singaporeans and permanent residents (PRs) from higher-risk countries to test negative for Covid-19 before returning, effective May 28. Travelers must present a valid negative PCR test taken within 72 hours and undergo a 21-day stay-home notice (SHN) upon arrival. Those who fail to comply may have their permit or pass canceled. Exemptions apply to those who stayed in lower-risk countries for 21 days before departure. The measure aims to minimize the burden on Singapore's healthcare system as it confronts new and more infectious variants of Covid-19.

site_title: Air freight market becomes a bright spot for Boeing in China
summary: Boeing is optimistic about the Chinese air freight market, citing a boom in e-commerce demand and a need for 750 new freighters over the next 20 years. Despite struggling with passenger plane sales due to trade tensions and the 737 MAX grounding, Boeing's freighter market dominance makes it harder for rivals to bypass. The company forecasts strong air freight rates, which are expected to stay robust for a while, driven by reduced capacity and high demand.

site_title: Quick takes: Listed firms seek to unlock value amid disruption
summary: Publicly-listed entities in Singapore are re-examining business strategies amid the ongoing COVID-19 economic impacts. Several firms, including Singtel, have announced strategic resets to unlock value. Singtel aims to maximize proceeds from the sale of its infrastructure assets, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss, and London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Amid these developments, companies are exploring new opportunities to create value for shareholders and navigate the ongoing economic disruption.

site_title: Biden's Asia czar says era of engagement with Xi's China is over
summary: The US is shifting its approach to China, entering a period of intense competition as China becomes increasingly controlled by President Xi Jinping, according to US Asia czar Kurt Campbell. The era of engagement with China is over, and a new set of strategic parameters will operate under a "dominant paradigm of competition." Campbell cited China's military clashes, economic campaign, and "wolf warrior" diplomacy as reasons for the shift, and emphasized the need for the US to work with allies and partners to counter China's growing assertiveness.

site_title: Top China, US trade officials hold 'candid' first talks
summary: US and China trade officials held "candid, pragmatic" talks, their first under the Biden era, amid scrutiny over whether China is meeting its end of a trade pact. The "phase 1" agreement, signed in 2020, requires China to increase US product purchases by $200 billion. US Trade Negotiator Katherine Tai has raised concerns that China is falling short on its agreement, with some experts estimating a 40% shortfall. The talks aim to check in every six months on the pact's progress.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, edging down 0.57% or 167.62 points to 28,998.39. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, easing 0.21% and 0.68 points respectively. The losses followed a healthy two-day rally, as profit-takers moved in.

site_title: Japan reassures Olympics can be safe as extended state of emergency eyed
summary: Japan is preparing to extend a state of emergency across much of the nation, including host city Tokyo, in an effort to control the fourth wave of the coronavirus pandemic. Despite concerns over the safety of the 2020 Olympics, which are set to open on July 23, the government has pledged to keep in close contact with stakeholders at home and abroad to ensure a safe and secure Games. Japan's vaccination rate is low, with just over 5% of the population vaccinated, and public opinion polls show a majority opposed to holding the Games this summer.

site_title: Shares of Jimmy Lai's Next Digital soar as trading resumes
summary: Shares of Next Digital Ltd, a media publisher controlled by jailed tycoon Jimmy Lai, surged 141.9% on its first day of trading after a week-long suspension, reaching a high of HK$0.80. The company stated it had sufficient working capital for at least 18 months without additional funding from Lai. Lai faces charges under China's national security law and is prohibited from dealing in assets, including shares in the listed company. The stock's volatility is attributed to retail investors' support for Lai and his pro-democracy publications.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.46 points, or 0.35%, to 1,583.28 on Thursday, with gains beating losses 302 to 218. Volume was 638.39 million lots worth RM308.02 million.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain as US inflation fears abate; miners jump
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,103.5, driven by gains in local miners and energy stocks following a higher Wall Street close, despite concerns over US inflation. Iron ore miner Champion Iron jumped 6.2% and BHP Group firmed 0.8%. Energy stocks rose 0.4%, while gold stocks fell 1.2%. In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark index fell 1.4%. The gains followed comments from Federal Reserve officials that helped tame inflation concerns.

site_title: Taiwan hurtles towards 'super-aged' status as birthrate plummets
summary: Taiwan's birthrate has plummeted, with the average woman now giving birth to less than one child, a trend also seen in Japan, South Korea, and Hong Kong. The island recorded more deaths than births last year, marking the first time its population contracted. The decline is attributed to increasing choice among younger people, especially women, to delay marriage and childbearing, as well as economic constraints. Authorities have introduced incentives, but activists argue that gender inequality remains unresolved, making it a rational choice for many women to remain childless, potentially leading to a "super-aged" society by 2025.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.31% and the Topix index down 0.22%. Investors are cautious due to modest Wall Street rallies and concerns about recovery in major economies.

site_title: Gold eases off 4-1/2-month peak as US dollar, yields rebound
summary: Gold prices eased 0.2% to $1,892.42 per ounce after reaching a 4-1/2-month high of $1,912.50 due to an uptick in the US dollar and bond yields. Investors awaited key US economic readings. US gold futures declined 0.4% to $1,894 per ounce. The decline was attributed to the rebound of the US dollar and yields, which had previously supported gold prices.

site_title: Sembcorp to turn portfolio 'from brown to green' in new strategic plan
summary: Sembcorp Industries unveiled a new strategic plan to transform its portfolio from "brown" to "green", aiming to increase sustainable solutions' profit contribution from 40% to 70% by 2025. The company targets a 30% compounded annual growth rate for its renewable energy portfolio and 10% for its integrated urban solutions portfolio, driven by its renewables and urban solutions business. This shift is expected to drive growth and contribute to the company's sustainable development.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Quarles sketches out potential components of crypto review
summary: US Federal Reserve Vice Chair Randal Quarles discussed the need for regulators to monitor the rapidly changing cryptocurrency landscape. Stablecoins, pegged to traditional currencies, have expanded the use of cryptocurrencies. Fed officials are working to develop a framework for monitoring digital currencies, including the potential development of a digital dollar. Quarles mentioned financial risks associated with private stablecoins and the need for supervisory guidance on handling crypto assets. This comes as the Fed considers releasing a discussion paper on the pros and cons of a US digital currency.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund head's pay fell 42% last year
summary: SoftBank Vision Fund head Rajeev Misra's total remuneration fell 42% to 931 million yen (S$11.3 million) in the past business year. COO Marcelo Claure's remuneration dropped 15% to 1.8 billion yen, including relocation costs. Chip designer Arm's CEO Simon Segars received the highest remuneration of 1.9 billion yen. These figures were reported in a SoftBank Group Corp filing.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at Thursday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) losing 9.7 points to 3,136.39, despite a modest rally on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers 88 to 47, with QT Vascular and Ntegrator International seeing brisk trading. Singtel announced a strategic reset, while local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB were mixed. This follows Wall Street's modest gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 closing flat, and European stocks also ending flat.

site_title: Uber agrees world-first union deal for UK drivers
summary: Uber has agreed on a world-first union deal with the GMB union in the UK, representing 70,000 drivers. The collective bargaining agreement grants workers' rights, including a minimum wage and paid leave, following a Supreme Court ruling. The deal marks a shift in Uber's business model, as the company had previously argued its drivers were self-employed freelancers. The agreement is seen as a precedent for the industry, with the GMB union calling for other operators to follow suit, and Uber supporting drivers in signing up as members.

images.alt_text: US ride-hailing giant Uber announced on Wednesday a "historic" pact with a British trade union to represent its 70,000 drivers in the UK, after a court ruling granted them workers' rights.

site_title: ExxonMobil, Chevron investors vote for more action on climate change
summary: US oil giants ExxonMobil and Chevron saw investors reject their responses to climate change, installing activist board members at ExxonMobil and directing Chevron to deepen emissions cuts. ExxonMobil's Engine No. 1 won enough votes to secure board seats, while Chevron approved a proposal to reduce "scope 3" emissions. The decisions mark a shift in mainstream investors' stance on climate change, with Environmental Defence Fund's president Fred Krupp calling it a "financial imperative."

site_title: Singtel to unlock value of infrastructure assets, posts 93% lower H2 net profit
summary: Singtel has announced a strategic reset, including unlocking the value of its infrastructure assets, such as towers, satellites, and data centers, to bridge the valuation gap between individual assets and the integrated telco assets. The company aims to monetize non-core assets, with estimates suggesting they could be worth S$5-6 billion. Singtel also plans to leverage its 5G leadership to reinvigorate its core consumer and enterprise businesses, and develop new growth engines in ICT and digital services. The company reported a 92.7% decline in H2 net profit, with Ebitda falling 12% and group revenue declining 1%.

site_title: Total, Chevron suspend payments to Myanmar junta from gas project
summary: French oil and gas company Total and US energy company Chevron have suspended payments to Myanmar's junta from a gas project, earning praise from pro-democracy activists. The decision follows pressure from rights groups and Myanmar's parallel civilian government to review operations. Total, which holds 31.24% of the Moattama Gas Transportation Company, and Chevron, with 28%, suspended cash distributions to the junta. The move condemns violence and human rights abuses in Myanmar, with both companies stating they will comply with international authorities and sanctions.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as rally stalls, inflation casts shadow
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday, with investors taking a breather after a recent rally. Concerns about inflation and its potential impact on monetary policy continue to cast a shadow, despite optimism about the global recovery. Central banks in several countries, including New Zealand and Canada, are signaling they may start tapering their bond-buying programs or interest rates next year. Investors remain cautious, with strategist Craig W. Johnson warning that the window of confidence could close without supporting evidence.

site_title: Cybersecurity firm Ensign InfoSecurity sets its sights on regional market for growth
summary: Ensign InfoSecurity, a joint venture between StarHub and Temasek Holdings, aims to expand in the regional market for managed security services. CEO Tammie Tham expects double-digit revenue growth driven by surging industry demand. The cybersecurity firm plans to capitalize on the growing need for managed security services in the region, positioning itself for continued growth.

site_title: GIC backs Esco Lifesciences in oversubscribed US$200m Series A round
summary: Esco Lifesciences, a Singapore-based life sciences tools company, has raised US$200 million in an oversubscribed Series A round led by Vivo Capital and Novo Holdings. Singapore's GIC also participated in the round, valuing the company at over US$800 million. The funds will be used to expand in China and acquire western technologies to bring to the Asian market. The company plans to create an innovation hub in Boston and increase its R&D efforts. Esco Lifesciences is preparing to go public in Hong Kong and is expected to become a global leader in innovative technologies, tools, and equipment in the life sciences and pharmaceutical industries.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, CapitaLand, Sembcorp, Bukit Sembawang
summary: Singtel and CapitaLand saw new developments on Thursday. Singtel commenced a strategic review, including unlocking its infrastructure asset portfolio, following a 12% drop in H2 FY2021 earnings. CapitaLand acquired a 50% stake in DLSP-Ascendas Co, a Chinese IT park, for S$103.9 million. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positive sentiment despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Why we must learn to trust our 'cobots'
summary: Asia is poised to become a manufacturing hub with the rise of "cobots" or collaborative robots, crucial for Industry 4.0 technologies. Thailand and Singapore are leading the way, with Thailand having the highest number of industrial robots in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) in 2019. Cobots will increase collaboration between humans and automation, driving productivity, quality, and safety. Experts agree that automation can breathe new life into traditional workflows, empowering people. By 2030, the optimised production processes of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) could add trillions to the global economy.

images.alt_text: SCHNEIDER Batam Factory workers trained to operate digital tools that automate SE factory
SCHNEIDER Automated Guided Vehicle in action at SE SMart Factory Batam

site_title: Ditched Olympics could wipe out most of Japan's growth this year
summary: Japan's economy may suffer a 1.7% growth hit if the Tokyo Olympics are cancelled, according to economists. The games' postponement would exacerbate the country's ongoing virus emergency, which has led to a slow vaccine rollout and high infection numbers. A cancellation would cause a direct economic loss of about 1.4 trillion yen and knock back growth this year. Analysts warn that a second straight quarterly contraction is now more likely, with economists divided on whether the Olympics should proceed despite public opposition and concerns about the medical system's capacity.

site_title: German researchers tie cold viruses used to deliver Covid-19 vaccine to rare blood clot risk
summary: German researchers have linked rare blood clotting events among Covid-19 vaccine recipients to adenovirus vectors used in AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson vaccines. The researchers suggest that these vectors can send payload into cell nuclei, causing misreading of instructions and potentially triggering blood clot disorders. The findings are not yet reviewed by experts and contradict mRNA-based vaccines, which deliver genetic material only to cell fluids. The study proposes modifying adenovirus sequences to increase safety, but vaccine makers have yet to comment on the findings.

site_title: 'Very Hungry Caterpillar' author Eric Carle dies aged 91
summary: Eric Carle, author and illustrator of 'The Very Hungry Caterpillar', has died at the age of 91. The beloved children's classic, first published in 1969, has sold over 50 million copies worldwide. Carle attributed the book's enduring popularity to its message of hope, saying "children need hope" and that the caterpillar's transformation into a butterfly represents the possibility of growth and talent. Tributes poured in on social media, including from actress Mia Farrow, with many praising Carle's timeless and educational works.

images.alt_text: Eric Carle, author and illustrator of the beloved children's classic The Very Hungry Caterpillar has died aged 91, according to a statement from his official Instagram account on Wednesday.

site_title: UK car output rebounds after last year's lockdown low
summary: UK car output rebounded 34,573% in April, reaching 68,306 cars, compared to 197 in the same month last year due to lockdowns. Factories have operated with Covid-safe measures, despite semiconductor shortages. SMMT chief executive Mike Hawes emphasized the need for strong domestic demand and export-led growth to drive a recovery. Output remains slightly below April 2019 levels.

site_title: Amazon's Washington critics set to pounce on MGM deal
summary: Amazon's planned $8.45 billion acquisition of MGM, the owner of the James Bond franchise and other notable films, has sparked concerns among US lawmakers, with some calling for an investigation into the deal's potential impact on competition. Despite experts citing limited antitrust concerns, Senators Josh Hawley and Amy Klobuchar have expressed skepticism, with Hawley labeling Amazon a "monopoly platform." Amazon has faced criticism in the past for its market power and alleged anti-competitive practices, and the deal's approval is likely to be closely watched by antitrust regulators.

site_title: Gulf 2021 deficits to plunge to US$80b on higher oil prices
summary: Gulf Cooperation Council countries' budget deficits are expected to drop to US$80 billion in 2021 due to higher oil prices, fiscal consolidation, and economic recovery from coronavirus measures. This represents a sharp decline from the US$143 billion in 2020. The improvement is attributed to the easing of coronavirus measures and higher oil prices, which is expected to support economic output.

site_title: CapitaLand acquires remaining equity interest in DLSP-Ascendas Co for 501m yuan
summary: CapitaLand acquired the remaining 50% stake in DLSP-Ascendas Co for 501m yuan, becoming a wholly-owned subsidiary. The acquisition, made through its Singapore subsidiary Ascendas (China), aims to obtain full control of Dalian Ascendas IT Park in China. The deal has no expected impact on CapitaLand's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2021. The acquisition price reflects the adjusted net asset value as of March 31, 2021, with a call option granted to the joint-venture partner for repurchase six months after the conditional equity transfer agreement.

images.alt_text: Capitaland said on Thursday that it acquired the remaining 50 per cent stake in DLSP-Ascendas Co, which owns Dalian Ascendas IT Park (pictured) in China, making it a wholly-owned subsidiary.

site_title: South Korea's central bank holds rates, raises growth and inflation outlook
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, held interest rates steady at a historic low of 0.50% despite upgraded economic outlooks. The bank now expects the country's economy to grow at 4.0% this year, the fastest since 2010, and inflation to rise to 1.8%. The decision shifts focus from monetary policy to growth prospects, as exports and inflation have picked up. Analysts had expected the rate hike, with 26 predicting the move in a Reuters poll.

site_title: Top Federal Reserve official downplays inflation, warns against acting early
summary: Top Federal Reserve official Randal Quarles downplayed the threat of persistent inflation, warning that prematurely acting could derail the US economy's recovery. He expressed optimism about the country's growth prospects, citing consumer savings that will boost spending. Quarles stated that most inflation factors are temporary and that the Fed will remain patient until unemployment falls and inflation stays above 2.0%. He also acknowledged that some factors driving up prices are not temporary, but the central bank is prepared to address them if necessary.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat as banks falls offset travel and leisure gains
summary: European stocks ended flat on Wednesday, led by bank shares, despite travel and leisure gains. The Stoxx 600 index remained unchanged as central bank policymakers pledged to keep monetary policy loose. This decision offset earlier gains, which were fueled by US Federal Reserve officials' reaffirmation of a dovish stance.

site_title: Singapore's corporate bond issuance stays robust amid low interest rates
summary: Singapore-listed companies issued S$19.35 billion in corporate bonds in 2020, a 63.7% increase from the previous year. Despite rising inflation and bond yields, demand for corporate debt is expected to remain strong, driven by ultra-low interest rates and companies' efforts to tap lower funding rates and refinance maturing debt. Experts predict that sectors such as technology, consumer staples, and industrials will lead the way in debt issuance.

site_title: A new crop in Pennsylvania: warehouses
summary: A new warehouse crop is sprouting in Pennsylvania, with many warehouses being built at an alarming rate, causing local concerns about the area's long-term economic stability. David Jaindl, a third-generation farmer, worries about the impact on his business and the local community. The rapid construction of warehouses is a stark contrast to his family's traditional farming practices, which have sold turkeys to Whole Foods and the White House. As the logistics industry continues to grow, the effects on the local economy and residents are yet to be fully understood.

site_title: Oil gains as demand optimism offsets fears of supply glut
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday as demand optimism outweighed concerns about a potential supply glut. Brent crude oil futures for July rose 44 cents to $69.09 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude for July rose 28 cents to $66.35 a barrel. The increase was driven by improved US fuel demand estimates and a decrease in weekly inventory levels, offsetting fears of increased Iranian oil supplies.

site_title: Oil settles higher on stronger demand outlook as US inventories fall
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday as US crude stockpiles fell, boosting demand expectations ahead of the summer driving season. Brent crude settled at $68.87 a barrel, up 16 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $66.21 a barrel, up 14 cents. The drop in US inventories and refiners' increased utilization rates supported the price increase, despite concerns over a possible return of Iranian supply.

site_title: Workers worldwide return to weirder offices
summary: Workers worldwide are returning to offices, with firms transforming workspaces to prioritize Covid safety and employee comfort. Offices now feature movable walls, touchless lifts, and improved air quality. To address retention concerns, companies are offering perks like live music and flexible workspaces. The co-working industry is also capitalizing on the demand for flexibility, with WeWork integrating hologram technology and Deloitte moving its entire office to a larger space.

site_title: NZ central bank signals rate hike in 2022 as growth returns
summary: New Zealand's central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged but signaled a rate hike by September 2022, projecting a 1.5% official cash rate by 2023. The decision sent the local currency to a three-month high. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand cited recent positive economic data, including a strong domestic economy and commodity prices, as reasons for the potential rate hike. The bank's decision also affected the New Zealand dollar, which jumped 1% to a three-month high of US$0.7308.

site_title: US: Wall Street closes on Wednesday with modest gains
summary: US stocks closed with modest gains on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average ending flat at 34,323.05 and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes rising 0.2% and 0.6%, respectively. Positive corporate news, including Amazon's $8.45 billion acquisition of MGM studios and retailers reporting earnings surges, countered concerns over global recovery and US inflation. Federal Reserve Vice Chair Randal Quarles reassured investors that current price spikes are unlikely to last, and investors are becoming convinced the Fed will take steps to keep inflation under wraps.

site_title: Stop selling commodities-linked products to retail buyers, China lenders told
summary: China's banking regulator has ordered lenders to stop selling investment products linked to commodities futures to retail buyers, citing concerns over investment losses amid volatile commodity prices. The China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) has also asked lenders to unwind their existing books for these products, which have been linked to significant losses in the past, including a $1.8 billion loss by Bank of China. The move aims to curb speculative bets and prevent further losses for small investors.

site_title: Biden orders intelligence report on Covid-19 origins within 90 days
summary: US President Joe Biden ordered intelligence agencies to report on the origins of Covid-19 within 90 days, amid controversy over whether the virus emerged from an animal source or a laboratory accident in Wuhan, China. The US intelligence community has coalesced around two likely scenarios, but has not reached a definitive conclusion. The lab theory has gained traction in the US, despite China's denials and accusations of spreading conspiracy theories. The report's findings will have significant implications for China and the US, and calls for transparency are growing among scientists.

site_title: M&S reports 88% slump in annual profit
summary: M&S reports an 88% slump in annual profit to £50.3m, down from £403.1m in 2019-20, due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on clothing sales. The retailer, however, says it's making progress with its turnaround plan, trading well in the early weeks of the 2021-22 year, and expects underlying pretax profit to recover to £300-350m in the current year. This has led to a 4% increase in shares.

site_title: Ford says 40% of sales to be electric vehicles by 2030
summary: Ford plans to reach 40% of its sales with electric vehicles by 2030, investing over $30 billion by 2025 in zero-emission cars and infrastructure. The company unveiled an all-electric F-150 truck, the Lightning, and has received 70,000 reservations in a week. Ford aims to reduce battery costs by 40% by 2025 and will produce its own batteries. The move is part of its "Ford+" plan to boost growth, which also includes partnerships with Google and Amazon.

images.alt_text: Ford once again is ramping up investment in zero-emission cars and expects 40 per cent of volume by 2030 to be comprised of fully electric vehicles, the company announced Wednesday.

site_title: US insurers have lowest ESG credentials: report
summary: US insurers have the lowest environmental, social, and governance (ESG) credentials, according to a report from nonprofit ShareAction. American International Group, Nationwide Mutual Insurance, and Genworth Financial received the lowest scores, along with China's Ping An Insurance Group and People's Insurance Company of China. Despite the importance of addressing climate change, biodiversity loss, and human rights, insurers are not doing enough, with only 13% having policies to exclude investment in companies breaching human rights. Insurers can play a significant role in managing risks and contributing to risk prevention, but their ESG policies and practices lag behind other financial sectors.

site_title: Lamborghini not for sale after reported 7.5b euro bid: VW
summary: Volkswagen has received a non-binding $12.1 billion offer for Lamborghini, but the supercar brand is not for sale, according to Audi. The offer was made by a consortium led by Switzerland's Quantum Group AG, which includes job assurances for existing employees and the creation of 850 new jobs. Volkswagen had previously considered divesting Lamborghini to make it more independent, but the group has decided to keep the brand. Lamborghini's CEO, Stephan Winkelmann, plans to invest $1.5 billion in hybrid and electric models by 2024.

site_title: Swift tech updates a boon for vaccination exercise
summary: Singapore's national vaccination programme, launched in December 2020, has overcome numerous hurdles, with the public healthcare technology agency Integrated Health Information Systems (IHiS) releasing seven versions of GPConnect, an integrated IT system, in under six months. The system now auto-populates vaccine cards, tracks observation periods, and has a backup version, enabling a vaccination process that takes an average of 35-40 minutes. IHiS' CEO Bruce Liang said the team worked to address constraints on manpower and ensure a user-friendly system, with the government aiming to finish the Covid-19 inoculation programme by the end of this year.

site_title: US arrests Bolivian ex-minister on bribery, money laundering charges
summary: A former Bolivian cabinet minister, Arturo Murillo, 57, was arrested in the US on bribery and money laundering charges. He, along with three US businessmen and his ex-chief of staff Sergio Mendez, were arrested on May 21 and 22 in Florida and Georgia. The indictment alleges they received bribes from a US company and laundered the funds through the US financial system to secure a Bolivian government contract.

site_title: Goldman forms wealth venture with China's largest bank
summary: Goldman Sachs has formed a wealth management joint venture with China's largest bank, Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), boosting its distribution network and access to wealthy customers. The venture, which holds 51% of the asset pool, is estimated to surpass $70 trillion by 2030. Goldman is investing heavily, doubling its workforce in China and expanding its footprint in investment banking and asset management. The partnership is part of a rush by foreign financial institutions to capitalize on China's growing financial industry, with estimated investable assets set to double over the next few years.

site_title: Democracy promotion is no substitute for diplomacy
summary: The US under President Joe Biden is promoting democracy as a tool in its foreign policy, forming a coalition of democratic nations to counter a resurgent China. However, this approach has its drawbacks, including the lack of evidence that China is seeking to export its authoritarian model to other countries. Instead, China seeks to advance its interests through diplomacy. The US should focus on sustaining its liberal-democratic system as a model, rather than turning diplomacy into an ideological crusade. This approach may require collaboration with nations like India, rather than punishing them for curbing democratic freedoms.

site_title: Malaysia's Covid cases per million overtake India's; country urged to prepare for worst
summary: Malaysia reports 7,478 new coronavirus cases, its highest daily rise in infections since the start of the pandemic, with the country's daily cases per million people exceeding India's. The nation is urged to prepare for the worst as the outbreak follows an exponential trend. With only 3% of the population fully vaccinated, the government aims to achieve herd immunity by year's end. The healthcare system is stressed, with hospitals running low on ICU beds, particularly in the states of Penang and the Klang Valley area.

site_title: Two primary school pupils, one pastor added to Jem and Westgate Covid-19 cluster
summary: Two primary school pupils, an 11-year-old boy and a six-year-old girl, and a 30-year-old pastor from Grace Assembly Church have been added to the Jem and Westgate Covid-19 cluster, bringing the total cases to 60. The trio were among 26 new cases announced by the Ministry of Health, including two more cases linked to the McDonald's delivery riders cluster. The number of new cases in the community has decreased, with 61,916 total cases reported, and 61,345 patients have fully recovered from the disease.

site_title: SoftBank-backed Jellysmack eyes global expansion
summary: SoftBank-backed Jellysmack, a New York-based company, is expanding globally with acquisitions and a focus on Europe and emerging markets. The startup, which helps online content creators and brands promote their offerings across platforms, aims to strengthen its operations in France, the UK, Germany, Mexico, Brazil, and India. Jellysmack takes a share of revenue in return for its services.

site_title: SGX cannot rely on the goodwill of some companies to make its new quarterly reporting regime a success
summary: Singapore's risk-based quarterly reporting (QR) regime, introduced 15 months ago, appears to rely heavily on the voluntary efforts of companies to succeed. The regime, which focuses on high-risk companies, has seen some positive trends, including a proportion of issuers producing voluntary business updates and consistent information. However, the success of the regime is uncertain, as voluntary disclosures vary across companies and time, and some analysts and investors express concerns about the lack of consistency and frequent updates. Regulators must find ways to ensure the consistent release of good-quality information without relying on the goodwill of some companies.

site_title: How Singapore is warming to crypto and digital assets
summary: Singapore is warming up to crypto and digital assets, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) planning to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, which may involve digital assets. The development comes as OCBC Bank names Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong who is retiring. This shift in leadership may signal a more open approach to crypto and digital assets in the banking sector. However, no specific details on crypto regulations have been announced yet.

site_title: Gucci owner Kering continues to wind down Puma stake
summary: Kering, the French luxury group that owns Gucci, plans to sell an additional $1 billion worth of shares in Puma, a German sportswear maker, as part of its efforts to unwind its investment in the company. The sale, which will reduce Kering's stake to 4% of Puma's outstanding shares, is part of its strategy to focus on higher-end luxury brands. The proceeds from the sale will be used for general corporate purposes and to strengthen Kering's financial structure. Kering had originally acquired a majority stake in Puma in 2007.

images.alt_text: French group Kering, which owns Gucci, said on Wednesday it will sell a further US$1.0 billion worth of shares in Germany's Puma as it continues to unwind its investment in the sneaker and sportswear maker to focus on higher-end luxury brands.

site_title: Indonesia's Tiket weighs SPAC merger this year
summary: Indonesia's online travel startup Tiket.com is considering a merger with a special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) valued at about $2 billion, which could take place this year. The company is also exploring a traditional initial public offering (IPO) and potentially combining with a South-east Asian super app. CEO George Hendrata said a traditional IPO could take a year or two for full travel recovery, while a SPAC merger could be quicker. This move follows local rival Traveloka's talks to go public through a SPAC merger.

site_title: Kiwi holds gains after surprise rate hike projection
summary: The New Zealand dollar surged 1.1% to a three-month high after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand hinted at a possible interest rate hike by September 2022. The Australian dollar also rose, while the US dollar remained near five-month lows. The move was seen as a positive signal for the Australian dollar, with markets questioning the Reserve Bank of Australia's commitment to its "no hikes before 2024" stance.

site_title: WhatsApp sues India govt, says new rules mean end to privacy: sources
summary: WhatsApp has filed a lawsuit in Delhi against the Indian government, seeking to block new regulations that would require the company to break end-to-end encryption to identify the "first originator of information" when authorities demand it. The company argues that complying with the law would compromise user privacy, and experts have backed its claims that the law fails to meet the tests of legality, necessity, and proportionality. The lawsuit escalates a growing struggle between the Indian government and tech giants, including Facebook and Twitter, over the new rules that are set to come into effect on Wednesday.

site_title: 24 new local Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including three unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 26 new COVID-19 cases, including 23 community cases and 3 unlinked, bringing the total to 61,916. 21 cases are linked to previous infections, and 14 have been quarantined. Two imported cases are under stay-home notice. The Ministry of Health will provide more details on Wednesday night.

site_title: The curious world of NFT real estate and design
summary: The market for digital real estate and design as nonfungible tokens (NFTs) has surged, with companies like SuperWorld selling "thousands of properties" and users spending an average of $2,000 on virtual real estate platforms. Virtual properties, such as Mars House, have sold for millions of dollars, sparking debate about the practical use of virtual space.
