While some critics question the trend, proponents like Krista Kim see it as a step towards a future where virtual worlds can replicate physical experiences, with potential applications in architecture, design, and advertising.

site_title: Global deal on tax nears first stage as G-7 seeks common ground
summary: A global tax agreement on corporations, potentially featuring a minimum rate and encompassing digital giants, is nearing its first stage as the G-7 nations aim for a consensus. Finance ministers are set to meet virtually and in person, with European governments optimistic about an initial accord. The US has proposed a global tax floor of at least 15%, while countries like the UK have expressed concerns. A deal could pave the way for a wider G-20 agreement and replace digital services taxes.

site_title: HDB upgraders are fuelling mass-market condominium sales
summary: HDB upgraders are driving mass-market condominium sales in Singapore, with private non-landed homes in the outside central region (OCR) being the top choice. Owners who sold their existing HDB flats are benefiting from price appreciation and cash-over-valuation amounts, enabling them to upgrade to private housing. The OCR market is expected to benefit from stricter COVID-19 curbs on arrivals from certain countries, which may delay BTO project construction and prompt more homebuyers to turn to HDB resale flats.

site_title: Ntegrator International enters into placement agreement to raise S$2.06 million
summary: Ntegrator International has entered into a conditional placement agreement to issue 187.86 million new shares at S$0.01094 per share, raising approximately S$2.06 million. The shares represent 17.63% of the company's existing total issued share capital. The company intends to use 80% of the net proceeds to fund acquisitions and new business opportunities, while the remaining 20% will be used for general working capital requirements.

site_title: Watches go sustainable with ethical, vegan options
summary: Luxury watch brands are incorporating sustainable features into their timepieces, including ethically sourced gold, vegetable waste straps, and solar-powered movements. This shift towards eco-friendliness is driven by changing consumer preferences and the need to reduce environmental impact. While it remains to be seen whether this trend will be sustained, brands are taking steps to reduce their ecological footprint and appeal to environmentally conscious consumers.

site_title: China in the global inflation scare
summary: China's rising producer price inflation (PPI) is causing global market concern due to its significant impact on global markets as a major buyer and supplier. However, the author argues that China's inflation is more likely to be "cost-push" rather than "demand-pull," and that global wage-price spiral pressures are absent. The author suggests that China's disinflationary force, driven by its focus on social stability and output growth, is limiting the pass-through of PPI inflation to consumer prices. As a result, PPI inflation is unlikely to sustainably drive global inflation, and volatility may rise but not last long.

site_title: Washington sues Amazon, accuses it of controlling online prices
summary: The District of Columbia has filed a lawsuit against Amazon, accusing the company of artificially raising prices for products online by abusing its monopoly power. The lawsuit claims Amazon prohibits merchants from charging lower prices elsewhere, raising prices across multiple marketplaces. The District's attorney general, Karl Racine, said Amazon has used its dominant position to win at all costs. Amazon has denied the allegations, stating that sellers set their own prices. This is the first government antitrust suit against Amazon in the US, part of a broader pushback against tech giants.

site_title: Japan's ruling party exec calls for 26t yen extra budget
summary: Japan's ruling party executive Kozo Yamamoto has called for a 26 trillion yen (S$316.29 billion) extra budget to cushion the economic blow from the Covid-19 pandemic. Yamamoto also urged the Bank of Japan to increase asset buying to weaken the yen and aid the export-reliant economy, which appears to be sliding back into deflation. The proposed budget and asset buying plan are expected to be compiled in October or November, aiming to support Japan's economy amid the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Goldman forms wealth venture with China's largest bank
summary: Goldman Sachs has received approval from Chinese regulators to establish a 51-49% joint venture with Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) for a wealth management venture. The venture aims to tap into China's estimated $70 trillion asset pool by 2030. This move is part of a broader effort by financial groups to capitalize on China's growing financial industry, which is expected to double in investable assets over the next few years. The joint venture will focus on wealth management and is seen as a key strategy for Goldman and ICBC to expand their presence in the market.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs Group received approval from Chinese regulators to set up a wealth management joint venture in the world's second-largest economy to go after an asset pool it estimated will surpass US$70 trillion by the end of this decade.

site_title: EU-Japan summit to help set G-7 and G-20 agenda
summary: European Union and Japan leaders will meet on Thursday for a summit that will set the agenda for the G-7 and G-20 meetings in June and October, respectively. The EU-Japan relationship, built on shared values and principles, aims to deepen bilateral strategic partnerships in areas such as trade, investment, climate action, and research innovation. The summit will also focus on implementation of the EU-Japan strategic partnerships, with leaders committed to strengthening relations and promoting multilateralism and open market economies. The talks are seen as crucial for shaping the global agenda.

site_title: Roblox accused in suit of ripping off kids with bogus purchases
summary: A federal lawsuit has been filed against Roblox, accusing the gaming platform of ripping off users, mostly children, by selling in-game items and later deleting them without reimbursement. The company earns a 30% commission on third-party sales, which it takes before deleting items citing moderation policies. The lawsuit claims Roblox's decision to sell first and moderate later has obvious monetary benefits. The plaintiff, a Michigan girl, bought digital items that were later deleted without warning or explanation.

site_title: A lost Brontë library surfaces
summary: A trove of Brontë family manuscripts, acquired in the 19th century, is set to be auctioned at Sotheby's, estimated to fetch $1.3-$1.8 million for a handwritten Emily Brontë poem. The Honresfield Library, assembled by two Victorian industrialists, contains over 500 manuscripts, letters, and rare first editions from notable authors, including the Brontë sisters. The auction includes family letters, annotated books, and relics that provide insight into life in the Brontë household, including a heavily annotated copy of Bewick's History of British Birds.

site_title: Obese pigs in China are fuelling relentless pork price decline
summary: Chinese obese pigs, weighing up to 200kg, are contributing to the 40% decline in wholesale pork prices since January due to farmers holding onto larger pigs in hopes of a rebound. The surge in imports and panic selling have exacerbated the issue. Experts say the "super-sized" pigs are delaying a price rebound and that the market is being reshaped by new regulations aimed at combating African swine fever. The slump is expected to continue until next year or 2023, with Chinese hog producers seeing significant losses, including Muyuan Foods Co's 30% decline in Shenzhen.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for fifth consecutive session
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a fifth consecutive session, driven by gains on Chinese shares and recovering from early trading jitters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.31% to 28,642.19, while the Topix index inched up 0.06% to 1,920.67. This follows a similar trend in Singapore, where the STI index rose 0.4% on Thursday, and US stocks also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edging higher.

site_title: Amazon buying MGM for US$8.45 billion
summary: Amazon has acquired MGM, the US movie studio behind the James Bond franchise, for $8.45 billion. The deal aims to boost Amazon Prime Video's content offerings, competing with streaming rivals like Netflix and Disney+. MGM's library includes classic films and popular TV shows, which Amazon plans to reimagine and develop. The acquisition is part of Amazon's strategy to expand its entertainment business and increase spending on content, following a record quarterly profit and over 200 million Prime subscribers.

site_title: New Zealand central bank signals rate hike in 2022 as growth returns
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), left its benchmark interest rate at an all-time low but signaled a rate hike by September 2022, with projections of a 1.5% official cash rate by the end of 2023. This decision led to a 1% jump in the New Zealand dollar, reaching a three-month high of US$0.7308. The RBNZ retained its large-scale asset purchase program and Funding for Lending Programme unchanged, citing a need for the economy to meet inflation and employment targets before raising rates.

site_title: Coherent policy framework will enhance macroeconomic and macro-financial stability: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's managing director of the Monetary Authority, Ravi Menon, emphasized the need for a coherent policy framework to enhance macroeconomic and macro-financial stability in the face of growing risks of international economic fragmentation. Emerging market economies (EMEs) and advanced economies are turning to various policy tools, including macroprudential measures, to manage large capital flows and promote financial stability. Menon highlighted the need for a theoretical framework to provide coherence across policy tools and traditional monetary and fiscal policies, and called for research to better understand the interactions between these instruments.

site_title: Hong Kong debates what to do with its pile of unused Covid shots
summary: Hong Kong is struggling with a surplus of unused Covid-19 vaccine doses, with 840,000 doses from BioNTech set to expire in mid-August and 1.05 million from Sinovac Biotech remaining unused. The city has a daily inoculation rate of only a quarter of available doses, with 12.3% of its 7.5 million population fully vaccinated. Authorities are considering donating excess doses to places in need via the World Health Organization's Covax program and postponing or cancelling certain vaccine deliveries. This surplus could hinder Hong Kong's chances of securing more vaccine doses in the future.

site_title: Three dead as Japan fishing boat collides with Russia ship
summary: A Japanese fishing boat collided with a Russian ship off Hokkaido, killing three crew members and injuring two others. The incident occurred in an area disputed between the two countries, with Japan claiming four islands as the Northern Territories and Russia referring to them as the southern Kurils. The dispute has prevented the two countries from signing a formal peace treaty since World War II.

site_title: Why billionaires like Bill Gates can't fix problems they create
summary: Bill Gates and his wife Melinda French Gates have been criticized for their philanthropic efforts, particularly their management of the Gates Foundation, which has been accused of giving money to lucrative corporations while perpetuating inequality. The foundation's large size and secretive management structure have made it difficult to scrutinize, and its investments in pharmaceutical and credit card companies have raised concerns about its motives. Critics argue that billionaires like Gates are not the solution to problems they create, as they often benefit from corporate practices that undercut workers and deepen inequality. The Gates Foundation's actions have been compared to an arsonist trying to put out a fire they themselves started.

images.alt_text: The University of Oxford was reportedly considering offering a Covid vaccine developed by its scientists on a non-exclusive basis, which would have made it possible for manufacturers across the world to produce it more cheaply and widely. But urged on by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, it signed an exclusive vaccine deal with AstraZeneca that gave the pharmaceutical giant sole rights and no guarantee of low prices.

site_title: Two primary school pupils, one pastor added to Jem and Westgate Covid-19 cluster
summary: Two primary school pupils, an 11-year-old boy and a 6-year-old girl, and a 30-year-old pastor from a church cluster have been added to the Jem and Westgate Covid-19 cluster in Singapore. The cluster now has 60 people and is the second-largest active cluster in the country. The pastor was detected asymptomatic during surveillance testing operations on May 24. The new cases bring Singapore's total tally to 61,916, with 31 patients discharged on Wednesday, leaving 242 in hospital and 282 recuperating in community facilities.

site_title: China Haida JV to supply aluminium products for projects in Singapore, Malaysia
summary: China Haida JV partners with K-United Builder to supply and install aluminium products for projects in Singapore and Malaysia. The first project in Johor, Malaysia, has a contract value of S$1.68 million, while the Singapore projects have a total contract value of S$0.75 million. The joint venture aims to diversify China Haida's geographical concentration risk and generate additional income sources, with profits to be split equally between the two companies. The JV will be funded through internal resources, with the company planning to undertake fund-raising activities in the future.

site_title: Manage data like your finances to thrive in the New Economy
summary: Data analytics has become a crucial component of economic growth, with data-driven businesses experiencing significant advantages during the current crisis. However, strong capabilities in analytics are not enough; good data management is equally important. Treating data like personal finances, organizations can access the right data at the right time, in the right place. This can be achieved by acquiring organizational buy-in, discovering data silos, and ensuring data is stored and used efficiently. Companies that implement data management strategies report 69% more revenue, 57% more profits, and 72% greater customer satisfaction.

site_title: Will India Covid crisis replay in South-east Asia?
summary: South-east Asia is experiencing a new wave of Covid-19 infections, putting pressure on healthcare systems and threatening economies. Thailand has seen its highest-ever daily cases, with nearly 135,000 cases, while Malaysia has daily cases of over 6,000. The Philippines has also seen a surge, with hospitals overwhelmed and thousands dying at home. Experts warn that countries like Cambodia, Laos, and Myanmar are more vulnerable due to under-equipped healthcare systems. The World Health Organisation estimates the global excess death toll to be up to 10.2 million, with South-east Asia likely to bear a significant share.

site_title: Views mixed on whether new quarterly reporting regime works
summary: Singapore's new quarterly reporting regime, introduced 15 months ago, has received mixed views on its effectiveness. Critics argue that the risk-based approach has led to a dilution of corporate governance and reduced transparency. Analysts and investors say that while some companies have made efforts to provide timely disclosures, the quality of information remains a concern. Regulators claim that the regime has allowed companies to focus on responding to Covid-19 while ensuring timely material disclosures. However, experts warn that the lack of effective enforcement and the ease of getting off the list of required companies pose significant risks.

site_title: WhatsApp sues India government, says new media rules mean end to privacy: sources
summary: WhatsApp has filed a lawsuit in the Delhi High Court against the Indian government, claiming that new media rules will force the company to break its end-to-end encryption and compromise user privacy. The rules, set to come into effect on Wednesday, require social media companies to identify the "first originator" of information when authorities demand it. WhatsApp argues that this would require it to break encryption for both senders and receivers, making it impossible to comply with the law. The lawsuit escalates a growing struggle between the Indian government and tech giants over regulation in the country's key global growth market.

site_title: Japan ruling party executive calls for 26t yen extra budget
summary: Japan's ruling party lawmaker Kozo Yamamoto calls for a 26 trillion yen extra budget to cushion the economic blow from the Covid-19 pandemic, citing deflation concerns and urging the Bank of Japan to increase asset buying to weaken the yen. Yamamoto also proposes boosting government bond purchases and looking for new assets to buy, citing the need to pull the pandemic-hit economy out of the doldrums. The proposal, submitted to Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, comes ahead of a lower house election in autumn.

site_title: Engine Biosciences raises S$57m in oversubscribed Series A led by US-based Polaris Partners
summary: ENGINE Biosciences, a biotech company using machine learning and large-scale biology testing, raised S$57 million in an oversubscribed Series A funding round led by US-based Polaris Partners. The round, valued at US$82 million, brings the startup's total funding to S$70 million. New investors include Invus Group and a Singapore-based institutional investor, while existing investors participated. The funding will be used to continue discovering precision medicine-based therapies for cancer and other diseases.

site_title: Old-school tycoons of Hong Kong are losing to China's moguls
summary: Hong Kong's old-school tycoons are losing ground to China's tech-savvy moguls. The combined wealth of China's 10 richest people has surged threefold since 2016 to US$425 billion, while Hong Kong's 10 richest people have seen their wealth double to US$218 billion. Many Hong Kong tycoons, including Li Ka-shing, are struggling to adapt to the changing market landscape, with their listed businesses trading at deep discounts to their net assets. China's tech industry is driving growth, with most of its richest billionaires coming from this sector.

site_title: EV charger maker Tritium going public in SPAC merger deal
summary: Tritium, a maker of fast electric vehicle chargers, has agreed to go public through a merger with blank-cheque company Decarbonization Plus Acquisition Corp II, valuing the company at $1.2 billion. The deal, expected to generate $400 million in proceeds, does not include a private placement, a departure from typical SPAC mergers. Tritium's combination with Decarbonization Plus II will allow the company to raise capital without issuing shares to investors, instead relying on the SPAC's existing cash reserves.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on May 26, 2021, following a jittery session on Wall Street, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.38% or 109.76 points to 28,444.22. The Topix index also declined 0.35%. The lower opening is attributed to eyes on US economic data.

site_title: China will more than double millionaires by 2025: HSBC
summary: China is expected to more than double its number of millionaires to five million by 2025, with the middle class growing by 45% to over 500 million, boosting consumption and economic growth. Household wealth is projected to rise 8.5% annually, reaching 300 trillion yuan, and China's consumption will increase by about $1.1 trillion per year for every $20 increase in daily spending by the newly made middle class. However, the wealth gap in China is widening, with the top 1% of households owning 30% of the country's wealth.

site_title: Wall Street bank CEOs to tout Covid relief push, diversity efforts before Congress
summary: Wall Street bank CEOs will testify before Congress this week, highlighting their institutions' role in supporting the US economy during the pandemic and their efforts to address climate change and structural racism. CEOs from JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup, and others will face tough questions on hot-button social and economic issues, including economic inequality, fair lending, and diversity. The hearings are likely to be politically risky, with scrutiny of the industry growing under Democratic leadership, and may not result in policy proposals.

site_title: MAS joins Mojaloop Foundation to promote financial inclusion among the underserved
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has joined the Mojaloop Foundation as a sponsor-level member, making it the first central bank to do so. This collaboration aims to advance financial inclusion in emerging economies through digital currency-based settlement systems and foundational digital infrastructure. The Mojaloop Foundation, a charitable non-profit, seeks to enhance the economic well-being of 1.7 billion unbanked adults worldwide through financial inclusion. The partnership is expected to deliver opportunities for fintech players in Singapore and the broader Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Malaysia's Covid cases per million overtakes India's; country urged to prepare for worst
summary: Malaysia's COVID-19 cases per million people have surpassed India's, with a surge in infections following an exponential trend since last month. The nation is urged to prepare for the worst, with health director-general Noor Hisham Abdullah warning of a "vertical surge." New cases have stayed above 6,000 for seven straight days, and the health ministry predicts a possible 8,000 cases by next month if protocols are not followed. The country's daily infections per million people have exceeded India's since Sunday, and the healthcare system is under stress due to the worsening outbreak.

site_title: SoftBank-backed media startup Jellysmack eyes global expansion, acquisitions
summary: SoftBank-backed media startup Jellysmack plans to expand globally with acquisitions, focusing on Europe, Mexico, Brazil, and India. The company, which has received $6 million in funding, will use the investment to strengthen operations, invest in technology, and acquire companies building influencer infrastructure. Jellysmack aims to become a unicorn, with a valuation of over $1 billion, and may go public in the next few years. The company's co-founder, Michael Philippe, believes in a "creator revolution" and that talent alone is not enough for success in the social media ecosystem.

site_title: UK to propose powers to block London listings that pose security risks
summary: The UK is set to introduce stricter rules for companies going public on the London Stock Exchange, allowing the listing of companies to be blocked on national security grounds. The plan, to be unveiled through a public consultation, aims to bolster the UK's reputation as a clean and transparent financial centre. This move follows earlier announcements by Finance Minister Rishi Sunak to modernise listing rules and attract high-growth companies. The UK's Financial Conduct Authority has also been granted more flexibility to regulate markets, making the City of London more attractive to global investors.

site_title: Bitcoin heads toward US$40,000 as cryptos bounce back from selloff
summary: Bitcoin rallied 5.2% to $39,588, rebounding from a selloff fueled by Elon Musk's criticism of the token's energy consumption and China's regulatory rhetoric. The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index advanced 8% as other cryptocurrencies also gained. Despite the recovery, experts are cautious, citing a pause in the bull market and a significant spike in volatility. Bitcoin remains about $25,000 shy of its record high of $65,000, but its value is still up 342% in the past year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at the open on Wednesday, extending the previous day's rally. The Hang Seng Index gained 0.50% to 29,056.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.15% to 3,586.84. The rally followed a weak Wall Street lead and traders' dismissal of new US threats.

site_title: Xiaomi says US has formally lifted securities ban
summary: Xiaomi announced that a US court has removed the company's designation as a Communist Chinese Military Company (CCMC) and lifted all restrictions on US persons buying or holding its stock. The US Department of Defense had previously removed Xiaomi from a government blacklist, marking a reversal by the Biden administration. Xiaomi chairman Lei Jun stated that the company is an open, transparent, and independently operated corporation, refuting the earlier designation. This move is seen as a positive development for the Chinese tech giant, allowing it to expand its US business operations.

site_title: A-Sonic Aerospace proposes bonus issue of warrants
summary: A-Sonic Aerospace proposes a bonus issue of up to 14.62 million warrants, with each warrant entitling the holder to subscribe for one new share at S$0.08, a 88% discount to the previous day's closing price. The issuance aims to reward shareholders and improve trading liquidity. If fully exercised, the warrants will raise up to S$1.17 million, used for general corporate and working capital purposes. The company's issued share capital will increase to approximately 73.1 million shares.

site_title: Things didn't smell right at Wirecard - then a whistleblower was stonewalled
summary: A former Wirecard executive, Pav Gill, revealed that the company's Asia-Pacific operations had numerous red flags, including suspicious accounting practices and potential links to intelligence agencies. Despite his concerns, Gill was blocked from raising red flags and was even paid off to silence him. Authorities have launched criminal probes into the company's collapse, which revealed $3.09 billion in missing funds. Gill argues that whistleblowers are often shielded from complicit powers and calls for improved regulations to protect them, particularly in Singapore, which is positioning itself as a financial hub.

site_title: Ant shelves sales of debt backed by online loans after crackdown
summary: Ant Group Co has suspended issuance of securities backed by online loans as it overhauls its business to meet new rules. The Shanghai stock exchange terminated sales of two ABS totaling 18 billion yuan by Ant units. The company is scaling back its consumer finance business after a crackdown on its financial technology firm, which also derailed its record IPO. Ant's dominance in online payments, consumer lending, and wealth management is expected to be restricted by new regulations. The company may need to inject 80 billion yuan into its consumer lending units to comply with funding and leverage requirements.

site_title: US exchanges offer a rich potential target for hackers
summary: US financial exchanges face a significant threat from hackers due to their high value and potential for disruption. Despite assurances from major exchanges that they are taking steps to secure their networks, recent incidents in New Zealand and the US pipeline hack have highlighted the risk. Cyberattacks could pose a threat even more severe than the 2008 financial crisis, with potential consequences including payment system failures and loss of business operations.

site_title: Asahi daily, an official Tokyo Olympics partner, calls for cancellation of Games
summary: Asahi Shimbun, an official Tokyo Olympics partner, has called for the cancellation of the Summer Games due to risks to public safety and strains on the medical system from the Covid-19 pandemic. The editorial, which broke ranks with other partners, comes amid growing public opposition and protests from doctors' associations and investors. Japan has struggled to control a fourth wave of infections, with only 5% of the population vaccinated, and remains under a third state of emergency. The move intensifies focus on the viability of the Games, with the International Olympic Committee (IOC) yet to make a decision.

site_title: Covid lab origin theory gains traction in United States
summary: The Covid-19 origin theory that the virus emerged from a lab leak in Wuhan is gaining traction in the US, with top officials like Anthony Fauci and Rochelle Walensky expressing openness to all possibilities. A US intelligence report suggests that three Wuhan Institute of Virology researchers were hospitalized with a seasonal illness in November 2019, but China has dismissed the report as untrue. The World Health Organization's report on the pandemic's origins found a natural origin to be the most probable scenario, but some scientists are calling for more transparency to determine the true cause of the outbreak.

site_title: Ecuador confirms Galapagos tortoise is from species thought extinct
summary: Ecuador's Environment Minister confirmed a Galapagos tortoise found in 2019 on Fernandina island is a member of the species thought to be extinct for over 100 years, Chelonoidis phantasticus. Genetic tests confirmed the discovery, reconfirming the tortoise's existence after a century of believed extinction.

site_title: Prosecutor in Trump criminal probe convenes grand jury: sources
summary: Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance has convened a grand jury to decide whether to indict Donald Trump, indicating he believes evidence of a crime has been found. The grand jury, expected to sit three days a week for six months, will also hear on other matters. Vance's office has been investigating Trump's pre-presidency business dealings for over two years, including tax and insurance fraud and falsification of business records. The investigation, which began as a criminal probe, has reached an advanced stage and may result in Trump being charged with a crime.

site_title: US prepares for summer air travel spike, may allow more foreign visitors
summary: The US is preparing for a summer air travel spike, with airlines and agencies expecting increased domestic travel. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) plans to hire more officers to screen passengers. Despite this, foreign travel remains restricted, with the US continuing to bar non-US citizens from most of Europe. Industry officials believe the UK and Ireland may be the first countries to be lifted from the restrictions, with cases declining in both countries. The government is evaluating the decision daily, with the potential for changes in June.

images.alt_text: US airlines and agencies are preparing for increased domestic air travel this summer even as the government continues to debate whether to allow more foreign travellers to visit.

site_title: Boustead Projects reports record earnings; proposes special dividend for FY2021
summary: Boustead Projects, a property firm, reported record earnings for the second half of FY2021, driven by the divestment of 14 properties to an industrial fund. The company generated S$133.9 million in net profit, more than 10 times the S$12.6 million recorded in the corresponding period last year. Boustead Projects also announced a special dividend of 14.5 Singapore cents, in addition to a final dividend of 0.9 cent, and expects to be profitable for FY2022, driven by strong performances from its real estate segment and new fund-management business.

site_title: Gold firms near 4-1/2-month peak on weaker US dollar, yields
summary: Gold prices held near a 4-1/2-month high on Wednesday, supported by a weaker US dollar and lower US Treasury yields. Spot gold remained steady at $1,899.11 per ounce, while benchmark US Treasury yields fell to a two-week low of 1.56%. A drop in the dollar index, near a 4-1/2-month low, made gold cheaper for other currency holders. This supported investors' view of gold as a hedge against higher inflation, following stimulus measures.

site_title: South Koreans no longer need masks outdoors if vaccinated against Covid-19
summary: South Korea announced that masks will no longer be required outdoors for those vaccinated against Covid-19 starting July, as part of efforts to encourage vaccination and reach an immunization rate of 70% by September. People vaccinated with at least one dose will also be allowed to gather in larger numbers starting June. The country aims to vaccinate its 52 million population, with the general public aged 65-74 set to begin vaccination on Thursday in over 12,000 clinics.

images.alt_text: South Korea on Wednesday said masks will no longer be required outdoors from July for those vaccinated with at least one Covid-19 shot.

site_title: Oil prices edge up as rising demand faces Iran supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose 0.3% on Tuesday, settling at $68.65 a barrel for Brent crude and $66.07 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude. Rising demand ahead of summer driving season and lifted coronavirus restrictions countered concerns about Iran's potential return to the market, which could lead to a supply glut. US crude inventories fell by 439,000 barrels last week, while the US dollar weakened to a 19-week low, supporting oil prices. The market awaits weekly US oil inventory reports expected to show a decline of 1.1 million barrels last week.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends slightly lower as investors eye inflation clues
summary: US stocks ended slightly lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite failing to stray far from their unchanged marks. Investors continue to assess inflation concerns, with yields on US Treasuries falling for a fourth straight day, hitting a fresh two-week low. Federal Reserve officials downplay rising price pressures, while market participants expect prices to increase as the economy recovers.

site_title: Tesla doubles down on camera-based Autopilot amid growing scrutiny
summary: Tesla is equipping its Model 3 and Model Y vehicles in North America with cameras for semi-automated driving, abandoning radar sensors. The move comes amid growing scrutiny over Autopilot's safety amid a series of crashes. The camera-based system may limit certain features like lane-centring and parking assistance. All new Model S and Model X cars, as well as vehicles outside North America, will still have radar sensors. Tesla's driver assistance system relies on cameras, radar, and sensors, but the shift to cameras has reduced costs and commercialized features.

images.alt_text: Tesla said on Tuesday its Model 3 and Model Y vehicles will be equipped with cameras and no radar sensor for semi-automated driving in North America starting this month.

site_title: Fed policymakers edge closer to opening debate around tapering
summary: US Federal Reserve policymakers are moving closer to debating the timing of reducing their crisis support for the economy, with some officials suggesting it may be necessary to scale back asset purchases. Federal Reserve President Mary Daly stated that the economy still needs support, while Vice Chair Richard Clarida indicated that the Fed may discuss tapering in upcoming meetings. The Fed has promised to give markets notice before changing policy, avoiding a repeat of the "taper tantrum" in 2013. The Fed's inflation target is 2%, and policymakers are divided on the risks of inflation, with some warning of potential rate hikes.

site_title: Amazon showdown grinds on with first antitrust case in US
summary: The US attorney general for Washington, DC, Karl Racine, has filed an antitrust lawsuit against Amazon, alleging the company engages in anticompetitive practices that raise prices for consumers. The lawsuit claims Amazon prohibits third-party sellers from offering products at lower prices on rival platforms, artificially increasing prices and allowing the company to build monopoly power. Racine said he would welcome states to join the case, but no decisions have been made. The lawsuit marks the first time Amazon has faced antitrust charges in the US, but investors have shown resilience, with Amazon's shares recovering after the news.

site_title: ST Telemedia unit forms JV to grow Indonesian data-centre operations
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) has formed a joint venture with Temasek and Triputra Group to develop a new data-centre campus in Jakarta, Indonesia. The first campus, expected to be completed by 2023, will support up to 72 megawatts of IT capacity. This partnership aims to strengthen STT GDC's Asian network and tap into Indonesia's growing internet economy. The move is seen as a strategic entry into the Indonesian data-centre market, with STT GDC aiming to reinforce its position as a leading player in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Six supertrends to keep an eye on
summary: The finance industry is shifting towards investing with purpose, focusing on long-term societal and environmental goals. Six supertrends have been identified: decarbonizing the economy, technology, the silver economy, infrastructure growth, anxious societies, and millennials. These trends prioritize climate action, healthcare, sustainable infrastructure, affordability, and digitalization, with companies in these areas poised to benefit. The updated supertrends align with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals, providing a framework for investors to prioritize their investments according to their purpose.

site_title: Vital to have stronger data protection in post-pandemic world
summary: The post-pandemic world requires stronger data protection measures as organisations increasingly rely on user data and remote work. The number of data breach alerts in Singapore tripled in the February-March period, highlighting the urgency for organisations to strengthen their data privacy policies. The European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) has set a precedent for regulatory regimes worldwide, but its applicability to non-European countries is becoming increasingly complicated. In response, Europe is establishing a sovereign digital ecosystem through the GAIA-X project, which aims to provide a common set of guidelines and requirements for data storage and transfer.

site_title: Exxon Mobil faces off against activist investors on climate change
summary: Exxon Mobil faces a challenge to its climate change policies at its annual shareholder meeting, with activist investors Engine No 1 contesting the election of one-third of the company's board. The investors, backed by several large pension funds, argue that Exxon has not invested enough in cleaner energy and will hurt its profits in the future. Exxon's management, led by CEO Darren W. Woods, has proposed new board members, including a climate expert, but the company has not committed to investing in renewable energy. The outcome of the vote will determine the direction of Exxon's strategy on climate change.

site_title: US dollar hits January lows as inflation jitters ebb
summary: The US dollar hit 4½-month lows against a basket of peers on Tuesday, reaching a low of 6.4016 per US dollar, its strongest level since June 2018. The decline was attributed to the US Federal Reserve's assurance that policy would remain pat, calming inflation concerns. The yuan strengthened past 6.4 to the US dollar, while the US dollar fell against other major currencies.

site_title: Deutsche Bank's nightmare decade is gone, but not yet forgotten
summary: Deutsche Bank, once considered the "sick man" of European finance, appears to be on the mend. In March 2021, the bank received a margin call related to its exposure to Archegos Capital Management, but the situation was not as dire as initially thought. The bank's current woes are largely a relic of the past, and it is poised for a turnaround. Christian Sewing, the bank's CEO, led the response to the margin call and has since overseen efforts to stabilize the bank's finances.

site_title: Metro sees demand for decentralised offices as companies diversify beyond CBD
summary: Metro Holdings, a Singapore property and retail group, sees demand for decentralized office space as companies diversify beyond the central business district. The company's occupancy at its Grade A office towers at Tampines Regional Centre stood at 88.9% as of March 31, 2021, with co-working operator JustCo set to manage a space there from Q3 2021. Metro's retail operations remain challenging, with the company receiving support from the government and landlords during the pandemic. The group also plans to build a larger purpose-built student accommodation portfolio.

site_title: Airborne, droplet or surface transmission: How Covid-19 could have spread in Jem and Westgate
summary: A 53-year-old cleaner at a stay-home notice facility in Singapore is suspected of being a source of infection that led to a community cluster at Westgate and Jem malls. Experts suggest the virus could have spread through airborne transmission or contaminated surfaces, rather than direct contact. The cleaner would have likely been infected at work and then transmitted the virus to others, possibly through respiratory droplets or contaminated surfaces.

images.alt_text: Investigations on how the virus managed to spread and result in clusters at Westgate and Jem as well as Changi Airport are still ongoing, hence it is possible that multiple modes of transmission were involved.

site_title: Grab's base fee hike drives debate over competitiveness
summary: Grab, a dominant ride-hailing company, will increase its base fare by S$1 across all services except Standard Taxi, GrabHitch, and GrabCoach, effective June 1. The move aims to improve driver earnings, but some question the timing. Competitors, such as ComfortDelGro and Gojek, may follow suit, while experts believe the price increase may not significantly impact demand, as the market is already weakened by the pandemic.

site_title: UK's Shaftesbury posts wider half-year loss as pandemic pummels retail
summary: UK retail landlord Shaftesbury reported a wider half-year loss of £338.5 million due to pandemic-related restrictions on non-essential retailers. The company's EPRA net tangible assets plummeted 21.5% to £5.83, and its valuation declined 10.1% to £2.8 billion. Despite this, CEO Brian Bickell said an encouraging increase in demand for space and lettings has been seen since the reopening of indoor areas in April.

site_title: Thailand-made AstraZeneca vaccine to make its debut in June
summary: Thailand's domestically-made AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine is set to debut in June, following significant progress in local production. However, details on the production deal are scarce, raising concerns about the rollout. The UK-based multinational pharmaceutical company, AstraZeneca, confirmed the first batch of the vaccine will be ready for delivery to the Thai government in June.

images.alt_text: Thai PM Prayut Chan-o-cha displaying his certificate of vaccination after receiving his second dose of the AstraZeneca vaccine at Bamrasnaradura Infectious Diseases Institute in Thailand on May 24.

site_title: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine highly effective in 12 to 17 year-old adolescents: study
summary: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine was highly effective in 12- to 17-year-old adolescents, with 93-100% efficacy in preventing symptomatic Covid-19, according to a study. The vaccine met its primary goal of inducing immune responses comparable to those in adults and showed no significant safety concerns. The results are set to be submitted to the US FDA and regulators globally in early June, paving the way for potential authorization for younger teens. This could help broaden the US immunization campaign, but demand for shots has peaked in the US, with daily doses decreasing from over 3 million in mid-April.

site_title: Record bid for Tengah EC site, 15 bids for Ang Mo Kio condo plot signal developers' hunger for land
summary: Developers in Singapore are showing strong interest in land with top bids exceeding market expectations for two 99-year leasehold plots. CDL-MCL Land's joint venture bid a record S$603.17 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) for an executive condominium (EC) development in Tengah, while a UOL-led consortium paid 6.3% above the next highest bid for a private housing plot in Ang Mo Kio, fetching S$1,118 psf ppr. The strong competition reflects developers' positive outlook on demand and dwindling unsold inventory.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end below record high as mining losses offset tech rally
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index ended flat at 445.20 points, despite a record high earlier in the day, as mining stocks fell due to concerns over Chinese markets. Technology stocks rallied 1.3% after a Wall Street rally, while real estate stocks rose 0.4%. The German economy shrank more than expected in the first quarter, but business morale improved. The Stoxx 600 is up 12% this year, largely in line with the S&P 500.

images.alt_text: European stocks closed flat on Tuesday, as a billion-dollar German property deal and a rally in technology shares were offset by losses in major mining stocks due to concerns over Chinese markets.

site_title: Factory output growth eases to 2.1% in April, but analysts unfazed
summary: Singapore's factory output grew 2.1% in April, its sixth consecutive month of growth, driven by the linchpin electronics cluster. The expansion eased from the previous month's 7.6% year-on-year increase and fell short of median estimates. Analysts were unfazed, with UOB economist Barnabas Gan attributing the decline in biomedical manufacturing to a high base print in April 2020. The electronics cluster rose 6.1%, while precision engineering and chemicals output accelerated, with chemicals experiencing its fastest pace of growth since 2015. Despite this, analysts maintained their GDP growth forecasts, citing a cautious outlook due to the ongoing Covid-19 resurgence.

site_title: Smarter and safer cities with effective cybersecurity measures
summary: Governments in South-east Asia are building smart cities with advanced technologies, but these efforts are vulnerable to cyber threats. A recent ransomware attack on the US fuel pipeline operator Colonial Pipeline highlighted the risks of cyberattacks. To mitigate these risks, smart cities should adopt four key strategies: (1) stay ahead with strategic cyber intelligence, (2) fight AI-powered attacks with AI-powered self-defence systems, (3) rethink regulatory environments for cybersecurity, and (4) adopt a people, technology, process, and governance framework. By implementing these measures, smart cities can become smarter and safer, fostering economic growth and bettering citizens' lives.

site_title: Kopiko coffee candy hitting a sweet spot for Mayora
summary: Mayora Indah, Indonesia's largest coffee candy manufacturer, sees a surge in popularity and stock price following a cameo by its product, Kopiko coffee candy, in the hit Korean drama series Vincenzo. The company's savvy product placement has boosted its share price, riding public sentiment. Mayora's success is attributed to its strong products, marketing efforts, and ability to adapt to changing consumer tastes and preferences, with a growth forecast of 20% in 2022. The company's global presence, with Kopiko sold in over 100 countries, further solidifies its position as a leading coffee candy manufacturer.

site_title: China launches antitrust probe into Tencent-backed property broker KE: sources
summary: China's market regulator has launched an investigation into KE Holdings, the country's largest housing broker backed by Tencent Holdings, over suspected anti-competitive practices. KE Holdings was warned by regulators last month to conduct self-inspections and has been accused of forcing real estate developers to list housing information only on its platforms. The investigation follows similar probes into other "platform" companies, including Tencent and Meituan, which have been accused of exploiting consumers. KE Holdings' New York-listed shares fell nearly 10% in pre-market trading after the Reuters report.

images.alt_text: The regulator has been investigating if KE Holdings forces real estate developers to list housing information only on its platforms, which includes Lianjia and Beike.

site_title: Timely for CityDev to launch a UK Reit?
summary: CityDev's planned UK Reit listing may be welcomed by investors following CDL's recent struggles, including a net loss of S$1.92 billion for the full year ended Dec 31, 2020. The group's hotel business saw a 52% year-on-year decline in revenue per available room globally. CDL's Reit listing could provide a fresh start for the struggling property heavyweight.

site_title: Data centre Reits navigate growth amid competing forces
summary: Data centre Reits navigate growth amid competing forces, with expansion relying on acquisition firepower and keen interest in building assets from scratch. The three Reits in Singapore, Keppel DC Reit, Ascendas Reit, and Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT), have seen significant growth, with total unitholder returns ranging from 70% to 214% over the past five years. As the market tightens, Reit sponsors may look to develop data centres from scratch, and investors should watch their lease mix to mitigate risks. Analysts also suggest that emerging markets like India and Europe present opportunities for acquisitions.

site_title: Rosy and thorny for two shipping industries
summary: Container shipping companies are experiencing a surge in profits due to the pandemic-driven shift in consumption habits and supply-chain disruptions. The industry's operating margin reached 13.0% in 2020, with estimated profits of US$26.6 billion. However, experts predict that this upswing will be short-lived, with demand and supply chains expected to return to normal in the next two years. For shippers and hauliers, the situation is less rosy, with freight rates expected to remain high and consumers ultimately bearing the costs. Digitalization is seen as a key solution to relieve supply-chain bottlenecks, with platforms like Haulio aiming to uplift the lives of haulers and drivers through technology.

site_title: World Class Global gets nod to delist if takeover approved by shareholders, court
summary: World Class Global has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) to delist if its proposed takeover is approved by shareholders and sanctioned by the court. The frontline regulator has allowed the delisting in principle, pending a court hearing on May 27 to hold a scheme meeting.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Boustead Projects reported record earnings for the second half of 2021, driven by the divestment of 14 properties to an industrial fund. The company will reward shareholders with a special dividend of 14.5 Singapore cents and a final dividend of 0.9 cent.

site_title: Tesla sets up China site to store data locally
summary: Tesla has established a data storage site in China to store data from its vehicles sold in the country, following growing concerns over data security and privacy. This move comes as China drafts rules to ensure the security of data from connected vehicles. The company's decision is seen as a response to security concerns, including staff at government offices being told not to park Tesla cars due to security risks from vehicle cameras. This is Tesla's first major move to address data storage concerns in China, the world's largest car market.

site_title: US consumer confidence falls as job, income prospects ebb
summary: US consumer confidence fell to 117.2 in May, the first decline this year, as Americans became less optimistic about future job and income prospects. The Conference Board's index remained steady despite a three-month low in economic expectations and a pandemic high in sentiment about current conditions. Fewer people expect more jobs in the next six months, while a gauge of current conditions rose to 144.3.

site_title: Asean's new digital banks will be valued like traditional banks, not pure Internet plays: report
summary: New digital banks in ASEAN will be valued like traditional banks, not pure internet plays, according to a report by Citi. The report notes that while these digital banks may start with optimistic internet valuations, they will converge to traditional bank valuations over time due to regulatory requirements and high costs. Citi has initiated "buy" calls on Grab-Singtel and Sea, with target prices of S$3.44 and US$300, respectively. The launch of new digital banks will impact the banking landscape and earnings/ROE outlook for incumbent banks, with potential losers being non-bank financial companies, particularly in Indonesia.

site_title: The secret psychology of sneaker colours
summary: Athletic shoe companies such as Adidas, Reebok, and New Balance are leveraging colour theory to create desired emotions and drive business. By manipulating colour combinations, they aim to stop traffic online and create buzz around limited-edition collectibles. Research shows that 70-90% of subconscious judgment on a product is made in a few seconds on colour alone, with colours triggering emotions such as excitement or calmness. Brands are experimenting with new colour combinations, including pastels, neon hues, and metallic tones, to evoke feelings of energy and positivity, and to tap into cultural associations and nostalgia.

site_title: Hong Kong may soon toss millions of unused Covid-19 vaccine doses
summary: Hong Kong is at risk of discarding millions of unused Covid-19 vaccine doses due to low vaccination rates and distrust in the government. With only 19% of the population having received one dose and 14% having received two doses, the city's 7.5 million doses of Pfizer-BioNTech and Sinovac vaccines are approaching their expiry date. The government has warned that unused doses will be wasted, and new shipments are unlikely to be delivered. The city's vaccine task force has called for improved vaccination efforts to avoid wasting the vaccines.

site_title: HDB launches over 3,800 BTO flats; 2,500 balance flats also on offer
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,879 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats across four projects in Singapore, with 2,494 flats also available through the Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) scheme. The smallest BTO project is in Bukit Merah, with 175 three-room and four-room flats starting from S$419,000 and S$602,000 respectively. The projects are estimated to be completed in 2025 and 2027, with prices ranging from S$113,000 to S$602,000. Analysts predict high demand for the Bukit Merah and Geylang projects, with some expecting over 10 applicants for each available flat.

site_title: 5 investment pitfalls even veterans should beware
summary: Veteran investors are not immune to common mistakes, including falling into the "value trap," holding onto losing positions, selling winners too early, and buying into false promises. A value trap occurs when an investment appears cheap but is actually undervalued. Holding onto a losing position can lead to self-deception and permanent losses. Selling winners too early can result in missing out on future growth. Buying into false promises can lead to investing in companies that fail to deliver. Downplaying risks can also lead to overlooking potential declines. Recognizing these pitfalls and constantly learning and growing is key to becoming a smart investor.

site_title: How global tax changes can impact Singapore's intellectual property ecosystem
summary: Singapore aims to strengthen its position as a global hub for intellectual property (IP) transactions through the Singapore IP Strategy (SIPS) 2030, launched on World IP Day. The strategy seeks to support international activities, attract and grow innovative enterprises, and build a high-calibre workforce. However, the evolving international tax developments pose a challenge to companies seeking to extract full value from their IP and intangible assets. The Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project aims to align the value derived from IP to where the key functions in the IP lifecycle are undertaken, requiring companies to adapt to new global tax rules to avoid eroded margins.

images.alt_text: Every product or service originates from an idea - a creation of the human mind.

site_title: Three students, pre-schooler and Sengkang General Hospital staff among 18 new Covid-19 community cases
summary: Singapore reported 30 new community COVID-19 cases, including three students, a pre-schooler, and a hospital staff member, on May 25. The cases were linked to various clusters, with 15 cases unlinked. The total number of cases in the community increased from 163 to 176 in the past week, while the number of unlinked cases decreased from 37 to 30. There were also nine imported cases on stay-home notice, bringing the total number of cases to 61,890.

site_title: World trade is waiting for Biden to reverse Trump's policies
summary: US President Joe Biden has yet to reverse former President Donald Trump's damaging trade policies, which have shaken America's reputation and future prospects domestically and internationally. Trump's protectionist measures, including tariffs and trade wars, have hindered the US ability to achieve broader economic and foreign-policy goals. Reversing these policies is crucial for the new administration to repair the damage done to critical institutions like the WTO and promote a broader range of economic and foreign-policy goals.

site_title: With events in limbo, Singapore's top golfer Gregory Foo does part-time teaching
summary: Singapore's top golfer, Gregory Foo, is balancing his professional golf career with part-time teaching due to the Covid-19 pandemic's impact on the local golf schedule. Foo, 27, teaches at Tanah Merah Country Club and joins other professionals to supplement his income. He aims to eventually compete in Challenger events in the region, Europe, or the US. Foo's schedule allows for 30-40 hours of teaching per week, prioritizing his own practice sessions and playing time.

site_title: US home prices surge most since 2005, fuelled by bidding wars
summary: US home prices surged 13.2% in March, the largest gain since December 2005, driven by a shortage of properties and bidding wars. This follows a 12% jump in February. The real estate market has seen a surge in demand for suburban homes, with low mortgage rates fueling the rally. Experts attribute the trend to Covid-19, which may have accelerated purchases that would have happened over the next few years.

site_title: Bitcoiners waving eco-friendly credentials are betting on a premium
summary: Bitcoin miners and companies are shifting towards eco-friendly credentials to capitalize on growing demand for environmentally friendly investments. With companies pledging to cut carbon emissions and governments setting tough carbon goals, investors are seeking out renewable energy-based Bitcoin mining. Some miners are using renewable energy sources, while others are exploring innovative methods such as using idle computer processing power. The market for green Bitcoin is expected to command a premium of up to 10%, with companies like DMG Blockchain Solutions and Gather mining crypto using renewable energy sources.

images.alt_text: A natural gas generator powering a Bitcoin mining data centre on an oil field in North Texas. Today, only about 55-65 per cent of total Bitcoin mining is done using renewable energy.

site_title: Retirement adequacy amid the pandemic
summary: The article discusses retirement adequacy in Singapore, particularly for the "sandwich class" of middle-income households. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, retirement benefits are likely to be reduced globally, and Singaporeans are not spared. To mitigate this, experts recommend starting to save and plan for retirement early, even if it's just a few decades away. Key steps include building emergency savings, diversifying investments, and getting educated on personal finance. The author also warns against making excuses for not saving and putting all eggs into a few baskets. Ultimately, individuals must take responsibility for their own retirement planning to ensure a secure future.

site_title: Vallianz Holdings expects red ink for financial year 2021
summary: Vallianz Holdings expects to report a loss for the financial year ended March 2021, as it finalizes its financial results and will disclose details on May 30. The offshore vessel support group's counter ended flat before the profit guidance was released.

site_title: China's tourism spend will dry up if travel curbs last for years: Barclays
summary: China's travel spending, a significant contributor to global tourism, is expected to dry up for years due to ongoing travel restrictions. The Barclays report warns that countries reliant on Chinese tourists, such as Thailand and Vietnam, will be severely affected, with emerging economies facing a long-term disruption. Global mobility, accounting for 10% of GDP, may not return to pre-pandemic levels until 2026, with a starker divide between developed and developing economies emerging. The report highlights the challenges of vaccine passports, uneven vaccination rates, and the need for countries to open their borders simultaneously to restore travel.

site_title: US: Optimism over reopening economy boosts stocks
summary: US stocks rose early Tuesday, driven by optimism over the reopening economy, despite inflation concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 added 0.1% and 0.4% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.4%. Analysts point to a pullback in the 10-year US Treasury yield as a sign that inflation worries are easing. The market remains cautious, but a "tentative calm" has settled in, with many expecting a gradual return to growth. Moderna's positive Covid-19 vaccine trial results also boosted the tech-rich Nasdaq.

site_title: Get vaccines to where they're really needed
summary: A global alliance, Covax, is shortchanging countries in desperate need of Covid-19 vaccines by allocating doses proportionally by population. This approach is ethically wrong, as it prioritizes countries with few cases or limited capacity to distribute vaccines over those hit hardest by the pandemic. Covax must abandon its population-based distribution formula and prioritize countries based on need, distribution capacity, and risk. The organization's current approach has led to precious vaccine doses being destroyed or left unused in countries with few cases or limited ability to distribute them effectively, while others with high risks have received inadequate doses.

images.alt_text: As the global supply of vaccines expands, vaccine manufacturers and nations expecting to have extra doses, including the US and Britain, must decide which countries to help and how many doses to send to global organisations like Covax.

site_title: Bank of England to step up drive to encourage new insurers
summary: The Bank of England plans to step up efforts to attract new insurers to the UK market, taking advantage of the post-Brexit opportunity to tailor rules to the UK's needs. According to Anna Sweeney, the BoE's executive director for insurance supervision, Brexit allows Britain to set its own direction, enabling the sector to refashion itself and attract more new entrants while maintaining high regulatory standards. This move aims to strengthen the UK's globally important insurance sector.

site_title: Sarine Technologies targets lab grown diamonds segment in partnership with Constell Group
summary: Sarine Technologies, a diamond technology firm, has entered a strategic collaboration with the Constell Group to target the rapidly growing lab-grown diamonds segment. The partnership aims to provide technological solutions and competitive pricing for customers. Sarine will process stones and be paid for each processed stone, regardless of technologies applied. The collaboration seeks to optimize and streamline the polishing process, ensuring a "verifiably sustainable supply" of diamonds. The partnership is expected to increase the realized value of lab-grown diamonds through the application of Sarine's advanced technological solutions.

site_title: Beijing-backed firm bags Sri Lanka's foreign highway contract
summary: A state-backed Chinese firm, China Harbour Engineering Company (CHEC), has been awarded a contract to build a 17-kilometre, four-lane highway in Colombo, Sri Lanka, by the country's Cabinet. The project is expected to be completed in three years and operated by CHEC for 15 years before being transferred back to Sri Lanka. This move is seen as a boost for Beijing as it competes with other regional powers for influence in the island nation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks rebound as inflation fears fade
summary: South Korean stocks rebounded 0.86% on Tuesday, snapping a three-day losing streak, as inflation worries eased and foreign investors resumed buying shares. The Kospi benchmark closed at 3,171.32, with heavyweights like Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, and Naver rising. Foreign investors bought $60.91 million worth of shares, ending a nine-day selling run. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates at record lows for the rest of 2021 due to economic recovery concerns.

site_title: 10 ways for museums to survive and thrive in a post-Covid world
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has severely impacted museums in the US, with earned revenue dropping to near-zero and philanthropy failing to fill the gap. Many museums have been forced to slash their programming and payroll, with some considering selling off works from their collections. The pandemic also intensified outrage against racism and discrimination in museums, leading to the resignation of several high-profile curators and directors. To survive and thrive, museums must adapt and innovate, potentially exploring new revenue streams and prioritizing digital engagement to reach audiences in a post-pandemic world.

site_title: Architecture and Building Services tradeshow in Singapore moved to November amid pandemic
summary: The Architecture and Building Services 2021 trade show in Singapore has been postponed from June to November due to tightened measures and restrictions under Phase 2 (Heightened Alert). The event, originally scheduled for June 30 to July 2, will now take place in November with a hybrid format, combining on-site and virtual elements. The decision prioritizes public health and follows consultation with the Singapore Tourism Board. The event aims to remain a "first-choice hub" for international conferences and exhibitions, with organizers hopeful that the situation will improve by November.

site_title: Google sees sweeping German antitrust probes into data terms
summary: Germany's Federal Cartel Office has started two investigations into Google's market power and data collection practices, citing a "strategic advantage" from the information it collects. The probes focus on Google's data processing terms and whether users have sufficient choice over how their data is used. This marks the biggest Google probe in the region since the European Union's 2019 investigations, which resulted in $9 billion in fines. Google has stated it will cooperate fully with the authority, while the probe's outcome may impact the company's business model of tracking users online for advertising.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang FY2021 earnings more than double; proposes higher special dividend
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates' FY2021 earnings more than doubled to S$189.4 million, driven by higher profit from development projects and lower borrowing costs. The company proposes a special dividend of 29 Singapore cents, up from seven cents last year, and a final dividend of four Singapore cents. Earnings per share rose 149% to 73.17 cents, while net asset value per share increased to S$5.73.

site_title: Singapore draws S$2.8 billion in fixed asset investments in Q1
summary: Singapore drew S$2.8 billion in fixed asset investments in the first quarter of 2021, with the services sector contributing the largest amount. Despite this, challenges such as global economic and domestic factors are emerging, including resource constraints and increasing focus on carbon. The investments are expected to generate S$7.5 billion of value-added and create over 3,700 jobs. US investors accounted for the largest share, followed by European investors, with the Economic Development Board working to attract investors despite these challenges.

site_title: Vaccine inequity only prolongs the pandemic; wealthy nations must step up
summary: Wealthy nations must step up efforts to address vaccine inequity, which is prolonging the COVID-19 pandemic in poorer economies. Despite Covax's global rollout, the organization has fallen short of its goal of 2 billion doses by end-2021, with only 70 million doses distributed to 125 countries as of May. The pandemic's resurgence in these countries is crippling healthcare systems and economies, highlighting the need for increased vaccine access and distribution.

site_title: Airlines start shunning Belarus; opposition leader says journalist tortured
summary: Airlines have started shunning Belarus's airspace amid international outrage over Minsk forcing down a jetliner and arresting a dissident journalist, Roman Protasevich. A video released showed Protasevich confessing to organizing anti-government demonstrations, with opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya claiming he was tortured. European air traffic control agency Eurocontrol recommended re-routing flights over Belarus, and several airlines, including Lufthansa and Singapore Airlines, have halted flights. The EU and Ukraine have also announced bans on flights to or from Belarus, and French President Emmanuel Macron has invited the Belarusian opposition to meet Group of Seven leaders. Belarus denies abusing detainees and claims the incident was a response to a bomb scare.

site_title: Thailand unveils US$16b borrowing to fund Covid-19 relief
summary: Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn has endorsed a $16 billion borrowing plan to fund COVID-19 relief measures, despite the amount being less than the Cabinet's initial approval. The plan aims to support small- and medium-size enterprises and individuals affected by the outbreak, adding 1.5 percentage points to the country's GDP. The borrowing will be staggered to avoid crowding out private borrowers and will be managed with prudence to maintain fiscal stability.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP's upside surprise muted by Covid-19 resurgence, outlook to remain
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP growth surpassed expectations at 1.3% year-over-year, despite a resurgence of COVID-19 cases. This data was initially seen as a reason to upgrade the 2021 growth outlook, but economists now consider it a "wait-and-see" approach. The Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained its 4-6% full-year growth target, and a "wait-and-see" stance is expected for the economic outlook.

site_title: Australia: Shares end at a two-week high
summary: Australian shares closed at a two-week high, ending 0.98% higher at 7,115.2 on the S&P/ASX 200 index. The gain was driven by heavyweight miners gaining on firmer iron ore prices and financial stocks tracking US peers higher. This marks a positive finish for a fourth straight session.

site_title: EU expects more than a billion Covid-19 shots by end of September
summary: The European Union expects to receive over 1 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses by the end of September, according to a document presented to EU leaders. This exceeds the initial goal of immunizing 70% of the adult population by the end of summer. The EU expects to receive 413 million doses in the second quarter and 529 million in the July-September period from four drugmakers, including Pfizer-BioNTech and AstraZeneca. The total expected doses by the end of the year are 1.5 billion, with the EU also planning to share 100 million doses with poorer nations outside the bloc.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Q1 GDP showed an upside surprise, but the outlook remains muted due to a Covid-19 resurgence. The country's trade sector is expected to continue growing due to demand for semiconductors. Meanwhile, Grab is raising its base fare by S$1 from June, while a ST Telemedia unit formed a joint venture with Temasek and Triputra to expand Indonesian data centre operations. The STI rose 0.7% as investors took a positive view of macroeconomic data.

site_title: Upgraded trade forecasts can't lift GDP outlook, as services drag on virus measures
summary: Singapore's trade sector is expected to continue growing, with upgraded forecasts predicting a 1-3% year-on-year growth in non-oil domestic exports (NODX) and a 5-7% rise in total merchandise trade. However, the broader economic outlook remains unchanged at 4-6% GDP growth, as the services sector is still expected to be impacted by Covid-19 measures. Analysts attribute the revised forecasts to stronger-than-expected semiconductor demand and optimistic GDP forecasts for the US and China.

site_title: Support system launched to help marine and offshore engineering industry go digital
summary: A new support system, the Marine And Offshore Engineering Industry Digital Plan (IDP), has been launched to help Singaporean marine and offshore engineering enterprises digitalize. Developed by Enterprise Singapore and the Infocomm Media Development Authority, the IDP provides digital roadmaps and training plans for industry players. The plan aims to benefit approximately 1,000 enterprises, helping them streamline operations and maximize productivity through digital tools. Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling emphasized the importance of digitalization in making businesses more resilient and adaptable to changing market conditions.

site_title: Singapore Airlines reroutes Europe flights to avoid Belarus airspace
summary: Singapore Airlines is rerouting its Europe-bound flights to avoid Belarusian airspace following the forced landing of a Ryanair flight in Minsk on May 23, where opposition journalist Roman Protasevich was arrested. The airline aims to minimize potential disruption to its operations.

site_title: KL train crash: Test train was going in the wrong direction
summary: A test train in Kuala Lumpur's Light Rail Transit system collided with another train traveling in the opposite direction, resulting in 213 injuries, including 47 serious ones, with no fatalities reported. The investigation suggests the driver of the test train was traveling in the wrong direction, contrary to automated train protocols. A task force will be formed to determine the cause of the collision, which is the first head-on collision in the system's 23-year history.

site_title: JTC launches site at Jalan Papan for application
summary: JTC launched an industrial site at Jalan Papan (Plot 9) for application under the 2021 industrial government land sales (IGLS) programme. The 1.01-hectare site has a 20-year tenure, gross plot ratio of 1.4, and is zoned B2 for heavy industrial use. Applications can be submitted by June 30, 2021, at 11am, with a tenderer's packet available for purchase online at S$107. This is the last of three reserve list sites for the first half of the IGLS programme.

site_title: Wagamama owner says sales near pre-pandemic levels since UK outdoor dining resumed
summary: Restaurant Group Plc, owner of Wagamama and Frankie & Benny's, reported that sales from outdoor dining at its chains are near pre-pandemic levels, with about 85% of 2019 levels in the five weeks to May 16. This comes as Britons stepped out to meet after months of lockdown. The company also saw a surge in orders during the lockdown, with average standalone delivery and takeaway sales at Wagamama tripling and leisure unit sales increasing five times. Despite uncertainty, Restaurant Group has over £200m in cash to protect against a resurgence of the virus.

site_title: Europe: Equity markets ahead at open
summary: European stocks opened higher on Tuesday, driven by easing inflation fears and a healthy rally on Wall Street. London's FTSE 100 index rose 0.1% to 7,059.76 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index gained 0.8% to 15,554.45 points. The gains followed a long holiday weekend in Frankfurt and came as traders took heart from the global economic recovery outlook.

site_title: Why climate-based goals are starting to appeal to businesses: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore's Minister for Sustainability and the Environment, Grace Fu, notes that countries are increasingly adopting climate-based approaches, with significant net-zero announcements from nations like the UK, Japan, China, and the US. Fu emphasizes the need for international cooperation, partnerships, and knowledge sharing among governments, businesses, and organizations to address climate change while balancing economic growth and recovery. The preservation of tropical forests in South-east Asia can generate up to $46 billion worth of carbon credits annually, and a new global marketplace for high-quality carbon credits is set to launch in Singapore by the end of this year.

site_title: OUE C-Reit prices S$150 million offering of 3.95% notes due 2026
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) has priced a S$150 million offering of 3.95% notes due 2026, to be guaranteed by DBS Trustee. The net proceeds will be used to refinance existing borrowings and working capital requirements. The notes will mature on June 2, 2026, with semi-annual interest payments, and can be redeemed by the issuer on any interest payment date. The offering is under OUE C-Reit's S$2 billion multi-currency debt scheme, with CIMB Singapore, DBS, OCBC, and Standard Chartered serving as joint lead managers and bookrunners.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose six points to 1,577.82 on Tuesday, with a total of 6.335 billion lots traded worth RM3.84 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 582 to 464.

site_title: Malaysia Covid-19 spike may spark 'vertical surge,' warns health chief
summary: Malaysia's COVID-19 cases are following an exponential trend since April, with health director-general Noor Hisham Abdullah warning of a potential "vertical surge." The nation is preparing for the worst, urging people to comply with new measures requiring most government officials and 40% of private sector staff to work from home. The exponential growth may lead to a significant increase in infections, highlighting the need for collective action to break the chain of infection.

site_title: STI up 0.7% as upbeat macroeconomic data lifts investor sentiment
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index rose 0.7% to 3,146.09, driven by upbeat macroeconomic data, including a 1.3% year-on-year growth in the first quarter and a 9.7% increase in non-oil domestic exports. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC were among the biggest gainers. Aviation-related stocks recovered after Monday's losses, while Malaysia-based Southern Alliance Mining was the biggest loser. Markets in other Asian countries, such as Thailand and South Korea, also saw gains.
