site_title: UK must hasten crypto rules to win business, lobby group says
summary: The UK needs to hasten crypto rules to win business and attract companies, according to TheCityUK, a lobby group for the finance industry. Nearly 10 million people in Britain own digital assets, with the UK's G-7 presidency providing a platform to lead oversight and coordination. The group urges swift and nuanced regulation to avoid deterring innovation, citing market perceptions that the UK is trailing behind other countries. Clarity on crypto regulation will determine firms' appetites to launch products and services in the UK.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.75% on Tuesday, following a strong Wall Street lead, as investor concerns about inflation shifted to optimism about the global recovery outlook. The Hang Seng Index increased to 28,910.86, while the Shanghai Composite Index jumped 2.40% to 3,581.34. This Asia-wide advance comes despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: SingHaiyi sinks into the red with S$8.7m H2 net loss
summary: SingHaiyi Group, a real estate developer, reported a net loss of S$8.7 million for the second half of 2021, with a loss per share of 0.207 Singapore cent. Revenue more than doubled to S$102.3 million, driven by recognition from two Singapore condominiums. For the full year, the group's net loss widened to S$13.3 million, with no dividend declared due to the net loss.

site_title: Crypto carnage, and a cautionary tale
summary: Cryptocurrency markets experienced a recent downturn, with bitcoin's value plummeting over 50% from its April peak. The volatility is attributed to the lack of intrinsic value, driven by demand and supply, and the absence of central authority. Manipulation is also a concern due to anonymity on cryptocurrency exchanges and the influence of high-profile figures like Elon Musk. Leverage trading in the crypto market amplifies risks, and the industry's carbon footprint is substantial, with bitcoin mining consuming more electricity than some countries. Despite this, financial institutions continue to explore digital currency investments, highlighting the ongoing regulatory and environmental challenges in the crypto sector.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin hit record highs after Tesla said it had invested US$1.5 billion in the cryptocurrency and BNY Mellon said it would help clients hold, transfer, and issue digital assets.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio 99-year private housing plot draws 15 bids; Tengah EC plot, seven bids
summary: A 99-year leasehold private housing site in Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 drew 15 bids, with the highest offer of S$381.38 million or S$1,118 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) from a joint venture between UOL Group, Singapore Land Group, and Kheong Leong Company. The site is near the Mayflower MRT station and will feature a 24-25 storey project with over 370 units. Meanwhile, a 99-year plot in the Tengah estate drew seven bids, with the highest offer of S$400.32 million or S$603.17 psf ppr from a tie-up between CDL and MCL Land.

images.alt_text: A 99-year leasehold private housing site in Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1, sited opposite the Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park, has drawn 15 bids at a state tender that closed on Tuesday.

site_title: ST Telemedia unit forms JV with Temasek, Triputra to grow Indonesian data centre operations
summary: ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC) formed a joint venture with Temasek and Triputra Group to develop a new data centre in Jakarta, Indonesia. The first campus will be built in Kota Deltamas, supporting up to 72 megawatts of IT capacity. Construction is expected to start in the coming months, with completion anticipated by early 2023. This partnership aims to grow Indonesian data centre operations, capitalizing on the country's growing demand for IT infrastructure.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher for fourth day
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for the fourth consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 0.7% and the Topix index up 0.3%. The gains followed Wall Street's tech shares rallying as long-term yields sank. The benchmark indices ended at 28,553.98 and 1,919.52, respectively. This follows a rally in Singapore stocks for a fifth day and comes as investors brush off new US President Trump's threats, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records.

site_title: Coronavirus hit on German economy bigger than expected in first quarter
summary: The German economy contracted by 1.8% in the first quarter of 2021, surpassing expectations, due to coronavirus-related curbs on private consumption. On a year-over-year basis, the gross domestic product contracted by 3.1%. This marks a larger-than-expected decline, contrary to a Reuters poll that predicted a 1.7% quarterly contraction and 3.0% yearly decline.

images.alt_text: The German economy shrank by a bigger than expected 1.8 per cent on the quarter in the first three months of the year as coronavirus curbs crushed private consumption in Europe's largest economy, data showed on Tuesday.

site_title: No commodities 'super-cycle' but copper demand from green economy bright
summary: Commodities experts disagree on a "super-cycle" for the next few years, with only 6.49% of a polled audience predicting such a trend. Instead, they point to the green economy's growing demand for metals like copper, nickel, and lithium, driven by the energy transition and renewable energy sectors. Copper demand is expected to be strong, with infrastructure and new energy vehicle markets driving growth, and a potential deficit forecast for 2024-2025. Experts also expect liquidity and inflation to play a significant role in commodity markets.

site_title: Greenwashers can't hide forever, top Australian ESG fund says
summary: Top Australian ESG fund manager Nathan Hughes warns that greenwashing by companies will eventually be exposed, as his fund has returned 45% over the past year, beating 95% of peers, by engaging with companies on environmental, social, and governance goals. The fund excludes investments in firms with ties to fossil fuels, tobacco, and weapons, and focuses on companies with meaningful net-zero plans, including Australia's top banks, which have undergone significant changes since the Royal Commission. Hughes aims to hold companies accountable for achieving net-zero targets, with near-term meaningful targets.

site_title: Indonesia may tax the rich, top polluters for more state revenue
summary: Indonesia's finance ministry proposes tax reforms to increase state revenue, aiming to reduce the budget deficit and debt ratio. The proposed changes include a carbon tax on polluters, a new 35% income tax bracket for high-income individuals, and multiple tiers for value-added taxes. Additionally, the government is finalizing a formula to tax digital companies and considering another tax amnesty program to collect unpaid taxes. The goal is to sustain the state budget and keep the deficit within the 3% limit of GDP.

site_title: Cicada sushi, anyone? US chef serves up sustainable 'Brood X' delicacy
summary: US chef Bun Lai hosted a cicada hunt and cookout in a Washington city park, promoting sustainable food methods amidst the "Brood X" cicada invasion. The event aimed to discuss alternative farming and eating practices, as the cicadas' emergence was seen as a rare opportunity. Locals harvested and prepared cicadas as a side dish, with some finding the experience "delightfully surprising" and the cicadas "tasty." The chef emphasized the need for a revolutionary approach to eating to address diet-related diseases, while cautioning against over-reliance on cicadas as a food source.

site_title: UK kicks off fiscal year with S$60b budget deficit
summary: The UK reported a 31.7 billion-pound budget deficit (S$59.9 billion) in April, in line with economists' median forecast. This marks a significant improvement from the 47.3 billion pounds deficit in April last year. Chancellor Rishi Sunak faces a challenge to balance the deficit, with borrowing expected to total over 200 billion pounds this fiscal year. The UK's debt rose to 2.17 trillion pounds, or 98.5% of economic output, and Sunak aims to bring debt under control over the medium term while driving a strong economy recovery.

site_title: Demand for decentralised offices as companies diversify outside CBD: Metro
summary: Metro Holdings sees growing demand for decentralized office space in Singapore, driven by companies diversifying outside the central business district. The company's Grade A office towers at Tampines Regional Centre have seen occupancy at 88.9% as of March 31, 2021, with potential interest from financial services and logistics sectors. Metro's retail operations continue to face challenges, but the company remains optimistic with plans to build a bigger purpose-built student accommodation portfolio. Net profit rose 50% year-over-year to S$16.97 million, despite a 25.7% slide in revenue.

site_title: London's West End is coming back to life, says major landlord
summary: London's West End is experiencing a revival, with Shaftesbury Plc's vacancy rate decreasing from 11.9% to around 6-7% since the start of re-opening on April 12. Demand for empty stores and eateries is increasing, and footfall and spending are returning to the area. The company's CEO, Brian Bickell, notes that a broad-based economy is now underway in the West End, which was severely impacted by the pandemic. Shaftesbury has collected half of the rent owed for the year, helping to reduce the value of its portfolio by £342.6 million.

images.alt_text: Life is returning to the shops and restaurants of London's West End, says one of the district's largest landlords.

site_title: Singapore factory output posts sixth straight month of growth; up 2.1% in April: EDB
summary: Singapore's factory output posted its sixth consecutive month of growth in April, rising 2.1% from the previous year, according to the Economic Development Board (EDB). This growth was driven by the electronics cluster, which increased 6.1% and precision engineering, which grew 20.4%. The biomedical manufacturing segment declined 22.7%, while transport engineering expanded 19% and general manufacturing output rose 18%. The growth eased from the 7.6% increase in March and fell short of the median estimate of 3.5%.

site_title: Shepherd hailed as hero in deadly China ultramarathon race
summary: A Chinese shepherd, Zhu Keming, has been hailed as a hero after saving six stricken runners during a 100-kilometer ultramarathon in Gansu province. The event turned deadly due to extreme weather, with 21 competitors dying. Zhu, who was grazing his sheep, took shelter in a cave and rescued the runners by massaging their frozen hands and feet, carrying them to safety, and providing warmth. He regrets not being able to save others who succumbed to hypothermia. Authorities have ordered sports competitions to improve safety in light of the tragedy.

site_title: New Icelandic airline plans June launch after two-year hiatus
summary: Iceland is set to welcome a new airline, Play Air, launching flights to seven European cities on June 24, after a two-year hiatus. The startup, founded by former Wow Air executives, aims to capitalize on Iceland's recovery and inclusion on the UK's green list for quarantine-free travel. Play Air plans to raise up to $20 million through a rapid listing and will initially operate one Airbus A321neo jet, with plans to expand to US routes and a fleet of four jets by the end of the year.

site_title: Sakae clarifies what it meant by 'close collaboration' with SGX's regulatory arm
summary: Sakae Holdings has clarified its statement regarding a "close collaboration" with the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo). SGX questioned the meaning of the term, as it stated that the company had not collaborated on any work. Sakae clarified that the statement was meant to convey a positive working relationship, not a specific collaborative project.

site_title: Tax hikes pose risks to Indonesia's GDP and inflation outlook: Citi
summary: Indonesia's proposed tax hikes could pose a downside risk to its GDP growth and upside risk to inflation in 2022, according to a Citi Research report. The tax reforms aim to boost revenues and reduce the budget deficit, but may disproportionately affect households and consumers, potentially restraining household consumption. The report estimates that a 5% increase in the blended VAT rate could lead to 1% higher CPI inflation, potentially reaching the upper bound of Bank Indonesia's 2-4% inflation target.

site_title: Green groups slam UK bank links to carbon emissions
summary: Greenpeace and the UK arm of the World Wildlife Fund have criticized the UK financial sector for its significant carbon emissions, which exceeded the net annual output of most countries in 2019. A study found that banks and asset managers in the UK financed 805 million tonnes of carbon dioxide, making the sector the ninth biggest emitter of CO2. Green groups are calling for legislation to force banks to align their financing activities with the Paris accord's goals of limiting global temperature increase to 1.5C by 2050.

site_title: Indonesian brands bank on BTS, Song Joong Ki, to win on home ground
summary: Indonesian brands are leveraging the popularity of K-pop stars BTS and Blackpink to promote their products domestically. The K-pop industry has generated $564.24 million in exports in 2018, and its influence is spreading globally. Indonesian brands like Tokopedia and Mayora, which produces Kopiko coffee candy, are partnering with K-pop idols to reach their young audience. Song Joong Ki, a Korean actor, has endorsed Kopiko in the Netflix series Vincenzo, and his Instagram posts drew attention from Indonesian fans. This "glocalization" strategy aims to promote global brands to local tastes, with potential success in Indonesia's large youth population.

site_title: Swedish minister targets 'horrendous' wealth gap between sexes
summary: Sweden's minister for gender equality, Marta Stenevi, is targeting a "horrendous" wealth gap between the sexes, citing a 30% difference in retirement income between men and women. The gap has remained unchanged over the past decade, with the European Commission estimating no country is on track to achieve gender equality by 2030. Sweden's government has appointed a commission to address the issue, focusing on salaries and public fund distribution. The minister also highlighted the lack of racial equality, stating that the situation is even worse for women of color.

site_title: Huawei CEO calls for push into software to weather US pressure
summary: Huawei CEO Ren Zhengfei has called for the company to aggressively push into software development as part of its diversification strategy to weather US sanctions. The move aims to give Huawei autonomy in its future development and counter US control. Following US curbs, Huawei has vowed to develop its own smartphone operating system and expand into enterprise and cloud computing. Ren outlined an ambitious plan to develop software that adapts to and embraces the world, with the company having ample resources to support the effort.

site_title: Asean's new digital banks will be valued like traditional banks, not pure Internet plays: report
summary: ASEAN's new digital banks, initially valued like internet startups, are expected to converge to traditional bank valuations over time, according to a Citi report. Licensed banks are subject to strict capital and regulatory requirements, limiting scalability and growth. This difference in model contributes to digital banks' early struggles with high costs and potential losses. As these startups mature, they are likely to adopt more traditional banking practices and valuations, similar to established financial institutions.

site_title: China's commodity markets hear mixed message in price crackdown
summary: China's commodity markets are receiving mixed signals from the government, with Premier Li Keqiang urging stronger imports and storage while also cracking down on price hikes. The contradictory directives highlight the government's delicate balance between controlling inflation and maintaining economic growth. Despite initial warnings, copper prices rebounded after the China's warning on high prices, with some analysts believing China's reach may be limited in tightly supplied markets like copper. The government's efforts to curb price rises may not be enough to slow down China's growth.

site_title: Top Global privatisation offer turns unconditional
summary: Top Global's voluntary conditional cash offer to acquire the company has turned unconditional after receiving valid acceptances for 90.28% of shares. The offeror, SW Investment Holding, now holds over 90% of voting rights, allowing it to proceed without conditions. The offer price of S$0.39 per share marginally exceeded the volume-weighted average price of the shares. The offer will remain open until June 28, after which the counter will be delisted due to the public float falling below 10%.

site_title: Hack, disinform, deny: Russia's cybersecurity strategy
summary: Russia's cybersecurity strategy revolves around hacking, disinformation, and denial. The country has a history of cyberattacks, with alleged groups such as Fancy Bear and the SVR targeting the US, Europe, and other nations. Russia's military intelligence and security services are suspected of sponsoring these attacks, which have included manipulating elections, sabotaging critical infrastructure, and discrediting opponents. The Kremlin has consistently denied involvement, while also proposing cooperation on cybersecurity, but experts believe Russia may use hacking to force the West to cooperate.

site_title: Hong Kong could soon bin millions of unused vaccine doses
summary: Hong Kong faces a potential vaccine waste crisis due to low inoculation rates and approaching expiry dates. The city has secured more than enough doses for its 7.5 million population, but distrust and online misinformation have hindered vaccination efforts. Only 19% of the population has received one dose, and 14% have received two doses. With millions of unused Pfizer-BioNTech doses set to expire, the government is considering sending them overseas if vaccination rates don't improve.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong may soon have to throw away millions of Coronavirus vaccine doses because they are approaching their expiry date and not enough people have signed up for the jabs, an official warned Tuesday.

site_title: Obese pigs in China are fuelling relentless slump in pork prices
summary: China's pork prices have plummeted over 40% since mid-January due to sluggish demand, increased imports, and panic selling by farmers. The slump is partly attributed to "super-sized" pigs, which were fattened to nearly double their normal weight in hopes of higher returns. However, these large animals are now being sold off, potentially delaying a rebound in prices. The African swine fever outbreak has driven up pork imports, and new regulations are reshaping the market, leading to regional price differences. The pig herd is expected to recover by June or July, but the number of hogs available for slaughter may take another four months to return to normal.

site_title: Rupee outperforms on bets India's Covid crisis may have peaked
summary: India's currency, the rupee, has rebounded 1.5% against the dollar in May, becoming Asia's top-performing currency, as daily infections decline and the nation's economy emerges from a recession. The rupee's revival reflects efforts to tackle the pandemic, with local lockdowns helping to reduce cases that were the world's highest in April. The Reserve Bank of India may step in to limit the currency's gains, but analysts expect the rupee to continue its upward trend, potentially reaching 72.50 per dollar by the end of the quarter.

site_title: Rising cyberattacks in West highlight vulnerabilities
summary: A series of high-profile cyberattacks in the West has highlighted the vulnerability of companies and institutions, with the US-based Colonial Pipeline and hackers from Russia compromising US government software in 2020. Cybersecurity experts warn of a rising tide of online attacks, with many organizations being complacent about their defenses. Western governments are prioritizing building up their cyber-military powers to investigate and deflect attacks, but experts worry that a state-backed cyberattack could trigger a spiral of reprisals and counter-reprisals.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally as inflation fears ease, oil extends gains
summary: Asia's stock markets rallied on Tuesday as inflation concerns eased, with traders optimistic about the global economic recovery. Tech firms led the way, with investors taking heart from Federal Reserve officials' assurances that a temporary spike in prices would not lead to tighter monetary policy. Oil prices extended gains, driven by Iran's tempered optimism over its nuclear deal. Bitcoin also rose, boosted by Elon Musk's supportive tweet, despite China's warnings of a crackdown on cryptocurrencies.

images.alt_text: Easing inflation concerns helped push equities higher in Asia on Tuesday, tracking a healthy rally on Wall Street, with traders taking heart from the global economic recovery outlook, while oil prices extended gains as Iran tempered optimism over its nuclear deal.

site_title: Chinese consulting firm iResearch's owner weighs exit
summary: Henry Yang, founder of iResearch Consulting Group, is considering selling his 44.3% stake in the company for approximately 1 billion yuan (S$207.63 million). Yang is working with an adviser to identify a buyer, reaching out to local companies and private equity firms. This move comes after several ownership changes, including Focus Media Information Technology Co and US private equity firm Silver Lake Partners acquiring stakes in the company. Yang could decide against a sale, and the company is currently raising funds that will lead to a change in shareholding.

site_title: Forever 21 owner Authentic Brands plans IPO this year
summary: Authentic Brands Group LLC, the owner of brands such as Brooks Brothers, Juicy Couture, and Forever 21, plans to go public this year, with a potential valuation of around $10 billion. The company, founded by Canadian Jamie Salter, has held discussions with potential advisers and is exploring an initial public offering. Authentic Brands has acquired over 30 brands, including bankrupt Barneys New York and Forever 21, and is backed by investors such as BlackRock Inc and General Atlantic. The company aims to maintain a brick-and-mortar presence and fuel its e-commerce strategy.

site_title: Uniqlo's bet on comfortable bras pays off
summary: Uniqlo, a Japanese fashion retailer, has seen significant success in the women's intimate wear market, particularly with its wireless bras, after doubling its market share in recent years. The company's focus on comfort and functionality has paid off, especially during the pandemic, as consumers sought out value and comfort. Uniqlo's bra segment has become a key part of its brand image, and the company has been innovating around wireless bras since the early 2000s. The success has positioned Uniqlo to be a major player in women's underwear, a rarity among apparel giants.

site_title: Grab to raise base fare by S$1 from June across most ride-hailing services
summary: Grab will raise its base fare by S$1 across most of its transport offerings in Singapore starting June 1, aiming to improve earnings for driver-partners. The increase is in response to rising costs and will apply to most services except Standard Taxi, GrabHitch, and GrabCoach. Up to 100% of the S$1 increase will go to drivers until June 30, with the remainder subject to a 20% commission rate. Grab also offers S$1 vouchers for peak hour rides and introduces support measures for drivers, including rental rebates and medical leave insurance.

site_title: China offers vaccines to Taiwan to fight covid-19
summary: China has offered to send Covid-19 vaccines to Taiwan, amid a sharp rise in coronavirus infections on the island. China claims it wants to help, but Taiwan has accused Beijing of spreading fake news and trying to limit its access to the World Health Organization. The US has expressed support for Taiwan, saying its vaccines don't come with strings attached and it will continue to provide doses to the island. Taiwan has received only 700,000 vaccines for its 23 million people, and is running out of doses as the pandemic worsens.

site_title: Cargill heads to record profits on booming agricultural markets
summary: Cargill Inc, the largest private US company, has reported its most profitable year ever, with net income of almost $4.3 billion in the first nine months of its fiscal year. The surge in global agricultural markets, driven by strong demand for meat, corn, and soybeans, has contributed to the record profits. Cargill's underlying earnings, or Ebitda, are expected to reach a record high, with Fitch Ratings predicting a 30% increase to over $8 billion. The company's CEO, David MacLennan, has credited the strategy of selling under-performing businesses and betting on demand for protein as key to the profit boom.

site_title: EU to finalise huge farm policy overhaul; climate groups cry foul
summary: The European Union is set to finalize a major overhaul of its farm policy, with a focus on making subsidies greener and fairer. The plan, worth 387 billion euros, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from farming by 10% by 2050. However, environmental campaigners have criticized the proposal for lacking firm targets and allowing polluting forms of farming to continue. The new rules, which will kick in from 2023, aim to allocate 23-25% of payments to environmentally-friendly schemes, but details on implementation and enforcement are still being negotiated.

site_title: India police visit Twitter offices after government tweet flagged
summary: India's police visited Twitter's offices after the social media platform flagged a tweet by the ruling Hindu-nationalist party's spokesperson as "manipulated media". The move follows tensions between the Indian government and Twitter over the blocking of critical accounts and the removal of posts criticizing Prime Minister Narendra Modi's handling of the coronavirus crisis. Twitter has refused to comment on the visit, but the incident highlights ongoing disputes between the Indian government and tech giants over free speech and content moderation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, following a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.17%, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.15% and 0.14%, respectively. This uptrend comes as recovery optimism returns after weeks of volatility.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index up 0.49% at 28,503.67, and the Topix index up 0.29% at 1,918.56. The gains followed a rally on Wall Street, where tech shares rose amid declines in long-term yields.

site_title: Cyberattacks: Bigger, smarter, faster
summary: Cyberattacks have become increasingly sophisticated over the past 15 years, with notable incidents including the 2007 Estonia cyberattack and the 2021 US$4.4-million ransom paid after a major US pipeline shutdown. As technology advances, AI is also becoming more capable of lying, scheming, and threatening its creators. Meanwhile, companies are investing in AI-focused innovation hubs, such as the Singapore AI Hub, to improve business operations and stay ahead of cyber threats.

site_title: Singapore ups full-year trade outlook after non-oil exports rise 9.7% in Q1 2021
summary: Singapore has raised its full-year trade outlook for 2021, citing a "better-than-expected" Q1 showing in non-oil exports, which rose 9.7% year-over-year. Total merchandise trade is projected to increase by 5-7% this year, with non-oil trade growth offsetting a decline in oil trade. Electronics and petrochemicals drove the growth, with shipments of electronic products up 14.8% year-over-year. The revised outlook is a reversal of previous forecasts of zero to 2% expansion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.02 points to 1,571.84. Volume was 535.74 million lots worth RM211.58 million. Gainers outpaced losers 258 to 212. The index has been steady, with no significant events reported.

site_title: EU says tensions with UK stem from Brexit, not Northern Ireland protocol
summary: The European Union's head, Ursula von der Leyen, stated that EU tensions with the UK stem from Brexit, not the Northern Ireland protocol. All 27 EU member states agree that the full and correct implementation of the protocol is necessary. Von der Leyen emphasized that there should be no doubt about the protocol's importance.

site_title: Over 140 tech job openings available for women at this year's DBS virtual career fair
summary: DBS announces its second virtual career fair, "DBS Women in Tech", with over 140 job openings for female technologists in Singapore. The fair aims to improve female representation in engineering roles, a space with a lack of women in the industry. Interested applicants must complete an 80-minute online assessment and attend a virtual interview. DBS plans to focus on five engineering roles, including engineering lead, solution architect, and full stack developer. The fair is part of the bank's efforts to drive diversity and inclusion in its workforce.

site_title: HDB launches over 3,800 BTO flats, including in areas like Bukit Merah, Geylang
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 3,879 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats across four estates in Singapore, with prices starting from S$419,000 for a three-room flat and S$602,000 for a four-room flat. The projects, including Telok Blangah Beacon in Bukit Merah and MacPherson Weave in Geylang, are expected to be completed in 2025 and 2027, with the longest wait being over five years. Buyers can apply online and will be allocated through balloting, with applications closing on May 31.

images.alt_text: In total, 6,373 new flats were launched on May 25, 2021.
In Geylang, 1,382 two-room flexi, three-room and four-room flats are on offer at MacPherson Weave.

site_title: Metro H2 net profit surges 50.5% to S$17m; revenue falls
summary: Metro Holdings posted a 50.5% surge in net profit to S$17m for the second half of 2021, driven by a fair-value gain on investment property and reduced losses from associates. Revenue fell 25.7% to S$60.6m due to lower contributions from its property segment and Covid-19 impact. Despite the decline, earnings per share rose to 4.4 cents, up 13.6% from the previous year. The company proposed a final cash dividend of 2.25 cents per share.

site_title: UK refuses to back Biden push for minimum corporation tax: The Telegraph
summary: The UK treasury is refusing to support a global minimum corporation tax proposed by US President Joe Biden unless stricter rules targeting US tech giants, such as Google and Facebook, are included. The UK is pushing for a more detailed deal on taxation of digital businesses before backing the proposal. Other European states, including France and Germany, have supported the US proposal for a 15% global minimum corporate tax rate. The UK's decision comes despite the US welcoming the commitment to finding a solution, with the US Treasury Secretary proposing a 21% US corporate minimum tax in April.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise to two-week high as energy stocks rally
summary: Australian shares rose to a two-week high, driven by a 3% jump in oil prices, boosting energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 0.5% to 7,079.1, its fourth consecutive session of gains. Energy stocks surged 1.4% as traders anticipated increased demand due to COVID-19 vaccinations. The rally was also influenced by an overnight rally on Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at open after upbeat GDP, non-oil exports data; STI up 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.7% to 3,145.31 points, driven by upbeat GDP and non-oil exports data, outperforming advance estimates. The country's full-year trade outlook for 2021 was also raised. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, rose in early morning trade. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground on Wall Street, while Tokyo stocks and European stocks held close to record highs.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 105 to 32, or about three securities up for every one down, after 81.8 million securities worth S$80.6 million changed hands.

site_title: 53% of Republicans view Trump as true US president: Reuters/Ipsos poll
summary: A Reuters/Ipsos opinion poll found that 53% of Republicans believe Donald Trump is the "true US president" despite losing the 2020 election to Joe Biden. The majority of Republicans (61%) also believe the election was "stolen" from Trump, while 67% of overall respondents trust election officials to do their job honestly. The poll was conducted online among 2,007 adults, including 909 Democrats and 754 Republicans, and has a credibility interval of about 4 percentage points.

site_title: Central banks running out of options as recovery falters in Asia
summary: Central banks in Asia are struggling to support the region's economic recovery, which is being hindered by surging coronavirus infections and slow vaccination rates. With interest rates already low, central banks are expected to keep rates on hold and focus on supporting governments with more borrowing. Fiscal stimulus is seen as a key response, with Indonesia, South Korea, and New Zealand planning to increase spending. The region's slow vaccine rollout is also affecting economies, with Singapore and Taiwan among those struggling to contain outbreaks.

site_title: B2B marketplace startup Eezee raises pre-Series A round led by Wavemaker
summary: Eezee, a Singapore-based B2B marketplace startup, has raised an undisclosed pre-Series A round led by Wavemaker Partners, with other investors including January Capital, Pags Group, and Insignia Ventures. The fresh funds will be used to expand its digital procurement services for multinational corporations and government institutions in Singapore, and the company plans to set up shop in the Philippines and Indonesia. Founded in 2017, Eezee aims to simplify complex procurement processes, allowing businesses to place orders in an average of five minutes, and has secured contracts with notable clients such as Shell and the Singapore government.

site_title: Major cruise lines to restart voyages for vaccinated passengers
summary: Three major cruise lines - Norwegian, Carnival, and Royal Caribbean - will resume US voyages with vaccinated passengers. Norwegian will start sailing from Seattle to Alaska on August 6, while Royal Caribbean's inaugural cruise will depart on July 19. Carnival's Holland American Line will begin on July 24. The US CDC's approval for vaccinated passengers allowed the resumption of cruises, following a year-long suspension due to the pandemic. All crew and passengers must be fully vaccinated, with varying age requirements for each company.

site_title: Singapore Q1 GDP grows 1.3%, but outlook has become more uncertain: MTI
summary: Singapore's first-quarter GDP grew 1.3% year-over-year, exceeding expectations, but the Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) will not upgrade its full-year outlook due to heightened uncertainties from the Covid-19 pandemic. The manufacturing sector led the growth, while tourism and aviation-related sectors continued to shrink. Despite this, MTI maintains its 4-6% full-year growth forecast, citing significant downside risks, including the trajectory of the pandemic. The government has tightened restrictions, including a ban on dining-in and social gatherings, until June 13, which may lead to a more uneven pace of recovery.

site_title: Citing Covid risk, US warns against travel to Olympic host Japan
summary: The US State Department issued a travel advisory warning its citizens not to travel to Japan due to the growing Covid-19 pandemic risk. Japan has a low vaccination rate, with just 2% of its population fully vaccinated, and a recent surge in infections has put hospitals under strain. The advisory cited government health advice and other factors before making the warning, which comes just two months before the Olympic Games are set to begin.

site_title: China targets 'speculators and hoarders' to stop raw-materials boom
summary: China's government vows to show "zero tolerance" for monopolies and speculation in raw-materials markets, targeting "speculators and hoarders" to cool a commodities boom. This move led to a 5% drop in steel prices and a 4.7% drop in iron ore prices. The campaign aims to rein in surging prices fueled by optimism over the global economic recovery and the pandemic's receding effects, while also tackling the consequences of China's efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: Australia reinstates Covid-19 curbs in Melbourne after fresh outbreak
summary: Australia's second-largest city, Melbourne, reinstated Covid-19 restrictions after a fresh outbreak grew to five cases. Home gatherings are limited to five guests, public meetings are restricted to 30 people, and face masks are mandatory indoors from 6pm local time until June 4. Acting Premier James Merlino deemed the measures necessary to control the outbreak, stating it's a "responsible step" to get on top of the situation. The restrictions will be in place until at least June 4, as authorities scramble to find the source of the outbreak.

site_title: Federal Reserve's George says she doesn't dismiss risk of inflation surge
summary: US Federal Reserve President Esther George cautioned against a "rigid" approach to monetary policy, citing potential changes in inflation and employment dynamics post-pandemic. She emphasized the need to adapt to new circumstances, rather than adhering to a fixed policy framework. George's comments come as the Fed continues to buy $120 billion in bonds monthly and keep interest rates near zero, despite rising prices. She did not explicitly signal a policy change, but suggested the Fed should be prepared for a potential inflation surge.

site_title: Japan Foods swings back to profitability in H2, proposes 1.75 S cents final dividend
summary: Japan Foods, a Catalist-listed restaurant operator, reported a profit of S$3.3 million in the second half-year ended March 31, 2021, compared to a loss of S$0.5 million in the same period last year. The company proposed a final dividend of 1.75 Singapore cents per share, up from 0.25 cent in the previous year. The improved earnings were attributed to the easing of dining restrictions in Singapore after the "circuit-breaker" period.

site_title: FLCT private placement raises S$335.8m; 2.8 times subscribed at S$1.399
summary: FLCT's private placement raised S$335.8 million, 2.8 times subscribed at S$1.399. The funds will partially fund the acquisition of six properties in Germany, Netherlands, and UK for S$548.7 million. The Reit expects the deal to be distribution and net asset value accretive. A total of 240 million units were issued, with 20 million additional units under an upsize option. The new units will start trading on June 3, with the issue price representing a 2.4% discount to the volume-weighted average price.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FLCT, Top Global, Metro, Japan Foods, ThaiBev, CDL
summary:
Here is a 100-word summary of the article:

Several companies saw new developments that may affect trading of their securities. Top Global's voluntary conditional offer to take the company private has turned unconditional, with 90.28% of shares accepted. Metro reported a 50.5% surge in net profit to S$17 million for the second half-year. Japan Foods returned to profitability, and CDL's chairman warned of potential cooling measures to control residential property prices. Other companies, including FLCT, ThaiBev, and Dyna-Mac, also reported developments. The news may impact trading of their securities, with some shares rising and others falling.

site_title: Aviva Singlife names DBS senior executive Pearlyn Phau as group CEO
summary: Aviva Singlife has appointed Pearlyn Phau as its new executive director and group CEO, subject to regulatory approval, effective August 18. This appointment comes after the S$3.2 billion merger between Singlife and Aviva Singapore in November last year.

site_title: Judge offers tough questions as Epic-Apple trial draws to close
summary: A federal judge questioned attorneys for Apple and Epic Games in a high-stakes antitrust trial over Apple's App Store, as the case drew to a close. Judge Yvonne Gonzalez Rogers expressed skepticism about Epic's claim that Apple stifles competition, while also questioning Apple's revenue-sharing model. The judge also raised concerns about Epic's potential to disrupt the mobile ecosystem if it were to gain access to the App Store. The verdict is expected to be issued in writing, with some analysts suggesting Epic's case may have strengthened, but the outcome remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A federal judge peppered attorneys for Apple and Epic Games with pointed questions on Monday on the workings of the massive Apple online marketplace as a high-stakes trial with implications for the mobile commerce world concluded.

site_title: India's Covid-19 resurgence drags on Singapore companies
summary: India's ongoing Covid-19 resurgence is affecting Singapore companies, with some firms diversifying their sources to avoid supply disruptions, while others struggle with shortages and payment delays. Despite implementing contingency plans, the surge is taking a toll on businesses, highlighting the need for adaptability in the face of the pandemic's ongoing impact.

site_title: US: Wall Street stocks push higher, shrugging off recent volatility
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, pushing higher despite recent volatility, as investors shrug off concerns about inflation and supply chain challenges. The three major indices, including the S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow, closed in positive territory. Analysts attribute the rally to continued monetary stimulus and the return to normal life, citing the "bull market" and "fear of missing out" mode. Inflation readings are expected to be released this week, with some analysts predicting a positive impact on corporate earnings.

site_title: Empathy, not just logic, helps build solidarity in a crisis
summary: Singapore's government has been criticized for not showing enough empathy in its response to public discontent over the Covid-19 situation. Former editor Leslie Fong suggests that the government's reliance on logic and pragmatism can come across as dismissive, and that citizens want to feel heard and understood. Associate Professor Simon Tay argues that public discourse should be limited during a crisis, but Fong counters that true cohesion requires a genuinely-felt solidarity, and that the government should show more empathy and explain its decisions better. The government has been praised for its economic imperatives, but critics argue that it should also consider the emotional and social impact of its decisions.

site_title: Firms call for help, but now's not the time for fiscal firepower
summary: The Singapore government is facing pressure from businesses to provide more fiscal support amid the current Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) period, but economists argue that a selective shutdown and support is a more strategic move to protect the economy. Business owners are calling for wage subsidies and rental rebates, citing a 40-90% decline in sales for food and beverage concepts. The government has already raised the Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) wage support level to 50% for F&B operators, but analysts believe further targeted relief is needed.

site_title: Oil jumps over 3% as fears of Iranian exports ease
summary: Oil prices rose over 3% on Monday as traders gained optimism that the market can absorb Iranian oil exports if sanctions are lifted. The US dollar strengthened against the euro, contributing to the price increase. A decline in Covid-19 deaths in India and a potential new deal with Iran also boosted expectations for rising oil demand. Despite a potential increase in Iranian exports, analysts believe the market can absorb the supply, with Goldman Sachs forecasting Brent prices to reach $80 per barrel by the end of the summer.

site_title: Two LRT trains collide near KLCC station
summary: A collision between an LRT Kelana Jaya Line passenger train and a vacant train on a test run near KLCC station in Kuala Lumpur injured at least 166 people, with 47 suffering serious injuries. The incident occurred at 8:33pm on May 24, 2021, with 232 people on board the occupied train. An investigation is underway to determine if controller negligence was involved, with the Transport Minister confirming that ambulance and medical personnel treated those with less severe injuries.

site_title: Couple rent plane for Covid lockdown-busting mid-air wedding
summary: An Indian couple chartered a Spicejet passenger jet to stage a mid-air wedding, defying COVID-19 restrictions that limit weddings to 50 guests. The flight, which flew over the Meenakshi Amman temple, carried 161 guests, including the newlyweds, without masks or social distancing. The Indian civil aviation authority has ordered an investigation and suspended the crew, with potential bans on all passengers. The move comes as India struggles with a devastating coronavirus wave, with over 300,000 deaths and 26 million cases recorded.

images.alt_text: An Indian couple chartered a passenger jet to stage a mid-air wedding that hijacked coronavirus restrictions by taking more than 160 guests, reports said Monday.

site_title: The great unfunded green hydrogen dream of Europe's oil refiners
summary: Europe's oil refiners are investing in green hydrogen to reduce operational carbon emissions, with Royal Dutch Shell's Rheinland refinery in Germany set to be the first European plant to go online in July. The project will produce 1,300 tonnes of hydrogen annually, but experts say the technology is still developing and expensive to build. Refiners are also considering blue hydrogen, which relies on established carbon capture technology, and most plan to use it in fuel production rather than as a power source.

site_title: Commodity transfer pricing under extra scrutiny
summary: Commodity transfer pricing is under scrutiny from tax authorities globally, with potential consequences for the commodity trading industry in Singapore. The complexity of international commodity supply chains, involving multiple countries and subsidiaries, makes it challenging to determine arm's length prices. Companies must clearly explain their functions, assets, and risks to ensure compliance. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development's updated Transfer Pricing Guidelines provide a framework for assessing transfer prices in the context of the entire supply chain. Effective documentation and consultation with tax authorities are crucial in defending fair transfer prices and profit margins.

site_title: Resolving the chicken-and-egg issue in funding digital transformation
summary: Singaporean SMEs are willing to adopt digital technologies, but 40% are concerned about costs. Traditional bank financing methods are unfavorable, as they focus on asset-based underwriting and ignore productivity return on investment (ROI) metrics. To address this, the Government is re-examining financing and credit grant processes. Meanwhile, other news includes a startup aiming to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel, OCBC targeting S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs, and Shatec shutting its Orchard campus and training restaurant.

site_title: How some US baby boomers are ageing in place comfortably, stylishly and safely
summary: Baby boomers are aging in place comfortably, stylishly, and safely with the help of safety-focused attention to detail. A throuple in their mid-60s, Susan Farnsworth, Leigh Hough, and Jean-Philippe Jomini, purchased a 0.7ha lot in Connecticut and designed a 3,300-sq-ft one-storey house with universal design principles. The home features wheelchair-accessible spaces, zero-threshold showers, and an easily maintained yard. AARP and other experts emphasize the importance of intentional planning to create an ideal space to age in place, and offer resources such as the HomeFit app and certified ageing-in-place specialists. Simple upgrades, like grab bars and contrast lighting, can make a big difference in safety and accessibility.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit saw its public offer 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower following Trump's fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall in H2, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks continued a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Libra Group lacks funds for AGM, financial statements, annual report
summary: Libra Group, a Catalist-listed company, faces breaches of Singapore Exchange rules due to lack of funds for AGM, financial statements, and annual reports. The company expects to rectify the situation upon completion of its proposed debt restructuring exercise and injection of funds by potential investors. This breach occurred despite the company's response on May 18, stating it would address the issues.

site_title: UN envoy still hopes to get to Myanmar
summary: UN special envoy Christine Schraner Burgener remains hopeful of visiting Myanmar, seven weeks after being blocked by the junta. She met with General Min Aung Hlaing in Indonesia, saying he did not rule out speaking with her, but deemed it "not yet" to come to the country. Burgener will visit Japan for meetings, and expressed willingness to discuss with China. A draft UN resolution to suspend arms shipments to Myanmar has been put on hold due to disagreements among Asian countries, with some seeking to remove language on an arms embargo.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near record highs, Cineworld gains
summary: European stocks hovered near record highs, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 index rising 0.1% to 445.07 points. Technology stocks led the charge, while economy-sensitive sectors like banks and basic resources declined. Cineworld Group Plc surged 3.2% after its film "Peter Rabbit 2: The Runaway" performed better than expected. European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said it's too early to discuss policy changes, citing strong earnings growth and reasonable valuations.

site_title: US dollar stuck near 3-month lows; cryptos struggle
summary: The US dollar is near three-month lows against major currencies, with the dollar index hovering around 90, down 0.2% on the day. The euro has gained 4% against the greenback over the past three months, driven by optimism over a robust global economic recovery. Cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, have also seen a rebound, with Bitcoin rising 6% to nearly $37,000. The decline in the US dollar is attributed to bets on a strong economic recovery and is also influenced by the potential for the Federal Reserve to taper policy.

site_title: CityDev's Kwek Leng Beng warns of more property cooling measures
summary: Singapore property developer City Developments (CDL) chairman Kwek Leng Beng warned that the government may introduce further cooling measures to control rising property prices. CDL's chief executive Sherman Kwek expressed confidence in the office and hotel markets, citing high occupancies and pent-up demand for private residential properties. Despite uncertainty over new cooling measures, Kwek sees the residential market as stable, with the group's projects performing well.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings secured a S$197 million contract for a fabrication project with BW Offshore group, bringing its order book to S$368 million until 2023. Spindex Industries warned of an impact on its Malaysia factory due to tightened Movement Control Orders, while NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology also warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss for the second half of the year.

site_title: Sea change: global freight sails out of the digital dark ages
summary: Digital freight startups have accelerated the industry's shift out of the digital dark ages, driven by global supply chain snarls and the Covid-19 pandemic. Companies like Flexport, Forto, and Loadsmart have developed software-powered freight tracking technology, integrating with customers' transportation management systems and making it easier to use remotely. Traditional freight giants are also beefing up their systems, while smaller companies may struggle to fund the transition, leading to consolidation in the industry. The shift to digitalization is expected to continue, with analysts predicting more deals and opportunities for new digital operators.

images.alt_text: The freight industry's shift out of the digital dark ages is benefiting a fast-growing cluster of startup companies that had struggled to sell their software-powered freight tracking technology, until now.

site_title: BlackRock joins funds betting on Indian assets amid outbreak
summary: BlackRock is increasing its investment in Indian assets, despite the ongoing pandemic. The firm plans to add to its long position in the Indian rupee, while GW&K Investment Management and Invesco Hong Kong are boosting their stock holdings in sectors such as sustainable investing and renewable energy. This move comes as overseas investors remain confident in India's economic rebound.

site_title: Changi Airport T3 cluster began at arrival gates and baggage claim hall
summary: A COVID-19 cluster at Changi Airport's Terminal 3 began at arrival gates and baggage claim halls, with 43 positive cases detected among airport staff. Investigations found that half of the infected staff worked in the arrival zone, leading to secondary clusters of infection that spread to over 100 people. The cluster was caused by staff mingling with others in the transit areas, departure gates, and the Basement 2 food court, where 12 staff members visited. The airport's central transit area remained relatively clean, with zero cases except for a specific cluster.

site_title: Art competition in support of BT Budding Artists Fund
summary: TRCL, a charity arts organisation in Singapore, launched its inaugural youth visual arts competition in support of The Business Times Budding Artists Fund. The competition, open to youths aged 13-19, encourages them to express themselves through canvas and digital artworks. A panel of local artists and art professionals will judge submissions based on concept, creativity, and originality. Winners will receive cash prizes, with the top award going to gold winners. The competition aims to nurture and recognise young talents, with proceeds from the sale of winning artworks going towards the BT BAF.

site_title: Bondholders hire Rothschild to help oppose Emirates Reit revamp: sources
summary: A group of Emirates Reit creditors, representing 40% of Islamic bonds, hired Rothschild and Clifford Chance to oppose the proposed exchange of US$400 million sukuk for new instruments. The creditors plan to negotiate a better deal, potentially re-setting management fees or waiving past breaches. Emirates Reit, struggling after the coronavirus outbreak, aims to bolster its balance sheet by extending bond maturity to 2024 and deferring coupon payments. The exchange offer was described as "investor-friendly" by Equitativa and Houlihan Lokey, but the creditors' move may complicate the proposal.

site_title: Singapore should get ready with a carbon border tax
summary: Singapore should consider implementing a carbon border tax (CBT) to discourage carbon-intensive trade and encourage other major economies to switch to low-carbon energy. As the world's most trade-dependent high-income economy, Singapore's actions can influence global climate-friendly trade. With global carbon emissions reaching 420 ppm and sea levels increasing, Singapore's own carbon footprint is only 0.1% of the global total, making a low-carbon path imperative. Implementing a CBT could help achieve carbon neutrality by 2050 and demonstrate Singapore's commitment to sustainability.

site_title: Pandemic offers southern Italians chance to return home
summary: Southern Italians have taken advantage of the pandemic to return home, seeking a better quality of life and lower living costs. Many workers, particularly from the poorer south, have moved to warmer regions like Sicily, where they can work remotely. This trend, known as the "south working phenomenon," could benefit all of Italy by driving up public services and innovation. With around 10,000 followers on Facebook, a think-tank and advocacy group called South Working is supporting the movement, which could reverse the brain drain that has plagued the Italian south.

site_title: Malaysia's latest MCO curbs face indifference, confusion
summary: Malaysia's latest Covid-19 curbs under Movement Control Order 3.0 have sparked indifference and ridicule from the public, with many feeling the restrictions offer little difference from earlier measures. Despite this, the country's infection numbers continue to climb, breaking new records. The government's handling of the pandemic is being questioned, with some calling into doubt its competence in curbing the spread of the virus.

images.alt_text: Many Malaysians are gradually losing trust in how the rules have been introduced and executed due to an apparent lack of streamlining across government departments.

site_title: China Sky Chemical Fibre doesn't have funds to make exit offer for delisting
summary: China Sky Chemical Fibre, under judicial management, is unable to provide an exit offer for delisting due to insufficient financial resources. The company's creditors are not interested in making an exit offer, and its controlling shareholders have not expressed intention to do so. China Sky will be placed under provisional liquidation in the Cayman Islands, where liquidators will apply to dissolve the company. Shares have been suspended since August 2016. The judicial management order expires on September 13, and the judicial manager will apply for discharge instead.

site_title: Malaysia probes allegations of under-dosage of Covid-19 shots
summary: Malaysia is investigating allegations that some recipients of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine were not given the correct dosage. At least two individuals have claimed on social media that they were under-dosed, prompting the health ministry to announce new rules for medical personnel administering the jab. The ministry also emphasized the importance of verifying the vaccine dosage before administering the shot. The investigation comes as Malaysia battles a spike in Covid-19 infections and aims to achieve herd immunity by the end of the year, with over 2 million people having received at least one dose.

site_title: Every citizen must play his part, no matter how small, to defeat the virus
summary: Singapore is in the third week of Phase 2 economic reopening, with tightened rules in place to combat COVID-19. The government has implemented a four-week Phase 2 (Heightened Alert) period with stricter measures, including reduced capacities and work-from-home arrangements. Despite this, some businesses, particularly in the food and beverage industry, are struggling. The government has penalized companies and individuals for breaching safe management measures, with fines and closures issued for various offenses. The author emphasizes the need for every Singaporean to play their part in containing the outbreak, regardless of the effort, to ultimately defeat the virus.

site_title: Japan's biggest dating app hack exposes two million accounts
summary: A Japanese matchmaking app, Omiai, was hacked, exposing the personal information of over 1.7 million account holders, including photos of IDs used to confirm user ages. The hack, discovered in April, did not leak credit card data, but the company has yet to confirm if the information was misappropriated. The breach led to a 19% drop in Net Marketing Co's shares, valued at around $70 million. This incident highlights the vulnerability of the online dating market, which has seen significant growth in Japan over the past four years.

site_title: From used chopsticks to sustainable furniture
summary: Canadian startup ChopValue is expanding into Singapore with its first international franchise, serving as a flagship and training facility. The company upcycles used chopsticks into sustainable furniture, such as desks and shelves, and aims to divert 35 million chopsticks within the first three years. Founded in 2016, ChopValue has already recycled over 34 million chopsticks and transformed them into home and office products. The Singapore franchise, led by Evelyn Hew and Hsu Hui En, will target 300-400 restaurants and dining establishments and aims to inspire others to transform urban waste into a viable resource.

site_title: Aviva Singlife names DBS senior executive Pearlyn Phau as group CEO
summary: Aviva Singlife has named Pearlyn Phau as its new executive director and group CEO, effective August 18, following the merger between Singlife and Aviva Singapore last November. Phau, a veteran in the financial services industry, will replace Nishit Majmudar and oversee the group's operations, aiming to push for new heights and challenge the industry. The appointment is subject to regulatory approval.

site_title: Fifty and fabulous: Mickelson defies age to win PGA Championship
summary: Phil Mickelson won the PGA Championship by two strokes, becoming golf's oldest major winner at 50. He overcame strong winds and pressure to record a one-over-par 73 at the Ocean Course. Mickelson beat Brooks Koepka and Louis Oosthuizen, solidifying his victory. This win marks a significant achievement in his career, defying age expectations and cementing his status as a major champion.

site_title: Bullish fund managers ignoring stagflation fears
summary: Global fund managers, with 7 in 10 respondents, are expecting "above-trend" growth and inflation, despite stagflation fears, according to a Bank of America survey. Fund allocations to commodities have risen to protect against inflation, and most (93%) expect European growth to improve over the next 12 months. However, economists warn of the risk of stagflation due to slowing China, the pandemic in India, and uncertainty in the US and Europe. Fund managers are also overweight in UK stocks, with many predicting equities will peak next year, and inflation is seen as a market risk by only 35%.

site_title: Covid-19 breath test startup Breathonix raising US$5m capital
summary: Breathonix, a Singapore-based startup, has raised US$5 million in Series A funding to fuel its growth. The company, which has received provisional authorisation for its Covid-19 breath test, plans to use the funding to build its research and development pipeline for other diseases and hire talent. The breath test, which achieved an accuracy rate of over 90%, is less invasive and provides results in under a minute. Breathonix will deploy the system at Tuas Checkpoint for incoming travellers, alongside a traditional swab test, and plans to expand its commercialisation efforts.

site_title: F9 drives its way to mighty US$162m debut overseas
summary: The film "F9" has achieved a record-breaking US$162.4 million in ticket sales in eight international markets, including China, South Korea, and Hong Kong, marking the best start for a Hollywood blockbuster since the Covid-19 pandemic. The film's success in China, where it earned US$135 million, is particularly notable, with the franchise now pushing past US$6 billion globally. The film's director, Justin Lin, and star Vin Diesel have praised the movie's strong fanbase and encouraging start to the summer movie season.

site_title: Europeans threaten to limit Belarus air traffic after 'state piracy'
summary: European leaders threatened to limit Belarus air traffic and target its ground transport after a Ryanair plane was forced to land in Minsk, where a dissident journalist was arrested. The incident, dubbed "state piracy," was condemned by Western countries as an act of aviation piracy. The EU is considering suspending international overflights over Belarusian airspace and banning the Belarusian airline Belavia from European airports. The US and other countries have already imposed financial sanctions on Belarus, but the regime has shrugged off previous sanctions.

site_title: More than 200 hurt in KL train collision
summary: A collision between two light rail transit trains in Kuala Lumpur's underground tunnel injured 213 people, with 47 seriously hurt and 166 sustaining light injuries. Transport Minister Wee Ka Siong confirmed the incident and stated that the seriously injured have been sent to the hospital.

site_title: Retail Reits facing a bump in the road - for now
summary: Singapore's retail Reits face a temporary setback due to tougher safe-distancing measures announced earlier this month. Despite this, domestic demand has helped retail sales grow 6.2% year-on-year in March, with a 3% month-on-month increase. The restrictions, which will remain in place until June 13, may further weigh on investor sentiment, particularly for Reits already grappling with inflation and rising bond yields concerns.

site_title: Crypto recovery stalls as miners eye exits
summary: Cryptocurrency prices plummeted on Monday after miners in China halted operations due to increasing scrutiny from authorities, despite weekend support from Tesla's Elon Musk. Bitcoin climbed to $35,970, but remains 45% below its record peak. Rival cryptocurrency ether hit an almost two-month low, and dogecoin traded at $0.30. Analysts attribute the sell-off to a combination of factors, including regulatory risks, a shakeout in the market, and the attention on Chinese miners who account for 70% of supply.

site_title: US: Stocks gain as markets monitor infrastructure debate
summary: US stocks rose Monday as investors monitored President Joe Biden's infrastructure package, with the Dow Jones up 0.3%, the S&P 500 up 0.7%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index up 1.1%. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is set to testify before congressional panels, while Biden's proposal has been trimmed from $2.3 trillion to $1.7 trillion. Analysts see the potential for more fiscal stimulus, but concerns over funding remain. Individual companies like Virgin Galactic surged on its third successful space launch.

site_title: Mary Chia applies for more time to announce FY2021 financial statements
summary: MARY Chia Holdings has applied for a one-month extension to announce its unaudited financial statements for FY2021, originally due on May 30. The delay is attributed to its finance team in Malaysia working from home due to the Movement Control Order and limited access to the accounting system. The group's audit by Foo Koo Tan LLP is also affected. The unaudited financial statements for Singapore entities are currently being reviewed by auditors. The company expects to file its statements by June 30.

site_title: The Israeli-Palestinian war: Who 'won', who 'lost'?
summary: A ceasefire between Israel and Hamas has ended after 11 days of fighting, marking the third war between the two parties since 2014. While no clear winner can be determined, Hamas and its patron Iran appear to have emerged stronger, while the Israeli and Palestinian people have suffered significant civilian casualties and destruction. The conflict is likely to continue, and the long-term impact on the region remains uncertain.

site_title: Mainstream markets shrug at volatile US$1t crypto rout
summary: Mainstream markets have largely shrugged off the recent US$1 trillion drop in cryptocurrency value, with traditional assets such as equities and treasuries showing minimal reaction. The Bloomberg Galaxy Crypto Index plummeted 40% last week, its worst performance since the pandemic began. Experts warn that the sector may face further volatility and potential contagion, but a 5% Bitcoin allocation in a 60-40 portfolio is deemed too high-risk for institutional investors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close up for third straight session
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher for a third consecutive session, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.17% to 28,364.61. The move followed the opening of Japan's first mass vaccination centers, which investors welcomed. The broader Topix index also rose 0.44% to 1,913.04. This upward trend is attributed to the positive market reaction to Japan's vaccination efforts.

site_title: Singapura Finance divests stake in digital bank licence applicant after bid fails
summary: Singapura Finance divested its 10% stake in MatchMove PowerBank, a digital bank licence applicant, after its bid for a licence in Singapore failed. The lender sold the stake to MatchMove Pay in exchange for a 0.3% stake in MatchMove Pay. MatchMove PowerBank will continue to apply for digital bank licences in other Asean nations, while Singapura Finance focuses on the Singapore market. The decision allows Singapura Finance to concentrate on backing a Singapore digital bank.

site_title: HSBC CEO says Bitcoin not for us
summary: HSBC CEO Noel Quinn stated that the bank has no plans to launch a cryptocurrency trading desk or offer Bitcoin as an investment to customers due to its volatility and lack of transparency. In contrast, HSBC is exploring central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), which it believes can facilitate international transactions and operate in a transparent manner. Quinn expressed skepticism about cryptocurrencies, citing difficulties in assessing ownership and converting them into fiat money. This stance differs from rival Goldman Sachs, which has restarted its cryptocurrency trading desk.

site_title: Thai Beverage shareholders can get updates from management and board via informal meeting
summary: Thai Beverage will hold an annual information meeting for shareholders on June 21 from 11 am to noon via live webcast. The meeting will provide updates on the company's business and presentation slides will be made available after the meeting. Shareholders can pre-register and submit questions until June 16, and questions can be submitted through the company's website, email, or post. This meeting is informal and no resolutions will be presented.

site_title: Grim deaths spark outrage over China's haphazard 'marathon fever'
summary: China's ultramarathon industry has faced criticism after 21 runners died in a cross-country mountain race in the northwestern province of Gansu due to extreme weather conditions. The incident has sparked outrage over the lack of preparation and safety measures by event organizers. Authorities have launched an investigation, and the government has called for better regulations and organization. This tragedy is the latest in a series of controversies surrounding China's booming marathon and running events, which have been plagued by cheating, poor safety, and reckless behavior.

site_title: Covid shadow hangs over WHO international meet
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) began its annual member state meeting, with discussions focusing on COVID-19 pandemic response and potential reforms to avert future pandemics. The 74th World Health Assembly will address vaccine distribution, with wealthy nations criticized for hoarding life-saving doses. National leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron, will deliver statements, and the meeting will also address other global health concerns.

site_title: Dyna-Mac secures S$197m contract for fabrication project
summary: Dyna-Mac Holdings secured a S$197 million contract from BW Offshore group for a fabrication project. The contract involves supplying and constructing topside modules for the Barossa FPSO vessel operating in offshore Darwin, Australia. This brings Dyna-Mac's order book to S$368 million, with deliveries up to 2023. The contract is not expected to impact the group's earnings per share and net tangible assets for the current financial year.

site_title: Spindex warns of impact on Malaysia factory as it reduces operations
summary: Spindex Industries has warned of an impact on its Malaysia factory due to the Malaysian government's tightened Movement Control Orders, limiting staff to 60% on-site and 40% working from home from May 25 to June 7. The reduced operational staff will affect factory operations, but the financial impact is currently volatile and quantifiable. The company will monitor the situation and keep shareholders informed of any developments. Shares closed flat at S$1.210 on Monday.

site_title: 'Black fungus' hitting India's Covid-19 patients
summary: India is experiencing a rapid rise in cases of mucormycosis, also known as black fungus, amid its massive second wave of Covid-19 infections. The disease has a close link to diabetes and compromised immune systems, and its mortality rate is 54%. Excessive use of steroids on virus patients is believed to be a contributing factor, and a severe shortage of the main anti-fungal drug, amphotericin B, has led to imports starting to arrive. Experts say unsanitary conditions and prolonged hospitalization with mechanical ventilators also increase the risk of infection.

site_title: Should you go for Singapore-listed US office Reits?
summary: The Singapore-listed US office Reits, including Manulife US Reit, Keppel Pacific Oak US Reit (KORE), and Prime US Reit, are trading below their initial public offering (IPO) prices, with yields around 8% compared to 5% for Singapore-centric office Reits. Despite resilient operating performance, the Reits face challenges, including a spread to the 10-year US treasury yield of over 600 basis points. The US economy is expected to grow 6.5% this year, with office workers returning to physical offices, but investors may be cautious due to lingering pandemic uncertainties and rising remote working productivity tools.

site_title: Banking tech startup wins US$250m from SoftBank
summary: Banking technology startup Zeta raised US$250 million from SoftBank Vision Fund II at a valuation of $1.45 billion, more than quadrupling its valuation from 2019. Zeta aims to expand in the US and Europe as banks move online, providing backbone technology for credit and credit-card processing. The company plans to double its headcount and target 60% of its revenue from the US in five years.

site_title: Kwek Leng Beng warns of cooling measures if residential property prices continue to rise
summary: Kwek Leng Beng, chairman of City Developments (CDL), warned that the government may introduce further cooling measures to control rising residential property prices in Singapore. Despite the current market stability, he noted that prices could continue to rise, prompting the need for cooling measures. The chairman expressed confidence in the office and hotel markets, with the group's Republic Plaza achieving high occupancies and the hotel industry expected to recover this year.

site_title: Boris Johnson sets wedding date: report
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his fiancée Carrie Symonds have set a wedding date for July 30, 2022, according to a report. The couple, who have been together since 2018, will be only the second prime minister to marry while in office, following Robert Jenkinson in 1822. Johnson, 56, and Symonds, 33, have been delayed in their plans due to the pandemic and have been dealing with a recent scandal over the redecoration of their Downing Street flat.

site_title: In weighing HDB 'lottery effect', Singapore mulls raising subsidies, imposing clawbacks
summary: Singapore's housing minister, Desmond Lee, suggests raising subsidies and imposing clawbacks to balance the "lottery effect" in the public housing system, where flats in prime locations are allocated randomly. To keep these flats affordable, additional subsidies may be needed. However, this idea faces complex considerations and downstream effects, making it challenging to implement. The government aims to maintain an egalitarian and inclusive housing system, with flats in prime locations remaining affordable.

site_title: G-7 is close to agreement on taxation of world's largest companies: FT
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) countries are close to reaching an agreement on taxing the world's largest companies, with the US agreeing to a minimum rate of 15% and other countries expressing support. A global deal could be finalized as early as Friday, paving the way for a deal among nearly 140 countries to rework rules for taxing multinational groups and big tech companies by summer. This agreement aims to address the "race to the bottom" and promote a global minimum tax.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 9.65 points to 1,571.82 on Monday, driven by a 902-283 gain-to-lose ratio. The market closed with 6.753 billion lots worth RM3.479 billion.

site_title: Emirates warns Boeing it will refuse 777x jets if they don't meet commitments
summary: Emirates President Tim Clark has warned Boeing that it will refuse delivery of 777x jets if the US planemaker fails to meet contractual performance commitments. Clark expressed concerns over Boeing's history of over-promising on new jet performance, citing examples from the 737 MAX and 787 Dreamliner. Despite test flights beginning in 2020, Clark has not received performance details on the 777x engines.

site_title: Deals of the week: Thunes doubles share price; ZumVet raises seed round
summary: In the past week, several South-east Asian tech startups secured significant funding rounds. Thunes, a cross-border payments startup, raised US$60 million, doubling its share price to S$3.70. Pet telemedicine startup ZumVet also secured a seven-figure seed round. Fintech companies in Singapore raised S$656 million in Q1, up 355%, with Grab Financial Group's Series A round contributing to the growth. Additionally, clinical-stage biotech outfit Hummingbird Bioscience raised US$125 million in a Series C round.

site_title: Changi Airport T3 cluster began at arrival gates and baggage claim hall
summary: A Covid-19 cluster at Changi Airport's Terminal 3 began at the arrival gates and baggage claim hall, where airport staff worked closely with arriving passengers. The primary infection site was the arrival zone, with staff then mingling with others in the transit areas, leading to secondary clusters and over 100 infections. Of the 43 positive cases, about half were in the arrival zone, with the Basement 2 foodcourt and Jewel being identified as secondary sources of infection.
