Investigations are ongoing to determine the initial transmission, with no specific country pinpointed as the source.

site_title: Malaysia probes allegations of under-dosage of Covid-19 shots
summary: Malaysia is investigating allegations that some recipients of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine received an under-dosage, with at least two individuals claiming they received less than the required amount. The health ministry has taken note of the allegations and announced new rules for medical personnel administering the vaccine. The investigation is ongoing, but no confirmation has been made on whether the recipients were indeed under-dosed.

images.alt_text: Malaysia on Monday said it was investigating allegations that some recipients of the AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine were not injected with the correct dosage.

site_title: The great unfunded green-hydrogen dream of Europe's oil refiners
summary: Europe's oil refiners plan to boost green hydrogen production to reduce operational carbon emissions. Royal Dutch Shell's Rheinland refinery in Germany is set to be the first European plant to produce green hydrogen, with a small electrolyser starting production in July. The project aims to produce 1,300 metric tons of hydrogen annually, but experts say the technology is still being developed and expensive, requiring significant scale to make a significant difference. Refiners are also exploring blue hydrogen, which relies on carbon capture technology, as a more established alternative.

site_title: Singapore stocks begin week in the black, STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,123.61 on Monday, driven by positive sentiment from Singapore's core and headline inflation figures and global efforts to overcome the coronavirus. Tech play iFast Corporation was the biggest gainer, while Jardine Matheson Holdings was the biggest loser. The market is expected to focus on local data releases, including the final GDP report for Q1 and industrial production reports for April.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Ministry of National Development is exploring measures to address the "lottery effect" in Housing and Development Board (HDB) housing allocations. The government may consider raising subsidies and imposing clawbacks to balance competing considerations. Meanwhile, NUS' Breathonix has secured provisional approval for a 60-second Covid-19 breath test system. Singapore's inflation rates remained positive in April, with core and headline inflation increasing due to the low base from last year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MOM) has fined 11 companies for failing to ensure work-from-home arrangements.

site_title: With electrification, Nissan's Gupta sees new spark for Renault tie-up
summary: Nissan Motor Co. is standardizing and sharing electric-vehicle components with alliance partner Renault SA, shifting the focus to electrification as the main pillar of their collaboration. This move aims to cut costs and capitalize on economies of scale, with Nissan's COO Ashwani Gupta stating that adopting a uniform standard across the alliance would "contribute significantly" to their efforts. The companies have agreed on common specifications for batteries and will share components such as batteries, electric powertrains, and electronic architecture, with Nissan's global sourcing of components ensuring no supply challenges.

site_title: Malaysia's bourse to launch East Malaysian palm oil contract in Q3
summary: Malaysia's Bursa Malaysia Derivatives Exchange plans to launch a new palm oil futures contract, the East Malaysian Palm Oil Futures (FEPO), in the third quarter. The contract will cater to East Malaysian producers, allowing for physical deliveries through three designated ports, and provide greater price discovery for the region. The launch aims to eliminate a price discount faced by East Malaysian producers, resulting in estimated annual losses of over RM1 billion. The new contract is expected to start trading earlier, at 9 am, to coincide with Chinese trading hours.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: The ABCs of disability insurance plans (Ep 96)
summary: BT Money Hacks podcast episode 96 discusses disability insurance plans, a crucial aspect often overlooked during the pandemic. Great Eastern's managing director, Colin Chan, explains why disability insurance is essential, even for young individuals. The episode highlights the importance of having a plan in place, including add-on critical illness coverage and a critical illness cover calculator. The episode aims to educate listeners on the must-do list for their financial well-being during this pandemic.

site_title: WHO sets new targets for vaccinating world's poorest to end 'scandalous inequity'
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has set new targets to vaccinate the world's poorest countries, aiming to end the "scandalous inequity" in vaccine distribution. WHO director-general Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned that the pandemic is not over until the Sars-CoV-2 virus and its variants are under control globally. The new targets aim to vaccinate 40% of the global population in the poorest countries by the end of 2022 and 70% by 2023, with a focus on low- and middle-income countries.

site_title: Pressure to accept China vaccines intensifies as Taiwan battles Covid surge
summary: Taiwan is under pressure to accept Chinese COVID-19 vaccines amid a surge in domestic cases, despite having only vaccinated 1% of its population. The island has clashed with Beijing over the pandemic, with Taipei accusing Beijing of spreading fake news and preventing full WHO participation. Beijing claims Taipei is playing politics with its people's lives by refusing Chinese vaccines. The situation intensifies as Taiwan waits for new vaccine shipments.

site_title: Myanmar's Suu Kyi defiant in first comments since coup
summary: Myanmar's detained leader Aung San Suu Kyi defied the military in her first public comments since the coup, vowing her ousted party would "exist as long as the people exist." Despite facing criminal charges, Suu Kyi sounded "healthy and fully confident" during a meeting with her lawyer. The junta has threatened to dissolve the National League for Democracy, which won elections in 2020. The military has been accused of killing over 800 people in near-daily protests, and a nationwide civil disobedience movement continues.

site_title: MOM fines 11 companies for failing to ensure WFH as default arrangement
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) fined 11 companies for failing to implement work-from-home (WFH) as the default work arrangement, despite guidelines issued on May 14 requiring employers to provide WFH facilities. The fines were issued after inspections of over 530 workplaces from May 8-21. Employers must ensure adequate safe-management measures are in place, including staggering start times and social distancing, and only allow employees who cannot WFH to work on-site. The MOM will step up inspections to ensure compliance with the latest guidelines.

site_title: 24 new Covid-19 cases in the community, two unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 36 new COVID-19 cases, including 24 community cases and 12 imported cases. The community cases linked to a cluster at adjacent malls Jem and Westgate in Jurong East have increased to four. Two cases remain unlinked, one a vaccinated 60-year-old woman and the other a 74-year-old woman. There are currently 242 active cases in hospital, including three in critical condition, and 256 in isolation in community facilities.

images.alt_text: There were 36 new coronavirus cases confirmed at noon on Monday, taking Singapore's total to 61,860.

site_title: Singapore's core, headline inflation continue positive trend in April
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to 0.6% in April, its third consecutive month of gains, while headline inflation remained at 2.1%. Analysts and economists are divided on the implications, with some adjusting forecasts and others predicting policy adjustments in October. The increase in core inflation can be attributed to low base effects, while private transport and accommodation costs are expected to remain resilient. Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) expect headline inflation to remain stable in the near term, with core inflation continuing to rise.

site_title: 'Peter Rabbit 2' helps Cineworld draw crowds after lockdown in UK
summary: Cineworld Group Plc reported a strong reopening of its UK cinemas, with more than 97% of US cinemas also operating, after a months-long Covid-19 lockdown. The success was attributed to the success of "Peter Rabbit 2: The Runaway" and a gradual easing of curbs in the UK. Cineworld's CEO Mooky Greidinger expects a good recovery in attendance over the coming months, with a strong performance next week also expected. The company has also received a US$203 million tax refund under the US government's coronavirus relief program.

site_title: 'Charlie Bit My Finger' video fetches US$760,000 at NFT auction
summary: A 55-second YouTube video from 2007, "Charlie Bit My Finger," featuring a British toddler's incident with his baby brother, sold for nearly US$761,000 at an NFT auction on its 14th anniversary. The viral sensation, which gained widespread attention and memes, is now part of a growing trend of digital collectors buying and selling unique internet content as non-fungible tokens.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start week with loss
summary: Hong Kong stocks started the week with a loss, closing 0.16% lower at 28,412.26. Traders weighed concerns about inflation and new virus cases in Asia against optimism about the global economic recovery. In contrast, China's Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.31% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.75%. The losses were attributed to concerns about spiking inflation and the impact of new virus cases in Asia, despite a positive global economic outlook.

site_title: US business chamber calls on Vietnam to ease quarantine, free up vaccines
summary: The American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Vietnam has urged the government to ease its lengthy quarantine period for vaccinated travelers, allowing private companies to help procure Covid-19 vaccines for employees. 81% of AmCham members would consider traveling to Vietnam if the mandatory quarantine period was reduced from 21 days to 7. Vietnam has a low virus tally of 5,308 cases, but a new outbreak has prompted calls for an accelerated vaccination program. Currently, only 28,961 people in Vietnam have been vaccinated.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near record high, Cineworld gains
summary: European stocks hovered near a record high, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.02% to 444.50 points. Cineworld Group surged 3.1% after a successful film release, while travel stocks declined due to COVID-19 travel restrictions. Markets in Austria, Denmark, and Germany were closed for holiday.

site_title: EU calls for international inquiry into forced landing of Ryanair plane
summary: The European Union has called for an international investigation into the forced landing of a Ryanair plane in Minsk, Belarus, citing concerns over passenger and crew safety. EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell stated that the incident jeopardized safety and must be investigated to determine if international aviation rules were breached. EU leaders will discuss additional sanctions against Belarus at a summit in Brussels.

site_title: Five EHT Chapter 11 assets receive qualified bids, boosting consideration by US$24.8m
summary: Five out of 15 Eagle Hospitality Trust's Chapter 11 assets received qualified bids, boosting consideration by US$24.8m. The successful bidders include Madison Phoenix LLC for nine non-auctioned properties with an aggregate purchase price of US$326.5m. The remaining properties, including Queen Mary Long Beach and Hilton Houston Galleria Area, will be subject to approval by the United States Bankruptcy Court at a hearing scheduled for May 28. The trustee will continue to explore options for the remaining properties.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises Grand Venture target price on semiconductors-driven Q1 earnings surge
summary: CGS-CIMB raised its target price for Grand Venture Technology to S$1.12, almost double from S$0.605, following a 434.9% increase in net profit to S$3.3 million in Q1 2021, driven by semiconductor segment growth. Revenue rose 59% with semiconductor segment up 68.5% and life sciences segment up 38.4%. Analyst William Tng expects a new chapter of growth and increased competencies in advanced manufacturing.

site_title: SP Group signs MOU with BCG Energy to invest in renewables in Vietnam
summary: SP Group, Singapore's national grid operator, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with BCG Energy to invest in renewable energy projects in Vietnam. The partnership will allow SP to acquire up to 49% of Skylar Joint Stock Company, a subsidiary of BCG Energy specializing in rooftop solar assets. The aim is to enhance Vietnam's electricity supply capacity and support the country's goal of increasing renewable energy production to 30% by 2030.

site_title: World's supply of chips is in danger unless Taiwan gets vaccines
summary: Taiwan is struggling to vaccinate its population, with only 1% of citizens fully vaccinated, due to a lack of COVID-19 vaccines from China. This shortage poses a significant threat to Taiwan's chip industry, which dominates the local economy and is critical to the global supply. The US and Europe are seeking to reduce their dependence on Taiwan and boost domestic chip production, citing concerns over intellectual property theft and the potential for Chinese companies to poach Taiwanese engineers. Taiwan is working to draft new export control measures and tighten curbs on exports to China.

images.alt_text: Back in February, as the world was beating a path to Taiwan's door for help to tackle a shortage of semiconductors, the health minister got into a scrap with China over Covid-19 vaccines.

site_title: Gold hovers near 4-1/2-month high on tepid dollar, inflation jitters
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to near a 4-1/2-month high at $1,883.21 per ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and inflationary pressure. The dollar's decline made gold cheaper for other currency holders, while a slide in cryptocurrencies boosted its appeal as an alternative investment asset. Rising US inflationary risks have lifted gold's appeal as an inflation hedge, with holdings of the SPDR Gold Trust rising 0.6%.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks slide for third day on concerns over crypto, US inflation
summary: South Korean stocks slid for a third consecutive day, closing 0.38% lower at 3,144.30, amid concerns over cryptocurrency volatility and anticipation of US inflation readings. Bitcoin plummeted 13% on Sunday, while chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell. Foreigners sold 237.6 billion won worth of shares, and the won remained nearly unchanged against the dollar. The central bank announced plans to build a digital currency pilot platform, and investors await US inflation figures for guidance on monetary policy.

site_title: Japan premium melons go for US$24,800 after virus slump
summary: A pair of premium Japanese Yubari melons sold for US$24,800 at auction, more than 22 times the virus-hit price of last year. The record-breaking sale is seen as a sign of a post-pandemic recovery, with buyers seeking to encourage people by placing high bids. The price tag is still lower than previous records for the prized produce.

site_title: Thailand says its tourism industry may not recover until 2026
summary: Thailand's tourism industry may not recover until 2026, according to the National Economic and Social Development Council. The sector, which contributed about one-fifth of the country's economy before the pandemic, is expected to return to normal after a five-year delay due to the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. The delayed recovery will impact over 7 million workers, with the economy contracting for five straight quarters. The government has set a target of 500,000 visitors for this year, a small fraction of the 6.7 million who came in 2020.

images.alt_text: It could take another five years before tourism revives fully in Thailand - an ominous sign for one of the most tourism-dependent economies in the world.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend gains to third day on gold, energy boost
summary: Australian shares closed 0.2% higher on Monday, extending gains into a third session, driven by gains in gold and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 7,045.9. Heavyweight miners were weighed down by a slump in Asia's iron ore futures. Gold stocks led the gains, with a 2.2% rise, while energy stocks rose 1.1%. The Australian mining trio of BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group slipped between 2% and 4.3%. Online retailer Kogan.com was the top gainer, jumping 13.8%.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly down as inflation trumps recovery optimism
summary: Asian markets declined on Monday as inflation concerns outweighed optimism over the global economic recovery, despite upbeat eurozone data and progress in vaccination drives. The impact of the US stimulus package and potential central bank policy changes are also weighing on investors. Experts warn of a long period of high inflation, forcing central banks to reconsider ultra-loose monetary policies.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine to acquire majority stake in PT BBR to strengthen foothold in Indonesia
summary: Marco Polo Marine announced plans to acquire a majority stake in PT BBR, an Indonesian shipping agency, to strengthen its presence in the country. The acquisition, pending shareholder approval, will see Marco Polo Marine's stake rise to up to 72% through a rights issue. PT BBR will become a key subsidiary, serving as a growth platform for Marco Polo Marine's Indonesia operations. The deal is expected to boost the company's core ship chartering business, which is recovering from the downturn in the offshore oil and gas sector.

site_title: Crypto miners halt China business after Beijing's crackdown, Bitcoin dives
summary: China's crackdown on bitcoin mining and trading has led to a halt in operations by major crypto miners, including Huobi Mall and BTC.TOP. The State Council announced the crackdown, targeting virtual currency mining, a significant business in China accounting for 70% of the world's crypto supply. As a result, Bitcoin has plummeted nearly 50% from its all-time high, with Huobi Mall suspending its custody businesses and BTC.TOP announcing the closure of its China operations. Regulators predict that Chinese crypto mining rigs will be sold overseas, potentially shifting computing power to foreign markets.

site_title: Airbus backs lightweight wing to preserve its lead over Boeing
summary: Airbus is developing a lightweight composite wing to improve fuel efficiency and production rate for its A320 aircraft family. The new wing, set to start assembly in the coming weeks, aims to reduce costs and increase efficiency. Airbus plans to deploy the wing on an upgraded A320 series and possibly on a stretch of the A321, which could accommodate more seats and range extension. The move aims to preserve Airbus' lead over Boeing, which is considering a new aircraft after the 737 Max crisis. The new wing is also seen as a key component in the development of a hydrogen-powered jet.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip downgrades Koufu to 'neutral' on delays to recovery
summary: Phillip Capital downgraded Koufu to "neutral" with a lower target price of S$0.64 due to a slower-than-expected recovery in consumption despite increased government support. The group's food courts near offices and in downtown areas have been heavily affected by reduced footfall, leading to temporary suspensions of operations. Phillip analyst Terence Chua attributed the negative impact to the shift to working from home and home-based learning, as well as delayed construction of an integrated facility.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI upgrades Uni-Asia to 'outperform' with higher S$0.91 target price
summary: KGI Securities has upgraded its call on Uni-Asia Group to "outperform" from "neutral", citing attractive valuations and resilient property markets in Japan and Hong Kong. The analyst raised its target price to S$0.91, representing 0.44 times FY2021 price-to-book value. The shipping business has strongly recovered, making up 60-70% of revenue, according to the latest business update.

site_title: GM improves rating in annual supplier relations study
summary: General Motors (GM) improved its rating in the annual Working Relations Index by 20 points to 289, moving closer to industry leaders Toyota and Honda. Despite the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic and semiconductor chip shortage, GM strengthened its relations with suppliers. The company's efforts to improve supplier ties are reflected in the survey results, which show benefits including stronger business results and supplier willingness to invest in new technologies. GM's rating increased from 269 in the previous year, while Ford Motor Co's rating dropped 15 points to 249.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong slides after reporting US$1.7b net loss
summary: Genting Hong Kong, a cruise ship operator, reported a net loss of $1.7 billion and net operating cash outflow of $629 million for the year ended December, citing the Covid-19 pandemic as a major challenge. The company's shares slid 2.2% due to concerns about its ability to continue as a going concern, with current liabilities exceeding assets by $3.3 billion. Genting Hong Kong remains optimistic about the cruise industry's return to normalcy by 2023, but faces significant uncertainty due to travel restrictions and government policies.

site_title: India passes 300,000 Covid-19 deaths: health ministry
summary: India has reported over 303,000 COVID-19 deaths, surpassing the US and Brazil as the third country to reach this milestone. The surge in infections has overwhelmed the healthcare system, with record single-day rises in fatalities and a severe shortage of oxygen and critical drugs. Many experts believe the real number of deaths is higher due to the spread of the disease in rural areas with poor health facilities and record-keeping. Harrowing images of long queues for funerals and makeshift pyres have emerged, highlighting the devastating impact of the pandemic in India.

images.alt_text: India has been hitting record single-day rises in infections and fatalities in recent weeks amid the brutal surge.

site_title: Millions of accounts exposed in hack of leading Japan dating app
summary: A leading Japanese matchmaking app, Omiai, was hacked, exposing personal information of over 1.7 million account holders. The data includes photos of ID used to confirm age, such as drivers' licenses and passports, but not credit card information. The breach is the latest in a string of high-profile online attacks, including the 2015 hack of adultery website AshleyMadison.com. Net Marketing Co, the app's developer, has reported the incident and is working to confirm misappropriation of the information.

site_title: Cannibal mice plague threatens Sydney homes and Australian farms
summary: Millions of mice are swarming eastern Australia, threatening homes, hospitals, and farms, particularly in New South Wales and Queensland. The rodents are causing significant damage, with reports of them eating dead rodents, contaminating crops, and damaging machinery and storage vessels. The crisis is expected to reach Sydney in weeks, with the state of New South Wales preparing to use a highly toxic chemical to tackle the problem. The agriculture industry is facing a $51 billion crisis, with farmers refraining from planting winter crops due to the risk of damage.

site_title: BlackRock joins funds betting on Indian assets amid outbreak
summary: BlackRock is increasing its long position in Indian assets, while other global funds like GW&K Investment Management and Invesco Hong Kong are boosting their holdings in the country's sustainable investing and renewable energy sectors. Despite the ongoing pandemic, investors remain confident in India's long-term growth prospects, driven by consumption. The Indian stock market has outperformed its peers, and the rupee has rebounded to become Asia's best performer in May. However, some fund managers are adopting a cautious stance due to concerns about a worsening outbreak.

site_title: Future sours for Hong Kong's brazen Apple Daily tabloid
summary: Hong Kong's pro-democracy Apple Daily newspaper faces uncertain future as its billionaire owner Jimmy Lai is jailed and many reporters fear arrest. The newspaper, known for its critical stance against Beijing and Hong Kong leaders, has seen declining circulation and advertising revenue. With its assets frozen, Apple Daily may only have 9-10 months of funds left. Chief Editor Ryan Law remains defiant, but staff morale is low, with some considering quitting. The newspaper's future is threatened by China's crackdown on dissent and Hong Kong's slide down press freedom rankings.

site_title: CCCS grants conditional approval for LSEG's acquisition of Refinitiv units, assets
summary: The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) has granted conditional approval for London Stock Exchange Group's (LSEG) acquisition of Refinitiv units and assets. The approval is contingent on LSEG's final commitments to address competition concerns, including making Refinitiv's foreign exchange benchmarks available to all existing and future customers. The commitments also ensure pricing and commercial terms are not changed in a way that undermines access to the benchmarks. A monitoring trustee will be appointed to monitor compliance, and a dispute resolution mechanism is available for users to seek recourse.

images.alt_text: The competition watchdog approved LSEG's final commitments to address competition concerns arising from the transaction.

site_title: Covid-19 breath test: NUS' Breathonix gets provisional nod for 60-second test after airport trial
summary: Singapore-based startup Breathonix has received provisional authorisation from the Health Sciences Authority for its 60-second Covid-19 breath test, the BreFence Go Covid-19 Breath Test System. The test detects volatile organic compounds in exhaled breath and has achieved an accuracy rate of over 90% in clinical trials. Breathonix will deploy the system at Changi Airport, where incoming travellers will undergo screening alongside antigen rapid tests. The company aims to target a service model with a price point of $20 per test, and is in discussion with local and overseas organisations to use the system.

site_title: Oil prices rise as storm forms in Gulf, doubts emerge on Iran deal
summary: Oil prices rose Monday as a storm formed in the Gulf of Mexico and Iran's monitoring deal expired, raising doubts about a potential deal to lift US sanctions on Iranian crude exports. Brent crude futures rose 0.5% to $66.76 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate rose 0.6% to $63.93 a barrel. The expiration of the monitoring deal could plunge indirect talks between Washington and Tehran into crisis, following a recent statement by US President Donald Trump that the US is ready to lift sanctions on Iran's oil, banking, and shipping sectors.

site_title: Almost 40% jump in CPF members who topped up savings amid pandemic
summary: The number of Central Provident Fund (CPF) members who topped up their retirement savings nearly tripled to 141,130 in 2021, contributing $2.97 billion, compared to 103,800 in 2019 and $2.14 billion. Voluntary housing refunds also increased by nearly 280% to 14,980, with $1.48 billion in refunds, compared to 5,500 in 2019 and $513 million. Experts attribute the surge to the pandemic's impact on financial markets and the benefits of using CPF funds for retirement savings.

site_title: Citi appoints Serene Gay as Singapore head of credit cards and personal loans
summary: Citi appoints Serene Gay as its new Singapore head of credit cards and personal loans, succeeding Vikas Kumar. Gay, with over 16 years of experience in Citi across Singapore, Thailand, and China, will oversee credit card and loan portfolios, driving customer growth and portfolio management. Her appointment reflects Citi's efforts to develop and grow Singaporean talent, with Brendan Carney and Kartik Mani praising her international experience and leadership skills.

site_title: S&P Global Ratings revises Vietnam's outlook to 'positive'
summary: S&P Global Ratings has revised Vietnam's outlook to 'positive', the only country to have its outlook improved by Moody's, S&P, and Fitch since the pandemic began. The decision reflects the country's continued economic outperformance and improving administrative processes. Despite near-term Covid-19 risks, Vietnam's economy is well-placed for a healthy recovery over the next one to two years. S&P maintains its 'BB' long-term and 'B' short-term ratings, but may raise them if the government sustains its track record of effective administrative capacity and fiscal stability.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.01 points, or 0.26%, to 1,566.18 on Monday. The index saw a gain of 278.57 million lots worth RM120.14 million. Gainers beat losers 374 to 85.

site_title: Japan opens mass vaccination sites for elderly ahead of Olympics
summary: Japan has opened two mass vaccination sites for the elderly ahead of the Tokyo Olympics, with the goal of vaccinating thousands daily. The sites, in Tokyo and Osaka, will use Moderna Inc's vaccine and operate for three months. The move aims to boost Japan's vaccination drive, which has been sluggish, with only 4.4% of the population vaccinated. The decision comes as the country battles a fourth wave of Covid-19 infections and faces concerns about the Olympic Games due to start on July 23.

images.alt_text: Japan opened two mass inoculation centres on Monday as the country races to vaccinate most of its elderly population against Covid-19 before the start of the Tokyo Olympics.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise on energy boost; US inflation data in focus
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 7,058.9, driven by a 0.5% gain in the energy index, led by Whitehaven Coal and Ampol. Investors await US inflation data, which could impact the Federal Reserve's monetary policy stance. The metals and mining index fell 0.1% due to slumping iron ore prices, while financial stocks dipped 0.1%. In New Zealand, the benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.4% amid a forecasted annual loss by dairy producer Synlait Milk.

site_title: 18-year-old Thai Pan zhi char latest restaurant to bite the dust
summary: Thai Pan, a 18-year-old restaurant in Singapore, will shut down at the end of the month due to financial difficulties exacerbated by the Covid-19 pandemic. The 80-year-old owner said the restaurant has struggled to stay afloat despite negotiating lower rent. Thai Pan joins a list of Singaporean eateries that have closed down, including Swee Kee Eating House, The Rice Table, and Bakerzin, due to various reasons including financial struggles and changing consumer landscape.

site_title: Race to avert disaster at China's biggest 'bad bank'
summary: China's state-owned "bad bank" Huarong Asset Management Co is facing a financial crisis, with the company owing $41 billion on the bond markets. Corporate chairman Wang Zhanfeng and his team are working to clean up the mess, but the situation remains uncertain. The Chinese government has stepped in to provide support, but experts warn that a default could have severe consequences for the nation's financial system and global investors. The government is planning to celebrate the 100th anniversary of its founding on July 1, which may influence its decision on how to handle Huarong. A possible solution involves foreign bondholders taking a haircut, but a long-term solution remains unclear.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start day with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, falling 0.14% to 28,417.99, following a tepid lead from Wall Street. The decline comes as investors monitor rising virus infections in Asia, prompting governments to impose fresh containment measures. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index was barely moved, and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.08%.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose at Monday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) gaining 0.4% or 13.72 points to 3,131.61. Enviro-Hub was the most actively traded counter, with its shares up 10.6% after announcing the acquisition of Pastel Gloves Sdn Bhd. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors maintaining a positive stance despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Building the right digital foundation for a post-Covid world
summary: Singapore's initiatives aim to help businesses adapt to the post-Covid-19 landscape by investing in digital technologies. The estimated growth of Asia Pacific's digital sector could result in over $8.6 trillion in economic surplus by 2025. In other news, Vietnam is seeking a lower tariff rate following Trump's announcement, while Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3% and a rate cut was made to shield the economy from tariff threats. Additionally, GoTo shares are expected to rebound after a $2.2 billion sell-off and foreign investors are returning to Vietnam's stocks.

site_title: Australia's Zip to acquire two buy-now-pay-later firms for A$160m
summary: Zip Co of Australia is acquiring two buy-now-pay-later firms, Twisto and Spotii, for A$160 million. Twisto operates in Europe, while Spotii is in the Middle East. The acquisitions will complement Zip's presence in the UK and expand its international footprint. This follows Zip's recent expansion plans, including a strategic stake in the Philippines-based firm TendoPay and a soft launch in Canada. The deal is expected to occur in the third quarter of 2021.

site_title: Golf: Mickelson never lost the desire, will to win, says caddie brother
summary: Phil Mickelson, the six-time major champion, has never lost his desire to win, according to his brother and caddie Tim. Mickelson won the PGA Championship at 50 years old, becoming golf's oldest major winner. This was his first major title since the 2013 British Open. Tim has been on Mickelson's bag since 2017, making Sunday's triumph the first time he has shared victory in a major from inside the ropes. Mickelson finished six-under par with a one-over-par 73.

site_title: Japan's Osaka city crumples under Covid-19 onslaught
summary: Japan's Osaka city is struggling under a surge of new Covid-19 infections, with hospitals running out of beds and ventilators, and doctors warning of a "system collapse". The city's healthcare system is buckling under the fourth wave of the pandemic, with 3,849 new cases reported in the week to Thursday, a fivefold increase from three months ago. The government is considering a state of emergency due to the high hospitalization rate, which is currently 96% of available beds. The situation raises concerns about hosting the Tokyo Olympics in July.

site_title: South Korea's central bank moves to develop pilot digital currency
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, plans to develop a pilot digital currency platform through an open bidding process. The pilot, set to run from August to December, will test the practicalities of a central bank-backed digital currency (CBDC) in a simulated environment, including mobile payments and fund transfers. This move follows global trends, with central banks in China, Britain, and Sweden exploring digital currencies to modernize their financial systems and ward off the threat from cryptocurrencies. The BOK aims to prepare for changes in the payment settlement system.

site_title: Veteran stock picker to join 'Son-chan' on SoftBank board
summary: Veteran Koei Tecmo chair Keiko Erikawa, 72, will join SoftBank Group's board, bringing her stock-picking expertise and authoritative voice after the loss of senior industry figures. Her appointment comes after SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son shifted from operating companies to pure investing, and follows a period of alignment between SoftBank and investors calling for change. Erikawa's involvement is seen as a strategic move to suit SoftBank's new investment-focused direction, and her reputation for savvy investing in tech stocks is expected to add value to the board.

site_title: Iraq says US$150b stolen oil cash smuggled out since 2003
summary: Iraq's President Barham Saleh stated that approximately US$150 billion in oil revenue has been smuggled out of the country since 2003. In response, he introduced a draft law to combat corruption, recover stolen funds, and hold perpetrators accountable. The law aims to curb endemic corruption and its effects on the nation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: FLCT, Frasers Property, Marco Polo, Sasseur Reit, KSH, Sinostar PEC
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include FLCT's proposed acquisition of six European properties for S$548.7 million, Marco Polo Marine's plan to take a majority stake in Indonesian shipping company PT BBR, and Sasseur Reit's expected net loss for FY2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Other notable announcements include the retirement of CRPU's CEO and the resignation of Sinostar's lead independent director, Teo Moh Gin. Trading halts were also implemented for various companies, including ecoWise and Enviro-Hub.

site_title: Taiwan slams WHO's 'indifference' after failing to get into key meeting
summary: Taiwan's government criticized the World Health Organization (WHO) for its "indifference" to the health rights of Taiwanese people after being excluded from a key meeting. Taiwan, which is not recognized as a country by the WHO due to China's objections, had been lobbying for observer status. The WHO's decision was seen as a capitulation to China's political interests, with Taiwan's government stating that it will continue to seek participation. Taiwan's health minister, Chen Shih-chung, accused the WHO of prioritizing politics over public health, while Foreign Minister Joseph Wu expressed regret over the WHO's "continued indifference".

site_title: UK's Labour pushes for vote on US minimum corporation tax plan
summary: The UK's Labour Party plans to push for a vote in parliament on introducing a global minimum corporation tax rate, following the US Treasury Department's acceptance of a floor of at least 15% during international negotiations. The proposed rate is lower than the US's proposed 21% minimum for multinational firms. Labour argues the tax will benefit Britain and stop multinationals from undercutting businesses. The UK will raise its main corporation tax rate to 25% in 2023, and finance minister Rishi Sunak has expressed support for reaching an international agreement on taxing digital companies.

site_title: US says unclear Iran ready for nuclear pact return
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken stated that it's unclear whether Iran is ready to return to compliance with the multination nuclear agreement. Blinken spoke ahead of a fifth round of talks in Vienna, amid reports that Washington may lift some sanctions to facilitate a deal. However, Blinken emphasized that any sanctions lift would need to be consistent with the nuclear agreement, and it remains unclear if Iran is willing to take the necessary steps. The outcome of the talks remains uncertain.

site_title: FLCT proposes to acquire six Europe properties for S$548.7m, four from sponsor
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) has proposed acquiring six European properties for S$548.7 million, with four from sponsor Frasers Property. The acquisition is expected to be distribution per unit (DPU) and net asset value (NAV) accretive, boosting DPU by 1.8% and NAV by 1.9%. The properties include a business park in the UK and logistics facilities in Germany and the Netherlands, with a total lettable area of 123,328 square meters. The acquisition is expected to be completed by June 2021 and will strengthen FLCT's portfolio, diversifying its tenant base and reducing tenant concentration.

images.alt_text: Blythe Valley Park, a business park located in Birmingham in the UK. The property is one of the six FLCT has proposed to acquire.

site_title: Jem and Westgate become new Covid-19 cluster with four community cases
summary: A new Covid-19 cluster has emerged in Singapore, centered around the Jem and Westgate malls in Jurong East, with 21 community cases linked to the area. Four cases, including a music teacher and a cleaner, have been confirmed, with the B1617 variant detected in one individual. The malls have been closed for two weeks for cleaning, while other local community cases have been reported at Changi Airport, Pasir Ris Elias Community Club, and Tan Tock Seng Hospital.

site_title: China braces for US$1.3t maturity wall as defaults surge
summary: China's corporate bond market is facing a significant challenge as US$1.3 trillion of domestic debt comes due in the next 12 months, with investors bracing for another turbulent stretch due to unprecedented defaults. Average corporate bond maturities have decreased to 3.02 years, the shortest annual average since 2016, as investors seek shorter-term investments to limit exposure to credit risk. Chinese authorities are struggling to balance reducing moral hazard by allowing more defaults while turning the domestic bond market into a more reliable source of long-term funding.

images.alt_text: Domestic Chinese bonds issued in the first quarter had an average tenor of 3.02 years, down from 3.22 years for all of last year and on course for the shortest annual average since Fitch Ratings began compiling the data in 2016.

site_title: US Covid cases and deaths drop to lowest levels in nearly a year
summary: The US is experiencing its lowest levels of COVID-19 cases and deaths in nearly a year, with daily cases averaging 25,700 and deaths at 578, a 39% and 14% decrease from two weeks ago, respectively. Nearly 50% of Americans have received at least one vaccine shot, and hospitalizations have fallen to their lowest point in 11 months. Experts predict the virus will become a manageable threat, but warn that communities with low vaccination rates remain at risk, emphasizing the need for continued vaccination efforts.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.32% to 28,407.29 and the Topix index up 0.44%. Investors eyed the potential extension of a virus state of emergency in several Japanese regions and monitored bitcoin's price.

site_title: Wuhan lab staff sought hospital care before Covid-19 outbreak disclosed: WSJ
summary: US intelligence report reveals that three Wuhan Institute of Virology researchers sought hospital care in November 2019, months before China disclosed the Covid-19 pandemic. The report may fuel calls for a broader investigation into the virus's origins. The Biden administration continues to have "serious questions" about the pandemic's origins, and is working with the WHO to support an expert-driven evaluation. China denies the lab leak theory, calling it a "hype" and saying it's focused on tracing the source. A WHO-led team concluded a lab leak was extremely unlikely after visiting the virology institute in February.

site_title: Study shows dogs can detect Covid-positive arrivals
summary: Researchers have found that dogs can detect over 90% of Covid-19 infections, even in asymptomatic patients, due to their exceptional sense of smell. This ability is similar to their capacity to detect other diseases such as cancer and malaria. The study suggests that trained dogs could potentially replace quarantine measures for new arrivals, providing a reliable and non-invasive method of COVID-19 detection.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange's new CEO is put on cleanup duty
summary: Hong Kong Exchange's new CEO, Nicolas Aguzin, has been tasked with reviewing the exchange's practices following a bribery scandal and censure from the regulator. Aguzin, a veteran banker from JPMorgan Chase, takes charge on Monday as the bourse delivers record earnings. His predecessor, Charles Li, oversaw significant growth but faced criticism for prioritizing business over investor protections. Aguzin is expected to prioritize the exchange's role as a regulator alongside its growth ambitions, but some experts question whether meaningful reforms will be implemented. The appointment has raised concerns about the exchange's continued status as an international financial hub amid China's tightening grip on the city.

site_title: S&P500 ascending channel widens
summary: The S&P500 is trading near the bottom of its ascending channel, which has exhibited relatively less severe price declines compared to earlier months. However, rising inflation sentiment and the US Federal Reserve's potential to scale back asset purchases due to inflation concerns may lead to further bearish pressure on the index. The channel's bottom, around 4,100, is expected to act as a strong support level, potentially preceding a price rally after two weeks of bearish turbulence.

site_title: Myanmar anti-coup insurgents seize police post, kill security forces
summary: Anti-coup insurgents in Myanmar seized a police station in the town of Mobye, killing at least 13 security forces and capturing four, according to local media. The attack is part of a surge in conflict since the February coup, which overthrew elected leader Aung San Suu Kyi. The junta, led by Min Aung Hlaing, disputes the death toll, while protesters demand the release of nearly 4,300 arrested individuals, including Suu Kyi.

site_title: Britain to unveil plans for 'digital border'
summary: The UK is set to unveil plans for a "fully digital border" with the introduction of electronic travel authorisation for pre-checking travellers, similar to the US system. Interior Minister Priti Patel will announce the plans in parliament, which also include a points-based migration system and stricter immigration rules. The new system aims to provide control over who enters the country, making it easier to identify potential threats. The move is part of a wider overhaul of the country's immigration system, following Brexit promises to tighten immigration rules and secure borders.

site_title: New Zealand's Synlait Milk expects annual loss on shipping delays
summary: Synlait Milk, a New Zealand dairy firm, forecasts an annual loss of between NZ$20 million and NZ$30 million due to shipping delays and disruptions to its key supply channel to China. The company's woes follow its customer and shareholder A2 Milk's downgrade of its full-year revenue forecast, which is largely dependent on the "daigou" channel. The channel has been constrained since last year due to border closures and a drop in Chinese students. Synlait's CEO and CFO left their roles earlier this year amidst market uncertainties.

site_title: Bitcoin volatility puts weekend traders on stomach-churning ride
summary: Bitcoin's extreme volatility carried into the weekend, with the cryptocurrency trading at US$33,052, down 13% as of Sunday, below its 200-day moving average. The price swing is comparable to the US equity market's VIX indicator, sitting above 130. Despite the volatility, Bitcoin remains up over 250% in the past year. Recent negative headlines, including a tweet from Elon Musk and China's warning on cryptocurrency mining, contributed to the price drop. Investors are experiencing one of the rockiest weeks ever for Bitcoin, with prices swinging 30% in each direction on Wednesday.

site_title: Bubble risks test China's commitment to no sharp turn in policy
summary: China's efforts to curb asset bubbles, including rising home prices, may not be enough to prevent a sharp turn in monetary policy. The government's attempts to control price increases through measures like a national property tax and increased supply are being challenged by rapid gains in raw materials, prompting concerns about inflation. The People's Bank of China is facing a delicate balance between restraining inflation and maintaining a benign monetary policy scenario, which could lead to a shock to China's financial markets.

site_title: Britain's Prime Minister Johnson to wed fiancee Symonds next summer: newspaper
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his fiancée Carrie Symonds have set a July 30, 2022, wedding date, according to a report by The Sun. The couple, who have been living together since 2019, will exchange vows at a secret location. Johnson, 56, and Symonds, 33, have been engaged since February 2020 and share a son. This will be Johnson's third marriage, following previous marriages to Marina Wheeler and Allegra Mostyn-Owen. The wedding invitation has been sent to family and friends.

site_title: UK's Patel to unveil post-Brexit overhaul of immigration
summary: UK Home Secretary Priti Patel is set to announce a "wholesale" reform of the nation's immigration system, allowing Britain to attract skilled workers while tightening security. The overhaul includes introducing work routes, suspending the cap on skilled workers, and free visa extensions for healthcare workers. Patel also plans to fix the asylum system, which costs over £1 billion, and advocate new legislation to tackle people smuggling and remove dangerous criminals. The reforms aim to address the "broken" immigration system, with the goal of attracting skilled workers while keeping the country safe.

site_title: 25 new Covid-19 cases in S'pore, including 21 in community and 1 in workers' dorm
summary: Singapore reported 25 new Covid-19 cases on May 23, including 21 in the community and 1 in a workers' dormitory. The total number of cases now stands at 61,824. The health authority is concerned about the rise in unlinked cases, with 61 cases reported in the past week, and is considering more aggressive measures to contain the spread. The country is in its second week of heightened mobility restrictions.

images.alt_text: Singapore confirms 21 new Covid-19 cases in the community and 1 in a workers' dormitory.

site_title: Garuda plans major restructuring that may halve operating fleet
summary: Indonesian carrier Garuda Indonesia plans a major restructuring, potentially halving its operating fleet from 142 aircraft to 70, in an effort to survive the Covid-19 pandemic crisis. The airline has around 70 trillion rupiah ($6.5 billion) of debt and negative cash flow, with its equity valued at minus 41 trillion rupiah. Failure to restructure could lead to an abrupt end of the company, according to President Director Irfan Setiaputra. Garuda has also been offering an early retirement program for employees as part of cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Taiwan promises quick fix to Covid testing issue after criticism
summary: Taiwan's Health Minister Chen Shih-chung promised to resolve the issue of delayed reporting of Covid-19 tests, after announcing 570 new cases whose positive tests had not been included in previous reports due to reporting delays. The move sparked criticism from opposition politicians, who claim the government is "inventing words" and spreading fear. Chen said the "regression calibration" of case numbers was necessary to accurately reflect the state of infections, but the opposition parties argue the reporting system needs improvement, not a new term. Taiwan has reported 4,322 cases, including 23 deaths, since the pandemic began.

site_title: Agility and resilience to hurdle ahead
summary: Businesses must adapt to recurring Covid-19 clampdowns with agility and resilience. Experts emphasize the need for a business continuity plan, involving all stakeholders, to build resilience in the new normal. Companies should focus on identifying new opportunities, maintaining supply chain resilience, workforce safety and productivity, and rapid digital adoption. With the pandemic likely to become endemic, businesses must be ready for multiple scenarios, adopting a cultural shift from avoiding risk to managing and accepting risk. Leveraging technology and embracing change are crucial for thriving in this new landscape.

site_title: Consortium led by Kenya's Safaricom and Japan's Sumitomo wins Ethiopian licence
summary: A consortium led by Kenya's Safaricom and Japan's Sumitomo has won the operating licence in Ethiopia, paying US$850 million. The licence award marks the beginning of a new era in the country, with the operator expected to create up to 1.5 million jobs and invest US$8.5 billion in infrastructure. The Ethiopian government also plans to sell a 45% stake in state-run mobile operator Ethio Telecom and will open up mobile financial services to competition after a year.

site_title: Unmanned supermarkets to the rescue in Sweden's rural areas
summary: In rural Sweden, unmanned supermarkets in mobile containers are providing a convenient shopping solution for villagers who previously had to travel miles to buy food. The stores, operated by Lifvs, allow customers to unlock the door and scan items using a smartphone app, and are linked to bank accounts and national identification systems for added security. The stores have been a hit, with one store in Veckholm selling hundreds of items daily, and the company plans to open its first unmanned supermarkets outside Sweden early next year.

site_title: After US$690b slump, traders see value in Asia tech stocks
summary: Asian tech stocks have seen significant losses, with combined losses totaling around $690 billion from their first-quarter peaks. However, investors are now looking for buying opportunities, with JPMorgan Asset Management suggesting a "valuation story" and a potential rebound. Analysts point to secular trends in digitalization, AI, and machine learning as drivers of growth, and see select "secular growth names" as attractive value. Despite concerns over valuations and inflation, many investors remain bullish on Asian tech, citing strong macro support and the long-term positive tech cycle.

site_title: Growing sustainably with Frasers' S-Reits
summary: Frasers Property, a Singapore-based REIT group, reported a record revenue of S$231.7 million and adjusted net property income (NPI) of S$173.9 million in the first half of FY21, driven by a merger with Frasers Commercial Trust. The REIT achieved a 95.1% year-on-year increase in revenue and 79.3% increase in NPI, with a portfolio occupancy rate of 96.8%. Frasers Centrepoint Trust and Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust are among the group's three SGX-listed trusts, with FLCT entering the Straits Times Index in April 2021.

site_title: Brazilian architect da Rocha, who won the Pritzker, dies aged 92
summary: Brazilian architect Paulo Mendes da Rocha, winner of the 2006 Pritzker Prize, died at 92 in Sao Paulo, Brazil. Da Rocha was a prominent figure in Brazilian and worldwide architecture, known for his brutalist and modernist style. He was banned from teaching by the military government in the 1970s for his opinions on the social role of architects. Da Rocha's iconic works include the Portuguese Language Museum and the Pinacoteca art museum in Sao Paulo, and he also designed the National Coach Museum in Lisbon.

site_title: Oil has worst week in over a month with potential Iran return
summary: Oil benchmarks experienced their worst week in over a month due to a potential nuclear deal with Iran that could lift US sanctions on Iranian crude, causing a 2.7% decline in WTI futures and a 3.2% decline in Brent. Iranian President Hassan Rouhani stated that major sanctions will be lifted as part of any nuclear deal, sparking concerns about the additional supply of 4 million barrels per day that Iran could bring back into the market.

site_title: Good Class Bungalow prices keep rising
summary: Good Class Bungalow prices in Singapore continue to rise, driven by strong demand from wealthy buyers, low interest rates, and limited supply. A record-breaking S$4,291 psf was set for a Cluny Hill bungalow, while two vacant plots in Chatsworth Road sold for nearly 40% above the previous year's deal. Experts predict continued price growth, with estimates of a 20% increase in prices near the Singapore Botanic Gardens and a 10% increase in the Holland area. The scarcity of properties and the exclusivity of GCBs contribute to the strong demand, with many buyers willing to match or exceed sellers' price expectations.

images.alt_text: Two adjoining freehold vacant plots in Chatsworth Road with wide frontage are being sold for a total of S$78.06m.
A local tech entrepreneur who recently sold a startup firm is in the early stages of buying this bungalow being built along Cluny Hill, for S$63.7m.

site_title: Vietnam holds parliament election amid new Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Vietnam held its parliamentary election on Sunday amidst a rapidly spreading Covid-19 outbreak, with tens of millions expected to cast their ballots for a largely rubber-stamp legislature. The election, which is held every five years, saw fewer independent candidates than before, with 92% of candidates affiliated with the Communist Party. The country's Communist Party retains tight control over media and tolerates little dissent, with 99% of registered voters participating in the 2016 elections.

site_title: Finding love for reflation in both banks and tech
summary: Tech stocks are experiencing a correction due to rising interest rates and concerns over debt, but Citi Private Bank argues this is not a fundamental problem with technology. Instead, it's a market adjustment as investors reassess valuations and focus on companies with strong fundamentals, such as those in healthtech and fintech. Meanwhile, banks are benefiting from reflation as rates rise, allowing them to reprice loans faster than deposits, and are well-positioned to absorb credit losses.

site_title: Diverted flight passengers saw Belarus activist 'panicking'
summary: Passengers on a Ryanair flight diverted to Minsk, Belarus, reported that opposition blogger Roman Protasevich appeared anxious and "panicked" after realizing the plane was being diverted, stating he was facing the death penalty. However, once the plane landed, Protasevich reportedly became calm, suggesting he had anticipated the outcome. Protasevich was later detained in Minsk, sparking concerns about his safety and the potential implications for Belarus' human rights record.

images.alt_text: Passengers on Ryanair flight FR4978 described the anxious minutes for opposition blogger Roman Protasevich after he realised that the plane was being diverted to Minsk, where he was later detained.

site_title: Hin Leong's Lim family fail in legal bids against court-appointed managers
summary: The Singapore High Court has frozen Lim Oon Kuin's and his children's US$3.5 billion assets worldwide, including properties and shares, as part of a bid to recoup billions owed to Hin Leong Trading's creditors. The liquidators also successfully claimed US$19 million from the Lim family in relation to Ocean Tankers. The Lim family may appeal the court's decision, which marks a significant step in their bid to recover the debts owed.

site_title: US dollar rises on upbeat US factory data
summary: The US dollar rose against a basket of currencies on Friday, boosted by encouraging US manufacturing data, despite concerns about taper talk from the US Federal Reserve. The dollar index was 0.222% higher at 89.993, on pace for a weekly loss of 0.4%. Strategists say the Fed's accommodative stance remains, but improved US data, especially relative to Europe, bolsters the bull case for the greenback.

site_title: Airbus to boost A220 jet's range, newest operator says
summary: Airbus plans to increase the range of its A220 jet, allowing airlines to open more international niche routes. The move comes after its newest operator, David Neeleman, discussed adding extra endurance to the jetliner with Airbus in 2021. The A220, designed by Canada, has been taken over by Airbus since 2018. The enhanced range is expected to boost the jet's competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Demand for luxury penthouses holds steady despite pandemic
summary: Demand for luxury penthouses in Singapore remains steady despite the pandemic, with 9 transactions this year, including 7 in the Core Central Region and 2 in the Rest of Central Region. The sales of high-end penthouses have been bolstered by ultra-high-net-worth individuals and foreign investors, who are attracted to the city-state's financial hub status and stable political environment. Experts predict that demand for luxury homes will regain momentum once travel restrictions are eased, with Knight Frank's Wealth Report 2021 naming Singapore as the leading destination for prime homes among well-heeled Asians.

site_title: Sarine looks to downstream diamond technology to polish out new growth
summary: Sarine Technologies, a mainboard-listed company, is shifting its focus to downstream diamond technology to drive long-term growth. The Israel-headquartered company, which was established in 1988, is developing technology to grade diamonds using artificial intelligence and machine learning, enabling more accurate and consistent grading. This e-Grading business line is valued at around US$0.30 to US$0.60 per share and has the potential to shape the entire diamond grading industry. Sarine is also focusing on traceability of diamonds, using technology to track and verify the origin of diamonds, amid a rising trend of customers interested in sustainable products.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report highlights a mixed week for the tanker and dry bulk markets. The Capesize market rebounded, with a solid gain, largely driven by the Pacific region. The North Atlantic remained weak, while the Transatlantic and Transpacific markets saw significant differences. The Panamax market saw mixed opinions, with solid support for front haul trips from the North Americas and weak transatlantic demand. The FFA market saw thin activity, but reports of an 82,000-dwt fixing at $25,000 for 12 months emerged. The Ultramax/Supramax sector saw a positive week, with better numbers from the US Gulf and Asia.

site_title: Hin Leong's Lim family fail in bids against court-appointed managers
summary: The Singapore High Court has ruled in favor of Hin Leong Trading's liquidators, granting them a Mareva injunction to freeze up to $3.5 billion of Lim Oon Kuin and his children's assets worldwide. The liquidators, led by Goh Thien Phong, are seeking to recover billions of dollars owed to over 20 creditors, including major banks. The Lim family may appeal the decision, which follows a similar court victory for the liquidators in their bid against Ocean Tankers, another troubled company in the Hin Leong empire.

images.alt_text: The liquidators of failed Hin Leong Trading have scored a big win in their bid to recoup mega bucks from scandal-hit tycoon Lim Oon Kuin and his children of the Hin Leong group, one of Asia's largest oil services firms.

site_title: Montreal's hot housing market still affordable, Quebec says
summary: The Quebec government reassures that Montreal's hot housing market remains affordable, despite rising prices. Median home prices in metropolitan Montreal climbed 18% to C$473,000 in the past year, and condo prices increased 23%. Finance Minister Eric Girard says fundamentals of the market remain strong and the economy is recovering well, making Montreal an affordable city compared to other major Canadian cities. The government welcomes tighter lending rules to prevent buyers from waiving property inspections to secure deals.

site_title: PBOC says it will keep yuan exchange rate at 'basically stable' levels
summary: The People's Bank of China (PBOC) announced it will maintain the yuan's exchange rate at "basically stable" levels, following comments from officials suggesting the currency should appreciate. Vice-governor Liu Guo-qiang stated the future trend will be determined by supply and demand, and the yuan will be kept at reasonable and balanced levels. This decision comes amid rising global commodity prices, which China is struggling with. The PBOC has also indicated it will eventually let the market decide the exchange rate, a shift from its previous control.

site_title: Personal accident plans: icing on the cake
summary: Personal accident insurance plans provide coverage for death and injuries from accidents, as well as from other causes such as food poisoning and infectious diseases. Some plans cover up to age 99 and offer reimbursement for non-traditional treatments like Traditional Chinese Medicine and chiropractic treatment. Insurers have added Covid-19 cover at no extra cost, and premiums have dropped by 5% to S$167.9 million in 2020. The General Insurance Association reported that awareness of PA and its value is higher among younger people, with 18-34-year-olds listing PA as the most important general insurance in the next 12 months.

site_title: Inside the long-lost brickyards that built NYC
summary: A long-lost brickyard complex in Kingston, New York, has been transformed into a boutique hotel and retreat, honoring the industry's past. The site, once home to over 135 brickyards along the Hudson River, produced millions of bricks for New York City buildings between 1800 and 1950. The Empire State Building, Museum of Natural History, and Brooklyn Bridge arches were all built with Hudson Valley bricks. After a developer restored the site, it now features 31 cabins, an open-air restaurant, a spa, and walking trails amidst the ruins of the old kiln sheds and brick buildings.

images.alt_text: Old bricks in the Hudson River near the Hutton Brickyards property in Kingston. It's fairly safe to assume that any brick building constructed between 1800 and 1950 includes some form of sediment from the banks of the Hudson River.

site_title: Should investors answer SIA's call for more cash?
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) may need to issue over 3.47 billion new shares by 2030 to meet its cash needs, following the maturity of mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs). Despite initial low demand, Temasek Holdings took up a significant portion of the initial 3.5 billion S$ tranche, holding 95.9% of the MCBs. The airline group's chairman and CEO also saw their provisional allotments lapse, highlighting the challenge SIA faces in attracting investors.

images.alt_text: When Singapore Airlines offered its shareholders the first S$3.5 billion tranche of mandatory convertible bonds (MCBs) last year there were few takers other than Temasek Holdings.

site_title: The art of the sneaker
summary: A new exhibition at the Design Museum in London showcases the rise of global sneaker culture, from its early beginnings as a performance shoe to a cult collector's item. The exhibition, "Sneakers Unboxed: Studio to Street," features over 270 pairs of sneakers, highlighting their role in fashion, art, and culture. The show charts the history of sneakers from the 1900s to the present day, including their impact on youth cultures, the adoption by different communities, and their increasing value as a collector's asset. The exhibition also explores the environmental issues surrounding the industry, with innovations such as sustainable materials and 3D-knitting robots.

site_title: Europe's risky bonds tempt traders as ECB signals no taper yet
summary: Europe's riskiest government-bond markets are experiencing a heated debate over the European Central Bank's (ECB) asset purchase plans. The ECB's decision not to taper its stimulus has sparked a rally in Italy's sovereign debt, with yields reaching a one-year high. Market participants are weighing the risks of a premature tightening against the potential for continued monetary support. ECB President Christine Lagarde has signaled that the ECB will maintain its current stimulus settings, but some analysts predict that the extra spread on 10-year Italian debt may narrow in the coming months, depending on inflation expectations.

site_title: EU denounces Myanmar junta's electoral proposal to dissolve Suu Kyi party
summary: The European Union has denounced a proposal by Myanmar's junta-appointed election commission to dissolve Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy, which won the general election in November. The EU's executive Commission described the proposal as "blatant disregard for the will of Myanmar's people and for due legal process." The proposal follows the junta's claim of vote fraud, which the EU and independent observers have disputed. The EU will continue to denounce attempts to overturn the will of the Myanmar people and alter the election outcome.

site_title: 33 director acquisitions and S$30 million in buybacks filed
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) declined 0.4% from May 14 to 20, bringing its total return for the 2021 year to 11.0%. The top institutional inflows were DBS, Singapore Telecommunications, and OCBC. Meanwhile, 10 primary-listed stocks conducted share buybacks, with OCBC, Wilmar International, and Keppel Corporation leading the consideration tally. Notable director acquisitions included Calvin Ho Han Leong's 4.04 million shares of First Sponsor Group, and Wee Ee-chao's 769,000 shares of UOB-Kay Hian Holdings.

site_title: Singapore a popular base for China tech firms
summary: China tech firms are increasingly setting up their regional headquarters in Singapore, drawn by the country's stable business climate, excellent internet infrastructure, and market access to a large population in Southeast Asia. More than 80 of the world's top 100 software and services companies have a presence in Singapore, including Alibaba, Tencent, and ByteDance. Companies like Alibaba, Tencent, and Ping An Insurance are expanding their operations in Singapore to separate their domestic business from their overseas business, driven by US-China trade tensions and the decoupling of the tech sectors.

site_title: Singapore to review support for vulnerable firms amid outbreak
summary: Singapore will review its support for vulnerable firms amid the new wave of Covid-19 infections, which have led to increased restrictions and reduced business activity. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the government will monitor the situation and assess how to further support viable but vulnerable businesses. The review aims to address the impact of the restrictions on firms that have not been required to cease operations.

site_title: Summers says crypto has chance of becoming 'digital gold'
summary: Former US Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers says cryptocurrencies, like bitcoin, have a chance of becoming "digital gold" and a safe-hold asset for wealth. He believes crypto's market value could reach a third of gold's value, potentially appreciating by 14-fold or more. Summers notes that cryptocurrencies don't impact the overall economy and won't replace traditional payments. Nobel laureate Paul Krugman also expressed skepticism about crypto's value but acknowledged its potential as an alternative to gold.

site_title: Air India says February's data breach affected 4.5m passengers
summary: Air India confirmed a data breach in February that affected approximately 4.5 million passengers, with personal data leaked in a cyberattack on its data processor, SITA. The compromised servers were later secured, and no abnormal activity was observed. SITA, which serves several airlines, reported a "highly sophisticated" cyberattack in March and initiated containment measures. The airline is currently dealing with financial and legal issues, including a $1.2 billion arbitration award from Cairn Energy. This incident is part of a growing trend of major cyber incidents in the aviation and travel industries.

site_title: Salary of Hong Kong bourse's new chief tops his predecessor's
summary: Hong Kong's new stock exchange chief, Nicolas Aguzin, will earn a basic salary of HK$10 million (S$1.7 million) per year, surpassing his predecessor Charles Li's HK$9.315 million. Aguzin, a former banker at JPMorgan Chase & Co, will serve a three-year term and be awarded 211,756 shares worth HK$96 million. Half of the shares will be cashable after one year, while the rest will vest after two years. This compensation package is considered a significant increase, highlighting the growing importance of the stock exchange in Hong Kong.

site_title: Venice Architecture Biennale explores post-pandemic living
summary: The 17th International Architecture Exhibition, titled "How will we live together?", opened in Venice, exploring post-pandemic living and coexistence. Curator Hashim Sarkis asked architects to reflect on the future and its challenges. The exhibition runs for six months, focusing on the question of how to live together in a world affected by the pandemic.

site_title: India's JSW Steel considering bid for Gupta's British business: sources
summary: India's JSW Steel is considering a bid to buy Liberty Steel in Britain and other mills, including Adhunik steel mill in eastern India, as part of Sanjeev Gupta's global commodities empire sale. This move could mark a new chapter for Britain's steel industry, which has been privatized and sold to overseas buyers as its manufacturing strength declined. The potential sale would further consolidate the global steel market, with JSW Steel being India's largest steel producer.

site_title: Investors cut emerging market bond positions by most in five years: survey
summary: Investors have cut emerging market bond positions by the largest margin in five years, according to a JPMorgan survey. The 221 participants managing $1.4 trillion in assets under management reduced their "hard currency" emerging market sovereign bond positions by 10.5%. Half of the investors are worried about higher-than-expected inflation, and 70% expect financial market risks from India's Covid-19 situation to be contained to India.

site_title: Online charity initiative raises over S$1m to benefit needy during the pandemic
summary: An online charity initiative called Mind The Gap (MTG) in Singapore raised over S$1.1 million to benefit needy families during the pandemic. Launched by Anthea Ong, the funds were disbursed by a coalition of eight non-profit organizations to support those who couldn't qualify for government financial assistance or received inadequate aid. The initiative helped over 700 families, including sex workers, transgender individuals, and those living in Pulau Ubin, and was praised for its collaborative spirit and quick response.

site_title: 25 passengers arrive in Singapore from India every day, 180 fly back on repatriation flights
summary: Singapore sees an average of 25 passengers arriving daily from India, mostly Singapore citizens and permanent residents, while 180 depart daily on repatriation flights to India. All flights are operated by Indian carriers, with Singapore's approval, and take place at Changi Airport's Terminal 1. The Indian government has banned all other passenger flights between the two countries since March last year. The recent B1617 coronavirus variant has raised concerns in Singapore, with a cluster reported at Changi Airport.

site_title: Sinostar PEC announces cessation of lead independent director
summary: Sinostar PEC Holdings announced the cessation of Teo Moh Gin, 62, as its lead independent director, effective May 21, due to personal and health reasons. Teo, who also chaired several committees, cited these reasons for his departure. The company reported a significant jump in net profit to 59.3 million yuan for the first quarter of 2021, driven by increased production volume and gross margins.

site_title: New Yorkers enjoy US$260m park floating on Hudson River
summary: A US$260 million public park, Little Island, has opened on the Hudson River in New York, offering a 2.4-acre artificial island with lush green spaces and scenic views. The park, accessible via two pedestrian bridges, was financed by billionaire Barry Diller and his wife Diane von Furstenberg, with Diller committing to bear the costs of maintenance for 20 years. The park's opening follows the lifting of New York's coronavirus restrictions, which had been in place for over a year, resulting in the loss of over 30,000 lives.

site_title: Gold eases as dollar climbs on strong US data, but set for weekly gain
summary: Gold prices inched lower on Friday due to a stronger US dollar, despite expected weekly gains. Spot gold eased 0.1% to $1,876.42 per ounce, while US gold futures settled down 0.3%. Strong US manufacturing data and subdued Treasury yields are supporting gold prices, which are still on track for a third straight weekly gain. The dollar's rise makes gold more expensive for other currency holders, but analysts expect gold to rise as the negative impact of Fed minutes wears off, with a possible resistance at $1,900/oz.

site_title: London leading a post-pandemic theatre streaming revolution
summary: London's theatres have successfully transitioned to streaming shows to survive the pandemic, with almost half of stage venues developing digital offerings. Theaters are using 3D technology, live editing, and dedicated streaming platforms to create engaging content. Streaming has helped claw back lost revenue and has become a new source of income. Theaters are now planning to continue streaming even after reopening, with some planning to stream every new production. This shift is driven by the success of London's digital offerings, which have attracted over 100,000 viewers from 90 countries.

site_title: Myanmar ethnic army attacks jade mining town, media say
summary: Myanmar's Kachin Independence Army (KIA) launched an attack on military positions in the jade mining town of Hkamti, northwest of the country, on Saturday. The attack, which began early in the morning, is part of the KIA's advance into new territory as Myanmar remains in chaos since the army seized power in February. The site attacked is near a mining venture involving the military-owned Myanma Economic Holdings conglomerate, and the fighting is still ongoing, with reports of gunshots and smoke rising from the area.

images.alt_text: Forces of the Kachin Independence Army (KIA), one of the ethnic factions opposed to Myanmar's coup, attacked military positions at the northwestern jade mining town of Hkamti on Saturday, local media reported.

site_title: MOM apologises to ex-DJ Jade Rasif for accusing her of 'inaccurate' account of Covid scare
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) in Singapore has apologized to former DJ Jade Rasif for labeling her account of a domestic worker's Covid-19 scare as "inaccurate". The ministry retracted its post and removed the word "inaccurate" after realizing it could have portrayed Rasif's account as false. The apology comes after a Facebook post by MOM on May 17, which Rasif had criticized for its tone and content.

site_title: Increasing number of China technology firms boost local tech ecosystem
summary: China technology firms are increasingly investing in Singapore, bolstering the local tech ecosystem and drawing foreign investment. The country has become a hub for tech enterprises, with 65% of fintech funding in South-east Asia flowing to Singapore between 2015 and 2019.
