To accelerate the shift to lower carbon economies, experts say stronger impetus in the form of job opportunities and socio-economic benefits are needed, highlighting the need for tangible drivers to speed up the transition.

site_title: Ferrari's SF90 Spider is a S$2m antidote to the pandemic
summary: Ferrari has introduced the S$2m SF90 Spider, an open-top two-seater offering fresh air and sunshine. The hybrid drivetrain provides 1,000 horsepower, accelerating from 0-100km/h in 2.5 seconds. The plug-in hybrid electric vehicle has a 25km battery range at 135km/h, appealing to younger buyers. Ferrari's sales in Singapore have seen a record increase, with 44 Ferraris registered last year and 18 in the first four months of 2021. The SF90 Spider's high price and long waiting period may test the demand for Ferrari's latest model.

site_title: PhyDi infrastructure leads the path to sustainable growth in Asean
summary: Asian economies, led by China, have rebounded from the pandemic with infrastructure investments supporting growth. Asean nations, including Singapore and Vietnam, are launching new infrastructure projects to boost productivity, jobs, and economic growth. Higher-quality infrastructure can also positively impact health, education, and wealth outcomes. Examples include Singapore's planned MRT lines and Vietnam's US$5 billion North-South Expressway, with the latter also introducing a new law to spur investment. This investment is expected to have a powerful multiplier effect, boosting economic growth by up to 2.7 times.

images.alt_text: The future of infrastructure development lies in our concerted ability to leverage emerging technologies that enhance the efficiency and sustainability of physical buildouts: Standard Chartered Bank.

site_title: Blackstone agrees to buy UK-based St Modwen Properties for £1.2 billion
summary: Blackstone has agreed to buy UK-based St Modwen Properties for £1.2 billion (S$2.26 billion) in a cash offer of 542 pence per share. The deal values St Modwen at a premium of 21.1% over its previous price. The purchase will give Blackstone a larger stake in the UK's warehouse market, amid intensified competition from global investors. The UK warehouse market is outperforming other commercial properties, with lease agreements reaching a record in the first quarter. The deal marks Blackstone's latest move to expand its logistics portfolio in the UK.

site_title: Dream Industrial wins auction to buy assets in European warehouse fund
summary: Dream Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust has won an auction to buy a portfolio of 31 European warehouses for 880 million euros (S$1.4 billion). The Canadian Reit beat out rival bids, with the company's ability to execute the deal quickly being a key factor. The portfolio includes properties in six countries, offering opportunities for further development, and is expected to close in the next 60 days. Europe's warehouse market is experiencing a boom due to the growth in e-commerce during the pandemic.

site_title: US dollar slips as Fed minutes-fuelled bounce fades
summary: The US dollar slipped as minutes from the Federal Reserve's policy meeting showed a possible discussion of tapering its bond purchases, contrary to investor expectations. Despite this, the dollar remained above a recent low, trading 0.25% lower against a basket of peers. The Aussie dollar rose 0.4% and the euro 0.2% as the dollar's decline continued. Cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin and Ether, were volatile after a recent decline.

site_title: Ford unveils its first all-electric pickup truck
summary: Ford has unveiled its first all-electric pickup truck, the F-150 "Lightning," as part of its $22 billion campaign to ramp up electric vehicle offerings by 2025. The truck boasts a range of eco-friendly features, including the ability to supply electricity to a house for three days in the event of a power cut. Production is set to begin in spring 2022, with competition from start-up Rivian and General Motors' GMC Hummer EV expected to heat up the market.

site_title: SIA and Qantas' diverging fortunes show Covid disparities
summary: Qantas and Singapore Airlines are experiencing diverging fortunes amid the COVID-19 pandemic, with Qantas emerging strongly due to its buoyant home market and Singapore Airlines facing record losses. Qantas expects revenue from domestic routes to almost double, while Singapore Airlines forecasts passenger traffic to reach only 32% of pre-Covid levels by July. The airline's record annual loss of S$4.27 billion reflects the challenges faced by the global aviation industry.

site_title: A naturally growing wine scene
summary: Singapore's wine scene is expanding with the emergence of niche shops offering a wide variety of wines, including natural and Greek labels. New stores like Wine Mouth, Drunken Farmer, and Achinos provide customers with unique and affordable options, while online platforms like Clink Clink offer expertly curated wine selections. The growing demand for natural wines and Greek wines is driven by a shift in the wine world, with consumers seeking more sustainable and authentic options.

site_title: Myanmar air force chief in Moscow for military helicopter expo: reports
summary: Myanmar's air force chief, Maung Maung Kyaw, is attending the HeliRussia exhibition in Moscow, where he will discuss over 20 megaprojects, including the procurement of arms and military hardware, with Russian officials. This trip comes amid the ongoing crisis in Myanmar, where the military seized power in February, sparking near-daily protests and a crackdown that has resulted in hundreds of deaths. The visit highlights the growing defense ties between Russia and Myanmar, which have expanded in recent years, despite international sanctions on Myanmar's military.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SIIC Environment Holdings announced a supplementary agreement for a wastewater treatment project in Baoqing, China. The company also started commercial operations on seven wastewater treatment projects totaling 250,000 tonnes, contributing positively to its performance. In contrast, Koufu Group expects its FY2021 revenue and operating profits to be impacted by the one-month dining-in ban, with a 10% decline in same-store revenue compared to 2019.

site_title: China's regulatory tightening pains and gains
summary: China's regulatory tightening efforts, aimed at curbing the power of tech giants and promoting market competition, have put the country's economy on a more sustainable path with a cleaner government. Despite initial market volatility, the regulations have reduced systemic risk, fixed loopholes, and increased efficiency. China's experience shows that regulatory tightening has been effective in stabilizing debt and productivity growth, while the US has been slow to address similar issues. China's approach, focusing on anti-monopoly laws and data access, is seen as more pro-market and pro-innovation, potentially giving it an edge in fostering competition and driving digital innovation.

site_title: Lego celebrates diversity with rainbow coloured figurines
summary: Lego has unveiled a new set of rainbow-coloured figurines to celebrate diversity and the LGBTQI+ community. The "Everyone is Awesome" set features 11 unique mini figures with individual hairstyles and colours, designed to promote inclusivity and love. The set, which includes 346 pieces, will be available on June 1 to coincide with Pride Month. Set designer Matthew Ashton, a member of the LGBTQI+ community, created the set to spread "Lego love" and promote acceptance of differences, inspiring kids to be open to everyone. The set aims to make the world a happier, inclusive, and living place.

images.alt_text: Danish toy brick maker Lego unveiled a new set of rainbow-coloured figurines on Thursday to celebrate the diversity of its fans and the LGBTQI+ community.

site_title: Samsung Hub's level 9 sells at record S$4,050 psf
summary: Singapore's Samsung Hub has sold its ninth floor for a record-breaking S$53.1 million, or S$4,050 per square foot, surpassing the previous record of S$3,800 psf. The 13,110 sq ft floor, leased to three tenants, was sold by property investment group Sun Venture to Lee Kim Tah. The sale reflects a low-2 per cent net yield, but CBRE's Michael Tay notes that investors can take a position on office assets due to tight supply and high occupancy despite the Covid-19 outbreak.

site_title: Swedish house prices soar at fastest pace ever
summary: Sweden's housing market has set a record for the fastest price increase, with home prices rising 18.9% in April from the previous year, according to the Nasdaq OMX Valueguard-KTH Housing Index. This marks the fastest pace since data compilation began in 2005. The surge is attributed to ultra-low interest rates and increased demand fueled by the pandemic.

site_title: Rare whisky: liquid gold or evaporating asset?
summary: The value of rare whisky has increased 478% in the last 10 years, making it a top performer in the Knight Frank Luxury Investment Index. Specialist funds and cask investment schemes have emerged, but its long-term viability remains uncertain. Industry players and experts weigh in, with some warning of a bubble waiting to burst, while others see it as a passion investment with potential. As the pandemic recedes, a boom in the whisky market may be on the horizon.

site_title: US applications for home mortgages tick up
summary: US home mortgage applications rose 1.2% last week, driven by refinancing activity, while purchase applications fell 4% to a three-month low due to a housing shortage and rising prices. The shortage is constraining purchase activity, with existing home sales at a seven-month low in March. Mortgage interest rates remain low, but affordability is eroding, making home buying difficult for many households. The housing market, a strong performer during the Covid-19 recession, is slowing due to supply constraints.

site_title: Fashion's green future gets boost from seaweed coats and mushroom shoes
summary: Fashion's environmental record is getting a boost from innovative technologies, such as seaweed-coated garments, mushroom-made shoes, and bacteria-dyed clothes. Designers are creating carbon-free clothing and reducing toxic chemicals and water consumption. Companies like Bolt Threads and Adidas are partnering to produce sustainable materials, and experts say that improving existing systems and increasing transparency through technology can lead to large-scale transformation. While skepticism exists, many experts agree that the sustainability movement's strength comes from multiple actors working together to address the industry's environmental issues.

site_title: Shangri-La Dialogue cancelled amid Covid-19 uncertainties
summary: The Shangri-La Dialogue, a security summit in Singapore, has been cancelled due to the deteriorating global Covid-19 situation. The event, which was set to take place on June 4-5, was expected to be attended by defence ministers and senior officials from around the world. The cancellation comes just days after the World Economic Forum's annual meeting was also scrapped in Singapore. The International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS) cited rising local cases, new restrictions, and uncertainty over further tightening as reasons for the cancellation, with the event expected to return in the middle of next year.

images.alt_text: This year's Shangri-La Dialogue that was due to take place in Singapore on June 4-5 is cancelled "in light of the deteriorating global Covid-19 situation", said organiser International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS) on Thursday.

site_title: Branching off from traditional retail banking
summary: Banks are expected to reassess the role of physical branches as customers increasingly turn to digital services. According to Roland Berger's report, the number of branches in South-east Asia is expected to decline by 18% over the next decade, with 11,000 branches closing. The shift will force banks to adapt their branch network strategies and focus on providing customers with a personal touch and experience. The exact role of branches will vary by market, but banks must prioritize customer-centric approaches and consider innovations such as communal spaces and omnichannel strategies to remain successful.

site_title: Chinese commodities in sea of red as global rout spreads
summary: Global commodity prices plummeted in China, with iron ore, coal, and soybeans falling 7.6%, 7.5%, and 3% respectively. The decline follows a US market meltdown and is attributed to inflation fears and authorities' attempts to curb prices. China's State Council pledged to prevent rising commodity prices from being passed to consumers, while aggregate open interest in industrial commodities has fallen to near its lowest levels since February, indicating liquidated bullish bets. The recent rally in prices appears precarious, with economic data suggesting China's expansion may have peaked.

site_title: DBS can fund S$2.7b bid for Citi India unit: Bernstein
summary: DBS Group Holdings has sufficient capital to fund a potential S$2.7 billion bid for Citigroup's consumer assets in India, analysts from Sanford C Bernstein & Co said. This would be DBS's largest acquisition since 2001. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta has expressed interest in the US bank's assets in India, China, Taiwan, and Indonesia, with the Indian unit being considered the "crown jewel" due to its credit card and wealth business. The acquisition would further expand DBS's presence in India, where it has also acquired Lakshmi Vilas Bank.

site_title: Amid rising ESG pressure, Malaysia prepares oil and gas firms for green economy
summary: Malaysia is preparing its oil and gas firms for a green economy amid rising environmental, social, and governance (ESG) pressure. The country aims to have at least 70 oil and gas services and equipment (OGSE) companies adopt sustainable business operations by the end of the decade. Petronas, the state oil giant, has already announced plans to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The success of the industry will be measured by its competitiveness, resilience, and social licence to operate, with sustainability being a key pillar of the industry's 10-year blueprint.

site_title: Singapore fintechs raised S$656m in Q1, up 355%
summary: Singapore fintech companies raised S$656m in Q1 2021, a 355% increase from the previous year. This represents about 46% of the total funding raised in 2020. The largest contributors were Grab Financial Group's Series A round of over US$300m and Indonesian company Payfazz's US$30m investment in Xfers. Other notable funding rounds included Endowus' S$23m Series A and robo-advisory platform.

site_title: Biodiversity decline needs to become a top priority beyond governments
summary: The world's biodiversity is deteriorating at an alarming rate, with 85% of wetlands, 75% of terrestrial environments, and 66% of marine environments severely altered or threatened with extinction. Governments and businesses have failed to prioritize biodiversity conservation, resulting in a $800 billion annual funding gap. To address this issue, the private sector, financial institutions, and insurance companies must take a more active role in investing in biodiversity protection, reducing subsidies, and assessing the impact of investments on biodiversity. Time is running out to reverse the damage, and collective action is necessary to ensure a healthy ecosystem for future generations.

site_title: 2,000 more students, staff at SP to be tested after 4th student tested positive
summary: A fourth student at Singapore Polytechnic's School of Chemical & Life Sciences tested positive for Covid-19, prompting the testing of 2,000 students and staff. The student, who was last on campus on May 15, developed symptoms four days later. The Ministry of Health has assessed she was not infectious at the time of her last visit. This is the latest outbreak in the polytechnic, following previous cases.

site_title: Indonesian agency to scrutinise Gojek-Tokopedia merger to avoid tech monopoly
summary: Indonesia's anti-trust agency (KPPU) will scrutinize the merger of ride-hailing firm Gojek and e-commerce leader Tokopedia, forming tech company GoTo, to check for potential monopolistic behavior. The combined entity, valued at billions, will span online shopping, courier services, and other services in Southeast Asia. The KPPU's review aims to prevent the tech giant from dominating the market and stifling competition. The merger was announced earlier this week, making it Indonesia's largest-ever deal. The outcome of the review could impact the future of the tech industry in the country.

site_title: Bitcoin struggles for footing on worries over China and leverage
summary: Bitcoin regained some ground after a 14% drop to four-month lows, rising 8.75% to US$40,000 due to concerns over China's tightening regulation and leveraged positions in the cryptocurrency world.

site_title: SIA, Qantas' diverging fortunes show Covid-19 disparities
summary: Qantas Airways is experiencing a strong recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, with revenue from domestic routes expected to nearly double in the next six months. In contrast, Singapore Airlines is struggling, posting a record annual loss of S$4.3 billion due to limited international travel. The airline's fortunes reflect the global aviation industry's diverging paths, with some carriers like Qantas benefiting from buoyant domestic markets, while others like Singapore Airlines face significant challenges.

site_title: Covid-19 ignites unexpected revolution at aviation shopfloors
summary: A pandemic-induced crisis has triggered an unexpected revolution in the aviation industry's maintenance and engineering sectors. The industry has long been slow to adopt technological innovation, but the pandemic's impact has forced a digital transformation. Key changes include eliminating paper-based operations, automating manual and repetitive tasks, and integrating disparate systems to achieve a more efficient and agile delivery model. This transformation is crucial for the industry to reduce costs, improve efficiency, and remain competitive in a post-pandemic market.

site_title: MOH seeks 'light vaccination teams' to provide Covid-19 jabs for homebound persons
summary: The Ministry of Health in Singapore is seeking "light vaccination teams" to provide Covid-19 vaccinations to homebound individuals, including those bedbound and caregivers, starting from June. Five teams, each consisting of a doctor and a nurse, will be deployed to vaccinate individuals in their residences and other locations, such as senior care centers. The teams must be self-sufficient with medical supplies and equipment, and the doctor must have basic cardiac life support certification. The contract is for six months with the option to extend.

site_title: Koufu expects dining-in ban to hit revenue and operating profits for FY2021
summary: Koufu Group expects a significant impact on revenue and operating profits for FY2021 due to the latest one-month ban on dining-in, with a 10% decline in same-store sales for the first four months of 2021 compared to 2019. Despite improved takeaways and delivery orders, the group anticipates further losses when the restrictions are lifted and dining-in allowed again. Koufu has activated business-continuity plans and reports a strong cash flow, but is uncertain about the full extent of the financial impact due to evolving Covid-19 situation and potential further tightening measures.

site_title: South Korea to run mix-and-match trial of Covid-19 vaccines
summary: South Korea plans a clinical trial mixing AstraZeneca and Pfizer Covid-19 vaccine doses to address supply delays and safety concerns. The trial will involve 500 military personnel, examining immune cells and neutralizing antibodies. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the combination vaccine in a diverse age group. The move comes as South Korea's vaccination campaign lags behind, with just over 7% of the population vaccinated, and the country's herd immunity goal of November in jeopardy.

site_title: Malaysia's business groups fear full lockdown will be devastating
summary: Malaysia's business groups warn that a full lockdown could be devastating, citing the ongoing presence of Covid-19 and its variants in the community. They prioritize implementing strict standard operating procedures (SOPs) and ramping up the vaccination programme to curb the spread of the virus. The groups emphasize that a full lockdown may not be effective in curbing the virus, as it will remain present in the community for a long time.

images.alt_text: People waiting to be vaccinated at a vaccination centre in Kuala Lumpur. There was a new record of 6,806 infections across the country on Thursday, taking the total cases to date to 492,302.

site_title: Safe haven for the pandemic
summary: Architect Kee Jing Zhi designed a bungalow in Singapore with private spaces and common areas for a family to cope with the pandemic. The home features an entertainment room, home gym, and outdoor terrace, which have become treasured spaces during the lockdown. The design prioritized functionality and comfort, providing a safe haven for the family to "hunker down" at home. The architect's focus on private spaces and outdoor areas has become a key feature in pandemic-era home design, prioritizing well-being and mental health.

site_title: Asian 'omakase' with a twist
summary: Asian omakase sets offer a convenient and varied dining experience. MOBOMOGA's appetizer platter features a compilation of small bites, including raw and cooked seafood, for a fixed price of S$50 to S$128. Teochew Paradise's Luxury Trio includes a soup, main dish, and dessert, all heat-retained in thermal bags for S$158. Hashida Singapore's takeaway omakase features a seven-course set with dishes like abalone pie and monkfish liver for S$200. These options cater to those seeking a hassle-free and delicious dining experience during the lockdown.

images.alt_text: Above: Meta's Korean heritage menu -- a set meal that serves one, but the portions can easily feed two.
Hashida offers a takeaway omakase that features some of the highlights of his previous pop up which never made it to his current set up in Amoy Street.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher after three down sessions
summary: US stocks rose early Thursday, shaking off three down sessions, as new unemployment filings declined for the third straight week, indicating progress in the labor market. The Federal Reserve minutes suggested the US economy may soon be healthy enough to taper asset purchases, a sign of a shift in the central bank's easy money policies. The Dow Jones rose 0.2%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.0%.

site_title: Kia Carnival review: Make room for the Guv'nor
summary: The Kia Carnival is a large, multi-purpose vehicle (MPV) that defies conventional expectations. With up to eight seats, it offers an impressive amount of space, comfort, and features. The interior boasts modern conveniences, including a 12.3-inch touchscreen and ample storage. The seven-seat version is more focused on comfort, while the eight-seater is more about cosiness. The Carnival's diesel engine provides a smooth ride, although it can be loud. With a hefty price tag, the Carnival offers an enormous amount of car for the money, making it a compelling option for those seeking a spacious and practical vehicle.

images.alt_text: The Fed's meeting on Wednesday is unlikely to result in a rate hike, but it still looks daunting for bulls. Stocks could sell off if the Fed raises more concerns about the effects of tariffs on growth or inflation.

site_title: BBC fell short over Princess Diana interview
summary: A report by a former senior judge found the BBC fell short of its integrity standards when persuading Princess Diana to give a 1995 interview, with journalist Martin Bashir using fake bank statements to gain her brother's trust. The BBC apologized for its actions, with Director-General Tim Davie saying the broadcaster "cannot turn back the clock" but can make a full apology. The report concluded Bashir's behavior was "deceitful" and the BBC's actions were a "fall short" of its high standards.

site_title: Bitcoin's star backers, dip buyers help cryptos recover
summary: Bitcoin rebounded 14% to near $42,000 after a 14% drop the previous day due to concerns over China's tighter regulation of cryptocurrencies and leveraged positions. Smaller rival ether rose 20% to $2,935 after a 28% decline. Prominent backers such as Cathie Wood and Elon Musk indicated their support, fueling a "buy the dip" sentiment. However, analysts warn that volatility is expected to continue, and it's unclear if the rebound has legs, with $9.13 billion in cryptocurrency positions being liquidated in 24 hours.

site_title: DBS, SGX, StanChart and Temasek to launch global carbon exchange
summary: Singapore is set to launch a global carbon exchange and marketplace called Climate Impact X (CIX) by the end of the year, aimed at incentivizing emissions cuts. Four key entities, including DBS, SGX, StanChart, and Temasek, have joined forces to provide better price transparency and verification of high-quality carbon credits. CIX will start with carbon credits from Natural Climate Solutions, involving protection and restoration of natural systems, and plans to scale up with more partners to fund the project. The initiative aims to create a leading carbon services and trading hub, aligning with Singapore's goal to become a net-zero future.

site_title: European airports vow to be CO2 neutral by 2030
summary: More than 90 European airports have pledged to be carbon neutral by 2030, two decades ahead of the planned 2050 target. This commitment, made by 235 airports representing two-thirds of Europe's passenger traffic, coincides with the EU's goal of being "climate neutral" by 2050. Ten airports have already achieved carbon neutrality, and others, such as Athens International Airport, aim to reach the target in 2025. The move comes as the aviation industry faces financial distress due to the Covid-19 pandemic, prompting calls for EU and European countries to provide aid and support.

site_title: New US filings for unemployment aid down for third straight week
summary: US unemployment filings declined for the third straight week, reaching a new pandemic low. The Labor Department reported 444,000 new filings, seasonally adjusted, in the week ended May 15, 34,000 less than the previous week. Filings under the Pandemic Unemployment Assistance program also decreased, with nearly 9,000 fewer claims. The number of people receiving unemployment aid has been trending down, with nearly 16 million receiving aid as of May 1, a decrease from the previous week.

site_title: Aspen Glove chief operating officer tenders resignation during probationary period
summary: Aspen Glove's chief operating officer Calvin Ng, 48, has resigned during his probationary period to pursue other interests. Ng, appointed in September 2020, will hand over responsibilities to managing director Iskandar Basha until June 17. The company has shortlisted candidates to replace Ng, with the appointment expected to be announced after due diligence. Shares in Aspen closed 2.3% lower on the news.

site_title: Singapore market unmoved by Wall Street's overnight dip
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index closed at 3,109.81 points, up 0.18% or 5.60 points, despite Wall Street's overnight dip. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 ending 0.19% higher. US Federal Reserve officials are considering tapering government bond purchases, which may cause market jitters. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Singapore Airlines were top performers, while Wilmar International fell 1.2%.

site_title: Indonesia trade surplus widens to US$2.2b as exports surge 51.9% in April
summary: Indonesia's trade surplus widened to $2.2 billion in April, driven by a 51.9% year-on-year surge in exports, surpassing economists' expectations. Imports also rose 29.9% year-over-year. The country's exports were boosted by China, a key trading partner, while the decline in palm oil exports was attributed to lockdowns in India. Despite a broad-based decline in imports, economists believe Indonesia's exports will continue to grow due to strong global growth and rising commodity prices, supporting the country's economic recovery.

site_title: Myanmar air force chief in Moscow for military helicopter exhibition
summary: Myanmar's air force chief, Maung Maung Kyaw, is visiting Moscow to attend the HeliRussia exhibition, showcasing Russian military helicopters. The trip comes amid US sanctions for his role in the February coup that ousted Aung San Suu Kyi's government. Russia aims to strengthen military ties with Myanmar despite the coup. The delegation, including businessman Tay Za, will discuss over 20 megaprojects, including arms procurement, with Russian officials. Defence ties between Russia and Myanmar have grown in recent years, with Moscow providing training and university scholarships to thousands of soldiers.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.20 points lower on Thursday, at 1,575.32, due to a 832-288 loss-to-gain ratio. Volume reached 6.739 billion lots worth RM4.574 billion.

site_title: IMF headquarters to start phased return to in-person work on June 1
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) will start a phased return to in-person work at its headquarters on June 1, after more than a year of remote work due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The easing of work-at-home status reflects improving health and safety conditions in the US capital. While the IMF will resume limited operations, many virtual aspects of its operation will continue. In-person meetings, including the fall meetings scheduled for mid-October, are still being planned but no decisions have been made on logistics.

site_title: Keppel Land prices S$280m of 2% notes due 2026
summary: Keppel Land, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, priced S$280 million of 2% notes due 2026 at a 100% price of principal amount. The notes will be issued in denominations of S$250,000, with interest payable semi-annually. The net proceeds will be used for debt refinancing, potential acquisitions, or general corporate purposes. UOB has been appointed as the sole lead manager, and the notes are expected to mature on May 28, 2026.

site_title: Malaysia sees another record in Covid-19 infections, deaths
summary: Malaysia reports a new daily record in coronavirus infections and deaths, with 6,806 new cases and 59 fatalities, pushing the total cases to 492,302. The country is under a nationwide lockdown and a state of emergency, with the health ministry citing an increasing number of serious Covid-19 infections due to highly infectious variants. The occupancy rate of beds at intensive care units is over 70%, prompting a call for private hospitals to increase bed capacity.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Shangri-La Dialogue, a prominent international security conference, has been cancelled due to the deteriorating global Covid-19 situation. The event, scheduled for June 4-5 in Singapore, was cancelled by the International Institute for Strategic Studies (IISS).

site_title: UBS, Nomura fined US$452m for financial crisis bond cartel
summary: The European Union has fined UBS Group, Nomura Holdings, and UniCredit a total of US$452 million for colluding on euro government bond trading during the 2007-2011 sovereign debt crisis. The traders shared commercially sensitive information in chatrooms, impacting EU member states. UniCredit and UBS were fined 172 million and 129.6 million euros respectively, while Nomura was fined 69 million euros. The EU's antitrust chief criticized the actions as "unacceptable" and allowed customers to sue for damages if they can prove higher costs were passed on.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end the day lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index easing 0.50% to 28,450.29, following a sell-off across world markets. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index dipped 0.11% and the Shenzhen Composite Index edged up 0.12%. The decline came as investors returned from a midweek break.

site_title: Hong Kong raises IPO profit minimum in watered-down move
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange has raised the annual profit minimum for companies seeking to list on its main board to HK$80 million (S$13.7 million), a 60% increase from the current HK$50 million threshold. The move was watered down after opposition from banks, which had opposed doubling or tripling the level. The exchange and regulator vowed to crack down on suspicious IPO activities, including inflating market capitalization and unusually high underwriting commissions. The higher earnings minimum is expected to stop 62% of rejected IPO applications, but critics argue it will harm smaller firms and local businesses.

site_title: Suntec City rolls out enhanced safety measures and tenant support for Phase 2
summary: Suntec City in Singapore has implemented enhanced safety measures and tenant support for Phase 2 (Heightened Alert). The mall will enforce temperature screening and the TraceTogether-only SafeEntry system for visitors, and provide in-mall and digital marketing support for affected tenants. The property will also waive payment gateway fees and commission for food and beverage tenants, and allow flexibility for tenants to shorten store operating hours. These measures aim to help essential personnel and mitigate the impact of stricter government restrictions.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed after Federal Reserve taper talk, Bitcoin stabilises
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday after minutes from the Federal Reserve's April meeting showed some officials considering a wind-down of its monetary easing measures. The news sparked concerns about a potential tapering of the Fed's asset purchases, which could impact the global economy. Bitcoin stabilized after a wild day, closing at around $37,800. Despite the mixed markets, the outlook for the global economy remains upbeat, with many analysts expecting continued growth as the world recovers from the pandemic.

site_title: The Hour Glass full-year net profit rises 8% to S$82.5m
summary: The Hour Glass, a luxury watch retailer, reported an 8% increase in full-year net profit to S$82.5 million, driven by higher earnings per share. Revenue fell 1% to S$742.9 million, but the company attributed this to reduced advertising and promotion activities. Gross margin improved to 29.2% due to its "long-term strategy" to attract domestic spending. The company proposes a final dividend of 4 cents per share and expects to be profitable in FY2022, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: Australia: Shares see best day in nearly two weeks on jobless data, banks boost
summary: Australian stocks closed 1.3% higher, their best session in nearly two weeks, driven by tech and banking stocks and upbeat employment data. The country's jobless rate in April fell to the lowest in a year, with the "big four" banks gaining between 1.4% and 3.2%. Tech stocks led the gains, with Afterpay surging 7.7% and Qantas Airways jumping 4%.

site_title: SIA cuts cash burn to S$100-150m a month; sees robust bookings for travel bubble
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has reduced its monthly cash burn rate to S$100-150 million, a significant decrease from S$350 million a year ago. The airline group reported a record net loss of S$4.27 billion for FY2021, the "toughest year in its history." SIA attributes the improvement to robust bookings for the travel bubble, which is expected to drive the airline's recovery. However, fuel hedges may impact the airline's cash burn, and the company will continue to monitor the situation.

site_title: Shangri-La Dialogue cancelled
summary: The Shangri-La Dialogue, a security summit in Singapore, has been cancelled due to the deteriorating global Covid-19 situation. The event, set to take place on June 4-5, was expected to attract defence ministers, officials, and strategists from around the world. This cancellation comes just days after the World Economic Forum's special meeting was scrapped in Singapore. The IISS cited the Covid-19 situation as the reason for the cancellation, marking a significant change in plans for the event.

site_title: Over half of workers in Singapore feel pandemic has accelerated pace of workplace digitalisation: survey
summary: A survey of 1,000 employees and 251 companies in Singapore's technology, banking, finance, and enterprise sectors found that over half of employers (56%) believe the pandemic has accelerated workplace digitalization. 37% of companies in the banking industry and 35% in finance have increased technology spending. Employees are more likely to see technology as an opportunity (59%) rather than a burden (24%), but 58% are worried about automation and AI threatening their job security.

site_title: Malaysia's AirAsia X posts record quarterly loss, eighth in a row
summary: Malaysia's AirAsia X, a long-haul budget airline, reported a record quarterly loss of RM5.67 billion (S$1.82 billion) for January-March, its eighth consecutive quarterly loss due to the coronavirus pandemic's impact on air travel demand. Revenue fell 11.2% to RM38.5 million. The airline impaired assets worth RM5.28 billion, primarily due to the pandemic, and is restructuring to reconstitute RM64.15 billion in debt. AirAsia remains committed to resuming commercial operations upon successful restructuring completion and international border reopening.

site_title: Gold ticks higher on inflation anxiety, but firm US dollar caps gains
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,875.74 per ounce, driven by US inflationary pressure, but gains were limited by a strong US dollar and rising Treasury yields. Federal Reserve policymakers hinted at a possible shift in future policy, fueling inflation concerns. Despite this, gold's appeal is diminished by higher opportunity costs due to rising interest rates. Spot gold may retest a resistance at $1,893 per ounce.

site_title: Visitors to Alexandra Hospital ward barred after employee tests positive for Covid-19
summary: A 24-year-old Singaporean employee at Alexandra Hospital tested positive for Covid-19, prompting the hospital to bar visitors to the affected ward until further notice. The employee, who provided basic nursing care, had been asymptomatic but developed a cough after returning to work after a 10-day leave. The hospital has disinfected areas and is caring for the employee in an isolation room. Contact tracing and swabbing of close contacts are ongoing, and the hospital apologizes for any inconvenience caused.

site_title: DBS, SGX, StanChart and Temasek set to launch global carbon exchange
summary: Singapore is set to launch Climate Impact X (CIX), a global exchange and marketplace for high-quality carbon credits, in partnership with DBS Bank, the Singapore Exchange, Standard Chartered, and Temasek Holdings by the end of 2021. The platform aims to provide price transparency and verifiability to incentivize emissions cuts, addressing fragmented carbon-credit markets. CIX will use satellite monitoring, machine-learning, and blockchain technology to enhance transparency and quality, and is expected to grow the demand for voluntary carbon credits 15-fold to two billion tonnes by 2030.

site_title: Singapore retail landlords dish out marketing support for F&B tenants
summary: Singapore retail landlords are offering marketing and operational support to food and beverage (F&B) tenants amid the latest COVID-19 restrictions. GuocoLand, City Developments Ltd, CapitaLand, and Frasers Property Retail are providing initiatives such as bulk order purchases, discounts, free deliveries, and marketing support to help F&B tenants cope with the period. The initiatives aim to expand sales channels, promote F&B sales, and provide flexibility in rental payments for tenants facing cash flow issues.

site_title: Hot stock: iFast rises 6.2% to continue run as 'Singapore's best-performing stock'
summary: Shares of iFast Corp rose 6.2% on Thursday, continuing its run as Singapore's best-performing stock over the past year, with a 552% surge in the last 12 months. The company aims to grow its assets under administration to S$100 billion by 2028, primarily driven by its expansion into China and a retail-trading frenzy. CEO Lim Chung Chun believes the Chinese market holds immense potential, despite generating "manageable amounts" of losses.

site_title: Virgin and O2 clinch UK approval for US$44.4b deal
summary: Telefonica and Liberty Global's UK operations, O2 and Virgin Media, have received approval for a $44.4 billion merger, clearing the way for a powerful telecoms company in the UK. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) concluded that the deal would not lead to higher prices or poorer services, citing strong competition amongst mobile communications providers. The merged entity will cover about half of the UK with fibre and 5G connections, posing a challenge to BT Group. The deal is expected to be completed on June 1, with new CEOs and branding decisions pending.

site_title: 41 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 27 in community
summary: Singapore reported 41 new COVID-19 cases, including 27 in the community, as of May 20, bringing the total to 61,730. Of the community cases, six are unlinked, while 21 are linked to previous cases. There were also 14 imported cases, including 10 returning Singaporeans or permanent residents. The new cases follow a second-highest daily figure for community cases this year, with 38 cases reported on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: There were 41 new Covid-19 cases, including 27 in the community, as at noon on Thursday (May 20), said the Ministry of Health (MOH).

site_title: Singapore domestic wholesale trade falls 4.7% in Q1, dragged by lower petroleum sales
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade contracted 4.7% in Q1 due to lower petroleum sales, according to data from the Department of Statistics Singapore. Excluding petroleum, wholesale sales increased 6.1%. The chemical and metals industries saw significant growth, with 18.3% and 10.7% year-on-year increases, respectively. In contrast, the industrial and construction machinery industry declined 18%, and the petroleum industry fell 15%. Despite this, all wholesale trade industries recorded higher domestic sales on a quarter-on-quarter basis, except for the mentioned industries.

site_title: DBS can fund S$2.7b bid for Citi India unit, says Bernstein
summary: DBS Group Holdings has sufficient capital to bid for Citigroup's consumer assets in India valued at S$2.7 billion, according to Sanford C Bernstein & Co analysts. This would be DBS's largest acquisition since 2001. DBS CEO Piyush Gupta has expressed interest in expanding in India and China, and a takeover of Citi's India unit would be attractive due to the country's economic growth rate and population size.

site_title: Europe: Markets attempt recovery at open
summary: European stock markets staged a partial recovery on Thursday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.5% to 6,984.18 points, and the eurozone's DAX 30 index increasing 0.7% to 15,221.42 points. The recovery followed a slump on Wednesday due to concerns about central banks winding down easy money policies to combat high inflation. Asian markets diverged, with some Federal Reserve officials considering a wind-down of monetary easing measures.

site_title: Governance failings impede Asian companies ESG efforts: report
summary: Asian regulators should provide guidance on reforming company boards to address environmental, social, and governance (ESG) challenges, according to a regional corporate governance group. The recommendations include adjusting corporate governance codes to include ESG reporting and training for boards. While ESG standards have improved in Asia since 2018, corporate governance mechanisms remain fragmented, and connections between CG and ESG policies are unclear. The Asian Corporate Governance Association ranked markets by corporate governance standards, placing Australia first, followed by Hong Kong and Singapore. Japan rose two places to fifth due to improvements in climate change reporting.

site_title: Australia's April unemployment falls to year low, Australian dollar rises
summary: Australia's unemployment rate fell to 5.5% in April, the lowest in a year, with 30,600 fewer jobs created than expected. This marks a sixth consecutive month of decline, with the labor market still showing spare capacity. The Australian dollar rose in response to the better-than-forecast job numbers. The Reserve Bank of Australia believes full employment could be around 4% or lower.

site_title: ByteDance co-founder Zhang Yiming to step down as CEO
summary: ByteDance co-founder Zhang Yiming is stepping down as CEO, to be succeeded by co-founder Rubo Liang. Zhang cited a desire to focus on longer-term initiatives and acknowledged his limitations as a manager, preferring analytical work over people management. The transition will occur over the next six months, with Zhang working closely with Liang to ensure a smooth handover. This marks the biggest corporate shake-up at ByteDance since its launch in 2012.

site_title: US House votes to set up commission on Capitol riot
summary: The US House of Representatives voted 252-175 to establish a 10-member bipartisan commission to investigate the January 6 Capitol riot, overcoming Republican opposition. Despite Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell's opposition, the House bill allows for a 50-50 commission split and equal subpoena power. The commission is seen as a step towards depoliticizing the investigation and uncovering the truth, with some Republicans warning it may be used to attack former President Trump. The move comes after President Trump urged Republicans to oppose the commission.

site_title: Deutsche Bank sets up ESG nexus in Singapore
summary: Deutsche Bank has established an ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) centre in Singapore, focusing on innovating at the nexus of ESG and fintech to develop new products addressing gaps in the ESG market. The centre will house a "sizable team" across all divisions, working on impact monitoring, data management, and payments to unbanked communities. The goal is to set standards for "evidence-based, data-driven transactions" supporting sustainable growth in Asia, where sustainable development calls are growing louder.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower on Fed taper talk, crypto anxiety
summary: South Korean shares closed lower on Thursday, following overnight Wall Street losses, as the US Federal Reserve released minutes of its April meeting discussing potential bond purchases. The benchmark Kospi fell 0.34% to 3,162.28, amid concerns over Fed tapering and a cryptocurrency crash. Foreigners sold $575.11 million worth of shares, while tech giant Samsung Electronics and internet giant Naver rose. The market rebounded on Tuesday, with LG Chem and SK Hynix also gaining.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 0.48% and the Topix index 0.25% lower. Investors were disheartened by falls on Wall Street, including a plunge in bitcoin, and concerns over Federal Reserve policy changes.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.2% at 28,098.25, and the Topix index gaining 0.04% at 1,895.92. Investors are optimistic about expected approval of Covid-19 vaccines in Japan, driving the market higher.

site_title: Japan's March core machinery orders rise 3.7% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders rose 3.7% in March from the previous month, exceeding economists' expectations of a 6.4% rise. This is a reversal from the 2.0% drop seen in March of the previous year, which was forecast to be 2.6%. The data indicates a potential increase in capital spending in the coming months.

site_title: Hot stock: No Signboard up 12.7% after new controlling shareholder announcement
summary: No Signboard Holdings' shares rose 12.7% on Thursday after the company announced a new controlling shareholder, Gugong, which owns a 74.91% stake, entered into a sale and purchase agreement with Su Hai Jin for a 20% stake. The counter hit an intraday high of 7.4 Singapore cents, with 21.6 million shares changing hands. The move is seen as a positive development for the restaurant operator, with its shares trading at 7.1 cents.

site_title: Surge in buying of face masks in Singapore continues; some manufacturers plan to lower prices
summary: A surge in demand for face masks in Singapore continues, with sales on e-commerce platforms like Qoo10 and Lazada exceeding pre-pandemic levels. Retailers report strong demand for surgical masks, with some seeing a 50% decrease in sales after the initial "fever" following the government's announcement. Manufacturers, such as Razer and ST Engineering, plan to lower costs and increase production to meet demand. The Health Sciences Authority has updated guidelines on choosing masks, encouraging the public to use masks with better filtration capabilities.

site_title: Japan's April exports jump 38% y-o-y: MOF
summary: Japan's exports jumped 38% in April from the previous year, exceeding economists' expectations of a 30.9% increase. This follows a 16.1% increase in March. Imports rose 12.8% year-over-year, with a trade balance surplus of 255.3 billion yen. The strong export performance suggests a solid recovery in overseas demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 1.66 points, or 0.11%, to 1,578.86. Losers beat gainers 224 to 166, with volume reaching 296.53 million lots worth RM169.67 million.

site_title: MIT proposes US$1.32b acquisition of 29 data centres in the US
summary: MAPLETREE Industrial Trust (MIT) proposes a US$1.32 billion acquisition of 29 data centers in the US, increasing its assets under management to S$8.6 billion and data centers to S$4.6 billion. The acquisition is expected to boost distribution per unit and net asset value per unit, and will make MIT one of the largest data center owners among Asia-Pacific Reits. The deal is expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2021 and will diversify MIT's data center footprint, with new exposure to established markets in Chicago, Los Angeles, and Houston.

site_title: Highest bid for Blue Origin's maiden space voyage at US$2.6m and climbing
summary: Blue Origin is offering a seat on its maiden crewed spaceflight for a record-breaking $2.6 million, with bidding set to close on June 10. The 10-minute journey will reach an altitude of 60 miles, offering weightlessness and a view of the Earth's curvature. The company, founded by Jeff Bezos, has received over 5,200 bids from 136 countries, with a live final round scheduled for June 12. The proceeds will go to Blue Origin's charitable foundation, targeting a July 20 launch from its Texas facility.

site_title: Oprah-backed Oatly raises US$1.4b in IPO: source
summary: Oatly, a Swedish vegan milk maker backed by Oprah Winfrey and others, raised US$1.4 billion in its US initial public offering, pricing 84.4 million shares at US$17 each, valuing the company at US$10 billion.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% at the opening bell on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,117.08. The gains came despite overnight falls on Wall Street and tariff uncertainty. Index stock Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the most actively traded counter, gaining 2.8%. The rally marks a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data release, with investors staying positive despite mixed Fed views and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Hongkong Land CFO to step down by end-August 2021
summary: Hongkong Land's CFO, Simon Dixon, is stepping down by end-August 2021 to return to Australia. He will be succeeded by Craig Beattie, CFO of Mandarin Oriental International, effective September 1. Beattie, who has held various senior finance roles, will replace Matthew Bishop. The group's CEO, Robert Wong, praised Dixon's contributions to operational improvements and sustainability efforts, despite a 0.6% decline in shares on Wednesday.

site_title: Australia: Shares recover on financial, tech boost
summary: Australian shares recovered 0.3% on Thursday, led by IT stocks and financials, while miners and energy sectors fell due to a drop in commodity prices. IT stocks including Afterpay, Appen, and EML Payments rose 2.7%, 2.5%, and 15.4% respectively. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 6,952.1 points, its highest close since April 7. The benchmark shed 1.9% in the previous session, its lowest close in April 7.

site_title: Bitcoin plunges: A bust or a buy?
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 30-45% on Wednesday, wiping nearly $1 trillion off the crypto sector's market capitalization, following China's ban on financial and payment institutions providing cryptocurrency services. Despite this, Tesla's Elon Musk and Ark Invest's Cathie Wood expressed support for bitcoin, helping to limit losses. Analysts attribute the decline to leverage in crypto stocks and inflation fears, with some predicting further losses. Bitcoin has dropped 40% from its record high, with ether and dogecoin also experiencing significant declines.

site_title: SIIC bags wastewater treatment contract in Baoqing, China
summary: SIIC Environment's indirect 58%-owned subsidiary has signed a supplementary agreement for the upgrading and expansion of a wastewater treatment project in Baoqing, China. The project has a designed capacity of 20,000 tonnes per day with a discharge standard upgrading from Class I Standard B to Class I Standard A. This is part of seven wastewater treatment projects, including two expansion projects and five upgrading projects, which have started commercial operations since late 2020. The group expects these projects to contribute positively to its performance going forward.

site_title: Japan manufacturers' mood rises to highest since late 2018: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturers have reported a two-year high in business confidence, with the Reuters Tankan poll showing a 21-point improvement in May, the highest since December 2018. Strong overseas demand and progress in coronavirus vaccinations have boosted confidence, but firms are still feeling the pandemic's impact, particularly in the greater Tokyo area. The service sector index also expanded for the first time since February last year, rising to 2 from minus 3 in April.

site_title: Sakae responds to Sias, says Deloitte's opinion 'represents positive progress'
summary: Sakae Holdings responded to Sias' comments on its internal audit function, stating that Deloitte's qualified opinion represents positive progress from the 2019 disclaimer of opinion. The company clarified that its internal audit function is approved by the audit committee and that recommendations from auditors have been implemented progressively since 2019. Sakae also acknowledged concerns raised by Sias regarding its 2020 annual report, but stated it had responded where necessary. The company's share price remained unchanged following the statement.

site_title: US flying taxi startup steps up legal pressure on rival over trade secrets
summary: US flying taxi startup Wisk Aero filed a motion with a California court to stop rival Archer Aviation from using its trade secrets and infringing on its patents. Wisk accuses Archer of stealing trade secrets and alleges the rival's eVTOL aircraft development timeline is too short to be true. The case is part of Wisk's ongoing litigation against Archer, which also involves a criminal US probe into Archer's alleged theft of Wisk's intellectual property. The court hearing is set for July 7.

site_title: Japan's Daiwa plots China expansion to tap wealth management
summary: Japan's Daiwa Securities Group plans to expand its presence in China's rapidly growing asset-management market. The firm's Beijing-based joint venture, Daiwa Securities (China), is set to launch later this month with investment banking, stock broking, and fixed-income trading services. Daiwa's CEO Seiji Nakata aims to establish a foothold in Shanghai and apply for asset management licenses, capitalizing on China's huge market potential. This expansion marks Daiwa's entry into the Chinese financial sector, following other Japanese firms like MUFG, which has also set its sights on the US securitization business.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mark worst day in one week as inflation concerns mount
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.5% on Wednesday, their worst daily fall in a week, amid concerns over rising inflation and potential early monetary policy tightening. Inflation in the UK more than doubled in April, with electricity and gas bills and clothing prices increasing. Investors worry that this may lead to central bank policy tightening globally. European equities volatility gauge reached a near-weekly high, while chip stocks fell over concerns of a global semiconductor shortage.

site_title: CDL reports operational improvements but is wary of Covid-19 impact
summary: CDL reported a 72% increase in sales value to S$513.6 million in the first quarter of 2021, with 319 units sold across various property categories. The company attributes this growth to operational improvements, but remains concerned about the prolonged Covid-19 pandemic's impact on its operations.

site_title: Facebook touts progress in curbing hate, violent content
summary: Facebook reported progress in curbing hate speech and violent content, citing a 50% drop in hate speech prevalence from mid-2020 to 0.05-0.06% in the first quarter of 2021. The company removed 25.2 million pieces of hate speech content, 8.8 million pieces of bullying and harassment content, and 9.8 million pieces of organized hate content. Refinements in artificial intelligence have helped filter out more hateful and violent content, including violent and graphic content, nudity, and sexual material, which were cut to less than 0.04% on Facebook and under 0.02% on Instagram.

site_title: UK sees renewed demand for city-centre apartments: Rightmove
summary: Demand for city-centre apartments in the UK has seen a 39% rise in interest since January, according to Rightmove. This is a 35% increase compared to demand for city-centre housing in general and a 32% rise for rural locations. The boost is attributed to the extension of property purchase tax cuts and a new mortgage guarantee scheme for first-time buyers announced by Finance Minister Rishi Sunak in March. This uptick in demand is seen as a positive sign for the UK property market, with Rightmove's director stating that city centres are staging a comeback.

site_title: Thailand to borrow 700b baht for Covid relief: sources
summary: Thailand plans to borrow an additional 700 billion baht (S$29.6 billion) to counter the worst wave of Covid-19 in South-east Asia's second-largest economy. The government proposes to spend 400 billion baht on social aid, 270 billion baht on reviving the economy, and 30 billion baht on medical supplies and vaccines. The borrowing can be completed before September 2022 and is on top of an ongoing 1-trillion baht debt plan. Thailand's public debt-to-GDP ratio may rise to 58.6% by September, but remains below the nation's 60% debt ceiling.

site_title: Boeing resumes 737 MAX deliveries after electrical problem
summary: Boeing has resumed deliveries of the 737 MAX after the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) approved a fix for an electrical problem that had grounded over 100 planes. The issue, affecting three parts of the plane, was identified in models built after 2019 design changes. Deliveries to American Airlines and United Airlines have resumed, while Southwest Airlines is still implementing changes. This comes after a 20-month grounding caused by two fatal crashes in 2018 and 2019. The move revives a key revenue stream for Boeing and follows recent deliveries of the 787 "Dreamliner" plane.

site_title: US: Stocks end modestly lower as oil-linked shares tumble
summary: US stocks ended modestly lower on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.5% at 33,896.04, while the S&P 500 fell 0.3% to 4,115.68. Oil-linked shares tumbled as oil prices slid amid worries over weakening demand in India and other markets. The Federal Reserve minutes showed officials considering tapering asset purchases, a shift in the central bank's monetary policy. The Nasdaq Index slipped less than 0.1% to 13,299.74, following a three-session decline.

site_title: Singapore wants to move beyond 'new Covid-19 strain' controversy, says envoy in Delhi
summary: Singapore aims to move beyond a controversy sparked by an Indian politician's false comments about a "new strain" of Covid-19 in Singapore. High Commissioner to India Simon Wong said the government is ready to put the episode behind it, citing clarifications from External Affairs Minister S. Jaishankar. Wong expressed gratitude for Jaishankar's tweet, which denounced the comments as "irresponsible" and stated that the Delhi chief minister doesn't speak for India. The Singapore government has vowed to continue its aid efforts to India, including sending over 8,000 oxygen concentrators, despite the controversy.

site_title: US waives sanctions on Nord Stream 2, builder of Russia-Germany pipeline
summary: US President Joe Biden's administration waived sanctions on Nord Stream 2, a Russia-Germany gas pipeline, citing national interests. The move defused rising tensions between Washington and Berlin, with Germany welcoming the conciliatory step. However, Republican Senator Jim Risch criticized the waiver, calling it a "gift to Putin" that weakens the US's leverage in upcoming summit talks. The US did approve sanctions on vessels and smaller companies involved in the pipeline. The waiver was seen as a positive move by the Kremlin and Germany's foreign minister, Heiko Maas.

site_title: New Zealand's budget boosts benefits, focuses on pandemic recovery
summary: New Zealand's 2021 budget focuses on pandemic recovery, boosting benefits by up to NZ$55 per adult, the largest hike in a generation. The government allocated billions towards housing, healthcare, and infrastructure, addressing child poverty and climate change. The budget predicts a 5.3% deficit in 2022, narrowing to 0.6% by 2025, and net debt reaching 48% of GDP in 2023. The economy is forecast to grow 2.9% in 2021, reaching 4.4% by 2023, as the country recovers from the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK reforms rail travel as virus slashes demand
summary: The UK has unveiled long-awaited reforms of its railways, including a new centralised price and reservations system. Great British Railways, a public body, will integrate the railways, owning infrastructure, collecting fare revenue, and setting most fares and timetables. The reforms aim to increase efficiency and control, with Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government taking a greater role in the sector. The reforms come as the COVID-19 pandemic has significantly reduced rail travel demand, prompting the need for reform. The new system is expected to be implemented in the coming years.

images.alt_text: Britain on Thursday unveiled long-awaited reforms of the country's railways, including a new centralised price and reservations system, but insisted it was not backtracking on privatisation started in the 1990s.

site_title: Virus surge in Asia has traders seek more data for investments
summary: Asian countries are closely monitoring the surge in COVID-19 cases, with traders seeking more data to inform investment decisions. The pandemic's resurgence has worsened Asian stocks' underperformance this year, with several countries imposing restrictions and vaccination rollouts being a key factor. Key markets, such as India and Vietnam, have defied similar worries, while others like Singapore and Taiwan have seen significant declines. Analysts warn that delayed recovery could be a concern, with Indonesia's stock benchmark narrowly missing a technical correction amid fears of a jump in cases post Eid holidays.

site_title: BT Explains: What is 'net zero'?
summary: "NET zero" refers to the net amount of carbon emissions produced by an entity, achieved when emissions are offset by equal amounts absorbed from the atmosphere. It's impossible to stop all emissions, so aiming for removal is more realistic. Countries and companies can achieve net-zero by planting more trees, offsetting emissions through nature-based projects, or capturing and storing carbon from industrial processes. However, the lack of uniformity and transparency in net-zero targets and achievements is a concern, and more detailed targets and disclosure are needed to make pledges meaningful.

site_title: Oil prices dive US$2 on fears of Asian pandemic, possible US rate hikes
summary: Oil prices dropped US$2 a barrel on Wednesday, reaching their lowest in three weeks, due to concerns over surging Covid-19 cases in Asia and potential US interest rate hikes. Traders also cited progress in Iran nuclear talks, which could boost global crude supplies and depress prices. Brent futures fell 3.0% to US$66.66 a barrel, while US WTI crude fell 3.3% to US$63.36 a barrel.

site_title: Qantas expects A$2b-plus annual loss but positive H2 cash flow
summary: Qantas Airways announced a loss before tax of over A$2 billion for the year ending June 30, but expects a positive cash flow in the second half of the business year. The airline is implementing cost-cutting measures, including a two-year wage freeze and offering voluntary redundancy to cabin crew. Debt is expected to fall below A$6.05 billion as domestic travel rebounds. Qantas forecasts annual underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) at A$400-450 million. The airline's stock price rose nearly 5% following the announcement.

site_title: Eurozone inflation surge is temporary: ECB's Schnabel
summary: European Central Bank board member Isabel Schnabel stated that the surge in euro zone inflation is temporary and consumer prices are expected to fall sharply next year. Schnabel also indicated that there's no reason for an interest rate hike at the moment, keeping financing conditions favorable to support the economy. The ECB's inflation target is nearly 2% and underlying price growth remains below 1%, a low level that is uncomfortably close to the target.

images.alt_text: The surge in euro zone inflation is temporary and consumer prices should fall sharply next year, European Central Bank board member Isabel Schnabel told German broadcaster ARD on Wednesday.

site_title: US vaccine drive gives airlines a boost
summary: US air travel has surpassed Asia for the first time since February, driven by a powerful vaccine drive in the US. North America's air travel has gained momentum, with airlines adding capacity to international destinations, particularly in the Caribbean and Latin America. Global air travel capacity has risen to 58% of pre-crisis levels, with Europe closing the gap with 2019 levels by 4.4 percentage points. The US is "two to three months ahead of Europe" in vaccine roll-outs, with vaccination rates accelerating in Western countries. Airlines are pushing for a meaningful restart of transatlantic flights and are urging governments to act responsibly and in unison to boost confidence and demand.

site_title: Dollar around lowest levels of year before Fed minutes
summary: The US dollar hovered at its lowest levels of the year, falling to 89.686 in early European trading, before rising back against a basket of six major currencies. The move comes as traders await the release of US Federal Reserve minutes, which are expected to confirm policymakers think interest rates will remain low. Meanwhile, China's ban on cryptocurrency services sent Bitcoin and Ether tumbling, with Bitcoin falling to a three-month low of $36,250.

site_title: Strong trade with China points to valuable ties: Australian PM
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison highlighted strong trade volumes with China despite soured ties, citing a valuable relationship. However, his remarks were met with criticism from the opposition party, who accused him of using alarmist rhetoric for domestic gains. The two countries' relations have deteriorated due to Australia's call for a global inquiry into COVID-19's origins, leading to China's restrictions on Australian imports.

site_title: Singtel joins Valuable 500 movement
summary: Singtel has joined the Valuable 500 global movement, committing to corporate responsibility towards equity and inclusion. The telecommunications group outlined four strategies to create equal opportunities for students with disabilities, ensure accessibility in customer experiences, empower persons with disabilities, and develop enabling technologies. Singtel's CEO, Yuen Kuan Moon, stated that the disability-inclusion agenda is a core tenet of their sustainability strategy, aligning with their vision to build a more inclusive workplace.

images.alt_text: A Singtel employee volunteer interacting with students with special needs at a 2019 event. Through the Singtel Touching Lives Fund, the company has raised over S$48 million since 2002 in support of special education schools that equip their students with skills to join the workforce.

site_title: BT Lifestyle: Tightening up, but the show must go on
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts faced challenges due to the city's Heightened Alert status, with performances cancelled and possible future restrictions. Artists and organisers are coping with the situation, and BTLifestyle explores options for creative artists. Meanwhile, a home is showcased as a perfect setup for pandemic times, with ample space for family bonding and private areas. The article also highlights themed meal ideas and unusual wines available for delivery, offering variety and convenience during these tumultuous times.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials mull curtailing asset purchases
summary: Federal Reserve officials are considering curtailing asset purchases to aid the US economy's rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic. The decision comes amid expectations of strong economic growth this year, despite concerns about inflation. According to the minutes of the April 27-28 FOMC meeting, officials suggested that if the economy makes rapid progress toward its goals, they might discuss adjusting the pace of asset purchases in upcoming meetings. This shift in policy could mark a significant change in the central bank's easy money policies.

images.alt_text: Some Federal Reserve officials believe the US economy may soon be healthy enough to taper asset purchases meant to aid its rebound from the Covid-19 pandemic, one of the first signs of a shift in the central bank's easy money policies.

site_title: Stimulus cheques, reopening economy help Target sales hit the mark
summary: Target Corp beat quarterly sales estimates with a 22.9% increase in overall sales, driven by a strong vaccination drive and stimulus cheques encouraging shoppers to spend on home goods and clothes. Comparable sales rose 18% at stores and 50% digitally, with apparel sales jumping 60%. The company forecasts positive single-digit comparable sales growth for the last two quarters of the year, beating analyst expectations.

site_title: Singapore needs common framework for climate-change disclosures: panel
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) executive director Abigail Ng calls for a common reporting framework for climate-related financial disclosures to improve consistency and comparability of climate information. Currently, only 1.9% of listed companies use frameworks by the Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures, the Carbon Disclosure Project, or the Science Based Targets initiative. Experts agree that a common framework is needed to create more value and attract global capital flows, and the government has announced plans to lead with GreenGov.Sg and Enterprise Sustainability Programme to support local enterprises in developing new sustainability capabilities.

site_title: In the current climate, will the recovery last?
summary: The global economy is showing signs of a strong recovery from the pandemic-induced recession, driven by massive fiscal and monetary policy responses and the development of effective vaccines. However, the recovery remains uncertain due to ongoing Covid-19 cases in developing economies, such as India, and concerns about inflation and financial market volatility. The UK's new Covid variant and the distribution of vaccines to lower-income countries are also key factors shaping the recovery trajectory. While many sell-side analysts expect GDP growth to continue, policymakers will need to balance the need for redistributive policies with the risk of exacerbating inflation and financial market concerns.

site_title: Clear targets a must for climate-change action
summary: Singapore's climate-change efforts face inconsistencies due to differing standards and definitions of key terms. A common reporting framework for climate-change disclosures is needed for comparability of data. The term "net-zero" lacks agreement, with countries and companies having different targets and methodologies. Experts suggest clarifying scope, adequacy, and roadmaps for targets, including specifying emission sources, gases covered, and implementation plans. Singapore's The Green Plan 2030 aims to limit carbon emissions through eco-friendly measures, promote sustainable living, and set clear targets, such as peaking carbon emissions by 2025 and making 80% of buildings green by 2030.

images.alt_text: Countries party to the agreement have pledged to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible with the aim of achieving a "climate neutral" world by 2050.

site_title: What investors and banks in Asia do next matters most
summary: Asia-Pacific markets have experienced a resurgence, driven by the influx of new economy companies, increased investment in advanced technologies, and rising interest in environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) themes. Initial public offerings (IPOs) in the region have raised $23.4 billion in new funds, while retail fund flows have surged, with net inflows of $17 billion in January 2021. Financial firms are increasingly investing in technologies such as artificial intelligence, blockchain, the cloud, and digitalization to improve performance and eliminate complexity, with 75% of firms expected to spend 10-40% of their IT budget on next-gen technologies by 2023.

site_title: 34 new Covid community cases in Singapore, including four unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 34 new Covid-19 community cases, including four unlinked cases, on May 19, 2021. The cases include a safe distancing ambassador, a basic care assistant, and two pre-school teachers. The remaining 30 cases are linked to previous cases, with 28 already in quarantine. The number of new community cases has increased to 187 in the past week, while the number of unlinked cases has risen to 49. The total number of cases in Singapore now stands at 61,689.

site_title: EU to reopen borders, easing rules for travel
summary: The European Union has agreed to reopen borders to nations and travelers deemed safe, allowing vaccinated travelers to enter quarantine-free and people from countries with controlled COVID-19 outbreaks. The decision, made by EU ambassadors, comes as 32.4% of EU citizens have received at least one vaccination dose. The new rules, set to be formally approved, include a 14-day new case rate of less than 75 per 100,000 and a "white list" of non-EU countries with low disease risk. The move aims to boost the EU's summer tourist season and ease pandemic-induced restrictions.

site_title: G-7 turns eye on security issues, with sights set on China
summary: The G-7 foreign ministers' meeting in London highlighted the group's importance in international security, with discussions on Russia's troop build-up, Myanmar's military, and China's "arbitrary, coercive policies and practices". The G-7 agreed to improve resilience to China's influence and is considering a US-led alternative to China's "Belt and Road Initiative" to fund infrastructure projects. However, the plan faces criticism from China, which has strongly objected to the communique and accused the G-7 of "blatantly meddling" in its internal affairs.

site_title: Trust matters: Driving growth for the future
summary: The global economy's shift to digitalization has heightened the importance of trust, driving growth and innovation. Building and maintaining trust is crucial for collaborative action and the adoption of technological innovations. Governments and regulators worldwide are working together to establish principles-guided legislative frameworks that promote efficient and effective technological development. Common standards, such as those implemented in Germany's IT Security Act 2.0, are essential for fostering trust in critical infrastructure and global trade. The success of the digital economy depends on the widespread adoption of regulations and standards, ensuring secure data transmission and respecting user privacy and sovereignty.

site_title: Net-Zero
summary: Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, as part of its net-zero emissions goal. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is also evolving its climate investing approach, while the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Additionally, Singapore is considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines and Temasek's sustainability-aligned investments have reached S$46 billion in FY2025, putting pressure on electric vehicle battery makers to reduce emissions.

site_title: Chip crisis in 'danger zone' as wait times reach new record
summary: The global semiconductor industry is facing a severe crisis, with lead times reaching a record 17 weeks in April, indicating users are desperate to secure supply. This is the longest wait since 2017, dubbed the "danger zone" by analysts. Chip shortages are affecting industries worldwide, causing automakers to lose $110 billion in sales and idling factories. The crisis is partly due to a resurgence of COVID-19 cases in Taiwan, a key chip manufacturing location, and a shortage of display driver integrated circuits. The situation is expected to worsen, with 70% of tracked companies experiencing expanding lead times.

site_title: Matching Bach's inventions
summary: Pianist Dan Tepfer has created a new project, "Inventions/Reinventions," where he improvises his own responses to Bach's missing two-part inventions, filling out the composer's 15 pieces. Tepfer, a jazz artist, used a computer program to flip the original variations, and then improvised his own free responses.
