site_title: More than 7 billion additional doses are needed to keep the world pandemic-free: DHL
summary: DHL estimates that 7-9 billion additional vaccine doses are needed annually from 2022 to maintain low re-infection rates. The company calls for "free borders" in vaccine delivery to ensure timely distribution. DHL's white paper highlights the need for international collaboration, proactive transport management, and locally tailored distribution models to prepare for future mutations and re-infections. The company advises countries to keep manufacturing capacity ready to ramp up production in case of an emergency.

site_title: Vietnam woos Singapore investors to Da Nang
summary: Vietnam is seeking to attract Singaporean investors to support its transformation into an economic powerhouse, particularly in the coastal city of Da Nang. The city aims to develop three main pillars: tourism, high-tech, and marine industries. Vietnamese officials offered attractive incentives, including tax exemptions and public-private partnerships, to investors in high-tech and IT parks. Da Nang is also planning to upgrade its ports, airport, and infrastructure projects, with a focus on sustainable development and connectivity with Singapore. The city's 2045 vision is aligned with Vietnam's Prime Minister's approval, and the relationship between Vietnam and Singapore is at an all-time high.

site_title: Should Singapore further tighten border controls on new Covid wave?
summary: Singapore is facing a more infectious wave of Covid-19, prompting calls for border closure. However, economists say tightening border controls may not be the best solution, as it could harm business links and reputation. Some propose banning specific flights for a fixed duration or implementing a hard cutoff on positive cases from on-arrival tests. Others argue that Singapore's open borders have helped maintain consumer confidence and supply of essential workers, but also come with costs such as increased Phase 2 measures. The government is considering chartering evacuation flights to bring citizens and residents back, while economists emphasize the need to adapt border-control strategies to address emerging risks.

site_title: US Treasury's Yellen says tax hike, infrastructure plan will boost profits
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen defended President Biden's $2.2 trillion infrastructure plan, stating it will enhance corporate profitability and competitiveness. The plan includes investments in broadband networks, research and development, and modernized schools. Yellen also emphasized the importance of a global minimum corporate tax to "return the corporate tax rate toward historical norms." The proposal aims to create jobs, improve global competitiveness, and address childhood poverty.

site_title: What most active versus passive debates miss
summary: The CFA Society Singapore highlights that the active versus passive debate is just one of the key factors investors should consider. Active funds can outperform their passive counterparts, but it's not the most important issue. Investors should also consider the number of securities available, dispersion between best- and worst-performing stocks, and the proportion of retail versus professional investors. The choice between active and passive investments depends on individual investors' abilities, and a more practical approach involves evaluating qualitative factors such as fund managers' people, philosophy, and process. Ultimately, investors should assess their own capabilities and consider seeking passive options if they cannot pick good funds with the time and information they have.

images.alt_text: The current fund assessment process, which is conducted through in-person meetings and email exchanges, is cumbersome, opaque, and costly. It is also accessible only to large research and advisory firms are influential enough.

site_title: Singapore firms may soon be able to trade carbon credits in the race to net zero
summary: Singapore firms may soon be able to trade carbon credits as the country deepens its participation in the carbon trading market. Platforms are emerging to allow businesses to purchase carbon offsets, enabling them to meet sustainability targets. The move aims to tackle greenwashing concerns and align with the Paris Agreement's goal of moving the world off fossil fuels. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is also working to improve the efficiency of the carbon-credit market.

site_title: Insight Partners leads US$60m Series B extension round in cross-border payments startup Thunes, doubling its share price
summary: Singapore-based cross-border payments startup Thunes has secured US$60 million in funding led by Insight Partners, nearly doubling its share price to S$3.70. The funding round, led by existing investors, values Thunes at S$690.3 million. The company has seen its top line and transaction volume double over the past year, scaling up infrastructure in emerging markets. This round brings Thunes' total funds raised to US$130 million, with plans to further expand its services in fragmented and complex payment ecosystems.

site_title: Temasek-backed payments firm Flywire eyes US$2.4b valuation in US IPO
summary: Flywire Corp, a payments firm backed by Temasek Holdings, is seeking a US$2.4 billion valuation in its US IPO. The company is offering 8.7 million shares between US$22 and US$24 each. Founded in 2011, Flywire focuses on payments in education, healthcare, and travel sectors. The IPO comes amid a surge in fintech interest, with companies like Affirm and Stripe raising capital at high valuations.

site_title: Viking Offshore & Marine gets nod for new deadline to submit SGX resumption proposal
summary: Viking Offshore & Marine has received no objection from the Singapore Exchange Regulators (SGX RegCo) for an extension to June 30 to submit its proposal to resume trading. This is the third request for a fresh deadline, following previous submissions on May 14, 2021, and March 9, 2021. The company is undergoing a court-supervised process to reorganize its liabilities, and its shares have been suspended from trading since June 14, 2019. The company will resubmit its resumption proposal on a later date.

site_title: Tata Motors posts US$1b loss as Jaguar costs hit bottom line
summary: Tata Motors reported a US$1 billion loss in the first quarter of 2021, despite a 42% revenue jump, due to restructuring costs related to its Jaguar Land Rover brand. The company narrowed its losses from the previous year and posted a consolidated net loss of 76 billion rupees. Revenues surged as coronavirus restrictions eased, but renewed lockdowns have dampened demand, prompting temporary plant shutdowns. Tata Motors' shares have surged 78% in 2021, driven by expectations of a sustained recovery in profitability.

site_title: US: Stocks flat on strong retail earnings, weak housing data
summary: US stocks remained flat in early trading Tuesday as strong quarterly earnings from retailers like Walmart and Home Depot offset disappointing US housing data. Retail shares rose 1.3% after beating expectations, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average remained steady at 34,323.60. However, the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% and the Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.2%. Weak US housing data, which fell 9.5% in April, also weighed on the market. Investors are weighing signs of rising inflation against hopes for strengthening economic growth in the second half of 2021.

site_title: Dollar slumps as expectations of flat rates grow
summary: The US dollar slumped to a six-year low against the Canadian dollar and teetered near multi-month lows against other major currencies due to renewed expectations that the US Federal Reserve will not hike interest rates anytime soon. The dollar's decline was fueled by comments from Dallas Federal Reserve president Robert Kaplan, who reiterated that interest rates won't rise until next year. The benchmark 10-year US Treasury yield also stalled, and the dollar traded near its highest against the euro since February.

site_title: Waterway Point owner gets maiden S$589m green loan
summary: Sapphire Star Trust, owner of Waterway Point, has secured a S$589 million green loan from Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation and United Overseas Bank. The loan will refinance existing borrowings, working capital, and corporate funding. FCT owns a 40% stake in Sapphire Star Trust and will enjoy a reduced margin if Waterway Point retains its Green Mark GoldPlus certification. The loan is part of FCT's sustainability goals, with the trust aiming to finance 80% of its sustainable asset portfolio with green financing by 2024.

site_title: Clobbered by Covid-19, Thailand's jobless rate hits record
summary: Thailand's jobless rate reached a record 2% in the first quarter of 2021, surpassing the 1% mark for over a decade, largely due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic. This high unemployment rate is deemed unusual in the country.

images.alt_text: Thailand's official unemployment rate hit a new peak in the first quarter of this year, reaching 2 per cent of the labour force.

site_title: Walmart beats estimates for sales on stimulus spending boost
summary: Walmart reported a 6% increase in same-store sales, excluding fuel, in the first quarter, beating analyst estimates of 0.86%. The company attributed the growth to stimulus spending and increased demand for apparel and electronics. Online sales rose 37%, but lost some momentum compared to the previous quarter. Walmart raised its full-year earnings forecast, expecting a high single-digit increase in earnings, and reported a 32.3% rise in operating income to $6.91 billion.

site_title: Sea's Q1 net loss rises 50.3% even as revenue more than doubles
summary: Sea Ltd, a Singapore-based company that owns e-commerce platform Shopee and game developer Garena, reported a net loss of US$422.1 million for the first quarter of 2021, a 50.3% increase from the previous year. Despite a 111.4% rise in digital entertainment revenue to US$781.3 million, the company's operating expenses increased, leading to a net loss. Revenue more than doubled to US$1.76 billion, with the e-commerce segment seeing a 153% year-on-year increase in gross orders. The company's chairman attributed the results to strong user growth and engagement, with digital adoption expected to continue supporting Sea's sustained growth.

site_title: 'Leadership, technology, commitment key to sustainability efforts'
summary: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu emphasized the importance of strong leadership, technology, and commitment in driving Singapore's sustainability efforts. She highlighted the need for businesses to adopt long-term solutions to climate change and environmental challenges, leveraging technology such as data, fintech, and AI to enhance decision-making and resource optimization. The government has introduced various initiatives, including the Enterprise Sustainability Programme and the Green Finance Action Plan, to promote sustainability and green growth in the country.

site_title: 'New virus variants likely behind higher transmission rate; higher-quality masks urged'
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health has advised the public to stay home "only for essential activities" amid a rise in community Covid-19 cases, citing new virus variants as a possible cause for the increased transmission rate. The guidelines, which include wearing higher-quality masks, are in response to "recent clusters suggesting a higher level of transmission." The measures, which include limiting social groups and daily household visitors, aim to minimize potential transmission within the community and are subject to review based on the impact of restrictions on virus transmission.

site_title: Singapore shares advance with Asia despite rising virus infections
summary: Singapore shares advanced 2.04% on Tuesday, driven by bargain-hunting and a dismissal of rising virus infections in the region. The Singapore Straits Times Index rose to 3,142.63, with key benchmark indices in Asia also ending the day higher. Transport-related stocks, such as Singapore Airlines and ComfortDelGro, led gains, while Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust was the best-performing stock. Analysts believe Singapore's growth is unlikely to be derailed by social restrictions, despite potential market volatility from rising infections.

site_title: 27 new Covid-19 community cases in Singapore; 11 unlinked
summary: There were 38 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore as of May 18, 2021, including 27 in the community and 11 unlinked cases. The remaining 16 cases were linked to previous cases.

site_title: China's Baidu beats quarterly revenue estimates on AI, cloud boost
summary: China's Baidu reported a 25% increase in quarterly revenue to 28.13 billion yuan (S$5.8 billion) in the first quarter, beating estimates, driven by 70% year-on-year growth in its non-advertising revenue, including cloud services. The company diversified its revenue sources to fend off competition from local internet giants Alibaba and ByteDance. Baidu's cloud and AI services contributed significantly to the revenue boost, as the company expands its offerings to counter the competition.

site_title: German top court throws out challenge to ECB bond-buying
summary: Germany's top court has dismissed a challenge to the European Central Bank's eurozone-wide bond-buying programme, ruling that the cases are unfounded. The Federal Constitutional Court had initially threatened to block the Bundesbank's participation in the stimulus plan unless the ECB could prove its government debt purchases were not "disproportionate". After receiving documentary evidence, Germany's Parliament concluded that the ECB had adequately shown it did not overstep the mark. The decision effectively allows the Bundesbank to continue participating in the programme.

site_title: Vietnam orders Foxconn plant to shut as virus surges
summary: Vietnam has ordered Foxconn Technology Group and Luxshare Precision Industry Co to temporarily shut their factories in the northern region amid a surge in COVID-19 cases. The factories, located in four industrial parks, will close starting Tuesday to help contain the spread of the virus and limit disruptions to the global supply chain. Vietnam aims to resume operations in two weeks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end the day higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose over 1% on Tuesday, following an Asia-wide advance, driven by hopes for global recovery and outweighing concerns over regional infections. The Hang Seng Index surged 1.42% to 28,593.81, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.32%. The rally comes despite rising infections in parts of the region.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher
summary: European stock markets rose at the open on Tuesday, driven by recent falls triggered by rising inflation fears. London's FTSE 100 index climbed 0.7%, while the eurozone's DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices gained 0.8% and 0.6%, respectively.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media defends appointment of watch-listed group adviser's wife, calling her a 'separate and independent' party
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holdings defended the appointment of Lian Lee Lee as deputy CEO, stating she is a "separate and independent" party from her husband John Ho, a substantial shareholder and group adviser under the Singapore Exchange Regulation watchlist. The company cited her 25 years of media and entertainment industry experience and her independent decision-making skills in her previous leadership roles. GHY claimed that Ms Lian's appointment was not affected by her relationship with Mr Ho, contrary to concerns raised by corporate governance advocate Mak Yuen Teen.

site_title: Tokyo doctors call for cancellation of Olympic Games due to Covid-19
summary: Tokyo doctors urge the cancellation of the Tokyo Olympics due to a surge in coronavirus infections, citing overwhelmed hospitals and a shortage of medical staff. The Tokyo Medical Practitioners Association, representing 6,000 primary care doctors, argues that holding the Games would put a significant strain on the healthcare system. The association has called on the International Olympic Committee to cancel the Games, citing the risk of heat exhaustion patients during the summer months and potential rise in deaths.

site_title: Singapore Reinsurance extends closing date for Fairfax Asia's cash offer
summary: Singapore Reinsurance Corp extended the closing date for Fairfax Asia's cash offer from May 18 to June 2, 5:30pm. The offer price is 35.35 Singapore cents, a 20.6% premium over the 1-month VWAP. Fairfax Asia needs to acquire more than 50% stakes to close the deal. As of May 18, Fairfax Asia and its parties owned 84.12% of shares, with public acceptances at 55.14%. The deal aims to delist Singapore Reinsurance, a subsidiary of Fairfax Financial Holdings.

site_title: Lamborghini will drop US$1.8b on electrifying its supercars
summary: Lamborghini plans to electrify its supercar lineup, spending $1.8 billion by 2024 on plug-in hybrid and fully electric models. The company aims to halve emissions across its product line by 2025. Lamborghini's first all-electric model is expected to arrive in the second half of the decade, with CEO Stephan Winkelmann stating that the brand must balance performance with reduced emissions. The move is part of Volkswagen AG's push into electric cars, which may also extend to its French brand Bugatti and Croatian electric supercar maker Rimac.

images.alt_text: Lamborghini is the latest supercar maker to pivot from screaming V-12 combustion engines to electric.

site_title: Delfi Q1 Ebitda down 6% year on year to US$18m, sees uptick from previous quarter
summary: Delfi Ltd reported a 6% year-over-year decline in Ebitda to US$18m in Q1, attributed to lower sales and gross margins. Revenue fell 5.7% to US$119.4m, with regional markets experiencing a 1% decline. However, on a quarter-on-quarter basis, revenue rose 14.4% and Ebitda increased 37.7%. The company maintained a cautious outlook due to macroeconomic and operating challenges, but is optimistic about its FY 2021 performance.

site_title: UK rushes to vaccinate as contagious India Covid variant advances
summary: The UK is racing to vaccinate its population as a highly contagious COVID-19 variant from India spreads rapidly. The Indian strain has more than doubled in a week, with 2,323 cases identified, and is estimated to be 40-50% easier to transmit than the Kent variant. Despite concerns, early data suggest vaccines work against the strain, and the government aims to fully reopen on June 21. Authorities are accelerating vaccination efforts in hardest-hit areas, with almost two-fifths of the population on track to be fully vaccinated by then.

site_title: Some big US hedge funds bought value stocks, SPACs during first quarter
summary: US hedge funds shifted their portfolios in the first quarter, buying value stocks and blank-check acquisition companies (SPACs) amid rising bond yields and inflation concerns. Funds such as Third Point and Bridgewater Associates added shares in companies like Carvana, Uber, and General Motors, while selling out of tech stocks like Alibaba. Over 400 SPACs have listed shares since 2021, but most underperform the broader market. The moves reflect investors positioning for a growing economy, with value stocks surging 17% and bond yields increasing.

site_title: Prime US Reit Q1 net property income down 2% to US$23m
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 2% decrease in net property income to US$23m in Q1, driven by a 1.2% decline in distributable income. Despite this, the Reit maintained a solid rent collection rate of 99% and booked 80,084 sq ft of new leases with positive rental reversion. The Reit's portfolio has a weighted average lease expiry of 4.3 years, and its gearing ratio stands at 33.8%. The Reit's manager expects a majority of businesses to return to office in the coming months, positioning the company for accretive acquisitions and tenant growth.

site_title: CDL rolls out support for tenants amid heightened alert
summary: CDL announces support initiatives for tenants amid heightened Phase 2 restrictions in Singapore. The company will provide flexibility in rental payments, marketing and operational support through its online platform CDL eMall, and absorb onboarding costs. CDL has also committed over S$40 million in property tax and rental rebates since the pandemic began. The company will also extend the grace period for delivery drivers at City Square Mall to 30 minutes, starting May 19.

site_title: China's Neusoft Medical mulls US$400m Hong Kong IPO
summary: China's Neusoft Medical Systems Co, a medical devices arm of software company Neusoft Corp, is considering a Hong Kong initial public offering (IPO) that could raise US$400-500 million. The company, which makes X-ray and CT scanners used in over 110 countries, had previously withdrawn its application to Shanghai's STAR board due to tightened rules. Deliberations on the potential IPO are at an early stage, with details such as size and timing subject to change.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks climb as more economies reopen
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.23% on Tuesday, with the Kospi index climbing 38.53 points to 3,173.05, driven by the accelerating pace of economic growth as more economies reopen in the west. Technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix led the gains, while LG Chem and Naver also saw significant increases. Investors weighed the risks of spiking coronavirus cases in Asia against the economic recovery.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore to delay second dose of Covid-19 vaccine to get shots into more arms, potentially reaching an extra 400,000 people by end-July. This change affects bookings made on or after May 19. The country also reported 100,000 fewer workers in construction and services sectors if migrant workers had been allowed to enter. In other news, CDL provides support for tenants amid heightened alert, Hummingbird Bioscience raises $125m in funding, and PUB launches a coastal protection strategy with a City-East Coast study. Singapore shares rose 2.04% in the STI today.

site_title: KTL Global receives writ of summons from CEO of Vibrant Group
summary: KTL Global received a writ of summons from CEO Khua Kian Kheong of Vibrant Group, claiming S$933,900 for shares acquired in 2015. The company must respond within eight days. Separately, Khua faces a court charge for allegedly pushing former KTL Global chairman Tan Tock Han down the stairs in January, causing Tan to suffer a fractured shoulder. KTL Global shares fell 2.6% to 7.6 Singapore cents on the news.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after recent falls
summary: Tokyo shares closed higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index jumping 2.09% to 28,406.84, and the Topix index adding 1.54% to 1,907.74. Investors sought bargains after recent falls, including a 0.92% loss in the Nikkei index on Monday, and the yen's appreciation against the dollar provided some support to the market. The news of Japan's economy contracting 1.3% in the three months to March was seen as broadly expected and factored into market expectations.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts maintain 'buy' for Frencken on semiconductor growth; DBS raises target price
summary: Analysts at DBS, Maybank Kim Eng, and RHB have maintained a "buy" rating for Frencken Group due to strong Q1 2021 performance driven by semiconductor growth. The company posted a 54.7% increase in net profit and expanded its gross profit margin to 17.3%. DBS raised its target price to S$1.98 from S$1.55, citing diversified product offerings and stable earnings. Analysts expect the automotive segment to soften but believe Frencken's semiconductor momentum will drive strong performance in H1.

site_title: No new fossil fuel projects for net-zero: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has warned that the world must scrap all new fossil fuel projects to reach net-zero carbon emissions by 2050 and limit global warming to 1.5C. The agency predicts a sharp decline in fossil fuel demand, with oil and gas producers shifting focus to emissions reductions. By 2050, renewables capacity and efficiency will drive global energy demand down by 8%, with investment in renewables projected to boost global GDP by 4%. The IEA also calls for a rapid ramp-up of renewable energy investment and capacity, and for all inefficient coal power plants to close by 2030.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.86 points to 1,591.32, with a trading volume of 5.836 billion lots worth RM3.151 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 812-279.

site_title: Heineken considers takeover of South African brewer
summary: Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, is considering a takeover of South African wine and spirits maker Distell Group Holdings Ltd, valued at around $2.3 billion. This would be Heineken's largest transaction since 2018 and would add to the $7.4 billion in deals announced in the global beverage industry this year. The deliberations are ongoing, with no certainty of a deal. The move would see Heineken accelerate its strategy of tapping growth opportunities in Africa, led by CEO Dolf van den Brink.

images.alt_text: Heineken NV, the world's second-largest brewer, is weighing a takeover of South African wine and spirits maker Distell Group Holdings Ltd, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: India's tally of coronavirus infections crosses 25 million
summary: India's total coronavirus cases surpassed 25 million, with 263,533 new infections reported over the last 24 hours. The country's death toll from Covid-19 rose to 278,719, making it the world's second nation to reach this milestone after the United States.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, defying news of Japan's negative economic growth due to lingering Covid-19 concerns. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.82% and the Topix index added 0.63%. Despite global economic uncertainty, the market shrugged off concerns, with investors focusing on other regional markets and economic data releases.

site_title: Martech startup Affable.ai raises US$2m to boost global adoption of its influencer marketing platform
summary: Affable.ai, a Singapore-based martech startup, has raised US$2 million in funding from Prime Venture Partners, Decacorn Capital, and SGInnovate to expand its influencer marketing platform globally, particularly in the US. The platform uses machine learning and Big Data analytics to help brands and agencies find micro-influencers, manage campaigns, and measure performance. With its total funding now at US$2.8 million, Affable aims to capitalize on the growing influencer marketing industry, expected to reach US$15 billion globally by next year, and tap into the US market to boost adoption.

site_title: Leadership, technology and commitment key to sustainability efforts: Grace Fu
summary: Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu emphasized the importance of strong leadership, technology, and commitment to sustainability in Singapore's efforts to transition to a low-carbon economy. She highlighted the need for businesses to transform practices and inspire others, leveraging technology to enhance decision-making and reduce waste. The government will lead green initiatives, and businesses must make a commitment to finding long-term solutions, with adequate environmental, social, and governance processes. Singapore aims to drive its sustainability goals through the Green Plan 2030, with measures to support small and medium enterprises, promote innovation, and boost green finance.

site_title: California farmers facing drought are choosing empty fields
summary: California farmers are struggling with a severe drought, forcing them to abandon plans to grow crops this season. Growers north of San Francisco are pulling out of local farmers markets and produce-box programs due to lack of water. The state, which produces a third of the US's vegetables and two-thirds of its fruits and nuts, is expected to remain dry until October. The drought is attributed to a La Nina weather pattern that pushed winter storms away from the state, leaving it with less moisture than usual.

site_title: Hong Kong temporarily suspends operations at representative office in Taiwan
summary: Hong Kong's representative office in Taiwan has temporarily suspended operations, citing no relation to the rise in coronavirus cases. The decision follows tensions between the Beijing-backed Hong Kong government and Taiwan, which have risen since pro-democracy protests in Hong Kong in 2019. The Hong Kong government said requests for assistance will be handled through hotlines and the website, without providing further explanation. Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council is working on a response to the matter.

site_title: Hummingbird Bioscience raises US$125m in Series C round led by Novo Holdings
summary: Hummingbird Bioscience has raised US$125 million in a Series C round led by Novo Holdings, with additional investors including EDBI, Frazier Healthcare Partners, and Octagon Capital. The funding will support the advancement of Hummingbird's lead antibody assets targeting cancer tumors and the development of its proprietary Rational Antibody Discovery (RAD) platform. This marks the company's third funding round, following a US$19 million Series B round in 2019 and a US$6 million extension in May last year.

site_title: JPMorgan appoints Elaine Zhang as China market leader for Singapore
summary: JPMorgan Private Bank has appointed Elaine Zhang as its new China market leader for Singapore, starting in August. Zhang, a managing director, brings over 20 years of experience in private banking, including serving ultra-high net worth Chinese clients and leading China market relationship managers. The appointment follows JPMorgan's plan to double the number of private bankers serving Chinese clients from Singapore over the next two years.

site_title: Two four-storey freehold buildings at Kim Keat Road for sale with S$15.7m guide price
summary: Two four-storey-plus-attic freehold buildings at Kim Keat Road in Singapore are up for sale with a collective guide price of S$15.7 million. The site has a gross plot ratio of three and a total gross floor area of 10,495 sq ft, with main road frontage and a mechanical car parking system. The properties are zoned for residential use with commercial space on the first floor and are near private tertiary education institutions and health facilities, attracting students and healthcare workers. Interest is high from property funds, family offices, and high net worth investors.

site_title: Vatican's new Hong Kong bishop says religious freedom must stay
summary: Hong Kong's newly appointed Catholic bishop, Stephen Chow, has vowed to defend religious freedoms, stating it's a "basic right." Chow, who will tread carefully with Beijing authorities, expressed his commitment to unity within the congregation while acknowledging the need for prudence when discussing sensitive topics. The appointment comes at a tumultuous time for Hong Kong's Catholic Church, with the city's relations with Beijing strained due to China's authoritarian rule and security law. Chow's role is to balance the Vatican's interests with the local government's demands, amid concerns about the erosion of religious freedoms in Hong Kong.

site_title: High traces of Viagra in Seoul's sewers, research shows
summary: Researchers in South Korea found high traces of Viagra and other erectile dysfunction medications in Seoul's sewers, with levels 31% higher on weekends and in areas with nightlife spots. The chemicals, known as Phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (PDE-5i), were found to be barely treated by sewage treatment plants and discharged into the environment. The study suggests that the increasing market size for PDE-5i, which reached $133 million in 2019, will lead to more chemical discharge in urban areas, affecting water quality.

images.alt_text: High traces of Viagra and other drugs used to treat erectile dysfunction were found in Seoul's wastewaters, and their presence in the urban area is expected to increase, South Korean researchers say.

site_title: Thailand considers releasing 50,000 inmates as Covid-19 hits prisons
summary: Thailand is considering releasing 50,000 inmates, approximately 16% of its prison population, due to a rapid spread of COVID-19 among inmates and prison workers. Over 10,000 new cases have been reported in 12 densely-packed prisons, contributing to record-high daily case counts. The outbreak reflects the challenges of vaccinations and the spread of infections in crowded areas of Bangkok.

images.alt_text: Thailand, already facing its worst coronavirus outbreak since the start of the pandemic, is considering cutting its prison population by as much as 16 per cent to counter the rapid spread of infections among inmates and workers in overcrowded facilities.

site_title: Bolt undercuts rivals in nine-city German e-scooter roll-out
summary: Estonian start-up Bolt launched electric scooter services in nine German cities, offering ultra-low pricing of 0.05 euros (S$0.08) per minute with no unlocking fee. This undercut rivals, who typically charge 1 euro per trip plus 15-25 euro cents a minute. Bolt aims to expand its presence into 150 European cities this year, with a 100 million euro investment strategy, and is looking to become the region's largest micromobility provider.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index remaining unchanged at 1,583.48. Volume was 383.46 million lots worth RM166.69 million. Gainers edged out losers 263 to 165.

site_title: Taiwan mobilises diplomats to seek out Covid-19 shots
summary: Taiwan is mobilizing its diplomats to secure a faster delivery of COVID-19 vaccines, with the island having vaccinated less than 1% of its population amid a sudden rise in domestic cases. Taiwan has reported over 700 new infections in the past week and has received only about 300,000 AstraZeneca vaccines so far. The US has pledged to send at least 20 million vaccine doses abroad by the end of June, and Taiwan is in talks with the US to receive a share. Taiwan hopes to provide domestically-developed vaccines by the end of July.

site_title: Argentina halts beef exports for 30 days to contain prices
summary: Argentina's government has halted beef exports for 30 days to combat rising inflation, which has approached 50% annually. President Alberto Fernandez's decision aims to control prices and appease local consumers ahead of a midterm election. The measure may impact the country's $3 billion beef exports, which have surged for four years. The suspension is part of a broader effort to restrict speculative practices and fiscal evasion, with the possibility of shortening the period if results are positive.

site_title: UK ministers considering contingency plans for local lockdowns: The Times
summary: British ministers are considering contingency plans for local lockdowns or a delay to reopening after June 21 due to concerns over the spread of the Indian coronavirus variant. Officials have drawn up plans modelled on Tier 4 restrictions, advising people to stay at home and closing non-essential shops and hospitality if the variant isn't brought under control. Businesses in affected areas would receive up to £18,000 in grants, with payments adjusted according to restriction length. The government awaits more data before deciding on further easing of lockdown restrictions.

site_title: PUB to kick off coastal protection strategy with City-East Coast study
summary: Public Utilities Board (PUB) in Singapore will start a site-specific study along the City-East Coast, marking the first of a series of planned coastal protection studies. The 57.8km coastline will be examined for vulnerability to rising seas and potential flood risks. The study, expected to take four years, aims to explore solutions to protect the area from climate change impacts, including formulating adaptation measures and developing flood mitigation designs. This is part of PUB's longer-term coastal protection plans, which also include studies for other areas such as Jurong Island and the North-West coast.

site_title: Australian PM stands firm on border closure due to Covid-19, as industries plea for reopening
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has reaffirmed his stance on keeping international borders closed due to COVID-19, despite industries and residents urging for a faster reopening. Morrison stated it's not safe for fully-vaccinated residents to travel overseas, and plans to reopen borders to the rest of the world in mid-2022. Authorities in New South Wales require at least 80% of its adult population to be fully vaccinated before considering quarantine-free entry. The national immunization drive is administering 1 million doses in 17 days, but has fallen short of initial targets.

site_title: 100,000 fewer workers in construction and services sectors had borders been shut to migrant workers: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) revealed that if Singapore had barred migrant workers from entering the country after the "circuit-breaker" period, there would be 30,000 fewer construction workers, 70,000 fewer migrant workers in the services sector, and 30,000 fewer domestic workers. MOM attributed this to the outflow of migrant workers exceeding the inflow due to border restrictions. Businesses have appealed for more workers to be allowed to enter to address manpower shortages, while MOM emphasized the need for safe worker inflow to prevent transmission risks.

site_title: Alibaba leads US$400m investment in Vietnam retail giant
summary: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. has led a US$400 million investment in Vietnam retail giant Masan Group Corp's retail arm, The CrownX. The deal gives Alibaba a 5.5% stake, while Masan retains 80.2%. The investment implies a pre-investment valuation of US$6.9 billion for The CrownX. This move will expand Alibaba's online groceries business in Southeast Asia.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. and partners are investing US$400 million in Vietnamese conglomerate Masan Group Corp's retail arm, a deal that will expand the Chinese e-commerce giant's online groceries business in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Chinese firm GDS weighs buying GLP's data centres: sources
summary: GDS Holdings, a Chinese cloud computing company, is considering acquiring GLP's data centres business, valued at $8 billion to $10 billion. The deal would make GLP a shareholder in Shanghai-based GDS. Preliminary talks are ongoing, and the companies may decide against pursuing a transaction. Details, including valuation and deal structure, are still in the early stages.

site_title: Maersk's drilling rig sale boosts New Fortress' floating LNG plans
summary: Maersk Drilling sold two oil drilling rigs to New Fortress Energy Inc, which will convert them into floating liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities. The rigs, Maersk Guardian and Maersk Gallant, were sold for a total price of $31 million. The conversion is part of New Fortress' strategy to expand into the global LNG market, with the rigs expected to start production by the end of 2023. This move allows New Fortress to quickly access markets with underutilized natural gas from Brazil to Southeast Asia and Africa.

site_title: US blocks new draft UN statement on Israeli-Palestinian violence
summary: The US blocked a joint UN Security Council statement on Israeli-Palestinian violence for the third time in a week, citing inability to support an expression calling for a halt to the violence. The draft, submitted by China, Tunisia, and Norway, condemned Israeli actions and called for de-escalation and protection of civilians. The US has been accused of obstructionism, with the UN seeking a unified voice on the conflict. A new emergency meeting is set for Tuesday, amid a week of violence that has claimed over 200 lives, with the UN General Assembly also holding a ministerial-level debate on Thursday.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin Tuesday's session with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with gains, driven by optimism over economic recovery. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.87% to 28,438.03, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.09% to 3,520.65. Despite rising virus infections in Asia, traders appeared to be brushing off concerns.

site_title: Oil climbs 1% on economic recovery hopes despite fresh Asian restrictions
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday, driven by European economic reopenings and rising US demand, despite fresh Asian restrictions. Brent crude climbed 75 cents to $69.46 a barrel, while WTI crude rose 90 cents to $66.27. European reopenings, US air travel, and summer travel bookings supported oil prices, but concerns about the coronavirus variant and interest rate hikes persisted.

site_title: Gold advances to three-month high on virus woes, inflation
summary: Gold prices surged to a three-month high amid concerns over the global recovery and rising coronavirus cases in Asia. The World Economic Forum cancelled its meeting, and investors await the Federal Reserve's minutes for clues on inflation. Fed officials expect price pressures to ease in 2022, but inflation fears are boosting gold demand. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,870.73 an ounce, with silver, palladium, and platinum also gaining. The rebound erases this year's declines, with ETF inflows signaling a boost to investor sentiment.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise but virus, inflation fears linger
summary: Asia markets rose on Tuesday as investors focused on the global recovery, despite rising virus infections and inflation concerns. Tokyo led gains after data showed the Japanese economy contracted more than expected in the first quarter. Hong Kong and Seoul also rose, while Taipei rallied after a surge in virus cases. However, some markets, including Shanghai and Wellington, fell. Traders await the release of US Federal Reserve minutes for clues on inflation and interest rates, which could impact the region's economic recovery.

site_title: US airlines add Covid-tested flights to Italy as country reopens to tourists
summary: US airlines United, Delta, and American have added Covid-tested flights to Italy, allowing leisure travelers from the US to visit the country for the first time in over a year. The Italian government has eased travel restrictions, including scrapping mandatory quarantine for visitors who test negative for Covid-19. US travelers must take a Covid test 48 hours before boarding and again on arrival, with vaccinated travelers exempt from quarantine for return travel. The move aims to boost summer tourism as cases decline globally and the EU considers easing travel restrictions.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Roxy-Pacific, Dasin Retail Trust, Jumbo
summary: Roxy-Pacific's indirect associate Mequity Hills acquired a 999-year leasehold site for S$23 million, financing through internal funding and bank borrowings. Dasin Retail Trust's revenue rose 87.4% year-over-year in Q1 FY2021, with malls recovering to 94% of pre-pandemic levels. Jumbo, despite Covid-19 restrictions, plans to open two new food and beverage outlets.

site_title: New Zealand to reset immigration policy, cut low-skilled workers
summary: New Zealand plans to reset its immigration policy, reducing the number of low-skilled immigrants when it reopens its borders after the coronavirus pandemic. The country aims to attract more highly skilled workers and rich investors. The move is aimed at addressing housing and infrastructure pressure, as well as suppressing wages by relying on lower-skilled migrant labor. The government's decision is expected to make it harder to find skilled labor, sparking concerns from business lobby groups.

images.alt_text: New Zealand plans to reset its immigration policy, cutting the number of overall immigrants, particularly low-skilled migrants, when it reopens its borders following the coronavirus pandemic, the government said.

site_title: In big ask, Australia's central bank aims for wages to grow 'sustainably' above 3%
summary: Australia's central bank aims for annual wage growth to exceed 3% to meet inflation goals, a challenging task given current growth of 1.4%. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) believes wages must more than double to reach its inflation target, with core inflation at an all-time low of 1.2%. The RBA left interest rates unchanged and plans to extend bond purchases if needed to achieve its goals of full employment and inflation. The bank expects economic growth to rebound, with a forecast of 4.75% for 2021, and unemployment to decline to around 5% by the end of the year.

site_title: UK risks Italy-style decline as economic challenges mount: think tank
summary: The UK faces significant economic challenges, including Brexit, Covid-19, climate change, and an ageing population, that could reduce its economic performance to that of struggling Italy. The Resolution Foundation warns that Britain risks failing to address slow productivity growth, stagnant living standards, and high inequality without proper plans. A decade of major public policy challenges is predicted, with the UK's GDP per capita potentially falling closer to Italy's than Germany's if current trends continue. The think-tank is calling for a new economic approach to address these challenges.

site_title: Australia: Shares rise as gold, iron ore miners gain
summary: Australian shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by gains in the mining and gold sectors. The S&P/ASX 200 benchmark index increased 0.6% to 7,063.8, with mining subindex rising 2% and gold stocks climbing over 3%. Global miners Rio Tinto and BHP rose 1.6% and 2% respectively. Energy stocks also gained after an overnight rise in oil prices, while technology stocks were weighed down by a weak lead from Wall Street.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,103.12. Sembcorp Marine and Singapore Press Holdings led the gains, while local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC also rose. The rally followed a negative lead on Wall Street, where tech stocks fell due to inflation concerns. Asian markets also opened higher, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index up 0.8% and European shares flat.

site_title: Samsung Electronics could begin construction of new US chip plant in Q3: newspaper
summary: Samsung Electronics may begin construction of a $17 billion US chip plant in Austin, Texas, in Q3 2021, with a target of being operational in 2024. The plant will utilize an advanced 5-nanometer EUV lithography process. This move comes as US President Joe Biden proposes $50 billion to support chip manufacturing, prompting investments from companies like Intel and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing. The project is expected to create 1,800 jobs, further solidifying Samsung's presence in the US chip market.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades EC World Reit to 'trading buy' on potential offer
summary: RHB upgraded EC World Reit to "trading buy" with a raised target price of S$0.83, citing a potential takeover offer from Forchn International. The Reit's high FY2021 dividend forecast and logistics-focused portfolio make it an attractive acquisition target for funds seeking stable recurring income. No decision has been made on the divestment, and there's no certainty of a transaction occurring. The upgrade represents a 7.1% upside from the Reit's current trading price.

site_title: Ryanair posts record annual loss, but sees recovery from Covid-19
summary: Ryanair reported a record annual after-tax loss of 815 million euros due to Covid-19 restrictions scrapping over 80% of flights. Despite this, the airline expects a recovery from the pandemic, with bookings increasing and a vaccine rollout potentially leading to a strong recovery in the second half of the year. Ryanair's group CEO Michael O'Leary stated that the airline is on track to break even in the current fiscal year, but warned of production issues with Boeing's 737 MAX aircraft, which may delay delivery.

images.alt_text: The airline forecasts that passenger numbers for the current fiscal year would be towards the lower end in the range of 80 million to 120 million passengers.

site_title: HSBC's multi-currency e-wallet for SMEs offers quicker, more secure global payments
summary: HSBC has launched its Global Wallet, a multi-currency digital wallet for small and medium enterprises (SMEs), allowing for quicker and more secure global payments. The service eliminates the need for third-party providers, reduces correspondence fees, and beneficiary bank charges. SMEs can send and receive money in multiple currencies, hold and manage those currencies, and make payments via their domestic payment networks. The wallet is fully integrated into HSBCnet and aims to make international payments more efficient and cost-effective for businesses expanding their international connections.

site_title: Refineries given lifeline in Australia on the back of fuel security risk
summary: Australia's government has provided a $2 billion package to protect fuel security, ensuring the country's two remaining refineries, Ampol's Lytton facility and Viva Energy Group's Geelong plant, will remain open until at least 2027. The deal aims to safeguard fuel security and mitigate the impact of low refining margin cycles. The refineries will receive variable payments linked to refining margins and production levels, with a minimum payment of 1.8 cents per liter. The package also includes upgrades to refinery infrastructure and an industry-wide review of petrol and diesel standards.

site_title: Biden releases tax return, restoring tradition Trump broke
summary: President Joe Biden and his wife Jill released their joint tax return for 2020, showing federal adjusted gross income of $607,336 and an effective tax rate of 25.9%. This marks a return to transparency, as former President Donald Trump refused to release his tax returns during his presidency. The Biden's tax return also shows their second family, including Vice-President Kamala Harris and her husband Doug Emhoff, reporting a higher income of $1,695,225. The released tax returns suggest that the Biden administration's proposed American Families Plan could result in higher taxes for the wealthy.

site_title: Brazil deforestation 94% illegal: report
summary: Brazil's Amazon deforestation is largely illegal, with 94% of deforestation in the region and surrounding areas considered illicit. President Jair Bolsonaro's promise to eliminate illegal deforestation by 2030 appears doubtful due to lack of transparency on authorized land use. Researchers found that even with permits, authorities struggle to document land clearing, making it difficult to distinguish between legal and illegal deforestation. This lack of transparency has led to concerns that environmental crimes are contaminating Brazil's agricultural and forestry production.

site_title: Singapore must remain open to global talent and skills
summary: Singapore's Emerging Stronger Taskforce emphasizes the need for the country to remain open to global talent and skills to grow a "strong Singapore core." National Development Minister Desmond Lee and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat urged against protectionist instincts, instead focusing on the commitment to Singapore's well-being and that of its citizens. The taskforce's 118-page report calls for upskilling and developing local workers, while also tapping into global talent to complement the Singapore core, potentially opening up new work opportunities for Singaporeans.

site_title: Japan's economy contracts more than expected as Covid-19 hits consumption
summary: Japan's economy contracted 5.1% in the first quarter, exceeding expectations, due to slow vaccine rollouts and a resurgence in Covid-19 infections, which hit consumption. Private consumption fell 1.4% and capital expenditure slipped 1.4%, while exports grew 2.3% but were offset by a decline in net exports. The contraction marks the first in three quarters and could limit recovery in the current quarter. Analysts expect extended state of emergency curbs to keep any recovery modest.

images.alt_text: Japan's economy shrank more than expected in the first quarter as slow vaccine rollouts and a resurgence in Covid-19 infections hit consumption, reinforcing expectations the country will lag major trading partners in emerging from the pandemic.

site_title: Luxury sales could return to pre-Covid levels this year: Bain
summary: Luxury goods sales are expected to recover to pre-Covid levels this year, with a 30% probability of reaching 280 billion euros, according to consultancy Bain. The sector's sales fell by 23% last year, but a strong US rebound and soaring sales in China have helped revenues bounce back. Europe is lagging behind due to a slower vaccination campaign and tourism restrictions. The industry's biggest groups, such as LVMH and Hermes, have already surpassed 2019 levels, while smaller labels are catching up. A full rebound is predicted for 2022.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end flat between Asia worries, British reopening cheer
summary: European stocks ended flat on Monday, weighed down by underwhelming Chinese data and concerns over the spread of a Covid-19 variant, despite optimism on the British economy's reopening. Travel and leisure stocks declined 2.3%, while telecommunication stocks rose, led by gains in Telefonica. Mining stocks gained 0.9% and Swedish Kinnevik surged 8.5% after transferring its Zalando stake to shareholders. The Stoxx 600 index ended flat, despite the European Union's partial truce with the US over metal tariffs and discussions on global overcapacity and China's trade policies.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kaplan says inflation readings could remain elevated at year end
summary: Federal Reserve Bank President Robert Kaplan stated that inflation readings may remain elevated at the end of the year due to pandemic-induced imbalances in supply and demand. He expects US GDP growth to reach 6.4% and the unemployment rate to fall to 4% by year-end. Kaplan emphasized the Fed's focus on monitoring inflation closely to keep consumers' inflation expectations anchored near the 2% target. This suggests that the Fed is prepared for potential inflationary pressures, despite anticipating a decline in inflation readings in the fall.

site_title: Singtel's review of its digital units is long overdue
summary: Singtel, a major telco in Singapore, has announced impairments on its digital businesses Amobee and Trustwave due to significant losses, prompting a strategic review. The move comes after years of under-performance and failure to demonstrate value, despite being valued like start-ups. The company's new CEO, Yuen Kuan Moon, has vowed to take action, marking a shift from Singtel's conservative approach to investments. Analysts hail the review as a catalyst for better days ahead, but questions remain about the extent of damage and the time it will take to put the company back on track.

site_title: Lessons from the circuit breaker
summary: Singaporean SMEs have navigated the economic challenges brought by the pandemic through digital readiness, innovation, and resilience. Businesses such as Far East Flora, Lunch Actually, and Cicheti successfully boosted online sales and pivoted to delivery services during the "circuit breaker" period. Others, like SF Group and Top International Holding, diversified their business streams and made strategic decisions to stay afloat. While Covid-19 restrictions are temporary, SMEs must remain nimble and adaptable to overcome these hurdles.

site_title: Is it the calm before the storm for office market?
summary: Singapore's office rental market showed a 3.3% quarter-on-quarter rise in Q1 2021, reversing a 3.5% decline in Q4 2020. However, the long-term trend remains uncertain due to the structural changes brought by COVID-19, such as the shift towards remote work. As vaccination efforts progress, some analysts predict the office rental market will bottom out this year before recovering in 2022. Office landlords must adapt and compete by investing in higher-quality space, as non-office venues may encroach on traditional office space.

site_title: Renewed pandemic wave may delay - not derail - Asean's economic recovery
summary: A renewed wave of COVID-19 cases in Southeast Asia may delay, but not derail, the region's economic recovery, according to experts. Countries such as Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia have implemented strict curbs to contain the outbreak, with vaccinations underway across the region. While the emergence of a more contagious virus variant is a concern, there is no evidence it has vaccine-resistant properties. Economists believe the region's strong fiscal support and accommodative monetary policies will mitigate the impact of the curbs, and the recovery is expected to continue, albeit at a slower pace.

site_title: Microsoft conducted probe on Bill Gates' involvement with employee
summary: Microsoft conducted an investigation into Bill Gates' involvement with an employee in 2000, after being informed of a romantic relationship attempt. The board reviewed the matter with an external law firm, but Gates stepped down before a conclusion was reached. The investigation found Gates' involvement to be inappropriate, but the outcome was not made public due to his prior departure from the board. Gates' decision to leave the board was attributed to philanthropy, not the matter.

site_title: China's home market 'out of control' as prices climb further
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.48% in April, the fastest pace in eight months, amid buyer enthusiasm. This follows a 0.4% increase in the secondary market. Year-to-date residential sales have more than doubled from 2019. Authorities have failed to stem price growth, prompting repeated statements to cool expectations. A national real estate tax trial may be introduced to curb speculation. Despite curbs, the market remains "out of control," with price gains accelerating across cities, including Wuhan and Haikou.

site_title: US: Wall Street indices close lower as tech continues to hurt
summary: US stocks closed lower on Monday, with tech stocks bearing the brunt of investor concerns over rising inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%, the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.4%, and the S&P 500 lost 0.3%. Concerns about inflation led to a decline in tech shares, including Netflix and Apple, as investors fear a potential interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The market's mixed performance was also influenced by news of Bill Gates' departure from Microsoft's board and AT&T's plan to spin off its media companies.

site_title: Thailand Q1 slump eases, outlook cut as Covid-19 woes linger
summary: Thailand's economy contracted 2.6% in the first quarter of 2021 due to coronavirus outbreaks, but the decline was less than expected. The country's GDP rose 0.2% on a quarterly basis, beating forecasts. The National Economic and Social Development Council downgraded its economic growth outlook to 1.5-2.5% due to the latest wave of infections, which has crimped domestic activity and led to a slow vaccine rollout. The government has implemented stimulus measures and relaxed some restrictions to boost economic activities, but tourism is expected to return to normal levels in two to three years.

site_title: Analysts expect impact of Phase 2 restrictions to be short-lived
summary: Analysts at UOB Kay Hian and CGS-CIMB expect the impact of Phase 2 restrictions in Singapore to be short-lived, with the share price declines likely a "knee-jerk reaction". The STI recovered slightly on Monday, closing at 3,079.69. UOBKH recommends focusing on companies with strong franchises and overseas earnings, while CGS-CIMB expects investors to deploy their money in financial markets instead of discretionary spending. Key stock picks include the Singapore Exchange, Sheng Siong, and OCBC.

site_title: Newly-formed GoTo to heat up fintech battle in South-east Asia
summary: Gojek and Tokopedia have merged to form GoTo Group, a fintech company specializing in e-commerce, on-demand services, and financial services. The merger solidifies the three-way battle for South-east Asia's fintech market, with GoTo competing against Sea and Grab. GoTo's co-CEO Andre Soelistyo will lead the company, which includes GoPay, an e-wallet. Industry observers believe GoTo has a strong position in financial services, but lacks the scale of its rivals in regional markets. The company plans to expand in existing markets and is expected to list on public markets, potentially in Indonesia first.

site_title: Reimagine, re-plan, re-create Singapore's future greener transport
summary: Singapore aims to decarbonize its transport sector, with a focus on electric vehicles and green infrastructure. The country's 3R framework, proposed by KPMG, involves reimagining a greener transport landscape, re-planning to grow a green economy, and recreating the transport ecosystem through technology and innovation. To achieve its goal of net-zero emissions, Singapore will need to overcome implementation hurdles, including low EV adoption and inadequate charging infrastructure. The government will also need to upskill and reskill the workforce, develop in-house expertise in carbon measurement, and invest in digitalization and technological innovations.

site_title: China to relax birth policy but wary of social risks, sources say
summary: China is expected to relax its birth policies, but with caution, amid a declining population and aging population. The country's fertility rate of 1.3 children per woman is comparable to aging societies like Japan and Italy, raising concerns about irreversible population decline. Top leaders are working out a plan to encourage childbearing, including easing financial burdens on couples, and raising the retirement age to slow workforce decline and ease pension pressures. Changes are likely to be gradual, with the focus on social stability and addressing demographic challenges.

site_title: Econ Healthcare's first China nursing home begins operations
summary: Econ Healthcare, a Singapore-based private nursing home operator, has commenced operations at its first nursing home in China, a joint venture project with Chongqing Guangda Bailingbang Eldercare Industry. The JV holds a 60-40 stake, with Econ Healthcare and its partner holding the majority and minority stakes respectively. This marks Econ Healthcare's entry into the Chinese market, expanding its international presence in the healthcare sector.

site_title: Ports on US West Coast race to clear ship backlog by August
summary: US ports on the West Coast are racing to clear a backlog of arriving cargo before peak season begins in August. As of Sunday, 19 container ships were anchored outside the Los Angeles and Long Beach ports, a decrease from a week earlier. The average wait for berth space was 6.1 days, down from 6.6 days. Port officials aim to have "few if any" ships waiting by June 1 to meet August's volume target. The backlog has persisted since November, with imports outpacing exports, and shipping companies are hesitant to wait for US exporters.

site_title: Bitcoin hits 3-month low, then rallies, on Elon Musk tweets
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 9% to its lowest since February 8, then rebounded 5% after Tesla CEO Elon Musk clarified the company has not sold its bitcoin holdings. Musk's tweets had sparked concerns about Tesla's massive bitcoin holdings, but his latest statement calmed investors. However, the volatility has spooked even seasoned traders, and some are calling for the wild ride to end. The price drops come despite a surge in the asset class this year, with dogecoin up about a hundredfold and ether up more than fourfold.

site_title: London office market undergoes facelift to woo post-Covid workforce
summary: London's office market is undergoing a facelift to cater to the post-pandemic workforce, with 56% of new construction projects set to involve upgrading existing office stock. The city's developers anticipate a 10-15% reduction in office demand due to new working patterns. Despite this, 59% of new developments were pre-let, driven by the TMT sector, which accounts for 40% of all space under construction. The shift towards more flexible and eco-friendly office spaces is expected to be key, with occupiers prioritizing ESG principles and people welfare.

site_title: Japan refiners to sell assets, rush reform as pandemic dents demand
summary: Japanese refiners Eneos Holdings and Idemitsu Kosan plan to sell assets and speed up reform amid a prolonged COVID-19 pandemic and accelerating global decarbonization trend. They downgrade profit goals due to a 30% contraction in domestic fossil fuel demand by 2030. To realign portfolios and trim CO2 emissions, Eneos will exit coal mining and downsize oil assets, while Idemitsu will focus on low-carbon fuels and expand renewable energy projects. Both companies aim to shift away from coal and oil to renewable energy and cleaner fuels by 2050.

site_title: Blackstone's A$8.4b Crown bid rejected as too low
summary: Blackstone's A$8.4 billion takeover bid for Crown Resorts Ltd was rejected due to being deemed too low. Directors unanimously decided the offer undervalued the company and expressed uncertainty over regulatory approval. This decision gives rival suitor Star Entertainment Group Ltd an advantage in potentially acquiring Crown. Crown had discussed the proposal with Blackstone, watchdogs, and shareholders but ultimately decided against it. The rejection also clouds the future for Crown's biggest shareholder, billionaire James Packer.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence steady despite rising costs, shrinking building materials
summary: US homebuilder confidence remains steady at 83 in May, despite rising construction costs and shrinking materials availability. Historically low mortgage rates help offset these costs, and a gauge of sales expectations rose slightly. The market's strength is evident in the stable confidence reading, which has held within a two-point range since the start of the year.

site_title: Cutting healthcare waste: a win-win for providers, payers, patients
summary: Singapore's healthcare system is facing rising costs and inefficiencies, with 30-50% of healthcare expenditures attributed to quality-associated waste. A lack of data and transparency between healthcare providers and insurers has led to distrust, with the Life Insurance Association Singapore (LIA) and Singapore Medical Association (SMA) disagreeing on the causes of rising costs. To address this, experts propose the use of digital data aggregation and analytics, and activity-based costing to optimize healthcare processes and resource allocation, ultimately reducing waste and improving care.

site_title: Tan Tock Seng Hospital to resume admissions from Tuesday
summary: Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) in Singapore will resume admissions starting Tuesday, May 18, after a two-week halt due to a Covid-19 cluster. The hospital has completed six rounds of testing for inpatients and staff, with consistently negative swabbing results. Admissions will resume with a three-pronged approach to protect patients and staff, including regular testing, surgical masks, and visitor restrictions. The hospital will initially allow one pre-registered visitor per patient, with limited visits and strict mask-wearing requirements.

site_title: US dollar firm as virus curbs in Asia unnerve investors
summary: The US dollar remained stable on Monday, despite new Covid-19 restrictions in Asia and mixed Chinese data, as investors sought safer currencies. The Australian and New Zealand dollars were negatively affected by a pullback in commodity prices. Bitcoin fell to a three-month low after Elon Musk suggested Tesla may have sold some of its holdings, but recovered slightly. Meanwhile, NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, and Singapore stocks rallied for a fifth consecutive day ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Building a homeware superstore from scratch
summary: Brien Chua, CEO of Houze, a Singapore-based homeware superstore, shares his journey from financial struggles to building a successful business from scratch. Initially, Chua launched and closed four businesses, including a Chinese doughnut franchise that left him in debt. After the 2008 financial crisis, he resigned from his banking job and worked in China before returning to Singapore to start Houze in 2017. Despite initial resistance and challenges, the company has grown through e-commerce and adapting to changing trends. Houze's success is attributed to its lean setup, willingness to adapt, and focus on sustainability. The company aims to expand into new markets and implement technology to increase efficiency.

site_title: Hmlet bags US$6m injection from investors in a 'down round' for turnaround; exits Australia
summary: Hmlet, a US-based co-living operator, has secured a US$6 million investment from existing investors, including Burda Principal Investments and Sequoia Capital, in a "down round" financing. This funding aims to aid the company's turnaround amid a recovering rental market. Hmlet had previously faced challenges, including the pandemic, CEO departures, and a dwindling cash runway. The company's valuation has decreased, with former CEO Yoan Kamalski's 18.9% stake to be divested over the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Co-living operator Hmlet has received a US$6 million injection, which the company hopes will help turn the tides in its favour amid a recovering rental market.

site_title: That new hybrid office may not be as flexible as you hoped for
summary: Companies are testing hybrid office models, where staff come in-person 2-3 days a week, as they navigate the post-COVID work environment. This approach aims to balance flexibility with in-person collaboration. Global finance and startup leaders are united in planning for hybrid work, driven by Covid concerns or a desire for workplace change. The short-term goal is to establish a flexible work routine that suits employees and businesses.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit saw its public offer 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, US stocks opened lower due to a fresh tariff salvo on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue below target, with similar operating losses as the first half. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen green and transition finance cooperation.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: DASIN Retail Trust's revenue for Q1 FY2021 rose 87.4% on a year-on-year basis, despite the pandemic's impact. Four of its retail malls recovered to 94% of pre-pandemic levels. JUMBO Group opened two new food and beverage outlets in Singapore, allowing delivery and takeaway services. MEQUITY Hills, an associate of Roxy-Pacific Holdings, acquired a 999-year leasehold residential site for S$23 million.

site_title: Drag commodity traders out of the shadows
summary: The US Treasury eased sanctions on Israeli tycoon Dan Gertler in January, allowing him to profit from the Democratic Republic of Congo's mineral resources. However, the Biden administration reversed this decision in March, citing concerns over corruption. The incident shed light on the world of commodity traders, who wield significant influence over global markets and economies. Companies like Glencore, which dominated deals with Gertler, operate with little scrutiny, generating massive wealth for a few individuals while facing little accountability. Strong laws and regulations are needed to shed light on this powerful sector of the global economy.

site_title: Miss Mexico wins Miss Universe title in glitzy ceremony
summary: Miss Mexico, Andrea Meza, has been crowned Miss Universe 2021, beating 73 contestants in the pageant. The event, held in Florida, marked the return of the Miss Universe competition after last year's postponement due to the pandemic. Meza, 26, used her platform to advocate for female empowerment and activism, following in the footsteps of the pageant's recent shift towards these values. The competition also highlighted the struggles in Myanmar, with Miss Myanmar Thuzar Wint Lwin drawing attention to the country's military coup.

images.alt_text: Dressed in a sparkling red evening gown, Ms Meza tearfully walked the catwalk as Miss Universe for the first time, before rushing back for a group hug with the other competitors. She is the third woman from Mexico to win the title.
Miss Myanmar Thuzar Wint Lwin (above) made waves when she used her time in the spotlight to bring attention to the coup in her country.
Miss Singapore Bernadette Belle Ong (above) - who did not make the top 21 - also used the national costume portion to make a political statement amid a surge in anti-Asian violence in the US.

site_title: Malaysia mulls shutdown of richest state amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysia's health ministry considers imposing a total lockdown on the country's most industrialized state, Selangor, due to a surge in Covid-19 cases. The state has reported over 1,000 new cases daily since May 5, making up a quarter of national cases. If current measures are unable to contain the spread, a full lockdown could be considered, potentially impacting the state's significant contribution to Malaysia's economy and employment. The country's vaccination program is also criticized for being slow, with only 1.19 million people having received at least one dose so far.

site_title: Pandemic uncertainty clouds new private home sales sentiment
summary: Singapore's private home sales may fall to around 1,000 units or lower for the remaining eight months of 2021 due to pandemic uncertainty. Despite healthy demand, the pandemic continues to cloud the road to economic recovery. Analysts expect a prolonged spread of Covid-19 infections to moderate market activity, with some predicting a total of 10,000 new sales for the year. The market is taking a breather, with no launches planned in May and June, and virtual tours may help to mitigate the impact of reduced capacity in showflats.

site_title: Rich and famous converge on France's rose vineyards
summary: Wealthy individuals and luxury companies, such as LVMH, are investing in France's rose vineyards, a growing sector in the wine market. The region has seen a surge in demand, with prices increasing due to the influx of high-end buyers. A 78-year-old statistician, Jean-Louis Croquet, has sold his Chateau Thuerry vineyard to investors, citing "offers keep getting higher" despite his repeated denials of selling. The trend is expected to continue with the imminent arrival of American actor George Clooney.

site_title: Connecting the dots between digital maturity and financial performance
summary: Digital maturity has been linked to significant financial performance improvements among businesses. According to Deloitte's Digital Transformation 2020 report, companies identified as "well along the road to digital transformation" achieved revenue growth three times higher than those not rated as highly mature. Digital maturity brings benefits such as higher efficiency, improved product quality, and increased customer satisfaction, contributing to better financial performance. By embracing digital innovation and experimentation, businesses can drive growth, reduce costs, and increase workforce diversity, ultimately achieving their full potential.

site_title: Hot, drought-hit Taiwan hit by power cuts for second time in a week
summary: Taiwan experienced its second power outage in a week, affecting 660,000 homes on Monday due to a technical failure at a power plant and high demand amid a heatwave and drought. The outage, caused by insufficient hydropower generation, was expected to be phased out. The state-owned power company, Taipower, said 40% of the supply was restored by 8:40 pm. The power outage occurred amidst a record-high temperature of 40 degrees Celsius in parts of the island, which is experiencing an unusually hot May.

images.alt_text: Taiwan launched island-wide power cuts on Monday evening following a spike in demand amid a heatwave and drought and failure at a power plant, the second such outage in the global tech hub in a week.

site_title: JD Logistics launches HK IPO to raise up to US$3.4b
summary: JD Logistics, a logistics offshoot of JD.com, is launching an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong to raise up to US$3.4 billion, with a price range of HK$39.36 to HK$43.36 per share. The company will sell 609.1 million shares, representing 10% of its total shares, and has an over-allotment option to sell an additional 91 million shares. JD Logistics recorded a 64.1% revenue increase in the first quarter of 2021, but its gross profit decreased by 72.7%. The IPO is seen as a barometer of investor appetite for major share sales amid global equity market volatility.

site_title: India says 'minuscule' clotting cases after AstraZeneca vaccine
summary: India has reported 26 suspected cases of bleeding and clotting among recipients of the AstraZeneca vaccine, but the health ministry described the risk as "minuscule" out of 164 million doses administered. This is the first serious reaction to the vaccine in India, prompting concerns in some countries to suspend or restrict its use. Despite the risk, health experts say the vaccine's benefits outweigh its risks.

site_title: NIE student, NSF among 11 unlinked Covid-19 community cases
summary: Singapore reported 11 unlinked Covid-19 community cases, including a National Institute of Education student, a part-time tutor, and a full-time national serviceman. Ten patients were linked to previous cases, with one cluster at White Sands Shopping Mall in Pasir Ris now containing four cases. The Ministry of Health stated these cases are unlinked to each other, indicating no known transmission chain.

images.alt_text: There were 11 unlinked Covid-19 cases reported in the community on Monday (May 17). These include a student at the National Institute of Education who is also a part-time tutor, a full-time national serviceman (NSF) and a second student from Singapore Polytechnic.

site_title: World has entered stage of 'vaccine apartheid' says WHO head
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, stated that the world has entered a situation of "vaccine apartheid" due to a lack of sharing of COVID-19 vaccines. He called on manufacturers to make shots available to the Covax facility sooner, citing a supply shortfall caused by Indian export disruptions. This comes as the global vaccine distribution faces challenges, with some countries struggling to access vaccines.

site_title: SRA, Lazada to host Great Singapore Sale 2021 in omni-channel format
