summary: The Singapore Retailers Association (SRA) and e-commerce platform Lazada will host the Great Singapore Sale (GSS) 2021 in an omni-channel format from June 6 to July 7. Lazada will handle the online aspect, while SRA members can integrate their online and offline outlets. This partnership aims to provide customers with additional delivery options and pave the way for hybrid retail models. SRA members who join Lazada's platform will not be charged commission fees for three months to ease the transition to online sales.

site_title: Why SIA might report stronger q-o-q results for Q4
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) may report stronger quarterly results for Q4, driven by higher revenues from passengers and freight flown, as well as gains in fuel hedging. The airline group flew 25.9% more passengers and 22.5% more passenger-kilometres in Q4 FY2021 compared to the previous quarter. Passenger revenue is expected to reach S$224 million, while cargo revenue could reach S$759 million. Despite the challenges posed by the Covid-19 resurgence, SIA's top line is likely to be higher than its previous quarters, potentially making it the highest in the four quarters.

site_title: Is the honeymoon over for Biden?
summary: President Joe Biden is entering the post-honeymoon period of his presidency, facing challenges from US-China tensions, inflationary pressures, and the Middle East crisis. The economy is experiencing a labor shortage, leading to higher wages and inflation, despite administration officials' claims that a rapid recovery can create inflationary bumps. The Biden administration's spending plans are being met with opposition from Congressional Republicans, and the president is under pressure to address the growing tensions in the Middle East, where violence between Israelis and Palestinians threatens to escalate into a wider conflict.

images.alt_text: President Biden could find himself in a political no-win situation, being drawn into the mess in the Middle East while he is trying to make the economic recovery at home and the growing challenge from China his two main policy priorities.

site_title: World Economic Forum cancels meeting in Singapore; Shangri-La Dialogue organiser remains hopeful
summary: The World Economic Forum (WEF) has cancelled its special annual meeting in Singapore from August 17-20 due to the spike in Covid-19 community cases in the city-state. The decision was made in response to global uncertainties caused by the pandemic, including differing vaccination rollout speeds and uncertainty around new variants. The meeting, which would have brought together 1,000 global leaders, will now take place in the first half of 2022.

site_title: Brazil's Christ the Redeemer statue lights up for vaccine equality
summary: The Christ the Redeemer statue in Rio de Janeiro was lit up to promote vaccine equality in Brazil, where 17% of residents have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine and 8% are fully vaccinated. This comes as new cases of Covid-19 rise in the country, with 82% of peak infections in March. Brazil ranks 30th globally in vaccination efforts, far behind countries like Israel and the US. The event was organized by Unidos Pela Vacina in partnership with the Cristo Redentor Sanctuary and Ogilvy Brazil.

site_title: Angelina Jolie's Those Who Wish Me Dead DOA as Spiral claims No 1
summary: Angelina Jolie's survival action thriller "Those Who Wish Me Dead" underperformed at the US box office, earning $2.8 million in its opening weekend despite a hybrid release on HBO Max. The film's poor performance is attributed to the current market favoring family films and CGI spectacles, as well as mediocre reviews. In contrast, "Spiral" took the No 1 spot with $8.7 million, while "Army of the Dead" generated an estimated $800,000. Holdovers like "Wrath of Man" and new releases like "Demon Slayer: Mugen Train" and "Raya and the Last Dragon" rounded out the top five.

site_title: STI closes 0.81% higher despite return to Phase 2 (Heightened Alert)
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.81% to close at 3,079.69 points on Monday, despite the city-state going into heightened alert amid a fresh wave of infections. The benchmark index rose 24.67 points, with Sembcorp Industries being the best performer, up 4.2%. The STI has notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the broader market seeing 331 gainers outnumbering 144 losers.

site_title: UK sanctions Myanmar's state-owned gem enterprise
summary: The UK has imposed sanctions on the Myanmar Gems Enterprise (MGE), a state-owned enterprise overseeing the country's multi-billion dollar gem activities, in an effort to cut revenue for the ruling military junta. The move follows a similar action by the US and aims to deprive the junta of a key source of funding. The sanctions, which take effect immediately, prevent anyone from dealing with funds owned or controlled by the MGE in the UK. The UK has also announced sanctions against other military-linked conglomerates and called for further action, including a ban on imports of gems.

site_title: China to relax birth policy but wary of social risks
summary: China is considering relaxing its birth policies, but will tread carefully to avoid social risks. The country's population grew at its slowest in a decade, with a fertility rate of 1.3 children per woman, similar to Japan and Italy. Top leaders are working out a plan to encourage childbearing, including easing financial burdens on couples and raising the retirement age. The changes are expected to be gradual, with the goal of creating at least 10 million new urban jobs a year. China's main population challenge is not size, but ageing, which will put heavy pressure on government finances.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 0.94 points higher at 1,583.46 on Monday, with a total volume of 6.602 billion lots worth RM3.801 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,061 to 195.

site_title: Bankers flee Wall Street, head home to virus-free Australia
summary: Australians are returning home in record numbers, with over 25,000 people leaving the US, UK, and Hong Kong to settle in the country, driven by its successful COVID-19 response. The influx is boosting the property market and increasing applications for private school places in cities like Sydney. Many are drawn by the prospect of working in a relatively virus-free environment, with some former Wall Street bankers now joining Australian firms such as Jarden Securities and Barrenjoey Capital Partners. The trend is expected to continue, with Australia's economy benefiting from the return of talent.

site_title: 21 community infections among 28 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 28 new Covid-19 cases, including 21 in the community, as of May 17. Of the community cases, 11 are unlinked, while the remaining 10 are linked to previous cases. The new community patients include six who were already in quarantine. The total number of cases in Singapore has reached 61,613. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is also investigating a cluster linked to a Learning Point tuition centre and a cook at Wok Hey (White Sands) restaurant.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as inflation worries persist
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on Monday, falling 0.02-0.46% due to lingering concerns over inflationary pressures and potential monetary policy tightening. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened at 34,375.29, 4,169.92, and 13,368.80 respectively. Investors remain cautious despite a sharp recovery late last week, as signs of inflationary pressures continue to build in the economy.

site_title: Dubai eases Covid-19 restrictions, allows full hotel capacity
summary: Dubai has eased Covid-19 restrictions, allowing hotels to operate at full capacity and permitting concerts and sports events where attendees and participants are vaccinated. Social distancing and face masks remain mandatory, while capacities for restaurants and entertainment venues have increased. The decision comes as the UAE ranks highly globally for Covid-19 testing and vaccination rates.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's retail tenant group SGTUFF suggests that another partial lockdown may be better for the public and businesses than progressively tightening measures to curb the resurgence of Covid-19. The group argues that a lockdown could provide a more controlled environment to combat the spread of the virus, potentially reducing economic losses and stress on the public. This proposal comes as Singapore has been grappling with a 'zombie' situation, where the virus continues to spread despite measures in place.

images.alt_text: Crowds appeared significantly reduced inside and outside Lucky Plaza on Sunday afternoon.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong shares closed with gains on Monday, following a strong lead from Wall Street, extending a rally at the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.59% to 28,194.09, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also increased. Despite rising coronavirus numbers in Asia, traders remained optimistic.

site_title: Jumbo to open new F&B outlets for Tsui Wah and Kok Kee brands even as Covid-19 restrictions bite
summary: Jumbo Group announced plans to open two new food and beverage outlets for its Tsui Wah and Kok Kee brands in Singapore despite current Covid-19 restrictions. The new Tsui Wah outlet at Jem in Jurong East will offer delivery and takeaway services, while a second Kok Kee stall will open at Marina Bay Sands food court on May 18. This move is seen as a way to support F&B operators during the month-long ban on dining out, with the government providing wage support and rent waivers for affected establishments.

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust Q1 revenue up 87.4% despite Covid-19 impact
summary: Dasin Retail Trust's Q1 revenue rose 87.4% year-over-year, driven by China's 33.9% increase in retail sales, despite the Covid-19 pandemic's impact. Revenue from four of its retail malls recovered to 94% of pre-pandemic levels. The trust's gearing stands at 37.2%, with a focus on optimizing tenant mix and maintaining a healthy financial position. Its portfolio valuation is 11.6 billion yuan, and it has completed nine right-of-first-refusal projects and six under development.

site_title: Working 55 hours a week increases risk of death: UN
summary: A UN study by the World Health Organization and International Labor Organization found that working 55 hours a week increases the risk of death from heart disease and stroke, with an estimated 35% rise in stroke risk and 17% in ischemic heart disease risk compared to working 35-40 hours. The study, based on data from hundreds of thousands of participants, estimated that 398,000 people died from stroke and 347,000 from heart disease in 2016 after working at least 55 hours per week.

site_title: Global luxury sales could return to pre-Covid levels this year, Bain says
summary: Global luxury sales could return to pre-Covid levels this year, with a 30% probability, driven by Chinese and US shoppers, according to consultancy Bain. Luxury goods sales fell 23% in 2020, but have already recovered sharply in the first quarter of 2021. The US market has been a bright spot, while Europe lags behind due to slower vaccination and tourism restrictions. The industry is expected to make a full rebound in 2022, with handbags, leather goods, and jewelry driving the recovery, alongside spending on clothes and cosmetics.

site_title: Malaysia mulls shutdown of richest state amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Malaysia's health ministry considers shutting down the country's richest state, Selangor, amid a surge in Covid-19 cases, which may involve highly contagious variants. The government has imposed strict curbs, including banning social activities and travel, but may need to further restrict business activity if the situation worsens. Health Minister Adham Baba stated that the government will reassess the situation and consider a total lockdown if the current measures are ineffective. The move aims to curb the spread of the virus and protect public health.

site_title: Deals of the week: GoTo finally gets to merger; an eye for AI
summary: GoTo Group, formed by the merger of Indonesian tech giants Gojek and Tokopedia, has completed its long-awaited merger. Impress.ai, a startup specializing in AI recruitment solutions, secured S$4 million in pre-Series A funding to expand into new markets and accelerate product development. Renowned investor Jim Rogers joined the board of Singapore-based foodtech company Life3 Biotech, highlighting the growing demand for plant-based protein alternatives.

site_title: Thailand to face setbacks to recovery in Q2: report
summary: Thailand's GDP contracted 2.6% in Q1, outperforming expectations but facing setbacks in Q2 due to a surge in COVID-19 infections. A report from Oxford Economics predicts a 2.8% GDP growth for the year, but Q2 prospects are hindered by a third wave of infections. The country has over 80,000 cases and 589 deaths, with a third of cases occurring in April. Social distancing measures are expected to hit business confidence and household consumption, and a stricter lockdown could delay the opening of tourist destinations.

site_title: Covid is airborne, scientists say; now authorities think so too
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) have acknowledged that COVID-19 can spread through the air, a shift in perspective that comes with significant implications for indoor air quality and public health. Researchers are calling for improved ventilation systems, similar to those used for public water supplies, to prevent the spread of airborne pathogens. The study's authors argue that upgrading ventilation and filtration in buildings could offset the cost of implementing these changes, potentially saving billions of dollars in productivity losses and healthcare costs.

site_title: EU, US reach truce on metal tariffs ahead of Biden visit
summary: The European Union and US have reached a truce on metal tariffs ahead of US President Joe Biden's visit to Brussels, where they will discuss trade cooperation. The EU will refrain from increasing tariffs on US products, including bourbon whiskey and Harley Davidson motorbikes, which were set to double to 50% on June 1. The agreement aims to resolve the 2018 dispute over national security and tackle global steel and aluminum excess capacity. The truce is seen as a gesture of goodwill to repair ties between the EU and US, with talks to suspend the duties altogether expected to continue.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific associate acquires a 999-year leasehold residential site for S$23m
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' associate, Mequity Hills, has acquired a 999-year leasehold residential site at 11 Institution Hill for S$23 million. The site has an estimated land area of 5,539 sq ft and a plot ratio of 2.8 under the 2019 Master Plan. The acquisition is expected to be financed by internal funding and bank borrowings, with no material impact on the group's earnings and net tangible assets. Mequity Hills will amalgamate the site with another 999-year leasehold site at 10A and 10B Institution Hill for residential development.

site_title: Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble bursts again, spiked by rising Covid-19 cases in Republic
summary: The Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble has been suspended for the second time due to rising Covid-19 cases in Singapore. The seven-day moving average of unlinked cases exceeded the threshold of five, prompting the decision not to proceed with the bilateral quarantine-free travel arrangement. The bubble was initially set to launch on May 26 but will now be reassessed at the end of Phase 2 in Singapore, with a new launch date uncertain. This decision comes after a spike in cases in Singapore and Hong Kong, prompting tightened safe management measures and airport closures.

images.alt_text: The two governments decided not to proceed with the bilateral quarantine-free travel arrangement. This decision comes about 10 days before the relaunch on May 26, Singapore's Ministry of Transport said in a statement on Monday.

site_title: Lessons from the circuit breaker
summary: Singapore's economy has shown resilience in the face of the pandemic, with some businesses adapting to stay afloat. Digital readiness, online sales, and innovative services have been key factors in their success. Examples include Far East Flora's online gardening sales, Lunch Actually's virtual dating services, and Cicheti's island-wide delivery and reheatable pizza. Strategic planning and diversification have also helped businesses like SF Group and Top International Holding emerge unscathed. While Covid-19 restrictions are temporary, businesses must remain nimble and innovative to overcome economic challenges.

site_title: China bars foreign curricula, ownership in some private schools
summary: China has introduced new regulations for private schools, banning foreign curricula and ownership from kindergarten to grade nine (K-9) by September 1. The Private Education Promotion Law requires school boards to be composed of Chinese nationals, including regulators, and prohibits private K-9 schools from organizing entrance tests and recruiting in advance. The measures aim to ease pressure on school children and boost the country's birth rate by lowering family living costs. The regulations are expected to challenge the revenues and profits of private K-12 players, according to a research note by US bank Citi.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on gold, energy boost
summary: Australian shares ended 0.1% higher, driven by gains in gold stocks and energy companies after the government funded their refineries. Gold stocks rose 4.3%, with Newcrest Mining reaching its highest level in nearly a month. Energy stocks also jumped 1%, led by Ampol Ltd and Viva Energy, which benefited from the government's US$1.8 billion funding. New Zealand's benchmark index snapped an eight-day losing streak, ending 0.3% higher.

site_title: Thai banks strong, can weather economic uncertainty: central bank
summary: Thailand's banking system remains resilient due to high capital buffers and liquidity, able to weather economic uncertainty caused by a third wave of coronavirus infections. Loan growth slowed to 3.8% in the first quarter, with corporate loans growing 3% and consumer loans increasing 5.3%. Non-performing loans remained stable at 3.1%. The central bank is monitoring the situation and is ready to implement measures if needed, particularly in the tourism sector. Debt relief measures for smaller debtors have been extended until the end of the year.

site_title: China takes Covid-19 controls to Everest with climber ban
summary: China has banned attempts to scale Mount Everest from its side due to concerns of Covid-19 infection from climbers starting in Nepal, where the pandemic is raging. The decision, made by the China Sports Administration, comes as China has largely contained the disease with strict border controls. With borders closed since March 2020, China fears a rebound of infections could emerge from abroad, prompting the cancellation of all climbing activities. A "separation line" was previously proposed to protect against coronavirus on the summit.

site_title: Ryanair 'upset' with Boeing, fears no MAX deliveries before summer
summary: Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost carrier, is "quite upset" with Boeing over delays in delivering its 737 MAX aircraft. Initially expected to receive 16 planes by summer, Ryanair now fears no deliveries before summer 2021 due to production issues. The airline believes the problems will resolve in the medium term and is in talks with Boeing about a significant order of the MAX 10 aircraft. Ryanair aims to have 60 of the aircraft in place by summer 2022.

site_title: London house-price premium at 8-year low as buyers look to North
summary: The UK property market is experiencing a shift as buyers in London are seeking bargains in northern England due to the pandemic-induced "race for space". Asking prices for homes in Wales, northwest England, and Yorkshire have surged by over 10% since the pandemic began, narrowing the gap with London house prices to its lowest level since 2013. This trend suggests the housing market has sufficient momentum to withstand the planned withdrawal of Chancellor Rishi Sunak's tax cut on home purchases.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades Sheng Siong to 'trading buy' on grocery activity pick-up
summary: RHB upgraded Sheng Siong to "trading buy" with a raised target price of S$1.95 due to expected increased grocery shopping activities amid Singapore's Phase Two restrictions. The research team forecasts sales to climb in the May-June period and increased profit. However, new store openings are likely to be delayed due to construction delays and job backlogs. Shares of Sheng Siong were trading 2.4% lower at S$1.62 following the announcement.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower as virus spikes across Asia spur caution
summary: South Korean stocks closed lower on Monday, down 0.60% at 3,134.52, as investor sentiment was dented by rising Covid-19 cases in Taiwan and Singapore. Technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix fell 0.62% and 0.84%, respectively. Foreigners sold $528.66 million worth of shares, contributing to the decline. Despite a 9.08% year-to-date gain, the Kospi has faced caution due to regional concerns.

site_title: End of wind power waste? Vestas unveils blade recycling technology
summary: Vestas has unveiled a technology to recycle wind turbine blades, reducing waste and landfill disposal. The technology separates glass or carbon fibre from epoxy resin, then breaks down the resin into base materials similar to virgin materials. The goal is to achieve industrial-scale production within three years, with potential applications in airplane and car components. This innovation addresses 43 million tonnes of waste expected in 2050, according to a 2017 study.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank KE raises ThaiBev target price on post-Covid recovery prospects
summary: Maybank KE has raised its target price for ThaiBev to S$0.99, citing a post-Covid recovery prospects and the company's stable spirits segment sales. The research house also raised FY2021-2023 estimates by 4% after ThaiBev's H1 earnings exceeded expectations. Analysts from Maybank and UOB Kay Hian maintain a "buy" call on the stock, while CGS-CIMB lowered its target price to S$0.84 due to concerns over near-term revenue growth and operating margins. ThaiBev's shares were trading 3% higher at S$0.69.

site_title: Lockdown may be better than current 'zombie' situation: SGTUFF
summary: Singapore's retail industry may benefit from a partial lockdown, or 'circuit breaker', instead of progressive tightening of measures to curb Covid-19, a retail tenant group said. The group, Singapore Tenants United For Fairness, polled 150 members and found that 86% plan to close shops or lay off staff due to the current restrictions. Retailers are struggling with 45% experiencing an 80% drop in sales, and 36% seeing a 50-80% drop. The group is seeking support measures, including increased wage support and rent relief, to help retailers recover.

site_title: Gojek, Tokopedia complete merger to form GoTo
summary: Indonesian tech giants Gojek and Tokopedia have completed a merger to form GoTo Group, specializing in e-commerce, on-demand services, and financial services. The combined group has a gross transaction value of over $22 billion and 11 million merchant partners. GoTo will be headed by Gojek's co-CEO Andre Soelistyo, while Tokopedia's president Patrick Cao will serve as GoTo's president. The merger is the largest-ever business combination in Indonesia and the largest between two Asia-based Internet media and services companies.

site_title: Sias 'seriously concerned' over Sakae audit disputes, calls for internal reporting to AC
summary: Sias, the Securities Investors Association of Singapore, has expressed concern over Sakae Holdings' internal audit disputes, calling for the company to implement all internal control recommendations. Despite a disclaimer of opinion by Deloitte & Touche for Sakae's FY2019 accounts, the Singapore Exchange Regulation flagged erroneous accounting entries and internal control weaknesses. Sias recommends Sakae's internal audit function be performed by independent professional service providers reporting directly to the audit committee, emphasizing the importance of corporate governance and transparency.

site_title: UK proposes to phase in new Irish Sea border checks on food products: BBC
summary: The UK is proposing to introduce new Irish Sea border checks on food products in four stages from October, as part of implementing the Brexit deal. The checks will target goods moving from mainland Britain to Northern Ireland, which now borders the EU via Ireland. This move aims to prevent the reintroduction of tariffs and checks that were previously in place. The plan aims to maintain unfettered trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. The UK had promised no hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland following Brexit.

site_title: Japan refiners to sell assets, rush reform as pandemic dents demand
summary: Japan's top refiner Eneos Holdings and second-ranked Idemitsu Kosan plan to sell assets and accelerate structural reform as fuel demand is expected to fall due to the prolonged COVID-19 pandemic and global decarbonization trend. The companies downgraded their profit goals and will shift away from coal and oil to renewable energy and cleaner fuels. Eneos will exit coal mining and downsize its upstream oil assets, while Idemitsu will focus on low-carbon fuels and expand renewable energy projects. Both companies aim to become carbon neutral by 2030.

site_title: ARA partners SMBC after raising US$500m equity funds
summary: ARA Asset Management has raised $500 million in equity financing led by Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation (SMBC), becoming the company's new strategic shareholder. ARA aims to strengthen its core business and expand into new sectors such as logistics and data centers. The company expects to leverage growing real estate investment trusts and alternative asset markets in the Asia-Pacific region, predicting rapid proliferation of listed Reits in new markets like India, China, and South Korea.

site_title: High Street Centre makes second attempt at collective sale with S$800m reserve price
summary: High Street Centre, a 30-storey mixed-use tower in Singapore, has been put up for sale via a second public tender with a reserve price of S$800 million. The site, located on 1 North Bridge Road, has a total gross floor area of 43,300.72 sq m and an allowable gross plot ratio of 7.72. The property consultant Cushman & Wakefield expects the site to attract developers for commercial use, with the potential for a mix of office, retail, and hotel spaces. The land rate works out to about S$2,257 to S$2,439 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: High Street Centre, a mixed-use tower at 1 North Bridge Road, has been put up for sale via a second public tender.

site_title: China offers banks nearly S$20b to maintain liquidity
summary: China's central bank injected S$20.7 billion into the financial system through a medium-term lending facility, aiming to maintain stable borrowing costs as the economy recovers. The People's Bank of China kept interest rates unchanged at 2.95% and supported liquidity-sensitive stocks and bonds. This move eased concerns about further tightening of fiscal and monetary policies, with China's economic activity moderating in April. The benchmark CSI 300 Index rose 1.8% following the injection, driven by ample liquidity and capital inflows.

site_title: Europe: Stocks up at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets rose slightly at the open on Monday, driven by gains in mining and healthcare shares. London's FTSE 100 index increased 0.2% to 7,057.64 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 also rose 0.2% each. The mixed Asian market performance and rising inflation concerns contributed to the slight gains.

site_title: Built environment sector appeals for entry of foreign workers, more relief measures
summary: The Construction Industry Joint Committee (CIJC) in Singapore has appealed to the government to allow the entry of foreign workers from China, India, and Bangladesh, citing a severe manpower shortage in the sector. The committee argues that the current border restrictions have led to a "very limited inflow and high outflow" of workers, causing contractors to poach workers, which is "unhealthy for the industry." CIJC also requests additional relief measures to help stakeholders cope with the challenges posed by tightened border measures, which could lead to job losses and project delays if not addressed.

site_title: April's new private homes sales eased to 1,262
summary: Singapore's private homes sales eased to 1,262 units in April, down 2.6% from March, according to the Urban Redevelopment Authority. Despite the decrease, sales reached 1,342 units when including executive condominiums. The majority of sales came from two new launches, with Irwell Hill Residences and One-North Eden selling 85.5% and 60% of their units, respectively. Experts expect monthly sales to fall below 1,000 units in the rest of 2021 due to the ongoing Phase 2 restrictions, but slower sales may prevent policy measures to cool the market.

site_title: Australia to pay last two oil refineries up to US$1.8b to stay open
summary: Australia has agreed to pay up to $1.8 billion to keep its last two oil refineries, owned by Ampol Ltd and Viva Energy Group, open until 2030. The package includes $125 million each to upgrade the refineries to produce ultra-low sulfur petrol, saving 1,250 jobs. The move aims to secure Australia's fuel security and protect the country's refining capacity, with the refineries committed to stay open until at least 2027.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares drop as coronavirus infections weigh on sentiment
summary: Japanese shares fell 0.92% to close at 27,824.83 on Monday, weighed down by concerns over the slow pace of domestic vaccination efforts. Despite a boost from solid gains on Wall Street, the market was overwhelmed by negative sentiment. Analysts attributed the decline to unique Japanese market factors, citing the lack of correlation between tech shares and the Nasdaq's higher finish on Friday.

site_title: JD Logistics seeks up to S$4.54b in Hong Kong IPO
summary: JD Logistics Inc, the delivery arm of JD.com Inc, is seeking up to S$4.54 billion in its Hong Kong initial public offering. The company, which operates over 900 warehouses across China, plans to use the proceeds to upgrade and expand its logistics networks. JD Logistics has attracted seven cornerstone investors, including SoftBank Vision Fund and Temasek Holdings, to its offering. The IPO is expected to begin trading on May 28 and is the second-largest in Hong Kong this year, following Kuaishou Technology's US$6.2 billion listing in February.

site_title: Sanofi, GSK say Covid-19 vaccine shows positive result
summary: Sanofi and GSK reported positive results from their Covid-19 vaccine, with strong immune responses observed in a Phase 2 study. The vaccine achieved rates of neutralizing antibody responses comparable to those in people who have recovered from Covid-19, across all adult age groups. The companies plan to move to a late-stage trial and expect a global pivotal Phase 3 study to start in the coming weeks, with a potential vaccine ready by the end of 2021. This reversal follows a setback in their research last year, and the companies believe the vaccine has the potential to play a role in addressing the global public health crisis.

images.alt_text: French pharmaceuticals giant Sanofi and Britain's GSK reported on Monday "strong immune responses" in early tests of their Covid-19 vaccine, raising hopes it could join the fight against the pandemic.

site_title: 'Virtually unlimited Singapore': Five recommendations of the Emerging Stronger Taskforce
summary: The Emerging Stronger Taskforce's report, accepted by the Future Economy Council, outlines five key recommendations for Singapore's post-Covid-19 economy. The taskforce suggests creating virtual frontiers through digitalisation, positioning Singapore as a carbon trading hub, growing "global champions" and a strong local workforce, institutionalising public-private partnerships, and strengthening international partnerships, particularly in South-east Asia. These recommendations aim to drive industry transformation, sustainability, and partnerships, marking the beginning of Singapore's journey towards a "Virtually Unlimited Singapore."

site_title: Frontline staff at Bangkok hospital brace for new Covid-19 cases
summary: Frontline staff at Bangkok's King Chulalongkorn Memorial Hospital are bracing for new Covid-19 cases as Thailand struggles with its worst wave of infections. Over 1,200 patients are being treated in critical condition, with 408 on ventilators. Staff, including nurses and doctors, are taking precautions, with some even stopping family visits due to the risk of infection. Thailand has administered 2.2 million vaccine doses and plans to expand vaccination efforts in June. Healthcare workers are urging the public to follow social distancing rules until the pandemic is over.

images.alt_text: As Thailand struggles to deal with its worst wave of coronavirus infections, staff in the intensive care unit of Bangkok's King Chulalongkorn Memorial Hospital are fearful of what may be to come.

site_title: Miss Mexico crowned Miss Universe
summary: Miss Mexico, Andrea Meza, was crowned Miss Universe on Sunday in Florida, finishing ahead of Brazilian and Peruvian finalists. Meza, 26, used her platform to bring attention to the ongoing military coup in Myanmar, where fellow contestant Thuzar Wint Lwin drew attention to the crisis. The 69th Miss Universe pageant marked the competition's return to television after the 2020 pandemic postponement.

site_title: India's oil demand shrinks further as virus crisis persists
summary: India's oil demand declined further in May due to local lockdowns to combat the Covid-19 pandemic. Road transport fuel sales dropped by 20% from the previous month and 28% from 2019. Gasoline sales fell to a one-year low, and diesel sales plummeted to a seven-month low. The decline in consumption is expected to weigh on oil prices and dampen global demand expectations. India's health system is strained, with over 300,000 daily infections, and the country's fuel sales and crude processing are curtailed to manage stockpiles.

site_title: Wife of Belgian envoy to Seoul invokes immunity over assault
summary: Belgium's ambassador to South Korea, Peter Lescouhier, will not face charges due to his wife's diplomatic immunity. The wife allegedly assaulted two boutique staff over shoplifting, with CCTV footage showing her hitting them in the head and slapping another employee. The Belgian embassy has expressed its intention to maintain the ambassador's wife's immunity, citing the Vienna Convention. Police will not pursue the case, citing South Korea's agreement to the convention, which grants diplomats and their families immunity from criminal prosecution. The incident has sparked public anger and criticism of diplomatic immunity.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks up at Monday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose on Monday, extending their rally at the end of last week, with the Hang Seng Index increasing 0.37% to 28,130.51. The rally followed strong leads from Wall Street and Europe. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw minor gains. This comes as investors continue to brush off new US threats, with stocks in Asia and Europe also performing well.

site_title: Hong Kong's Lai to plead guilty in protest case; assets frozen
summary: Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai, along with eight others, will plead guilty to organising and attending an unauthorised assembly in 2019. Lai faces additional charges under China's national security law, including asset freezes. Authorities have frozen shares of his Next Digital Ltd and local bank accounts, marking the first time the security law has been used to freeze a major investor's shares. This move has sparked concerns among the business community, with over 40% of surveyed members considering leaving the city.

site_title: 'Through the looking glass': How conspiracy theories wreck lives
summary: Conspiracy theories are spreading rapidly online, causing real-life harm to individuals and families. A US forum, QAnon Casualties, has over 150,000 members whose loved ones believe in QAnon, a movement claiming former US president Donald Trump is leading a secret war against Satan-worshipping paedophiles. Experts say conspiracy theories spread when people feel lied to and offer an explanatory software designating heroes and villains, often amplifying existing prejudices. Those affected often become isolated and cut off from society, with few returning to reality.

images.alt_text: Conspiracy theories are spreading fast on the internet, with very real consequences offline.

site_title: Over 80 per cent of Japanese oppose Olympics this summer: poll
summary: A recent poll in Japan found that over 80% of the population opposes hosting the postponed Olympics this summer, just under 10 weeks away. The surge in COVID-19 infections has put pressure on the country's healthcare system, leading medical professionals to warn about shortages and burnout. The poll comes as Japan expanded a coronavirus state of emergency.

site_title: UK firms seek staff after lockdown but foreign workers missing: survey
summary: British businesses are seeking new staff as lockdown restrictions in England are lifted, but a shortage of candidates persists, with over 10 job openings for every job-seeker in some cities. A survey by Adzuna found that job adverts increased by 18% in the first week of May, but foreign workers are in short supply due to reduced interest from western Europe and North America. The shortage is also affecting hospitality firms in the US and Australia, with a feared surge in job losses averted due to a public jobs subsidy scheme.

site_title: Free at last to hug and party: UK reopens for business
summary: The UK has reopened for business after a four-month Covid-19 lockdown, allowing 65 million people to hug, drink, and visit public places. Gatherings of up to 30 people will be allowed outdoors, and cafes, bars, and restaurants will reopen for indoor service. However, Prime Minister Boris Johnson has cautioned against excessive behavior due to the spread of a more transmissible coronavirus variant. The UK's official death toll stands at 127,679, and the economy suffered its worst decline in three centuries.

images.alt_text: Friends will hug, pints will be pulled and swathes of the British economy will reopen on Monday giving 65 million people a measure of freedom after the gloom of a four-month Covid-19 lockdown.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders weigh recovery and new infections
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Monday as optimism about the global recovery was offset by concerns over new coronavirus infections. Despite a strong lead from Wall Street, which reported flat US retail sales, consumer confidence fell due to rising prices, indicating inflation concerns. The release of minutes from the Fed's policy meeting will be closely watched for insights on inflation. Markets were also affected by a sharp decline in Tokyo and Singapore due to government efforts to contain new cases.

site_title: European climate group says EU needs far tougher van CO2 targets
summary: A European climate group, Transport and Environment, urges the EU to set tougher CO2 targets for commercial vans to phase out fossil-fuel sales by 2035. The group claims the current targets are too weak, allowing manufacturers to meet them without selling zero-emission vans. They recommend bringing forward the 2027 reduction target to 2027 and aiming for a 60% reduction by 2030, with a 100% CO2 reduction target by 2035. Electric van sales currently account for only 2% of the market, while EU sales of electric and hybrid passenger cars nearly tripled last year.

site_title: Singapore businessman Ng Yu Zhi faces seven new counts of cheating involving over S$23m
summary: Singaporean businessman Ng Yu Zhi, 34, has been charged with seven more counts of cheating involving over S$23 million. The allegations involve duping seven parties into purchasing fake receivables related to nickel trading. Ng, who was previously charged with 11 counts, now faces 18 counts of cheating, fraudulent trading, and forgery. If convicted, he could face up to 10 years in jail and fines of up to S$15,000 for each count of cheating. Investigations against him are ongoing, with his case set to be heard again on June 28.

site_title: Thailand Q1 slump eases, outlook cut as Covid-19 woes linger
summary: Thailand's economy shrank 2.6% in the first quarter of 2021, less than expected, due to coronavirus outbreaks hurting consumption and tourism. The country's GDP rose 0.2% on a quarterly basis, beating forecasts. The National Economic and Social Development Council downgraded its economic growth outlook to 1.5-2.5% due to the latest wave of infections. Despite stronger non-agricultural output and exports, the government expects just half a million foreign tourists this year, down from 3.2 million earlier. A relief package worth 255 billion baht was approved to help people cope with the outbreak.

site_title: Hong Kong's old boys club is living on borrowed time
summary: Hong Kong's corporate boards, traditionally all-male, are facing new rules that will require at least one woman director by the end of the year. The move aims to boost the city's status as an international financial center, which trails behind London and New York in terms of gender diversity. The proposed rules, set by the Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing, will give companies a three-year transition period to comply. The change is seen as a step forward, but advocates for greater diversity argue that quotas may be necessary to address the issue, with some suggesting a 40% female quota within six years.

site_title: StashAway launches group term life insurance plan
summary: StashAway, a Singapore-based robo-advisor, has launched a group term life insurance policy, StashAway Term Life, underwritten by Prudential Singapore. The policy is fully digital, renewable annually, and offers coverage ranging from S$100,000 to S$500,000. Clients can apply online with no in-person medical check required. The addition of this policy is part of StashAway's broader plans to become an "all-in-one" wealth management platform, offering affordable and transparent financial products.

site_title: Singapore NODX up 6.0% in April, but growth lags expansion in March
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 6.0% year-over-year in April, marking the fifth consecutive month of growth, but underperforming against analyst expectations of 11.5%. The growth was driven mainly by non-electronics, with electronics also increasing. This signals a potential downward trend from the 11.5% growth in March.

images.alt_text: Singapore exports grew in April from the same period last year, reflecting a general growth this year, but signalled a downward growth trend from March.

site_title: Microsoft conducted probe into Gates' affair with employee
summary: Microsoft conducted an investigation into Bill Gates' alleged affair with an employee in 2000, following a 2019 report of the incident. The board reviewed the matter with an external law firm, but Gates stepped down before the investigation was completed. Microsoft deemed Gates' involvement with the employee to be inappropriate, but did not reach a conclusion due to his departure. The investigation occurred during a time of heightened discussion about the treatment of women and Me-Too conversations in the industry, and amid other controversies surrounding Gates, including his dealings with Jeffrey Epstein.

site_title: Citi appoints Lee Lung Nien to head private bank in South Asia
summary: Citi appoints Lee Lung Nien as head of its private bank in South Asia, with responsibility for Singapore and Malaysia markets. Lee, a 30-year Citi veteran, will oversee talent, network, and product platform to serve clients across South Asia, a key growth area for the private banking arm. This move comes as the bank focuses on wealth hubs, including Singapore, and exits consumer markets in Asia-Pacific. Lee's appointment aims to capitalize on the region's potential, driven by entrepreneurship, developing capital markets, and a welcoming environment for family offices.

site_title: Australia: Energy, gold stocks push shares higher
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.4% to 7,038.5 points, driven by gold stocks and energy companies after the government announced A$2.3 billion in support to keep refineries open. Gold stocks gained 4.1% and energy stocks rose 2.1%, with Ampol and Viva Energy being the top gainers. The rebound in US Wall Street indexes also aided sentiment.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares rise at Monday's open
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.90 points or 0.37% to 1,588.42 on Monday, with 592.74 million lots traded worth RM258.67 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 388 to 180.

site_title: Australia's Crown says Blackstone offer undervalues company
summary: Crown Resorts in Australia has rejected a takeover offer from US private equity giant Blackstone Group Inc, citing uncertainty around regulatory approval conditions. The company stated that the offer undervalued it and would not be in the best interest of its shareholders. Crown's decision comes after Blackstone's approach, and the company will continue to explore other options.

site_title: Taiwan reassures on economy as stocks fall amid Covid-19 spike
summary: Taiwan's Premier Su Tseng-chang reassured the public that the country's economy remains strong despite a recent spike in domestic Covid-19 infections. The government is prepared to stabilize the stock and foreign exchange markets if needed. The economy has been driven by strong demand for export orders and normal production activities. The stock market fell 3% initially but recovered, with analysts noting that panic has not set in. Schools in Taipei will teach online until May 28, and the central bank will hold virtual news conferences. The government aims to maintain economic stability.

site_title: Singapore shares open weaker as stricter curbs take effect; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.6% on Monday, led by a decline in the Straits Times Index (STI) as stricter COVID-19 curbs took effect, including a ban on dining-in and reduced capacity limits. The curbs also prompted all students to shift to full home-based learning. Banking stocks also fell, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC declining 1.6%, 1.4%, and 0.5% respectively. The decline followed a rebound in US and European stocks on Friday, despite disappointing economic data.

site_title: Stocks to watch: First Resources, Aspen, Frasers Centrepoint Trust, ThaiBev, ST Group Food, Olam
summary: Stocks to watch: Several companies reported developments that may impact trading, including First Resources, which posted a net profit of US$8.8 million for the first quarter, down 60.5% from last year. Aspen's CFO is stepping down, while ThaiBev reported a 19.7% increase in second-quarter net profit. Olam Holdings BV secured a US$1 billion loan to finance the acquisition of US spice maker Olde Thompson. Other companies, such as Straco and Jiutian Chemical, also reported earnings and dividend declarations.

site_title: China's recovery comes off boil as consumer spending lags
summary: China's economic activity slowed in April, with retail sales missing forecasts at 17.7% growth, compared to a projected 25%. Industrial output rose 9.8% and fixed-asset investment grew 19.9% in the first four months of the year. The unemployment rate remained at 5.1%. Despite stabilization, China's economy faces challenges from the pandemic and a fragile recovery, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: UK confident vaccines protect against Indian variant
summary: The UK is confident that existing vaccines will provide protection against the Indian coronavirus variant, according to Heath Secretary Matt Hancock. The country has seen a rapid deployment of vaccines, with over 20 million adults vaccinated with two doses. Hancock defended the government's response to the variant, stating that the UK was "completely wrong" to impose travel restrictions on India earlier. The government plans to unlock parts of the economy on Monday, but further steps are uncertain due to the high transmissibility of the Indian variant.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, extending gains on Wall Street as US inflation worries ease. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.67% or 188.20 points to 28,272.67, while the Topix index gained 0.73% or 13.70 points to 1,897.12. This follows a strong rally on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Oil edges lower as Covid-19 restrictions in Asia fuel demand concerns
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Monday as the recovery of a US pipeline network and easing petrol shortages in the US East Coast alleviated supply concerns. However, new Covid-19 restrictions in Asia, including lockdowns in India and school closures in Singapore, fueled fears of lower demand. Brent crude oil futures fell 8 cents to $68.63 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude fell 7 cents to $65.30 a barrel. Analysts expect oil prices to remain in a trading range this week, with support at around $63 a barrel.

site_title: SingPost banks on e-commerce as Covid-19 hits other business segments
summary: SingPost's CEO Paul Coutts remains optimistic about the company's future despite a 47.7% drop in full-year net profit due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The company is focusing on e-commerce, which Coutts believes will help fill the gap created by the loss of international post and parcel business. SingPost is aggressively driving its e-commerce market share and investing in automation to reduce costs. Coutts views competition from logistics startups and government-owned services as a positive development, as it can help grow the market overall.

site_title: Bitcoin price lower after Musk tweet
summary: Bitcoin's price dropped below $45,000 on Sunday after Tesla CEO Elon Musk responded to an unverified tweet suggesting the company may have sold its bitcoin holdings. Musk replied "indeed" without confirming the sale. The tweet sparked criticism against Musk, leading some to speculate Tesla may have dumped its bitcoin holdings. The price drop was seen as a reaction to Musk's tweet, although the company's actual bitcoin holdings remain unclear.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust is committed to providing rental and operating assistance to its retail tenants amid Singapore's tightened Covid-19 measures until June 13. The trust has provided over S$70 million in rental rebates to eligible tenants since the pandemic start. In contrast, ST Group Food Industries' joint venture partner, Papparich Group Sdn Bhd, was ordered to wind up by the High Court of Malaya. BEST World International has secured a 120-day extension to hold its FY2020 AGM and lodge its annual return.

site_title: Saudi foreign minister, US's Blinken discuss developments in Palestine
summary: Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister Prince Faisal bin Farhan Al Saud held a phone call with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken to discuss developments in Palestine and the region. They reviewed strategic relations and ways to boost them, focusing on calming tensions in Israel and the West Bank and Gaza. The US Secretary of State expressed concern over the loss of lives and urged engagement to prevent a crisis, while also discussing bolstering Saudi defenses, a ceasefire, and progress on human rights in Yemen.

site_title: UK house prices boom outside of London: Rightmove
summary: UK house prices rose 1.8% over the past month, driven by sellers taking advantage of a tax break on property sales. Prices are now 6.7% higher than in March 2020, with regional differences seen. London prices rose 0.2%, while Wales saw a 13.0% increase. The UK's property market has defied predictions, with many richer Britons seeking larger homes for remote work. The tax break, extended by finance minister Rishi Sunak, will remain in full until June and at a reduced level until September.

site_title: French appeal set for convicted Russian money launderer
summary: Russian money launderer Alexander Vinnik, convicted of money laundering, is set to appeal a Paris court decision acquitting him of 13 cyber piracy charges. Vinnik, 41, was sentenced to 5 years in jail for money laundering but cleared of 13 charges of cyber piracy. Prosecutors claim he masterminded massive ransomware attacks, including the Locky ransomware attacks that affected 5,700 people worldwide, resulting in $217.2 million in losses. Vinnik's lawyers say he is innocent and aims to "shed light on his innocence" during the appeal.

site_title: Challenges faced by Chinese firms and Singapore's unique role
summary: Chinese firms face challenges in expanding to ASEAN, including cultural differences, language barriers, and concerns over job displacement. In Singapore, Chinese investments have largely come from the technology sector, with companies such as Tencent and Alibaba setting up regional headquarters. Despite these challenges, Singapore's unique blend of East and West, stable political environment, and financial system make it an attractive base for growing Chinese presence in the region.

site_title: Econ Healthcare's first nursing home in China commences operations
summary: Econ Healthcare's first nursing home in China, a 44-bed ECON Medicare Centre and Nursing Home - Chongqing, has commenced operations as a joint-venture project with Chongqing Guangda Bailingbang Eldercare Industry. The facility, located in Chongqing, features technology and innovation such as an automated robotic kitchen and intelligent eldercare panel. The project serves as a model for future nursing homes and is expected to have minimal impact on Econ Healthcare's earnings per share and net tangible assets per share. The company's shares rose 8.3% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: The 44-bed ECON Medicare Centre and Nursing Home - Chongqing is located in the Jiefangbei area, the central business district of Yuzhong District in Chongqing.

site_title: UN General Assembly to consider call for Myanmar arms embargo
summary: The UN General Assembly is set to consider a draft non-binding resolution calling for an immediate suspension of arms transfers to Myanmar's military junta. The resolution, introduced by Liechtenstein with support from the European Union, Britain, and the US, aims to halt the transfer of weapons and military equipment. The measure, co-sponsored by 48 countries, also calls for the military to end the state of emergency, release detained leaders, and allow humanitarian access. A vote is expected if consensus cannot be reached by consensus.

site_title: Iceland property with active volcano goes on the market
summary: Icelandic property owners are selling a plot of land with an active volcano, with at least two offers received amid interest in developing the site for tourism. The land, known as Hraun, has been owned by the same family for generations and has become a popular destination since a volcano emerged in March. The government has allocated funds to build infrastructure and ensure public access to the site, and potential buyers will not be allowed to limit access unless safety is compromised.

site_title: Construction for Aspen's ongoing developments to be 'affected slightly' by MCO 3.0
summary: Aspen's ongoing developments in Malaysia, including Vivo Executive Apartment and Viluxe, will be slightly affected by Malaysia's Movement Control Order (MCO 3.0) from May 12 to June 7. The company will take advantage of government incentives and launch four projects in H2 2021, including a new residential development and a high-rise development. Aspen's glove-making subsidiary, Aspen Glove, has commenced production and is on track to meet contractual obligations, with full production capacity expected by Q1 2022.

site_title: US dollar lower after weak data, and as inflation fears ease
summary: The US dollar declined against major currencies, falling 0.5% to 90.317, following weak retail sales data and concerns about accelerating inflation easing. Despite a surge in consumer prices, the Federal Reserve's pledge to keep interest rates low may have reduced expectations for earlier rate hikes, making the dollar less attractive. The euro gained 0.53% against the dollar, while the pound rose 0.80% on expectations of a strong economic recovery in Britain.

site_title: Nearly half of small UK manufacturers see recovery soon
summary: Nearly half of UK small manufacturers, 48%, expect to recover to their pre-pandemic health in the next three months, according to a survey by South West Manufacturing Advisory Service (SWMAS) and Manufacturing Growth Programme. The survey found 58% plan to raise investment and 54% intend to recruit more staff over the next six months. The optimism comes as the UK economy gradually reopens following a third national coronavirus lockdown, with further relaxations set to take place this week.

site_title: Long working hours are a killer, WHO study shows
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) reports that long working hours are killing hundreds of thousands of people annually, with 745,000 deaths from stroke and heart disease associated with long working hours in 2016. This represents a 30% increase from 2000, and the trend may worsen due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Premature to be envisaging second European stimulus plan: EU antitrust chief
summary: EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager says it's premature to consider a second stimulus plan, citing the existing 750-billion-euro pandemic recovery package. Vestager calls the idea of a new plan "bizarre," saying Europe needs to focus on the current recovery plan before considering further stimulus. This comes as US President Joe Biden proposes a $4 trillion economic stimulus package, raising questions about the need for additional support in Europe. France has pushed for a more ambitious recovery plan, but Vestager suggests Europe should prioritize the existing funds before considering more investment.

site_title: 38 community infections among 49 new Covid-19 cases
summary: There were 49 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including 38 in the community, as of Sunday noon. Of the community cases, 18 are unlinked, while 13 were already under quarantine. No new cases were reported in workers' dormitories. Additionally, 11 imported cases were placed on stay-home notice or isolated upon arrival.

site_title: France's Le Pen slams report over alleged embezzlement
summary: French far-right leader Marine Le Pen criticized a report alleging her party misused EU funds to pay employees. The report, by France's anti-corruption office, found the party suspected of an "embezzlement system" in a deliberate manner. Le Pen denied any wrongdoing and accused the report's publication of being a "perennial story" before the June 20 regional elections. The party has been charged with misuse of public funds, with Justice Minister Eric Dupond-Moretti denying accusations of a deliberate leak.

images.alt_text: French far-right leader Marine Le Pen lashed out Sunday over a press report detailing allegations that her party misused EU funds to pay its employees.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for May 14, 2021, reveals a downturn in the Capesize market, with the 5TC dropping $6,972 week-on-week to settle at $34,542. The C5 market also declined, and the North Atlantic saw virtually no activity. In contrast, the iron ore market remained strong, reaching $220-230 pmt levels. The Panamax market eased across the board, while the Ultramax/Supramax market showed mixed signals. The VLCC market remained stable, and the Suezmax market saw a slight increase. The Aframax market experienced a slight decline, and the Clean market saw a surge in enquiry following a cyber attack on the Colonial pipeline.

site_title: GovTech competing with Google, Shopee and more for tech talent
summary: GovTech, Singapore's digital government agency, has aggressively recruited tech talent, increasing its workforce from 1,800 to 3,000 in two-and-a-half years. The agency aims to hire 500 more people, competing with Google, Shopee, and other tech giants. GovTech's CEO, Kok Ping Soon, attributes the agency's success to its fast-track leadership trainee programme, technology bootcamp, and talent acquisition strategies. With a focus on digitalization and cloud migration, GovTech aims to become an agile entity delivering a "digital government" that impacts lives, makes Singapore more competitive, and creates jobs.

site_title: Public's trust needed in order for TraceTogether to succeed: GovTech chief
summary: GovTech's CEO Kok Ping Soon stated that public trust is essential for the success of Singapore's contact tracing app TraceTogether, emphasizing that the agency did not intend to mislead the public on data privacy. The app's development was focused on quickly tackling the coronavirus spread.

images.alt_text: The government agency behind the development of Singapore's contact tracing mobile app TraceTogether did not intend to mislead the public on data privacy, said its chief executive Kok Ping Soon.

site_title: Western S-Reits sanguine on post-Covid outlook
summary: Singapore's S-Reits, which are REITs (Real Estate Investment Trusts) listed for trading, are optimistic about the post-Covid outlook. Eight S-Reits with US and European assets reported average distribution yields of 7.5% and positive total returns of 8.9% in the first half of 2021. Cromwell European Reit and Manulife US Reit expect economic recovery in Europe and the US, respectively, driven by vaccination progress and easing restrictions. In contrast, United Hampshire US Reit and IReit Global anticipate strong demand for logistics and retail space in the US.

site_title: GLP sells world's largest US-dollar green perp offering at US$850m
summary: GLP sold the world's largest US-dollar green subordinated perpetual offering, pricing a US$850 million offering at a 4.5% coupon. The offering was upsized from the initial target size of US$500 million, with the orderbook more than six times subscribed. The green perpetual securities have a 25 basis points step-up margin from year 10 and an additional 75 basis points step-up margin from year 25, making them not callable for the first five years.

site_title: South-east Asia: A hotspot for Chinese enterprises in the post-pandemic era?
summary: Chinese companies are increasingly investing in South-east Asia, driven by the US-China trade tensions and the post-pandemic economic crisis. In 2020, China's direct investment in Asean reached $14.36 billion, with Singapore, Indonesia, and Vietnam being the top three recipients. Private sector companies like Alibaba, ByteDance, and Tencent have set up regional headquarters in Singapore, while Huawei has invested in a 5G innovation centre in Thailand. Chinese firms are drawn to Asean's growing middle class and complementary resources, with many focusing on e-commerce, digital economy, and manufacturing. The region's simpler relationship with China and lower political obstruction are expected to boost investment.

site_title: Strong inflation data pushes S&P 500 lower
summary: US stocks fell after inflation soared to 4.2% in May, the highest in 13 years, driven by new vehicle prices and vaccination normalization. Bond yields sparked fears of a recession, but historical data shows that rising bond yields don't necessarily halt equity market growth. Short-term technical analysis indicates further downside, with a double top formation confirmed if the S&P 500 fails to break above a 200% Fibonacci expansion level. However, quantitative easing by the Fed is expected to fuel cheap money flow into equity markets, making a strong downturn unlikely.

site_title: Dallas Fed's chief sees risk of inflation gaining a foothold in US economy
summary: Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan expressed concern that inflation expectations could gain a foothold in the US economy, citing imbalances between supply and demand for labor and goods. Kaplan urged his Fed colleagues to discuss scaling back the bond-buying program, citing the risk of inflation expectations rising to levels not consistent with the 2% target. He noted that the pandemic's impact, including global semiconductor shortages, could lead to prolonged bottlenecks in industries, fueling uncertainty and inflation concerns.

site_title: Wembley comes alive with noise and colour of fans' return
summary: Wembley Stadium hosted its largest sports crowd in England since the pandemic with 22,000 fans attending the FA Cup final, where Leicester City defeated Chelsea 1-0. The attendance marked a significant step towards easing COVID-19 restrictions, with similar crowds expected at English Premier League grounds for the final two matchdays. Despite issues with social distancing and some supporters booing players' pre-game protests, fans praised the energy and atmosphere created by the return of spectators, with Leicester manager Brendan Rodgers attributing his team's win to the connection with the fans.

site_title: Singapore mulls strategy to give more people at least one Covid-19 vaccine dose
summary: Singapore is considering a strategy to give as many people as possible at least one dose of the Covid-19 vaccine in the second phase of its vaccination exercise. Health Minister Ong Ye Kung said that one dose provides good protection from the virus without compromising efficacy, and the second dose can be given six to eight weeks apart without impacting vaccine efficacy. This move comes as the country faces a surge in cases and a shortage of vaccine supplies, with a quarter of the population already fully vaccinated and a third given at least one dose.

site_title: Facebook helps Zara owner sell clothes using video games
summary: Inditex, the owner of Zara, is partnering with Facebook and Instagram to develop a video game, "Pacific Game," to market its Pull & Bear brand to younger buyers. The game, accessible from the brand's social media accounts and website, aims to build a relationship with customers rather than making a direct sale. The move follows a shift towards online sales, with e-commerce accounting for a third of Inditex's revenue last year. The game is part of a larger effort to stay ahead in the digital market and invest in new technologies.

site_title: Soros bought up stocks linked to Bill Hwang's Archegos implosion
summary: Billionaire George Soros's investment firm, Soros Fund Management, purchased $194 million of ViacomCBS, Baidu, and other stocks as Archegos Capital Management collapsed. The hedge fund, led by Dawn Fitzpatrick, snapped up shares in the first quarter, capitalizing on the distressed remains of Archegos. The firm's investments, including Amazon.com and homebuilder DR Horton, now account for its second-largest public equity position. This move is part of Soros Fund Management's strategy to capitalize on market dislocations, as revealed in its 13F filing.

site_title: Israeli-Palestinian violence continues as diplomats push to restore calm
summary: Israeli air strikes killed 33 Palestinians, including 13 children, in Gaza, raising the death toll to 181, including 52 children. The strikes followed Israel's destruction of a 12-storey building in Gaza City that housed media operations, and militants fired rockets into Israel. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres called for an immediate ceasefire, while US President Joe Biden spoke to both Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu and Palestinian President Abbas in an effort to quell the violence. The conflict has been ongoing for a seventh day, with the US and Western powers not engaging with Hamas due to its designation as a terrorist organization.

site_title: UK isn't sold on Biden's global minimum business tax plan
summary: British officials are skeptical of the US plan for a global minimum business tax rate of 21%, citing concerns it may be too high over the long term. The UK intends to raise corporation tax to 25% in 2023, and instead wants to focus on measures to make multinational companies, especially digital giants, pay more tax in countries where they operate. Talks are ongoing, with a deal aiming for the summer, but British scepticism could potentially delay an agreement.

site_title: BT Explains: Why are condo, HDB rents rising?
summary: Condominium and HDB rents in Singapore have risen for four consecutive months, with a 1.3% increase in April from the previous month. Analysts attribute this trend to construction delays, low housing vacancy, and increased demand from HDB upgraders, young executives, and foreigners. The growing tech industry and foreign investment also contribute to the rising rents, with some companies like BioNTech investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Singapore. Despite the increases, condo rents are still down 11.9% from their peak in January 2013, while HDB rents are 10% down from their peak in August 2013.

site_title: Vaccines not a silver bullet for the market
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index fell 2.2% after the government introduced lockdown-like measures to contain rising Covid-19 infections. The measures include a ban on dining out and working from home, and reduced social gatherings. Despite the government's vaccination efforts, the vaccines are not seen as a silver bullet for the market, and investors should brace for continued turbulence. The government is studying the possibility of increasing the interval between Covid-19 vaccine shots to boost vaccination rates. Companies must adapt to the new normal by modifying products and services, shrinking premises, and investing in technology.

site_title: Covid kills over 1,000 bank employees as virus ravages India
summary: Indian banks have lost over 1,000 employees and many more are infected due to the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the All India Bank Officers' Association. The virus is affecting frontline workers, including bank employees, who are at high risk. The heavy toll of the pandemic underscores the challenges faced by India in its battle against the world's worst coronavirus crisis.

site_title: DBS Foundation ramps up support for social enterprises in Asia
summary: DBS Foundation has increased its funding for its 2021 social enterprise grant programme to S$3 million, more than double the amount in 2020. The programme supports early-stage social enterprises in Singapore, Hong Kong, Taiwan, China, India, and Indonesia, with grants of up to S$250,000. Successful applicants can access capacity-building programmes, networking opportunities, and the foundation's social enterprise community. A new "Towards Zero Food Waste" category has also been added to address climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions and food waste.

site_title: US requires inspections for wire failure on Boeing 737 Classic planes
summary: The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has issued a directive requiring inspections for potential wire failures on Boeing 737 Classic planes, following an investigation into the January Indonesian flight crash that killed 62 passengers. The issue affects 1,041 737-300, -400, and -500 Classic series airplanes worldwide, with US operators Aloha Air Cargo, DHL, iAero Airways, Kalitta Charters, and Northern Air Cargo required to check for secure connections to a safety sensor. The FAA is requiring initial tests within 250 flight hours and follow-on inspections every 2,000 flight hours to address the potential safety risk.

site_title: Billionaire's bitcoin dream shapes his business empire in Norway
summary: Norway's billionaire Kjell Inge Rokke's industrial investment company, Aker ASA, is open to accepting payment in Bitcoin, a move seen as a small leap of faith in the country where the central bank governor has lambasted the cryptocurrency. Aker, which owns oil producer Aker BP, isn't reconfiguring its payments system yet, but is curious about the technology and its potential to change market behavior. Rokke believes Bitcoin will be "on the right side of history" and sees its entry into the mainstream economy as inevitable.

site_title: Hong Kong 'Shop King' dies at 88
summary: Tang Shing-bor, a Hong Kong real estate mogul known as "Shop King," has died at 88. He was a renowned property investor who accumulated a vast retail property portfolio, valued at approximately HK$75 billion. Tang's career spanned six decades, from humble beginnings as an apprentice electrician to successful entrepreneur and investor. Despite facing challenges, including the 1997 Asian financial crisis and Hong Kong's economic downturn, he continued to develop his business and make positive contributions to society.

site_title: US pipeline hit by hackers says fully back to 'normal'
summary: The US pipeline network, operated by Colonial Pipeline, has returned to normal operations after a cyber attack by a Russia-based group, Darkside. The attack led to a ransomware payment of $5 million and the shutdown of the pipeline network, causing gas shortages and panic buying in eastern states. The network's full recovery has eased concerns, but it may take days for supply delivery chains to return to normal. The attack is believed to have been orchestrated by the US government, with former US Treasury secretary Larry Summers suggesting that heavy pressure was exerted on the Russian leadership to shut down the hackers.

site_title: Australia sticks to plan to reopen border in mid-2022 over Covid-19 fears
summary: Australia's government has decided to maintain its plan to reopen the country's international border in mid-2022, citing concerns over Covid-19. Treasurer Josh Frydenberg stated that the government will follow medical advice to avoid easing restrictions prematurely. This decision comes amid pressure from the ruling conservatives to end the border closure, which has been in place since March 2020.

site_title: Mississippi River reopens, freeing over 1,000 stuck barges
summary: The US Coast Guard has reopened the Mississippi River to maritime traffic, ending a shutdown that stranded over 1,000 barges. A crack in the I-40 Hernando DeSoto Bridge near Memphis, Tennessee, had cut off the biggest route for US agricultural exports. The river reopened on Friday, allowing 62 vessels and 1,058 barges to resume operations, with priority given to Department of Defense and red flag fuel barges. Experts expect river operations to return to normal by the middle of next week, with no threat to the record large US summer corn export programme.

site_title: F&B firms welcome delivery cost offsets, but seek more substantial rental, labour support
summary: Singapore's food and beverage (F&B) firms have welcomed the latest round of subsidies and rebates to offset delivery costs, following the reinstatement of the Food Delivery Booster Package by Enterprise Singapore. The package funds 5 percentage points of commission costs and 20% of delivery costs for orders made through third-party logistics partners. However, F&B operators still need substantial help with rental and labour costs, and are hoping for government support. To mitigate losses, some firms are exploring new revenue streams, such as selling frozen food online and offering meal subscription plans.

site_title: Iran gears up for return to oil market as US talks advance
summary: Iran is preparing to increase global oil sales as US talks to lift sanctions show signs of progress. State-controlled National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) has been priming oil fields and customer relationships to increase exports. If a deal is struck, Iran could return to pre-sanctions production levels of almost four million barrels a day in three to six months. However, the pace of Iran's comeback may be gradual due to the coronavirus pandemic and other factors, posing complications for the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) and its allies.

images.alt_text: An oil refinery in south-west Iran. Teheran is reviving petroleum sales, sending a flood of Iranian crude to emboldened Chinese buyers. Production has climbed almost 20 per cent this year to 2.4 million barrels a day, the highest in two years,

site_title: Schools to shift to home-based learning from May 19 till May 28 amid spike in community cases
summary: Singapore schools will shift to full home-based learning from May 19 to May 28 due to a spike in community COVID-19 cases. Primary, secondary, junior college, and Millennia Institute students, as well as those in Special Education schools, will participate. Pre-schools and student care centers will remain open for working parents. Schools will provide digital devices and internet access for students in need, and those requiring additional support can still access their schools.

site_title: Singapore considers giving more people at least one Covid-19 vaccine dose
summary: Singapore's government is considering giving more people at least one dose of the Covid-19 vaccine in the second phase of the nation's vaccination exercise. This strategy may help with rising community cases and limited vaccine supply, according to Health Minister Ong Ye Kung. The delay in the second dose could extend to six to eight weeks without significantly impacting vaccine efficacy. The move follows similar strategies in the UK and parts of Europe, and experts say it could help vaccinate more people while supplies catch up with demand.

site_title: Stapled developer and Reit structure suggested to arrest trading discounts
summary: Singapore-listed property developers are trading at half their book values, with Reit counterparts trading at book value on average. A banker, Kelvin Tan, is proposing a hybrid stapled vehicle combining Reit features with developer risk, to attract yield-paying investors. Tan's team is pitching this structure to developer clients. The proposed vehicle aims to capitalize on the attractive yields of Reits while allowing developers to tap into the capital markets.

site_title: A new era of short bets against German bonds is beginning
summary: Germany's safest asset, the bund, is experiencing a retreat, with yields climbing above 0% for the first time in over two years. Major banks, including Toronto-Dominion Bank, NatWest Markets, and Goldman Sachs, are calling for investors to sell bunds, citing the end of a "supercycle" that has seen the securities rally for nearly two decades.
