The European Central Bank's tapering of pandemic-era stimulus measures and rising inflation expectations are contributing to the shift, with long-term investors paying higher yields to hold German debt.

site_title: 'Chaos Monkeys' author calls Apple's statement on his departure defamatory
summary: Apple engineer Antonio García Martínez claims he was fired "in a snap decision" after thousands of coworkers signed a petition objecting to sexist and racist views in his 2016 book "Chaos Monkeys". Apple stated that behavior like his has no place in the workplace, which García Martínez says is defamatory and false. The company had been aware of his writing, and García Martínez claims he was interviewed by references provided to the company.

site_title: 2 new Covid-19 clusters in Singapore, including 5 kids at Learning Point tuition centre
summary: A new Covid-19 cluster has emerged in Singapore, involving 5 primary school pupils who tested positive after attending classes at Learning Point, an enrichment centre. The cluster, one of two reported, has 3 active cases, including a 7-year-old pupil. This brings Singapore's total number of active clusters to 13. The country has reported 61,505 cases, with 61,032 fully recovered and 180 patients in hospital.

site_title: ST Group Food's JV partner Papparich Group Sdn Bhd to wind up
summary: ST Group Food's joint venture partner Papparich Group Sdn Bhd (PGSB) has been ordered by the High Court of Malaya to wind up due to a petition filed by Chen Khai Voon on May 15, 2020. PGSB is not a subsidiary of ST Group Food, but holds a 50% equity interest in Papparich Australia Pty Ltd. The winding-up order is expected to have no impact on ST Group Food's business operations. The group will review the impact of the order after receiving the written court judgment and winding-up order.

site_title: Singapore's PM Lee on need for latest Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announced stricter COVID-19 curbs, citing the need to stop more cases from popping up amid new clusters and unlinked community cases. The measures include banning dining-in and limiting social gatherings to two people, starting from May 16. Lee urged the public to stay at home for non-essential tasks and follow government advisories to stem the transmission of the virus. The country has 13 active COVID-19 clusters, with 59 patients in one cluster linked to the Changi Airport cluster.

site_title: Developers need to find new ways to improve value
summary: Singapore's property developers are struggling to boost value through share buybacks, privatisations, and Reits. Despite attempts to increase efficiency, investors remain unsatisfied. The article cites CapitaLand's recent decision to consolidate its businesses under private ownership as a possible solution. Analysts suggest alternative approaches, such as creating private companies or boosting recurring income, could be more effective. However, these methods may not be suitable for all developers, and the market continues to favor Reits due to their transparency and liquidity.

site_title: Key city of London subway line to reopen as workers trickle back
summary: The 2.4-kilometer Waterloo & City subway line in London will reopen on June 21, marking the return of commuter traffic to the city's financial district. The line, closed in March 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, is crucial for the district's recovery. The service will run on weekdays with trains leaving every five minutes, providing reassurance to businesses relying on commuter traffic. The reopening comes as the UK government faces rising cases of the India variant, prompting concerns about lifting pandemic measures.

site_title: Trudeau government begins work on reopening US-Canada border
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's government is initiating internal discussions on reopening the US-Canada border, despite Canada being behind the US in vaccinations. Officials are considering a two-track system for vaccinated travelers, with relaxed quarantine and testing requirements. However, a senior official disputes the existence of new developments, stating talks have been ongoing for over a year.

site_title: US retail sales flat, inflation fears on the rise
summary: US retail sales remained flat in April, ending a 10.7% surge in March, amid supply bottlenecks and concerns over inflation. Consumer confidence fell, with a private survey showing concerns about rising prices. The Federal Reserve acknowledged supply chain issues but downplayed inflation concerns, stating they are transitory. Despite a decline in some sectors, sales in key areas such as cars, electronics, and healthcare remained strong. Economists predict the economic recovery will continue to gain steam, but officials warn of potential bumpy months ahead.

site_title: Biden revokes Trump order that sought to limit social media firms' protections
summary: US President Joe Biden revoked an executive order by former President Donald Trump that aimed to limit liability protections for social media companies. The order, issued in May 2020, was met with opposition from the Center for Democracy and Technology, which praised Biden's reversal. The 1996 Communications Decency Act shields companies from liability for user-generated content, and Trump's order sought to overturn this protection. The move was seen as a victory for social media companies and a setback for Trump's efforts to regulate online speech.

site_title: Payments firm Marqeta files for IPO showing revenue doubled
summary: Digital payments firm Marqeta has filed for an initial public offering (IPO), disclosing revenue that more than doubled to $290 million in 2020, despite shrinking losses. The company's backers include Goldman Sachs and Visa, and it plans to list its shares on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol MQ. Marqeta's IPO is being led by Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase & Co., with a placeholder offering size of $100 million. The company's valuation is expected to be around $10 billion.

site_title: STB to allow SingapoRediscovers Voucher refunds for cancelled staycation bookings
summary: The Singapore Tourism Board (STB) has announced that customers who used SingapoRediscovers Vouchers (SRVs) for cancelled hotel staycations booked during the tightened restrictions will be allowed refunds or rescheduling. The cancellation and refund process will be subject to terms and conditions, and authorised booking partners will assist customers. Alternatively, customers can reschedule their stays for a later date. The validity of attraction tickets and tours will also be extended, allowing customers to change their dates of visit. This move follows the extension of the SRV scheme by six months to the end of the year.

site_title: Food delivery players tweak fees as F&B merchants brace for impact of Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Singapore's stricter Covid-19 measures have prompted food delivery platforms to adjust their fees. Grab reduced commissions for eligible merchants, while GrabFood offered a 50% commission rebate for non-hawker centres. Foodpanda Singapore offered free delivery for hawker centre orders above S$35. To incentivize riders, foodpanda increased riders' service fees. Other platforms, such as WhyQ and Oddle, also ramped up services and launched new initiatives to support merchants. The government has also introduced the Food Delivery Booster Package to offset part of food delivery costs.

site_title: Mapletree Commercial Trust to provide more tenant support amid stricter Covid-19 measures
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) has pledged to provide rental and operating assistance to its retail tenants amid Singapore's tightened Covid-19 measures until June 13. The trust has already implemented over S$70 million in support packages, including rental rebates, since the start of the pandemic. MCT's properties have also introduced health and safety protocols, such as increased cleaning frequencies and digital contract tracing systems. The trust aims to support its tenants during this period, following its commitment to providing necessary assistance.

site_title: STI pares 2021 YTD total return to 9.1%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) ended the week down 4.5% at 3,055.02, with its 2021 year-to-date total return now at 9.1%. Despite a strong Q1 2021, the index entered the red in Q2 due to a 2.4% decline. The bank trio of DBS, OCBC, and UOB remain the cornerstone of the STI, with strong financials and averaging a 1.2% total return in Q2 2021. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding and Sembcorp Industries were the strongest performers in Q1 2021, with Yangzijiang ranking as the STI's strongest performer in the first half of Q2 2021.

site_title: Confusion reigns after US lifts mask guidance
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) lifted most mask guidelines for fully vaccinated individuals, but the change has raised confusion and questions about implementation. The non-binding guidance does not apply to public transportation or medical settings, and local authorities and employers must decide on policies. Many states and companies are reviewing or updating their mask mandates, with some, like Maryland and Virginia, lifting indoor mask mandates, while others, such as Minnesota and Pennsylvania, remain unchanged. The move aims to encourage vaccination and ease restrictions, but experts warn that some areas may still require masks due to high transmission rates.

site_title: Pandemic beneficiaries jump on stricter Covid-19 curbs, STI slides
summary: Singapore stocks slipped into negative territory, with the Straits Times Index (STI) closing 2.2% lower at S$3,055.02, amid stricter Covid-19 curbs and a potential delay in the Singapore-Hong Kong air travel bubble. Shares of pandemic beneficiaries like Sheng Siong Group surged 10.7%, while travel-related stocks tumbled. The delay may send travel-related stocks tumbling, with SIA Engineering, SATS, and Singapore Airlines losing 6%, 3.9%, and 5.7% respectively.

site_title: Taiwan says HK tycoon asset freeze a warning to global investors
summary: Taiwan warned that Hong Kong's asset freeze on media tycoon Jimmy Lai is a sign that doing business in the city is becoming increasingly risky for global investors. The asset freeze, announced Friday, includes all shares in Lai's company, Next Digital, the first time a listed firm has been targeted by national security laws. This move comes as the Taiwan arm of Lai's Apple Daily newspaper announced it would stop publishing its print version due to declining advertising revenue and difficult business conditions. The warning suggests investors should be cautious when engaging with Hong Kong.

site_title: Rakuten CEO calls Olympics 'suicide mission'
summary: Rakuten CEO Hiroshi Mikitani has called the Tokyo Olympics a "suicide mission" due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. Japan extended a coronavirus state of emergency, putting pressure on the country's healthcare system. Despite this, Olympics organisers claim they can safely hold the Games with virus countermeasures. The event has sparked public opposition, with a petition to cancel the Games garnering over 351,000 signatures. The government remains committed to holding the Games, with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga stating it is possible to hold safe and secure Games.

images.alt_text: Holding the Tokyo Olympics this summer would be a "suicide mission" as the coronavirus pandemic continues to rage around the world, the head of Japan's e-commerce giant Rakuten has warned.

site_title: Mexico's power plants burning fuel so dirty ships cannot use it
summary: Mexico is burning a large amount of fuel oil, a dirty byproduct of domestic gasoline production, to generate electricity, as the global shipping industry has banned the use of sulfurous fuel oil. This has led to a 50% increase in fuel oil consumption, with over 100,000 barrels a day being burned at power plants in Mexico City. The move is expected to raise emissions, despite President Lopez Obrador's pledge to reduce Mexico's dependence on fuel imports.

site_title: China's Zhurong rover touches down on Mars
summary: China's Zhurong rover successfully landed on Mars, marking a historic feat for the nation's first-ever Martian mission. The lander deployed the rover in a vast northern lava plain known as the Utopia Planitia after navigating the "seven minutes of terror" through the Martian atmosphere using a parachute. The mission was a triumph for Beijing's increasingly bold space ambitions.

images.alt_text: China's probe to Mars touched down on the Red Planet early Saturday to deploy its Zhurong rover, state media reported, a triumph for Beijing's increasingly bold space ambitions and a history-making feat for a nation on its first-ever Martian mission.

site_title: Manhattan's famed Flatiron Building gets a makeover for new crop of tenants
summary: The 120-year-old Flatiron Building in Manhattan is undergoing a renovation to attract new office tenants after being empty since 2019. With over 200,000 square feet of space available, the building is marketing its unique image and asking rents of over $100 per square foot, significantly higher than the Midtown South area average. Three proposals have been received from international firms, and the marketing process has just begun, as the city emerges from the pandemic with a high office supply and demand.

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump as energy, retail rise; ends lower for the week
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 1.1% on Friday, driven by gains in energy and retail sectors, but still fell 0.5% for the week due to rising US inflation concerns. The Federal Reserve's reassurances on monetary policy eased fears, and analysts see Europe as an attractive pick for global investors, citing its economic sensitivity. Some individual stocks, such as Italy's Banco BPM and France's Danone, saw significant price movements, while others like Atlantia reported losses.

images.alt_text: European stocks jumped on Friday, led by gains in energy and retail sectors after the Federal Reserve said there would be no imminent move to tighten monetary policy, easing fears of rising US inflation that pushed the Stoxx 600 index into negative territory for the week.

site_title: Bitcoin hovers around US$50,000 amid fallout from Musk's blast
summary: Bitcoin's price hovered around US$50,000 after Tesla CEO Elon Musk doubled down on his criticism of the token's energy demands, citing a surge in electricity consumption. Musk's tweets, which included a chart from the University of Cambridge, sparked a 10% weekly slump in Bitcoin prices. The move raises questions about the token's attractiveness as an investment, particularly as institutional firms increasingly focus on climate change and environmental issues. Musk's reversal comes after Tesla's US$1.5 billion investment in Bitcoin and its plan to accept it as payment.

site_title: 5,000 inmates, staff, vendors and volunteers to be tested for Covid-19 at Changi Prison
summary: The Singapore Prison Service (SPS) is conducting a COVID-19 testing exercise at Changi Prison Complex involving 5,000 inmates, staff, vendors, and volunteers after a prison kitchen chef tested positive for the virus. Inmate activities, including rehabilitation programs, have been suspended, and all inmate visits have been replaced with phone calls. The testing is part of the government's efforts to reduce the risk of COVID-19 transmission, following the Ministry of Health's announcement on tightening community measures.

site_title: Property players fall back on digitalisation efforts in response to stricter safe distancing measures
summary: Singapore property players are adapting to stricter safe distancing measures with digitalisation efforts. Developers have launched online booking systems, virtual tours, and online presentations to manage crowds and showcase properties. Despite the new restrictions, sales of new private homes have doubled in March, and prices are rising, with rents climbing 1.3% in April. Experts expect property prices to continue to climb, with some predicting a bullish recovery.

site_title: US: Stocks surge, undaunted by flat retail data
summary: US stocks surged, recovering from earlier losses, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.1% and the S&P 500 rising 1.5% to close at 4,173.85. Despite flat retail sales in April, the rebound was driven by optimism over mask requirements easing and travel shares, with Carnival Cruise Line jumping 8.3%. However, consumer sentiment index fell, raising concerns about inflation, and doubts remain about the Federal Reserve's assurances that price spikes are temporary.

site_title: F&B and retail companies to get help to offset delivery costs, go digital: Enterprise Singapore
summary: Enterprise Singapore has introduced two new packages to support food and beverage, as well as retail businesses affected by Covid-19 restrictions. The Food Delivery Booster Package will offset 5% of commission costs charged by food delivery platforms Deliveroo, Foodpanda, and GrabFood, while the E-Commerce Booster Package will help brick-and-mortar retailers go online. These packages aim to help businesses diversify revenue channels and reduce costs.

images.alt_text: To be eligible for the delivery funding, F&B businesses must sell food that is prepared on premise for immediate consumption.

site_title: Exxon says it will restart gas compressor at Guyana platform in June
summary: ExxonMobil Corp plans to reinstall a gas compressor at its Liza Destiny platform off Guyana's coast in June, following an equipment failure that prompted the company to slash output. The compressor failure had prevented Exxon from producing at full capacity without flaring excess carbon dioxide, a source of tension with the Guyana government. Exxon will produce 100,000-110,000 barrels per day while flaring less than 15,000 standard cubic feet per day. The company is working with the Environmental Protection Administration to develop a long-term regulatory approach for flare management.

site_title: Gold edges up as weaker dollar counters rate jitters
summary: Gold prices edged higher due to a weaker dollar, but gains were curbed by data showing a rise in US inflation and concerns of a sooner-than-expected rate hike. Spot gold rose 0.2% to $1,829.61 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.2% to $1,827.40. The dollar index fell 0.1% against rivals, making gold cheaper for other currency holders. Investors await US retail sales data, with some warning of a potential rate hike and others saying gold remains relatively supported.

site_title: Honda returns to profit but sees chip shortage crimping 2021 earnings
summary: Honda Motor reported a profit rebound in the fourth quarter, driven by cost cuts, but warned of chip shortages and raw material costs impacting 2021 earnings. The company forecast operating profit of 660 billion yen, short of analyst estimates. Honda expects 100,000 vehicles to be affected by the chip shortage, which will continue in the first half of the year. The company plans to sell 5 million vehicles this year, with a focus on electrification, aiming for 100% electric vehicle sales by 2040.

site_title: Why SPH's Anthony Tan is hooked on Muay Thai
summary: Anthony Tan, 48, deputy CEO of Singapore Press Holdings, credits his 7-year Muay Thai practice for instilling persistence, discipline, and order in his life. The sport has helped him establish a schedule, reducing distractions from his mobile phone, allowing him to focus on work and build professional networks. Tan believes that hard work is key to success, as quoted by Bruce Lee, and has adapted his routine during the pandemic, incorporating home workouts and Zoom classes.

site_title: Lexus UX 300e review: Soothing Japanese coy
summary: The Lexus UX 300e is a compact electric crossover that serves as a gateway car to a fossil fuel-free future. With a 204 horsepower motor and 54 kWh battery, it offers a smooth and quiet driving experience. The car's design and features are largely identical to its petrol-powered counterpart, with subtle modifications to accommodate its electric powertrain. However, its high price point of S$255,800 and limited range of 300km on a single charge make it less practical for some buyers. The UX 300e is a stopgap car for Lexus, which is working on launching 10 new electric vehicles by 2025.

site_title: ComfortDelGro's plans to unlock value of Australian assets likely to be catalyst for stock, say analysts
summary: ComfortDelGro's plans to unlock value from its Australian assets are expected to be a catalyst for the stock, with analysts citing higher-than-expected quarterly net profit and operating leverage as positives. The company's stock could be worth up to 32.3% more than its current value if the Australian assets are valued at 10 times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization. Analysts have raised their target prices, with UOB Kay Hian estimating a 23.4% upside potential.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro's taxi business showed the most improvement, thanks to a recovery in China and lower rental rebates given to taxi drivers in Singapore.

site_title: Walmart ditches mask mandate for vaccinated customers, staff
summary: Walmart has announced that fully vaccinated staff and customers can no longer wear masks, effective May 18. This decision, made in response to the CDC's guidance, allows vaccinated individuals to shop without face coverings at US Walmart and Sam's Club locations. The move is expected to set an example for the retail industry, with other companies like Costco and Trader Joe's also eliminating mask requirements for shoppers. However, some local ordinances may still require masks, and employees at Trader Joe's will still be required to wear them.

images.alt_text: Walmart said fully vaccinated staff and customers can now leave their masks at home, a decision that could influence how other businesses respond to the latest government guidance.

site_title: Outlook too cloudy for new wage guidelines but firms should reward workers fairly: NWC
summary: The National Wages Council in Singapore has postponed issuing new wage guidelines due to an uncertain economic outlook. Despite this, the council advises businesses to re-evaluate their situations and reward employees fairly, especially those doing well. The council will meet again later this year to develop new guidelines that will apply from December 1, 2021, to November 30, 2022.

site_title: Repeating your investment mistakes forever
summary: A recent discussion with a hedge fund manager prompted the author to reevaluate their investment philosophy, focusing on protecting against large downside risks in a cost-effective manner. Inspired by the concept of eternal recurrence, the author questions whether they would want to relive past investment decisions, including losses, over and over for eternity. They conclude that, despite the potential for emotional pain, it's essential to protect against significant risks, especially if done at a minimal cost to total returns. The author emphasizes the need for investors to honestly assess their willingness to accept all outcomes, aligning their personal investment philosophy with their portfolio.

site_title: Myanmar's generals run a nearly sanction-proof business empire
summary: Myanmar's military-run conglomerates, MEHL and MEC, have established a nearly sanction-proof business empire, employing thousands of civilians and military personnel, controlling various industries, and paying dividends to hundreds of thousands of soldiers. Despite international sanctions, the military sees itself as a winner, with analysts noting that the conglomerates' business interests are isolated from the international community. The military's control over the economy has led to a lack of cooperation with domestic businesses, and some companies, such as Kirin and Posco, are considering cutting ties or ending partnerships with MEHL and MEC.

site_title: More than 1,000 barges back up on lower Mississippi River
summary: More than 1,000 barges backed up on the lower Mississippi River, awaiting reopening after a bridge closure in Memphis, Tennessee. The US Coast Guard stopped traffic on the river on Tuesday due to a fracture in the Hernando DeSoto Bridge. The bridge's reopening depends on an inspection by the Tennessee Department of Transportation, with officials hoping for a decision within the next day or so. The closure is disrupting shipments of goods, including oil and corn, critical to US crop exports.

site_title: Binance faces probe by US money-laundering and tax sleuths
summary: The US Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service (IRS) are investigating Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, for potential money laundering and tax evasion. The probe, led by prosecutors and IRS agents, is aimed at rooting out illicit activity in the unregulated cryptocurrency market. Binance, incorporated in the Cayman Islands, has been accused of failing to prevent Americans from trading on its platform, despite blocking US residents from accessing it. The investigation follows a Chainalysis report that found 27% of illicit Bitcoin transactions flowed through Binance.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust chief financial officer to step down on July 24
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's (FCT) CFO, Tay Hwee Pio, will step down on July 24 to pursue personal interests. She has served as CFO since 2012 and will be succeeded once a new appointee is selected. FCT's shares ended the day at S$2.29, down 3% from the previous day.

site_title: Airbnb sees signs of rebound though loss widens on debt payment
summary: Airbnb reported a 52% increase in gross bookings to $10.3 billion in the first quarter, beating analyst estimates. Despite this, the company's loss widened due to debt repayment. Revenue rose 5% to $887 million, exceeding projections. The company expects a travel rebound, unlike any before, as conditions improve.

images.alt_text: Airbnb reported US$10.3 billion in gross bookings in the three months ended March 31, a 52 per cent increase from the year earlier period.

site_title: ThaiBev Q2 net profit up 19.7% to 5.93 billion baht
summary: ThaiBev, a Thai beverage company, reported a 19.7% increase in Q2 net profit to 5.93 billion baht, driven by gains from spirits and beer segments, as well as cost management efforts during the pandemic. The company's financial results surpassed expectations, with the increase attributed to the recovery in demand for beverages and effective cost management.

site_title: WHO urges caution over removing mask mandate for vaccinated people
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) advises caution when considering lifting mask mandates for vaccinated individuals, urging that local conditions such as transmission intensity and vaccine coverage be taken into account. In contrast, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recently advised that fully vaccinated people can avoid wearing masks outdoors and indoors in most places.

site_title: JD Logistics' US$3.5 billion IPO draws SoftBank, Temasek
summary: JD Logistics is set to raise up to $3.5 billion in its Hong Kong IPO, with SoftBank Vision Fund and Temasek Holdings as cornerstone investors. SoftBank will invest $600 million, accounting for 40% of the $1.5 billion worth of shares set aside for seven cornerstone investors. Other investors include Blackstone Group, Tiger Global, China Chengtong Holdings Group Ltd, Matthews Asia, and Oaktree Capital. The IPO is the second-largest in Hong Kong this year, following Kuaishou Technology's $6.2 billion listing in February.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: mm2 Asia raised nearly S$54.7 million after its rights issue, with the majority of proceeds to be used to reduce existing liabilities. Jiutian Chemical declared an interim dividend of 0.35 Singapore cents per ordinary share, its first since FY2008. Nam Cheong posted a first-quarter net loss of RM17 million, narrowing from RM114.3 million a year earlier. Olam International secured a US$1 billion loan to finance the acquisition of US spice maker Olde Thomson. Straco Corp reported a Q1 net loss of S$390,000, narrowing from S$3.4 million a year ago.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher with broad-based gains
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday with broad-based gains, driven by investor optimism over economic recovery prospects. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.09%, the S&P 500 gained 0.42%, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 1.00% as investors looked beyond inflation concerns. The gains followed a volatile week of trading, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Hong Kong tycoon Jimmy Lai's Taiwan paper to stop print edition
summary: The Taiwan arm of Hong Kong media tycoon Jimmy Lai's Apple Daily will stop publishing its print edition, citing declining advertising revenue and difficult business conditions in Hong Kong linked to politics. The decision was made due to the "monopoly" of digital platforms and the boycott of advertising resources by "pro-China forces" in Hong Kong. This move comes after Lai's Hong Kong Apple Daily vowed to fight on despite pressure from Beijing, following Lai's 14-month prison sentence for participating in pro-democracy protests in 2019. The Taiwan paper will shift all resources to digital.

site_title: Up on The Other Roof
summary: The Other Roof, a rooftop bar in Singapore, offers an extensive selection of "tea-finished" spirits, steeped in bespoke tea blends and caffeine-free tisanes. The bar features a unique menu, including cocktails like the Monkey See Monkey Do and The Other Mojito, and a food menu with sharing plates and tapas-sized mains. With a focus on refreshing drinks and a laid-back vibe, The Other Roof is a popular spot for Instagramming patrons. The bar is the sister of The Other Room, which features cask-finished spirits, and is set to debut a new menu in the coming months.

site_title: Jeff Bezos' new superyacht heralds roaring market for big boats
summary: Jeff Bezos' superyacht, project Y721, is set to become one of the largest sailing yachts ever built in the Netherlands, measuring 127m long with multiple decks and masts. Owned by Bezos, the billionaire founder of Amazon, the yacht is expected to be completed at a new shipyard next month. The project has sparked interest in the superyacht market, which is poised for growth.

site_title: Faith leaders urged to stamp out anti-LGBT+ rhetoric
summary: Religious leaders and institutions worldwide have been urged to condemn anti-LGBT+ rhetoric and practices that incite discrimination or violence. The call comes amid a debate on the relationship between religious freedoms and LGBT+ rights, particularly as Britain moves to ban conversion therapy. The United Nations and international human rights experts, including UN expert Victor Madrigal-Borloz, have stated that incitement constitutes hate speech and is protected neither by freedom of expression nor by freedom of religion or belief.

site_title: Myanmar troops battle militias as anti-coup resistance grows
summary: Myanmar's military imposed martial law in the town of Mindat, Chin State, after artillery shelling by troops targeting civilian militias. The Chinland Defence Forces claimed responsibility for the attacks, which also targeted a police station and bank. The military has struggled to restore order amid widespread anger over its February coup, which ousted the elected government of Aung San Suu Kyi. The resistance has expanded to attacks on administrators and security forces, with 788 reported killed in the military's crackdown, according to an advocacy group.

site_title: Memento mori
summary: Geriatrician Dr. Lucy Pollock's book "The Book About Getting Older (For People Who Don't Want To Talk About It)" offers a hopeful perspective on aging and dying. Despite common fears and misconceptions, modern medicine can still improve quality of life beyond 70 and 80. The book covers topics such as dementia, end-of-life decisions, and ways to prevent decline, including falls and medication misuse. With a calm and tactful approach, Pollock encourages readers to think carefully about their wishes for the end of life, promoting a more informed and empowered conversation.

site_title: Vertex-backed Binance faces probe by US money-laundering and tax sleuths
summary: The US Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service are investigating Binance Holdings, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, for alleged money laundering and tax evasion. The probe, led by Changpeng Zhao, Binance's CEO, follows concerns that cryptocurrencies are being used to conceal illegal transactions. Chainalysis, a blockchain forensics firm, found that more funds tied to criminal activity flowed through Binance than any other crypto exchange. Binance has denied any wrongdoing, stating it has a robust compliance program in place.

site_title: 'Covid Zero' havens find reopening harder than taming virus
summary: "Covid Zero" havens face a challenge in reopening as they maintain strict measures to control the virus, despite the global trend of normalizing and lifting restrictions. These countries, including China, Singapore, Australia, and New Zealand, have achieved lower death tolls during the pandemic but are at risk of being left behind due to slower vaccine rollout and stricter quarantine policies. Experts warn that sustaining zero infection rates long-term may not be feasible and that the virus will likely become endemic, making continued isolation a disadvantage for these economies.

site_title: ThaiBev Q2 net profit up 19.7% to 5.93b baht
summary: ThaiBev reported a 19.7% increase in Q2 net profit to 5.93 billion baht, driven by gains from spirits and beer segments. Despite this, the beverage industry experienced a decline in the first three months of the year due to measures affecting entertainment businesses and safety concerns over dining out and drinking at restaurants. Revenue dipped 3.2% to 59.46 billion baht, with the food segment taking the biggest hit, resulting in a net loss of 96 million baht.

site_title: Dining ban 'unfortunate' for newly opened F&B establishments
summary: Singapore's upcoming one-month dining ban from May 16 to June 13 will significantly impact newly opened food and beverage establishments, particularly those that rely heavily on dine-in services. Many operators, including Huggs Coffee and Senshi Sushi & Grill, have expressed disappointment and worry about the impact on sales and staff. To mitigate the effects, some establishments are focusing on delivery and takeaway services, while others are exploring wage support measures, such as the 50% wage increase under the Jobs Support Scheme.

site_title: US manufacturing production rises in April
summary: US manufacturing production rose 0.4% in April, driven by the return of plants damaged by February's stormy weather. This offset a decline in motor vehicle production. Manufacturing remains below pre-pandemic levels, with capacity utilisation rising to 74.1% in March. The increase in manufacturing output, combined with a 2.6% increase in utilities, lifted industrial production by 0.7%. Economists had forecast a 0.4% increase, and the sector's growth is underpinned by fiscal stimulus and a shift to goods production due to the pandemic.

site_title: Modi says virus is rapidly spreading in India's rural areas
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi warned of a rapid spread of COVID-19 in rural areas, urging villagers to take precautions. With 70% of the population living in rural areas, the lack of healthcare infrastructure poses a significant challenge. The country has reported over 300,000 daily infections for 22 consecutive days, and a research model predicts deaths could quadruple by end-July. The situation is particularly alarming in states where recent voter rallies were held, with some areas experiencing a more fierce spread than the first wave of the pandemic.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical declares 0.35-cent interim dividend, first since FY2008
summary: Jiutian Chemical declared an interim dividend of 0.35 Singapore cent per ordinary share, its first since FY2008. The company posted a net profit of 90.31 million yuan (S$18.48 million) in the first quarter, a 30-fold increase from the previous year. Strong demand for its products drove the growth, with earnings per share increasing to 4.54 fen. The board aims to maintain dividend stability and sustainability, with the interim dividend expected to be paid on June 18.

site_title: GHY Culture & Media appoints substantial shareholder's wife as deputy CEO
summary: GHY Culture & Media Holding has appointed Lian Lee Lee, the wife of substantial shareholder John Ho, as deputy CEO, effective immediately. Lian Lee previously served as executive director and events director at GHY. The nominating committee confirmed she acts independently and does not influence Mr. Ho. Mr. Ho holds a 10.6% stake, while Lian Lee holds a 2.79% stake. The appointment was made after assessing her independence.

site_title: 36 per cent of business leaders still go with their 'gut' when making decisions: survey
summary: A survey by Talend found that 36% of business leaders rely on their "gut" when making decisions, citing challenges with data. The survey of 529 global executives from medium and large companies with annual revenue over $10 million found that 78% face data literacy challenges. In the sales and marketing sectors, nearly half make decisions without considering data, while only 52% of business leaders work on both sides of data production and use. To overcome these challenges, Talend suggests aligning data practices and creating cross-industry standard metrics.

site_title: NutryFarm reaps fruits of labour in Q2 from durian sale
summary: NutryFarm International, a nutrition and health food products company, reported a net profit of HK$457,000 (S$78,363) in Q2, reversing a net loss of HK$5 million the previous year. Revenue rose seven times to HK$41 million, driven by the sale of 35 containers of fresh durians, with subsidiary Global Agricapital Holdings contributing HK$27.9 million. The company expects Q3 revenue to increase and plans to diversify into the fruits business, citing reasonable prospects for profit contribution and positive cash flow.

site_title: What's missing in Singapore's startup scene?
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem has matured, boasting over 3,000 startups and nine unicorns, but faces supply gaps in tech talent and deep tech funding. Funding rounds are becoming larger, but concerns arise that VCs are over-investing in unprofitable businesses. Discipline and cash management are key issues, with some startups burning cash without a clear return on investment. Coaching and mentorship gaps also exist, with a need for more diverse and mental health support in the ecosystem. Exits remain uncertain, with the Singapore Exchange struggling to attract tech companies.

site_title: JD Logistics US$3.5b IPO draws SoftBank, Temasek
summary: JD Logistics, a Hong Kong-based warehousing and shipping firm, is set to raise up to $3.5 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) with SoftBank Vision Fund and Temasek Holdings Pte as cornerstone investors. Blackstone Group and Tiger Global also committed to buying shares. SoftBank will invest $600 million, accounting for 40% of the IPO, while Temasek will purchase $220 million worth of stock. The IPO, valued at $1.5 billion, is the second-largest in Hong Kong this year, following Kuaishou Technology's $6.2 billion listing in February.

site_title: US retail sales unchanged in April; prior month revised higher
summary: US retail sales remained unchanged in April after a 10.7% surge in March, defying economists' expectations of a 1.0% rise. The boost from stimulus checks faded, but record savings and a reopening economy are expected to drive sales in the coming months. Core retail sales dropped 1.5% excluding automobiles, gasoline, and food services, but consumer spending still expanded at a 10.7% annualized rate in the first quarter, driven by a surge in March.

images.alt_text: US retail sales unexpectedly stalled in April as the boost from stimulus checks faded, but an acceleration is likely in the coming months amid record savings and a reopening economy.

site_title: S'pore has adequate stocks, says Chan Chun Sing, amid long supermarket queues
summary: Singapore's supermarkets remain open during the COVID-19 tightened measures, with adequate stock levels, according to Trade and Industry Minister Chan Chun Sing. NTUC FairPrice chief executive Seah Kian Peng confirmed higher inventory and stockpiles, citing increased traffic and purchases since the announcement. Long queues formed at various supermarkets, with shoppers stocking up on essentials like rice, oil, and vegetables. Despite the crowds, officials assured that supermarkets will remain open, and customers are encouraged to buy only what they need to minimize pressure on the system.

site_title: STI falls 2.18 per cent to 9-week low as Singapore imposes social curbs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index plummeted 2.18% to a nine-week low of 3,055.02, its largest drop in nearly a year, amid fresh lockdown rules to combat rising Covid-19 cases. The local bourse outperformed regional peers, which finished higher following Wall Street gains. Economists warn that the restrictions will freeze short-term private consumption, but disruption to businesses is expected to be less severe than during the 2020 circuit breaker period.

site_title: Stricter measures to be imposed as nightlife operators pivoting to F&B flout rules
summary: Singapore will impose stricter measures on nightlife operators that have pivoted to the food and beverage (F&B) industry, after some continued to flout safe management measures. The Singapore Food Agency will revoke food licences of ex-nightlife operators found to breach rules, and nightlife operators must apply for planning permission to convert premises into F&B establishments. Enforcement measures include revoking public entertainment and liquor licences, and fines of up to S$2,000 for repeated offences.

site_title: UK probes Gupta for fraud over Greensill financing
summary: The UK's Serious Fraud Office has launched an investigation into Sanjeev Gupta's GFG Alliance, alleging suspected fraud, money laundering, and fraudulent trading related to financing arrangements with Greensill Capital UK. This probe follows months of scrutiny from lawmakers and the media over Greensill's financing practices. The UK Financial Conduct Authority is also investigating Greensill and cooperating with international authorities, including German, Australian, and Swiss regulators.

site_title: Capacity restrictions to deal heavy blow to events, attractions ahead of June holidays
summary: Capacity restrictions for events and attractions in Singapore will be reduced to 100 attendees with pre-event testing, and 50 without, from May 16 to June 13. This move aims to curb the spread of Covid-19, which has led to a recent spike in infections. The restrictions will also limit social gatherings to groups of two. The move is expected to deal a significant blow to the business event and attractions industries, which are struggling to recover from the pandemic.

site_title: Mandatory for diners to return trays and clear table litter from June 1
summary: Singapore will make it mandatory for diners to return their trays and clear table litter starting June 1. The National Environment Agency will implement a three-month advisory period, during which no enforcement action will be taken. Table litter includes used tissues, straws, canned drinks, and food remnants. The measure aims to reduce waste and promote a cleaner dining environment.

site_title: Economists retain Singapore's full-year GDP forecast for now despite tighter Covid-19 rules
summary: Singapore's full-year GDP forecast remains unchanged despite the implementation of tighter Covid-19 restrictions, which include a ban on dining-in and reduced social gatherings. The changes are expected to impact the services sector, but economists believe the economy's recovery is on track. Workplaces will revert to remote work as the default, reversing earlier measures. The restrictions are seen as a precautionary measure following the discovery of a new Covid-19 cluster at Changi Airport.

site_title: Olam unit gets US$1b loan to finance acquisition of US spice maker Olde Thompson
summary: Olam International has secured a $1 billion two-year loan to finance the acquisition of US spice maker Olde Thomson. The loan is guaranteed by Olam and will be used to acquire the company at an enterprise value of $950 million. This deal is part of Olam's strategy to expand its presence in the North American spices sector, combining its global origination and sustainable supply chains with Olde Thomson's capabilities. The acquisition aims to provide differentiated value to customers and align with Olam's purpose to "re-imagine global agriculture and food systems".

site_title: Hong Kong Q1 GDP rises 7.9% year on year after six quarters of contraction
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 7.9% in Q1 from a year earlier, ending six quarters of contraction. The growth was driven by a lower coronavirus threat and mainland China's recovery. The government maintains its 2021 GDP forecast of 3.5-5.5%. The Q1 growth rate compares to a 2.8% decline in the previous quarter and a 0.5% growth in the previous quarter.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close sharply higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed sharply higher on Friday, extending US rallies on Wall Street after a previous session's rout. The Nikkei 225 index rose 2.32% to 28,084.47, while the Topix index rose 1.86% to 1,883.42. The gains followed US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Japan widens virus emergency to three more prefectures
summary: Japan has declared a state of emergency in three more prefectures - Hokkaido, Okayama, and Hiroshima - due to a surge in infectious virus strain 10 weeks before the Tokyo Olympics. This move brings 19 of Japan's 47 prefectures under curbs, including an 8 pm closing deadline for eateries and a ban on alcohol at most bars and restaurants. The decision reflects growing concern about the pandemic and comes as the government faces criticism over its response. The state of emergency will run through May 31.

images.alt_text: Japan is declaring a state of emergency in three more prefectures hit hard by the Covid-19 pandemic, it said on Friday, in a surprise move that reflects growing concern about the spread of the coronavirus.

site_title: WealthBT: Claims-based pricing in Integrated Shield plans and how it works (Ep 1)
summary: Genevieve Cua, BT's wealth editor, discusses Integrated Shield policies and claims-based pricing in the first episode of the WealthBT podcast. She breaks down the debate and controversy surrounding certain aspects of coverage. Claims-based pricing is a key aspect of Integrated Shield plans, where premiums are calculated based on the actual medical claims made. This pricing model aims to provide more accurate and transparent pricing for policyholders.

site_title: Singapore unlikely to meet criteria to resume air travel with Hong Kong
summary: Singapore is unlikely to meet the criteria to resume air travel with Hong Kong, according to Transport Minister Ong Ye Kung. The planned air travel bubble (ATB) has been deferred for a second time due to rising community cases in Singapore. Ong has agreed with Hong Kong to "restart safely" and respect the mechanism, but a review of the start date will be conducted early next week.

site_title: Dining-in banned from May 16 to June 13, social gatherings limited to 2 per group
summary: Singapore is tightening COVID-19 restrictions, banning dining-in from May 16 to June 13 and limiting social gatherings to 2 per group. The measures come after a cluster at Changi Airport became the largest in Singapore, with 46 cases. Workplaces will revert to working from home as the default, and activities like strenuous indoor exercise classes and playing wind or brass instruments will be prohibited. The government aims to curb the spread of the virus amid rising infections.

site_title: Hong Kong government freezes assets of media tycoon Jimmy Lai
summary: Hong Kong's Security Bureau has frozen assets of jailed media tycoon Jimmy Lai Chee-ying, including shares of Next Digital Limited and property in local bank accounts, under the national security law. Lai was sentenced to 14 months in prison for participating in unauthorized assemblies during 2019 protests. This marks the first use of seizure powers granted to authorities under the law.

site_title: 52 new Covid-19 cases, including 24 in community
summary: Singapore reported 52 new Covid-19 cases, including 24 in the community, bringing the total tally to 61,505. The community cases include four unlinked cases and 13 linked to the Changi Airport cluster, now totaling 59 patients. Seven community cases are linked to previous cases. The new cases also include 28 imported cases placed on stay-home notice or isolation.

images.alt_text: Singapore reports 24 new Covid-19 community infections, including 13 linked to the Changi Airport cluster.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong shares ended a volatile week on a strong note, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.11% to 28,027.57. The rebound followed a sell-off in New York fueled by inflation fears. Meanwhile, China's Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also increased, with gains of 1.77% and 1.80%, respectively. The strong performance was attributed to a rebound in global markets following the US Federal Reserve's split views on interest rates.

site_title: Irish health service hit by ransomware attack
summary: Ireland's health service operator shut down its IT systems due to a significant ransomware attack, which affected national and local systems. The attack, described as sophisticated, impacted central servers but not hospital equipment. The vaccination programme remained unaffected. The Health Service Executive (HSE) is assessing the impact and protecting as much information as possible. One maternity hospital in Dublin cancelled outpatient appointments, except for those requiring urgent care.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street to end higher
summary: Australia's shares ended 0.5% higher on Friday, tracking a Wall Street rebound, despite posting their biggest weekly drop in 11 weeks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose, led by gains in banks and energy stocks, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia hitting a record high. Energy stocks also gained 1.7% after shedding nearly 2% over the week. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5% for an eighth straight session, its worst weekly performance since February.

site_title: Rosneft swings to US$2b Q1 net income
summary: Rosneft, Russia's largest oil producer, reported a net income of US$2 billion in the first quarter, up from a US$2.1 billion loss a year earlier. The company's earnings were boosted by a 20% annual increase in oil prices, supported by global production cuts. However, production declined to 3.75 million barrels per day due to the sale of mature assets to raise capital for its Vostok Oil project. Revenue edged down 1.2% to 1.7 trillion roubles, while Ebitda rose 44% year-over-year.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore government announced tighter Covid-19 measures from May 16 to June 13 to curb the recent spike in infections. New capacity restrictions for events and attractions will also be implemented ahead of the June holidays. The government raised wage support for F&B firms to 50% while prohibiting dining-in. The STI plummeted 2.18% to a nine-week low, while the government cited new biopharma injections to generate up to 500 jobs. A second meeting of the National Wage Council (NWC) will be held to develop new guidelines for staff compensation.

site_title: Straco Corp Q1 net loss narrows to S$390,000
summary: Straco Corp reported a Q1 net loss of S$390,000, narrowing from S$3.4 million last year. Revenue more than doubled to S$8.1 million, driven by positive growth at attractions in China and Singapore. Operating profit was S$19,000, compared to a loss of S$3.6 million last year. Despite losses, the company's financial position remains strong with S$156.9 million in net cash holdings. Straco will continue cost-cutting measures while prioritizing workforce well-being due to ongoing COVID-19 precautions.

site_title: New biopharma injections in Singapore to generate up to 500 jobs: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing announced new biopharma injections in Singapore, expected to generate up to 500 jobs in the sector. The investments, including S$630 million by Sanofi and S$170 million by Thermo Fisher, will also rejuvenate industrial estates, such as the Tuas Biomedical Park. The goal is to move Singapore into higher-value manufacturing, focusing on know-how and skills rather than cost. This aligns with the country's plans to become a global business, innovation, and talent hub for advanced manufacturing under Manufacturing 2030.

site_title: Singtel's billion-dollar impairment the right call after longtime earnings drag: Analysts
summary: Singtel reported a net exceptional loss of S$1.21 billion for the financial year, mainly due to impairments on its struggling digital business units, including Amobee and Trustwave. Analysts view the move as a necessary step to address earnings drag and position the company for growth. The impairments are expected to be offset by gains from the sale of Optus' towers in Australia and a dilution in Singtel's effective shareholding in Bharti Airtel. Singtel's new CEO, Yuen Kuan Moon, has embarked on a strategic review to sharpen the group's focus and ensure its assets are positioned for growth.

site_title: Tighter Covid-19 measures from May 16 to June 13
summary: The Singapore government has announced tighter COVID-19 measures from May 16 to June 13, including reducing social gatherings to two people, banning dining-in at F&B outlets, and increasing the Jobs Support Scheme rate to 50% of gross monthly wages. Capacity limits for events and public spaces will also be reduced, and work-from-home will be the default. Suspension of indoor 'mask-off' activities, such as strenuous exercise classes and singing, has been implemented. The measures aim to curb the spread of the virus amid a recent spike in infections.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks log biggest weekly drop in nearly 3 months
summary: South Korean stocks logged their biggest weekly drop in nearly three months, declining 1.37% as investors began to shrug off inflation worries. Despite this, the benchmark Kospi rose 31.21 points, or 1.00%, to 3,153.32. Foreigners were net sellers of 419.3 billion won worth of shares. The Kospi has risen 9.74% so far this year, and volatility from higher-than-expected US inflation figures seems to be easing.

site_title: Wage support for F&B firms raised to 50% while dining-in is prohibited
summary: Singapore's government has raised wage support for food and beverage establishments to 50% due to the prohibition of dining-in from May 16 to June 13. The move aims to curb the spread of Covid-19. Other restrictions include reducing social gathering sizes to two per group and implementing capacity limits for events and attractions. The measures will be in place for six weeks, with work-from-home becoming the default at workplaces.

site_title: STI down 2.9% amid tighter restrictions, possible air travel bubble delay
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 2.9% to 3,032.38, amid tighter COVID-19 restrictions and a possible delay in the air travel bubble between Singapore and Hong Kong. The multi-ministry task force announced new restrictions, including gatherings of only two people and dining-in bans, effective from Sunday to June 13. The STI also fell due to concerns over the largest coronavirus cluster at Changi Airport. The delay in the air travel bubble was also a major contributor to the decline, with key stocks such as DBS, UOB, and Singapore Airlines also falling.

site_title: Amazon extends hiring spree with 10,000 more permanent UK jobs
summary: Amazon plans to hire 10,000 more permanent UK jobs, bringing its total to 55,000 by the end of 2021. The new roles will be in corporate offices and Amazon Web Services across London, Manchester, Edinburgh, and Cambridge. UK Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng welcomed the announcement, calling it a "huge vote of confidence in the British economy." This comes after Amazon hired 500,000 people last year, taking its global headcount to 1.3 million.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant posted 21.8b yuan profit after IPO halt
summary: Ant Group, a fintech giant led by Jack Ma, posted a 21.8 billion yuan profit in the December quarter despite Chinese regulators halting its record IPO and scaling back its business. This translates to a 50% increase from the previous quarter, with Ant contributing nearly 7.2 billion yuan to Alibaba Group Holding's earnings. Regulators have proposed restrictions on Ant's dominance in online payments and consumer lending, potentially curtailing its growth prospects and reducing its valuation.

site_title: Pupils from Kong Hwa School and St Stephen's test positive for Covid-19; more schools move to home-based learning
summary: Two pupils from Kong Hwa School and St Stephen's School in Singapore have tested positive for Covid-19, prompting the schools to move to full home-based learning. This brings the total number of affected schools to at least five in the past two weeks. All close contacts will be placed on leave or quarantined, and both schools will be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. The move follows an increase in local Covid-19 cases, with the Ministry of Education urging students and staff to practice good hygiene and adhere to safe management measures.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars test depth of support after sharp weekly reversal
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars experienced sharp losses, with the Aussie falling to US$0.7722 and the kiwi dollar to US$0.7175, after failing to sustain breaks to upside. The losses are attributed to risk aversion and speculation about the Federal Reserve's potential to start tapering earlier than thought. The Australian dollar risks cracking support at US$0.7675, while the kiwi dollar faces a potential retracement to US$0.7000. Experts believe the AUD is undervalued against its fundamentals and may see upside in coming months.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH, Maybank KE, RHB maintain 'buy' on ComfortDelGro
summary: Three brokerages, UOBKH, Maybank KE, and RHB, have maintained a "buy" rating on ComfortDelGro, with UOBKH raising its target price to S$1.95. The companies cited ComfortDelGro's higher-than-expected net profit and positive operating leverage in their reports. The transport operator's public transport division saw a 5% fall in Q1 revenue, while its taxi business benefited from rental rebates. Analysts expect value unlocking through the monetization of ComfortDelGro's Australia business to offer additional re-rating potential.

site_title: Citi launches automated securities lending solution for wealth managers
summary: Citi has launched an automated securities lending solution for wealth managers, partnering with fintech company Sharegain. The solution allows global wealth management firms to offer securities lending to their customers without developing an internal program, typically only viable for large financial institutions. The solution provides a fully digital user experience, enabling customers to decide on securities, track loans, and recall securities at any time. This aims to democratize securities lending, making it more accessible to private investors in Asia.

site_title: Fisker and Foxconn to build electric cars in US
summary: Taiwanese tech giant Foxconn has partnered with US electric car startup Fisker to build a factory in the US, aiming to start production in late 2023. The joint venture aims to produce an affordable electric vehicle with a starting price under $30,000 and a projected annual volume of over 250,000 units. Foxconn will invest $355 million in electric car development and work with suppliers worldwide to ensure supply chain reliability. The partnership, dubbed "Project Pear," aims to make electric mobility more accessible to the mass market.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.55% or 424.51 points to 27,872.52. The broader Topix index gained 1.33% or 24.63 points to 1,873.67. Investors took heart from rallies on Wall Street, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. The positive sentiment was also attributed to the ongoing Asia-Pacific economic trends and the recent Airalo funding round.

site_title: Musk decries Bitcoin's 'insane' energy use after Tesla payment U-turn
summary: Elon Musk criticized Bitcoin's "insane" energy usage, doubling down on his decision to stop accepting the cryptocurrency as a payment method for Tesla's electric cars due to environmental concerns. The move led to a 17% drop in Bitcoin's value, but it rebounded to $50,360 on Thursday. Musk remains a strong believer in cryptocurrencies, but is looking at alternative options that use less energy. The decision is seen as a pressure on companies to consider the environmental impact of accepting cryptocurrencies as payment.

site_title: Huge Titanic replica to open as Chinese tourist destination
summary: A full-scale replica of the Titanic is set to open as a Chinese tourist destination, featuring a 260-meter-long vessel with authentic details, including dining rooms and luxury cabins. The project, backed by investor Su Shaojun, has taken six years to complete and cost around $205 million. The replica will be the centerpiece of a theme park in Sichuan province, with plans to attract up to 5 million annual visitors. Despite controversy over the project's feasibility, Su hopes to keep memories of the Titanic alive and make a profit.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets climb at open
summary: European stock markets rose 0.6% at the open on Friday, driven by a strong recovery in Asia amid concerns over high inflation. London's FTSE 100 index rose to 7,002.36 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 and Paris CAC 40 indices also gained 0.6%. The gains followed a week of losses in global equities.

site_title: Outlook too uncertain for new guidelines, but staff should be rewarded fairly: NWC
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) has extended its guidelines on wages and employment until November 30, citing an uncertain and uneven economic outlook. The guidelines, originally set to expire on June 30, remain relevant and encourage businesses to reward employees fairly, particularly those doing well. Businesses should re-evaluate their situations and consider built-in wage increases, while those still struggling should continue to use government support schemes and implement cost-saving measures. A second meeting of the NWC is scheduled for later this year to develop new guidelines, which will apply from December 1.

site_title: Hot stock: Sheng Siong jumps 11.3% on F&B curbs; aviation stocks slide
summary: Sheng Siong's shares surged 11.3% after Singapore's multi-ministry task force announced tighter restrictions on food and beverage operators, including group gatherings of two instead of five and a ban on dining-in. The government will also raise its wage support for F&B establishments to 50% from 10%. Aviation stocks, including SIA Engineering, SATS, and Singapore Airlines, tumbled after the planned air travel bubble between Singapore and Hong Kong was likely to be delayed.

site_title: Foxconn profit leaps as Covid-19 drives demand for work-from-home devices
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn reported a 13-fold increase in first-quarter profit to T$28.2 billion, exceeding forecasts, amid the work-from-home boom driven by the Covid-19 pandemic. The company expects revenue growth of over 15% for consumer electronics and computing products in the second quarter, driven by demand for devices like smartphones and laptops. This surge in demand has helped Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, recover from the pandemic's impact on its business.

site_title: In surprise move, Japan adds three more prefectures to virus state of emergency
summary: Japan has declared a state of emergency in three more prefectures, Hokkaido, Okayama, and Hiroshima, due to the Covid-19 pandemic, bringing the total to eight prefectures under the declaration until May 31. The move comes as the country grapples with a surge of a more infectious strain of the virus, just 10 weeks before the Tokyo Olympics. Experts express concerns over medical resources being pushed to the brink and Japan's slow vaccination rate, with only 3% of the population vaccinated.

site_title: US brings back climate change website detailing ongoing threats
summary: The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has released its climate indicators website, detailing ongoing threats from climate change, after years of delays during the Trump administration. The new data shows Americans are already feeling the effects, including more frequent and intense heat waves, wildfires, and flooding. The EPA Administrator, Michael Regan, calls the relaunch "long overdue" and emphasizes the need for meaningful action. The data also highlights rising sea levels, melting ice sheets, and changes in marine life.

site_title: DBS Private Bank launches trust solution for cryptocurrencies
summary: DBS Private Bank has launched a trust solution for cryptocurrencies, allowing its private banking clients to invest, custody, and manage digital assets such as Bitcoin, Ether, and XRP. The solution, available only to institutional and accredited investors, aims to cater to growing interest in crypto assets among high-net-worth clients. The trust structure ensures confidentiality and avoids probate process complications, providing peace of mind for clients and their beneficiaries. The move follows similar initiatives by other major banks, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Golden Agri, IReit Global, ComfortDelGro, Sakae, AusGroup, Top Glove, Hatten Land
summary: Singapore stocks to watch: Singtel expects significant net exceptional losses, Golden Agri swung back into the black, IReit Global reported a 95.9% portfolio occupancy, and Top Glove shares rose 1.8% after a shipment of latex gloves was seized due to suspected forced labor. Meanwhile, AusGroup posted a net profit, and Hatten Land's net loss widened. Other companies reported significant revenue gains, including Geo Energy and Frencken Group.

images.alt_text: Golden Agri swung back into the black with a net profit of US$41 million for its first quarter ended March 31, 2021.

site_title: Singtel flags exceptional charges of S$839m for H2, starts strategic review of subsidiaries
summary: Singtel has launched a strategic review of two key subsidiaries amid significant impairments leading to exceptional losses of S$839m and S$1.21 billion for the second half and financial year ended March 31, 2021. The group's CFO, Arthur Lang, considers these costs "conservative" due to industry challenges and the pandemic. The company will report its H2 and FY2021 results on May 27.

site_title: Capacity limits cut for events, attractions, libraries to curb spread of Covid-19
summary: Singapore has cut capacity limits for events, attractions, libraries, and other venues from May 16 to June 13 to curb the spread of Covid-19. Capacity limits will be reduced to 100 for events and attractions with pre-event testing, and 50 without testing. Cinemas will limit attendance to 100 with testing, and 50 without. Museums, libraries, and shopping malls will operate at 25% capacity. Wedding receptions, congregational services, and funerals will also be affected, with some restrictions on attendance and gatherings.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.56% on Friday, tracking a rebound on Wall Street after a sharp decline fueled by inflation fears. The Hang Seng Index reached 27,872.69, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.19%. The Shenzhen Composite Index surged 7.12% on China's second exchange. The gains followed a rebound on Wall Street, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Prince Harry says moved to US to 'break cycle' of family 'pain and suffering'
summary: Prince Harry revealed in an interview that he moved his family to California to "break a cycle" of "pain and suffering" within the royal family, after realizing his father Prince Charles treated him similarly. Harry said he wants to avoid repeating the same mistakes with his own children and is now living in the US with his wife Meghan and son, expecting a daughter.

site_title: 'Friends' cast joined by Bieber, Beckham for May 27 reunion special
summary: The cast of "Friends" will reunite on HBO Max on May 27 for a special, with guests including Justin Bieber, David Beckham, Lady Gaga, and BTS. The reunion, titled "The One Where They Get Back Together," was delayed due to the coronavirus pandemic but will now debut exactly one year after HBO Max's launch. The six original cast members, including Jennifer Aniston and Matt LeBlanc, will reportedly earn $2.5 million each for participating. The special was filmed at the original "Friends" soundstage in Los Angeles.

site_title: New York City renters grabbing apartment deals as they plot office returns
summary: New York City renters are taking advantage of falling rents and empty office units to secure apartment deals closer to their future workplaces. With many employees still working remotely, renters are trying to snag bargains for when they return to the office. Empty units are piling up on the market, making it an ideal time for renters to find affordable options. As office employees plan their returns, the demand for apartments near office buildings is expected to increase, creating a new market trend.

site_title: Asia pares losses on bargain-buying but inflation fears remain
summary: Asia's markets recovered some losses due to bargain-buying after a week of steep declines, driven by a rally on Wall Street and a forecast-beating jobless claims report. Investors are still concerned about inflation fears, but analysts say a positive economic backdrop supports the value trade. The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq rose over 1%, while 10-year Treasuries eased, providing a boost to Asian markets. Despite some losses, Asia's markets remain upbeat, with Tokyo and Taipei indices climbing 1.8% and 1.3%, respectively.

site_title: Alibaba vows to hike spending after first loss in years
summary: Alibaba Group has forecast better-than-expected revenue and pledged to invest in new growth areas, signaling its intention to move past a Chinese antitrust probe that triggered its first loss in nine years. The company reported a 5.5 billion yuan net loss in 2021, but expects revenue to rise at least 30% to over 930 billion yuan in the year ending March 2022. CEO Daniel Zhang vowed to refocus on the business, plowing all incremental profit back into technology and community commerce. Despite this, analysts remain cautious, citing uncertainty in the broader clampdown on Alibaba and its rivals.

site_title: More snapping up luxe condos even as new private home sales in April slow
summary: Singapore's private home sales in April 2021 reached 1,342 units, easing 2.3% from March. Despite a slight dip in overall sales, luxury condos were in high demand, with 91 homes sold above S$3 million, a 27% increase from March. Central regions led the sales, driven by new launches like Irwell Hill Residences and One-North Eden. Developers attribute the uptrend to a brighter economic outlook and buyers' growing confidence in the property market. However, some analysts suggest buyer fatigue may be setting in, with subdued sales at two high-end launches.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.5% at the open on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) slipping to 3,108.17. The decline was attributed to a rise in community cases and Covid-19 clusters in the country. The most active counter was Sembcorp Marine, which dropped 1.1%, while Singtel fell 1.3% and DBS rose 0.2%. In contrast, US stocks rebounded after three down sessions, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 1.3% and the S&P 500 rising 1.2%.

site_title: AIA's new business value jumps 25% in rebound from pandemic slump
summary: Asia-focussed insurer AIA Group Ltd reported a 25.1% rise in first-quarter new business value, rebounding from pandemic disruptions in its main markets Hong Kong and China. The value of new business rose to $1.05 billion, up from $841 million a year earlier. AIA's mainland China business achieved "excellent growth" and its Hong Kong domestic customer segment recorded double-digit VONB growth. The insurer attributed the momentum to easing movement restrictions.

site_title: Disney sees positive signs for business as streaming growth cools
summary: Disney reported positive signs of recovery across its businesses, despite slower-than-expected growth of its streaming service Disney+. The company ended the quarter with nearly 104 million subscribers and saw revenue of US$15.6 billion, down 13% from the same period last year. Net income was US$901 million. Disney chief executive Bob Chapek stated that the company is focused on ramping up operations and fueling long-term growth. The company's theme parks and resorts, which were severely impacted by COVID-19, are showing signs of recovery.

images.alt_text: The Walt Disney Company on Thursday said it was seeing "encouraging signs of recovery" across a wide range of its businesses while its streaming television service grew slower than expected in the recently ended quarter.

site_title: HNWs in Singapore place bets on crypto going mainstream
summary: Singapore-based investors are optimistic about the mainstreaming of cryptocurrency, following Coinbase's direct listing in April. Venture firm Signum Capital, backed by the family of a Singaporean property tycoon, has invested in over 70 blockchain-enabled projects, including imToken and Velo Labs. Investors, including Dutchman Wouter Kneepkens, who invested in Coinbase in its seed round, see the industry as having "outsized returns potential" and are seeking exposure to crypto through their funds. The success of Coinbase's IPO and the growing interest in blockchain technology suggest that crypto is becoming more mainstream, with investors hoping for big payoffs from their stakes in crypto and blockchain projects.

site_title: Mainland China reports first local Covid-19 cases in over three weeks
summary: Mainland China reported 7 new Covid-19 cases on May 13, including 2 local transmissions in Anhui province, its first local cases in over 3 weeks. The other 5 cases were imported infections. China's total confirmed cases rose to 90,815, with the death toll remaining at 4,636. Authorities in Lu'an city are conducting mass testing in response to the cases, and the city's main urban area has been declared a "medium risk" zone.

site_title: Boeing wins US regulators OK for 737 MAX electrical fix
summary: Boeing has received US regulator approval for a fix to an electrical grounding issue affecting about 100 737 MAX airplanes. The fix, which is expected to take 3-4 days, was deemed "pretty straightforward" by FAA Administrator Steve Dickson. The move clears the way for the planes' quick return to service, relieving airlines anxious to get them back into the air as air travel demand increases ahead of the summer season.

site_title: India's prized 'investment grade' status hanging by a thread
summary: India's investment grade credit rating is under threat due to its severe Covid-19 crisis, with S&P, Moody's, and Fitch warning of a downgrade. The country's debt level is expected to reach a record 90% of GDP this year, sparking concerns among investors. Despite this, some analysts believe India's economy will bounce back quickly, while others warn of a 50/50 chance of a downgrade. A downgrade could have significant consequences, including exclusion from high-profile investment indexes and increased borrowing costs.

site_title: Stay home this weekend given growing Covid-19 cases in the community: Masagos
summary: Singaporean residents are advised to stay home this weekend due to the growing number of Covid-19 cases in the community, with 24 new cases reported on Thursday, the highest daily number since July 11 last year. The cases are linked to a cluster at Changi Airport, which now has 46 cases. Minister Masagos Zulkifli urged everyone to stay at home and go out only if necessary, emphasizing the need to follow safe management measures. The government is concerned about the increasing cases and the risk of another circuit breaker.

site_title: Major US pipeline delivering fuel but shortages continue
summary: The US pipeline network shut down by a cyber attack has resumed fuel deliveries, but gas stations along the east coast continue to face shortages. President Joe Biden hailed the "good news" and urged calm, stating supplies will return to normalcy over the next week. The Colonial Pipeline paid a $5 million ransom to hackers, contradicting reports of no payment. The incident highlights the need for improved IT security and has led to a national average gas price of over $3 a gallon for the first time since 2014.

site_title: Australia calls for empowering WHO
summary: Australia has called for the World Health Organization (WHO) to be given greater powers to investigate outbreaks, citing a need for increased independence and authority. An independent panel found that the early response to the COVID-19 outbreak in China lacked urgency, and the pandemic was preventable. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken expressed support for Australia's stance, criticizing China for not allowing timely access to international experts and real transparency. The US has reversed a decision to leave the WHO, citing its positive work and a desire to improve it from within, amid pressure from Beijing.

site_title: Hyflux subsidiary disputes alleged termination of Algerian O&M contract
summary: Hyflux's subsidiary, Hyflux Operation & Maintenance Algeria (HOMA), is disputing the alleged termination of its operations and maintenance (O&M) contract for the Magtaa seawater desalination plant in Algeria. The contract was terminated by TMM, the project owner, on April 20. HOMA is seeking to resolve the matter with TMM, according to a regulatory update by Hyflux's judicial managers, Borrelli Walsh.

site_title: Sunpower's Q1 profit falls 61% due to fair value changes on convertible bonds, warrants
summary: Sunpower Group, a provider of clean power solutions, reported a 61% decline in Q1 profit to 85.2 million yuan due to fair value changes on convertible bonds and warrants. Revenue rose 31.2% to 882.9 million yuan, driven by growth in the green investments segment.
