summary: ST Engineering's aviation asset management unit has signed a 50-50 joint venture with Temasek to build a US$600m portfolio of freighter aircraft within five years. The JV aims to convert passenger aircraft into efficient freighters to address the growing demand for freighter aircraft due to e-commerce and air cargo expansion. The company also plans to securitize leasing income streams through a business trust in the medium to long term.

site_title: Thailand seeking 'humanitarian' solution for detained Myanmar journalists
summary: Thailand is seeking a "humanitarian" solution for three Myanmar journalists arrested after crossing the border, amid concerns they could face persecution if returned to the coup-hit country. The journalists, employed by the Democratic Voice of Burma (DVB), were charged with illegal entry and could face detention while an investigation unfolds. Thai authorities and the DVB urge the authorities not to deport them, citing the risk of danger to their lives. Protests against the military rule continue in Myanmar, with the 100th day of democracy demands marked by crowds chanting "We want democracy."

site_title: Nine killed, many wounded in Russian school shooting
summary: A lone teenage gunman, 19, opened fire at a school in Kazan, Russia, killing 9 people, including 7 children, and wounding many others. The attack prompted a Kremlin call for tighter gun controls. The suspect, a registered gun owner, was arrested and claimed he had become a "god" and began to hate everyone, according to investigators. This is Russia's deadliest school shooting since 2018.

site_title: Bodies float down Ganges as nearly 4,000 more die of Covid-19 in India
summary: Scores of bodies are washing up on the banks of the Ganges in India as the country's Covid-19 death toll surpasses 400,000, with nearly 4,000 deaths reported daily. India's overwhelmed health system is struggling to cope with the surge, with rural areas running short of wood for traditional cremations. The World Health Organization has classified the Indian coronavirus variant as a global concern, and vaccines are also in short supply, particularly in Maharashtra and Delhi. The government is investigating the discovery of bodies in the Ganges and has imposed tougher restrictions to combat the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Scores of bodies are washing up on the banks of the Ganges as Indians fail to keep pace with the deaths and cremations of around 4,000 people a day from the novel coronavirus.

site_title: Norway to spend record US$50b of oil wealth on recovery
summary: Norway's government plans to spend a record US$50 billion from its US$1.3 trillion sovereign wealth fund to support its economy during the pandemic recovery. This represents a significant increase from last year's deficit of S$59.3 billion. The withdrawals will account for 3.7% of the fund, exceeding the central bank's initial estimate of 3.3%. The move is seen as a sign that the government believes a larger fiscal support is needed this year.

site_title: Excelpoint's Q1 net profit up 18 times to US$4.4m
summary: Excelpoint Technology, an electronics component distributor, reported a 19-fold increase in Q1 net profit to US$4.4 million, driven by higher demand for semiconductors. Revenue rose 32.9% to US$336.3 million, mainly due to sales growth in Singapore and Hong Kong. Gross profit increased 80.2% to US$23.4 million. The company's strong performance is attributed to accelerated technology adoption.

site_title: Taiwan tightens restrictions after new domestic Covid cases
summary: Taiwan has tightened public gathering restrictions after reporting six new domestic COVID-19 cases with no clear source of infection. The government has cancelled outdoor activities of over 500 people and indoor activities of 100 or more until June 8. This move comes after a rare rise in domestic cases, which has kept the pandemic well under control on the island. The restrictions are part of efforts to track down those who had been in contact with the infected and ensure social distancing measures.

site_title: Selfridges to offer wedding ceremonies at luxury London store
summary: Selfridges in London is offering wedding ceremonies in its luxury store for a limited time, allowing couples to get married with up to 20 guests. The store's temporary license will provide three different wedding packages, including hair and makeup appointments, clothing rental, and a four-hour DJ set. This initiative aims to meet the growing demand for wedding venues and offer a unique alternative during the pandemic. The ceremonies will take place in a designated "wedding suite" on the fourth floor.

site_title: Riverstone's Q1 net profit soars to RM522.7m
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a net profit of RM522.7 million for the first quarter of 2021, a 11-fold increase from the previous year. Revenue rose to RM1 billion, the largest quarterly revenue since 2017, with gross profit reaching RM708.3 million. This marks a significant improvement from the previous year's RM46.6 million net profit.

site_title: Relief for construction industry to share Covid-19 impact; Redas flags 'heavy burden'
summary: Singapore's construction industry has welcomed relief measures to share the burden of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) has flagged the "heavy burden" that developers have shouldered, but industry players have raised concerns over the parameters of the amended law and its impact on relationships. The government aims to ensure no single stakeholder group bears an "undue share" of the burden. Relief measures include adjustments for higher foreign manpower costs, easing the impact of border restrictions. However, disputes over contract costs and the lack of clear guidelines are expected to arise.

site_title: Europe: Inflation nerves drive stocks' worst sell-off in three weeks
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.9% on Tuesday, their worst sell-off in three weeks, amid concerns about rising US inflation. Travel, retail, and technology shares were hit hard, with the Stoxx 600 index poised for its biggest percentage decline since April 2021. Investors are wary of the Federal Reserve rethinking its monetary policy stance, and US tech stocks are expected to face further sell-off.

site_title: Twirl and spin: Damascus family preserves Sufi whirling tradition
summary: In Damascus, Syria, the Kharrat family has preserved the Sufi whirling tradition, a moving meditation seeking communion with the divine. The family's 20 dervish dancers, including 3-year-old Anas al-Kharrat, perform during the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, bringing relief from the conflict's economic crisis and pandemic. Whirling, a popular practice in Iran, Afghanistan, and Turkey, is a way for Sufis to reach God through prayer and humility. The Kharrats continue to perform locally, with evening shows during Ramadan being their last hope to make a living.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes down more than 3% on tech sell-off
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei index closed down more than 3% on Tuesday due to a tech sell-off, following a plunge in the Nasdaq on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 3.08% to 28,608.59, while the Topix index fell 2.37% to 1,905.92.

site_title: EC World Reit's Q1 DPU up 32.3%
summary: EC World Reit's Q1 distribution per unit (DPU) rose 32.3% to 1.532 Singapore cents, driven by a 30.9% increase in gross revenue and net property income to S$30.8 million and S$27.7 million, respectively. Occupancy of its eight properties was 99.1% as of March 31. The company retained 10% of distributable amount due to pandemic uncertainties, with distributions expected on June 29. Aggregate leverage was 38.3%, with a gearing ratio of not more than 40% for prudent financial management.

site_title: Ji Liang Gardens in Marine Parade up for collective sale with S$18.6m reserve price
summary: Ji Liang Gardens in Marine Parade is up for collective sale with a reserve price of S$18.6 million. The freehold residential development, comprising six units, sits on a 14,289 sq ft site zoned for residential use. The site has potential for redevelopment into 18 apartment units with an average size of 1,076 sq ft each. The tender exercise closes on June 15, and PropNex attributes the site's appeal to its rarity of fresh supply of residential land in the area.

site_title: Parking lot in the Pacific persists as imports jam US ports
summary: The US West Coast ports, particularly Los Angeles and Long Beach, continue to face congestion issues with 19 container ships waiting to enter the ports as of Monday. This is partly due to a decrease in ships going straight to the anchor queue, with 65% of arriving vessels waiting in April, down from 90% in February. The average wait for berth space was 6.6 days, and the cost to ship a container from Asia to the US is rising again. Bottlenecks on land remain, with containers taking an average of 3.9 days to clear terminals and 7.5 days to reach railroads.

site_title: NTUC, SCCCI to help SMEs with hiring efforts
summary: NTUC's Employment and Employability Institute (e2i) is collaborating with the Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce & Industry (SCCCI) to support local small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in their hiring efforts. Eight trade associations under SCCCI have joined forces to fill over 1,000 positions across various sectors, with a focus on Professional, Manager, Executive, and Technician (PMET) level jobs. The initiative aims to bridge manpower gaps and help SMEs cope with post-pandemic challenges.

site_title: Apple faces UK class action for app overcharging
summary: Apple faces a London lawsuit over claims it overcharged nearly 20 million UK customers for App Store purchases, with the claimants alleging the 30% standard fee is "excessive" and "unlawful". The suit, filed at the Competition Appeal Tribunal, seeks compensation for years of alleged overcharging, with estimated damages potentially exceeding £1.5 billion. This follows a US trial over Epic Games' claims that Apple is running its marketplace like a monopoly, and comes as Apple faces a global backlash over its fees and policies.

site_title: Covid certificate will be a signal for travel in EU, Germany says
summary: Germany's Europe Minister Michael Roth expressed hope for a swift agreement on a Covid-19 certificate that would allow vaccinated, recovered, or tested individuals to travel more easily in the European Union. The "green certificate" is expected to be introduced in June, but talks between the European Commission, EU lawmakers, and governments have yet to reach an agreement. Roth emphasized the importance of the certificate as a signal for freedom of movement and mobility in the EU, particularly ahead of the summer holiday season.

site_title: Australia: Shares pull back from record closing highs as inflation worries drag
summary: Australian shares pulled back from a record closing high on Tuesday, slipping 1.1% to 7,097, as tech stocks fell 4.5% amid concerns about inflation and potential US interest rate hikes. Investors worried about rising commodity prices and the impact on the US Federal Reserve's decisions. Consumer staple stocks were the only gainers, finishing 0.2% higher. The decline follows a record high on Monday and is attributed to a combination of inflationary chat and profit-taking.

site_title: EU says willing to give AstraZeneca more time for vaccine deliveries
summary: The European Union is willing to accept a delayed delivery of AstraZeneca's Covid-19 vaccines, agreeing to a revised contract that would see 120 million doses delivered by the end of June instead of the originally agreed-upon June deadline. In exchange, the EU would accept the full contract of 300 million doses only by the end of September. This move comes as the EU seeks to fulfill its contract with AstraZeneca, which has so far delivered only 50 million doses.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks hit 7-week low on anti-trust worries, tech sell-off
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted to a seven-week low on Tuesday, with the Hang Seng index falling 2.0% to 28,013.81, as tech sell-off on Wall Street and anti-monopoly fears weighed on tech giants. The Hang Seng tech index dropped 3% to a six-month low, with leading stocks down 30% from their record high. The decline follows a global tech sell-off, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Forestry firm Stora Enso to supply Diageo pulp for paper whisky bottles
summary: Forestry firm Stora Enso will supply Diageo with pulp for paper whisky bottles. This partnership aims to reduce the environmental impact of Diageo's packaging by using sustainable materials. Stora Enso's commitment to forestry sustainability and Diageo's efforts to minimize waste align with the company's goals. The collaboration is seen as a step towards a more eco-friendly whisky industry.

site_title: Taiwan says China is 'maliciously' blocking it from WHO
summary: Taiwan accused China of "maliciously" blocking its access to the World Health Organization (WHO), despite the US and G-7 calling for the island's attendance at the WHO's World Health Assembly. China claims Taiwan is part of China and refuses to allow it to participate in global health matters. Taiwan's foreign ministry says China is lying and prioritizing politics over people's well-being. The WHO's principal legal officer stated that Taiwan's participation would require a vote, and China can easily block it.

site_title: Forestry firm Stora Enso to supply Diageo pulp for paper whisky bottles
summary: Finnish forestry firm Stora Enso will supply pulp for sustainable packaging company Pulpex, a venture of Diageo, to produce paper bottles for various brands, including Johnnie Walker whisky. The partnership aims to reduce plastic use and increase recycling, aligning with the European Union's goal to halve waste by 2030. A scalable production line is set to be built in 2022, with the goal of producing 750 million paper bottles annually.

site_title: Britain lowers NatWest stake with US$1.5b share sale
summary: The British government has completed the sale of US$1.55 billion in shares of NatWest, lowering its stake to below 55% in the lender it bailed out in 2008. The sale, priced at 190 pence per share, resulted in a further £1.8 billion loss for taxpayers. NatWest shares fell 4% in early trading, and the bank is now closer to private ownership, reducing the government's holding from 60% previously. The sale follows a £45 billion bailout in 2008 and a £1.1 billion share buyback last month.

site_title: Social media in South-east Asia: skeptical Singaporeans rank first
summary: A study conducted by Blackbox Research found that Singaporeans are the most skeptical about social media giants' data usage in South-east Asia, with only 22% comfortable with how their data is being used. This is despite Singapore's reputation as a digital economy leader. Singaporeans are also less reliant on social media for news and have a higher percentage (38%) not getting their news from social media. Regulators and social media giants must work together to build trust in the digital economy, according to Blackbox Research CEO David Black.

images.alt_text: JUST one in five (22 per cent) Singaporeans are comfortable with how their data is being used by social media giants.

site_title: New sales in Singapore life insurance sector up 29% to S$1.25b in Q1
summary: Singapore's life insurance sector recorded S$1.25 billion in weighted new business premiums in Q1 2021, a 29% increase from the previous year. Online sales of life insurance policies grew 88,565 in Q1, while single-premium products saw a 85% quarter-on-quarter increase. Annual premium products also saw a 5% year-on-year increase, and 20,000 more Singaporeans were covered by Integrated Shield plans. Despite a 2% dip in retirement policy counts, the industry's workforce remains stable with 40 new hires, and the LIA is focusing on capacity building and digitalization.

site_title: Philippines' GDP contraction narrows to 4.2% in Q1 amid tenuous recovery
summary: The Philippines' GDP contracted by 4.2% in Q1, marking the fifth straight quarter of decline, amid lingering uncertainties from the Covid-19 pandemic and vaccine rollout. The country's economic recovery remains tenuous, with household consumption subdued due to high unemployment and limited savings. The central bank is expected to keep interest rates steady, guarding against inflationary pressures. A wider and more effective vaccination roll-out and government spending are seen as key factors to sustain solid growth revival in the second half of the year.

site_title: Malaysia's GDP slump eases in Q1 on export recovery
summary: Malaysia's economy contracted 0.5% in Q1, less sharply than forecast, as domestic spending improved and external demand rebounded. The economy has been recovering from a 5.6% contraction in 2020 due to COVID-19 restrictions. A recent spike in cases led to a nationwide lockdown, but the central bank expects the impact to be "less severe" and growth to remain within the 6-7.5% range for 2021.

site_title: Renewable energy powers ahead in 2020: report
summary: Renewable energy production capacity increased by 45% in 2020, with 280 GW added, the largest gain since 1999. This growth was driven primarily by wind power and China, which accounted for 50% of new renewable energy production. The International Energy Agency expects 270 GW of renewable capacity to be added in 2021 and 280 GW in 2022. Renewable energy accounted for 90% of new electricity generation installed last year, with wind turbines nearly doubling and solar panels hitting 160 GW by 2022.

site_title: IBM launches new cloud, AI services in bid to modernise business
summary: IBM launches Watson Orchestrate, a cloud-based tool that uses AI to automate tasks across sales, human resources, and operations functions. The product will be compatible with Slack, email, and popular business applications like Salesforce and SAP. Watson Orchestrate aims to help businesses modernize and capitalize on the rise of chatbots and virtual assistants. The product is expected to be available later this year, marking IBM's pivot toward cloud services and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Indian doctors warn against cow dung as Covid cure
summary: Indian doctors are warning against the practice of using cow dung to ward off Covid-19, citing no scientific evidence for its effectiveness and potential health risks. The practice, which originated from Hindu rituals, has gained popularity in Gujarat, with believers covering their bodies in cow dung and urine in hopes of boosting immunity. Experts say this could spread other diseases and hinder the fight against the pandemic. The Indian Medical Association has repeatedly warned against alternative treatments for Covid-19.

site_title: Qantas selling fly-me-to-the-Moon tickets as Covid drags on
summary: Qantas is offering a unique flight experience, "Fly Me to the Supermoon," departing Sydney on May 26 to witness a total lunar eclipse. Passengers will board a Boeing 787 Dreamliner and ascend to 43,000 feet for a viewing of the supermoon, accompanied by an astronomer providing commentary. The night flight will include pre-flight drinks and entertainment in the Qantas lounge. Tickets are priced at A$1,499 (S$1,560) for business class.

site_title: SLNG, Surbana Jurong, institutes to explore development of green modular data centre system
summary: SLNG, Surbana Jurong, and three institutions have collaborated to explore a green modular data centre system. The system aims to save 0.2 megawatts of power by utilizing chilled seawater from the Singapore Liquefied Natural Gas Terminal. The prototype, which will be installed with a supercomputer, demonstrates industrial symbiosis, where one industry's waste is converted into another's resource. If successful, the system could reduce the terminal's heat generated, showcasing a sustainable solution for data centre operations.

site_title: Australia's Victoria on alert after first Covid-19 case in two months
summary: Victoria, Australia, reported its first locally acquired Covid-19 case in over two months, with a man in his 30s testing positive after returning from overseas and completing hotel quarantine in South Australia. The infected person developed flu-like symptoms after arriving in Victoria last Tuesday. Authorities are searching for the source of the infection and have asked close contacts to undergo tests and self-isolate. This case follows a reported case in New South Wales, where authorities are still trying to identify the transmission path between cases.

site_title: GST voucher scheme to be enhanced: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's GST voucher scheme will be enhanced, with the goal of offsetting more GST payable by lower-income households. Currently, the bottom quintile of households receive more in vouchers than they pay in GST. The enhancement aims to address this issue, with Minister Lawrence Wong stating the scheme will be improved "on top of this".

site_title: Seoul: Stocks retreat from record close on tech rout, US inflation worries
summary: South Korean stocks fell 1.23% to close at 3,209.43, snapping a four-day winning streak, as chip heavyweights tracked an overnight tech sell-off on Wall Street. Investors await US inflation data, causing the won and bond yield to decline.

site_title: 30 fully vaccinated people test positive for Covid-19, majority asymptomatic: Gan Kim Yong
summary: Singapore's Health Minister Gan Kim Yong reported that 30 fully vaccinated individuals have tested positive for Covid-19, with 57% being asymptomatic. Among the 43 cases in a recent cluster, 7 fully vaccinated staff and 2 patients were infected, with none requiring oxygen support. The B.1.617.2 variant, more transmissible than others, was detected. Gan urged all Singaporeans to get vaccinated, stating that while vaccination does not eliminate the risk of infection, it provides critical protection against severe reactions and reduces transmission.

site_title: Hong Kong scraps plan to require vaccines for domestic workers
summary: Hong Kong has scrapped its plan to require foreign domestic workers to be vaccinated to secure work visas, citing potential legal problems and criticism that the policy was discriminatory. The policy change comes after a small outbreak of a Covid-19 variant infected some domestic workers, prompting authorities to test around 340,000 workers. Despite this, the city has handled the pandemic relatively well, with fewer than 12,000 total cases reported since the start of the pandemic. A second round of tests for foreign domestic workers will still be required by May 30.

site_title: Asia: Markets tumble as inflation fears haunt trading floors
summary: Asian markets tumbled on Tuesday as investors grew concerned about a surge in inflation that could force central banks to wind back their monetary policies earlier than forecast. The US retail sales and consumer prices data, set to be released this week, is expected to show a sharp rise, fueling worries about costs spiraling. Despite Federal Reserve assurances, inflation concerns continue to hover over trading floors, with Asia's major markets, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai, down more than 2% on the day.

site_title: SoftBank to invest US$60m in Malaysia's Axiata AI unit
summary: SoftBank Corp will invest US$60 million in Axiata AI's ADA unit, valuing it at US$260 million. SoftBank will hold 23% of ADA via new shares, with plans to use the funds to expand in South and South-east Asia. The investment will also establish ADA as SoftBank's core digital and data marketing partner in Asia. ADA aims to become a US$2 billion business over the next five years, leveraging proprietary technologies and consumer AI models. This marks SoftBank's second investment in ADA, following a 2018 US$20 million investment by Sumitomo Corp.

images.alt_text: SoftBank will own 23 per cent of ADA via new shares, with its investment valuing the unit at US$260 million.

site_title: 3-pronged approach to reduce Singapore's exposure to carbon trading risks: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore aims to reduce its exposure to carbon trading risks through a 3-pronged approach. The government will develop a taxonomy and guidelines for carbon credits, explore technology to improve credit verification, and establish a marketplace for transparency. This will help companies undertaking commercial agreements in carbon offset activities. The country also plans to invest in low-carbon technologies, foster international collaboration, and become a leading carbon services and trading hub. Singapore's robust financial foundation positions it to grow an internationally trusted carbon ecosystem in Asia.

site_title: Two Japanese regional banks eye tie-up to fight margin pressures
summary: Two Japanese regional banks, Aomori Bank and Michinoku Bank, are considering a business consolidation to combat narrowing margins due to Japan's rapidly ageing population and ultra-low interest rates. The deal, if successful, would be the first under a revised law exempting regional bank consolidations from antitrust rules. The move aims to strengthen the regional economy and follows a report by NHK that the banks are in talks to consolidate, giving them a 70% share in the prefecture. The deal is seen as a response to years of ultra-loose monetary policy and dwindling regional population eroding regional bank profits.

site_title: Former manager at BP and businessman jailed for 54 months each in graft case
summary: A former BP manager, Clarence Chang Peng Hong, and businessman Koh Seng Lee were sentenced to 54 months in jail each for accepting bribes totaling US$4 million. Chang accepted bribes between 2006 and 2010 to advance Koh's business interests with BP, while Koh agreed to pay S$500,000 to a pre-school, benefiting Chang's wife. Both were found guilty of 20 corruption charges and filed appeals against their convictions and sentences.

site_title: Authorities recover S$250m of the excess S$370m JSS payments: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry has recovered S$250 million, or over 68%, of the excess S$370 million in Jobs Support Scheme (JSS) payments made to businesses. The error occurred due to "source data errors" in firms' reopening dates, which affected about 4% of beneficiary firms. The government has secured commitments from larger affected firms to return an additional S$83 million. Businesses facing cashflow difficulties can approach the government for assistance, and instalment payment arrangements will be available. No firms have been wound up due to the erroneous payments.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp raises outlook again as global recovery takes hold
summary: German conglomerate Thyssenkrupp raised its full-year outlook for the second time in three months, citing a global economic recovery driving demand for steel, car parts, and materials. The group now expects adjusted earnings before interest and tax to reach mid triple-digit million euros, up from a previous forecast of almost breaking even. This marks a significant improvement from previous estimates, highlighting the resilience of the steel industry in the face of a recovering global economy.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit Q1 NPI, gross revenue almost equal to pre-Covid levels on acquisitions in new markets
summary: Cromwell E-Reit reported a net property income (NPI) of 30.8 million euros for the first quarter ended March 31, 2021, down 0.4% from the previous year. Gross revenue remained nearly unchanged at 48.5 million euros, matching pre-Covid levels due to the eurozone economy's minimal impact in the first quarter of last year. This suggests a strong recovery in the European real estate market.

site_title: Slumping live hog prices to put China's breeders under pressure
summary: China's hog prices have slumped to their lowest since January due to government restrictions on live-hog transportation, leading to a temporary imbalance in the local market. This has put pressure on hog producers, with smaller farmers at risk of losing money. However, larger producers, which account for a small portion of the industry, have reported higher sales and can continue to expand due to in-house breeding operations and access to capital. Experts warn that if smaller farmers step back, prices could rise in three to six months as supplies tighten.

site_title: Japanese prefecture says deaths at home surge amid 4th Covid-19 wave
summary: Japan's Osaka Prefecture has reported 18 deaths from Covid-19 at home, with most fatalities occurring since March 1, amid a fourth wave of infections. Highly infectious strains have caused a spike in new cases, with most deaths over 60 years old. Japan extended a state of emergency for much of the country to contain the pandemic ahead of the Tokyo Olympics. The fourth wave has prompted calls for tougher restrictions on movement.

site_title: Train maker Alstom earmarks new provisions for earlier Bombardier deal
summary: Alstom, a French train maker, has earmarked an additional 632 million euros for risks related to its earlier purchase of Bombardier's rail unit. The company reported a 5.7% increase in sales to 8.79 billion euros and a 2.1% increase in adjusted EBIT to 645 million euros. Integration of Bombardier Transportation is on track, with Alstom sticking to its plans for cost synergies and margin restoration. The deal is expected to be double-digit EPS accretive and preserve Alstom's credit profile.

images.alt_text: French train maker Alstom earmarked a further 632 million euros (S$1.042 billion) of provisions for risks on its earlier purchase of Bombardier's rail unit, while adding its integration of the Bombardier business was on track.

site_title: Colonial Pipeline hacking: CEO warns supply shortages could occur
summary: Colonial Pipeline CEO Joseph Blount warned state officials that supply shortages could occur despite plans to reopen the pipeline later this week. The 5,500-mile pipeline, which transports 45% of East Coast fuel, was paralyzed by a ransomware attack. Blount stated the company is developing a restart plan but won't resume shipments until the ransomware is removed. The US Energy Secretary and White House Press Secretary also expressed concern over the situation, with Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm calling the vulnerability of critical infrastructure a major issue.

site_title: How millennial MSME owners will drive Indonesia's economic rebound
summary: Indonesia's economy is expected to rebound by 4-5% in 2021, driven by millennial MSME owners, who are increasingly using digital tools and platforms. However, they face barriers to formal financing due to lack of collateral, credit history, and business skills. To tap this market, banks must bridge the digital gap by partnering with fintech companies and leveraging open banking ecosystems. This will enable them to access customer data, conduct credit analysis, and offer specialized financing products. Indonesia's young entrepreneurs, who account for 70% of the population, have the potential to drive growth, but require more accessible and flexible financing options.

site_title: Australia: Shares ease from record peak on tech rout
summary: Australian shares eased 0.48% from a record peak on Tuesday, following a sell-off in US tech stocks amid inflation fears. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell, with tech stocks plummeting 2.17% and nearmap losing 4.79%. In contrast, gold stocks fell 1.93% despite rising gold prices. The decline was largely driven by US market cues, with investors shifting towards cyclicals.

site_title: Foxconn iPhone India output drops 50% amid Covid-19 surge: sources
summary: Foxconn's iPhone 12 production in India has dropped by over 50% due to a surge in Covid-19 cases, with more than 100 employees testing positive and the company enforcing a no-entry ban at its factory in Chennai. The facility, which produces iPhones specifically for India, has reduced output to a small part of its capacity. This slump in production comes as India navigates a record-breaking second coronavirus wave, with officials imposing a full lockdown in the state of Tamil Nadu to try to slow the surging infections.

site_title: All about the money honey: Australia, NZ clash over manuka label
summary: Australian beekeepers Ana Martin and Sven Stephan face a potential blow to their manuka honey production as New Zealand producers launch proceedings to register the term "manuka" and claim its exclusive use. The move could lead to significant financial losses for Australian producers, who argue there's no difference in quality between their honey and New Zealand's. The New Zealand government is financially supporting the producers' legal efforts, which have been launched in multiple countries. The dispute raises concerns about the impact on the global honey market and the potential for counterfeit products.

site_title: Philippines records first two cases of Indian coronavirus variant
summary: The Philippines has detected its first two cases of the Indian coronavirus variant B.1.617, confirmed in two Filipino workers who returned from the UAE and Oman in April. The workers have been in isolation since their return. In response, the Philippines has temporarily barred travellers from India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, Nepal, and Bangladesh from entering the country.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hitch a ride on bull run in global resources
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached 10-week highs on Tuesday, driven by a bull run in global commodity prices, particularly a 10% surge in iron ore to record highs. The Aussie dollar edged back to US$0.7834, while the kiwi dollar stood at US$0.7259. The strong commodity prices have led to a revised budget deficit forecast for Australia, with analysts expecting a smaller-than-feared deficit and a boon for bonds.

site_title: Gold flat as US yields negate firmer dollar
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,836.26 per ounce as US Treasury yields retreated, offsetting a slight dollar rebound. Investors await key inflation data this week, while lower bond yields reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold. The dollar index rose 0.1%, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. Meanwhile, benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields were pinned below 1.6%.

site_title: A 1,100-year-old poem cost Meituan's outspoken CEO billions
summary: Meituan CEO Wang Xing's 28-character social media post referencing a 1,100-year-old poem sparked a controversy, causing his company's stock to plummet by US$26 billion over two days. The post was initially interpreted as criticizing the Chinese government, but Wang clarified it was about the short-sightedness of the tech industry. Despite the initial loss, Meituan's stock rebounded 4.3% on the following day, with Wang's wealth losing US$2.5 billion in value during the period. The incident highlighted the sensitivity of China's tech industry to public perception and government scrutiny.

site_title: Singapore condo resale volumes hit 11-year high, prices up 1.5% in April: SRX
summary: Singapore condo resale volumes reached an 11-year high in April with 1,993 units sold, a 7.9% increase from March. Prices rose 1.5% month-over-month and 5.8% year-over-year. HDB upgraders drove the market, with 56.9% of resale volumes in the outside central region. The median capital gain stood at $200,000, with District 21 posting the highest gain and District 4 the highest loss. Experts attribute the surge to construction delays for HDB flats and a preference for "move-in ready" properties.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 8.01 points, or 0.51%, to 1,575.91. Volume was 650.99 million lots worth RM255.03 million. Losers beat gainers 583 to 77.

site_title: Australia says record budget deficits needed to secure recovery
summary: Australia's conservative government will present a record budget with a shortfall of around A$150 billion due to the Covid-19 pandemic, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg said. The budget aims to secure the economic recovery through new spending in skills, infrastructure, aged care, and women's safety. Despite a record deficit, employment has improved, with jobless rates down to 5.6%, and resource exports have risen, reducing the forecasted shortfall to A$80 billion for the 2021/22 fiscal year. The budget is seen as a last-minute push before a general election expected by mid-2022.

site_title: US business lobby calls on China to play fair
summary: The American Chamber of Commerce in China has called on China to implement its commitments to equal treatment for foreign businesses, abandoning "implicit" guidance to favor domestic products. The chamber, representing 900 companies, also urged the US and China to cooperate on climate change and public health. This comes amid deteriorating relations between the two economies, with foreign businesses complaining about limited market access and intellectual property protection. The US has imposed punitive tariffs on China, and a top-to-bottom review of US-China trade policy is underway.

site_title: China targets some Australian LNG as trade dispute widens
summary: China has directed at least two smaller liquefied natural gas (LNG) importers to avoid buying new Australian LNG cargoes over the next year, amid worsening trade tensions between the two countries. The move, which applies to about 11% of China's total LNG imports, is seen as a further escalation of the dispute. However, larger state-owned importers plan to continue buying Australian LNG, limiting the impact on imports. The move raises concerns about the long-term implications for trade in LNG between China and Australia.

site_title: Amazon borrows US$18.5b it doesn't need in new debt sale
summary: Amazon issued $18.5 billion in debt, refinance debt, and buy back stock, despite having $30 billion in cash. The company sold bonds with a 40-year term at a yield of 95 basis points over Treasuries. This move took advantage of low borrowing costs, which proved too attractive for the online retail giant.

site_title: Simon Property beats profit estimates as Americans return to malls
summary: Simon Property Group Inc reported better-than-expected quarterly results, with net profit of US$1.36 per share, as Americans returned to malls after the pandemic. The company's lease income fell 9.3% to US$1.15 billion, but exceeded estimates. CEO David Simon attributed the growth to the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines and government stimulus, but lowered the full-year profit forecast to between US$4.47 and US$4.57 per share. Simon expects mall occupancy levels won't return to 2019 levels until next year or 2023, and is playing hardball in rent negotiations with tenants.

images.alt_text: Simon Property Group Inc reported better-than-expected quarterly results on Monday, as the largest US mall operator benefited from the return of pandemic-weary shoppers to brick-and-mortar stores.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares drop at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.08% at the open of trade on Tuesday, following steep losses on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 28,286.56, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The losses were attributed to investors' cautious stance ahead of the release of key US inflation data later in the week.

site_title: Stocks to watch: PropNex, Manulife US Reit, Bumitama Agri, Kimly, Keppel, F&N, UG Healthcare
summary: Stocks to watch: PropNex posted a Q1 net profit of S$14.8 million, nearly double the previous year. Manulife US Reit's portfolio occupancy fell to 92%, lower than the previous year. Bumitama Agri posted a 36.4% lower earnings in Q1. Kimly proposed acquiring a 75% stake in Tenderfresh for S$54 million. Keppel Shipyard secured a US$2.3 billion contract. F&N posted a 16.1% rise in net profit to S$83.4 million. UG Healthcare posted a net profit of S$34.3 million, nearly 57 times its previous year's profit.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after Wall Street fall
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on May 11, 2021, following a fall on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.94% and the Topix index down 0.64%. The decline was attributed to high-tech shares being hit hard.

site_title: Inflows of CMP workers unable to meet firms' needs even before tightening: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's strict border measures, including curbs on arrivals from higher-risk countries, have already failed to meet the country's labor needs, said Education Minister Lawrence Wong. The recent influx of Construction and Process Industries (CMP) workers has not been sufficient to meet the demands of firms, leading to delays in projects, including new public flats and marine industries. The manpower shortage will have a cascading effect on the economy, with companies struggling to find new workers, resulting in a backlog of applications for relevant approvals. Wong emphasized the need for a balanced approach, reopening borders while strengthening precautions and safeguards.

images.alt_text: Construction contractors in particular have been hard-hit, with building projects - including new public flats - being delayed.

site_title: China's factory-gate prices surge by most in over 3 years
summary: China's factory-gate prices surged 6.8% in April, the fastest rate in three and a half years, according to official data. This growth follows record-setting growth in the first quarter. The consumer price index rose 0.9%, contrasting with investor concerns about potential inflation and interest rate hikes. The producer price index increase is seen as a sign of China's economy continuing to gather momentum, but may also raise concerns about inflation and economic recovery.

site_title: China demographic crisis looms as population growth slips to lowest ever
summary: China's population grew at its slowest since the 1950s, reaching 1.41 billion with a 5.38% increase in 2020, according to the country's census results. The fertility rate of 1.3 children per woman is on par with aging societies like Japan and Italy. China narrowly missed its target to boost the population to 1.42 billion by 2020, with a fertility rate of around 1.8. The country is expected to face an irreversible population decline without accumulating household wealth of G-7 nations, prompting pressure to increase incentives for couples to have more children.

site_title: Kimly eyes 75% stake in halal food business Tenderfresh for S$54m
summary: Kimly, a coffee-shop operator, has proposed acquiring a 75% stake in home-grown food business Tenderfresh for S$54 million. The deal, which will be funded via a mix of cash and new Kimly shares, aims to expand into the growing halal food industry in Singapore and neighboring countries. Following the announcement, Kimly's shares rose 7.81% to close at 34.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Bumitama Agri's Q1 profit falls 36.4% on increased CPO levy and export tax
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 36.4% decline in Q1 earnings to 166.73 billion rupiah due to higher CPO levy and export tax. Revenue grew 14.4% to 2.31 trillion rupiah, driven by improved production and weather conditions. The company attributed lower gross profit to higher production volume and CPO price. Its gearing ratio stood at 0.54, and shares ended flat at 47.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Wednesday vote on ousting Cheney from US Republican leadership
summary: US House Republicans vote on Wednesday on potentially ousting congresswoman Liz Cheney from a leadership role for criticizing Donald Trump over election falsehoods. The vote comes amid party divisions, with Cheney, a traditional conservative, being replaced by congresswoman Elise Stefanik, a former moderate who has aligned with Trump. Cheney's removal is seen as a test of party unity ahead of the 2022 midterms, with some believing it will only deepen discord, while others hope it will smooth over divisions.

site_title: Non-hospitalised Covid patients have low risk of serious long-term effects: study
summary: A study published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal found that non-hospitalized Covid-19 patients have a low risk of serious long-term effects. However, they report more visits to general practitioners and outpatient hospital visits, suggesting potential Covid-19 sequelae. The study suggests that the absolute risk of severe post-acute complications is low, but ongoing monitoring is necessary to track any long-term effects.

site_title: PropNex Q1 profit nearly doubles to S$14.8m on higher revenue
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a first-quarter net profit of S$14.8 million, nearly doubling the previous year's S$7.6 million. Revenue increased 63.3% to S$220.6 million, driven by higher commission income from agency services and project marketing. Improved market sentiment, ample liquidity, and low interest rates contributed to the growth. No dividend was declared for the period, and shares closed at S$1.10, up 0.9%. The company expects buyer interest to continue in the new and resale private homes market as economic recovery gains traction.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Tuesday; STI down 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.6% to 3,162.51 at the open on Tuesday, tracking Wall Street's decline. Tech shares weighed on the market, while healthcare player Thomson Medical gained 0.1% to 8.9 cents. Banking stocks, including DBS, UOB, and OCBC, declined. The Dow and Nasdaq fell on Monday, with the S&P 500 down 1%. European stocks hit record highs, driven by commodity price surges and optimism about economic recovery.

site_title: WHO says virus strain in India a 'variant of concern' as Europe eases curbs
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has classified the B.1.617 virus mutation in India as a "variant of concern" due to its increased contagiousness and potential resistance to vaccine protections. This declaration comes as Europe eases Covid-19 lockdowns, with schools and stores reopening in parts of the continent. The WHO's Covid-19 lead, Maria Van Kerkove, made the statement, emphasizing the need for continued vigilance against the rapidly spreading variant.

images.alt_text: Schools and stores reopened in parts of Europe on Monday, easing out of months of Covid-19 lockdowns, but the devastating outbreak raged on across the sub-continent and health experts declared the virus mutation in India a "variant of concern".

site_title: Sustainability takes centre stage in education
summary: KinderWorld, Vietnam's largest international school operator, is integrating sustainability into its curriculum and operations. As part of its commitment, the group aims to incorporate three pillars of sustainable development into its strategy and operations. This includes environmental responsibility, social responsibility, and governance. The schools will strive for LEED certification and incorporate sustainable features such as green spaces, recycled rainwater, and high-efficiency electrical equipment. KinderWorld also partners with Outward Bound Vietnam to instill environmental awareness and community service among students.

site_title: Oil gains after cyberattack forces shutdown of crucial US pipelines
summary: US crude oil prices rose after a major cyberattack forced the shutdown of critical fuel supply pipelines, including Colonial Pipeline, which supplies nearly half of the US East Coast's fuel. The attack, involving ransomware, has prompted the White House to work closely with Colonial to recover from the shutdown. Oil prices jumped nearly 2% on Monday, with Brent crude up 69 cents to $68.97 a barrel and WTI crude up 61 cents to $65.51 a barrel. The attack has highlighted the fragility of US oil infrastructure, with analysts warning of potential price spikes ahead of peak summer driving season.

site_title: Oil settles higher as key US fuel pipeline plans restart
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday after the Colonial Pipeline, the largest US fuel pipeline, said it could largely restart within the week after a cyberattack forced its shutdown. The pipeline's shutdown had boosted crude prices, but fears of a resurgent coronavirus pandemic in India were offset by potential US demand growth. Brent crude settled up 4 cents to $68.32 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude settled up 2 cents to $64.92 a barrel. The US government is working with Colonial to help it recover, and a national security official said the US intelligence community is investigating potential ties to the Russian government.

site_title: UK shoppers buy clothes for outdoor social life, holidays at home
summary: British shoppers boosted retail spending in April, with total sales 7.3% higher than the same period two years ago. The surge was driven by warm clothing sales and furniture purchases, as people met outdoors and worked from home. Meanwhile, summer holiday bookings rose, but foreign trips declined due to restrictions. Essential items, such as supermarket shopping, saw the strongest growth, with a 10.1% increase. Consumer confidence also rose, with a 36% measure, its highest since February 2020.

images.alt_text: The British Retail Consortium said total sales were 7.3 per cent higher in April than in the same month two years ago.

site_title: US: Dow Jones falls back after topping 35,000 for first time, Nasdaq sinks
summary: US stocks fell on Monday after the Dow Jones topped 35,000 for the first time, with the Nasdaq sinking due to weakness in technology shares. Industrial names like Caterpillar and 3M gained, but large tech names like Amazon and Facebook lost ground. The Dow ended down slightly, snapping a three-day streak of records. The decline was attributed to investors rotating out of technology names to companies more connected to the economic recovery.

site_title: Discretionary mandates in the spotlight
summary: UBS' discretionary mandates have seen steady growth among Asian clients, with invested assets increasing 20% annually over the last five years. Clients employ discretionary strategies to manage longevity and legacy needs, and increasingly recognize the benefits of delegation and continuous rebalancing. UBS' MyWay platform, launched in 2020, allows clients to design their individual portfolios with 50 modular building blocks, and delegate implementation to portfolio managers. The platform incorporates sustainable investments and robust risk management processes, appealing to clients seeking disciplined investment approaches, especially in volatile markets.

site_title: How the wealthy are protecting their assets
summary: Wealthy families in Asia are re-evaluating their asset holding structures and risk management strategies amid the Covid-19 pandemic and potential global minimum tax on corporates. To shield assets from risks, they're exploring alternatives such as private equity, venture capital, and cryptocurrencies, and establishing trust and investment holding structures. Singapore has emerged as a popular base for these strategies, offering tax incentives and a stable financial environment. Wealthy families are also using life insurance products, pre-nuptial agreements, and sophisticated trust structures to protect their assets and ensure smooth succession.

site_title: Huggs Coffee carves new path with first outlet in residential estate
summary: Huggs Coffee, a Singaporean coffee chain, is expanding into residential estates with its new outlet at Thomson Plaza, marking its first foray into the suburbs. The 20th outlet, opening on Friday, features private pods, an amphitheatre-like seating, and a member's lounge with noise-cancelling headphones. The move comes as work-from-home becomes the default again, with the company aiming to create a "second home" for customers. This is part of Huggs' plans to stay relevant in the current situation and expand its operations beyond the Central Business District.

site_title: Manulife US Reit reports 92% portfolio occupancy in Q1
summary: Manulife US Reit reported a 92% portfolio occupancy in Q1, slightly lower than the previous year's 96.5%. The Reit's weighted average lease expiry is 5.3 years, and it executed 5.8% of leases with a 2.1% rental reversion. The company targets "magnet cities" with strong demand for healthcare, technology, and life sciences, and expects growth driven by these sectors. The Reit's gearing is 41.3% and interest coverage is 3.9 times, with a lower weighted average interest rate of 3%.

site_title: UMS Q1 net profit up 44% on sustained demand for semiconductors
summary: UMS Holdings, a precision-engineering firm, reported a 44% increase in first-quarter net profit to S$15.4 million, driven by sustained demand for semiconductors worldwide. Revenue rose 42% to S$49.6 million, with the semiconductor segment up 47% due to higher sales. The company announced an interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share and expects to benefit from the global semiconductor industry's forecasted record highs in fab equipment spending until 2022.

site_title: Formula One great to develop electric vans, SUVs for carmakers, startups
summary: The Gordon Murray Group, a supercar maker, plans a £300 million expansion over five years to develop electric SUVs and delivery vehicles for carmakers. Founder Gordon Murray aims to shift the company towards an all-electric supercar by 2030. The company will produce its first supercar, the T50, with a powerful V12 engine in 2022, followed by a hybrid model and a fully-electric supercar. Murray plans to sell electric SUVs and delivery vehicles to traditional manufacturers or startups, with a goal of picking up customers in the next two and a half years.

site_title: Beijing fines tutoring apps backed by Tencent, Alibaba
summary: China's State Administration for Market Regulation fined two online tutoring apps, Yuanfudao and Zuoyebang, 2.5 million yuan each for violating competition and pricing laws. The firms were accused of making misleading claims and falsifying user reviews. The fines are part of Beijing's crackdown on the education sector, which has seen increased scrutiny and penalties for private education providers. The regulator will intensify supervision and crack down on illegal activities, with the two apps accepting the penalties and promising to rectify their problems.

site_title: BioNTech to set up regional HQ, vaccine facility in Singapore
summary: BioNTech, a German biotech company, plans to establish a regional headquarters and vaccine manufacturing facility in Singapore, investing hundreds of millions of dollars. The facility, expected to be operational from 2023, will create over 80 jobs and enable the production of mRNA-based vaccines and therapeutics for infectious diseases and cancer. The move aims to strengthen Singapore's supply chain resilience and position it as a regional innovation hub for the healthcare industry, with the facility capable of producing several hundred million doses of mRNA-based vaccines annually.

site_title: 'Cautious hugging' and pints: PM Johnson to ease England's lockdown
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced the next phase of lockdown easing in England, allowing "cautious hugging" and serving pints inside pubs starting May 17. The move comes as the country's Covid-19 alert level is lowered, with cases and deaths decreasing sharply due to the rapid vaccine roll-out. Under the plan, people can meet indoors with groups of up to six or two full households, and indoor entertainment can resume. The easing applies only to England, with other countries setting their own rules.

site_title: US ship fires warning shots at Iranian boats in Strait of Hormuz: Pentagon
summary: A US Navy vessel fired warning shots at over a dozen Iranian fast attack boats in the Strait of Hormuz, following their close approach to a US submarine and escort ships. This is the second such incident in two weeks. The US Navy fired 30 shots in two volleys, and the Iranian boats retreated. Pentagon spokesman John Kirby described the harassment as "unsafe, unprofessional, and potentially leading to a miscalculation in the region." The incident highlights ongoing tensions between the US and Iran in the region.

site_title: US authorises Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine for 12-15 year olds
summary: The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) authorised the use of the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 12 to 15 years old, following a rigorous review of available data. This move brings the country closer to ending the pandemic and allows a younger population to be protected from Covid-19. The vaccine has shown to be safe and highly effective in a trial of 2,260 12 to 15 year olds. The authorisation comes after a similar approval was granted for individuals aged 16 and older.

site_title: New SPH Media entity to seek diversified sources of revenue: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's new media company, limited by guarantee (CLG), will operate as a revenue-seeking business with a "long-term sustainable business model" including advertising, circulation, and other revenue sources. The CLG will be capitalised with S$80 million and will have a chairman, Mr Khaw Boon Wan, who has no digital media experience. The government has agreed to provide support to the CLG, but not to subsidise shareholder returns. The restructuring aims to secure the sustainability of local media, which faces structural changes due to technological advances and the Internet.

site_title: Europe: Stocks end at record highs as miners rally
summary: European stocks reached record highs on Monday as miners led gains, with the Stoxx 600 index rising 0.1% to an all-time high. Commodity prices surged, lifting sectors that benefit from a recovery, while optimism about reopening economies and easy monetary policy also contributed. Key miners, such as Rio Tinto and Glencore, rose between 1.7% and 2.6%. Investors will monitor US inflation data later this week, which could impact interest rates and the Federal Reserve's policy stance.

site_title: Funding Societies partners Haulio to provide ready credit to hauliers
summary: Funding Societies, a digital financing platform in South-East Asia, is partnering with Haulio, a Singaporean haulier network, to provide ready credit to hauliers. This partnership aims to speed up payments, with pre-approved credit facilities available in as little as seven days, compared to the industry standard of 30 days or more.

site_title: Dollar struggles after weak US jobs report
summary: The US dollar fell to 2½-month lows after a weak US jobs report, sparking investors to unwind long positions in the greenback. The dollar index remained flat at 90.13, while the British pound and Australian dollar rallied, reaching their highest levels since February. The dollar's losses were attributed to a patient approach to monetary policy by the Federal Open Market Committee and a medium-term weight on the USD due to an improving global economic outlook.

site_title: Qatar's emir visits Saudi Arabia as rift eases
summary: Qatar's Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani visited Saudi Arabia, his second trip since the countries re-established relations in January. The visit, led by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, aimed to discuss bilateral relations and common interests. This marks a cautious step towards normalcy after Qatar's re-entry into the regional fold, following a 3-year feud. The reconciliation led to the resumption of air travel and the reopening of Qatar's land border with Saudi Arabia.

site_title: NBC drops next year's Golden Globes over diversity row
summary: NBC has cancelled its broadcast of next year's Golden Globes due to the Hollywood Foreign Press Association's (HFPA) lack of meaningful reforms to address diversity and transparency issues. The HFPA, comprising 90 journalists, has been criticized for racism, sexism, and bullying, and has faced backlash from major studios and stars like Tom Cruise and Scarlett Johansson. Despite approving reforms last week, the HFPA's plan to boost membership and hire diversity consultants has been deemed insufficient, leading to a potential fatal blow to the awards and the organization.

site_title: Australia takes on Mexico's tipple (just don't call it tequila)
summary: Top Shelf International Holdings Ltd, a Melbourne-based spirits company, plans to launch an agave spirit in select international markets, including the US and China. The company's 1,300km agave farm, the largest in Australia, aims to produce a uniquely Australian-flavored spirit with notes of honey, lime peel, and cut grass. Despite the challenges of competing with Mexico's tequila market, Top Shelf expects to reach A$100 million in annual turnover and US$9 billion in the US market by 2024.

site_title: Keppel unit bags Petrobras FPSO contract worth US$2.3b
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured a US$2.3 billion contract from Petrobras to deliver a floating production storage and offloading vessel (FPSO) to Brazil's deepwater Buzios field. The FPSO, P-78, is expected to have a production capacity of 180,000 barrels of oil per day and will be delivered in late 2024. The contract will be fabricated at Keppel's shipyards in Singapore, China, and Brazil, with Hyundai Heavy Industries providing the hull and living quarters. The project is expected to generate thousands of job opportunities for the local ecosystem.

site_title: Becoming a sustainable investor
summary: BNP Paribas Wealth Management (BNPP WM) has launched a web-based app called myImpact to educate investors on sustainable investing. The tool aims to help clients gain insights into their profile as a sustainable investor, including three broad profiles: Responsible Investor, Conviction Investor, and Engaged Investor. The app also includes a sustainable rating methodology called "clover rating" to assess portfolio and investments. With a growing interest in sustainability, BNPP WM hopes to pave the way for conversations with clients and contribute to a responsible and sustainable economy.

site_title: Malaysia enters nationwide lockdown from May 12 amid third wave of infections
summary: Malaysia will enter a nationwide lockdown from May 12 to June 7, following a third wave of Covid-19 infections, as the government seeks to contain the outbreak. The lockdown will restrict social gatherings, house visits, and travel, while allowing some economic sectors to operate with work-from-home arrangements. The measure aims to prevent a national crisis, with new coronavirus variants and high infection rates putting the public healthcare system under strain.

site_title: Struggling companies lifted by tie-ups with new economy players
summary: Locally listed companies in Singapore are forming alliances with startups and "new economy" players to launch initiatives providing entry points to untapped market opportunities. FJ Benjamin, Yeo Hiap Seng, and Khong Guan have seen significant jumps in share prices after announcing partnerships with startups. However, experts warn that the return on investment for such collaborations can be weak and subject to risks, particularly if there is a lack of commitment from one side to execute. The success of these tie-ups depends on the extent to which the old-economy companies can adapt to the new economy and disruptors.

site_title: Taiwan to quarantine all China Airlines pilots amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Taiwan has ordered a 14-day quarantine for all pilots of China Airlines Ltd amid a Covid-19 outbreak linked to the airline. The move aims to break a chain of transmissions, with 35 confirmed infections reported so far. The quarantine will effectively ground the airline, with pilots only allowed out once they test negative. The health minister cited the risk of community transmission from pilots' pre-confirmed infections in bars and restaurants before their infections were confirmed. The airport hotel where pilots stayed has been evacuated and deep cleaned.

site_title: Iron ore turns 'very hot' as 10% surge adds to commodities boom
summary: Iron ore futures surged over 10% to a record high, driven by optimism about central banks' supportive policies and expectations of China tightening environmental rules. Copper also jumped to a record high, with analysts predicting it could reach $11,000 a tonne in 12 months. The commodities boom has fueled concerns about inflation, with some warning that the surge in raw materials could eventually force central banks to tighten.

site_title: China tech giants bet US$19 billion on global electric car frenzy
summary: China's tech giants, including Huawei, Xiaomi, and Baidu, are investing nearly $19 billion in electric and self-driving vehicle ventures, marking a significant push into the automotive industry. The industry is highly competitive, with established automakers and local upstarts vying for market share. Tech giants are partnering with automakers to develop autonomous driving features and leveraging their expertise in sensors, operating systems, and data analysis to gain a foothold. The investments are expected to help the companies create intelligent cars and unlock new revenue streams through over-the-air system upgrades and software subscriptions.

site_title: A thriving local news media in the digital age
summary: Singapore's local news media faces a critical juncture due to the global decline of print advertising revenue and increasing competition from online news sources. The country's two main local news media organizations, SPH and Mediacorp, are under pressure to adapt to the digital age and maintain quality journalism. Despite holding out longer than most, SPH's media business has lost half its operating revenue in the past five years and posted its first ever loss in 2020. The government must take a long-term view and consider measures to support the local media industry, including public funding, to prevent a decline in quality and cohesion in Singaporean society.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies reported strong financial performances in the first quarter of 2021. Grand Venture Technology, a manufacturing-service provider, posted a net profit of S$3.3 million, a 59% increase from the previous year. SIIC Environment Holdings and Singapore Medical Group also reported significant rises in net profit, with 23.1% and 22.2% increases, respectively. Meanwhile, Fraser and Neave posted a 16.1% rise in net profit to S$83.4 million, while SBS Transit's profit more than doubled to S$23.3 million.

site_title: SINGA not expected to hurt Singapore's credit rating
summary: Singapore's Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA) aims to finance major long-term infrastructure projects without hurting the country's AAA credit rating. The Ministry of Finance and Monetary Authority of Singapore have engaged credit rating agencies to explain the government's borrowing approach, which includes issuing infrastructure bonds with longer tenors. SINGA is expected to create fiscal space of about 0.8% of GDP annually and will change how development costs for infrastructure projects are financed. The Act sets out four requirements for projects and has a gross borrowing limit of $90 billion.

images.alt_text: Mr Heng says SINGA will "create fiscal space" of about 0.8 per cent of GDP annually in the next decade, or about S$4 billion in current dollars.

site_title: Small can be beautiful in Singapore condo land
summary: In Singapore's condominium market, small units have become increasingly popular, with 55% of units sold at Irwell Hill Residences being one- and two-bedroom types. This trend is driven by demographics, with the average household size shrinking from 4.87 in 1980 to 3.22 in 2020. Smaller units keep absolute sums affordable for buyers and help developers achieve high price per square foot. This shift is also influenced by the rise of one-person households and the aging population, with 15.2% of residents aged 65 and older living alone in 2019.

site_title: Outlook for the rest of 2021
summary: Experts predict a strong recovery for the global economy, driven by the US and China, with Asian economies also benefiting from rising global demand. Pictet Wealth Management forecasts 6.5% US GDP growth and 9.2% Chinese growth, while Citi expects Asian equities to outperform due to strong tech sectors. The Fed is likely to remain dovish, with inflation and interest rates expected to rise in the next couple of months. Tech stocks are expected to gain cyclical leadership as growth moderates, and emerging markets are expected to benefit from a strengthening global recovery.

site_title: Construction firms to be able to seek relief for increased foreign manpower costs
summary: Singapore is set to introduce a new law allowing construction firms to seek relief for increased foreign manpower costs due to Covid-19 related measures. The amendment to the Covid-19 (Temporary Measures) Act Bill will enable contractors to adjust contract sums if their workers' salaries have been affected by entry restrictions. The law applies to contracts entered into before Oct 1 last year and will be enforced by an assessor who will determine the adjusted amount, which will be binding. The measure aims to provide relief to businesses impacted by the pandemic.

site_title: Poor local poll results force UK Labour party reshuffle
summary: UK Labour Party leader Keir Starmer has reshuffled his team after disappointing local election results, which strengthened Conservative Prime Minister Boris Johnson's grip on power. Labour lost control of several local authorities and parliamentary seats, including Hartlepool. Starmer has vowed to launch a policy review to settle on a clear agenda to challenge the Conservatives. Key appointments include Rachel Reeves as head of economic policy and Angela Rayner as policy chief on "the future of work".

site_title: 'Super Thursday' polls reveal deeply divided UK
summary: The UK's "Super Thursday" elections have revealed deep divisions in the country's politics, with Scotland emerging as a major threat to Boris Johnson's premiership. The Scottish National Party (SNP) and Greens won a clear majority, potentially paving the way for a second secession referendum. Johnson is likely to resist a new referendum, citing economic concerns, but the SNP and Greens will push for one. The elections also showed strong performances by Labour in Wales and the Conservatives in England, but Johnson's hold on power remains uncertain due to ongoing scandals and criticism of his handling of the coronavirus crisis.

site_title: Khaw Boon Wan to chair entity managing SPH's media business
summary: Former Singapore Cabinet Minister Khaw Boon Wan has agreed to chair the entity managing SPH's media business, CLG, following the proposed restructuring of the media company. Existing management shareholders, including major banks and telcos, have agreed to form the CLG and be its founding members. The move aims to ensure the local news media remains in the hands of trusted institutions with a long-term stake in Singapore, with profits to be reinvested into media operations. Khaw's appointment has been met with skepticism, with some questioning the lack of a global search and his close ties to the government.

site_title: Too much continuity between Biden and Trump
summary: US President Joe Biden's foreign policy speech to Congress on April 28 showed significant continuity with his predecessor Donald Trump, despite his domestic economic agenda being more progressive. The emphasis on China and the US, with Europe taking a backseat, raises concerns about Trumpian nationalism. Biden's refusal to send Covid-19 vaccines to European countries and his support for the Nord Stream 2 pipeline project, which threatens German eastern neighbors, are seen as gifts to Russian President Vladimir Putin. Biden's failure to address these issues and his reluctance to reconsider Trump's protectionist policies hinder his efforts to restore American global leadership.

site_title: Universal life insurance - not just a wealth protection plan
summary: Universal life insurance plans are seen as a wealth creation and long-term financial planning solution by the wealthy, offering a high death benefit, premium financing, liquidity, and uncorrelated market returns. Despite the pandemic, one insurance brokerage reported a 25% growth surge, crossing the $1 billion premium threshold for the first time. This growth is attributed to the increasing demand for large UL policies among wealthy clients, solidifying universal life insurance as a core feature in succession and wealth planning.

site_title: DBS issues more than S$450m in Sora-pegged SME loans
summary: DBS has issued over S$450 million in Sora-pegged SME loans, accounting for about one-third of all new SME loans in Singapore. This marks a positive sign for Singapore's transition to Sora as its main interest rate benchmark. DBS has been proactively engaging with SME clients to help them understand the changes, and has partnered with clients to achieve a seamless transition to alternative Risk-Free Benchmark Rates.

images.alt_text: DBS group head of SME banking Joyce Tee notes that it is important SMEs are not left behind even as the financial industry progresses with the transition to a Sora-centred Singapore dollar interest rate market.

site_title: UK house price growth hits five-year high in April: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose 8.2% annually in April, the largest gain since 2016, driven by the extension of tax cuts for buyers and the lifting of lockdown restrictions. This is the fastest annual rate of growth in five years. In April alone, prices increased 1.4%, the biggest monthly jump in seven months. The government's mortgage guarantee scheme and tax cuts on stamp duty land tax have fueled the housing market boom. However, Halifax managing director Russell Galley expects house price growth to fade later this year due to potential higher unemployment.

site_title: UBS dangles US$40,000 bonuses to slow junior banker defections
summary: UBS is offering a US$40,000 one-time bonus to its global banking analysts when they are promoted to associates, doubling what some competitors are offering. The move aims to reward and retain younger employees amid a surge in business and a prolonged work-from-home grind. This comes as banks raise pay for junior employees to prevent defections and ease discontent. The Swiss bank is also cutting jobs, taking a US$300 million restructuring charge. Other lenders, such as Goldman Sachs and HSBC, are also moving to raise pay and boost staff to avoid burnout.

site_title: How a luxury tower could change NYC's historic character
summary: A luxury tower project at 250 Water Street in New York City's South Street Seaport Historic District has sparked controversy over its potential impact on the area's historic character. The site, which costs around $20 an hour, has been under consideration for development for over 40 years. If approved, the project could alter the neighborhood's skyline and character, raising concerns among preservationists and local residents.

images.alt_text: A rendering of an orange-tinted proposed tower, left of the One World Trade Center in New York, which may go up on what used to be a parking lot in the South Street Seaport Historic District after real estate firm Howard Hughes Corp was granted a certificate of appropriateness.

site_title: Chip shortage in focus as Japan automakers ready to report profit drop
summary: Japan's major automakers, including Toyota, Honda, and Nissan, are expected to report depressed earnings this week due to the ongoing global chip shortage, which has forced production adjustments and suspensions. The shortage, exacerbated by blackouts and a fire at a chip plant, has dampened the post-pandemic recovery. While tighter supplies have pushed up vehicle prices, analysts expect earnings forecasts to be slashed, with Toyota expected to report a 12.5% drop in operating profit. Nissan is forecast to report a loss, but its profit is expected to swing to a profit in the current fiscal year.

site_title: Jason Statham's Wrath of Man storms in at No 1 with US$8 million
summary: Jason Statham's heist thriller "Wrath of Man" debuted at No. 1 at the US box office with $8.1 million, keeping exhibitors afloat until Disney's "Cruella" and Paramount's "A Quiet Place Part II" releases. The film's performance was a traditional theatrical release, unlike other pandemic-era movies. Meanwhile, "Godzilla vs Kong" crossed $92 million in the US, and "Demon Slayer" remains a top contender, with "Mortal Kombat" also performing well. The strong start is a welcome relief for the industry, which is slowly recovering from the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Going the extra mile for clients
summary: Insurance entrepreneur Calvin Lo, net worth $1.7 billion, prioritizes helping clients plan for wealth transfer across generations, citing a failure to plan as the primary cause of wealth dissipation. He attributes this to a cultural taboo in Asia regarding discussing death and estate planning. Lo's company, R.E. Lee International, has seen significant growth, with premiums reaching $1 billion annually, and has expanded to six locations worldwide. Despite his immense wealth, Lo emphasizes the importance of philanthropy, particularly in supporting children's education and the environment through his charitable foundation, The CFL Initiative.

images.alt_text: Commodity bellwethers including Exxon Mobil Corp., Freeport-McMoRan Inc., and Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. are among a raft of raw-materials companies expected to post higher profits in financial results this week and next.
If you paid top dollar for the iPhone X (above) and Apple Inc.'s other flagship smartphones expecting the fastest mobile internet speeds around, you won't like these results.
Facebook Inc. will double the amount of space it occupies in London as technology firms continue to expand in the UK.
