site_title: China's much-hyped digital yuan fails to impress early users
summary: China's digital yuan, launched in a trial in Shenzhen, has failed to impress early users, with many expressing indifference to the digital currency. Privacy concerns, such as the potential for real-time data tracking, have deterred some users. Despite initial hopes for global adoption, experts predict the digital yuan's global impact will be minimal, with a share of less than 1% of global payments. The People's Bank of China has acknowledged the digital yuan's domestic use, but its international ambitions remain unclear.

site_title: China Everbright Water bags project worth 253m yuan
summary: China Everbright Water has signed a supplementary agreement worth 253 million yuan (S$52.3 million) for an upgrading project in China's Shaanxi province. The project involves upgrading a waste-water treatment plant and advanced sludge dewatering. The concession period will expire in 2031 and 2044, and the upgraded plant will meet higher discharge standards, reducing sludge water content to 60%. The deal is expected to strengthen the company's waste-water treatment capabilities and enhance cooperation with local authorities.

site_title: Amazon says it blocked 10 billion suspected counterfeit listings
summary: Amazon blocked over 10 billion suspected counterfeit listings on its platform last year as part of a global crackdown, according to its first "brand protection report". The company seized 2 million counterfeit products and destroyed them, investing $700 million in anti-counterfeiting efforts. Despite increased attempts by bad actors, Amazon reported that fewer than 0.01% of products received a counterfeit complaint. The move comes amid pressure from US lawmakers and brands to step up efforts to verify product authenticity.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Meanwhile, the US stock market opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses. London's Heathrow is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its new CEO, replacing a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC are deepening cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks have had a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Bolivian wine-growers banking on 'distinctive' altitude flavour
summary: Bolivian wine-growers are banking on the unique flavor of their wines, produced at high altitudes of 1,600-2,000m, to capture a niche market. The region's temperate climate and intense sunshine result in thicker grape skins and a higher content of resveratrol, a chemical believed to protect against cancer and heart disease. Bolivian wines are distinct due to their concentration of aromas and unique color, appealing to those who prefer elegant wines with smooth aromas and flavors. Despite being dwarfed by Argentina and Chile, Bolivian wine production is gaining popularity, particularly in La Paz, and is expected to expand in quality.

site_title: Suga adviser under fire for downplaying pandemic
summary: A Japanese government adviser, Yoichi Takahashi, has sparked public outrage after downplaying the COVID-19 pandemic and joking about cancelling the Olympics. His tweet likening cases to a "ripple" and laughing off calls to cancel the games has garnered over 13,000 retweets. This comes as Japan has extended a state of emergency in Tokyo and three other areas until the end of May. Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has refused to comment on Takahashi's remarks, as his approval ratings have dipped to a new low of 40%.

site_title: US: Dow hits all-time highs as materials, energy stocks rise
summary: The Dow Jones Industrials hit a record high, rising 7.5 points or 0.02% to 34,785.27, driven by optimism over lower interest rates and a surge in commodity prices, particularly for miners, energy, and steel companies.

site_title: Moya's Q1 profit after tax dips 26%
summary: Moya Holdings Asia reported a Q1 profit after tax of S$9.5 million, down 26% from last year, with revenue rising 10% to S$62.9 million. EBITDA increased 18% to S$27.1 million. The group maintained positive operating cash flow despite the Covid-19 pandemic. Moya expects to remain profitable for the half year ending June 30, barring unforeseen circumstances.

site_title: US e-commerce mega-warehouses face new pollution rule
summary: The US e-commerce industry's largest warehouses in Southern California, including those used by Amazon, will face new pollution rules. A landmark rule adopted by the South Coast Air Quality Management District requires operators to slash emissions from diesel trucks or take other measures to improve air quality. The rule, which affects about 3,000 warehouses, aims to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions by up to 15% and public health benefits by up to $2.7 billion. The move sets a precedent for regulating the e-commerce industry and could spur a more rapid electrification of freight trucks.

site_title: The future of the Manchester United brand under scrutiny
summary: The Manchester United brand is under intense scrutiny following a fan invasion of the team's stadium and dressing rooms that led to a postponed match against Liverpool. The Glazer family, the club's US-based owners, have waved the white flag and promised to boost the club's prospects after years of limited communication with fans. This move comes after a series of protests and criticism over the family's handling of the club. The Glazers' commitment to improving the club's prospects is seen as a response to the growing discontent among fans.

site_title: UK cyber spies took down 15 times more scams in pandemic
summary: The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) reported a 15-fold increase in malicious campaigns taken down in 2020, with 700,595 scams launched during the pandemic. Hackers targeted hospitals and critical infrastructure, while impersonating government agencies and celebrities to trick people into giving up data or sending money. The rise in scams was attributed to the pandemic lockdown, with weaknesses in corporate security and people working from home. Companies like NameCheap and Amazon reported increased fraud and abuse cases, with response times decreasing to under 24 hours.

site_title: BioNTech committed to deliver 1.8b doses of Covid-19 vaccine this year
summary: BioNTech has committed to delivering 1.8 billion doses of its Covid-19 vaccine this year, with partner Pfizer, and expects 12.4 billion euros in revenue. This is an increase from a previous forecast of 9.8 billion euros. The company has also set up plans to produce several hundred million doses of its mRNA vaccines per year from 2023 in Singapore and has partnered with Fosun Pharma for up to 1 billion doses in China.

site_title: Washington should stop beating the war drums over Taiwan
summary: The US should reassess its diplomatic stance on Taiwan, amid growing tensions and warnings of a potential war between the US and China. Outgoing and current US Navy Admirals have expressed concerns that China will attempt to take over Taiwan within the next few years. However, Chinese officials have threatened military action if the US establishes full diplomatic relations with Taipei. The US has maintained a "strategic ambiguity" policy, but recent decisions to ease limitations on official US contacts with the Taiwanese government suggest a potential miscalculation, with the US possibly intending to contest the status quo.

site_title: India's Covid-19 cases dip from peak as calls for nationwide shutdown mount
summary: India's Covid-19 cases continue to rise, with 366,161 new infections and 3,754 deaths reported, taking the country's tally to 22.66 million and 246,116 deaths. Calls for a nationwide shutdown mount, with experts warning that India's actual figures could be far higher than reported. The Indian government is under pressure to address the crisis, with critics blaming Prime Minister Narendra Modi for allowing large gatherings and not taking decisive action earlier. Global support, including licensing deals with US company Eli Lilly, has poured in to help India combat the pandemic.

site_title: Archegos rout helps China hedge fund Seahawk to 120% gain in Q1
summary: A China-focused hedge fund, Seahawk China Dynamic Fund, led by Henry Liang, achieved a 120% gain in Q1, largely due to the collapse of Archegos Capital Management. The fund made bullish bets on Chinese fintech consumer lending platforms and wagers against over-hyped new-economy companies. These bets, including against GSX Techedu, contributed significantly to the quarterly return. Liang attributed the success to his strategy of betting against "bubble basket" companies.

site_title: Best World net profit more than doubles to S$37.9m
summary: Best World, a skincare products company, reported a net profit of S$37.9 million for the first quarter ended March 31, more than doubling from S$13.3 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 72.3% to S$128.5 million, primarily driven by increases in direct selling and franchise segments, particularly in China where sales jumped 87.1%. Despite a cautious outlook due to ongoing COVID-19 threats, the company's earnings per share increased to 6.97 Singapore cents.

site_title: SocGen to expand corporate banking after steep trading losses
summary: Societe Generale plans to shift its focus from volatile trading to corporate banking, aiming for a 10% return on normative equity by 2023. Following steep trading losses in 2020, CEO Frederic Oudea is reorienting the investment bank to prioritize client-centric services, including financing, advisory, and transaction banking. The bank expects a 3% revenue growth for its financing and advisory businesses and normalizes markets revenue to around €5 billion in 2023.

site_title: Suspected US pipeline hackers say aim is money, not mayhem
summary: A group called DarkSide, suspected of hacking into the US fuel pipeline operator Colonial Pipeline, claims its goal is to make money, not cause harm. The group stated that its actions are "apolitical" and not affiliated with any government. The hacking led to the shutdown of Colonial Pipeline's network, causing fuel deliveries to dry up and petrol prices to rise. The hackers have not specified how much money they are seeking, but have promised to avoid "social consequences" in the future.

site_title: Sterling surges above US$1.41, helped by Scotland relief and dollar weakness
summary: The British pound surged to a two-month high of US$1.4158 on Monday, driven by dollar weakness, improved economic forecasts, and market relief over the outcome of the Scottish election. Pro-independence parties won a majority in Scotland's Parliament, but the pound strengthened as market participants believed Nicola Sturgeon's party did not have a strong mandate for an immediate referendum. The pound also rose against the euro, and analysts attribute the move to dollar weakness and the Bank of England's bullish forecast for British economic growth.

site_title: Travellers from Singapore must undergo 14 days of quarantine in Malaysia, up from 10 days
summary: Travellers from Singapore must undergo a mandatory 14-day quarantine in Malaysia, starting May 13, up from the current 10-day period. The decision was made by Malaysia's National Security Council due to the presence of COVID-19 variants of concern (VOC) in Singapore. The VOCs include the B1351 South African variant, the B117 variant from Britain, and the B1128 variant reported in Brazil. This change affects travellers from Singapore who wish to enter Malaysia for business purposes, who will now need to go through the One-Stop Centre under the Malaysian Investment Development Agency.

images.alt_text: All travellers arriving in Malaysia from Singapore must undergo a mandatory 14-day quarantine from May 13, up from the current 10-day period.

site_title: US government, top fuel supplier work to secure pipelines as closure enters fourth day
summary: The US government and Colonial Pipeline, the top US fuel pipeline operator, worked to secure the network disrupted by a ransomware cyberattack, which entered its fourth day. The shutdown has sent fuel prices to a three-year high, with the southeastern US likely to see price increases at retail pumps first. The US government has organized a federal task force to assess the impact and avoid further disruptions. Experts suspect the hackers are from the cybercriminal group DarkSide, and the shutdown could last if the pipeline disruption continues, requiring alternative transportation methods to compensate.

site_title: Claims complaints process to be studied by panel for Integrated Shield sector
summary: Singapore's Integrated Shield (IP) sector may introduce a complaints process for patients and doctors, following concerns over insurers' medical panels and pre-authorisation. The Multilateral Healthcare Insurance Committee (MHIC) will study the issue, with the Academy of Medicine Singapore (AMS) and the Life Insurance Association (LIA) to support the process. The committee will also examine insurers' medical panels, transparency, and fee benchmarks, aiming to safeguard patient and public interests. The goal is to provide patients and doctors with an avenue for recourse and ensure the integrity of the healthcare system.

site_title: US Pentagon mulls ending JEDI cloud project amid Amazon court battle
summary: US Pentagon officials are considering ending the JEDI cloud-computing project amid a court battle with Amazon, which claims the Trump administration interfered in the contract process. Amazon lost the $10 billion contract to Microsoft in 2019. A US Court of Federal Claims judge recently refused to dismiss Amazon's claims, and the Pentagon completed a re-evaluation of contract proposals last year, determining Microsoft's submission represented the best value. The decision to end the project could be influenced by the ongoing court battle.

site_title: China turn to naturalised players to save World Cup hopes
summary: China has named five foreign-born players for critical World Cup qualifiers, including Brazilian trio Elkeson, Fernando Henrique, and Alan Carvalho, and former Everton defender Tyias Browning. Coach Li Tie has also picked former Arsenal midfielder Nico Yennaris. The move is part of China's naturalisation policy, which has been questioned by some Chinese media and pundits. China are second in Asian qualifying Group A, eight points behind leaders Syria, with their next matches set to take place in China from May 30 to June 15.

site_title: UBS explores offering crypto investments to rich clients: sources
summary: UBS is exploring offering cryptocurrency investments to its wealthy clients, joining US firms in expanding access to the asset class. The Swiss firm is considering alternatives, including investing through third-party vehicles, due to volatility concerns. Other global securities firms, such as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, are also developing cryptocurrency services. UBS aims to stay competitive and is monitoring the sector closely, with CEO Ralph Hamers looking to digitize operations and cut costs.

site_title: Six-storey commercial buildings in South Bridge Road on market
summary: Colliers International is selling two adjoining six-storey commercial buildings in South Bridge Road, Singapore, for S$45 million. The buildings, located on a lively F&B and lifestyle strip, offer high foot traffic and prominent frontages. The site has a gross plot ratio of 4.2 and is zoned "commercial," making it eligible for foreign buyers. The sale is seen as a "bite-size quantum" in the buoyant commercial market, with potential for reconfiguration and self-occupation. The EOI closes on June 16.

site_title: UG Healthcare posts S$34.3m Q3 net profit
summary: UG Healthcare posted a net profit of S$34.3 million for Q3 2021, almost 57 times its net profit in the previous year. Revenue more than doubled to S$93.5 million, driven by higher volumes of gloves sold and stable average selling prices. Gross profit jumped to S$58.6 million, with a 43.2 percentage-point increase in gross margin to 62.7%. The company has recorded four consecutive quarters of earnings growth and expects to commission additional production capacity of 500 million pieces per annum.

site_title: US state AGs urge Facebook to cancel Instagram for younger kids
summary: A group of 40 US state attorneys general urged Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to cancel plans to launch a version of Instagram for children under 13, citing concerns over the platform's impact on children's health and well-being. The letter cited a 2019 design flaw in Facebook's Messenger Kids app, which allowed children to join group chats with strangers. The attorneys general claim Facebook is creating a need for a platform, rather than responding to it, and that a version of Instagram for young children would put them at "great risk".

site_title: Brisbane edges closer to securing 2032 Olympics
summary: Brisbane is moving closer to securing the hosting rights for the 2032 Summer Olympics. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) is completing due diligence on the bid, with a vote expected by June 8. Influential Australian Olympic chief John Coates stated that Brisbane has cleared the final hurdles, and the city may be declared hosts as early as July. The Australian government has committed to splitting infrastructure costs 50-50 with local government, providing financial guarantees to the IOC. Brisbane would become the third Australian city to host the Olympics, after Melbourne and Sydney.

site_title: Malaysia declares nationwide lockdown as Covid-19 cases spike
summary: Malaysia has imposed a nationwide lockdown due to a surge in coronavirus cases and highly infectious variants, with Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin stating the country is facing a third wave of Covid-19. The lockdown, which will continue until June 7, bans inter-state and inter-district travel, social gatherings, and shuts educational institutions, while allowing economic sectors to continue operating. This is Malaysia's third lockdown since the pandemic began, with the country reporting 3,807 new cases and a total of 444,484 cases and 1,700 deaths.

site_title: SIIC Environment's Q1 profit up 23.1% to 160.1m yuan
summary: MAINBOARD-listed SIIC Environment Holdings posted a 23.1% rise in Q1 net profit to 160.1 million yuan, driven by revenue growth across all businesses, particularly construction income. Revenue rose 54% to 1.62 billion yuan. The company's construction income more than doubled to 570.9 million yuan, while operating and maintenance income increased 19.3%. CEO Yang Jianwei said the growth signals the group's operations are back on the "fast growth track."

site_title: UK PM Johnson's foreign travel investigated by Parliament watchdog
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is being investigated by Parliament's standards watchdog over his reporting of private foreign travel, including a 2019-2020 Caribbean holiday. Johnson declared a £15,000 accommodation benefit from a donor, but the opposition accuses his government of sleaze and cronyism. If found in breach, Johnson could face an apology or sanctions, including temporary suspension from Parliament or expulsion, which is extremely rare. The investigation increases scrutiny of Johnson's finances amid separate electoral authority reviews of his apartment refurbishment funding.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Critical illness insurance is more crucial than ever (Ep 95)
summary: Critical illness insurance is more crucial than ever, especially during the pandemic. The episode highlights the importance of having this insurance in your portfolio, as illnesses are happening at a younger age. Great Eastern's managing director, Colin Chan, explains how critical illness insurance can continue to cover you even after suffering from your first illness, and how a top-up premium is needed to ensure continued coverage. The episode also discusses the latest multi-pay critical illness plan and how to ensure continued coverage given the increasing age of illnesses.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 3.53 points lower at 1,583.92 on Monday, with a volume of 5.977 billion lots worth RM3.534 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 844 to 297.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit after tax jumps to S$23.3m, buoyed by government reliefs
summary: SBS Transit reported a profit after tax of S$23.3 million for Q1 2021, more than doubling from S$11.1 million the previous year, driven by government reliefs. Revenue fell 6.5% to S$317 million, while operating profit increased 70.9% to S$24.9 million. Ridership on the Downtown Line and North-East Line has shown a gradual recovery, but is unlikely to return to pre-Covid levels due to remote work practices. The company expects a prolonged and uneven recovery ahead, with reduced wage subsidies in 2021.

site_title: UK airline stocks cushioned by hopes for big June travel restart
summary: UK airline stocks lost 2-3% on Monday after the government announced a limited reopening of travel, but losses were cushioned by hopes for a bigger take-off in June. British Airways-owner IAG, easyJet, Jet2, and TUI saw declines, but analysts expect popular summer destinations like Spain, Italy, and the US to be added to the "green list" by June, sparking confidence in the industry. Crude prices rose, but expectations of loosening Covid restrictions and vaccine roll-out have lifted airline shares this year.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB, ex-unit seek recovery of US$23b in assets
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB and a former unit have filed 22 civil suits against firms including JPMorgan Chase & Co and Deutsche Bank to recover over $23 billion in assets linked to the scandal-plagued state-owned investment fund. The suits claim fraud and conspiracy against entities and individuals, including former Prime Minister Najib Razak and fugitive financier Jho Low. The government aims to recover billions allegedly siphoned from 1MDB, with recent settlements including Goldman Sachs' $3.9 billion pact and Deloitte's RM324-million settlement.

site_title: SPH Media CLG must set out new strategic direction, diversify funding: S Iswaran
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) must develop a new strategic direction and diversify funding for its media businesses after the government approves a restructuring plan. The new company limited by guarantee (CLG) will need to put forward a plan, and shareholders must approve the restructuring before the government decides on public funding. The government has set aside funding, but it will be capped, and the CLG must continue to be commercially driven, seeking out advertising and subscription revenue.

site_title: Pacific Star Q3 net loss widens; flags uncertainty over operating as going concern
summary: Pacific Star Development reported a net loss of S$8.2 million in Q3 2021, widening from S$8 million, due to a 90% decline in gross profit to S$56,000. Revenue fell 81% to S$674,000, primarily due to lower sales of Puteri Cove Residences units. The group faces uncertainty over its ability to operate as a going concern, with a S$69.3 million net liability position and potential contractual obligations. Discussions on restructuring loans and en bloc sales are ongoing, but their fruition is uncertain.

site_title: Cathay Pacific raises US$650m in first US dollar bond in 25 years
summary: Cathay Pacific has raised US$650 million in its first US dollar bond in 25 years, issuing 5.25-year senior unsecured notes priced at 4.875% per cent. The deal was priced 32.5 basis points cheaper than initially indicated, according to a term sheet seen by Reuters. The airline's move is seen as a significant step in securing funding and stabilizing its finances amidst ongoing challenges in the industry.

site_title: Second-biggest cryptocurrency ethereum breaks US$4,000 to hit record high
summary: Ethereum, the second-largest cryptocurrency, broke the US$4,000 mark for the first time, reaching a new peak for a third consecutive day. The coin jumped over 6% to US$4,175, driven by expectations of wider adoption, particularly in decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms. Analysts note that the current valuation may be overvalued, but the coin's soaring price this year is fueled by its potential for new uses.

site_title: F&N H1 net profit up 16.1% to S$83.4m
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) reported a 16.1% increase in net profit to S$83.4 million for the half-year ended March 31, 2021. Revenue rose 2% to S$988.6 million, driven by higher volumes in beverages and dairies segments. Beer revenue nearly doubled, while soft drink sales improved due to vending business and functional products. Dairies revenue inched up 1% due to higher canned milk sales and export volumes.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts lower targets on Genting Singapore on lower-than-expected earnings
summary: Brokerages have lowered their target prices for Genting Singapore following the company's Q1 FY2021 earnings, which missed expectations. Analysts attribute the decline to a 12% drop in total revenue, with non-gaming revenue falling 29% and gaming revenue increasing only 1.6%. The impact of the pandemic was deemed more severe than expected, with borders remaining closed and key foreign markets inaccessible. Analysts expect a recovery in the long term, citing Genting's strong balance sheet, but warn of slow near-term recovery prospects.

site_title: UMS Q1 net profit up 44% on sustained demand for semiconductors
summary: UMS Holdings, a precision-engineering firm, reported a 44% rise in Q1 net profit to S$15.4 million, driven by sustained demand for semiconductors worldwide. Revenue was up 42% to S$49.6 million, with the semiconductor segment increasing 47% due to higher integrated-system and component sales. The company also announced an interim dividend of one Singapore cent per share and benefited from a foreign-exchange gain. UMS expects to benefit from the sustained semiconductor upswing, with global fab equipment spending forecast to hit record highs until 2022.

site_title: Pandemic surge in European house prices raises fears of new bubble
summary: Europe's housing market is experiencing a surge in prices, driven by low interest rates, land shortages, and high demand. Cities like Stockholm, Berlin, and Luxembourg have seen double-digit price increases over the past year. Experts warn of a potential property bubble, with the Swedish central bank Governor Stefan Ingves stating that borrowing more and more could be a "worry not only for individuals but for society as a whole." To address the issue, governments are exploring innovative solutions, such as converting empty offices into homes and building on unused land. However, a quick fix is unlikely, and comprehensive structural changes are needed to bring the housing market into balance.

site_title: STI starts week on low note, falls 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares began the week on a cautious note, falling 0.6% or 17.85 points to close at 3,182.41 on Monday. Despite a strong Wall Street performance overnight, regional bourses ended mixed, with losses in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Malaysia offset by gains in China, Japan, South Korea, and Australia. Analysts attribute the losses to concerns about the US jobs recovery, but view it as positive for risk assets and negative for the US currency.

site_title: Monde Nissin attracts GIC, Fidelity to 48.6b peso IPO: sources
summary: Monde Nissin, a Philippine food maker, is set to raise 48.6 billion pesos (S$1.35 billion) through its 48.6 billion peso IPO, the country's largest-ever. The company, known for Lucky Me! instant noodles and Quorn in the UK, has attracted investors including GIC, Fidelity International, and AIA Group. The IPO, with a final price of 13.50 pesos per share, will begin trading on June 7. Monde Nissin plans to use the funds for loan repayment and general corporate use.

site_title: Grand Venture Technology Q1 earnings up 5 times
summary: Grand Venture Technology, a manufacturing-service provider listed on the CATALIST, reported a 59% rise in revenue to S$23 million in Q1, with a 32.1% gross profit margin, five times higher than the previous year. Revenue growth was driven by the semiconductor segment, which saw a 68.5% increase, and life sciences, which rose 38.4%. The company remains committed to maximizing shareholder value through strategic growth and resource deployment, with plans to enhance product and services offerings through research and development of advanced manufacturing techniques.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary:
Key events and facts include: 
KHAW Boon Wan to be chairman of SPH Media CLG, and will be joined by management shareholders as founding members. 
BioNTech to invest hundreds of millions to set up headquarters and vaccine manufacturing facility in Singapore. 
Singapore Business Federation stated the Republic cannot afford to close its borders completely to foreign workers. 
Government does not expect proposed SPH restructuring to affect its relationship with the newsroom.

site_title: BT Mark To Market: How to invest like Warren Buffett (Ep 7)
summary: Warren Buffett's investing philosophy, known as "Mark to Market," is discussed in the latest episode of the BT Mark To Market podcast. Host Ben Paul explains why Buffett's approach, which involves valuing assets at their current market value, is more relevant than ever. Paul analyzes key points from Buffett's strategy and shares insights on market trends and corporate issues in Singapore, emphasizing the importance of staying adaptable in the ever-changing investment landscape.

site_title: Australia: Miners help shares notch record closing highs
summary: Australian shares rose to record closing highs, led by a rally in miners due to strong commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index climbed 1.3% to 7,172.8, with BHP and Rio Tinto scaling record highs. US jobs data easing concerns about interest rate hikes aided equities globally. Broader Asian markets also rallied as Australian business conditions surged to all-time highs, and a buyout proposal for Crown Resorts boosted the stock.

site_title: Beijing slaps fines on tutoring apps backed by Tencent, Alibaba
summary: China has fined two of its fastest-growing tutoring apps, Yuanfudao (backed by Tencent Holdings) and Zuoyebang (backed by Alibaba Group), a combined 2.5 million yuan (S$515,000) for violating competition and pricing laws. The State Administration for Market Regulation found the firms made misleading claims, falsified qualifications of teaching staff, and faked user reviews. The fines are part of a crackdown on the private education sector, which has drawn increased scrutiny during the pandemic. Regulatory pressure is expected to continue, with the antitrust watchdog planning to intensify supervision and crack down on illegal activities.

site_title: 19 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, including two linked to Changi Airport cluster
summary: Singapore reported 19 new Covid-19 cases, including two linked to the Changi Airport cluster. Two workers at Changi Airport Terminal 3 tested positive, while a 59-year-old chef at MOS Burger - Suntec City also tested positive after visiting a hospital for an unrelated condition. The number of active clusters increased to 11, with the largest cluster at Tan Tock Seng Hospital. Meanwhile, 20 people were discharged, bringing the total number of fully recovered cases to 60,938.

site_title: BioNTech to invest 'hundreds of millions' to set up HQ, make vaccines in Singapore
summary: BioNTech plans to invest "hundreds of millions" in Singapore to set up its headquarters and a vaccine manufacturing facility, creating over 80 jobs. The facility, expected to open in 2023, will enable the company to produce mRNA-based vaccines and therapeutics for infectious diseases and cancer. The move aims to establish a footprint in Asia and provide a "rapid response production capability" for potential pandemic threats. The investment is supported by the Singapore Economic Development Board and is seen as a strategic step in building BioNTech's global footprint.

site_title: JPMorgan, Deutsche Bank are said to be among firms sued by 1MDB
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB has filed six lawsuits against nine unnamed entities, including JPMorgan Chase & Co and Deutsche Bank, seeking to recover over $23 billion in assets linked to the scandal-plagued state-owned investment fund. The lawsuits allege fraud and conspiracy against the firms and 25 individuals. This move comes after several other firms, including Goldman Sachs and Deloitte, have settled with the Malaysian government over their roles in 1MDB dealings. The government aims to recover losses from those involved in the scandal that brought down the government in 2018.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hit fresh record high as miners rally
summary: European stocks reached a fresh record high, driven by optimism over the reopening of economies and easy monetary policy. The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.1% as miners rallied 2.2% due to strong metal prices. The UK's FTSE 100 rose 0.2% despite a surge in the pound, with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson set to announce the next phase of reopening. The rally followed a 5-day streak of gains in Singapore stocks, with Asia's markets expected to remain positive amid US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Old, but gold
summary: Singapore is considering enacting a law against ageism despite its growing silver population, which could bring valuable life experience and contributions. Many CEOs, including Joanne Wong, argue that ageist attitudes hinder the potential of older workers. A law against ageism could help address this issue, but its effectiveness would depend on implementation and enforcement.

site_title: UK house price growth hits five-year high in April: Halifax
summary: UK house prices rose by 8.2% in April, the largest annual gain since 2016, driven by the extension of tax cuts for buyers by finance minister Rishi Sunak. House prices increased by 1.4% in April alone, the biggest monthly jump in seven months. The housing market has been boosted by the lifting of COVID-19 lockdowns and Sunak's tax cuts. Despite this, Halifax managing director Russell Galley expects house price growth to fade later this year due to potential higher unemployment.

site_title: Britain's Greggs raises profit outlook after trading recovers
summary: Greggs, a British bakery and fast-food chain, has raised its profit outlook after a strong recovery in sales following the easing of Covid-19 restrictions. Like-for-like sales in the eight weeks to May 8 were down 3.9% compared to the same period two years ago. The company expects profits to be around 2019 levels, reversing its previous expectation of 2022. This comes after the group expanded its home delivery services to 800 outlets and saw sales from this channel represent 8.2% of company-managed shop sales.

site_title: Taiwan to quarantine pilots of its largest airline amid Covid-19 outbreak
summary: Taiwan has quarantined all pilots of China Airlines, its largest airline, for 14 days amid a Covid-19 outbreak linked to the carrier. The move, implemented by Health Minister Chen Shih-chung, aims to stop the spread of the virus and prevent further transmission. The quarantine will impact China Airlines' passenger and freighter flights, with cargo flights prioritized. The airline has vowed to maintain some flight operations, but disruptions are expected. The outbreak has resulted in 35 confirmed cases, with some pilots believed to have contracted the virus overseas before returning to Taiwan.

site_title: In China's biggest cities, one in five cars sold is now electric
summary: China's six biggest cities now see one-fifth of new car sales as electric vehicles, with Shanghai reaching 31% and other cities averaging 16-25% penetration. This increase is attributed to local government policies, such as easier access to license plates in developed coastal cities. However, with rising traffic congestion, favorable treatment may not last, with Shanghai considering restrictions on small EVs. Overall, this trend is unlikely to impact long-term EV sales in China.

images.alt_text: Electric and hybrids now account for about one-fifth of new car sales on average in the six biggest Chinese cities, according to data from the China Passenger Car Association.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at record high as US jobs data shock eases rate woes
summary: South Korean shares ended at a record high on Monday, boosted by weak US jobs data that eased concerns over interest rate hikes. The benchmark Kospi rose 1.63% to close at 3,249.30, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rising 1.59% and 0.39%, respectively. Foreigners were net buyers of 238.7 billion won worth of shares, and the won rose 0.67% to 1,113.8 per dollar. The news supported expectations that interest rates would remain low for an extended period, lifting risk appetite and supporting a fourth consecutive gain for the Kospi index.

site_title: SINGA will lower hump in development expenditure from 5% of GDP annually to 4.2%
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat announced that Singapore's development expenditure will decrease from 5% of GDP to 4.2% annually over the next decade, thanks to the Significant Infrastructure Government Loan Act (SINGA). This estimate accounts for depreciation and borrowing costs. The reduction is necessary due to upcoming major projects such as new MRT lines and coastal defences, which are expected to increase development expenditure to 5% of GDP annually. The change aims to smoothen the upcoming development expenditure hump.

site_title: Meituan sinks after CEO deletes posting seen critical of Beijing
summary: Meituan's stock plummeted 9.8% in Hong Kong, its lowest in seven months, after CEO Wang Xing shared and then deleted a poem on social media that some interpreted as a criticism of Beijing. The poem, about book burning, was later clarified as a reference to competitors. This follows a trend of business figures facing consequences for perceived criticism of the government, including Jack Ma's public criticism last year. The incident has raised concerns among investors about the risks of speaking out against Beijing.

site_title: In China's 'Red Holy Land', tourists mark Communist Party centenary
summary: China is celebrating the 100th anniversary of its Communist Party with a propaganda push, showcasing its achievements in transforming a poor nation into a global superpower. The party has launched a PR campaign, including office history outings, big-budget movies, and media tours, in cities like Yan'an, dubbed the "Red Holy Land". Despite criticism from the West over human rights and ambitions, the party emphasizes its economic growth and rising living standards, while avoiding discussions of its darker past, including famine and crackdowns on resistance movements.

site_title: Not a 'global search': Khaw is the right pick to chair SPH Media, says Iswaran
summary: Singaporean Communications and Information Minister S Iswaran defended the appointment of Khaw Boon Wan as chairman of the SPH Media Company Limited, stating it was a "discussion" between the government and management shareholders, not a global search. Iswaran cited the precedent of former officials holding similar positions and emphasized the importance of editorial independence. Khaw accepted the role, acknowledging the "heavy responsibility" and vowing to ensure the project's success and uphold quality journalism.

site_title: Bring back your empty oxygen tanks to help conquer Covid, Nepal urges Everest climbers
summary: Nepal, struggling with a second wave of COVID-19, has asked climbers on Mount Everest to bring back their empty oxygen tanks to help alleviate the country's shortage. The country, which has issued permits to over 700 climbers for the April-May season, needs about 25,000 oxygen cylinders immediately. Nepal has only 1,600 ICU beds and fewer than 600 ventilators, with many hospitals unable to take in patients due to the shortage. The request comes as the country reports 8,777 new infections and 30 times the number of cases recorded on April 9.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares weighed down by technology sector
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.1% to 28,595.66, weighed down by the technology sector, which dropped 0.9% amid signs of anti-trust regulations. Alibaba and Meituan plummeted, while healthcare firms rebounded after US patent waiver proposal. Energy shares rose sharply after a cyber attack on a US pipeline operator. The Hang Seng Tech index also dropped due to the regulators' campaign against tech giants.

site_title: Iron ore turns 'very hot' as 10% surge adds to commodities boom
summary: Iron ore futures surged over 10% and copper hit a record, driven by optimism about central banks' supportive policies and expectations of environmental rule tightening in China. The commodities boom is stoking concerns about inflation worldwide. The Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index has climbed for 14 of the past 15 days, its highest level in nearly a decade. Iron ore prices have risen about 40% this year, while copper is seen reaching $11,000 and $14,000 per ton in the next 12 and 24 months, respectively.

site_title: Deals of the week: A US$300m Jek-pot; the debt-fuelled hustle for e-commerce brands
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several startups raised significant funding in the past week. Gojek received an additional $300 million from Telkomsel, while two Singapore-based startups, Una Brands and Rainforest, secured $76 million to acquire e-commerce brands. Fintech startup FewCents raised $1.6 million, and Big Data analytics startup Bonza secured $2 million. EDB New Ventures launched a $10 million pilot program to co-invest with large companies, and Acronis doubled its valuation to $2.5 billion after a $250 million funding round. Meanwhile, SCI Ecommerce raised over $50 million to expand in South-east Asia ahead of a potential Nasdaq listing.

site_title: Japan's Q1 GDP likely slipped back into decline as new Covid-19 curbs hit: poll
summary: Japan's economy likely contracted by an annualized 4.6% in the first quarter, according to a Reuters poll, due to coronavirus curbs offsetting robust global demand. Private consumption fell 2.0% and capital expenditure rose 1.1% in the quarter. The country's slow recovery from the pandemic is expected to continue, with state of emergency curbs and slow vaccine rollouts expected to keep growth feeble in April-June. The government will release preliminary January-March GDP data on May 18.

site_title: UBS bankers get US$40,000 bonus on promotion to associate level
summary: UBS Group will pay a US$40,000 one-time bonus to its global banking analysts when they are promoted to associate level, doubling the amount offered by competitors. The bonus, representing about 30% of the annual base pay, aims to reward and retain younger employees weighed down by increased business and work-from-home demands. This move follows other lenders, such as HSBC Holdings and Houlihan Lokey, in raising pay and promoting staff to avoid burnout.

site_title: Saudi non-oil economy grows for first time since pandemic
summary: Saudi Arabia's non-oil economy has grown for the first time since the pandemic, with a 3.3% increase in the first quarter. This growth was driven by consumer spending rebounding and plans to partially reopen borders. The oil sector, however, contracted 12% due to production cuts, leading to an overall economy contraction of 3.3%. The International Monetary Fund expects the economy to grow 2.1% this year. The kingdom's economy is gradually recovering after the twin crisis caused by oil market turmoil and coronavirus-related lockdowns.

site_title: India central bank relief measures to only delay stress for financial institutions: Fitch
summary: India's central bank relief measures to lenders and borrowers during the Covid-19 surge will only delay financial stress, Fitch Ratings said. The Reserve Bank of India's loan restructuring scheme and debt repayment extensions will provide temporary relief but won't address underlying asset-quality problems. Disruptions could persist longer and spread further, especially if lockdowns are introduced nationwide, and India's slow vaccination pace leaves it vulnerable to future pandemic waves. The measures are expected to have a short-term impact, with Fitch warning that the country's economic recovery may be delayed.

site_title: 'Vaccine tourists' fly from abroad for injections on US beach
summary: Dozens of travelers from Latin America, including Ecuador, El Salvador, and Venezuela, have flocked to Miami Beach, Florida, to receive a free, single-dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine, as vaccine rollout has been slow and supply shortages hindered access in their countries. The pop-up vaccination booth, with no proof of residence required, has vaccinated over 175 people, sparking concerns about unequal access to healthcare and the need for the US government to send vaccines overseas.

site_title: Gojek bags US$300m more in funding from Singtel Indonesia associate Telkomsel
summary: TELKOMSEL, an associate of Singtel Indonesia, has invested an additional US$300 million in ride-hailing startup Gojek, bringing the total investment to US$400 million. The investment, which was previously US$150 million in November, aims to strengthen their existing collaboration. The move has the approval and support of Telkomsel's shareholders, including Telkom Indonesia and Singtel group.

site_title: UK grid installs new kit to stop green power going to waste
summary: National Grid Plc in the UK is installing new smart valves to optimize renewable power distribution, reducing waste and freeing up enough power to supply a million homes. The technology will automatically route excess power to areas with available capacity, helping the UK reach carbon neutrality by 2025. The smart valves, installed at three substations, will unlock 500 megawatts of new network capacity, with plans to roll out the same technology at two more sites later this year. This move aims to maximize existing power lines and reduce costs for end consumers.

site_title: Singapore cannot afford 'convulsions and closures' in media landscape: S Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information, S Iswaran, expressed concern over potential "convulsions and closures" in the local media landscape, which could lead to a loss of diversity and choice. He emphasized the need for a high-quality, professional news media that reports "news by Singaporeans for Singaporeans" while maintaining accuracy, objectivity, and balance. The government has been an active steward of the local media industry, and Iswaran urged caution against restructuring that could disrupt the market, given global challenges faced by publications worldwide.

site_title: Khaw Boon Wan: What we know about 'Mr Fix-it', SPH Media's first chairman
summary: Khaw Boon Wan, Singapore's former Minister of Health and Housing, will become the chairman of the new SPH Media Company Limited by Guarantee. A veteran of the Sars crisis and transport minister, Khaw was known for tackling challenging portfolios. He has been involved in the PAP party's reforms and has held various ministerial positions, including Minister of Health and Housing. As chairman of SPH Media, Khaw will lead the management and drive reforms.

images.alt_text: Former transport minister Khaw Boon Wan was popularly known as the 'Fix-it' minister for taking on challenging portfolios.

site_title: DBS issues more than S$450m in Sora-pegged SME loans
summary: DBS has issued over S$450 million in Sora-pegged SME loans, accounting for about one-third of new SME loans, following Singapore's end of SOR loan product issuance. The bank's head of SME banking, Joyce Tee, sees this as a "positive sign" for Singapore's transition to Sora as the main interest rate benchmark. DBS is partnering clients to achieve a seamless transition to alternative Risk-Free Benchmark Rates, which are derived from overnight deposit rates. The move signals DBS's commitment to supporting SMEs during the transition to the new interest rate benchmark.

site_title: UK officials admit some markets to be subject to duties under post-Brexit deal terms: FT
summary: UK officials have confirmed that some freeport markets in Britain will be subject to duties under post-Brexit deal terms, specifically for exports to countries including Canada, Norway, Switzerland, and Singapore. This contradicts initial claims that freeports would be tax-efficient zones. The move affects companies in freeport-type zones, which will not benefit from the new trade agreements. The Finance Minister had previously announced plans to establish freeports at various airports and ports.

site_title: Gold firms as US jobs data miss cements low rates view
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to near a three-month peak at $1,832.26 per ounce, supported by weaker-than-expected US jobs data that suggests interest rates will remain low for some time. This has bolstered the metal's appeal, with US gold futures also up 0.1% at $1,832.60 per ounce. The data has reduced expectations of a rate hike, keeping interest rates low and making gold a more attractive investment option.

site_title: Government does not expect proposed SPH restructuring to affect relationship: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's government does not anticipate a change in its relationship with newsroom operator Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) following SPH's proposed restructuring of its media business. The proposed transfer of the media business to a company limited by guarantee (CLG) aims to reinvest profits into media operations rather than distributing them to shareholders. This move is expected to maintain the government's relationship with SPH, according to Minister for Communications and Information S Iswaran.

site_title: Asia: Stocks lifted by US jobs miss, oil rises on pipeline attack
summary: Asian stocks rose on Monday, driven by a better-than-expected US jobs report and rising oil prices after a cyber attack on a US pipeline. The US jobs report eased inflation concerns, with analysts predicting the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates low for some time. Oil prices jumped over 1% after the attack on the Colonial Pipeline Company, which serves 50 million consumers. Despite concerns about the impact of stimulus on job growth, the outlook for a strong recovery remains intact.

site_title: France's SocGen seeks to boost investment bank returns
summary: SocGen, France's third-largest listed bank, plans to reduce risk exposure in its global markets business and focus on financing and advising on deals to boost profitability. The bank aims to achieve a return on normative equity of over 10% in its global banking and investors solutions businesses by 2023. SocGen also targets a cost base of €5.5-5.7 billion in 2023, down from €5.8 billion in 2020, as it presses on with previously announced savings. The bank's shares have risen 46% this year, but its market value remains less than half its 2008 peak.

site_title: Khaw Boon Wan to be chairman of SPH Media CLG, management shareholders to be founding members
summary: Singapore's Khaw Boon Wan, a former minister, will chair a new company limited by guarantee (CLG) formed as part of Singapore Press Holdings' (SPH) restructuring. Existing management shareholders have agreed to form the CLG and be its founding members, with the goal of reinvesting profits into the media business. The CLG will operate as a revenue-seeking business, subject to commercial disciplines, and will be supported by the government with funds for digital innovation and capability development. Khaw will share his thoughts on the way forward, and the CLG aims to ensure the local news media remains in trusted institutions with a long-term stake in Singapore.

site_title: Kimly sees H1 profit more than double to S$21.7m, declares 0.56-cent interim dividend
summary: Kimly, a coffee shop operator, has reported a net profit of S$21.7 million for the first six months of the year, more than doubling from S$10.5 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 14.2% to S$122.6 million, with improved gross margin and lower cost of sales. The company has declared an interim dividend of 0.56 cent, double the previous year's dividend. Kimly attributes its growth to a steady recovery in the F&B sector, despite new COVID-19 strains emerging in parts of Asia.

site_title: Two South Bridge Road commercial buildings for sale with S$45m indicative price
summary: Colliers International is selling two adjoining freehold commercial buildings in Singapore's South Bridge Road area for S$45 million, or approximately S$3,550 per square foot. The buildings have a combined site area of 2,325 square feet and a total gross floor area of 12,700 square feet. The sale is part of an expression of interest process that began on May 11.

site_title: Shipyards in China's vessel-repair hub ban arrivals from India
summary: Shipyards in China's Zhoushan city have banned vessels from India and Bangladesh that called at or changed crews in the last three months due to rising COVID-19 infections. The ban, implemented after 11 crew members tested positive for the virus, prohibits arrival for maintenance and repair work. However, ships transporting cargoes from India are allowed to dock. The restrictions are expected to affect thousands of seafarers, particularly those from India, which makes up 15% of the world's total crew members.

site_title: Hot stock: SPH rebounds as much as 5.6% in early trading
summary: SPH shares rebounded 5.6% in early trading, reaching an intraday high of S$1.605, after falling 15.1% last Friday on news of its proposed restructuring. The media and property group will transfer its business to a company limited by guarantee for a cash injection of S$80 million and shares. Research firm UOB Kay Hian reiterated a "buy" rating, citing potential upside of 17.8% and estimates of lifted core earnings by 26% and 36% in FY2022 and FY2023, respectively.

site_title: Bolivian wine-growers banking on 'distinctive' altitude flavour
summary: Bolivian wine-growers are capitalizing on the country's unique high-altitude climate to produce distinctive wines. At over 2,000 meters above sea level, the region's intense sunshine and humidity produce thicker grape skins and higher resveratrol content, believed to offer health benefits. Bolivian wines are gaining popularity, particularly in La Paz, where a gastronomic boom is driving demand for local flavors. Despite limited production, experts believe Bolivia has room to improve quality and potentially establish itself as a notable wine-producing country.

site_title: South Korea President Moon vows to raise fiscal spending to create jobs
summary: South Korea President Moon Jae In announced plans to increase fiscal spending to boost jobs, aiming for an economic growth rate of over 4% this year. The move comes as the country faces its worst unemployment rate in two decades, with 5% of the workforce losing jobs in the first quarter. Moon vowed to focus on supporting young people and women, and will consider additional fiscal spending if needed to meet his goal of adding 500,000 new jobs annually. The government has already pledged 310 trillion won in fiscal outlays through supplementary budgets in 2020.

site_title: Ford recalls 661,000 Explorer SUVs in North America
summary: Ford Motor Co is recalling 661,000 Explorer SUVs in North America due to a potential issue with retention pins that could cause roof rail covers to detach. The recall affects 2016-2019 model year vehicles and will involve the installation of push-pins and replacement of damaged components.

site_title: Support for Japan's Suga hits new low after emergency extended
summary: Support for Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga has hit a new low, dropping to 40% in a poll after he extended a state of emergency to combat rising coronavirus infections. The poll also found 63% disapproved of his government's handling of the pandemic. Suga's government faces a party leadership election in September and must hold a general election by the end of October. Meanwhile, Japan's slow vaccine rollout has left only 2.4% of the population vaccinated, with many questioning whether the government can meet its immunization target by the end of July.

site_title: Osaka wants 'discussion' on Olympics amid virus surge in Japan
summary: Japanese tennis star Naomi Osaka suggests a "discussion" over holding the Olympics in Tokyo amid a new coronavirus surge in Japan. A virus state of emergency was extended in the capital city and other areas less than three months before the delayed Games. Osaka, a four-time Grand Slam winner, believes the Olympics should be postponed if it puts people at risk, but also wants them to happen. Over 10,000 athletes from 200 countries are set to travel to Tokyo, with a decision on domestic fan attendance to be made in June.

site_title: Singapore cannot afford to close borders completely to foreign workers: SBF
summary: The Singapore Business Federation (SBF) has stated that the city-state cannot afford to completely close its borders to foreign workers, citing insufficient manpower in key sectors such as food and beverage, healthcare, and logistics. The SBF welcomes the government's increase in foreign worker levy rebates for the construction, marine shipyard, and process sectors, but urges the government to relax new restrictions on entry approvals as soon as the Covid-19 situation allows. The chamber also hopes to expand the list of lower-risk regions to allow for more worker sources.

site_title: Australia's April business conditions surge to record high: NAB
summary: Australia's business conditions reached a record high in April, according to NAB's index, jumping 8 points to +32. This surge was driven by increased sales, profits, and employment across most sectors and regions. Confidence also reached a record +26, with capacity utilisation at 85.3%, indicating an expansion in business investment and hiring. The labor market is continuing its recovery, with the jobless rate at 5.5%. The index of national sales, profitability, and employment also reached historic peaks, suggesting ongoing strength in the economy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on Monday with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index gaining 0.58% to 28,776.99, driven by data showing fewer US jobs created last month, easing concerns about inflation. The benchmark Shanghai Composite Index also edged up, while Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.52 points, or 0.03%, to 1,586.93. The market saw 363.79 million lots traded worth RM197.17 million. There were 242 gainers and 241 losers.

site_title: Oil gains after cyberattack forces closure of US fuel 'jugular' pipeline
summary: US oil prices rose after a major cyberattack forced the shutdown of the Colonial Pipeline, a critical fuel supply network. The attack, which involved ransomware, forced the pipeline to shut down nearly half of the US East Coast's fuel supply. Oil prices increased by 0.6-0.5% at $68.66-65.24 per barrel. The White House is working with Colonial Pipeline to recover from the attack, and lawmakers are calling for stronger protections for US energy infrastructure from hacking attacks.

site_title: Rescuers save small whale stranded in the Thames
summary: Rescuers in southwest London successfully freed a small minke whale from the River Thames on Sunday night. The whale, estimated to be around 4 meters long, was hosed down and placed on a large yellow float before being moved to a safer location. A veterinarian will assess the whale's health to determine if it's fit for release. The incident occurred near a lock in Richmond, with a small crowd gathering to watch the rescue efforts. The whale is a species commonly found in the North Atlantic Ocean, but its exact origin is unclear.

site_title: UK cyber spies took down 15-times more scams during pandemic
summary: The UK's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) reported a 15-fold increase in malicious campaigns taken down in 2020, with 700,595 schemes detected, compared to 46,784 the previous year. The surge in scams was attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, with attackers impersonating celebrities, shops, and government agencies to trick people into giving up data or sending money. The NCSC targeted new types of activity and found that attacks were active for longer on average, with some campaigns lasting over 60 hours.

images.alt_text: The NCSC took down 700,595 malicious campaigns last year, 15-times more than a year earlier as the number of scams increased and the service began targeting new types of activity, the agency said in a report published on Monday.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Monday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by rallies on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index up 0.26% and the Topix index up 0.27%. Investors are monitoring the pandemic's impact on the global economy.

site_title: Gates divorce talks begun in 2019 on Epstein link: WSJ
summary: Melinda French Gates began working with divorce lawyers in October 2019 due to concerns about her husband Bill Gates' dealings with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Her unease about Epstein dates back to at least 2013, when the couple met with him. The divorce was negotiated during the pandemic, with the couple planning to remain co-chairs and trustees of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Gates transferred over $2 billion in equity stakes to Melinda in the days following the split, which was announced last week.

site_title: Food, glorious comfort food: How going digital will help F&B thrive
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated changes in consumer habits, with digital adoption increasing among younger generations in Asia. Traditional food and beverage (F&B) businesses, many of which are small and vulnerable, are struggling to adapt. Digital platforms and technology offer a new channel to attract and engage with consumers, with examples such as Fly-Food's partnership with Alipay, which has helped Thai restaurants reach expatriates. Governments in the region are also supporting F&B businesses through initiatives like Singapore's Hawkers Go Digital program. By embracing digital technologies, F&B businesses can improve resilience and sustainability, and thrive in the post-pandemic era.

site_title: Court wrong to let Citi's US$504m transfer error stand, groups say
summary: Citigroup was ordered to let investment firms keep $504 million they received in error, despite not being due for three years. Legal experts and advocacy groups argue that the decision misapplied legal precedent and could harm industry standards. The groups claim that the payment was a "giant red flag" and that the law should not encourage similar "self-imposed ignorance." Citigroup has appealed the decision, citing that the payment caused "shockwaves through the markets" and generated outcry across the financial industry.

site_title: US government working to aid top fuel pipeline operator after cyberattack
summary: The US government is working closely with Colonial Pipeline, the top fuel pipeline operator, to recover from a ransomware attack that forced the shutdown of a critical fuel network supplying eastern states. The Biden administration is prioritizing the fix, aiming to restart the pipeline network as quickly as possible to avoid severe fuel supply disruptions. The attack has prompted calls for strengthened protections against hacking of critical US energy infrastructure.

site_title: Two suspects held after French police officer shot and killed
summary: French police arrested two suspects, believed to be the shooter and accomplice, in the fatal shooting of officer Eric Masson in Avignon, southern France. Masson, 36, was killed while investigating a suspected drug-dealing site on Wednesday. The suspects were arrested around 20km from the city.

images.alt_text: Masson, 36, and a father-of-two, was shot and killed Wednesday while investigating activity at a known drug-dealing site in the city.

site_title: Inflation tantrum no easy win for consumer stocks
summary: Consumer stocks may benefit from inflation, but only if they can pass on price hikes to consumers. However, this is not a straightforward process, as commoditized products can be easily replaced by cheaper alternatives. Brands with strong market share, pricing power, and brand loyalty are more likely to succeed. Examples include British American Tobacco and WH Group, which have seen stable profits despite rising input costs. Investors should focus on companies with minimal lag in passing on costs to consumers and those with sustainable competitive advantages.

site_title: Dogecoin loses third of price after Elon Musk calls it a 'hustle' on 'SNL'
summary: Elon Musk's comments on Dogecoin as a "hustle" on Saturday Night Live led to a significant price drop, with Dogecoin losing over 36% of its value to $0.416 on crypto exchange Binance. The cryptocurrency's price later recovered, but Musk's remarks sparked concerns about the impact of his comments on the market. Despite this, some experts see the long-term fundamentals of Dogecoin intact and view the recent price drop as a buying opportunity.

site_title: Singapore shares edge lower at Monday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Monday, down 0.1% or 1.82 points, as hospitality-related stocks declined after four more workers at Changi Airport tested positive for Covid-19. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell to 3,198.44, with Genting Singapore and mm2 Asia among the top losers. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS, UOB, and OCBC beating analyst expectations. The US saw record highs on Friday, with the Dow and S&P 500 rising 0.7% and 0.9%, respectively.

site_title: Search is on for fastest growing companies in Singapore
summary: Singapore's fastest-growing companies will be identified through the annual rankings compiled by The Straits Times and Statista, with the report set to be published in January 2022. The criteria for consideration include annual revenue of at least S$150,000 in 2017 and S$1.5 million in 2020. Companies must register online by August 31 to be eligible. The survey highlights firms that have used technology to provide innovative twists to their businesses, with last year's list featuring companies in car sales and precious metal recycling.

site_title: Trump 'egged on' Capitol rioters: Facebook panel co-chair
summary: Facebook's oversight panel co-chair Michael McConnell stated that former US President Donald Trump "egged on" Capitol rioters, justifying his suspension from the platform. The panel gave Facebook six months to justify Trump's permanent ban, citing the platform's unclear and internally inconsistent rules. McConnell emphasized that private companies like Facebook are not bound by the First Amendment and that Trump is a customer, not a citizen. The panel also made recommendations to address potentially harmful content from world leaders and called for urgent action to prevent significant harm.

site_title: SpaceX to launch lunar mission paid with cryptocurrency Dogecoin
summary: SpaceX is set to launch a satellite to the Moon in 2022, funded entirely with cryptocurrency Dogecoin. The satellite, DOGE-1, will be launched aboard a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket and will aim to collect "lunar-spatial intelligence" using sensors and cameras. This mission will be the first-ever commercial lunar payload paid entirely with Dogecoin, marking a step towards interplanetary commerce. The announcement comes after SpaceX founder Elon Musk praised Dogecoin in a recent SNL sketch, calling it "an unstoppable vehicle that's going to take over the world."

site_title: How Singapore built a startup ecosystem from scratch
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem has grown significantly since its inception, transforming from a small scrappy operation to a thriving hub. The country's strategic location and favorable business environment have attracted numerous startups, including Grab, which expanded from Malaysia. Today, Singapore is a key player in the global startup scene, hosting companies like OpenAI and Manus, a Chinese AI startup. The city-state's success is attributed to its ability to foster innovation and collaboration between startups and corporations, making it an attractive destination for deep tech innovation and investment.

site_title: Singapore's stellar stock run stalls as virus cases jump
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index has stalled at almost 1% so far in May, paring its 2021 gains to around 13%, amid rising virus cases and a rethink of the global reflation trade. The country's high vaccine coverage and strong exports have supported the index, but social distancing rules and a seasonally weak month have weighed on investor sentiment. Analysts predict a pullback in the benchmark, with DBS Bank's Kee Yan Yeo saying the STI may turn sideways in coming months.

site_title: NZ's a2 Milk to review China plan as daigou woes force third sales downgrade
summary: New Zealand's a2 Milk has cut its full-year sales forecast for the third time due to disruptions and excess inventory in its key sales channel in China, where the company is reviewing its growth strategy. The company's daigou channel, which relies on international sales, has been impacted by fewer tourists and students. A2 Milk now expects 2021 revenue between NZ$1.20 billion and NZ$1.25 billion, down from its earlier forecast of NZ$1.40 billion, and will set aside NZ$80-90 million in provisions to cover writing off inventory.

site_title: Diesel jeans billionaire looks to stitch together Italian fashion front
summary: Diesel jeans billionaire Renzo Rosso is urging Italy's small fashion companies to work together to create a more united front and compete with global rivals. Rosso, appointed as a delegate of Confindustria, aims to convince entrepreneurs to form partnerships and alliances to boost visibility and sustainability. With iconic brands like Giorgio Armani and Salvatore Ferragamo potentially being acquired by foreign players, Rosso seeks to keep these companies in Italian hands by fostering collaboration and government support.

site_title: Turkey's new canal across Istanbul to cost US$15b
summary: Turkey's President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's Canal Istanbul project, a 45-kilometer waterway linking the Black Sea with the Sea of Marmara, will cost approximately US$15 billion. The project, which includes six bridges, aims to create a city with a population of half a million. Critics express concerns over the venture's impact on international agreements and environmental effects, while the government claims it will enhance control over shipping to and from the Black Sea. Two new dams will be built to compensate for water loss.

site_title: Johnson confirms indoor mixing allowed in England from May 17
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson confirmed that England will lift indoor mixing restrictions on May 17 as planned, with people allowed to stay overnight with friends or relations and indoor hospitality reopening. The decision comes after the UK's Covid-19 infection rate reaches its lowest level since September, with over 50 million vaccine doses administered. The government said limited international travel will also resume on May 17. Johnson stated that the "road map remains on track" and the UK is "not going to let this virus beat us."

site_title: Norway to tap green power to run pollutive offshore oil and gas fields
summary: Norway plans to electrify its offshore oil and gas platforms using land-based green hydropower, aiming to meet national climate targets and extend the industry's lifespan. The move, funded by taxpayers, will primarily reduce emissions from extraction, not consumption. Despite this, the initiative is seen as a way to balance economic interests with climate goals, as the country is a significant carbon exporter. Eight offshore platforms, accounting for less than 10% of the total, have already been connected to the power grid, with more planned, including the giant Troll B and C platforms.

site_title: Cars keep getting pricier, exacerbated by commodity boom
summary: Commodity prices, particularly copper, steel, and aluminum, have surged to record highs this year due to lagging supply and stimulus-driven demand, leading to increased costs for carmakers. This could result in higher car prices, potentially fuelling inflation. Analysts estimate a 83% increase in car raw material prices, which would translate to an 8.3% price hike for a $40,000 vehicle. Automakers like Ford and BMW are exploring alternative chemistries for EV batteries to mitigate the impact of rising commodity costs.

images.alt_text: Carmakers usually struggle to pass on higher costs, but demand is booming as major economies reopen, and many consumers continue avoiding public transportation.

site_title: Dogecoin tumbles after Elon Musk calls it a 'hustle'
summary: Dogecoin's value plummeted 28% to US$0.47 after Tesla CEO Elon Musk called it a "hustle" during a Saturday Night Live appearance. Musk had previously expressed support for the cryptocurrency, which has surged over 800% in the past month, and even said it had a "good chance" of becoming the "future currency of the Earth." Musk's comments, which were met with laughter from the show's cast, led to a sharp decline in dogecoin's price on major crypto exchange Binance.

site_title: US fuel sellers scramble to make delivery after hackers shut pipeline
summary: The nation's largest oil-products pipeline, Colonial Pipeline, was shut down after a ransomware attack, leaving fuel suppliers scrambling to secure alternative methods of delivery. Traders and fuel shippers are seeking barges and ships to deliver petrol, while others are securing tankers to store petrol in the US Gulf. The attack, which affected some of the pipeline's IT systems, comes as the US energy industry prepares to meet stronger fuel demand associated with summer travel, with petrol demand growing steadily this year.

site_title: Hackers of Colonial Pipeline steal data a day ahead of ransomware lockdown
summary: Hackers from the DarkSide cybercrime gang stole nearly 100 gigabytes of data from Colonial Pipeline in two hours before locking computers with ransomware, threatening to leak the data unless a ransom is paid. The attack, part of a double-extortion scheme, has halted pipeline operations on the US East Coast. Colonial Pipeline shut down the main source of petrol, diesel, and jet fuel without specifying when it would reopen. The incident highlights the leverage hackers have over victims in ransomware attacks, and it comes as the Biden administration has identified ransomware as a priority.

site_title: Australia's Star makes A$9b play for Crown, taking on private equity giants
summary: Australia's Star Entertainment Group proposed an all-stock buyout of Crown Resorts Ltd valued at A$9 billion, competing with private equity giants Blackstone Group and Oaktree Capital Group. Star offered 2.68 of its shares for each Crown share, valuing Star shares at A$5 each, up from A$3.91. The move follows Blackstone's A$8.4 billion all-cash offer and Oaktree's A$3 billion buyback proposal for Crown's founder's stake.

images.alt_text: Australian casino operator Star Entertainment Group on Monday proposed an all-stock buyout of larger rival Crown Resorts Ltd that it valued at A$9 billion (S$9.28 billion), vying with two private equity giants for control of the troubled target.

site_title: Stock bull run rolls on with JPMorgan doubling down on reflation
summary: US stocks continue their bull run, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 surging after a strong jobs report and President Biden's fiscal aid package. JPMorgan strategists are doubling down on the reflation trade, recommending clients increase holdings in cyclical and value assets as inflation is expected to rise. The Fed's accommodative stance and low interest rates are expected to sustain tech valuations, while banks and airlines are poised to benefit from inflation.

site_title: Da Vinci's 'Head of a Bear' drawing seen fetching up to US$16.7m
summary: Leonardo da Vinci's drawing "Head of a Bear" is set to fetch up to US$16.7 million at an auction in July, potentially breaking a record for a drawing by the Italian Renaissance master. Measuring 7cm squared, the silverpoint drawing on pink-beige paper is one of fewer than eight surviving drawings by Da Vinci in private hands outside of the British Royal Collection. The drawing will go on display in New York, Hong Kong, and London before the auction, with a price estimate of £8-12 million.

images.alt_text: Measuring seven centimetres squared, Head of a Bear is a silverpoint drawing on a pink-beige paper.

site_title: Banks, tech firms hit by new work pass restrictions
summary: Singapore's restrictions on work pass holders from higher-risk regions may cause temporary uncertainty for tech and financial companies, but industry experts believe it's unlikely to dent expansion plans. Companies have adapted to remote work and can pivot to meet needs. Hiring trends have shifted, with employers open to work-from-home arrangements. Some companies, like PatSnap and Ademco, prioritize local talent, while banks like OCBC and HSBC plan to continue seeking international talent. The restrictions may impact some projects, but experts expect banks to cope and adapt, and Singapore's reputation as a choice employer remains intact.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ESR-Reit, Genting, Singapore banks, Sarine, Sinostar PEC
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch on Monday include ESR-Reit, Genting, Singapore banks, Sarine, and Sinostar PEC. ESR-Reit's units fell 9.8% amid heavy trading after announcing a S$150 million fundraise. Genting Singapore's shares rose 0.6% after beating analyst expectations. The three local banks - DBS, OCBC, and UOB - also beat expectations with stronger fee income and lower credit costs. Sarine posted a revenue of US$17.3 million in its first quarter, while Sinostar PEC saw a significant jump in net profit to 59.3 million yuan. Tuan Sing shares fell 1.2% after announcing a group CFO change.

site_title: NY property managers take wait-and-see attitude over reopening
summary: New York property managers are taking a cautious approach to reopening their buildings after Governor Andrew Cuomo announced the city's full capacity reopening on May 19. While many tenants are eager to celebrate, property managers are hesitant to relax COVID-19 protocols, citing concerns about staff safety and the need for continued cleaning and disinfection. Many are instead focusing on vaccinating staff and exploring incentives, such as $100 to $200 bonuses, to encourage employees to get vaccinated.
