summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, down 0.20% or 58.64 points at 29,272.73, due to concerns over an expected extension of Japan's virus state of emergency. This countered rallies on Wall Street. The broader Topix index inched down 0.01% or 0.21 points to 1,927.19.

site_title: Washington weighs risk of defending Taiwan against China
summary: US President Joe Biden is expected to announce a strategy toward China soon, with calls growing for a clear public commitment to defend Taiwan militarily in the event of Chinese aggression. The US has pursued "strategic ambiguity" for decades, but experts like Richard Haass believe it's time for clarity to curb Chinese aggression and prevent Taiwan's formal declaration of independence. The US military fears a surprise invasion by China, and some advisers, like Avril Haines, warn that a clear policy would be "deeply destabilising" for China.

site_title: Japan seeking to extend state of emergency until May 31: economy minister
summary: Japan's economy minister announced plans to extend the current state of emergency in Tokyo and four other areas until May 31 to curb rising coronavirus cases. The extension would affect prefectures of Fukuoka and Aichi, adding to the existing areas of Osaka, Kyoto, and Hyogo. The move raises concerns about the city's ability to host the Tokyo Olympics, set to open in fewer than two months.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Friday, down 3.82 points, or 0.24%, to 1,574.51. Volume was 481.16 million lots worth RM247.85 million. Losers beat gainers 234 to 229.

site_title: Fasanara Capital to invest S$50m in Validus to boost SME lending in Singapore
summary: Fasanara Capital has invested S$50 million in Singapore-based fintech Validus to boost SME lending for underserved and unbanked businesses. The investment includes S$20 million in SME financing on Validus' marketplace and S$30 million in new funds for the Enterprise Financing Scheme, providing cashflow support and growth capital to affected SMEs.

site_title: Airlines, British holidaymakers brace for limited travel restart
summary: The UK is set to announce its plan to relaunch travel on Friday, but only a limited number of countries will be declared safe for quarantine-free travel. Mainland Spain and Greece, as well as France, are at risk of being excluded from the initial "green list". This decision is expected to be a major blow to tourist hotspots and the airline and holiday companies that rely on British tourists. The announcement comes after a year of travel restrictions, and the industry is eager for the restart of travel to boost spending.

site_title: Australia to reopen door to India, still probing Sydney
summary: Australia will reopen its border to Indian citizens starting May 15, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison standing by the biosecurity order banning flights to and from India. The decision comes as New South Wales state Premier Gladys Berejiklian criticizes the suspension of the travel bubble with New Zealand due to new infections in Sydney. Health officials are investigating a potential Indian variant of Covid-19, but a clear transmission path remains unclear. The move aims to allow stranded Australians to return home while keeping the border secure.

site_title: Corporate activism: Barbarians at the gate no more
summary: Investor activism has evolved from a focus on corporate takeovers to a more compassionate approach, demanding greater transparency, sustainability, and diversity. This shift is driven by societal pressure, including the Black Lives Matter movement and the COVID-19 pandemic, which has sparked conversations on corporate accountability and stakeholder primacy. As a result, boards are recognizing the value of engaging with activists and preparing for activism, rather than dismissing them as troublemakers. Proactive engagement and diversity initiatives are becoming increasingly common, with some boards even stepping up to lead the charge for change.

site_title: Singapore stocks open slightly higher on Friday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,176.59, with 59 to 49 advancers and decliners. The market tracked Wall Street's gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average reaching a new high. European shares fell 0.1%, while Tokyo stocks opened lower due to pandemic concerns.

site_title: Facebook panel punt on Trump puts onus back on Zuckerberg
summary: Facebook's top executives set up an independent oversight board to address explosive content, but the panel's first ruling on Donald Trump's ban sent the issue back to Mark Zuckerberg. The oversight board upheld the ban but sidestepped a decision on Trump's long-term access, giving Zuckerberg six months to justify the ban's permanence. Critics argue that self-regulation is ineffective and that the oversight board's decision shifts the responsibility back to Facebook.

site_title: Maxwell House collective sale tender awarded for S$276.8m
summary: SingHaiyi, Chip Eng Seng, and Chuan Holdings jointly won the collective sale tender for Maxwell House in Singapore with a price of S$276.8 million, 3.3% higher than the reserve price. The joint tenderers plan to redevelop the property into a mixed-use development with a gross plot ratio of at least 5.6 and a gross floor area of at least 21,746 square meters. The deal is considered an interested person transaction due to the controlling shareholders of both SingHaiyi and Chip Eng Seng. Approval from the Urban Redevelopment Authority and Singapore Land Authority is required for the completion of the acquisition.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose at Friday's open, following a healthy lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.29% to 28,721.13, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.15% to 3,446.41. The rally came ahead of US jobs data release later in the day, with traders brushing off new Trump threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Biden says US must invest because China 'eating our lunch'
summary: US President Joe Biden warned that Congress must adopt his $2.3 trillion infrastructure proposal to secure the US economy, as China is "eating our lunch" in terms of investment. Biden pitched the plan as a way to fix bridges and roads, fund broadband internet, and promote electric car research. Republicans oppose the plan, citing uncontrolled spending and proposed tax increases. Biden plans to negotiate with senior Republicans at the White House next week to secure the proposal.

site_title: Rental cars becoming scarce and expensive for US travellers
summary: US travelers are facing a shortage and high cost of rental cars due to the pandemic's impact on the industry. Car rental companies, such as Hertz and Avis, have reduced their fleets and struggle to meet increased demand. The global semiconductor shortage has further exacerbated the issue, forcing companies to hold onto their cars longer. This has led to higher prices for consumers, with some paying up to $600 for a two-day rental. Alternative platforms like Turo are benefiting from the shortage, offering travelers more options and value.

site_title: WHO warns of new Covid wave in Africa
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has warned of a new wave of COVID-19 infections in Africa due to delayed vaccine supplies, slow rollout, and new variants. The continent is lagging behind the rest of the world in vaccine administration, with only half of the 37 million doses received administered so far. Africa now accounts for just 1% of global vaccine doses, with sub-Saharan Africa receiving an average of just 8 doses per 1,000 people. The WHO urges African countries to catch up and deploy vaccines to prevent a "third wave" of infections.

site_title: Lendlease Global Reit's Q3 portfolio occupancy holds steady at 99.7%
summary: Lendlease Global Reit reported a 99.7% occupancy rate as of March 31, unchanged from the previous quarter, with a weighted average lease expiry (WALE) of 9 years by net lettable area and 4.6 years by gross rental income. Tenant sales at 313@somerset recovered faster than footfall, with a 62% retention rate. The manager expects the mixed-use asset to draw constant footfall and boost tenant sales. Despite improving demand indicators, leasing demand is expected to remain weak in the short term due to e-commerce growth and demand for experiential offerings.

site_title: Earnings wrap: Singapore banks make handsome beat on estimates in Q1
summary: Singapore banks reported a strong Q1 earnings performance, beating estimates with rising profits driven by fee income and reduced impairments. Weaker net interest income was offset by higher trading income and writebacks on bad-debt provisions. The banks' performance follows a trend of global banks exceeding expectations.

site_title: US: Healthy employment numbers make Wall Street happy
summary: US stocks rose on Thursday, driven by the Labor Department's report of fewer new claims for unemployment benefits, indicating the economy's rebound from the pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average reached a new high, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also gained ground. Investors were reassured by the data, which eclipsed concerns about inflation and potential interest rate hikes, allowing stocks to push past recent declines.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as oil, tech losses offset earnings boost
summary: European stocks closed 0.1% lower on Thursday, despite strong earnings from food and beverage companies. The travel sector declined 1.7% after UK rail operator Trainline reported an annual loss. Oil stocks fell, while technology shares dropped in tandem with US peers. The Bank of England slowed its trillion-dollar bond-purchasing program, but still expects policy tightening to come after the recovery has made significant progress.

site_title: Qatar arrests finance minister over alleged corruption
summary: Qatar's finance minister, Ali Shareef al-Emadi, has been arrested over alleged corruption and abuse of power. Emir Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad Al-Thani issued a decree relieving Emadi of his post, and the attorney general ordered his arrest on charges of damaging public money, abuse of function, and abuse of power. Emadi, who served as finance minister since 2013, is also the president of Qatar Airways and chairman of Qatar National Bank. The arrest marks the highest-profile corruption case under Sheikh Tamim and is seen as a move to demonstrate Qatar's commitment to the rule of law.

site_title: UK votes as independence debate heats up in Scotland
summary: British voters cast ballots in "Super Thursday" elections, with Scotland's pro-independence forces seeking a majority in the Edinburgh parliament. The UK's pro-independence party, the Scottish National Party (SNP), is expected to gain a slim majority, potentially putting pressure on Prime Minister Boris Johnson to permit another referendum on Scotland's independence. The elections also test the Conservative party's support after Brexit and the pandemic, with the outcome in England closely watched for its implications on the UK's future.

site_title: ESR-Reit prices private placement at 37.2 S cents, 3.4 times subscribed
summary: ESR-Reit's private placement to raise S$100 million was 3.4 times subscribed, exceeding the upsized option. The issue price was fixed at 37.2 Singapore cents per new unit, a discount of about 8.9% from the volume-weighted average price.

site_title: Florida governor tightens voter law in appeal to Trump base
summary: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis signed an election security bill, SB90, that restricts voting by mail, requires valid voter identification, and prohibits private funds in campaigns. The law aims to please Trump supporters but critics warn it poses barriers to voting. Florida joins a growing list of Republican-run states that have tweaked voter laws following Trump's baseless election fraud charges. The signing took place near Trump's Mar-a-Lago club, further fueling concerns about partisan politics.

site_title: Oil prices fall 1% on worries of pandemic surge in India
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Thursday due to rising Covid-19 infections in India and elsewhere, despite US crude inventories falling more sharply than expected. Brent crude oil settled at $68.09 a barrel and West Texas Intermediate (WTI) US crude futures dropped to $64.71. Analysts cited the potential impact of the pandemic surge on demand, while easing restrictions in Europe and falling US crude stocks provided some support.

site_title: Hong Kongers been busy buying properties in weak London market since visa announcement
summary: Hong Kongers have increased their property purchases in London by 144% since the UK's BNO visa announcement in July 2020, more than doubling transactions. This surge in activity, driven by the visa offering, has accounted for an estimated 4% of the market since July 2020, up from 1%. The increased demand is seen in both high-end and average market price thresholds, with buyers focusing on more affordable options. This trend has been a bright spot in a weak London market, particularly at the top end, during the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: US lumber futures extend steep rally to record heights
summary: US lumber futures surged to record heights, exceeding $1,500, as demand for home construction materials outpaced supply. The price of an average new single-family home has increased by $35,872 over the past 12 months. Sawmills struggle to keep up with demand, while labor shortages exacerbate the situation. The rally is expected to continue, potentially pushing first-time home buyers out of the market, and hitting pocketbooks.

images.alt_text: Prices have quadrupled in the past year, vaulting higher on an unexpected surge in home building and renovations.

site_title: VW raises full-year outlook, warns on growing chip shortage
summary: Volkswagen raised its full-year earnings outlook to 5.5-7% due to strong demand rebounding across the auto industry. The company, Europe's largest automaker, also warned about the growing semiconductor shortage, which will affect production lines in the second quarter. Despite this, Volkswagen's shares rose as much as 2.4% following the announcement, driven by its electric-vehicle push and positive first-quarter results.

site_title: OCBC geared for 'very strong' Greater Bay Area competition; Q1 profit more than doubles to record
summary: OCBC Bank posted a record net profit of S$1.5 billion in the first quarter, more than doubling its year-ago profit. The bank's CEO, Helen Wong, expects "very strong competition" in the Greater Bay Area, but believes the market is large enough for all banks to operate reasonably. OCBC is open to M&A opportunities, including Citi's consumer banking assets, and plans to expand its wealth management franchise and investments in sustainability and digitalization. The bank's loans grew 1% to S$271 billion, driven by customers in China and the UK, with a stable non-performing loans ratio of 1.5%.

site_title: Financial system needs paradigm shift: Nazir Razak
summary: Veteran Malaysian banker Nazir Razak calls for a paradigm shift in the financial system, prioritizing purpose over profit and making capitalism more sustainable. He blames the excesses of global finance for exacerbating climate and inequality crises. Razak, former chairman of CIMB Group Holdings, proposes measures to incorporate climate change and sustainability into the corporate agenda, including environmental regulations, impact testing, and progressive taxation. He emphasizes the need for senior bankers to contribute to overhauling the international financial system and for governments to impose rules to ensure compliance.

site_title: Nintendo warns chip crunch may hit Switch despite gaming boom
summary: Nintendo reported better-than-expected earnings for the March quarter, driven by hit games like Monster Hunter Rise. The company warned that global chip shortages may disrupt Switch production, despite targeting 25.5 million console sales for the current year. Nintendo aims to surpass its goal of selling 190 million Switch software units this year, with a focus on driving software sales and live services to support earnings growth.

site_title: Amazon fuels North America's most severe warehouse shortage
summary: Amazon's rapid expansion of its logistics footprint in Canada has fueled the country's most severe warehouse shortage, with vacancy rates in the Toronto area reaching a record low of 0.5%. The shortage is disrupting businesses and threatening the broader economy, with some companies forced to pack orders in parking lots or use farmers' fields. The shortage is also expected to drive up costs, which could be passed on to consumers, and is being exacerbated by a surge in demand driven by the pandemic.

site_title: NYC may freeze rent again for 2 million tenants
summary: The Rent Guidelines Board in NYC may freeze rents for 1.2 million regulated units, covering 2 million tenants, for another year. The board voted 5-4 to consider keeping one-year lease rents the same or allowing a 2% increase. Rents on two-year leases could rise by 1-3%. The decision would benefit tenants but harm landlords, amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Moderna vaccine 96% effective in 12-17 year-olds, study shows
summary: Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine has shown a 96% effectiveness rate among 12- to 17-year-olds in its first clinical trials, with no serious safety concerns identified. The vaccine was tested on 3,235 participants in the US, with two-thirds receiving the vaccine and one-third a placebo. The results were announced by Moderna, with the company stating that the vaccine is generally well-tolerated. This positive result could pave the way for the vaccine to be approved for this age group, providing protection against COVID-19.

site_title: Who gets Xanadu 2.0, the Gates family mansion?
summary: Bill and Melinda Gates' divorce may impact their lakefront estate in Seattle, valued at over $131 million. The couple's 66,000-square-foot home, nicknamed Xanadu 2.0, will likely be split between the two, but the exact division is unclear. The property's details have been kept private, but it features a spa, pool, gym, and stream for fish. The Gates Foundation, which the couple co-chairs, will remain unchanged, but the couple's personal lives and philanthropic efforts may be affected by the divorce.

site_title: More Singapore companies push into the NFT space
summary: Singapore companies are expanding into the NFT space, with fashion tech company republiqe and designer toy company Mighty Jaxx already auctioning off digital items on platforms like Rarible and OpenSea. Republiqe, which has sold over 500 garments, is now using NFTs to offer unique designs with full ownership rights. Other companies, such as Culture Group, are exploring the potential of NFTs in the music industry, where they could solve issues like digital piracy and ticket scalping. The market for NFTs has grown significantly, with over $2 billion spent in the first quarter of 2021, and major players like Binance launching their own NFT marketplaces.

site_title: Forbes Media in talks to be acquired by GSV-led group
summary: Forbes Media is in exclusive talks to be acquired by a group led by Michael Moe's GSV Asset Management, valuing the business-news publisher at over $600 million. The deal, if finalized, would be a significant turnaround for the company, which has produced three years of record results. Forbes was previously acquired by Hong Kong-based Integrated Whale Media Investments in 2014 for $475 million. The talks are private, but investors have consistently shown interest in the company, and a transaction could be agreed upon in coming months.

site_title: US jobless claims fall more than expected amid recovery
summary: US jobless claims fell more than expected, with initial weekly claims totaling 498,000 for the week ended May 1, the lowest level since mid-March 2020. This decline is attributed to the labour market recovery gaining steam amid an economic boom fueled by improving public health and government financial assistance. The data suggests the US economy is on the path to a strong recovery, with the US Labor Department reporting a significant drop in unemployment claims.

site_title: SPH deal aims to improve asset values, ease shareholder pressure off media unit
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) proposes restructuring its media business, transferring it to a not-for-profit entity, a company limited by guarantee (CLG), to preserve and grow its media operations. This move aims to free the media business from shareholder expectations for dividends and allow it to reinvest profits into its operations. The remaining non-media assets will be better valued once the media business is removed from the market. The deal is expected to improve SPH's bottom line and provide greater financial flexibility for strategic growth opportunities.

site_title: China condemns G-7 statement that censures Beijing, supports Taiwan
summary: China has condemned a G-7 statement criticizing Beijing's human rights record and labeling it a "bully". The statement expressed support for Taiwan, which China claims as its own. China views this as a gross interference in its internal affairs. The G-7 also vowed to use collective efforts to stop China's "coercive economic policies". China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: McLaren's new S$5.5m car has no roof or windscreen
summary: McLaren unveiled the Elva, a limited edition roadster priced at S$5.5 million, at an event in Singapore. The ultra-exclusive supercar features no roof or windscreen and is part of the Ultimate Series range. Only 149 units will be produced, available on a first-come-first-served basis.

site_title: Four ways today's teams are making us lonely
summary: A recent study by an executive education and consulting firm found that 76% of global executives and managers reported struggling to make connections with their teammates, despite being part of multiple teams. This highlights a growing concern of loneliness in the workplace, which can lead to health problems, reduced work performance, and poor decision-making. The study suggests that firms should view loneliness as an organizational issue, rather than a personal one, and make changes to team design to address the problem, rather than waiting for in-office work to resume.

site_title: Outlook positive for business parks but location matters
summary: Business parks are expected to have a positive outlook, but location plays a crucial role in their success. In real estate news, condo launches in Singapore's prime projects above S$3,000 psf may test demand, while US mortgage rates have risen after five weeks of declines. Manhattan rents have hit another record, and UK homebuyer demand has rebounded to a six-month high. Additionally, Goldman Sachs acquired a large hotel and retail asset portfolio in Seoul for 262 billion won.

site_title: Greenback falls; pound steadies before BOE meeting
summary: The US dollar fell 0.3% to 91.03 against a basket of currencies, reversing a two-week high, due to improved global market risk appetite. The pound remained steady against the dollar, while the euro rose 0.4% versus the dollar. The Bank of England's meeting, expected to signal a stronger economic recovery, and elections in Scotland also influenced market sentiment.

site_title: SPH will need to clarify future plans to secure shareholder approval
summary: SPH is restructuring its media business by hiving it off into a company limited by guarantee. This move aims to provide a long-term sustainable financial solution, balancing the interests of the public and shareholders. The media business has been on a decline for five years, with revenue halving during this period. The restructuring proposal must be approved by shareholders, and SPH will need to clarify its future plans to secure this approval.

site_title: Spain pours billions into fight for slice of European EV sector
summary: Spain is investing billions of euros from EU pandemic relief funds to build new battery and electric vehicle plants, aiming to remain the EU's second-largest car producer by 2030. The country plans to spend 13 billion euros on sustainable mobility, including promoting domestic EV sales, improving charging infrastructure, and building its first battery cell plant. Several companies, including Volkswagen and Renault, are investing in EVs in Spain, while the country competes with other European nations to attract carmakers and battery plant projects.

site_title: China suspends economic dialogue with Australia as relations curdle
summary: China has indefinitely suspended all economic dialogue with Australia due to a series of Australian measures perceived as disrupting exchanges and cooperation. China's National Development and Reform Commission cited a "Cold War mindset and ideological discrimination" as the reason. This move follows strained relations between the two countries, with China accusing Australia of launching a series of disruptive measures. The suspension marks a significant setback for bilateral economic ties.

site_title: Judge puts hold on ruling that voids US moratorium on evicting renters
summary: A US federal judge, Judge Dabney Friedrich, has ruled that the CDC's nationwide moratorium on evictions is void, citing that Congress did not intend to empower the CDC to include residential evictions in its measures to combat Covid-19. The ruling was a setback for millions of Americans struggling to pay rent, but the judge agreed to put a temporary hold on her decision as the government seeks to reverse the decision on appeal.

site_title: Be it a US$10 wine, or much more, the judgments come free
summary: A correlation between price and quality in wine exists, but the relationship varies depending on the price range. In lower-end wines, cost is often a result of production economics, such as vineyard site and labor costs. Higher-end wines, however, are often driven by factors like status, fame, and supply and demand. Simple, straightforward wines can be found at lower price points, but may lack inspiration and emotion. Spending more often buys a better wine, but it's not a guarantee, and informed choices are necessary to find high-quality wines.

site_title: New Korean cars breach S$200,000 mark here
summary: Two new Korean cars, the Kia Carnival and Hyundai Palisade, have entered the Singapore market with prices over S$200,000. The Kia Carnival offers an eight-seat version priced at S$205,999 and a seven-seat variant at S$211,999, while the Hyundai Palisade is priced at S$216,999. Both vehicles feature advanced driver aids, digital displays, and connectivity features, and offer more than just space, appealing to buyers who demand these features. Despite being priced above budget-friendly levels, the cars' large sales volume remains uncertain.

site_title: What's Up This Week
summary: Eyedeer, a green online retail store, has launched a Mother's Day gift option with handmade EM soaps and sustainable living recipes. The soaps, made in Singapore, contain Effective Microorganisms and are environmentally friendly. Meanwhile, Billecart-Salmon has introduced a champagne pairing experience for Mother's Day, featuring its limited-edition cuvée Elisabeth Salmon Rose 2008. The experience, priced from S$436++, is available at La Dame De Pic, Raffles Singapore, until June 20.

site_title: Bank of England slows bond buying, sees economy bouncing back more quickly
summary: The Bank of England slowed its trillion-dollar stimulus programme by reducing weekly bond purchases to £3.4 billion from £4.4 billion, while forecasting a faster economic recovery in 2021 with growth reaching 7.25% and unemployment peaking at 5.5% in the third quarter. The central bank also lowered its 2022 growth forecast to 5.75% and expects the economy to return to its pre-pandemic size by the end of 2021. Despite this, Governor Andrew Bailey emphasized that monetary policy is not being tightened and inflation is expected to be fractionally below the 2% target in two years.

site_title: Restoring trust in financial services
summary: Financial institutions must work to regain customer trust after recent events like the Archegos Capital collapse. UBS Asia-Pacific President Edmund Koh stated that there's no "future-proofing" the financial sector, but institutions can learn from past mistakes by re-examining processes. Experts agree that transparency, reliability, and a better understanding of customer needs are key to earning trust. The financial sector's shift towards technology, such as data science and algorithms, can also increase trust factors.

site_title: SEC chief hints at new rules that could threaten Robinhood, Citadel
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chairman Gary Gensler hinted at new regulations that could impact online brokerages like Robinhood and Citadel Securities. The proposed rules aim to address the complexities of online trading, social media, and real-time trading that were exposed during the GameStop Corp trading frenzy. Gensler emphasized the need for a clean-up of the market, focusing on online brokerages and market makers that dominate retail investors' equity orders.

site_title: Global rates volatility forces investor rethink on Asian bonds
summary: Foreign investors are reassessing their Asian bond holdings amid global rate volatility, shifting funds to safer markets like China. A surge in US yields has made lower-yielding Asian bond markets less attractive, with countries like Thailand, Singapore, and Malaysia becoming less appealing. China remains a popular destination due to its high real yields and close ties to a global trade rebound. Investors are trimming positions in Indonesian and Indian bonds, citing concerns over economic recovery, fiscal deficits, and currency weakness.

site_title: Daily Digest
summary: Judicial managers of Hiap Seng Engineering received three expressions of interest for a majority stake in the company. Olam International will be a technical partner in the privatization of Saudi flour mill Second Milling Co. Far East Orchard posted a net loss of S$700,000 in the first quarter due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Medtecs International Corp's net profit rose to US$13.2 million in the first quarter. Chaswood Resources Holdings will operate its restaurant only through take-away and delivery services due to Malaysia's movement control order.

site_title: China sets investment quota for scheme to integrate Hong Kong, Macau
summary: China has set an initial quota of 150 billion yuan (S$30.95 billion) for transactions under the Wealth Management Connect scheme, which links Guangdong province with Hong Kong and Macau. The scheme, part of President Xi Jinping's plan for a Greater Bay Area, allows residents to buy financial products in the other markets, with individual investment quotas of one million yuan. The move aims to open up China's capital account and financial markets, following similar cross-border initiatives in the past.

site_title: Credit Suisse boosts Asia hiring to tap fast-growing markets
summary: Credit Suisse has boosted its Asia-Pacific headcount by over 100 staff, seeking to increase its revenue share from the region's fast-growing markets. The bank has made significant hires, including Dragi Ristevski and Rachel Li, to focus on new economy and financial sponsors in Asia. Credit Suisse aims to triple its headcount in mainland China and raise its Asian revenue share to 25% from 20%. The bank has also reported a net hiring of 30 relationship managers in the first quarter for Asia.

site_title: Airbus sees China muscling in on rivalry with Boeing by 2030
summary: Airbus predicts China, through its state-owned company Comac, will become a legitimate rival in global planemaking by 2030, challenging the long-standing duopoly between Airbus and Boeing. China is close to delivering its first C919 single-aisle jet by the end of the year, marking a significant milestone in its attempt to build a narrowbody model. Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury notes that while it's hard to predict how quickly China will establish itself, Comac is likely to take a share of the market over time.

site_title: 21 million-dollar HDB resale flats sold in April
summary: In April, 21 million-dollar HDB resale flats were sold, marking the 10th consecutive month of price increases, with resale prices rising 1.2% compared to March. The total number of million-dollar flats sold in the first four months of 2021 reached 74 units, up from 14 units in the same period last year. Experts attribute the demand to the return to phase 2 Covid-19 curbs, as well as rising private property prices, with analysts predicting continued growth in HDB resale prices, expected to rise 7-10% this year.

site_title: When less is more
summary: Architect Woon Chung Yen designed a 3,401 sq ft semi-detached home in Upper Serangoon for a family of five who requested a "home that is adequate" rather than a maximized space. The three-storey dwelling prioritizes privacy, adequacy, and permanence, with small windows on the street side and a set-back design to maintain sunlight and privacy. The minimalist design features a series of connected spaces, including a tiered platform for extra seating, and a garden accessible through sliding glass doors. The family appreciates the home's simplicity and functionality, which aligns with their long-term living needs.

site_title: Social acceptance vital to success of novel food technologies
summary: Social acceptance is crucial for the success of novel food technologies, as concerns or risk perceptions can significantly slow their adoption. The emotional connection people have with food makes food innovation prone to social acceptance issues, and addressing these concerns requires a proactive approach. Companies and institutions investing in foodtech and agtech must develop strategies to address social acceptance, using the science of risk perception and behavioural science to guide communication and engagement efforts. Effective risk management begins early in the innovation pathway, and neglecting this aspect can result in wasted investments and lost confidence in the technology and sector.

site_title: UK construction sees biggest rise in workload since 2016
summary: The UK construction sector has seen its largest increase in workload since 2016, driven by strong demand for housing and resumption of projects as the pandemic eases. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) reported a balance of 26, its highest since early 2016, with private residential construction and infrastructure seeing significant rises. Productivity in the sector is down 5% due to social distancing, but a shortage of building materials is now the biggest constraint. Profit margins are expected to increase for the first time since 2019, and recruitment and volumes of work are forecast to rise.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat after jobless claims data; drugmakers extend fall
summary: US stocks opened flat on Thursday, despite a decline in weekly jobless claims and a rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, while the Nasdaq Composite dropped. Vaccine makers faced pressure over President Biden's plan to waive intellectual property rights for Covid-19 shots. The Dow Jones rose 0.04%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 0.04% and 0.18% respectively.

site_title: Two Singapore-based startups led by tech alumni raise US$76m
summary: Two Singapore-based startups, founded by former executives from Fave, Carousell, and foodpanda, have raised a combined US$76 million in seed funding and debt to acquire e-commerce brands. Una Brands secured US$40 million, majority debt financing from Kingsway Capital, while the other startup's funding details are not specified. This investment is part of a growing trend of tech alumni-backed startups in Singapore, highlighting the country's growing ecosystem for deep-tech innovation.

images.alt_text: JJ Chai, (above, left) leads Rainforest which buys and grows Asia-based brands that sell on Amazon. Una Brands will focus on acquiring companies with strong independent branding; its Singapore-based co-founders are (above right, from left) Tobias Heusch, Kiren Tanna and Kushal Patel.

site_title: The green art of the possible
summary: US President Joe Biden recently gathered 40 world leaders for a climate change summit, marking progress in forging a global strategy. However, tackling global warming is a long-term challenge, and the US needs to make difficult choices. Biden's climate plan avoids contentious measures like a carbon tax or cap-and-trade scheme, which are unpopular in the US, to maintain political support. Despite the progress, Biden faces the challenge of implementing meaningful climate measures in Congress, where bipartisan opposition is likely to hinder his efforts.

site_title: Mitsui weighs buyout of RM49 billion IHH Healthcare
summary: Mitsui & Co is exploring a potential deal to take Malaysian hospital group IHH Healthcare Bhd private, worth RM49 billion (S$15.9 billion). The Japanese trading house has reached out to Khazanah Nasional Bhd, IHH's second-largest shareholder, to pick up its stake. Discussions are in the early stages, and there is no certainty that Mitsui would proceed with an offer. Mitsui has a 32.9% stake in IHH, and the company employs over 65,000 people across 80 hospitals in 10 countries.

site_title: Staff-served buffet lines not faring well: caterers
summary: Singapore's staff-served buffet lines, suspended during the pandemic, have resumed under Phase 2, but caterers report lackluster demand, with only 10% of orders coming from buffets. Many caterers have shifted focus to bentos, tingkat meals, and bulk sales. With reduced corporate events and increased costs due to safe-distancing measures, businesses are struggling to stay afloat. Caterers are raising wages to keep staff, and some are hiring additional personnel to service buffet lines. The industry's reliance on corporate events has taken a hit, and food delivery services are becoming more convenient.

site_title: Intergenerational wisdom for a post-Covid world
summary: Leadership must adapt to a post-Covid world by embracing alternative perspectives and intergenerational wisdom. The pandemic has shown that innovations previously deemed unmainstream can quickly become mainstream, and that younger generations can bring fresh perspectives to the table. Ageism should be avoided, and a more inclusive learning dynamic should be developed. Leaders should remain receptive to new ideas, challenge assumptions, and be agile in embracing change. By doing so, they can thrive in the new normal and benefit from the collective wisdom of different generations.

site_title: Skoda Kamiq review: Go the full Monte
summary: The Skoda Kamiq is a compact Sport Utility Vehicle that stands out as one of the best in its class. With a 1.5-litre turbo engine and a twin-clutch, seven-speed gearbox, it provides a sweet combination of performance and handling. The Kamiq has a spacious cabin, decent boot space, and a range of safety features. It's also well-equipped, especially in the Monte Carlo edition, which offers a tastefully racy interior. With a starting price of S$143,900, the Kamiq is a fun and agile SUV that's worth considering for those seeking a thrilling driving experience.

site_title: Getting risk culture right in the age of hybrid working
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has permanently transformed the world of work, shifting towards a hybrid model that balances employee flexibility, autonomy, and performance. To manage emerging risks, companies must balance productivity and agility with cybersecurity and operational risks. Key measures include incorporating digital authentication tools, reassessing risk profiles, and training employees on security awareness. Building a strong risk culture is crucial, and companies should engage with technology leaders and review employee engagement and wellness programs to support holistic well-being in the age of hybrid work.

site_title: Russia says one-shot Sputnik Light vaccine has 79% efficacy
summary: Russia has approved a single-dose version of the Sputnik V Covid-19 vaccine, called Sputnik Light, with a 79.4% efficacy rate based on real-world data. The vaccine, which is the same as the first dose of Sputnik V, is intended for countries experiencing a significant Covid surge and may also work as a booster shot. The two-dose Sputnik V vaccine remains the main vaccine in Russia, and Sputnik Light is expected to be registered in several countries by the end of the month.

site_title: Ferrari's new 812 Competizione is faster than Superfast
summary: Ferrari has unveiled its new 812 Competizione, a lighter and more powerful version of the 812 Superfast, with 830 horsepower from a 6.5-litre V12 engine. The car can accelerate to 200km/h in 7.5 seconds and features advanced technologies, including automatic rear wheel steering and a camera system for the driver. Only 999 examples of the coupe version will be produced, while 599 of the open-top version, the 812 Competizione A, will be made. Both variants have sold out, with Ferrari claiming they will make a "very fast profit" from their high-end cars.

site_title: Cartier's gender neutral approach to watchmaking
summary: Cartier's director of style and patrimony, Pierre Rainero, discusses the brand's approach to watchmaking, which he believes is inherently gender neutral. The luxury brand's original design ethos focuses on unique shapes that appeal to both men and women. The Santos de Cartier, created in 1904 for Brazilian aviation pioneer Alberto Santos-Dumont, was initially offered to both sexes upon commercialization in 1911. Rainero attributes men's hesitation to fully embracing Cartier's elegance to their inhibitions. The brand's focus on timeless design transcends traditional notions of masculinity and femininity.

site_title: KPMG switches to flexible working plan for UK staff
summary: KPMG UK announces flexible working plans allowing staff to work in offices up to four times a fortnight starting next month. The 16,000-strong workforce can split their time between offices, home, and client sites. Employees will also receive an extra 2.5 hours off per week during summer months. The move follows similar hybrid working patterns adopted by other corporate giants. KPMG CEO Jon Holt believes the new approach will empower staff and improve work-life balance, with offices becoming a place for collaboration and learning.

site_title: ECB to inspect loans to shadow banks after Greensill, Archegos fiascos
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) will inspect bank loans to lightly regulated investment funds and specialised lenders, following the collapse of supply-chain lender Greensill and family office Archegos Capital Management. Regulators have long expressed concerns about shadow banking, which has come under scrutiny after the demise of these entities. The move aims to increase scrutiny and prevent similar failures, as the ECB supervisor, Andrea Enria, warned of the risks associated with lightly regulated entities. The inspection is expected to focus on the lending practices of these entities and their relationships with mainstream banks.

site_title: Singapore shares snap losing streak to rise on Thursday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore shares snapped a four-day losing streak, rising 0.6% on Thursday to close at 3,173.00. The STI gain was attributed to stabilizing community Covid-19 situation and dip-buyers. Leading gainers included Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, Singtel, and OCBC, while Keppel DC Reit was the biggest loser. The broader market saw 283 gainers for every 172 losers, with 1.79 billion shares changing hands.

site_title: Dukang Distillers faces suspension after plan for transfer to Catalist fails
summary: Dukang Distillers Holdings faces a trading suspension or delisting from the Singapore Exchange mainboard due to failing to secure shareholders' approval for transferring its listing status to the Catalist junior board. The company must record a full-year consolidated pre-tax profit and a six-month average daily market value of at least S$40 million within 36 months. Despite this setback, shareholders have approved the sale of Dukang's white liquor business and the company will change its name to China Shenshan Orchard Holdings.

site_title: Medtecs Q1 net profit jumps to US$13.2 million as PPE demand 'remains elevated'
summary: Medtecs International Corp, a protective gear maker listed on the Catalist, reported a significant jump in first-quarter net profit to US$13.2 million, more than tripling from US$3.67 million in the same period last year. Revenue rose 5.9% to US$42.2 million, driven by elevated demand for personal protective equipment (PPE) amid the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic. The company expects continued growth in the April-June period and is building its retail arm through Amazon, as well as constructing a PPE manufacturing facility to strengthen its position as a stockpile provider.

site_title: Bombardier says US joins investigation into Indonesian jet deals
summary: The US Department of Justice has joined an investigation into Bombardier's sales of jets to Garuda Indonesia between 2011 and 2012. The investigation is related to suspected bribery, following a probe by Britain's Serious Fraud Office. Garuda Indonesia's former CEO, Emirsyah Satar, was sentenced to eight years in prison for bribery and money-laundering in a related case. Bombardier is cooperating fully with authorities and has undergone changes in leadership since the deals under investigation. This case is part of a broader trend of aerospace groups facing scrutiny over the use of middlemen in past jet deals.

site_title: 95 serious 'adverse events' out of 2.2m Covid-19 vaccine doses in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Health Sciences Authority (HSA) has reported 95 serious adverse events, including anaphylaxis and other severe allergic reactions, out of 2.2 million Covid-19 vaccine doses administered. These events occurred at a rate of 0.004% of administered doses, similar to overseas rates. No deaths were associated with the vaccine, and the benefits of the Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines continue to outweigh the known risks. The HSA will continue to monitor vaccine safety and has reported no unusual cases of blood clots or heart attacks/strokes.

site_title: France, Britain send patrol boats to Jersey in post-Brexit fishing row
summary: France and Britain deployed maritime patrol vessels to the Channel island of Jersey amid a dispute over post-Brexit fishing rights. France, citing unfair deprivation of access to rich fishing grounds, sent a flotilla of trawlers to Jersey's main harbour, while Britain maintained two Royal Navy vessels to prevent clashes. The European Union calls for calm, while Jersey claims it is following the rules set out in Britain's trade deal with the EU. Talks between island officials and fishermen have been unsuccessful, with France warning of retaliatory measures if the issue is not resolved.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell more than expected, totaling 498,000 for the week ended May 1, the lowest level since mid-March 2020. This follows a rapidly improving public health situation and massive government financial assistance. Economists forecast 540,000 applications, but job cuts announced by US-based employers fell 25% in April, with planned layoffs down 84% from the same period in 2020. The labor market recovery gains steam, with consumers' perceptions of the labor market at their strongest in 13 months.

site_title: World must go beyond 'hot air' at COP26 climate summit: UK's Johnson
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged world leaders at the Petersberg Climate Dialogue summit to deliver concrete actions at COP26 in Glasgow, Scotland, to combat climate change. He warned that mere "hot air" would be insufficient, emphasizing the need for agreements, actions, and deeds. Johnson vowed to push G-7 leaders to make climate commitments, secure funding for climate finance, and support the transition to net zero carbon emissions. The summit will take place in November, with Britain pushing for an in-person meeting to accelerate measures by the world's biggest polluters.

site_title: Drugmakers say Biden misguided over vaccine patent waiver
summary: US President Joe Biden's support for waiving intellectual property rights for Covid-19 vaccines has been met with opposition from pharmaceutical companies, citing potential disruptions to supply chains and the need for rich countries to share more vaccine donations with developing nations. Companies such as CureVac and Moderna argue that waiving patents won't increase vaccine supply and that trade barriers, like the US Defense Production Act, are the real bottlenecks. The Gavi vaccine alliance, however, welcomed the move, emphasizing the need for increased vaccine sharing.

images.alt_text: Drugmakers on Thursday said US President Joe Biden's support for waiving patents of Covid-19 vaccines could disrupt a fragile supply chain and that rich countries should instead share more generously with the developing world.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio launches its first overseas store in Norway
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio has launched its first overseas store in Norway, marking a significant expansion into the global market. The company, employing over 9,000 staff, plans to start selling cars in Norway. Nio, backed by Tencent, has delivered over 100,000 cars since its founding in 2014, primarily in China. This move aims to capitalize on Norway's growing EV market and Nio's growing global presence.

site_title: 95 cases of serious suspected side effects out of 2.2 million Covid-19 vaccine doses in Singapore
summary: Singapore's Health Sciences Authority reported 95 serious suspected side effects out of 2.2 million Covid-19 vaccine doses administered, including 20 cases of anaphylaxis. The majority of adverse events were mild, with individuals under 60 years old accounting for 70% of cases. Serious events were similar to overseas rates, and no deaths were reported. The benefits of the vaccines are believed to outweigh the risks, with the HSA continuing to monitor safety profiles.

site_title: IBM unveils 2-nanometre chip technology for faster computing
summary: IBM has introduced the world's first 2-nanometre chipmaking technology, which could be 45% faster and 75% more power-efficient than mainstream 7-nanometre chips. The technology uses insulating material to stop electron leaks, allowing for smaller and faster transistors. This advancement is expected to take several years to come to market, but could significantly improve computing performance.

site_title: US remittance processor Remitly hires advisers for IPO: sources
summary: Remitly, a US remittance payments processor, has hired investment banks to prepare for an initial public offering (IPO) in New York, valued at around $5 billion. This is a significant jump from its $1.5 billion valuation in 2020. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, and Barclays are among the banks hired for the listing, expected to take place in the second half of the year. The company, founded in 2011, processes $548 billion in remittances annually, a significant portion of the global economy, and competes with money-transfer giants like Western Union and MoneyGram.

site_title: Jardine Matheson still unclear on full-year outlook amid Covid-19 business impact
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported its first-quarter interim business update, citing progress for "most businesses" despite challenges from the Covid-19 pandemic. Fully-owned Jardine Pacific and Jardine Motors saw earnings rise year on year, while Singapore-listed Jardine Cycle & Carriage reported a contraction. The company reiterated its prudent funding approach and affirmed its strong balance sheet and liquidity position. Its full-year outlook remains uncertain, with the pandemic expected to continue affecting certain businesses.

site_title: Bank of England slows bond-buying, sees economy bouncing back more quickly
summary: The Bank of England slowed its £1 trillion stimulus programme, citing a faster-than-expected economic recovery in Britain. Governor Andrew Bailey stated that the economy is set for a stronger recovery, with lower unemployment, but still faces a significant shortfall against its pre-pandemic path. This decision was made despite concerns about the UK economy shrinking for the second month in a row, a blow to Labour leader Keir Starmer.

site_title: Pfizer, BioNTech to provide Covid-19 vaccine to Olympic athletes
summary: Pfizer and BioNTech announced they will donate Covid-19 vaccine doses to Olympic athletes and their delegations participating in the Tokyo Olympics and Paralympic Games. The initial doses are expected to be delivered by the end of May, with the goal of ensuring second doses are administered ahead of the games. This move follows an agreement with the International Olympic Committee and aims to make the games safe and secure for all participants. The donated doses will be in addition to existing supply agreements with countries worldwide.

site_title: Cheung Woh director leads entity to mount offer at S$0.285 a share
summary: Cheung Woh Technologies' finance and administrative director Law Yu Chui and her family members are launching a voluntary conditional offer to acquire the company at S$0.285 per share in cash, with an option to receive new shares at the same consideration. The offeror, holding 78.7% of the total issued shares, has committed to accepting the offer. The deal represents a 92.9% premium over the 3-month VWAP and 109.7% premium over the 6-month VWAP. The offeror expects to save on compliance costs and gain greater control and management flexibility.

site_title: SPH restructuring: 6 other news outlets under media trusts and foundations
summary: SPH, Singapore's largest media company, plans to transfer its media business to a not-for-profit entity, a newly formed public company limited by guarantee. This move aims to improve asset values and relieve media unit of shareholder pressures. Similar models are used by international news outlets such as The Guardian, Ouest-France, and ProPublica, which are owned by non-profit organisations. The restructuring is expected to be completed by the end of the year.

site_title: SPH deal aims to improve asset values and relieve media unit of shareholder pressures
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) proposes a restructuring to transfer its media business to a not-for-profit entity, allowing future profits to be reinvested in the business rather than distributed to shareholders. The move aims to improve asset values and relieve shareholder pressures. Under the plan, SPH's media business will be transferred to a company limited by guarantee, free from shareholder expectations for a fair financial return and regular dividends. The remaining non-media assets are expected to be better valued by the market once the struggling media business is removed.

site_title: Far East Orchard posts Q1 loss of S$700,000 as pandemic hurts hotel revenues
summary: Far East Orchard, a MAINBOARD-LISTED property player, reported a net loss of S$700,000 in Q1 2021, reversing a year-ago profit of S$900,000. Revenue declined 29% to S$27.6 million, mainly due to lockdowns in Australia and low tourist arrivals in Singapore. Despite hotel openings, the company cited a challenging road to recovery due to limited international travel. However, its British PBSA business remained a bright spot, with occupancy exceeding 80% and sustained demand for the next academic year.

site_title: MCI expresses support for SPH's proposed restructuring
summary: The Ministry of Communications and Information (MCI) in Singapore has expressed support for Singapore Press Holdings' (SPH) proposed restructuring, which involves transferring its media business to a not-for-profit entity, SPH Media Holdings. The government is prepared to provide funding support to help SPH Media accelerate its digital transformation and build capabilities for the future. The MCI agrees that the listed company structure is not viable for the media business, and the government aims to help local news media and journalists adapt to the digital era while maintaining high professional standards.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks rise on energy boost, though Sino-West tensions weigh
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.77% on Thursday, driven by gains in energy firms, despite tensions between China and the West weighing on the market. The Hang Seng index closed at 28,637.46, while China's Shanghai Composite index fell 0.16%. The European Union's steps to guard against economic competition from China and China's suspension of a strategic dialogue with Australia were cited as contributing factors to the market's uncertainty.

site_title: Pair of adjoining conservation shophouses at Neil Road up for sale
summary: Two adjoining conservation shophouses at 73 and 75 Neil Road in Singapore's Chinatown area have been put up for sale via expression of interest with a collective guide price of S$30 million. The site, zoned for commercial use, offers a main road frontage and a courtyard, and is expected to become "more vibrant" with nearby developments. The property is currently fully leased and can be converted into a restaurant or fitness studio subject to approval. The expression of interest closes on June 10.

images.alt_text: Two adjoining three-storey conservation shophouses at 73 and 75 Neil Road have been put up for sale with a collective guide price of S$30 million.

site_title: Fintech-for-media startup Fewcents raises US$1.6m seed funding
summary: Fewcents, a Singapore-based fintech startup, has raised US$1.6 million in seed funding from M Venture Partners, Hustle Fund, and angel investors including former DBS chairman Koh Boon Hwee. Founded by Abhishek Dadoo and Dushyant Khare, Fewcents aims to enable easy monetization for digital publishers and creators globally through a pay-per-content service. The startup seeks to address the challenge of users being willing to pay for quality content but not committing to monthly subscriptions, instead opting for micro-payments across publishers in their local currency.

site_title: Chaswood sees impact on results from Malaysia's movement control curbs
summary: Chaswood Resources, a food-and-beverage operator, will operate only take-away and delivery services due to Malaysia's movement control order (MCO) in effect in six Selangor districts until May 17, 2021. The MCO aims to curb the spread of Covid-19, which has seen a recent surge in positive cases in Malaysia. Economic activities can continue, but social activities are barred during the period.

site_title: Malaysia's Maybank to stop financing new coal activities
summary: Malaysia's Maybank announced it will no longer finance new coal activities as part of a five-year strategy committing RM50 billion to sustainable financing. The decision comes after criticism from non-governmental organisations for funding coal plants despite ESG commitments. Maybank's group president and CEO Abdul Farid Alias stated there will be no new coal financing going forward.

site_title: EU 'ready to discuss' Covid vaccine patent waiver, says von der Leyen
summary: The European Union is willing to discuss a proposal to waive intellectual property rights for Covid-19 vaccines, following US backing. EU President Ursula von der Leyen stated the bloc is accelerating its vaccination effort, with 30 Europeans inoculated per second, and exporting over 200 million vaccine doses worldwide. This contrasts with limited vaccine sharing by the US and UK. Von der Leyen emphasized the EU's readiness to address the crisis in an effective and pragmatic manner.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.66 points to 1,578.33 on Thursday, driven by a higher closing price. The index saw 6.245 billion lots worth RM4.461 billion in trading, with losers outnumbering gainers 772 to 369.

site_title: Gold gains as subdued US dollar, bond yields lift appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,794.30 per ounce, driven by a subdued US dollar and Treasury yields. Benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields slipped below 1.6%, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest bearing gold. Investors await US non-farm payrolls data for April, which may impact the gold market. A dovish Federal Reserve is expected to keep yields lower, supporting gold prices.

site_title: Olam to act as technical partner in Saudi flour mill consortium
summary: Olam International has been selected as a technical partner in the privatization of a Saudi flour mill, part of a consortium that won the bid for the state-owned Second Milling Company. The deal was sold for 2.13 billion riyals (S$750 million) and is expected to be completed within the next six months. Olam will issue updates on the matter as developments occur, and its shares rose 0.59% to S$1.70 following the announcement.

site_title: ESR-Reit to raise S$150m as it acquires Singapore, Australia assets
summary: ESR-Reit is raising S$150 million through a private placement and preferential offering to fund the acquisition of a logistics facility in Singapore and a 10% stake in an Australian logistics investment. The Singapore acquisition costs S$119.2 million, while the Australian investment is valued at S$62.4 million. The funds will also be used for asset enhancement initiatives and debt repayment. The acquisitions are expected to be completed in May 2021, with ESR-Reit's manager citing the moves as distribution-per-unit-accretive and value-enhancing.

site_title: Investor group in exclusive talks to acquire Forbes for US$650m: source
summary: An investor group led by US merchant bank GSV's CEO Michael Moe is in exclusive talks to acquire Forbes Media for about $650 million. This marks a potential change in ownership seven years after Hong Kong-based Integrated Whale Media Investments purchased 95% of the company. Forbes has reported record results, and a deal must be finalized within a month before the exclusivity period expires. The publisher, known for its annual list of the world's wealthiest people, has been undergoing a digital transformation amid declining print revenue.

site_title: 'Get out of Thailand' campaign gains momentum as Covid worsens
summary: Hundreds of thousands of Thai students and young professionals have formed an online group, "Migrate," to discuss emigrating from Thailand due to dissatisfaction with the government's handling of the pandemic and slow vaccination pace. The group, with over 800,000 members, has gained momentum as the country faces its third and worst Covid-19 outbreak. Members are seeking better job and wealth prospects in countries like the US, Australia, and Japan, and some are planning to launch a website to compile information on emigration. The group's emergence is seen as a "vote of no-confidence" in the government.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: SPH to transfer media business to not-for-profit entity, amid falling advertising revenue. The Housing Board resale market saw 21 million-dollar flats sold in April, with overall resale prices rising for the 10th straight month. 95 serious suspected side effects from 2.2 million Covid-19 vaccine doses in Singapore have been reported. The Singapore Exchange Regulation is introducing AI solutions to oversee listed issuers. An e-commerce startup, Rainforest, launched with US$36 million in funding to buy and grow Asia-based brands on Amazon.

site_title: E-commerce dominates SingPost's top line, contributes 65%
summary: SingPost reported a 4.3% increase in revenue to S$696.9 million for the half-year, driven by strong e-commerce volume growth. E-commerce accounted for 34% of domestic post and parcel revenue, up from 21% last year. Despite higher costs, e-commerce's contribution to the top line outstripped the decline in letters and printed papers revenue. Net profit for the half-year more than halved to S$16.7 million, but the company aims to move more quickly to capitalize on e-commerce's growth.

site_title: SPH to transfer media business to not-for-profit entity
summary: SPH is transferring its media business to a not-for-profit entity, SPH Media Holdings, after a strategic review amid declining advertising revenue. The transfer, worth S$351.3 million, includes all media-related assets and employees. Profits from the media business will be reinvested into operations, freeing the business from shareholder expectations. The not-for-profit structure will allow SPH Media to seek funding for quality journalism and credible information. The move is expected to give SPH greater financial flexibility and allow the media business to operate sustainably.

site_title: Europe: Stocks near record high on strong AB Inbev, bank earnings
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% near record levels as strong earnings reports from AB Inbev and eurozone banks boosted the Stoxx 600 index. AB Inbev gained 3.4% after reporting ahead-of-expected first-quarter earnings, while UniCredit and Societe Generale surged 4.5% and 6.1% respectively. The wider euro zone banking sector hit a 14-month high, but Volkswagen slipped 0.5% despite raising its operating margin target for 2021.

site_title: Big Data startup Bonza clinches US$2m in latest pre-Series A funding round led by East Ventures
summary: Big Data startup Bonza has secured US$2 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by East Ventures, with participation from Elev8.vc. The funds will be used to develop and improve its no-code platform for enterprises to deploy data and AI solutions. This investment will help Bonza build a world-class engineering and data science team, accelerate platform development, and expand its presence in South-east Asia. The company aims to support digital-enabled companies and those adopting cloud-based data for the first time.

site_title: The SPH Journey: A timeline of key events since SGX listing
summary: Keppel Corporation has launched a S$2.2 billion bid to privatise Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) ex-media, offering S$2.099 per share, valuing SPH at S$3.4 billion. The scheme is subject to approval by SPH and Keppel shareholders, as well as other conditions and regulatory approvals. This marks the next step in SPH's strategic review to unlock and maximise value for all shareholders.

site_title: SGX RegCo to introduce AI, other tech solutions for oversight of listed issuers
summary: SGX RegCo to introduce AI and regtech solutions to enhance oversight of listed issuers, automating data extraction and analysis of financial risks. The regulator aims to use machine learning techniques and additional information sources to improve predictive capabilities. This will enable targeted regulatory responses and provide transparency to investors on signs of possible financial distress or irregularities in listed companies.

site_title: West must be 'very careful' about Chinese investment, Blinken says
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned that the West must be "very careful" about Chinese investment in Western economies, citing concerns over strategic assets. China's economic rise has been a significant geopolitical event, but the West has struggled to agree on a policy. Blinken emphasized that the US is not trying to contain China but rather uphold the rules-based international order. He advised caution on investments in strategic industries, but ruled out a complete boycott of Chinese business.

site_title: SpaceX successfully lands Starship rocket
summary: SpaceX successfully landed its Starship rocket prototype, SN15, at its Texas base for the first time in five attempts, marking a major milestone for the company. The test flight, which included a horizontal descent, ended with a small fire at the base of the 50m high rocket, but was quickly extinguished. The achievement comes ahead of a potential NASA contract to use Starship as a lunar lander, although the contract is currently suspended due to protests from rival companies.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares jump on Wall Street gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.8% on Thursday, driven by overnight gains on Wall Street, with the Nikkei 225 index ending at 29,331.37. The US dollar strengthened to 109.31 yen. Gains were seen in steel, mining, and maritime logistics sectors. However, investors are watching Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's comments on the pandemic situation, which may impact the market. Major shares, including Nippon Steel and Toyota, also rose.

site_title: Tesla to set up China database so drivers can access facts
summary: Tesla plans to set up a database in China allowing vehicle owners to access information generated by their electric cars. The database, expected to be operational later this year, will store driving data, following a highly publicized incident in China where a Tesla customer claimed the brakes failed. The data logs released after the incident showed the vehicle was traveling at 118.5 km/h before impact and slowed to 48.5 km/h after braking. The move comes as China considers new regulations requiring data from intelligent cars to be stored in the country.

site_title: 18 new cases of Covid-19 in Singapore, two in the community
summary: Singapore reported 18 new Covid-19 cases, with two in the community, on May 6, 2021. The community cases involve an 88-year-old fully-vaccinated cleaner and a 22-year-old national serviceman linked to the Pasir Panjang Terminal cluster. The cases bring the total number of cases in Singapore to 61,286. The Ministry of Health has taken measures to contain the spread, including disinfection and quarantine of close contacts.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on tech sell-off, escalating tensions with China
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 7,061.70, driven by a 3.6% decline in tech stocks amid concerns of an overheating economy. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's suggestion of rising interest rates also weighed on investor sentiment. The country's escalating tensions with China and fresh coronavirus curbs in Sydney further impacted investor sentiment.

site_title: Budweiser APAC to boost premium and non-beer offerings
summary: Budweiser APAC, the Asia arm of Anheuser-Busch InBev, plans to expand its premium beer brands and non-beer offerings in response to China's growing middle class and increasing disposable income. The company reported a 63.7% rise in first-quarter revenue and a 64.6% increase in total volume, driven by strong consumption during the Chinese New Year holiday. Revenue doubled in China from the same period last year, and premium brands saw high double-digit year-on-year growth. This shift aims to cater to the changing drinking occasions and needs of Chinese consumers.

images.alt_text: Budweiser Brewing APAC will step up promotion of premium beer brands including Hoegaarden and Corona and expand non-beer offerings, betting a rising middle class will boost demand for higher-end products.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank keeps key rate steady as virus cases surge
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 1.75% amid a surge in COVID-19 cases. The decision aims to support the economy's recovery despite the recent spike in infections. The bank expects lockdown measures to have a "less severe" impact on the economy, citing continued improvements in activity in the first quarter. The decision was in line with expectations from 13 economists polled by Reuters.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS initiates coverage on IReit Global with 'buy', S$0.76 target price
summary: DBS Group Research has initiated coverage on IReit Global with a "buy" call and a target price of S$0.76. The research house expects IReit to reap gains from an enlarged and diversified portfolio, with potential upside from rental escalation in its German portfolio and improved occupancy rates in its Spanish portfolio. DBS also expects stable and gradual increases in distributions, driven by rising rental rates. However, the company faces risks including the Covid-19 pandemic and lease expiries.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday's open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% at the opening of Thursday's trading, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,162.39 points. Anchor Resources gained 10.4% and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust rose 1.4% as Wall Street stocks finished higher, tracking solid private-sector hiring and rising service industry activity.

site_title: EDB New Ventures launches S$10m pilot programme to drive corporate innovation
summary: EDB New Ventures has launched a S$10 million pilot programme, the Corporate Venture Launchpad, to co-invest with large companies in Singapore, aiming to spur new growth areas. The programme, set to run for one year, will support up to 20 multinational and local enterprises in building new ventures beyond their core businesses. This initiative aligns with Singapore's efforts to help firms innovate and collaborate globally, following the successful incubation of over 40 corporate ventures in the past three years.

site_title: Nintendo warns chip crunch may hit Switch despite gaming boom
summary: Nintendo has reported better-than-expected earnings, beating estimates with operating income of 119.5 billion yen, thanks to hit games like Monster Hunter Rise. However, the company warned that global chip shortages may disrupt production of the Switch, despite a gaming boom. Nintendo's results suggest the gaming industry's resilience during the Covid-19 era.

site_title: Asia: Most markets lifted by recovery optimism
summary: Asia markets rose on Thursday as investors welcomed a strong US jobs report and optimism over the global economic recovery. The US added 742,000 jobs in April, with most in the services sector, and analysts expect further gains. The White House's support for a global waiver on patent protections for Covid vaccines also boosted hopes for a faster recovery in poorer nations. However, inflation concerns remain, and traders are cautious about the Federal Reserve's potential tightening of monetary policy.

site_title: Japan's vaccine drive may spur economic boost from 'forced savings': Bank of Japan
summary: Japan's Bank of Japan expects the national Covid-19 vaccination program to boost the economy with "forced savings" of $183 billion, accumulated during pandemic stay-at-home policies. Households may tap into this savings once vaccines are distributed widely, potentially rebounding consumption quickly. The bank forecasts a slow and fragile economic recovery, but expects private consumption to rebound larger-than-expected as the pandemic subsides. The recovery is driven by robust exports and a gradual rebound in consumption, with the pandemic expected to subside in Japan by next year.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise AA Reit target price; conversion of assets to data centres a positive surprise
summary: Analysts at DBS Group Research and RHB raised their target price for AA Reit to S$1.60 and S$1.58 respectively, citing a "goldmine" of untapped land bank and potential for rental growth. The real estate investment trust posted robust Q4 FY21 results, driven by recent acquisitions and better-than-expected rental performance. Analysts expect strong earnings momentum in FY2022, with estimates raised by 4-6% and a 10-11% rebound in distribution per unit.

site_title: Qantas to keep headquarters in Sydney after property review
summary: Qantas Airways has decided to retain its corporate headquarters in Sydney, and its low-cost arm Jetstar will keep its head office in Melbourne, after reviewing its property portfolio to cut costs during the pandemic. The airline had considered relocating its headquarters to other cities, but ultimately chose to stay in Sydney. Qantas will also make some changes, such as relocating maintenance on its Airbus A320 fleet from Singapore to Brisbane, and expanding maintenance operations in Melbourne.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 4.96 points or 0.31%, at 1,570.71. The index had a volume of 529.27 million lots worth RM373.30 million. Losers beat gainers 328 to 168, marking a lower trading day.

site_title: US embassy in the doghouse in China after student visa post backfires
summary: The US embassy in China faced backlash after a social media post comparing Chinese students to dogs was posted on Weibo, prompting an apology from the embassy. The post, which was meant to be light-hearted and humorous, was deemed insensitive by some netizens, who pointed out that dogs hold negative meanings in Chinese culture. The embassy took down the post immediately and apologized to those who were offended, marking a rare instance of animal-related remarks sparking a backlash in China.

site_title: 21 million-dollar HDB resale flats sold in April as overall prices rise for 10th straight month
summary: In April, 21 million-dollar HDB resale flats were sold, marking the 10th consecutive month of price increases. Resale prices rose 1.2% compared to March, with the number of million-dollar flats sold accounting for 0.9% of total resale volume. Experts attribute the demand to the return to phase 2 Covid-19 curbs, improved economic outlook, and firm private home prices. Analysts predict further growth in HDB resale prices, with some expecting a 7-10% increase this year.

site_title: China condemns G-7 statement censuring Beijing, supporting Taiwan
summary: China has condemned a joint G-7 statement that expressed support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations and criticized Beijing's human rights record. The G-7 foreign ministers called China a bully, accusing it of using economic influence to bully others. China views the statement as a gross interference in its internal affairs. The G-7 expressed concern about any unilateral actions that could escalate tensions in the Taiwan Strait, which China sees as a threat to its sovereignty. The statement was seen as a significant escalation in the US-China trade tensions.

images.alt_text: China condemned on Thursday a joint statement by G-7 foreign ministers that expressed support for Chinese-claimed Taiwan and cast Beijing as a bully, saying it was a gross interference in China's internal affairs.

site_title: Proxy adviser ISS cautions on pay of JPMorgan CEO Dimon
summary: Proxy adviser ISS recommended investors support JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon's pay at the bank's annual meeting on May 18, citing concerns about the compensation committee's discretion. ISS also advised backing all directors up for election despite opposition from climate activists. The proxy adviser expressed cautionary support for Dimon's pay, citing concerns about the bank's use of discretion in awarding compensation.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks post fastest daily gain in over three weeks on upbeat earnings
