summary: South Korean stocks closed 1% higher, marking their largest gain in over three weeks, driven by upbeat corporate earnings in the US and at home. The Kospi index rose 31.37 points to 3,178.74. Meanwhile, the Korean won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield fell. Notable movers included LG Chem's 1.96% gain and Naver's 0.82% loss.

site_title: Elon Musk among top leaders, businessmen to attend Bloomberg forum here in November
summary: Elon Musk will attend the Bloomberg New Economy Forum in Singapore from November 16-19, alongside top businessmen and government leaders. The forum, launched by Michael Bloomberg in 2018, will focus on global challenges and solutions, including climate change, finance, trade, and public health. The event aims to promote constructive dialogue and collaboration among leaders to address pressing issues, with a focus on Singapore's role as a neutral and trusted partner in the region.

site_title: Oil ends little changed, US oil inventories fall
summary: Oil prices ended little changed on Wednesday, despite a 2.3 million-barrel drop in US crude inventories, with Brent crude settling at $68.96 a barrel and US WTI crude settling at $65.63 a barrel. The market is weighing the outlook for demand amid rising coronavirus infections worldwide. Oil demand is gaining momentum, but pandemic-related restrictions in key importers India and Japan are expected to continue to impact prices.

site_title: US watching Chinese rocket's erratic re-entry: Pentagon
summary: The US Pentagon is monitoring a Chinese rocket's erratic re-entry into the atmosphere, expected this weekend, with the risk of crashing down in an inhabited area. The rocket, powered by the Long March 5B, is now in an irregular orbit and its re-entry trajectory is impossible to predict. The US is tracking the rocket's debris, but it's too soon to determine if any action can be taken to prevent potential harm. This is not the first time China has lost control of a spacecraft, with a similar incident occurring in 2018.

site_title: E-commerce startup founded by ex-Carousell, Fave executives launches with US$36m funding
summary: E-commerce startup Rainforest, founded by former Carousell and Fave executives, has launched with US$36 million in seed funding to acquire and grow Asia-based brands that sell on Amazon. The funding was led by Nordstar and includes a US$30 million debt facility. Rainforest aims to acquire profitable brands in lifestyle categories and eventually become a digitally native house-of-brands, similar to Newell Brands and The Hut Group.

images.alt_text: JJ Chai, chief executive officer of e-commerce startup Rainforest.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Thursday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 0.74% or 214.29 points to 29,026.92, and the Topix index advancing 1.10% or 20.96 points to 1,919.20. The gains followed rallies on Wall Street, with investors monitoring corporate earnings in Japan.

site_title: China to suspend economic dialogue mechanism with Australia
summary: China has indefinitely suspended its economic dialogue mechanism with Australia due to strained relations. The decision comes after Australia called for an international inquiry into the COVID-19 pandemic origins, prompting trade reprisals from China. The suspension was also triggered by Australia's cancellation of deals with China's Belt and Road Initiative and a review of a 99-year lease to a Chinese firm. The move reflects China's "Cold War mindset and ideological discrimination" towards Australia, according to China's state economic planner.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin with gains on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Thursday, driven by a positive lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.81% to 28,647.97, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up 0.14%. This follows a strong US services sector jobs report and as Shanghai reopened after a holiday weekend.

site_title: Bank of Japan board agreed to focus on keeping yields low: March meeting minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers agreed to keep yields low to support the economy still under strain from the Covid-19 pandemic. The central bank maintained its monetary policy steady at the March meeting and unveiled steps to make its tools sustainable. A government representative urged the BOJ to consider the impact of rising US interest rates on financial markets. The BOJ aims to achieve its 2% inflation target, but faces challenges in achieving this goal.

site_title: California police investigating fatal Tesla crash
summary: California police are investigating a fatal Tesla crash on a highway near Fontana, killing the 35-year-old driver and injuring a 50-year-old truck driver and a 30-year-old motorist who stopped to help him. The cause of the crash is unknown, and it's unclear if the Tesla was operating on Autopilot when it occurred. This is the 24th accident involving Tesla vehicles on Autopilot being investigated by federal regulators, who have yet to comment on the incident.

site_title: Ex-finance man at BreadTalk Chan Ying Jian to take over as Yeo Hiap Seng CFO
summary: Chan Ying Jian, a former finance executive at BreadTalk, will become Yeo Hiap Seng's new CFO on July 1. He replaces Koo Liang Kwee, who is leaving the company on May 31 to pursue other career opportunities. Chan has previously worked at The Learning Lab and at JP Morgan, and has held various finance roles. His hiring comes after Yeo Hiap Seng's CEO, Samuel Koh, joined the company in March 2020.

site_title: Bank bosses want a return to office, but staff aren't so sure
summary: Bank executives in North America favor a return to office, with 80% preferring employees spend 4-5 days in the office post-pandemic. However, many employees, who have proven productivity while working from home, are unlikely to comply with the plan. Flexibility in work schedules is seen as key to retaining female employees, with 29% of women in finance considering leaving their jobs or already having left due to the pandemic. Meanwhile, companies are planning to reduce their office space and explore new technologies to incorporate remote employees.

images.alt_text: Last week, JPMorgan Chase & Co became the first major bank to mandate that employees get back to the office in the coming months, while Goldman Sachs is planning to follow suit in June.

site_title: SingPost's H2 net profit falls 55.7% to S$16.7m on pandemic-related costs
summary: SingPost reported a 55.7% decline in H2 net profit to S$16.7m, attributed to pandemic-related costs. Revenue grew 4.3% to S$696.9m, driven by e-commerce growth in logistics and domestic post segments. However, the post and parcel segment saw a 10.1% decline due to air capacity constraints and higher conveyance costs. The group's total exceptional losses were S$12m, and its board proposed a final dividend of 0.6 Singapore cent per share.

images.alt_text: SingPost on Thursday posted net profit of S$16.7 million for the second half of the fiscal year ended March, down 55.7 per cent from S$37.7 million for H2 FY2020.

site_title: Australian regulator moves to block Qantas-Japan Airlines deal
summary: Australia's competition regulator has blocked a deal between Qantas and Japan Airlines, citing concerns that it would lead to higher fares for passengers. The five-year agreement, proposed in 2020, aimed to improve connections between 29 cities in Australia, Japan, and New Zealand. However, the regulator found that cooperation would cause "severe harm to competition" and eliminate Qantas and Japan Airlines' ability to compete for passengers. The regulator is open to granting exceptions to aid airlines' recovery, but only if it benefits the public and doesn't harm competition in the long term.

site_title: SPH shares halted: Media group recently announced strategic review
summary: SPH shares were halted on May 5, 2021, pending an announcement of a "significant corporate development". The company, which publishes The Business Times, is undergoing a strategic review to consider options for its various businesses, following a 26.1% increase in net profit for the half year ended February 28. The media business continues to be affected by the decline in print advertisement sales due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: ARA H-Trust posts 6.5% rise in Q1 gross revenue to US$19.6m amid recovery
summary: ARA H-Trust posted a 6.5% rise in Q1 gross revenue to US$19.6 million, driven by a recovery in the US hospitality market following record Covid-19 vaccinations and federal stimulus. Gross operating profit decreased 3.4% to US$2.8 million, while occupancy rose 2.9 percentage points to 42.3% and revenue per available room increased 11.4% to US$39. The trust achieved positive net property income for the first time in two quarters, with a reversal from negative US$1.7 million last quarter.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust H1 DPU up 9.5% to 3.8 S cents post merger
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) posted a 9.5% rise in distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.8 Singapore cents for the first half of 2021, driven by record revenue boosted by its merger with Frasers Commercial Trust in 2020. Revenue nearly doubled to S$231.7 million, while adjusted net property income grew 79.3% to S$173.9 million. The distribution will be paid out on June 18.

site_title: PayPal earnings soar on e-commerce boom
summary: PayPal reported a record quarterly profit of $1.1 billion, a significant increase from $84 million in the same period last year. The surge in earnings is attributed to the e-commerce boom driven by the pandemic. PayPal's CEO, Dan Schulman, attributed the company's success to the shift towards the digital economy. The strong earnings demonstrate sustained momentum in PayPal's business, positioning the company for continued growth in the online financial transactions market.

images.alt_text: PayPal on Wednesday reported record quarterly profit as the online financial transactions service benefited from an e-commerce trend boosted by the pandemic.

site_title: Despite lockdown, US birthrate dropped sharply in 2020
summary: The US birthrate dropped sharply in 2020, with 3.6 million babies born, a 4% decline from the previous year. This marks the sixth consecutive year of declining births and the lowest number since 1979. The total fertility rate was 1,637.5 births per 1,000 women, or 1.6 children per woman, below the required 2.1 to replace each generation. Births declined across all racial groups, with the largest drop among Asian Americans, and also among women in all age groups.

site_title: Biden administration blocks Trump rule on gig workers
summary: The US Labor Department has blocked a rule finalized under former President Trump that would have classified gig workers, such as Uber and Lyft drivers, as independent contractors rather than employees. The rule, which was set to take effect, would have made it easier to misclassify workers and denied them minimum wage and overtime protections. Labor Secretary Marty Walsh stated that the withdrawal of the rule will help preserve worker rights and protect essential workers. Rideshare companies Uber and Lyft opposed the move, citing it would undermine their business model.

site_title: Biden says Republicans have lost their way in 'mini-revolution'
summary: US President Joe Biden stated that the Republican Party has lost its way in a "mini-revolution" following Donald Trump's presidency. Biden criticized the party for struggling to define itself and urged a return to truth and fidelity to the Constitution. The criticism comes after pro-Trump elements pushed for the ousting of House Republican Liz Cheney, who has condemned Trump's false claims of election fraud. Biden emphasized the need for a two-party system, warning that the current situation is unhealthy for democracy.

site_title: Meghan Markle wins UK copyright claim over letter to father
summary: A British court upheld Meghan Markle's copyright claim against Associated Newspapers, the publisher of the Mail on Sunday and MailOnline, over its publication of a handwritten letter to her father Thomas Markle. The ruling means Meghan has won every part of her legal claim, including a statement acknowledging her victory on the front page of the Mail on Sunday. The court previously issued a "summary judgement" in her favor over privacy and data protection rights claims. Meghan's solicitor stated that lawyers for the Keeper of the Privy Purse and Jason Knauf denied any claim to copyright on behalf of the Crown.

site_title: WHO's Tedros hails 'historic' US support for vaccine patent waiver
summary: World Health Organization (WHO) chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus hailed the US support for a global waiver on patent protections for Covid-19 vaccines, calling it a "historic decision" that steps towards vaccine equity. The move, backed by India and South Africa, aims to increase vaccine production and accessibility for poorer nations. The US support comes after months of pressure from Tedros, who previously clashed with former US President Donald Trump. The WHO chief praised US President Joe Biden's commitment as a "powerful example of leadership" in addressing global health challenges.

site_title: Brazil's central bank raises interest rate to 3.5%
summary: Brazil's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate to 3.5% for the second time in a row to curb inflation, which reached 6.1% in March, exceeding the 5.25% target range. The decision aims to balance curbing inflation with avoiding a slowdown in the economy. The next rate hike is expected to be 75 basis points, set for mid-June. This move follows the bank's previous rate hike in March, the first in six years, as policymakers navigate the challenges of the coronavirus pandemic.

site_title: UK government condemns French threats over post-Brexit fishing
summary: The UK government has condemned French threats to cut off electricity to the Channel Island of Jersey over post-Brexit fishing rights, calling them "unacceptable" and "disproportionate". France warned it could involve the electricity supply via underwater cables after Jersey refused to issue licences to French vessels. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson spoke to Jersey Chief Minister John Le Fondré, stressing the need for a de-escalation in tensions. The dispute is one of several between the UK and EU since the UK's departure from the bloc's single market and customs union.

site_title: Bank of England to say UK recovery is accelerating
summary: The Bank of England is expected to announce that the UK's economy is accelerating towards a stronger recovery this year than initially forecast, with growth potentially exceeding 7% due to fast Covid-19 vaccinations. The BoE will keep its benchmark interest rate and bond-buying programme unchanged, but may start tapering its quantitative easing programme. The decision is seen as a moderate step towards reversing emergency stimulus, with most economists predicting the first rate hike in 2023.

site_title: BlackRock turns up heat on boards at AGMs
summary: BlackRock voted against more company directors and backed more shareholder resolutions in the first quarter, pushing boards to address climate and sustainability issues. This trend is expected to shape a tough shareholder voting season at major corporations this spring. The move is part of BlackRock's efforts to hold companies accountable for their environmental and social impact.

site_title: Cruise companies hope for smoother sailing this travel season
summary: Cruise companies have outlined travel schedules for the upcoming season, with safety protocols in place, including COVID-19 testing, vaccination requirements, and mask mandates. The industry has faced significant losses, including tens of billions of dollars and hundreds of thousands of job losses, following last year's pandemic-affected season. Despite these challenges, companies are hopeful for a smoother sailing this year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks bounce back from tech rout on strong data, commodities
summary: European stocks surged 1.8% on Wednesday, their best day in nearly two months, after strong data showed euro zone business activity picking up in April and commodity prices hitting decade highs. Resource stocks, including copper, jumped 4.7% to a 10-year peak, while oil and gas stocks surged 3.2% in their best day since mid-February. The Stoxx 600 index ended 1.8% higher, wiping out Tuesday's 1.4% loss, as investors became more optimistic about an economic recovery.

site_title: Singapore's big tech manufacturers
summary: Singapore's big tech manufacturers are facing challenges, with Creative Technology warning of potential revenue below target and operating loss similar to the first half of the year. Meanwhile, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang met with US President Trump ahead of his China trip. In other news, the US Justice Department approved T-Mobile's $4.4 billion acquisition of UScellular, and Huawei is seeking AI chip customers in the Middle East and South-east Asia. Meta poached an Apple AI engineer with a pay package over $200 million.

site_title: US: Dow Jones edges to record but Nasdaq falls again
summary: US stocks closed with mixed results, with the Dow Jones finishing at a record high and the Nasdaq falling for the second consecutive day. Private sector hiring added 742,000 jobs in April, and service sector activity showed expansionary territory. However, markets remain cautious about a potential rebound in prices. The Dow Jones gained 0.3% to 34,230.21, while the S&P 500 climbed 0.1% to 4,167.63, and the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.4% to 13,582.42.

site_title: Former CEO of foodpanda, Rocket Internet Asia build e-commerce startup with US$40m seed funding
summary: Una Brands, a Singapore-based e-commerce startup, has secured US$40 million in seed funding to acquire and scale e-commerce brands in the Asia-Pacific region. Led by Kingsway Capital, the round also involves 500 Startups, 468 Capital, Presight Capital, and Global Founders Capital. Founded by former Rocket Internet Asia CEO Kiren Tanna, Una Brands aims to acquire companies with annual revenue between US$300,000 and US$20 million, focusing on strategic growth and partnerships across leading e-commerce platforms. The company plans to complete transactions in under five weeks and integrate with sellers over an extended period.

site_title: Citi's Australia retail unit draws interest from major local banks
summary: Citi's Australian retail unit is drawing interest from major local banks, including National Australia Bank, Australia & New Zealand Banking Group, and ING Bank Australia, as the US lender seeks to sell its entire operations. The assets, valued at A$14.2 billion, include A$3.6 billion in credit card assets and A$11.6 billion in loans and finance leases. Discussions are ongoing, with non-binding bids due later this month, and the sale is expected to be finalized by July. The sale could fetch up to US$6 billion, according to Bloomberg News.

site_title: Nasdaq 100 sees worst day since March on inflation fears
summary: US tech stocks experienced their worst day since March due to inflation fears, with the Nasdaq 100 plummeting 3.4% amid concerns that interest rates may rise to curb the economy's overheating. The Federal Reserve's potential shift from near-zero rates was a major factor, with hedge funds and tech megacaps particularly affected. The selling pressure was also driven by stretched valuations, with unprofitable tech firms declining by almost 30% from their February peak.

site_title: UOB says keen to review Citi assets; Q1 profit up 18% on record fees, smaller impairment
summary: UOB has expressed interest in reviewing Citi's assets for sale in Asia Pacific, joining Singapore peers in pursuing acquisitions for growth. The bank's Q1 net profit rose 18% to S$1.01 billion, driven by record fee income and smaller impairment charges. UOB's loans under moratorium remain unchanged, and the bank is reviewing office space requirements amid the pandemic. The bank expects a 50% dividend payout ratio to resume once the regulator relaxes the cap. UOB's shares closed 1% down at S$26.03.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, SPH, FLCT, ARA H-Trust, SingPost, Dairy Farm, Hongkong Land, MIT
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article:

Several Singaporean companies saw new developments that may impact trading on Thursday. UOB posted an 18% increase in net profit for Q1 2021, while FLCT's distribution per unit rose 9.5%. ARA H-Trust and SingPost reported lower gross revenue and net profits due to Covid-19 disruptions. Dairy Farm's first-quarter performance was affected by the pandemic, and Hongkong Land's attributable interest in contracted sales fell. MIT and UMS also saw share price movements, with MIT ending down 1.1% and UMS shedding 2.9%. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Prudential wins lawsuit against former top agency manager
summary: Prudential Assurance Co Singapore has won a lawsuit against former top group agency manager Peter Tan Shou Yi, who poached over 220 agents for rival Aviva. The court found that Tan breached his contractual obligation to conduct his insurance business with integrity and honesty. Compensation will be determined when the insurer's loss of profit is assessed. Tan denied soliciting the agents but was found liable for the profits the insurer could have earned from the sales of the 227 agents who left.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KrisEnergy, a troubled oil and gas company, has removed earmarks on certain notes following a failed restructuring. The move affects S$139.5 million in senior secured zero-coupon notes, S$200 million in senior unsecured notes, and S$130 million in senior unsecured notes. The restructuring plan was announced last month, but fell through. The company has yet to announce the outcome of the restructuring.

site_title: Has SGX managed to address all governance concerns on SPACs?
summary: SGX has released a Consultation Paper on Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) for the third time, following previous attempts in 2008 and 2010 that were hindered by governance concerns. The latest proposal includes measures to protect investors, such as additional safeguards proposed by Sias, which may lead to a successful listing of SPACs. This could mark a significant development for SGX, addressing concerns and potentially paving the way for the listing of vehicles with no core businesses.

site_title: Germany, WHO announce creation of new data hub to fight pandemics
summary: Germany and the World Health Organization (WHO) have announced the creation of a new global data hub in Berlin to combat pandemics. The hub aims to gather health-related data worldwide, predict, prevent, and respond to pandemic and epidemic risks. German Health Minister Jens Spahn called for a "global reset" in the fight against pandemics, citing the need for improved data collection and inter-disciplinary risk analysis. The initiative follows criticism of the WHO's handling of the Covid-19 pandemic, with three independent panels set to report on reforms this month.

site_title: What it takes to keep South-east Asia's digital economy booming
summary: South-east Asia's digital economy is booming, with 70% of the population now online and a total of 400 million users. The sector is expected to grow from $100 billion in 2020 to over $300 billion in 2025, driven by double-digit growth in countries like Vietnam and Indonesia. Key trends include the growth of healthtech, edtech, and digital financial services, which require wider integration with healthcare providers and regulatory support to maintain momentum. Policymakers will need to address talent shortages and develop public infrastructure to support growth in emerging sectors.

site_title: Nissan follows Renault in selling Daimler stake for 1.15b euros
summary: Nissan Motor Co sold its entire stake in Daimler AG for 1.15 billion euros, joining Renault SA in generating funds for turnaround efforts. The sale follows the 2018 arrest of former Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn, which threw the alliance into disarray. Nissan plans to use the proceeds to enhance business competitiveness, including electrification investments. The industrial partnership between Nissan and Daimler remains unchanged, with the two companies continuing to collaborate in several areas.

site_title: Uncertainty over COE prices may lead SMEs to put the brakes on fleet expansion plans
summary: Singaporean SMEs may put the brakes on fleet expansion plans due to uncertainty over Certificate of Entitlement (COE) prices for commercial vehicles. Despite a slight decrease in COE prices, industry players expect a general uptrend, with the pandemic and supply chain issues affecting the market. Companies may turn to the rental market if COE prices stay high, with some opting for electric vehicles. Experts predict COE prices will continue to rise, with a possible peak around 2022, and warn that businesses will wait out high COE prices unless they have discretionary room in their decision-making.

site_title: Romeo and Juliet meets the hot vax summer
summary: A new filmed production of Romeo and Juliet has premiered on PBS, bringing a "spicy summer" to the stage. The film, starring Jessie Buckley and Josh O'Connor, is a sensual adaptation that focuses on the physical tension between the characters. Director Simon Godwin's direction emphasizes hands and touch, creating a palpable intimacy between the lovers. However, the film's portrayal of physical intimacy during the pandemic raises questions about the changing relationship to physical intimacy, with some viewers finding it alarming or even pornographic. The film's steamy portrayal sparks debate about the impact of the pandemic on our understanding of sex and intimacy.

site_title: Hong Kong is a renters' market as prices drop on expat exits
summary: Rents in Hong Kong have dropped to HK$33.60 (S$5.77) per square foot, the lowest since 2016, as expatriates exit the market following anti-government protests and a declining population. Typical two-bedroom apartments in Soho now rent for about US$3,500 a month, down from US$4,200 two years ago. Rents in other financial hubs, such as New York and London, have also declined, while Singapore remains an outlier with 2.4% higher rents. Economists predict another 5-10% decline in 2021 due to a shrinking population and travel restrictions.

site_title: ERA donates over S$20,000 to BT BAF
summary: ERA Realty donates S$20,000 to the Business Times Budding Artists Fund (BT BAF), supporting free arts lessons for hundreds of socially-disadvantaged children. The donation was made during ERA's Q2'21 Career Advancement Day, where the company also held a charity art exhibition featuring 48 paintings by 32 children. ERA's adoption of new technologies during the pandemic has been recognized by Desmond Tan, Minister of State for Home Affairs and Sustainability and the Environment, who praised the company's innovative approach to the industry.

images.alt_text: Desmond Tan (second from left), Minister of State for Home Affairs and Sustainability and the Environment, presenting a S$20,000 mock cheque to Helmi Yusof (second from right), deputy editor (lifestyle) of The Business Times, and Genii Koh (far right), board member of TRCL. With them are Jack Chua (far left), chief executive officer of ERA Singapore, and Gary Lau (third fom left), chief agency director of ERA Singapore.

site_title: Time to end the love affair with real estate. Here are some ideas
summary: Singapore's real estate market is criticized for favoring investors, making it difficult for the younger generation to afford homes. High property prices lead to increased business costs, market volatility, and divert funds from business investments. Foreign wealth is also parked in the market, driving up prices. A stable real estate market benefits the economy, but its influence and potential tax revenue needs to be re-examined. The article suggests that the market's impact on the economy and its tax implications require closer examination.

site_title: Dollar hits two-week high on rates talk, tech sell-off
summary: The US dollar reached its highest level in over two weeks, driven by speculation of potential US interest rate hikes and a tech sell-off, which negatively impacted the euro. The dollar surpassed the $1.20 mark against the euro, its lowest level in two weeks.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 6.2% in March
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.2% year-on-year in March, exceeding expectations, but economists caution that tighter Covid-19 measures in May may impact sales. The low base effect from last year's circuit breaker is expected to boost April's figures. Discretionary categories like watches and jewellery saw strong growth, while supermarkets and hypermarkets fell 14% year-on-year. Restaurant sales rose 17.9% and fast food outlets 5.5%, but food caterers saw a 25% year-on-year decline. The May retail sales data may be affected by the measures, which could impact sales in the second quarter.

site_title: Trust is key to realising vaccine multilateralism, says EDB chairman
summary: EDB chairman Dr. Beh Swan Gin emphasized the importance of trust in vaccine multilateralism, citing Singapore and Switzerland's successful co-chairing of the Covax facility as a demonstration of commitment to multilateralism. He noted that partnerships between countries are needed to tackle the Covid-19 crisis and that no one is safe until everyone is safe. Dr. Gin also highlighted the need for trust to be trustworthy and to face the truth, as Lord Brian Griffiths of Goldman Sachs stated, in order to have trust.

site_title: Red Hot Chili Peppers sell song catalogue for US$140m
summary: Red Hot Chili Peppers sold their song catalogue for $140-150 million to British investment firm Hipgnosis. The deal includes hits such as "Under The Bridge" and "Californication." The band members jointly approved the sale, which will provide immediate payouts rather than waiting for earnings. This sale is part of a song rights purchasing boom, with other notable deals including Bob Dylan's $300 million sale and Stevie Nicks' $100 million sale.

site_title: US vs other powers: When the chips are down
summary: The US is facing increased pressure from other world powers, particularly China, Iran, and Russia, which are exhibiting aggressive nationalism. A novel, "2034," predicts a war between the US and China, with Iran and Russia joining forces. Recent events, such as China and Iran's 25-year cooperation agreement and Russia's massing troops on Ukraine's border, mirror these predictions. This trend is concerning, especially as the US democracy is weakening, making it more vulnerable to external threats. The global landscape is shifting, with the US facing a growing challenge from other nations.

site_title: Undervalued property developers: are they worth a second look?
summary: Several Singapore property developers are trading at undervalued valuations, with some sitting on land parcels and others poised to launch residential projects. Developers such as T24, Tuan Sing Holdings, and Ho Bee Land could benefit from the ongoing residential upcycle, driven by low interest rates and demand from HDB upgraders. Analysts expect these companies to see a boost in share prices due to successful sales launches and potential IPOs. However, the risk of cooling measures remains a concern, which could weigh on the share prices of residential property developers in the near-term.

site_title: ARK's performance under pressure as tech stocks swoon
summary: ARK Innovation, a flagship ETF managed by Cathie Wood, saw a 1% gain in May, but its year-to-date performance is 9% down, ranking in the bottom 100th percentile among mid-cap growth funds. This decline is attributed to a rotation out of growth and technology stocks, particularly a slide in Tesla shares. The fund's underperformance contrasts with the S&P 500's 10.9% gain over the same period, highlighting the challenges faced by tech-focused investments.

site_title: Is the US economy recovering or overheating?
summary: The US economy is on track for a full recovery, with expected second-quarter growth rate of at least 8% and a potential full return to pre-pandemic production levels by the third or fourth quarter of 2021. Core inflation rose 0.4 percentage points over the past month, implying a nearly 5% annual inflation rate, but is expected to hover around the Fed's 2-2.5% target. The economy is emerging from the pandemic recession with a fundamentally altered inter-sectoral balance, and wage and price increases are seen as essential for rebalancing the economy, rather than indicative of "overheating."

site_title: White House eyes subsidies for nuclear plants to help meet climate targets: sources
summary: The White House is considering taxpayer subsidies for existing nuclear power plants to meet the US climate goals of being emissions-free by 2035. The proposed "production tax credits" would support nuclear facilities, which are the country's top source of emissions-free power generation, but are facing closures due to rising security costs and competition from cheaper alternatives. The move is backed by President Joe Biden's allies in the building trades unions and moderate Senator Joe Manchin, who holds significant power in the Senate.

site_title: Consumer, technology stocks among RHB's top picks for 2021
summary: RHB Investment Bank has released its Top Small Cap Companies Jewels 2021 book, highlighting 20 Singapore small-cap companies with a market capitalization of less than S$4 billion. The top picks include consumer stocks such as BRC Asia, Banyan Tree Holdings, and Food Empire, which RHB expects to benefit from an increase in consumer spending and tourism. The bank also favors technology companies, including Multi-Chem and ISDN Holdings, which are expected to benefit from the growing demand for IT-related products. RHB's outlook for small caps remains positive, with the bank noting that the sector remains undervalued and has room for growth.

images.alt_text: SBS Transit looks set to undergo a positive re-rating amid a recovery in ridership over the next 12 months, and a likely earnings uplift from a change in the DTL's operating model, says RHB.

site_title: US pressing Taiwanese firms on semiconductors: commerce chief
summary: The US is pressuring Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturers, particularly TSMC, to allocate their supply to American automakers amid a global shortage of critical components. US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said the country is looking to reduce its reliance on foreign suppliers, especially China, and is urging Taiwan to prioritize the needs of US auto companies. The shortage has led to production cuts and potential price increases for gadgets like game consoles and computer tablets, with Ford cutting its second-quarter production by half.

site_title: US private payrolls increase solidly in April: report
summary: US private payrolls increased by 742,000 jobs in April, according to the ADP National Employment Report, indicating the economy gained momentum in the second quarter. This boost is attributed to companies rushing to boost production amid rising demand, powered by government aid and rising vaccinations against Covid-19.

site_title: Ikea to buy back unwanted UK furniture in green push
summary: IKEA is launching a program to buy back unwanted furniture in the UK, aiming to reduce waste and meet growing demand for second-hand products. The company will offer vouchers for 30-50% of the item's original value, depending on condition, for fully-assembled items such as dressers and desks. Returned furniture will be resold or recycled, with the average price for eligible items at £29. This initiative follows testing in Scotland and aims to reduce the environmental impact of the company.

site_title: Blue Origin to begin space tourism ticket sales Wednesday
summary: Blue Origin, owned by billionaire Jeff Bezos, is set to begin selling tickets for suborbital sightseeing trips on its New Shepard spacecraft on Wednesday. The company has kept the cost a secret, but Reuters reported in 2018 that tickets could cost at least $200,000. Blue Origin will announce details on purchasing a seat, the first flight timing, and ticket cost. This marks a significant step in private commercial space travel, following rival Virgin Galactic Holdings' similar plans.

site_title: Twisted democracies: The vicious circle of Latin American politics
summary: Latin America's democracies are plagued by a vicious cycle of politics, with authoritarian left-wing and right-wing populists winning elections despite lacking support. Peru's Pedro Castillo and Ecuador's Guillermo Lasso will likely face significant governing challenges due to fragmented parliaments and weak majorities. The region's unique combination of presidentialism and proportional electoral systems has led to unstable governance, with politicians prioritizing short-term gains over long-term reforms. Scholars argue that this system has weakened parties and led to self-defeating policies, perpetuating a cycle of voter dissatisfaction and calls for further reforms.

site_title: Indonesia aims for V-shaped recovery with stimulus programmes to lift domestic demand
summary: Indonesia aims to achieve a V-shaped recovery by implementing stimulus programs to boost domestic demand. The country's GDP declined 0.74% in the first quarter, worse than expected, but an improvement from the 2.19% contraction in the final quarter of 2020. Indonesia's efforts to stimulate the economy come as the global economic landscape continues to face challenges.

images.alt_text: While factory activity and consumer confidence have shown a steady increase, core inflation and retail sales remain subdued as movement curbs limit household spending.

site_title: Developers' margins squeezed by higher land, construction costs: survey
summary: Singapore property developers face squeezed profit margins due to higher land, construction costs, and agent commissions. A recent survey found that nearly half of developers saw margins narrow by 5-10% from pre-pandemic levels, and 30% reported margins shrinking by 10-20%. The labour crunch in the construction sector and rising building materials costs are major contributors to the margin compression. The government has announced emergency legislation to address the disruption to the construction sector, with Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong promising to share the burden more fairly among parties.

site_title: Hyatt posts bigger loss as pandemic keeps people at home
summary: Hyatt Hotels Corp reported a bigger loss for the first quarter due to the Covid-19 pandemic, with total revenue falling 55.9% to $438 million. The company's comparable system-wide revenue per available room (RevPAR) fell 48.9%. Despite this, business demand gained momentum, with improved confidence in travel fueled by vaccine distribution and easing of travel restrictions. Net loss attributable to Hyatt was $304 million, or $2.99 per share, compared to a loss of $103 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Gold miner Anchor Resources changes name, expands into fintech business
summary: Anchor Resources, a gold miner, has changed its name to VCPlus Limited and is expanding into the fintech sector through a joint venture with CapitalX Global and five investors. The JV company, Custody Plus, will provide digital asset custody services and has received regulatory approval. VCPlus will have a 55% controlling interest, with CapitalX holding 35% and investors 10%. The company will utilize $2.6 million in net cash proceeds to finance its fintech business and working capital.

site_title: Virtually clothed, on social media
summary: Singapore-based fashion entrepreneur James Gaubert's company, Republiqe, has sold over 500 virtual fashion "garments" since August 2020, breaking even through the unique non-fungible token (NFT) sales model. This trend is part of the mainstream adoption of digital-savvy lifestyle companies turning to NFTs as an alternative revenue stream, with others in music, toys, and dining also exploring the technology.

site_title: Kuala Lumpur restricts movements to stem rise in new Covid-19 cases
summary: Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, has imposed movement restrictions from May 7 to 20 to combat a surge in new Covid-19 cases, with 3,744 new cases reported on Wednesday. The restrictions include dining-in bans, limited operating hours for grocery stores and gas stations, and farmers' markets operating from 6am to 2pm. The measures come as Malaysia reviews its curbs amid a rise in infections, including the Indian Covid-19 variant, and a slow vaccination pace, with only 2% of the population fully vaccinated.

site_title: Swiss digital therapeutics firm MindMaze in SPAC talks, seeks funds: sources
summary: Swiss digital therapeutics firm MindMaze is in talks with a US special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) to raise over $100 million in a deal valuing the company at over $2 billion. The firm, backed by Leonardo DiCaprio, aims to attract financing for growth and acquisitions. MindMaze offers virtual reality-based neuro restoration technology to help patients with stroke, Parkinson's, and other movement and cognitive disabilities. The company's CEO, Tej Tadi, is seeking to expand its digital therapeutics to address multiple diseases.

site_title: EU executive dials down China investment agreement
summary: The European Commission has scaled back efforts to ratify a planned investment agreement with China due to EU lawmakers' opposition to the deal amid China's sanctions on five EU colleagues. The Commission has put the agreement on hold, with a legal review and translation into EU languages underway. The EU Parliament is unlikely to evaluate the deal until 2022, with many lawmakers opposing it. China's human rights record and US skepticism have already cast doubt on the agreement's approval process.

site_title: Short-term profit-taking likely on latest round of Covid curbs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) has hit a one-month low due to the reinstatement of Covid-19 safety measures from May 8 to 30. Analysts predict short-term profit-taking in transport, travel, and retail sectors, while office, industrial, and logistics Reits are less likely to be affected. Supermarket plays and glove-sector stocks may see gains, while healthcare proxies like Q&M Dental are expected to benefit from increased testing.

site_title: Shell sells US refinery for US$350m in latest divestment
summary: Royal Dutch Shell sold its Puget Sound Refinery in Washington to HollyFrontier for $350 million, including $150-180 million for hydrocarbon inventories. This is part of Shell's efforts to divest from refining and focus on lower-carbon petrochemicals. The deal complements HollyFrontier's existing refining business, providing access to Canadian crude and premium product markets. The transaction is expected to be completed by the fourth quarter.

site_title: Prudential wins lawsuit against ex-top agency manager over exodus of more than 200 agents
summary: Prudential Assurance Co Singapore won a lawsuit against former top group agency manager Peter Tan Shou Yi over the poaching of over 220 agents for rival Aviva. Justice Chua Lee Ming found Tan liable for breach of contractual obligation to conduct business with integrity and honesty. Compensation will be awarded when assessed, but Tan can appeal. The court ruled that Tan was not entitled to a non-solicitation clause and did not owe fiduciary duties to Prudential, as he left the agency before the clause took effect.

site_title: US: Wall Street rises as growth stocks regain
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.09% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite opening higher by 0.30% and 0.72% respectively. This follows a selloff in megacap stocks the previous session. A survey showed a solid rise in private jobs in April, boosting investor sentiment. The gains come despite tariff uncertainty and mixed Federal Reserve views.

site_title: EU-India summit highlights Europe's engagement of key emerging markets
summary: The European Union is hosting an India summit, focusing on a landmark trade and investment deal, as part of its goal to strengthen its presence in emerging markets. The EU aims to collaborate with India on connectivity projects, including infrastructure development and 5G standards, and is also exploring joint initiatives on sustainability. The EU-India partnership is seen as a key prize, given the two countries' shared status as the world's largest democracies and India's largest single trade and investment partner. This is part of the EU's broader strategy to engage with emerging markets, including China and Africa, to drive economic and political advantage.

site_title: Amazon fuels North America's most severe warehouse shortage
summary: Amazon's rapid expansion of its logistics footprint in Canada has led to a severe warehouse shortage in North America, particularly in the Toronto area, where the vacancy rate has dropped to 0.5%. The e-commerce giant's demand for warehouses has outpaced new supply, driving up costs and threatening the broader economy. This shortage is expected to worsen by the end of the year, potentially affecting Canadian exports and domestic consumers, and may force companies to seek alternative storage solutions, such as using farmers' fields or converting office buildings into logistics space.

site_title: US, China to assess Phase One deal soon, Biden trade chief says
summary: US Trade Representative Katherine Tai expects to assess China's implementation of the Phase One trade deal, which aims to boost US exports and address intellectual property issues. The assessment will influence the fate of US tariffs on $370 billion in Chinese imports, with Tai suggesting they could be lifted if the deal is effective. Tai also emphasized the need for continuity in US-China trade policy and expressed hopes for cooperation on climate change and other areas. The Phase One deal expires at the end of 2021, and Tai's review will inform the Biden administration's approach to trade policy.

site_title: Indian delegation self-isolates at G-7 diplomats meeting
summary: India's foreign minister, Subrahmanyam Jaishankar, has self-isolated at a G-7 diplomats meeting in London due to possible exposure to coronavirus. Despite two positive cases among the Indian delegation, Jaishankar was not infected, according to Public Health England. The Indian team is now self-isolating, and Jaishankar will participate virtually in the sessions. The UK has deemed the risk low, and the summit is proceeding as planned, with leaders meeting in person in Cornwall next month.

site_title: Saudi Arabia cuts oil prices for Asia as India battles virus
summary: Saudi Arabia lowered oil prices for Asia by 10-30 US cents per barrel, citing a surge in coronavirus cases in India, the world's third-largest crude importer. The price cut, for June shipments, signals weakness in Asian oil markets. Saudi Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman urged Opec+ members to be cautious as the group eases supply cuts, which would still leave production below pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: EU executive slows drive for China investment deal
summary: The European Commission has scaled back efforts to secure a China investment deal, citing the EU lawmakers' imposition of sanctions on five of their colleagues as a major obstacle. The Commission acknowledged that the China Comprehensive Agreement on Investment (CAI) cannot be ratified while sanctions remain in place. The prospects for the deal's ratification now depend on the evolving situation, according to the Commission's statement.

site_title: Cooling measures cited as key risk by Singapore real-estate market, poll finds
summary: A poll of 50 senior executives in Singapore's real-estate firms found cooling measures as the biggest risk to the market, with 87.8% citing it as a potential risk over the next six months. Rising construction costs and inflation or interest rates were the second and third biggest risks, respectively. The composite sentiment index, which measures overall market sentiment, rose to 6.8, indicating improved market conditions. Developers expect moderately or substantially more unit launches and higher prices in the next six months.

site_title: Archegos prepares for insolvency as banks seek compensation: FT
summary: Archegos Capital Management, a family office run by Bill Hwang, is preparing for insolvency after defaulting on a margin call triggered by a ViacomCBS stock offering slump. Global banks, including Credit Suisse, Nomura Holdings, and Morgan Stanley, lost nearly $10 billion from the Archegos fallout. The fund's assets were around $10 billion, but it held positions worth over $50 billion. Banks are seeking compensation and may issue "letters of demand" before launching legal claims. Regulatory repercussions are expected, with the Securities and Exchange Commission and Federal Reserve under scrutiny.

site_title: Solskjaer says Man Utd fans' protest went 'too far'
summary: Manchester United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer described the anti-Glazer protest that forced the postponement of the team's match against Liverpool as "too far" after 200 fans invaded the pitch and clashed with police. Solskjaer reiterated his call for fans' voices to be heard, but emphasized the need for protests to be peaceful. He also stated that the team's focus should be on the football, while owners Joel Glazer has apologized for the Super League debacle. The match against Liverpool will be rescheduled, and United will face Roma in the Europa League semi-finals.

site_title: US Fed officials continue playing down risk of higher inflation
summary: US Federal Reserve officials have downplayed the risk of higher inflation despite unprecedented government spending in response to the pandemic. Chicago Fed President Charles Evans and Fed Governor Michelle Bowman stated that the risk of inflation running above 2% is "remote." The Fed has held interest rates near zero and will continue buying bonds at a pace of $120 billion per month until the economy reaches full employment and inflation goals. Projections show inflation remaining at or slightly above 2% for the next three years, with the unemployment rate declining to 3.5% by the end of 2023.

site_title: Kuala Lumpur restricts movements to stem Malaysia Covid rise
summary: Malaysia has imposed a movement control order in Kuala Lumpur to stem the rise in new Covid-19 infections, restricting movements from May 7 to May 20. The order follows similar curbs in Selangor and other states, where six districts will be under the first-tier MCO for 12 days. The country is struggling with a surge in cases, with daily infections topping 3,000 for the first time since February, and a slow vaccination programme, with only 2% of the population fully vaccinated.

site_title: Trump Facebook ban remains but oversight board rips company policies
summary: Facebook's oversight board upheld the suspension of former US president Donald Trump, but criticized the company's indefinite suspension as "inappropriate". The board gave Facebook six months to determine a "proportionate response" that aligns with its rules for other users. The decision aims to establish clear standards for handling rule-breaking world leaders on the platform.

site_title: Philippines LNG facilities are risky play for investors: report
summary: The Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis (IEEFA) warns that investing in liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities in the Philippines comes with significant risks, including regulatory and financial uncertainty. Despite officials' endorsement of rapid LNG development, the country has a history of incomplete LNG import projects. IEEFA energy finance analyst Sam Reynolds notes that LNG demand growth and investment returns are not guaranteed, and investors should carefully consider these risks before making a decision.

site_title: Sabana Reit's investment head quits after less than two years
summary: Sabana Reit's investment head, Siow Meow Cheng, has resigned after less than two years, effective June 12. Cheng, 49, left her position as head of investment and asset management in October 2019. The CEO, Han Yong Lee, stated there are no material differences in opinion between Cheng and the board, nor any unresolved matters related to her departure. The news did not impact Sabana Reit's shares, which closed flat at S$0.42 on the day of the announcement.

site_title: Dairy Farm's Q1 overall business performance hurt by ongoing Covid-19 pandemic
summary: Dairy Farm International reported a decline in its overall business performance for the first quarter of 2021, significantly affected by the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. Like-for-like sales for its grocery retail businesses dipped compared to the same period last year, and profitability took a hit due to lower sales. However, the group remains encouraged by its transformation progress, with underlying profitability surpassing 2019 levels. Its convenience business reported improved sales, while its health and beauty businesses suffered due to reduced footfall in malls.

site_title: Philippines' Monde Nissin gets investor commitments for US$1b IPO: sources
summary: Philippine food maker Monde Nissin Corp has secured investor commitments for a US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO) at 13.50 pesos (S$0.38) each, marking the country's largest IPO on record. The IPO, which includes an overallotment option, aims to raise 55.89 billion pesos. Monde Nissin, the owner of Quorn meat alternative, is banking on growing demand for consumer staples and higher-value products. More than a dozen cornerstone investors, including major asset managers, are backing the IPO, which will be the Philippines' biggest IPO of 2021.

site_title: Thai central bank leaves rate at record low, warns of Covid-19 risk
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, left its key interest rate unchanged at a record low of 0.50% for an eighth straight meeting, preserving limited ammunition to support the country's economy. The decision was made amid a third wave of coronavirus infections, which has slowed domestic activity. The central bank warned that economic growth is likely to sharply slow due to the outbreak, but stated that monetary policy will remain accommodative to support economic activity. The decision was expected by economists, who had forecast the bank to remain on hold.

site_title: Uncertainty lingers over Covid-19 impact on Hongkong Land's full-year financials
summary: Hongkong Land, a Jardines-backed property group, remains uncertain about the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on its full-year financials. Despite reporting resilience in its investment portfolio and improving market conditions in Singapore and mainland China, the group attributed a decline in contracted sales in Singapore to sales launch timing. Rental reversions were negative in Hong Kong and Singapore, but are expected to turn positive in Singapore by end-June. The group's financial position remains strong, with net debt at US$4.2 billion and committed liquidity flat at US$4.3 billion.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Wednesday, down 12.58 points to 1,575.67, with volume reaching 7.360 billion lots worth RM4.239 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 811 to 298.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust's diversified tenant base lends resilience, says manager
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust (MIT) remains resilient despite the challenging operating environment due to its large and diversified tenant base. The trust has over 2,000 tenants across 115 properties in six property segments, ensuring it's not overly dependent on any single tenant or trade sector. MIT's strong balance sheet and interest coverage ratio of 6.4 times also support its stability. The trust recently acquired a data centre in the US and redevelopment of the Kolam Ayer 2 Cluster is on track for completion in 2022.

site_title: Trust is key to realising vaccine multilateralism, says EDB chairman
summary: Singapore's Economic Development Board chairman Dr Beh Swan Gin emphasizes the need for trust and partnerships to realize vaccine multilateralism in the fight against Covid-19. He praises Singapore and Switzerland's collaboration on the Covax facility, which has enabled low-income economies to access vaccines earlier. Dr Beh notes that trust is crucial for countries to work together for the common good, but has been undermined by populist politics and weakened multilateral institutions. The 50th St Gallen Symposium, held in Singapore, highlights the importance of trust in tackling global crises.

site_title: Singapore shares fall for fourth day amid stricter Covid measures; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.8% on Wednesday, extending a losing streak for the fourth day, amid stricter Covid-19 measures announced by the government. The benchmark index closed at 3,153.59. Transport stocks, such as ComfortDelGro and SBS Transit, and retail Reit fell, while banks and travel-related stocks like Singapore Airlines also dropped. Analysts expect a near-term slowdown but not a sharp decline in economic activity due to the vaccination drive and improved testing capabilities.

site_title: US private payrolls increase solidly in April: ADP
summary: US private payrolls increased by 742,000 jobs in April, surpassing economists' expectations of 800,000. This growth suggests the economy is gaining momentum early in the second quarter, driven by government aid and rising vaccinations against Covid-19. Labour market conditions have improved, with new claims for unemployment benefits at a 13-month low. The economy is expected to experience double-digit GDP growth this quarter, positioning it for growth of at least 7%, the fastest since 1984.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS sees good value in Tuan Sing, raises target price
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "buy" call on Tuan Sing Holdings, raising its target price to S$0.54 from S$0.46. The brokerage cites improved office fundamentals, upcoming project launches, and potential IPO of Gultech (Jiangsu) Electronics as reasons for seeing good value in the stock. A stake sale in GJE by Tuan Sing's associated company Gultech China implies a valuation of about 3.35 billion yuan for the PCB firm, which could nearly double Tuan Sing's market capitalization.

images.alt_text: Tuan Sing's Opus Bay township project in Batam, Indonesia, will contain residential, retail, entertainment, and healthcare facilities.

site_title: Former Dow Jones CEO launches startup to tackle misinformation
summary: Former Dow Jones CEO Will Lewis is launching The News Movement, a startup to combat global misinformation. The company, backed by Lewis' seed funding, will deliver trustworthy information to mass audiences on social media. Lewis, along with former colleagues Ramin Beheshti and Eleanor Breen, will aim to create a content-monetization business model. The News Movement has plotted a proof-of-concept stage and is being incubated at the UK's ITN broadcast production company. Lewis, a former publisher at The Wall Street Journal and editor of the Daily Telegraph, is in early discussions with potential investors.

site_title: BRC Asia half-year net profit dips 15%, expects customers to be impacted by Covid-19 measures
summary: BRC Asia, a steel-reinforcement solutions provider, reported a 15% dip in half-year net profit to S$19.2 million due to lower operating profit margins. Revenue rose 7% to S$492.7 million, driven by a S$38.4 million gain from the sale of a property and higher steel prices. Excluding the property sale, revenue would have been comparable to the previous year.

site_title: UMS Holdings sticks to S$0.20-a-share price for JEP despite error in first offer document
summary: UMS Holdings has reaffirmed its S$0.20-a-share price for its mandatory unconditional cash offer of JEP Holdings, despite an error in the original offer document. The correction, attributed to an "inadvertent error", will not change the offer price, which remains the highest price UMS has dealt in during the six-month window. The deal values JEP at S$82.4 million. UMS shares fell 2.9% to S$1.35, while JEP shares ended flat at S$0.199, ahead of the views of JEP's independent directors and independent financial adviser on the offer.

images.alt_text: Andy Luong, founder of UMS Holdings. UMS had triggered a mandatory offer for shares in JEP in April, after it took its cumulative interest in JEP to 53.8 per cent.

site_title: Short-term profit-taking likely on pre-emptive Phase Two measures: analysts
summary: Analysts predict a short-term sell-off on the Singapore bourse as the country reinstates pre-emptive safety measures from May 8 to 30 amid rising Covid-19 cases. The Straits Times Index has hit a one-month low, and year-to-date performers like banks and travel-related stocks are likely to see a hit. Industrial Reits are expected to be less affected, while healthcare proxies such as Q&M Dental may benefit from increased testing. Investors are advised to adopt a balanced investment strategy, with some analysts recommending holding onto pandemic beneficiaries like supermarket plays and glove-sector stocks.

site_title: SF Holding to raise US$340m through listing of its Reit unit
summary: Chinese logistics giant SF Holding plans to raise US$340 million through a listing of its Reit unit, SF Reit, in Hong Kong. The IPO offers 520 million units at HK$4.68 to HK$5.16 each, with cornerstone investors State-owned China Orient Asset Management and CI Global Asset Management subscribing to US$25 million each. The proceeds will be used for acquisition of a predecessor group, transaction costs, and general corporate purposes, marking the first logistic Reit IPO in Hong Kong since 2019.

site_title: W Capital's Series A fundraising round from Thakral values firm at S$21 million
summary: W Capital Markets has completed its Series A fundraising round valued at S$21 million after Thakral Corp invested S$1.07 million, giving the firm a 5% stake. Founded by Wayne Lee in 2018, W Capital aims to become an international financial group with a presence in key financial centers. Thakral's investment is seen as strategically important for W Capital's expansion plans, while Thakral's CEO Inderbethal Singh Thakral believes the investment will deliver strong returns in the long term.

site_title: SIA Engineering seeking out investment opportunities abroad, likely to acquire control of JVs
summary: SIA Engineering is seeking investment opportunities abroad, potentially acquiring control of joint ventures. CEO Ng Chin Hwee stated this during an analyst call, citing SRT Technics Malaysia as an example. The company is conducting due diligence for a potential majority ownership and management takeover. This shift in strategy aims to expand SIA Engineering's global presence and increase its market share.

site_title: Australia's most populous state reports first Covid-19 case in more than a month
summary: Australia's New South Wales (NSW) state reported its first locally acquired Covid-19 case in over a month, with a man in his 50s testing positive in Sydney. The man visited several venues and is considered infectious since April 30. Close contacts have been told to self-isolate and get tested, raising concerns about the potential for social distancing restrictions to be reimposed. Authorities are working to trace the source of the infection and test for genetic links to other cases.

site_title: Hugo Boss sees China booming despite boycott call
summary: German fashion house Hugo Boss expects sales in mainland China to continue growing despite boycott calls launched in March over forced labor in Xinjiang. The company's first-quarter sales in mainland China almost doubled, and CEO Yves Mueller expects this momentum to continue. Despite at least three Chinese celebrities dropping Hugo Boss and internet users boycotting the brand, the company remains optimistic about its China sales.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower as consumer discretionary, tech shares weigh
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng index down 139.16 points or 0.49% at 28,417.98. Consumer discretionary and tech shares retreated ahead of China's market reopening, outweighing gains from banks and energy sectors. The Hang Seng China Enterprises index fell 0.41%. Key decliners included Tencent, Meituan, and Alibaba Group, while Hang Seng Bank was the top gainer.

site_title: Thailand records first case of Brazilian coronavirus variant in quarantine
summary: Thailand reported its first case of the Brazilian coronavirus variant in a state quarantine, according to the coronavirus taskforce. The individual was in quarantine, and the strain has not been detected in local communities, according to Apisamai Srirangsan. This marks the first detection of the Brazilian variant in Thailand.

site_title: Thai travel agencies offer Covid-19 'vaccine tours' to US
summary: Thai travel agencies are offering "vaccine tours" to the US, with packages ranging from $3,220 to $8,590, as wealthy Thais grow impatient for mass inoculations. The tours, which involve receiving a COVID-19 vaccine in the US, are available for trips to San Francisco, Los Angeles, and New York, with prices dependent on the time gap between doses. The tourism industry is seeking to capitalize on the growing demand for medical tourism, with agencies also offering similar trips to Serbia and Russia.

site_title: Myanmar's anti-junta unity government forms 'people's defence force'
summary: Myanmar's National Unity Government has formed a "people's defence force" to protect its supporters from military attacks and violence. The new force is a precursor to a Federal Union Army, aimed at making effective reforms in the security sector and terminating the 70-year civil war. The unity government, established last month, has pledged to end violence, restore democracy, and build a "federal democratic union." The move comes amid a surge of violence and daily protests since the military seized power on February 1, resulting in hundreds of civilian deaths.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark over 14-month closing high on mining, healthcare boost
summary: Australian shares reached their highest level in over 14 months, closing at 7,095.80, driven by commodity and healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.4% for the third consecutive session, despite weak overnight US session and comments from Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen on potential interest rate hikes. Investors largely shrugged off these concerns, instead focusing on the sector boost.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental warns of impending H1 underlying loss in interim business update
summary: Mandarin Oriental International has reported unaudited underlying losses of US$41 million for the first three months of the year, citing the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the hospitality industry. The company expects to finish the half-year in the red, with more losses in the second quarter. Despite this, the group's financial position remains robust, with US$536 million in net debt and US$150 million in cash reserves. The outlook for the second half of the year remains uncertain, with the restoration of viable operating conditions dependent on the roll-out of Covid-19 vaccines and travel curbs.

site_title: Retail sales recovery after March's 6.2% growth depends on Covid-19 measures: economists
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 6.2% year-on-year in March, driven by a low base effect from the previous year's Covid-19 restrictions. However, the recovery may be hindered by tightened Covid-19 measures in May, which could impact sales in discretionary categories like watches and jewellery, as well as food and beverage outlets. Economists predict that the sales trajectory will depend on the duration of the measures, with some expecting a temporary slowdown in May.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore retail sales rose 6.2% in March, surpassing February's 2.4% gain but falling short of economists' expectations. Local SMEs have improved beyond pre-pandemic levels, and OUE has established a joint venture to acquire a stake in Indonesian retailer Matahari. Prudential won a lawsuit against a former top agency manager over the poaching of 220 agents. Analysts expect short-term profit-taking on the Singapore bourse due to reinstated pre-emptive safety measures.

site_title: Indian minister to self-isolate at G-7 meeting of top diplomats
summary: Indian Foreign Minister Subrahmanyam Jaishankar will self-isolate at the G-7 meeting in London due to possible exposure to coronavirus. The event, which marks the G-7 debut of US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, risks being derailed. Jaishankar had met with UK Home Secretary Priti Patel and counterparts from the US, France, and other countries. The UK is taking precautions, but the situation remains uncertain, and the meeting's outcome is now in question.

site_title: Hyflux gets 7 bids in second stage of investor process
summary: Hyflux, a water-treatment company, has received seven bids in the second stage of its investor process, with one involving an investment of the entire company and another for the purchase of substantially all assets. Judicial managers are now in negotiations with the investors who submitted binding offers. Trading in Hyflux securities has been suspended since 2018, and the company had previously sued former suitor SM Investments over a $38.9 million deposit, which was settled without admission of liability. The judicial managers aim to determine if a potential restructuring is possible within the next 60 days.

site_title: UK new car sales recover in April from last year's lockdown hit
summary: British new car sales rebounded in April, posting a 30-fold increase from last year's lockdown-hit month of 4,321 vehicles. In contrast, April 2020 sales plummeted 97% due to the pandemic. Last month's sales stood at around 141,000 vehicles, still down 13% from the 2010-2019 average. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) will publish its final figure for April later.

site_title: Ikea to buy back unwanted UK furniture in fresh green push
summary: Ikea is offering to buy back unwanted UK furniture in exchange for a voucher, with the average price for returned items being £29. The retailer will pay 30-50% of the item's original value depending on its condition and will either resell or recycle the returned furniture. This move is part of Ikea's efforts to minimize waste and meet the demands of socially conscious consumers. The company aims to become a "fully circular and climate positive business" by 2030.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound after selloff, miners jump
summary: Europe's stocks rebounded 0.8% on Wednesday after a sharp selloff, driven by surging commodity prices and lifting mining stocks. The German DAX rose 0.9% and UK's FTSE 100 gained 0.6%, with big UK miners like Rio Tinto and BHP Group rising 2% on copper price increases. Tech stocks rose 1.4% after a 3.7% decline in the previous session, while Stellantis edged up 0.8% after reporting better-than-expected quarterly revenue.

site_title: BlackRock turns up heat on boards as AGM season gets going
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, voted against more company directors and backed more shareholder resolutions in the first quarter than a year ago, pushing boards to address climate and sustainability issues. The firm voted against 35% of shareholder meetings, up from 30%, and opposed 53 directors and 47 companies on climate issues. BlackRock's aggressive stance under its global head of investment stewardship reflects heightened expectations on urgent issues, with the firm backing 75% of environment and social-focused resolutions filed by shareholders.

site_title: Two office floors at Malacca Centre up for sale
summary: Two office floors at Malacca Centre in Singapore have been put up for public tender. The level 9 office spans 1,830 sq ft with an indicative price of S$6 million (S$3,278 psf), while the level 16 office has 2,142 sq ft and an indicative price of S$6.9 million (S$3,211 psf). The collective guide price is around S$12.9 million (S$3,242 psf). The offices are currently occupied and are expected to attract investors due to the tight office supply in the market.

site_title: Singapore steps up Covid-19 safety measures at pre-schools and early intervention centres
summary: Singapore has introduced stricter COVID-19 safety measures at pre-schools and early intervention centres, starting May 8, including a ban on all parents except those with newly enrolled children and suspending field trips and large group activities. The measures aim to slow viral transmission and include increased cleaning, temperature and health checks, and cohorting in centres. Exceptions will be made for certain programs and activities.

images.alt_text: There will be more entry restrictions at pre-schools and early intervention centres from Saturday (May 8), including a ban on all parents except those with newly enrolled children.

site_title: Federal Reserve's Kashkari says full US employment 'may take a few years'
summary: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari stated that full US employment may take a few years, despite plans to normalize monetary policy once the labor market is fully recovered and inflation returns to the Fed's target. Approximately 8 million Americans who were working at the start of the pandemic remain out of work.

images.alt_text: Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari on Tuesday said that while the Fed plans to normalise monetary policy once the labour market is fully recovered and inflation is back to the Fed's target, about 8 million Americans who were working at the start of the pandemic are still out of work.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 6.2% in March, improving from Feb but below expectations
summary: Singapore retail sales rose 6.2% year-over-year in March, beating February's 5.3% growth but falling short of economists' expectations of 7.1%. Online sales accounted for 11.8% of total sales. Excluding motor vehicles, sales rose 4.4% year-over-year. Discretionary categories such as watches and jewellery saw significant growth, while sales at supermarkets and department stores fell. Total food and beverage sales rose 8% year-over-year, driven by growth in restaurant sales.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales rose 6.2 per cent year on year in March, extending February's rise though falling short of economists' expectations of 7.1 per cent.

site_title: COE prices end mostly lower despite smaller quota
summary: Singapore's Certificates of Entitlement (COE) ended mostly lower in the latest tender, with COE for cars up to 1,600cc or 130bhp finishing at S$48,002, down from S$49,640 two weeks ago. COE for cars above 1,600cc or 130bhp closed at S$60,001, down from S$61,190. Open COE, which can be used for any vehicle type, ended at S$63,002, up from S$62,100. The decline is attributed to potential buyers being deterred by previous spikes.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing after Yellen spooks Wall Street, eyes on US jobs
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday after US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen suggested that US interest rates might need to be hiked to temper inflation, despite later clarifying her comments. The comments caused Wall Street to fall sharply, with tech firms more at risk from higher rates. Asian markets initially declined, but some bounced back as the morning wore on. Analysts expect the Federal Reserve to keep its policies accommodative for some time, with many believing the central bank will not tighten rates until the economy is well on track.

site_title: Gold prices edge higher as pullback in US dollar lifts appeal
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,781.14 per ounce, lifted by a decline in the US dollar, but gains were tempered by US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's comments that interest rates may need to rise. Gold prices fell 1% on Tuesday after Yellen downplayed concerns of inflation. Higher interest rates may reduce gold's appeal as it increases the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Investor focus shifts to April payrolls data for further cues on the US economy.

site_title: Japan considering state of emergency for Tokyo, other areas beyond May 11: media
summary: Japan's government is considering an extension of the state of emergency for Tokyo and other major urban areas beyond May 11, citing a surge in coronavirus infections. The emergency, which was initially set to end on May 11, would impact the Tokyo Olympics, which are just over three months away. Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga will discuss the extension with relevant cabinet ministers on May 5.

site_title: Australian regulator files insider trading lawsuit against Westpac
summary: Australia's corporate watchdog, ASIC, filed an insider trading lawsuit against Westpac Banking Corp, alleging the bank's traders bought and sold derivative products ahead of a US$12 billion interest rate swap deal in 2016. Westpac was informed it would likely be selected to execute the transaction, and the trades had the potential to negatively impact the price of the swap for a consortium. ASIC is seeking pecuniary penalties, without elaborating on financial details. Westpac has stated it is considering its position and takes the allegations seriously.

site_title: Australia drops plans to fast track tax cuts for wealthy: newspaper
summary: Australia's government has dropped plans to fast track tax cuts for wealthy individuals, instead extending tax cuts for low and middle-income earners for another year. The decision comes as the country's economy recovers more quickly than anticipated from the pandemic-led downturn. Tax relief for high-income earners is now scheduled for 2024, with the government having pledged A$17.8 billion in personal tax cuts in last year's budget to create one million new jobs over the next four years.

site_title: 16 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, one in the community
summary: Singapore reported 16 new Covid-19 cases, with one in the community, linked to a workplace cluster at Pasir Panjang Terminal. The cluster includes the tenth active cluster in the country. The new case, a 59-year-old trailer truck driver, developed symptoms on Sunday and was at home. The Ministry of Health is investigating the source of the cluster.

images.alt_text: The sole Covid-19 community case reported on Wednesday and three previously reported cases have been linked to their workplace at Pasir Panjang Terminal, forming the tenth active cluster here.

site_title: Indonesia's Q1 GDP shrank 0.74%, in line with expectations
summary: Indonesia's Q1 GDP shrank 0.74% from the same period last year, in line with expectations. This marks the fourth consecutive quarter of contraction, but at a slower pace than the 2.19% decline in Q4. The country's planning minister had forecast a 0.6-0.9% drop.
