On a quarterly basis, the economy contracted 0.96% from Q4. The data suggests Indonesia's economy is stabilizing, but still facing challenges.

site_title: India central bank gives small borrowers debt relief as Covid-19 cases spike
summary: India's central bank, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), has announced measures to provide debt relief to small borrowers and lenders struggling with bad loans. The RBI will offer one-time debt restructuring for loans taken by individuals and small and medium enterprises that did not restructure in 2020. The move aims to enhance liquidity and boost lending to needy sectors as the country faces a surge in Covid-19 cases. RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das said "small businesses and financial entities at the grassroot level are bearing the biggest brunt" of the second wave of infections.

site_title: Facebook's Workplace tool reaches 7 million paid subscribers
summary: Facebook's Workplace tool has reached 7 million paid subscribers, a 40% increase from the previous year. This growth is attributed to the shift towards remote work during the Covid-19 pandemic, fueling demand for enterprise connectivity platforms. Workplace, launched in 2016, has seen a significant increase in users, with Microsoft Teams reaching 145 million daily users, compared to 115 million in October.

site_title: Singapore SMEs performance and health have improved beyond pre-'circuit-breaker' levels: OCBC
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) have seen improved business performance and health in Q1 2021, surpassing pre-"circuit-breaker" levels. The OCBC quarterly SME index rose to 51.2, driven by a 5% year-on-year improvement in sales collections and a 4% year-on-year increase in payments. The healthcare and transport and storage sectors led the recovery, while the business services sector remains affected by pandemic restrictions. Despite this, the demand for loans is expected to remain positive, with businesses focusing on growth rather than exigency loans.

site_title: Cruises eye smoother waters with vaccines, 'health bubbles'
summary: Cruise ship companies are gradually resuming operations with stricter health protocols after a year-long shutdown due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Italian cruise line Costa Cruises and MSC France have set sail from ports in Italy and France, respectively, with passengers and crew tested for the virus and required to wear masks. Vaccination is not mandatory, but passengers who are "fully vaccinated" at least two weeks before departure can sail. Cruise lines in the US, UK, and other countries are also planning to resume operations with similar health measures, including vaccination requirements and restricted capacity.

site_title: OUE in joint venture to acquire controlling stake in Indonesian retailer Matahari
summary: OUE Limited has formed a joint venture with Auric Bespoke I to acquire up to a 40% stake in Indonesian retailer Matahari Department Store Tbk for 1,530 rupiah (S$0.14) per share. The acquisition will be funded by a S$95 million facility and shareholder loans of up to S$150 million. The joint venture, Auric Digital Retail, will own up to 50.12% of Matahari, becoming its controlling shareholder upon completion. OUE believes Matahari's assets and management can be revitalized with a new strategy, and the acquisition will expand its consumer division into Indonesia's growth market.

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners lift shares; tech stocks track Wall Street peers lower
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,080.80, led by miners and banks, while tech stocks lagged behind Wall Street peers due to overnight losses. The gains were capped by losses in tech companies.

site_title: Yellen clarifies inflation remark, sees no need for Federal Reserve to hike
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen clarified her previous comments on inflation, stating she doesn't foresee interest-rate hikes to combat inflation spurred by President Biden's proposed spending. She emphasized the Federal Reserve's independence and said the central bank has tools to deal with inflation if it occurs. Yellen expressed her independence and confidence in the Fed's ability to manage the economy.

site_title: New Zealand PM Ardern plans summer wedding
summary: New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern plans to get married during the summer season, which typically runs from December to February in the southern hemisphere. Ardern, 40, and her partner Clarke Gayford, 44, have a two-year-old daughter and were engaged in 2019. The wedding date has not been disclosed, and Ardern joked about not feeling old enough to have a bridal party.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks dropped 0.45% to 28,427.67 on Wednesday, following a negative lead from Wall Street, amid concerns of rising US interest rates. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's comments suggested inflation may push up rates. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at open on Phase 2 reversion; STI down 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.8% at the open on Wednesday due to the government's tighter Covid-19 restrictions and a weak Wall Street performance. The Straits Times Index (STI) slipped to 3,154.26 as index counters and real estate investment trusts (Reits) declined. The Dow Jones edged up, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index closed lower. Asian markets were closed for a public holiday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.63 points to 1,588.88. The market saw 288.32 million lots traded worth RM135.80 million, with 221 gainers surpassing losers 181-0. The market reaction to the US and EU trade talks and new Trump threats is being observed, but no significant impact was noted.

site_title: Tokyo, China, South Korea: Markets closed for holiday on Wednesday
summary: Financial markets in Japan, South Korea, and mainland China are closed on Wednesday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have reached a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while Asia's traders are brushing off new Trump threats to extend their stocks rally. In Europe, mining and healthcare stocks are propelling shares upward, with US-EU trade talks in focus. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq have also reached fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views, with Airalo raising US$220 million in new funding and lifting its valuation to over US$1 billion.

site_title: Wall Street eyes return to normalcy as virus fears recede
summary: Wall Street is moving towards normalcy as the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) lifts some Covid-19 restrictions, allowing additional personnel on the trading floor, including media representatives, to resume in-office work. Goldman Sachs has set a date of June 14 for staff to return to downtown New York, following a week after JPMorgan Chase announced similar plans. New York Governor Andrew Cuomo has also lifted major coronavirus restrictions, allowing businesses to welcome as many people as they want with six feet of social distancing.

site_title: Hong Kong is now a renters' market as prices drop on expat moves
summary: Hong Kong's rental market has shifted to a buyer's market, with prices dropping to their lowest since 2016. Rents in the first quarter fell to HK$33.60 (S$5.77) per square foot, down from US$4,200 two years ago. The decline is attributed to a decrease in expatriate moves due to anti-government protests, a shrinking population, and higher unemployment. Despite this, home prices remain resilient, with selling prices dropping by less than 4% from their peak in mid-2019.

images.alt_text: There's rarely been a better time to be apartment hunting in Hong Kong than right now.

site_title: Ascendas Reit private placement 2.6 times subscribed at S$2.944
summary: Ascendas Reit's private placement of 142.7 million new units to raise S$420 million was 2.6 times subscribed. The placement priced at S$2.944 per unit, a 5.2% discount to the previous day's volume-weighted average price. This represents the lower end of the indicative range of S$2.944 to S$3.019.

site_title: GE shareholders reject CEO Culp's US$230m pay in rare rebuke
summary: General Electric (GE) shareholders overwhelmingly rejected CEO Larry Culp's compensation package, worth up to $230 million, in a rare rebuke of a major corporation's executive pay. The vote, which was non-binding, follows GE's layoff of 20,000 workers last year. The move is seen as a step towards corporate governance reform, as it comes after several other S&P 500 companies were rejected by shareholders over executive pay this year.

site_title: ANZ lifts dividend as profit doubles from Covid-19 slump
summary: ANZ Banking Group reported a 109% increase in first-half cash profit to A$2.99 billion, more than doubling from the previous year. The bank released A$491 million, a sharp rebound from the A$1.67 billion charge taken last year. ANZ raised its interim dividend to 70 Australian cents per share, up from 25 Australian cents last year, as the country's economic recovery and controlled pandemic fueled an economic boost. The bank's CET1 ratio rose to 12.4% and chief executive officer Shayne Elliott said the extra capital would be used to return to shareholders.

site_title: Prize winner? Welcome to Britain with relaxed visa requirements
summary: The UK's interior ministry announced that prize winners, including Nobel Prize, Oscar, and Golden Globe winners, will have their applications for work visas fast-tracked from Wednesday. This move is part of the government's post-Brexit pledge to attract the "best and brightest" to the country. The new system, which is based on points, aims to create a fair treatment of migrants from around the world. The changes will allow winners to make a single visa application, rather than undergoing an endorsement process, and will be applied to the Global Talent visa route.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says financial system vulnerabilities remain
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) stated that New Zealand has weathered the COVID-19 pandemic better than anticipated, but financial vulnerabilities persist. The bank attributed this to successful public health measures and monetary and fiscal policy support. However, it warned of potential risks from an inflated housing market, citing high debt-to-income and loan-to-value ratios. The RBNZ is prepared to tighten lending conditions if necessary and will monitor market conditions. New capital rules for banks will be implemented from October 1, 2021.

site_title: AIMS APAC Reit posts 45% rise in Q4 DPU to 2.9 S cents
summary: AIMS APAC Reit reported a 45% increase in Q4 DPU to 2.9 Singapore cents, driven by contributions from a recently acquired property and higher rental and recoveries. Gross revenue rose 16.1% to S$32.8 million, while net property income increased by S$3.5 million to S$24 million. The Reit's portfolio occupancy rose to 95.4%, and it executed 37 new and renewal leases representing 14% of total net lettable area. The company expects high occupancy to be sustained due to demand for logistics and warehouse facilities.

site_title: Nissan to sell entire Daimler stake for 1.15b euros
summary: Nissan has announced the sale of its 1.54% stake in German auto giant Daimler for approximately 1.15 billion euros, aiming to strengthen business competitiveness and invest in electrification. This move follows Renault's similar sale of its stake in Daimler. The divestment is part of Nissan's efforts to become profitable again after the departure of former leader Carlos Ghosn.

site_title: Krispy Kreme eyes new dough with confidential IPO filing
summary: Krispy Kreme has confidentially filed for an initial public offering (IPO) with US regulators, marking the doughnut chain's return to the stock market five years after being taken private. The move comes as companies tap into a historic boom in US capital markets, with a record $167 billion raised in 2020. Krispy Kreme, known for its glazed sugary treats, has 1,400 shops in 33 countries and operates in 12,000 grocery and convenience stores in the US. The IPO could help the company capitalize on rising demand for snacks and sweets during the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: US pressing Taiwanese firms on semiconductors, Commerce chief says
summary: US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said the country is pressuring Taiwanese semiconductor manufacturers, particularly TSMC, to allocate some of their supply to American automakers amid a global shortage of crucial components. The shortage has led to production cuts and warned of hits to output for Detroit automakers, including Ford, which will cut its second-quarter production by half. Raimondo emphasized the need for the US to reduce its reliance on foreign suppliers, particularly those in China, and to increase domestic production of industrial components.

site_title: Pfizer sees Covid-19 as 'durable' revenue stream as profits rise
summary: Pfizer sharply increased its 2021 profit projections, citing strong Covid-19 vaccine sales that are expected to provide a "durable" revenue stream. The company reported a 45% jump in profits and 45% increase in revenues, with nearly a quarter of sales coming from Covid-19 vaccines. Pfizer is ramping up vaccine production and is studying the efficacy of booster shots, with plans to provide doses to underserved countries through 2024. However, critics have raised concerns about the company's profits, citing a "shocking imbalance" in vaccine distribution and calls for governments to step in to ensure access to vaccines for all.

site_title: US interest rates may have to rise if economy heats up: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen suggests that interest rates may rise "somewhat" to control inflation if the economy heats up due to President Biden's spending proposals. The proposals, totaling nearly $4 trillion over a decade, aim to revamp the US economy after the pandemic. Yellen clarifies she's not predicting or suggesting rate hikes, but acknowledges the possibility of modest increases. She emphasizes the need for the investments to be competitive and productive, and believes the Federal Reserve can address inflation if it arises.

site_title: US dollar firms as risk appetite ebbs
summary: The US dollar strengthened as investors reduced risk appetite, awaiting upcoming data and policy speeches. Major stock indices remained stable, while bond yields slightly increased, bolstering the dollar's safe-haven appeal. This move partially reversed a month-long decline in the dollar.

site_title: Oil climbs nearly 2% as travel seen rising
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Tuesday as more US states eased lockdowns and the European Union sought to attract travelers. The US crude inventories fell more than expected, according to American Petroleum Institute estimates, contributing to the price increase. Brent crude futures rose to $69.36 a barrel, driven by post-settlement trade. However, soaring Covid-19 cases in India capped gains.

site_title: US: Tech stocks hammered after Yellen rate comment
summary: US tech stocks plummeted in trading on Tuesday after Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned that higher lending rates could be coming, potentially ending the current rally in the sector. The economy is recovering, but the Federal Reserve is not expected to lift rates until at least 2024. Yellen's comments, which were seen as cautioning against a rate hike, led to a decline in tech stocks.

site_title: Europe: Shares dragged down by tech's worst day since October
summary: European shares declined 1.4% on Tuesday, with the technology sector experiencing its worst day since October, due to profit-taking and a sell-off on high-performing stocks. The tech-heavy Nasdaq slipped 2% and Germany's bourse fell 2.5% due to its tech-heavy composition. Despite a positive earnings season, with 73% of Stoxx 600 companies beating profit expectations, some analysts attribute the drop to a "nervous" positioning.

site_title: Why you should pay attention to China's semiconductor industry
summary: China's semiconductor industry is poised for supercharged growth due to rising domestic demand and extensive state support. Despite being a significant player in electronics manufacturing, China has struggled to produce its own chips, with limited technological capabilities. The country aims to achieve 70% self-sufficiency in semiconductor production by 2025, with supportive government policies, including a national fund and tax incentives. This growth potential makes China's semiconductor industry an attractive investment opportunity, with companies like SMIC and the Global X China Semiconductor ETF worth considering.

site_title: Industry, trade and investment to boost Vietnam's strong growth: ADB
summary: Vietnam is expected to see strong growth of 6.7% in 2021 and 7.0% in 2022, driven by export-oriented manufacturing, increased investment, and expanding trade. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) attributes the growth to the country's success in controlling the virus spread and ongoing reforms to improve the business environment. However, significant risks remain, including the emergence of new coronavirus variants and a delay in the government's vaccination plan, which could impact the country's ability to return to its pre-pandemic growth path.

site_title: Manhattan's office space leasing falls in April
summary: Manhattan office space leasing rose to an all-time high in April with 16.5% availability, a 11th consecutive month increase. Despite a 27% lower demand compared to last year, rental prices continued to fall. This marks a renter's market, as availability above 10% is considered a favorable condition for tenants.

site_title: Bill and Melinda Gates to divorce with US$146b at stake
summary: Bill Gates and Melinda Gates, co-founders of the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, announced their decision to divorce after 27 years of marriage. The couple, worth an estimated $146 billion, emphasized their commitment to continuing their philanthropy, with no changes planned to their roles or the foundation's operations. They will remain co-chairs and trustees, working together to shape and approve foundation strategies. The divorce comes after Jeff Bezos and MacKenzie Scott's split in 2019, and the couple's financial plans remain unclear, with concerns about how their wealth will be divided.

site_title: Space aged: wine matured aboard ISS expected to sell for US$1m
summary: A bottle of Petrus 2000 wine, aged for 14 months aboard the International Space Station, is up for private sale with an expected price of US$1 million, making it the most expensive wine ever sold. The wine was part of a research project by Space Cargo Unlimited, which sent 12 bottles into orbit to study how food and drink matures in space. Tests found the wine had "remarkable differences" in color, aroma, and taste, and is considered a great wine. Proceeds will fund future space missions focused on agricultural research.

site_title: AEM is latest tech play to miss analysts' earnings expectations
summary: AEM Holdings, a technology-related stock, has missed analysts' earnings expectations in Q1, with net profit down 63.1% and revenue down 45.4%. The company's shares fell 7.9% after the earnings report, amid a global chip shortage affecting the sector. Analysts have cut their revenue and net profit estimates for AEM, citing the sector's challenges and the company's conservative guidance.

site_title: Restaurants may see spate of cancellations with tighter cap on social gatherings
summary: Singapore's restaurants anticipate cancellations ahead of Mother's Day due to a tightened cap on social gatherings from 8 to 5 people from May 4 to 30. To mitigate this, eateries are offering takeaways and discounts. Some retailers have also seen a drop in foot traffic following the government's call for reduced social interactions. The Restaurant Association of Singapore expects revenue losses, while retailers are understanding the need for stricter measures to control community infections and flatten the curve.

site_title: Biden says 'hope and expectation' for Putin meeting in June
summary: US President Joe Biden expressed hope and expectation for a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin in June during a trip to Europe. A summit has not been confirmed, but planning is underway, with Austria and Finland expressing interest in hosting. The meeting comes amid rising tensions over Ukraine, cyber attacks, and the 2020 presidential election. The Biden administration aims to bring stability to the relationship and cooperate on key areas like nuclear weapons and the climate crisis, despite recent expulsions of Russian diplomats.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden said Tuesday he expects to hold a summit with his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin during a June trip to Europe.

site_title: Reverting to Phase 2 'unlikely to derail Singapore's recovery'
summary: Singapore's Covid-19 taskforce has implemented stricter measures, including reduced social gatherings and activity sizes, to slow the spread of the virus. Economists and business associations, such as the Singapore Business Federation, express support for the measures, believing they will have a limited impact on the recovery. The measures are expected to be manageable for businesses, particularly those with the ability to work from home. The recovery momentum is expected to continue, with some economists predicting positive second-quarter growth, despite the setback.

site_title: Stocks to watch: AA Reit, Ascendas Reit, OUE, StarHub, OUE C-Reit, First Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported new developments that may impact trading. AA Reit boosted its Q4 2021 distribution per unit to 2.9 Singapore cents, while OUE Reit acquired a 75% stake in a business park for S$534.4 million. StarHub reported a 1.6% drop in first-quarter net property income. First Reit's Q1 DPU fell to 0.65 Singapore cents. Cheung Woh Technologies requested a trading halt. The Reits' units ended trading with varying changes, ranging from 0.7% to 3.8%. The companies' shares will continue to be watched for further developments.

site_title: Legal issues with remote working in the post-pandemic era
summary: Remote working has become a permanent feature of working life, with employers and employees considering a global workforce. However, implementing remote working poses several key legal issues, including employment and visa issues, restricted industries, and employment laws. Employers must obtain relevant work permits, register in the country, and comply with local laws and regulations. Tax implications also need to be considered, as foreign-based employees may create foreign tax exposure for the company. Employers must properly review remote working arrangements to avoid falling foul of country legislation and unwanted tax consequences.

site_title: Three Seas Region - shared history, and shared future
summary: The Three Seas Region, comprising 12 countries between the Baltic, Black, and Adriatic seas, has significant potential, accounting for 30% of the European Union's area, 25% of its population, and 20% of its GDP. Despite being linked by history and geography, the region has outstripped Western countries in many aspects. The Three Seas Initiative, a unique integration project, aims to tap into this potential, benefiting the entire European Union by promoting intra-regional integration and reducing reliance on external networks.

site_title: Yellow and black gold trends
summary: Gold prices have retreated 19% from highs near US$2,089 to lows around US$1,690, while oil prices have risen 62% from a low of US$40 to current levels around US$65. However, both commodities' uptrends are showing signs of potential change, with gold facing resistance and oil's long-term rise capped by a recent stumble. The trend behavior suggests a shift away from complacency and towards a potential trend change for both gold and oil.

site_title: Indonesia sets up new ministry to make country more investor-friendly
summary: Indonesia establishes a new Ministry of Investment to boost economic growth and attract foreign and domestic direct investments. The ministry, led by Minister of Investment Bahlil Lahadalia, aims to simplify licensing procedures, rationalize laws and regulations, and promote investments from small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The move comes as the country struggles with low investor confidence due to excessive red tape and a stagnant ranking in the World Bank's Ease of Doing Business (EODB) rankings. The government hopes the new ministry will help achieve its goal of boosting GDP growth and improving the country's investment climate.

site_title: Australia's central bank lifts outlook, plans to review bond programmes
summary: Australia's central bank, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), has upgraded its economic outlook, expecting 4.75% GDP growth this year and 3.5% over 2022, with unemployment expected to decline to around 5% by the end of the year. The RBA will review its bond programmes in July and maintain interest rates at emergency levels until at least 2024. Governor Philip Lowe emphasized the need for a return to full employment and inflation, despite subdued inflation pressures.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to buy remaining 75% stake in Galaxis for S$534m
summary: Ascendas Reit has agreed to buy the remaining 75% stake in Galaxis, a business park at one-north in Singapore, for approximately S$534.4 million. The acquisition will increase the Reit's business and science park portfolio by 18% to S$4.9 billion and provide better operational and tax efficiency. The deal has a net property income yield of 5.3% post transaction costs and is expected to improve the Reit's distribution per unit by 0.4% in the first year. The acquisition is subject to unitholders' approval at an extraordinary general meeting.

site_title: Hyflux gets six final offers with one covering retail investors: source
summary: Singaporean water-treatment company Hyflux has received six final offers, including one restructuring bid that considers retail investors, after missing its April 30 target for binding term sheets. The restructuring bid, the only one involving retail investors, is for the company's perpetual securities and preference shares. Hyflux, which has around 34,000 individual investors, is running out of money and has just enough cash to survive five months. The bids are from overseas companies, including some that expressed interest before Hyflux's judicial manager took control.

site_title: India's Covid calamity: It should consider a hard national lockdown
summary: India is grappling with a massive spike in Covid-19 cases, with over 400,000 new cases daily and a total caseload of 20.3 million. The government has resisted calls for a nationwide lockdown, instead allowing states to implement customized restrictions. However, experts argue that a hard lockdown is necessary to curb the virus spread. The government must ensure provisions are made for families and migrant workers affected by the crisis, and a temporary shutdown should be implemented to stem the spread. A coordinated national effort is needed to address the crisis, which has already claimed over 222,000 fatalities.

site_title: SIAEC in the black for H2, but posts full-year loss
summary: SIA Engineering Company (SIAEC) posted a net loss of S$11.2 million for the 12 months ending March 31, despite staying in the black for the second half of its financial year due to government wage subsidies. Revenue fell 55.4% to S$443.0 million, and earnings per share decreased to 0.69 cents from 9.48 cents previously. The company attributed the loss to the severe impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on flight activities and will continue reviewing and rationalizing its portfolio to pursue new opportunities for expansion.

site_title: It may be mission possible for Biden's Bigger is Better
summary: US President Joe Biden's proposed ambitious social-economic agenda, dubbed "Bigger is Better," aims to shift the government's central role in determining the nation's well-being and charting its destiny. The plan involves trillions of dollars in spending on healthcare, childcare, education, infrastructure, climate change, and industrial policy. However, it faces strong opposition from Republicans and some centrist Democrats, who argue that it may not be feasible due to economic realities and potential inflation concerns. Biden's success in implementing this plan is uncertain, and some experts suggest that promoting necessary and gradual reforms could be a more effective approach.

site_title: Frustration erupts over slow pace of seafarer's vaccinations
summary: Seafarers' vaccinations against Covid-19 face significant delays due to bureaucratic hurdles. The International Maritime Organisation (IMO) and shipping bodies have been criticized for their slow pace in addressing the issue, with over 1.5 million seafarers worldwide still at risk. InterManager, a ship-management company association, has decided to work separately to obtain vaccines, citing the lack of progress in international efforts. Despite efforts by the IMO and other organizations, widespread vaccination for seafarers remains unlikely this year, and the crew-change crisis continues to affect the global shipping industry.

site_title: Clearer rules on B2B events welcomed; could tamp down rising anxiety
summary: Singapore has revised its COVID-19 guidelines, allowing B2B events to host up to 100 people without pre-event testing and 250 with testing. The move aims to prevent clusters and anxiety, with most upcoming events opting for hybrid or virtual formats. Event organizers welcome the changes, citing the need for caution, and express confidence in their ability to control human traffic and prevent outbreaks. The revised guidelines are seen as a necessary step to tackle the ongoing pandemic, with many industry players urging caution and urging the public to stay the course.

site_title: Sony strikes deal to get Discord app onto PlayStations next year
summary: Sony has invested in Discord, aiming to bring the popular social app onto its PlayStations early next year, connecting over 140 million gamers. The partnership will integrate Discord with PlayStation Network, enhancing the console's appeal. This move seeks to edge Sony against rival consoles, particularly Microsoft's Xbox. Discord, with 140 million monthly active users, has rejected a $12 billion takeover from Microsoft and is exploring a potential public listing.

site_title: Asia's energy transition needs to pick up pace
summary: Asia's energy transition is crucial for global climate change mitigation, but the region's pace has been insufficient to curb emissions. Asia's heavy reliance on thermal coal, with Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines showing an uptrend, must be phased out. Renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, are on the rise, with installations tripling in the region between 2010 and 2019. Hydrogen and energy efficiency also hold potential as low-carbon fuel options. The region has made progress in reducing energy intensity, but more work is needed to strengthen policy frameworks and measures for energy efficiency, particularly in buildings and utilities.

site_title: Saudi Aramco follows Big Oil rivals with bumper Q1 earnings
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 24% year-on-year increase in adjusted net income to 78.6 billion riyals (S$28 billion) in the first quarter, driven by a recovery in global oil and gas markets. The company maintained its quarterly payout of US$18.75 billion, which funds the Saudi Arabian government's budget. Despite a 31% gain in Brent crude to over US$68 a barrel, free cash flow remained low, covering only a portion of the dividend. Aramco expects capital expenditure of US$35 billion in 2021.

site_title: Gym, hotel and tour operators say they'll take the hit in their stride
summary: Singapore has announced a slew of tightened community measures to combat rising Covid-19 numbers, including closing indoor gyms and fitness studios from May 8-30. Industry leaders, however, are puzzled by the decision, citing low infection rates among gym-goers. The measures are expected to impact the tourism and hospitality industries, with tour operators and hotels bracing for reduced group sizes and potential cancellations. Despite concerns, some operators are taking proactive steps to adapt, such as offering free online training and reducing capacity.

site_title: What are your rights as an investor?
summary: Investors in Singapore have limited rights, unlike consumers, according to the CFA Institute's Statement of Investor Rights. The rights include honesty, independent and objective advice, prioritizing investors' interests, fair treatment, and avoiding pressure or rushed decisions. However, a 2020 survey by CFA Institute found that only 49% of Singaporean investors believe their financial adviser puts their interest first, compared to the 15-market average of 82%. The survey also highlighted the need for retail investors to improve their financial literacy to better understand and compare different financial products.

site_title: StarHub Q1 net profit down by 24% to S$30.5 million
summary: StarHub reported a 24% year-on-year decline in Q1 net profit to S$30.5 million, driven by lower service Ebitda and losses in its enterprise units. Revenue fell 3.8% to S$487.1 million, mainly due to the consumer mobile business and fewer security projects. The company attributed a 20.8% drop in consumer mobile service revenue to intense competition. Despite a decline in subscribers, broadband service revenue grew 12.6%.

site_title: Blackstone bets on Asia amid housing boom
summary: Blackstone Group expects demand for residential apartments to be resilient in some parts of Asia, particularly in major cities like Australia, China, and Japan, as millennials opt to rent instead of buy due to high property prices. The firm is focusing on multi-family residential properties and commercial opportunities linked to the technology, logistics, and life-sciences sectors in Asia. Blackstone has invested heavily in commercial properties in India and has completed several high-profile deals in China and Singapore.

site_title: Sterling dips ahead of BOE meeting, Scottish elections
summary: Sterling dropped 0.3% against the dollar ahead of Thursday's Bank of England meeting and the Scottish parliamentary elections. Analysts expect the BOE to consider tapering its bond purchases, and some see a potential decision as a market focus. The Scottish National Party is expected to win a majority, which may lead to another independence referendum. Despite this, experts believe the impact on sterling may be limited due to the referendum's potential delay and the 2014 referendum's lack of material impact on the pound.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust has upsized its multi-currency debt scheme to S$2 billion, doubling the maximum principal that could earlier be issued. Frasers Centrepoint Trust has appointed liquidators for an inactive subsidiary, with no expected impact on its net tangible assets or distributions. Falcon Energy Group has requested extensions for its scheme meetings, while OKP Holdings has purchased two freehold conservation shophouses for S$12.38 million. These developments follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Ascendas Reit to buy remaining 75% stake in Galaxis for S$534m
summary: Ascendas Reit is acquiring the remaining 75% stake in Galaxis, a business park at one-north, for approximately S$534.4 million. This includes acquisition fees, stamp duty, and other expenses, totaling S$543.8 million. The acquisition is expected to yield a 5.3% net property income post-transaction costs, improving the distribution per unit (DPU) by 0.4% for FY20.

site_title: OUE C-Reit's Q1 net property income dips due to rental rebates
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 1.6% drop in Q1 net property income to S$61.1 million due to rental rebates to retail tenants. Revenue fell 3.9% to S$74.7 million, and lower property operating expenses boosted the amount available for distribution by 2.7%. The Reit's hospitality segment generated S$16.9 million in revenue, with net property income increasing 3% year-over-year. OUE C-Reit also announced the divestment of a 50% interest in OUE Bayfront, with proceeds to be used to redeem convertible preferred units and share gains with unitholders.

site_title: BOE weighs when to taper its stimulus as UK economy rebounds
summary: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee is expected to discuss easing its stimulus measures as the UK economy rebounds from the pandemic. Despite maintaining its £150 billion bond purchase target for this year, officials may slow the pace of buying to stretch the program to the end of the year, rather than ending it in November. This move could be influenced by the UK's economic recovery and global economic trends.

site_title: Back on track
summary: The global economy is expected to recover, driven by vaccine roll-out and fiscal stimulus, according to recent developments. The US Treasury 10-year yield has risen to 1.6% and equities are experiencing a broadening rally, shifting from growth sectors to value sectors. Investors are advised to employ a buy-write strategy to enhance income as the economy moves from "A New Hope" to "Back on Track".

site_title: Pfizer bets on Covid-19 vaccine demand for years, sees sales of US$26b in 2021
summary: Pfizer raises its 2021 Covid-19 vaccine sales forecast by over 70% to $26 billion, driven by demand from governments worldwide. The company expects to sell over 1.6 billion doses this year, with revenue accounting for more than one-third of its full-year sales. Pfizer aims to produce up to 2.5 billion doses this year and plans to manufacture at least 3 billion doses next year. The vaccine's sales could be more than 50% above projections if all doses are sold at similar prices.

site_title: Spotify urged to rule out 'invasive' voice recognition tech
summary: A coalition of over 180 artists and human rights groups urged Spotify to rule out the use of a speech recognition tool that analyzes users' speech and background noise to suggest tracks based on their mood, gender, age, accent, or surroundings, labeling it as "creepy" and "invasive". Spotify has never implemented the tool and claims not to plan to do so, but critics argue it raises significant privacy concerns and could exacerbate existing disparities in the music industry. The group, including musicians Tom Morello and Talib Kweli, called for a public commitment to never use the technology.

site_title: Goldman readies June return to office, Vanguard goes hybrid
summary: Goldman Sachs plans to have US employees return to offices by June 14 and UK employees by June 21, following a similar timeline set by JPMorgan Chase & Co. CEO Jamie Dimon. Vanguard Group will adopt a hybrid model, allowing most staff to work remotely on Mondays and Fridays. The move is driven by an expanding vaccination drive and a desire to return to pre-pandemic routines. Many employees may resist the shift, with 80% of financial services executives preferring a mix of in-office and remote work.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as rotation out of megacaps weighs
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday as investors shifted out of megacap growth stocks and into companies benefiting from economic reopening. The Dow Jones fell 0.10%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.32%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.87%. This rotation out of megacaps comes as economies reopen and investors seek more stable gains.

site_title: Keppel commits S$3m to Garden City Fund
summary: Keppel Corporation has committed S$3 million to the Garden City Fund to support the planting of 10,000 trees in Singapore over the next five years. The trees will be planted at various parks and nature reserves, including the Labrador Nature Reserve, to enhance existing green spaces and promote a "city in nature". National Development Minister Desmond Lee attended an event marking the start of Keppel's pledge, where 50 coastal forest trees were planted. The goal is to mitigate the effects of climate change and urbanization, protect biodiversity, and create a greener Singapore for future generations.

site_title: World's biggest economies bet vaccine passports can save tourism
summary: The world's top economies have agreed to support vaccine passports to revive the tourism industry, crucial for global economic recovery. The Group of 20 tourism ministers endorsed the Digital Green Certificate, which will show vaccination, immunity, or recent negative testing. EU Commissioner Thierry Breton committed to accelerating the certificate's introduction. Tourism ministers emphasized the sector's key role in recovery, with travel and tourism contributing 49% less to global output in 2020, causing 62 million job losses. Reopening borders with low infection rates and vaccination requirements is expected to start as soon as May.

site_title: EU targets China with new powers over state-backed firms
summary: The European Union is proposing new powers to control Chinese state-backed firms in Europe, targeting those seeking to acquire European companies worth 500 million euros or more. The regulation aims to strengthen EU control over Chinese inroads into Europe's economy, amid concerns over Beijing's increasing authoritarianism. The proposal also includes state aid investigations and could open probes of companies enjoying illicit subsidies. The move is seen as a response to China's growing influence in Europe, while maintaining a delicate balance in EU-China relations.

site_title: Can Sembcorp Marine reinvent itself as a green champion?
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singaporean offshore and marine company, faces a grim outlook for 2021, with analysts estimating slow recovery from three consecutive years of losses. However, the company's shares have gained significantly since its separation from Sembcorp Industries, driven by its potential in the green-energy space. Recent contracts, including a £600 million deal for the UK-based Sofia Offshore Wind Farm, have boosted its momentum. With a patient shareholder in Temasek Holdings, Sembmarine may be able to reposition itself as a green champion, but a merger with Keppel's offshore and marine business could be a near-term catalyst.

site_title: Rockefeller's Fleming sees US taxes rising on the corporate 'honeypot'
summary: Greg Fleming, head of Rockefeller Capital Management, predicts US corporations will face a significant tax increase, from 21% to 28%, under President Joe Biden's proposed tax overhaul, amounting to $1 trillion. This would be a primary target for tax revenue. Fleming advises clients to be patient, as the impact of the tax changes is uncertain and other factors, such as estate tax and cryptocurrency regulations, will also be considered.

site_title: First Reit DPU falls 65.1% to 0.65 S cent after new rights units issued
summary: FIRST Real Estate Investment Trust (First Reit) saw its first-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fall 65.1% to 0.65 Singapore cent due to the issuance of over 791 million new rights units. The DPU would have decreased by 31.7% to 1.27 cents without the new unit issuance. The company's distributable income and net property income decreased by 30.5% and 33.9% year-over-year, respectively. First Reit issued new units as part of a S$158.2 million fund-raising exercise to repay syndicated loan facilities.

site_title: OUE Commercial Reit's Q1 net property income dips due to rental rebates
summary: OUE Commercial Reit (OUE C-Reit) reported a 1.6% drop in Q1 net property income to S$61.1 million due to rental rebates to retail tenants. Revenue fell 3.9% to S$74.7 million, and the Reit's aggregate leverage was 40.4%. The Reit also announced the divestment of 50% of OUE Bayfront, generating S$262.6 million in proceeds, with S$155 million to redeem convertible preferred units and S$15 million for unitholder share distribution.

site_title: Football: Roma appoint Mourinho as manager starting next season
summary: AS Roma has appointed former Tottenham Hotspur manager Jose Mourinho as their new head coach, starting the 2021-22 season on a three-year contract. Mourinho replaces Paulo Fonseca, who left the club at the end of the current campaign. The Portuguese manager aims to guide Roma to Champions League places, and Roma's hierarchy hopes he can bring his winning mentality to boost the club's ambitious project. Mourinho, a former Porto and Inter Milan manager, joins as one of only five managers to lift the Champions League with two different clubs.

site_title: Infineon points finger at contract partners over chip shortages
summary: German chipmaker Infineon blames contract partners for chip shortages, citing lack of investment in new capacity. Despite this, Infineon raised its forecast for sales and profit margins due to a surge in demand following the pandemic. The company expects supply constraints to ease in the second half of the year, with lost volumes only likely to be made up in 2022. Infineon's shares declined after a winter storm knocked out its plant in Austin, Texas, exerting pressure on profit margins.

site_title: US and Chinese trade experts among the WTO chief's new deputies
summary: The World Trade Organization (WTO) has appointed four new deputy directors-general, including US trade expert Angela Ellard and Chinese vice-trade minister Zhang Xiangchen, as part of a delicate geopolitical balancing act. This move maintains a balance between two fractious powers while achieving gender balance for the first time in the organization's history. Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, the first woman and African at the WTO helm, expressed her commitment to strengthening the organization with talented leaders. The US and Chinese appointments could provide a channel for trade discussions between the two countries.

site_title: Twitter acquires news startup Scroll in push for subscriptions
summary: Twitter has acquired news startup Scroll, aiming to launch a subscription service featuring long-form content, including audio and news articles from publishers such as Insider and USA Today. The acquisition allows users to subscribe without ads, earning publishers more revenue than traditional advertising. This move follows Twitter's previous acquisition of newsletter platform Revue, and is part of the company's efforts to diversify its content offerings and attract new revenue streams.

site_title: Palladium extends record run on supply shortfall
summary: Palladium prices surge to a record high of US$3,017.18 per ounce, driven by supply concerns and a shortage of the metal used in emissions-controlling devices for automobiles. Prices have jumped 21% since mid-March, with some analysts predicting further gains. However, some experts warn that the metal may be at risk of a price correction if it fails to hold above the US$3,000 mark. Meanwhile, gold prices retreat due to a stronger dollar, while silver and platinum also see fluctuations in the market.

site_title: Singapore extends travel-history tracking, stay-home notice period to 21 days for higher-risk arrivals
summary: Singapore is tightening its border and quarantine measures for travelers from higher-risk countries or regions, requiring a 21-day stay-home notice (SHN) for those with travel history in the past 21 consecutive days. This change, effective May 7, applies to all countries or regions deemed "higher risk," except for Australia, Brunei, mainland China, New Zealand, Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macao. The move aims to minimize transmission risk and follows a tightening of community measures.

site_title: S&P Dow Jones Indices launches cryptocurrency indices
summary: The S&P Dow Jones Indices has launched three cryptocurrency indices, including the S&P Bitcoin Index, S&P Ethereum Index, and S&P Crypto Mega Cap Index, measuring the performance of bitcoin, ethereum, and digital assets. The move was announced in December 2020, and the indices will use data from New York-based virtual currency company Lukka. The new index series is expected to expand to include additional coins later this year.

site_title: Singapore shares fall for third consecutive day; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.2% on Tuesday, marking the third consecutive day of decline, amid ongoing Covid-19 fears. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,179.13. Dairy Farm International was the top gainer, rising 1.9%. The decline follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with investors weighing tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Ericsson to launch subscription service for remote office
summary: Ericsson launches a subscription service for remote office work in North America, offering small businesses access to licensed apps, cloud storage, and security tools. The service, available for around $100 per employee per month, allows businesses to activate workers in minutes without needing a dedicated IT technician. Ericsson has partnered with companies such as Microsoft and Telarus to offer the platform, which is expected to face competition from smaller companies offering remote desktop products. The US market for virtual workspaces is estimated to be around $90 billion.

site_title: Singapore Exchange website back up after evening outage
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) experienced a Web services outage on Tuesday evening, approximately 4 hours before the market close, due to a domain name system (DNS) issue. The outage affected the exchange's website, but not trading systems. SGX attributed the issue to a DNS problem and stated that there was no indication of a cyber attack or malicious cause. The website was restored at 8:40 pm, and users were advised to visit brokers' websites or alternative sources for price information until full restoration was complete.

site_title: Malaysia to place six Selangor districts under first-tier MCO
summary: Malaysia will impose the first-tier movement curbs on six districts in densely populated Selangor state for 12 days starting Thursday. The curbs ban the "balik kampung" exodus and home visits for those outside the state, but allow relaxed home visits for those staying in the same state. Defence Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob denied widespread lockdowns despite surging Covid-19 figures. The decision aims to curb infections without imposing a full lockdown.

site_title: Hyflux gets six final offers with one covering retail investors: source
summary: Singaporean water-treatment company Hyflux has received six final offers, including one to restructure the entire firm, after missing its April 30 target for finalizing binding term sheets. The restructuring bid considers retail investors' losses, with approximately 34,000 individual investors affected. The remaining five bids are for specific assets, with some attracting no interest. Hyflux has enough cash to survive five months, but its creditors and investors are awaiting a bidder to avoid further financial strain.

site_title: UK banks slammed over 'hollow' climate stance on coal
summary: UK's largest banks, including Barclays, HSBC, and Standard Chartered, have been criticized for their "hollow" climate stance on coal, providing $56 billion in funding to coal firms over two years. The British government aims to hit net-zero carbon emissions by 2050, but banks must back up their zero-carbon ambitions with concrete measures, including an end to coal finance. The banks have made some commitments, but Reclaim Finance argues that their pledges are insufficient, urging UK regulators to push for a renewed effort to get UK financiers out of coal.

site_title: UK and India agree to £1 billion bilateral trade and investment deal
summary: The UK and India have agreed on a £1 billion bilateral trade and investment deal, paving the way for a future free trade agreement. The deal includes £533 million of new Indian investment in the UK, creating over 6,000 jobs, and lowers non-tariff barriers on fruit and medical devices. Other agreements include a £240 million Serum Institute investment in vaccine business, 1,000 new jobs at Infosys, and £446 million in new export deals. Negotiations for a full free trade deal are set to begin in the autumn, with the UK seeking to lower or remove India's tariffs on imported cars and whisky.

site_title: Space startup Firefly raises US$75m, studies public listing
summary: Firefly Aerospace, a US-New Zealand space startup, has raised US$75 million in private capital, bringing its total funding to US$400 million. The company aims to become a multibillion-dollar company by the end of 2021 with milestones including a static fire test and a possible first space flight. Firefly is exploring a public listing through a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC) or a traditional IPO. The company is working on a reusable spacecraft, a lunar lander, and a compact satellite launch system.

site_title: StarHub Q1 net profit down by 24% to S$30.5 million
summary: StarHub's Q1 net profit fell 24% to S$30.5 million, driven by lower service Ebitda and losses in its enterprise units. Consumer mobile service revenue dropped 20.8% due to intense competition, while pay-TV income contracted 4%. However, broadband service revenue grew 12.6% and the company reported free cash flow of S$97.4 million. Despite this, the net debt-to-Ebitda ratio improved to 1.29 times, and the board reaffirmed its full-year payout guidance of S$0.05 per share.

site_title: P&G to work with 27 Asia startups on industry challenges
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) has partnered with 27 Asia-based startups to explore innovative solutions for advertising, retail, and supply chain challenges. The collaboration, called iLab, will roll out pilots across the Asia-Pacific, Middle East, and Africa regions. Selected startups will work with P&G to address industry challenges and leverage Singapore's strong innovation ecosystem. The partnership aims to drive digital transformation and power innovation across P&G's business, with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat highlighting the importance of innovation in Singapore's economic transformation.

site_title: Britain will announce travel 'green list' shortly: minister
summary: Britain is set to announce its "green list" of countries for quarantine-free travel on the UK, with trade minister Liz Truss stating it will be published shortly. The list will determine which countries are safe for travel, with procedures in place to ensure safe travel. This announcement comes after the European Union recommended easing restrictions for fully vaccinated or low-risk countries. The move is expected to boost travel stocks and bookings, with UK travel companies reporting a 50% increase in bookings for summer trips.

site_title: US trade deficit hits a record high amid pent-up demand
summary: The US trade deficit reached a record high of $74.4 billion in March, driven by pent-up demand fueled by the White House's pandemic relief package and the expansion of the Covid-19 vaccination program. Imports soared 6.3% to a record $274.5 billion, with goods imports reaching a record high, while exports surged 6.6% to $200.0 billion. The trade gap is expected to widen further as the US economy rebounds faster than its global rivals.

images.alt_text: The US trade deficit jumped to a record high in March amid roaring domestic demand, which is drawing in imports, and the gap could widen further as the nation's economic activity rebounds faster than its global rivals.

site_title: Singapore's Acronis doubles valuation to US$2.5b after funding round; eyes exit in 3 years
summary: Singapore-based cybersecurity firm Acronis has more than doubled its valuation to over US$2.5 billion after securing a US$250 million funding round led by CVC Capital Partners VII. The company, founded by Serguei Beloussov, is now considering an initial public offering within the next three years to provide liquidity for investors. Beloussov stated that the company will evaluate all options, including listing in North America, where it is currently the largest market. The funding round follows a previous US$147 million round led by Goldman Sachs in 2019, valuing the company at over US$1 billion.

site_title: SIA Engineering Co H2 net profit sinks 92.7% to S$7.8m
summary: SIA Engineering Co reported a net loss of S$7.8 million for the first half of its financial year, down 92.7% from the previous year. Despite paring staff and costs, the company managed to stay in the black due to government wage subsidies. Revenue fell 54.3% to S$220 million. The company attributed the loss to the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and the subsequent decline in demand for its maintenance and repair services.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's financial sector plans to add 6,500 jobs in 2021, but faces a "large mismatch" between demand and supply of technology workers. A JLL report found that older properties in the Asia-Pacific region hold $40 billion in untapped value. Crisis-hit water-treatment company Hyflux received six final offers, including one to restructure the firm. Ride-hailing startup Gojek launched a taxi booking feature and began ESG reporting ahead of an expected listing. Singapore shares fell for the third consecutive day due to Covid-19 fears.

site_title: Zara unveils cosmetics line in push into beauty products
summary: Zara, a Spanish clothing retailer, has launched a new cosmetics line called Zara Beauty, available in refillable containers for eyes, lips, face, and nails. The products will initially be sold in European, North American, and Asian stores, with a gradual rollout elsewhere. This move follows a trend set by luxury retailers such as Burberry, and joins other fast-fashion competitors like Hennes & Mauritz, Asos, and Boohoo Group, which already sell cosmetics.

site_title: China's new flash point with US allies is a hotspot for spying
summary: China is increasing its military presence in the Yellow Sea, near the disputed island of Baengnyeong, which has long been a key location for US allies in Seoul to spy on North Korea. China's warship passed a self-imposed boundary near the island in December, prompting South Korea's Navy to respond with a battleship. The move is part of China's efforts to expand its maritime influence and secure a path for its fleets to exit the Pacific Ocean. Tensions between China and South Korea have risen, with residents on the island calling for increased action to deter Chinese fishing boats.

site_title: Gojek launches taxi booking feature, starts ESG reporting ahead of expected listing
summary: Gojek has launched GoTaxi, a dedicated taxi booking feature on its app in Singapore, allowing users to book taxis via the app and pay a metered fare. The feature is set to launch next week, providing benefits to both riders and drivers. This move comes ahead of Gojek's expected listing.

site_title: Emirates expects to fly 70% of normal capacity by winter, CCO says
summary: Emirates plans to operate around 70% of its normal capacity this winter, up from current 120 destinations, due to easing coronavirus restrictions and reopened borders. The airline, which currently operates 151 Boeing 777s, expects to increase Airbus A380 flights to 30-40 over the summer. The restoration of capacity largely depends on countries easing restrictions and permitting international travel, with Dubai's Emirates lacking a domestic market to cushion against border closures.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.48 points to 1,588.25. The market saw 7.455 billion lots traded worth RM4.129 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 529 to 524.

site_title: Singapore returns to tighter Covid-19 curbs on gatherings, workplaces, gyms
summary: Singapore tightens Covid-19 curbs from May 8 to May 30, reducing group sizes to five from eight, lowering workplace capacity to 50% from 75%, and closing indoor gyms. The measures aim to mitigate the risk of further transmission due to the increased transmissibility of new virus variants. The government also brings forward the implementation of TraceTogether-only SafeEntry from June 1 to May 17. The tightened curbs include restrictions on events, weddings, funerals, and mass-participation sports events.

site_title: How are banks building tech talent in Singapore?
summary: Singapore's financial sector is facing a shortage of tech talent, with banks expecting 2,500 to 3,500 new tech roles annually. To address this, banks are implementing various strategies, including building innovation labs, providing training and development programs, and encouraging cross-pollination of talent between Singapore and other countries. Citi is building an equities hub in Singapore and looks for mid-career hires with adjacent skills, while DBS is experimenting with artificial intelligence and machine learning. JPMorgan actively leverages Singapore's junior talent and runs apprenticeship and rotational re-entry programs.

site_title: Hong Kong: Energy leads stocks higher on pandemic recovery signs
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.7% on Tuesday, led by energy stocks as signs of pandemic recovery emerged globally. The Hang Seng index closed at 28,557.14, snapping a two-session decline. Energy stocks led the gains, while mining and healthcare sectors also contributed to the rally.

site_title: 17 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, five are linked to TTSH cluster
summary: Singapore reported 17 new Covid-19 cases on May 4, bringing the total to 61,252, with five linked to the Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) cluster, now totaling 40 cases. Five community cases were also reported, linked to the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) officer cluster. The number of new cases has increased to 60 in the past week, with 10 unlinked cases in the community.

site_title: Sony to integrate Discord chat app into PlayStation
summary: Sony has invested in Discord, the popular chat app with over 140 million monthly users, and plans to integrate it into the PlayStation starting early next year. The goal is to bring Discord and PlayStation experiences closer together, allowing users to communicate and play games together more easily. This move follows reports that Discord had terminated talks with Microsoft and other companies had expressed interest in partnering with the service. Details of the deal, including its value, will be shared in the coming months.

site_title: KPMG appointed judicial manager for Envy group of companies
summary: KPMG has been appointed by Singapore's High Court as the interim judicial manager for companies Envy Global Trading and Envy Asset Management, amid an alleged bogus nickel trading scheme. The scheme, led by former managing director Ng Yu Zhi, is believed to have raised at least S$1 billion from investors. Ng has been charged with cheating and fraud, and the companies have not been accused of wrongdoing. KPMG will conduct an inquiry into the companies' affairs and prepare a report for the Court within four weeks.

site_title: Standard Chartered executes its first ESG-linked derivative
summary: Standard Chartered has priced its first ESG-linked derivative with Trafigura, combining conventional derivatives risk management with sustainability-linked KPIs to reduce greenhouse emissions and promote sustainable sourcing. The transaction offers a premium or discount to Trafigura based on fulfilling pre-agreed ESG KPIs, which are independently monitored and reported. This move reflects Standard Chartered's commitment to supporting clients in achieving sustainability goals through ESG-linked derivatives, a solution that provides capital to help clients reduce their environmental impact.

site_title: Saudi Aramco beats quarterly profit forecast, maintains dividend
summary: Saudi Aramco reported a 30% increase in first-quarter net profit to $21.7 billion, beating forecasts, and maintained its dividend payout. The strong oil prices, driven by a global surplus of crude and recovering fuel demand, contributed to the earnings boost. The company also announced plans to spend $35 billion on capital expenditures in 2021. Aramco's CEO, Amin Nasser, expressed optimism about the energy demand outlook for 2021, citing the Opec+ group's plan to ease output cuts and the kingdom's efforts to diversify its economy.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end five-day losing streak; heavyweights lead gains
summary: South Korean stocks ended a five-day losing streak, rising 20.17 points or 0.64% to 3,147.37. Heavyweights such as Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix, LG Chem, and Hyundai Motor led gains, with increases of 1.10%, 0.38%, 1.43%, and 2.52%, respectively. The market recovery was driven by concerns over stock short-selling resumption worries. The benchmark bond yield also rose, while the won appreciated.

site_title: Vietnam's VinFast reports customer to police after 'untrue' YouTube complaints
summary: Vietnamese car maker VinFast has reported a customer, YouTuber Tran Van Hoang, to the police over comments he made about the quality of his VinFast Lux A2.0 car, which the company deemed "untrue" and affected its reputation. The police have received VinFast's complaint and scheduled a meeting with Hoang. VinFast plans to launch electric vehicles in the US next year and has also considered a possible $60 billion share sale. The incident is VinFast's first report to authorities to protect its reputation and customers.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS expects near-term weaknesses for Reits with tightening of Covid-19 measures
summary: DBS Group Research predicts near-term weaknesses for Reits (Real Estate Investment Trusts) due to tightened Covid-19 measures, particularly for those focused on discretionary trades like SPH Reit and Starhill Global Reit. However, analysts expect stocks not to revisit March 2020 lows, citing better preparedness from the government and minimal financial impact on landlords. Reits with more exposure to discretionary trades are expected to experience more volatility.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines says travel demand to stay weak until 2023
summary: Malaysia Airlines forecasts weak air travel demand until 2023, with a full recovery expected after the end of the year. The airline has cut over 1,500 jobs and plans to reduce capacity further as part of its restructuring. Malaysia Airlines aims to break even in 2023 and have 83 aircraft by 2025, transforming into a global travel group. The aviation industry may consolidate amid travel curbs and targeted lockdowns to combat Covid-19 infections.

site_title: Europe: Mining, travel stocks lift shares on recovery bets
summary: European stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by gains in mining, travel, and energy sectors. The UK's FTSE 100 led the gain, up 0.8%, following speculation of a green list for holiday travel. The travel and leisure sector's 1.3% gain was the largest in Europe.

site_title: London's feisty mayor fighting for second term
summary: London Mayor Sadiq Khan is running for re-election, aiming to secure a second term as the city's leader. A former human rights lawyer and Labour party member, Khan has risen from humble roots to become a vocal critic of Brexit and successive Conservative prime ministers, including Boris Johnson. He has a strong track record, including being the first Muslim mayor of a Western capital and championing affordable homes and jobs. Khan's campaign focuses on tackling the pandemic, Brexit fallout, and the crisis in London's financial sector, with many predicting he could run for Downing Street in the future.

site_title: India coronavirus cases top 20 million as US, Europe ease curbs
summary: India's coronavirus cases surpassed 20 million on Tuesday, with over 350,000 new cases reported, as the country struggles to contain the outbreak. In contrast, the US and Europe are easing curbs, with the European Union considering allowing vaccinated foreign tourists. Wealthier nations have implemented rapid immunization programs, leading to a decline in new cases. Meanwhile, the World Health Organization (WHO) urged rich countries to increase funding for vaccines in poorer nations, citing global inequality in access to Covid-19 supplies.

site_title: US car rental firm Avis Budget tops revenue estimates as demand recovers
summary: US car rental firm Avis Budget Group Inc reported higher-than-estimated revenue for its first quarter, driven by recovering demand after the COVID-19 pandemic. The company's revenue per day increased 12% in the Americas, with a 14% fall in revenue from its largest market. Despite a net loss of $170 million, Avis Budget beat estimates and aims to increase fleet utilization efficiency. The company has realigned its fleet and now focuses on leisure customers, with new car deliveries every day.

site_title: Boris Johnson predicts lockdown ending June 21 as he seeks votes
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson predicts the end of coronavirus lockdown rules in England by June 21, allowing people to stay overnight with friends or relations and reopening indoor hospitality from May 17. He also warns of careful monitoring of international travel to avoid reimporting the virus. Johnson is on the campaign trail ahead of key elections in England, Wales, and Scotland, where the outcome could impact governance and the prospect of a new Scottish independence referendum.

site_title: Chipmaker TSMC eyeing expansion of planned Arizona plant: sources
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co Ltd (TSMC) plans to build up to six 12-inch wafer fabrication plants in Arizona, US, in addition to the one currently planned, according to three sources familiar with the matter. The expansion is reportedly in response to a request from the US, and TSMC has already acquired land for the initial plant. The company aims to start volume production in 2024 with a 20,000 wafer per month 5-nanometer technology. TSMC's planned investment in the US exceeds its initial $12 billion factory, with the company aiming to invest $100 billion over the next three years.

site_title: Duterte says China a benefactor, rejects rude comments
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte stated that China remains a benefactor, despite tensions in the disputed South China Sea. The country is negotiating for monthly vaccine deliveries from China and Russia, aiming to double inoculations to 2 million persons this month. Duterte rejected rude comments towards China, emphasizing the importance of maintaining good relations. The government aims to contain the spread of more contagious variants through strong border control and quarantine protocols.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte said China remains a benefactor, as the Southeast Asian nation seeks to increase vaccine delivery from the mainland amid brewing tensions in disputed waters.

site_title: Not a god: Taiwan defends health minister amid uptick in Covid cases
summary: Taiwan's health minister, Chen Shih-chung, has faced criticism amid a cluster of 26 Covid-19 infections linked to a hotel at Taoyuan airport. Premier Su Tseng-chang defended the minister, saying even a god could not protect against every eventuality. Taiwan has kept the pandemic under control due to early and effective prevention measures, including border closures. The government is reviewing procedures to tighten controls, and hospital cases remain extremely small with only 75 people being treated. Taiwan has reported 12 deaths and is considering banning people who had been in badly-affected India.

site_title: Temasek-backed Oxford Nanopore valued at £2.48b ahead of IPO
summary: Oxford Nanopore, backed by Temasek, has been valued at £2.48 billion ahead of its planned initial public offering later this year. The company raised £195 million in new investment from Singapore's Temasek, Wellington Management, M&G Investments, and Nikon. Existing investors also contributed £70 million. Oxford Nanopore is expected to list on the London stock market in the second half of the year, following the appointment of banks to manage the process.

site_title: India crisis reveals complacency and lack of foresight: Rajan
summary: India is facing its worst COVID-19 outbreak, with record deaths and over 350,000 new cases daily, prompting calls for strict lockdowns to stem the spread. Former Reserve Bank of India Governor Raghuram Rajan blames complacency and a lack of foresight for the crisis, citing India's relative success against the first wave of infections and slow vaccine rollout. Rajan also warns of potential market volatility and a possible rethink by the US Federal Reserve due to a massive fiscal stimulus program and economic recovery.

site_title: Carbon copy? Pandora takes a shine to lab-made diamonds
summary: Pandora, a Danish jewellery maker, announced it will stop selling mined diamonds and focus on lab-grown gems, citing sustainability and affordability. The company aims to "transform the market for diamond jewellery" with its new collection of man-made stones. Lab-grown diamonds are now up to 10 times cheaper than mined diamonds, attracting millennials who prioritize cheaper, conflict-free options. Pandora's new collection will be launched in the UK and other key markets next year, with the company expecting lab-grown diamond sales to outpace overall growth.

site_title: Singapore's financial sector to create 6,500 roles in 2021
summary: Singapore's financial sector plans to create 6,500 jobs in 2021, with a significant portion (4,800) in non-tech roles such as relationship management and product sales. However, a "large mismatch" between demand and supply of technology workers means the industry will continue to rely on foreign tech talent, with 44% of new roles open to mid-careerists with adjacent or no experience. The sector's reliance on foreign tech talent is expected to persist due to a shortage of local tech skills, with 70% of net job growth in cybersecurity engineers and UX/UI designers going to Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Singapore's financial sector has plans to add 6,500 jobs this year, but the "large mismatch" between demand and supply of technology workers means the industry will continue to depend on foreign tech talent over the next few years, said MAS managing director Ravi Menon.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as traders eye US jobs data
summary: Asia's equity markets were mixed on Tuesday, awaiting US jobs data. Despite a positive lead from the Dow and S&P 500, Tokyo and mainland China's bourses were closed for holidays. A top Federal Reserve official reaffirmed the bank's ultra-loose monetary policy, predicting the US economy will grow at its quickest pace since the 1980s.

site_title: Australia sees remote chance of jail for India travel ban offenders
summary: Australia Prime Minister Scott Morrison has said it's "highly unlikely" travelers from Covid-ravaged India will face the maximum penalties of 5 years jail and a $66,000 fine for breaking border rules. The ban, in place until May 15, aims to prevent the virus from returning. Critics, including former Australia cricket player Michael Slater, have lambasted the government for the travel ban, while the Australian Human Rights Commission is set to approach the government with concerns. Repatriation flights from India may resume as planned, with the government looking to double quarantine capacity by mid-month.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.25 points to 1,591.98. The index saw 248 gainers out of 199 losers. Volume was 352.25 million lots worth RM184.97 million.

site_title: CLP's EnergyAustralia to expand gas-fired power plant with state support
summary: EnergyAustralia, a unit of CLP Holdings, has secured state and federal support to expand its gas-fired Tallawarra power station in New South Wales, Australia, with a $300 million investment. The plant, which will also utilize hydrogen, aims to address a power supply gap after AGL Energy shuts its Liddell coal-fired plant in 2023. The expansion, set to begin in 2025, will provide 300 megawatts of power and support the green hydrogen industry, with EnergyAustralia committing to buy 200,000 kilograms of green hydrogen annually.

site_title: Hong Kong leader flags 'fake news' laws as worries over media freedom grow
summary: Hong Kong leader Carrie Lam announced plans to introduce "fake news" legislation to tackle misinformation and lies, amid growing concerns over media freedoms in the city. The move comes as the government has taken a swift authoritarian turn following the imposition of a national security law in 2020. The government is researching the legislation, with no timetable set, as public broadcaster RTHK faces criticism and censorship, including the non-renewal of journalist contracts and removal of archives. The move has sparked worries over the erosion of media freedom in Hong Kong.

site_title: Samsung windfall gives richest Korean woman US$7b fortune
summary: Hong Ra-hee, the wife of late Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-hee, has inherited about 83 million shares in Samsung Electronics Co., boosting her fortune to over $7 billion. As the largest individual shareholder with a 2.3% stake, Hong is now the richest woman in South Korea. The inheritance comes after her husband's massive wealth transfer, with her son Jay Y Lee now worth $12.6 billion and her sisters Boo-jin and Seo-hyun worth $5 billion and $4.4 billion, respectively. The transfer ensures Jay Y Lee's stable control over the conglomerate while increasing his siblings' stakes.

site_title: E-commerce service valued at US$235m targets US IPO
summary: Singapore-based e-commerce service provider SCI Ecommerce has raised over S$50 million, valuing it at US$235 million, ahead of a potential Nasdaq listing. The company plans to expand in South-east Asia, set up local teams in Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines, and hire at least 100 people. SCI aims to become the No 1 e-commerce solution provider in South-east Asia, combining Shopify and Baozun's services. The startup, backed by Alibaba's earliest employees, plans a primary listing in New York with a target market valuation of US$1 billion.

site_title: Commodities reach new highs on rosy oil-demand outlook
summary: Commodities prices reached new highs due to a rosier outlook for oil demand, a weaker dollar, and investor appetite for precious metals. The Bloomberg Commodity Spot Index rose 0.7% and has not been at these levels since 2012. Oil prices climbed after the EU proposed easing travel restrictions, potentially boosting fuel demand globally. The world may reach 100 million barrels of crude oil per day by the end of 2021, according to Enterprise Products Partners, with demand for hydrocarbons expected to reach all-time highs next year.

site_title: Hot stock: AEM down as much as 6.9% after Q1 earnings plunge
