summary: AEM's shares plummeted 6.9% after the electronics services provider reported a 63.1% year-on-year decline in Q1 earnings to S$13.3 million. Revenue fell 45.4% to S$80.2 million, with the group now expecting revenue of S$460-520 million for FY2021. Analysts flag concerns over conservative management and seasonality, but some remain optimistic about a strong recovery in the second half of the year.

site_title: Myanmar parcel bomb blasts kill five including ousted lawmaker
summary: Blasts from parcel bombs in Myanmar have killed five people, including an ousted lawmaker and three police officers who joined a civil disobedience movement. The attacks occurred in a village in Western Bago, targeting residential areas. This is the latest in a series of small blasts in Myanmar since the elected government was overthrown in February. The blasts are believed to be linked to the civil disobedience movement opposing military rule.

site_title: Fidelity slashes Ant valuation after China's tech crackdown
summary: Fidelity Investments has slashed its valuation estimate for Ant Group to about $144 billion, down from $295 billion, following China's regulatory crackdown on the fintech giant. The move follows other global fund managers in cutting estimates for Ant's worth. The company's future and valuation remain uncertain amid a fintech industry overhaul and the departure of its CEO, Simon Hu. Ant's IPO was halted in November, and the company has committed to revamping its business.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH and CGS-CIMB maintain 'hold' on Sembmarine, raise TPs
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and CGS-CIMB have maintained a "hold" rating on Sembmarine, raising their target prices to 18 cents and 22.6 cents respectively. The shipyard company expects net losses due to pandemic and labor shortages, but has operated at peak capacity in Q1. Its order book is at S$1.89 billion, with potential earnings from new renewable energy projects. The analysts praise Sembmarine's efforts in the renewables sector and its pivot towards greener solutions, but note potential challenges in competing with Chinese and South Korean counterparts.

site_title: Malaysia GDP poised for 5.6% rebound in 2021 despite Covid-19 wave: AMRO
summary: Malaysia's GDP is forecasted to rebound 5.6% in 2021 and 6.2% in 2022, despite a renewed Covid-19 wave, according to the Asean+3 Macroeconomic Research Office (AMRO). The strong rebound is driven by the external sector, with targeted lockdowns continuing to dampen growth. Malaysia's banking system is seen as resilient to increased credit risks, with strong capital buffers. AMRO advises restoring fiscal buffers through tax reforms to lower the fiscal deficit.

site_title: 5Qs with Bayer on the trend of self-care
summary: Bayer's region head, Alvin So, discusses the trend of self-care in health and wellness in ASEAN, where 80% of respondents in Malaysia, Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam seek more access to self-care solutions and government support. Governments and medical communities agree that self-care can address the impact of Covid-19 and promote sustainable health systems. However, underserved communities are being left out due to limited access to health education and nutrition. Bayer's "Nutrient Gap Initiative" aims to reach 50 million people in underserved communities by 2030 through partnerships with NGOs. The company also scaled up its digital business capabilities to expand consumer access to self-care solutions, running successful digital campaigns and launching online products.

site_title: Wealth and philanthropy of Bill and Melinda Gates
summary: Bill Gates, the world's fourth-richest person with a net worth of $130.5 billion, is divorcing his wife Melinda after 27 years of marriage. The couple established the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation in 2000, which has donated over $36 billion to public health, education, and climate change initiatives. The foundation's assets, including a custom mansion valued at $130.8 million, will be divided in the divorce. The couple's wealth and philanthropic activities will be subject to complex decisions in the coming months.

site_title: US to authorise Pfizer vaccine for age 12 and up: report
summary: The US is expected to authorise the Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine for children aged 12 and up by early next week, according to a government official. Pfizer submitted data from a clinical trial of 2,260 12- to 15-year-olds showing the vaccine's effectiveness and tolerability. The US Food and Drug Administration is expected to grant approval, followed by a CDC advisory committee recommendation on vaccine use. This move could expand the US mass vaccination program to millions more people, particularly as vaccine hesitancy remains a major obstacle, with 29% of Republican voters saying they will never take the vaccine.

site_title: South Korea April inflation accelerates to near four-year high, beats forecasts
summary: South Korea's consumer prices rose 2.3% in April from a year earlier, the fastest growth since August 2017 and beating forecasts. This is the highest inflation rate in nearly four years. The month-on-month inflation rate was 0.2%, slightly faster than the 0.1% increase in March. The data indicates a continued upward trend in inflation, which may pose challenges for policymakers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise at Tuesday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened 0.28% higher on Tuesday, edging up to 28,438.15 on the Hang Seng Index, following two days of steep losses. Trading activity was limited due to a holiday in mainland Chinese markets. This marks a slight recovery from previous losses.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday morning following two days of steep losses, with trading activity limited owing to a holiday in mainland Chinese markets.

site_title: Singapore stocks slip at Tuesday's open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks slipped 0.1% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dipping 3.74 points to 3,181.02. The decline was attributed to rising Covid-19 cases in the country, including an outbreak linked to Tan Tock Seng Hospital. Banking stocks were mixed, while US stocks gained on Monday due to investor optimism over strengthening economic growth.

site_title: Impossible Foods wins ruling to continue use of key additive
summary: Impossible Foods has won a court ruling to continue using soy leghemoglobin, a genetically modified ingredient, in its meat substitute products. The US Food and Drug Administration had previously approved the use of soy leghemoglobin, and a federal appeals court in San Francisco upheld this decision. The ruling allows Impossible to extend its burger sales from restaurants to grocery stores. The court denied a request from the Centre for Food Safety to overturn the FDA decision, stating that the agency had applied the correct standard in reviewing the ingredient's safety.

site_title: Top Global's concert parties raise stake to 87.3%
summary: Top Global's executive director and controlling shareholder Sukmawati Widjaja acquired nearly 1.2 million shares at S$0.39 apiece, increasing her stake to 87.3% as of May 3. This is the latest in a series of acquisitions, which had previously raised her interest to 87.1% prior to March 10. The deal was made through her investment holding company SW Investment Holding, with shares closing 1.3% higher at 39 cents on Monday.

site_title: Oil rises over 1% as demand hopes bolster sentiment
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Monday, driven by hopes of strong demand in the US and China, the world's top two oil consumers. Brent crude rose to $67.50 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate rose to $64.38 a barrel. Despite record-breaking infection rates in India, vaccination numbers in developed markets are seen as a positive sign. Opec+ plans to boost supply slightly from May 1, but concerns over India's fuel sales and ongoing US-Iran talks on reviving the 2015 nuclear deal may impact prices.

site_title: Old, outdated properties sitting on US$40b of untapped value in Asia-Pacific: JLL
summary: A JLL report found that properties in the Asia-Pacific region, valued at US$40 billion, are underutilized due to outdated infrastructure. Rental rates for aged buildings are 10-40% lower than modern counterparts, potentially leading to missed income opportunities and cost savings. As newer buildings designed for the post-pandemic era enter the market, the gap in rental rates is expected to widen. Real estate investors and landlords are advised to upgrade or repurpose their properties to capitalize on the growing demand for modern spaces. This could lead to increased revenue and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: No entry to hospitals for visitors with recent trip to TTSH
summary: Singapore hospitals are imposing stricter restrictions on visitors who have recently visited Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH), citing a growing cluster. Hospitals are declining entry to visitors and those accompanying patients if they visited TTSH wards from April 18. Those who have been discharged or visited TTSH may be reviewed via teleconsultation or seen in separate rooms, with non-urgent cases postponed for at least two weeks. The TTSH cluster has grown to 35 cases, with the hospital locking down wards and halting elective procedures.

site_title: Modi resists pressure to lock down India as virus deaths rise
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi has resisted pressure to impose a nationwide lockdown as the country's virus deaths rise, despite warnings from experts and business leaders. Modi had previously called lockdowns "the last option," but now sees them as the only way to stem the outbreak. Despite this, many states, including those run by his party, have ignored his advice and imposed local restrictions. Economists warn that a failure to flatten the virus curve could exacerbate economic pressures, while experts suggest a more targeted approach, such as limiting indoor activities, may be more effective.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust prices S$300m perps at 3.15%
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust priced S$300 million of perpetual securities at 3.15% in a successful issuance that drew "strong participation" from investors, resulting in oversubscription and a tighter price. The Series 002 securities, rated 'BBB-' by Fitch Ratings, will be listed by May 21, 2021, and are expected to lower MIT's aggregate leverage ratio to 36% from 40.3%. Net proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including refinancing existing debt.

site_title: Tokyo, China: Markets closed for holiday on Tuesday
summary: Financial markets in Japan and mainland China are closed on Tuesday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, in Singapore, the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday as investors remained positive despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views. The US stock market also saw S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge towards fresh records. Additionally, Airalo raised $220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion, and eSIM platform companies continue to attract investors.

site_title: Epic Games CEO cites Apple's 'total control' over iPhones at first day of antitrust trial
summary: Epic Games CEO Tim Sweeney testified in an antitrust trial against Apple, stating that Apple exercises "total control" over the iPhone ecosystem and has a sway over 1 billion iPhone users. Epic introduced its own in-app payment system in "Fortnite" to circumvent Apple's 30% commission, leading to Apple kicking the game from its App Store. The trial aims to determine whether Apple's App Store rules and payment requirements harm competition in the software market. Epic seeks orders to end many of Apple's practices, not monetary damages.

site_title: Stocks to watch: MIT, Top Global, OUE C-Reit, Procurri, AEM, Sabana Reit, Jumbo
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies saw new developments that may affect trading on Tuesday. MIT priced S$300 million of perpetual securities at 3.15%, while BHO's executive director acquired nearly 1.2 million shares. OUE C-Reit plans to redeem S$155 million of convertible preferred units on June 1. Procurri Corp's partial offer to acquire a stake has lapsed, and AEM reported a decline in first-quarter earnings. Jumbo Reit's co-founder was fined S$8,000 for harassment, and 42R expects a net loss for the first half-year due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Trading halts were also requested for Jasper Investments.

site_title: Hard but sweet-smelling slog in Morocco's Valley of the Roses
summary: In Morocco's Valley of the Roses, rose pickers like Izza face a physically demanding yet lucrative job. They collect 3 kg of flowers at dawn, which are then distilled into oil worth $18,000 per kilo. The six-hour harvest is crucial, as the flowers are damaged by sunlight. Despite the challenges, the women earn just enough to live on, with the income supporting their families. This labor-intensive process is a vital part of Morocco's economy, highlighting the value of traditional craftsmanship and the resilience of women in the face of adversity.

site_title: UK's Arrival, Uber to develop electric ride-hailing 'Arrival Car'
summary: Uber and British electric van and bus maker Arrival have partnered to develop an electric car for ride-hailing, the "Arrival Car," set to go into production in late 2023. The affordable, purpose-built vehicle aims to prioritize driver comfort, safety, and convenience while ensuring a premium passenger experience. Uber plans to become a fully electric mobility platform in London by 2025 and across North America and Europe by 2030, with a goal of signing up 20,000 additional drivers in Britain.

site_title: UK and India announce £1b investment boost, step closer to trade deal
summary: Britain and India announced a £1 billion investment boost, including £533 million from Indian companies, with the goal of a free trade deal. The deal includes £240 million from the Serum Institute for vaccines and £446 million of export deals for British businesses. The partnership aims to double bilateral trade from £23 billion per year by 2030, creating over 6,500 jobs in Britain. The two countries will also finalise an 'Enhanced Trade Partnership' to lift export barriers and open up India's legal services sector to UK firms.

images.alt_text: Britain and India announced £1 billion pounds (S$1.85 billion) of private-sector investment and committed to seek a free trade deal ahead of a virtual meeting between Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Indian leader Narendra Modi on Tuesday.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly rise, but Nasdaq ends lower
summary: US stocks rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.7% and the S&P 500 up 0.3%, despite the Nasdaq falling 0.5%. The mixed report was driven by optimism over US growth, but concerns over inflation and supply chain issues. The Nasdaq's decline was attributed to weakness in Amazon and other large tech names. Industrial shares, energy, and materials companies were higher, while investors remain optimistic about the economy.

site_title: US to grow 7% this year, fastest since 1980s: Federal Reserve's Williams
summary: The US economy is expected to expand by 7% this year, its fastest rate since the early 1980s, according to Federal Reserve President John Williams. Williams attributed the growth to the Fed's stimulative policies and strong fiscal support. However, he cautioned that the economy still needs several months of strong employment growth to achieve a full recovery. Williams also noted that inflation will fall back to the central bank's 2% target in 2022, and that rising energy prices are a temporary concern.

site_title: G-7 to discuss decisive action to counter threats like Russia and China
summary: Britain is seeking decisive action from G-7 partners to counter threats from Russia and China, as the country hosts a foreign ministers' meeting in London to lay groundwork for a leaders' summit in June. The UK aims to unite open, democratic societies to tackle shared challenges and rising threats. The meeting comes as the global landscape faces growing concerns over democracy, freedoms, and human rights.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Hyflux and former white knight SM Investments have settled a lawsuit over a $38.9 million deposit without admission of liability. Jumbo Group warned of an expected net loss for the first half-year, while Trendlines Group announced a partnership with Mitsubishi Corporation. AEM Holdings reported a 63.1% decline in net profit and a 45.4% drop in revenue for the first quarter. City Developments Ltd saw the resignation of its fourth director, Jenny Lim, following disagreements over an investment in Sincere Property Group.

site_title: US Secretary of State presents new North Korea approach as G-7 meets in person
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken presented a new approach to North Korea at the G-7's first in-person talks in two years, a middle ground that has been denounced by Pyongyang. The meeting, held in London, focused on a post-pandemic agenda and prepares for a G-7 summit in England next month. The US review aims to revive stalled talks with North Korea, but the North Korean response has been negative, indicating a possible setback in diplomatic efforts.

site_title: India's young fight the pandemic with apps and oxygen
summary: In India, young people are stepping up to combat the country's brutal second wave of COVID-19 infections. Apps, volunteers, and social media are being used to crowdsource aid, deliver supplies, and direct resources to those in need. Organizations like UNCUT, led by 17-year-old Swadha Prasad, are building online databases of medical resources and working 24/7 to help patients. Despite the challenges, lives have been saved, and the youth-led efforts have provided emotional support to those affected. However, experts say the government must also play a crucial role in tackling the pandemic, particularly in implementing measures to ensure access to resources for all.

images.alt_text: Her exam revision done, schoolgirl Swadha Prasad gets on with her real work: finding life-saving oxygen, drugs and hospital beds for Covid-19 patients as India reels from a brutal second wave of infections.

site_title: Under Armour to pay US$9m to settle charges of revenue misdirection
summary: Under Armour agreed to pay US$9 million to settle charges with the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) for misleading investors about its revenues. The company inflated sales for six quarters from 2015 to 2016 to meet analysts' expectations. To avoid missing revenue targets, Under Armour pulled forward US$408 million in orders from future quarters.

site_title: Europe: Stocks close higher on positive data, reopening hopes
summary: European stocks closed higher on Monday, driven by positive data and reopening hopes. The euro zone stocks index rose 0.6% and the pan-European Stoxx 600 index gained 0.6%. Travel and leisure stocks rose 0.2% after the European Commission recommended loosening Covid-19 restrictions on tourism. Strong factory and retail sales data also contributed to the optimism.

site_title: Top copper producer Chile facing bonanza challenge
summary: Chile, the world's top copper producer, faces uncertainty amid rising demand and high prices, but political unrest and regulatory changes may hinder production. Copper prices surged to a 10-year high due to increased infrastructure spending, a weak US dollar, and strong demand in China. Protests in Chile, including a strike by port workers, have raised concerns about supply, while a proposed new mining tax and constitutional changes threaten the mining industry's future. Despite this, analysts expect copper production to rise, driven by growing demand for renewable energy systems.

site_title: Bill and Melinda Gates announce divorce after 27 years
summary: Bill Gates and his wife Melinda, a fellow philanthropist, announced their divorce after 27 years of marriage. The joint statement on Twitter stated they made the decision after a great deal of thought and work on their relationship. The couple, with an estimated net worth of $130 billion, cited no further details on the split.

site_title: Demon Slayer overtakes Mortal Kombat to top US box office
summary: Demon Slayer: Mugen Train has taken the top spot at the US box office, earning US$6.4 million in ticket sales, surpassing Mortal Kombat's US$6.2 million. The film has now grossed US$34.1 million in the US and Canada, becoming the third-highest grossing anime title in North America. Demon Slayer has also set box office records in Japan and globally, with US$368 million and US$423 million respectively.

site_title: New York to lift many Covid-19 restrictions
summary: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo announced a major easing of COVID-19 restrictions, including the resumption of 24-hour subway operations starting May 17. From May 19, business and cultural venues will be allowed to operate without occupancy limits, provided social distancing is maintained, and proof of vaccination or a negative test is shown. Outdoor gatherings will double to 500 people, and large-scale indoor events will be allowed at 30% capacity. The announcement paves the way for Broadway theaters to plan their return, with Mayor Bill de Blasio aiming for a full reopening by July 1.

site_title: New Indonesian low-cost carrier Super Air Jet to focus on millennial travellers
summary: Indonesian low-cost carrier Super Air Jet plans to launch with a focus on tech-obsessed millennials, aiming to capitalize on domestic air travel demand. The airline, linked to Lion Air Group, will initially operate 180-seat Airbus planes on domestic routes before expanding internationally. Its CEO, Ari Azhari, believes strong demand from the millennial community exists for air travel, particularly in Indonesia, which is the world's sixth largest aviation market. Super Air Jet's inaugural flight is scheduled for the "near future," pending license approval from the Indonesian transport ministry.

site_title: Robinhood's core business more than triples in Q1
summary: Robinhood's revenue from "payment for order flow" more than tripled to US$331 million in Q1, driven by its popularity among young investors amid the meme-stock frenzy. This revenue stream, where market makers pay retail brokers like Robinhood for routing orders, peaked at US$121 million in February before dropping 20% in March. The company's co-founder and CEO, Vlad Tenev, has testified that this is its largest source of revenue, which has been a topic of controversy over potential incentives for excessive trading.

site_title: France rejects British fishing demands as Brexit row deepens
summary: France has rejected British fishing demands near the Channel Islands, calling them "null and void" in a post-Brexit row. The French fisheries ministry claims Britain introduced new regulations without declaring them to the EU under the Brexit deal. This move follows weeks of clashes between French and British fishermen over fishing licenses. The dispute deepens tensions between the two countries, with French fishermen saying they are being prevented from operating in British waters. The situation remains unresolved, with no clear resolution in sight.

site_title: SIA raises S$2b from sale-and-leaseback transactions for 11 jets
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has raised S$2 billion from sale-and-leaseback transactions for 11 aircraft, comprising seven Airbus A350-900s and four Boeing 787-10s. Four parties, including Aergo Capital and Altavair, arranged the transactions. This deal reinforces SIA's ability to navigate the pandemic from a "position of strength," with the airline now holding about S$15.4 billion in fresh liquidity.

site_title: Australia home prices continue to climb, but pace slows in April
summary: Australia's home prices rose 1.8% in April, slowing the pace of ascent, despite affordability concerns. National prices climbed 7.8% from last year, with Sydney up 2.4%, Melbourne up 1.3%, and Brisbane up 1.7%. The market has boosted consumer wealth and confidence, but CoreLogic's Tim Lawless warns the pace of gains may slow due to rising inventory levels and affordability constraints.

site_title: Listed developers are not going extinct
summary: Singapore's listed property developers, despite trading at significant discounts to net asset value (NAV), are not going extinct. Family-owned groups like Ho Bee Land and Hong Fok Corporation can benefit from independent directors and strengthened corporate governance. While some, like CapitaLand, have opted for restructuring to trade relatively well, others like Ho Bee have transformed operationally and strategically, growing their investment property portfolios and maintaining a resilient income base. Despite undervaluation, these groups can continue to execute well and sustain business value through generations.

site_title: Indebted HNA Group assets attract interest from Fosun, JD.com
summary: Fosun Group and JD.com are among potential investors considering a deal to acquire the domestic operations of HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate under government control. HNA's assets, including airlines, airports, and retail businesses, are being reorganized and sold off to pay off debts of over $40 billion. Other bidders, such as Ping An Insurance Group, Juneyao Airlines, and Air China, are also studying HNA's assets. The sale could raise billions of dollars and is part of the government's efforts to return HNA to its aviation roots.

site_title: Tesla steps up engagement with China's regulators amid scrutiny
summary: Tesla is increasing its engagement with Chinese regulators amid scrutiny over safety and customer service complaints. The US electric vehicle maker is boosting its government relations team and participating in policy discussions, including auto data storage and vehicle-to-infrastructure communication technologies. This shift comes as China tries to regulate large private companies, particularly in the tech sector. Tesla's move aims to address setbacks in its second-biggest market, where it accounts for about 30% of global sales, and maintain its business development in China.

site_title: Why CFOs need to focus on ESG
summary: CFOs are increasingly required to focus on Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) performance due to its growing importance in financing rates, insurance premiums, and investment decisions. As governments and regulators step up their efforts to meet the Paris Climate Agreement, companies will be expected to report on their ESG performance, and those that fail to meet targets may face higher interest rates and insurance premiums. CFOs are well-suited to track and measure ESG performance, and companies that prioritize ESG will see benefits such as improved financing rates, customer loyalty, and share price.

site_title: Oil drops as India's falling demand hits recovery optimism
summary: Oil prices fell 0.4% as weaker demand from virus-hit India partially offset optimism over the global economic recovery. India's April sales of petrol and diesel hit record lows, and the president of the Confederation of Indian Industry urged the government to curb economic activity. Oil prices have rallied in 2021 on vaccine rollout prospects, but uneven recoveries persist. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is easing supply curbs, while traders monitor US-Iranian deal efforts and US oil output struggles.

site_title: European Commission recommends letting in more foreign travellers
summary: The European Commission recommends easing Covid-19 travel restrictions to allow foreign travellers from more countries to enter the EU. The new proposal would allow citizens who have been fully vaccinated against Covid-19 and those arriving from countries with a "good epidemiological situation" to enter the EU. Currently, only seven countries, including Australia and Singapore, are exempt from travel restrictions. EU member states will discuss the proposal, and reciprocity will be considered when deciding to allow leisure travel from third countries.

site_title: WHO begs G-7 to step up and combat Covid-19
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) urged the G-7 to increase funding for global COVID-19 recovery, warning that the crisis cannot be resolved worldwide without their support. WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus called on the G-7 to take decisive action at their June summit to fund vaccines, tests, and treatments. The organization is short of $19 billion in its $22-billion target this year, with an additional $35-45 billion needed next year to ensure global immunization. Former British Prime Minister Gordon Brown also emphasized the need for immediate action, citing the potential for a "man-made catastrophe" if the pandemic is not addressed.

site_title: Sembmarine expects losses to continue for FY2021
summary: Sembcorp Marine, a Singapore-listed offshore and marine company, expects losses to continue for FY2021 due to ongoing supply chain constraints and a shortage of skilled workers. The company faces challenges as foreign workers who left Singapore in the past year remain unable to return due to border controls in countries such as India and Bangladesh. This is the second consecutive year Sembmarine expects losses.

site_title: Tanglin Shopping Centre, Orchard Towers among ageing Orchard buildings heading for en bloc
summary: Several ageing Orchard buildings, including Tanglin Shopping Centre and Orchard Towers, are set for en bloc collective sales. The apportionment method for the sales has been deemed fair, potentially garnering more support. Meanwhile, Ming Arcade, a 1980s-built freehold strata-titled building near Orchard Road, is also considering a collective sale. These developments indicate a growing trend of property owners opting for collective sales to rejuvenate their ageing buildings.

site_title: Public science infrastructure investment is vital for nations
summary: US President Joe Biden's infrastructure plan includes a stepped-up commitment to funding science, recognizing its importance in creating jobs, saving lives, and staying competitive internationally. The US has retreated from its commitment to public funding of basic science, falling to 0.6% of GDP, while China is doubling down on its science investment. A comprehensive plan should include major investments in creating new technology hubs across the US, particularly in cities with excellent universities and highly-educated populations. The plan allocates $20 billion for these investments, and raises taxes on corporations to ensure the benefits of public science investments are shared broadly.

site_title: Bigger is better with BT's relaunched tablet apps
summary: The Business Times (BT) has launched new tablet apps for iPad and Android tablets, replacing the standalone iPad app and offering a universal app for iOS devices. The new apps feature improved speed, security, and a streamlined reading experience, optimized for larger screen real estate. Key features include a faster reading experience, more stories listed per page, and a text-to-speech function for hands-free reading. The apps are available for download starting May 4, 2021.

site_title: DBS reinitiates 'buy' on emerging logistics play Cromwell E-Reit
summary: DBS Group Research has reinitiated coverage on Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust (Cromwell E-Reit) with a "buy" rating and a target price of 60 euro cents, implying a target yield of 5.9% and a price to net asset value multiple of 1.18 times.

site_title: ERA starts S$10m kitty for agents' professional development
summary: ERA Network Realty is investing over S$10 million in a 2021 Covid-19 business-support plan to help more than 8,000 agents with their professional development. The plan includes three grants: digital adoption, skills upgrading, and career progression, with each agent receiving approximately S$1,340. The grants cover digital tools, training, and career progression, aiming to enhance agents' skills and business capabilities.

site_title: India's Covid-19 tally nears 20 million as new cases rise by over 300,000 for 12th straight day
summary: India's COVID-19 cases have surpassed 19.93 million, with 368,147 new cases reported over the past 24 hours, pushing the total infection count to just shy of 20 million. The death toll has risen to 218,959, with at least 3.4 million people currently being treated. Medical experts predict the pandemic could peak in the next few days, with hospitals facing capacity issues, a shortage of medical oxygen, and swamped morgues and crematoriums. The government is reluctant to announce a national lockdown, but has postponed a doctor's exam to allow more personnel to join the fight against the virus.

site_title: Taking on a giant in a spat? Take stock of your weak spots first
summary: Australia's trade and diplomatic tensions with China serve as a warning to countries reliant on exports to a single market. China had become Australia's top export market by 2019, worth US$104 billion, but trade relations turned sour after Australia banned Huawei and retaliatory measures followed. The dispute escalated with Prime Minister Scott Morrison's call for an independent inquiry into the Covid-19 virus origins, which China rejected. As a result, Beijing imposed restrictions on Australian imports, and Canberra is now reviewing a 99-year lease of Darwin Port to a Chinese company.

site_title: RHB, Jefferies up DBS target price on business momentum
summary: DBS' robust Q1 earnings, driven by record fee income and lower provisions, has prompted RHB and Jefferies to raise their target prices for the bank's shares. RHB increased its target price to S$34, while Jefferies raised it to S$33.50, maintaining their "buy" recommendations. The banks cited strong business momentum and higher loan growth guidance as reasons for their optimism.

site_title: OUE C-Reit to redeem S$155m in convertible units
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) will redeem approximately S$155 million of convertible units on June 1, as part of its capital management strategy to optimize its capital structure for sustainability. The redemption will be made in cash, funded by proceeds from the partial divestment of OUE Bayfront, and will reduce outstanding units to 220 million. The decision aims to mitigate dilution in distribution per unit and is approved by the trust's audit and risk committee.

site_title: The back-stage nightmare in a time of the pandemic
summary: Renée Fleming performed an 85-minute indoor concert at the Shed in New York, marking the venue's return to live events after 386 days of shutdown. The show, co-sponsored by NY PopsUp, was the fourth in a series and featured a mix of classical, jazz, and popular music. Despite careful planning, the event highlighted the challenges of mounting indoor events during the pandemic, including safety protocols, reduced ticket revenue, and logistical complexities. The concert required hundreds of dollars in safety equipment and nearly $2,500 in coronavirus tests, and Fleming and the musicians rehearsed only once in person before the show. The event was attended by 150 people, who followed strict Covid-19 protocols, including temperature checks and social distancing.

site_title: Manhattan storefronts struggling as office vacancies soar with remote working
summary: Hundreds of Manhattan storefronts, including locally owned retailers, are struggling due to remote working and office vacancies. Landlords are offering rent breaks to keep stores afloat, but these deals may not be sustainable. The fate of these stores hinges on how long landlords can offer rent reductions. With office vacancies soaring, many storefronts have not seen a rebound, and the city's economy and employment are heavily reliant on small businesses. Employment at small service-industry businesses in Manhattan neighborhoods is down 20% from pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Australia reviewing Chinese lease on Darwin port
summary: Australia is reviewing a 99-year lease on Darwin Port to a Chinese company, Landbridge, due to concerns over national security. Defence Minister Peter Dutton has asked his department to provide advice on whether to force Landbridge to divest, citing strategic implications. The review could lead to the lease being scrapped, further straining relations between Australia and China, which are already in crisis.

site_title: Just like in 80s and 90s, Hong Kongers mull: Should I stay?
summary: Hong Kongers are grappling with the decision to stay or leave the territory due to China's tightening grip, with over 100,000 residents planning to relocate to countries like Britain, Canada, and Australia. The city's expat community, which once attracted people to stay for a lifetime, is now losing its allure. The government's restrictions on media and civil liberties, including the banning of the Tiananmen Square vigil, are also driving some to consider leaving. The decision to stay or go has become a pressing concern for Hong Kongers, with many fearing China's retaliation if they hold foreign passports.

site_title: Investors must act now to back net-zero carbon initiatives
summary: US President Joseph Biden's climate summit marked a significant moment in the battle against global warming and climate change. The summit's results exceeded expectations, with over 70% of the world's economy committed to carbon neutrality and the US recommitting to reducing carbon emissions by 52% below 2005 levels by 2030. The US has rejoined the 2015 Paris Accord, limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels. The summit's renewed sense of multilateralism aims to achieve a net-zero carbon emissions world by the end of the decade.

site_title: UK on course to ditch social distancing rule in June: PM
summary: The UK is on track to drop its one-meter social distancing rule by June 21, according to Prime Minister Boris Johnson. This follows a roadmap to end lockdown restrictions in stages as vaccination rates increase. Johnson's government has set May 17 as the next stage, where foreign travel restrictions will be eased but not lifted. The move has been welcomed by the hospitality industry, which has been heavily criticized by the one-meter plus rule.

site_title: KKR 'to list Australian majority-owned pub group'
summary: KKR is seeking to raise A$352 million in the initial public offering (IPO) of its majority-owned Australian pub group, Australia Venue Co (AVC). The deal values the group at A$903 million, with shares being offered at A$2.33 per share, 15 times forecast 2022 earnings. Proceeds will be used to repay debt facilities and redeem convertible notes. KKR's current 80% ownership will be diluted as the firm does not intend to sell any shares. The IPO is being managed by KKR, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs, with a bookbuild for institutional investors set for May 10.

site_title: Dollar retreats as traders await more US data
summary: The US dollar retreated against major currencies, including the euro and yen, due to cautious trading ahead of central bank meetings and US economic data. The dollar index fell 2% in April, and analysts expect it to drop further if interest rates rise. The euro gained against the dollar after comments from the European Central Bank's vice-president, and the Australian and New Zealand dollars also edged higher. The South Korean won hit a one-week low due to tensions with North Korea, while the rupee was pressured by concerns over a national lockdown in India.

site_title: Apple faces down 'Fortnite' creator Epic Games in major antitrust trial
summary: Apple is facing an antitrust trial with Epic Games, the creator of "Fortnite," over its App Store business practices. Epic alleges Apple's rules and payment requirements harm competition and abuse developer power. The trial centers on Apple's requirement for third-party software distribution through the App Store and its in-app purchase system, which charges up to 30% commissions. Epic is seeking orders to end many of Apple's practices, not damages. The three-week trial begins with opening arguments from both sides, with key executives from both companies expected to testify.

site_title: What history can teach banks about making change
summary: Financial institutions have made commitments to racial equity, but mostly mirrored others' efforts instead of leveraging their unique power to drive change. Despite pledges to diversify hiring and invest in Black businesses, the industry has yet to fully address systemic racism. The article suggests that banks can use their influence to actively undermine the systems perpetuating inequality, but their recent actions have been limited. A more proactive approach is needed to drive meaningful change and address the root causes of racial inequality in the financial sector.

site_title: Sabana Reit co-founder fined for harassment
summary: Sabana Reit co-founder Tay Chiew Sheng, 45, was fined S$8,000 for harassment after pleading guilty to two counts. He sent anonymous letters to multiple organizations, including the Ministry of Finance and StarHub, alleging incompetence of investment professional Ng Shin Ein, who resigned from Sabana Reit as an independent director. Tay's actions were motivated by a proposed merger between ESR-Reit and Sabana Reit, which he believed would harm Sabana Reit's value. The court found Tay's actions to cause maximum damage to Ng, who filed a police report after receiving the letters.

site_title: Are Singtel's digital assets hot buys, or hot potatoes?
summary: Singtel's digital assets, including its e-wallets and advertising unit Amobee, could be worth over S$3.99 billion, according to an analyst. However, retail investors have expressed impatience with the wait for returns, citing skepticism about the value of these digital businesses. Singtel has spent over S$1.09 billion on acquisitions over the past decade, leading to concerns about the company's ability to monetize its digital assets. The value of these assets remains uncertain, leaving investors to weigh the potential benefits against the risks.

site_title: UK car park operator NCP seeks restructuring to cut rental costs
summary: NCP, the UK's largest parking operator, is seeking a court-ordered restructuring to cut rental costs amid plummeting demand during the pandemic. The company failed to reach a consensual deal with property owners and received significant support from 85% of its landlords. The restructuring plan aims to rebase rents, exit unprofitable facilities, and maintain management in place. Shareholder Park24 Co has threatened to stop funding the business if the plan fails, and a court hearing is set for May 28. The move is part of a growing trend among UK companies seeking to curb costs through restructuring.

site_title: Singapore sees jump in family offices as Asia's ultra-rich set up camp
summary: Singapore has seen a significant increase in the number of family offices, with 221 single and multi-family offices opening in the country last year, up from 129 in 2019 and 22 in 2018. The majority of these offices are dominated by those from North Asia, with the proportion of foreign directors from that region rising to 27.3% in 2020. The country's safe haven reputation, favourable tax rates, and stability are major draws for the affluent from North Asia seeking to institutionalize and diversify their investments.

site_title: Family offices are a booming business, but present challenges
summary: Family offices, which manage the financial affairs of wealthy families, are experiencing growth but also face challenges. The lack of standardized standards and oversight can lead to poor investment decisions, as seen in the Archegos Capital Management default. Talent scarcity is another issue, with demand outstripping supply for senior fund management personnel. To address these concerns, Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) is working with the private sector to build the asset management and fund domiciliation business. The industry's growth is driven by Asian families seeking sophisticated solutions for their complex needs, with private banks positioning themselves to capture a share of the family-office market.

site_title: Ageing buildings take another crack at going en bloc
summary: Ageing buildings in Singapore's Orchard vicinity are exploring collective sales, with Tanglin Shopping Centre (TSC) and Orchard Towers among those seeking a sale. TSC, a 50-year-old building, aims for a reserve price of S$785 million, with close to 60% of owners signing the collective sale agreement. Orchard Towers, a freehold building, is in the early stages of the process, with an extraordinary general meeting convened to form the collective sale committee. Developers see the buildings' age, freehold tenures, and prime locations as attractive redevelopment opportunities, despite the challenges of meeting the minimum 80% consent threshold for owners.

site_title: China's April home prices up again, smaller cities lead growth
summary: China's new home prices rose 0.23% in April, driven by strong demand in smaller coastal cities, while major centers saw a decrease due to tighter restrictions. This marks a marginal increase from March's 0.2% growth. The data comes from China Index Academy, a leading real estate research firm. The report highlights the varying housing market trends across China, with smaller cities outperforming larger centers.

site_title: Greater global response needed to win battle against pandemic
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic is accelerating globally, with the worst yet to come, despite efforts to combat it. World leaders are urged to act with extreme urgency to halt the humanitarian catastrophe, with a greater global response needed to improve vaccine distribution and address financial disparities. The WHO warns that the pandemic is growing exponentially, and intensive care units are overflowing in many countries, with the risk of mutations and mutations, such as the B.1.617 variant, exacerbating the crisis. The international community is calling for a global minimum corporation tax rate and a solidarity or wealth tax on the wealthiest individuals to address extreme inequality.

site_title: Malaysia makes AstraZeneca vaccine optional amid safety fears
summary: Malaysia will begin a parallel COVID-19 inoculation program for AstraZeneca vaccine recipients, allowing those who choose to receive the jab on a first-come, first-serve basis. The decision comes after 8,000 people cancelled online vaccination registrations due to public safety fears over the vaccine's link to rare blood clots. The program starts this week, with 268,000 doses available, and will be expanded when more doses arrive. The government has also limited the use of Sinovac Biotech's vaccine to those aged 60 years or older amid a spike in coronavirus cases.

site_title: Credit Suisse gave Archegos big leverage for little collateral
summary: Credit Suisse lent Archegos Capital Management, a family office of Bill Hwang, highly-leveraged stock bets with minimal collateral, exposing the lender to losses of up to $5.5 billion when the firm collapsed. The bank offered leverage up to 10 times, with only 10% collateral required, compared to peers who offered 5 times leverage. This strategy led to a significant loss for Credit Suisse, while Nomura Holdings took a $2.9 billion hit. In response, the bank is reviewing its prime brokerage unit and cutting lending to hedge funds by $35 billion.

site_title: Novavax plans to ship Covid-19 vaccines to Europe from late 2021: EU
summary: Novavax plans to deliver its Covid-19 vaccine to the European Union (EU) starting late 2021, with a total of up to 200 million doses to be supplied. The vaccine is seen as an alternative to Pfizer's mRNA-based shot, with the EU aiming to vaccinate at least 70% of its adult population by the end of July. Novavax's production issues have been addressed, and a formal deal could be signed as early as this week, complementing Pfizer's planned supply of 1.8 billion doses.

site_title: Philippines foreign minister issues expletive-laced tweet over China sea dispute
summary: Philippine Foreign Minister Teodoro Locsin issued an expletive-laced tweet demanding China's vessels leave the disputed South China Sea waters. The comments follow Manila's protests of hundreds of Chinese boats inside the Philippines' 200-mile Exclusive Economic Zone. China claims almost the entire sea, while the Philippines has filed 78 diplomatic protests since 2016. The dispute escalates tensions between the two nations, with the Philippines vowing to continue maritime exercises in its EEZ.

site_title: Malaysia makes AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine optional amid safety fears
summary: Malaysia introduces an optional AstraZeneca Covid-19 vaccine program amid public safety concerns over rare blood clots. The decision comes after 8,000 people cancelled vaccination registrations and data showed increased vaccine hesitancy. The parallel program allows people to choose the AstraZeneca vaccine on a first-come, first-serve basis, starting this week. Malaysia has also limited the use of Sinovac Biotech's vaccine to those aged 60 or older due to concerns over its safety.

site_title: LNG cargoes diverted from India as Covid crisis dampens demand: sources
summary: LNG cargoes are being diverted from Indian ports due to a surge in coronavirus cases, reducing demand and impacting trade and shipping. Since April 20, six tankers have changed their destinations to northeast Asia, Europe, and Kuwait. Gas demand has decreased due to lockdowns, with city-gas distribution and power demand also down. India's LNG imports dropped 11-14% in April, still higher than last year's levels. The diversion is expected to continue, with some companies adopting a wait-and-see approach to lockdown restrictions.

site_title: Singapore's total market cap down 3.9% in April
summary: Singapore's total market capitalization fell 3.9% in April to S$867.08 billion, snapping a five-month rising streak, due to delistings that reduced the number of listed companies to 682. The STI rose 1.7% to 3,218.27, marking the sixth consecutive month of gains. The financial sector led the market's recovery, with DBS emerging as the strongest performer, followed by OCBC and UOB. Despite this, market strategist Geoff Howie predicts a potential pullback in the near term due to factors such as Covid-19 measures and seasonally weak May.

site_title: Hong Kong ends longest recession in decades
summary: Hong Kong's economy has ended its longest recession in decades, growing 7.8% in the first quarter of 2021 after six consecutive quarters of negative growth. The city was hit by the US-China trade war, social unrest, and the coronavirus pandemic, but a sharp resurgence in exports fueled the recovery. However, the economy remains below pre-pandemic levels, with unemployment at 7% and the tourism and retail sectors still struggling. Full-year growth is forecast at 3.5-5.5%, but the recovery is expected to be uneven.

site_title: Brokerage Wealthsimple raises money at US$4b value; Drake buys in
summary: Wealthsimple, a Canadian online brokerage, raised C$750 million in a funding round valuing it at approximately US$4 billion. Existing investors Meritech Capital Partners and Greylock Partners, along with celebrities such as Drake, Ryan Reynolds, and Michael J Fox, participated in the round. The company aims to expand its services to become users' primary financial institution, building on its commission-free stock trading and automated investing offerings. The funding will support this growth strategy.

site_title: Trendlines and Mitsubishi team up to identify agrifood start-ups
summary: Trendlines Agrifood, an investment vehicle of Trendlines Group, partnered with Mitsubishi Corporation to identify emerging technologies and start-ups in the agrifood sector. Trendlines, an Israel- and Singapore-based investment group, will help Mitsubishi tap into the rapidly developing agrifood sector in Israel. The partnership aims to discover promising technologies that can provide breakthrough innovation to global enterprises.

site_title: US: Stocks open higher as earnings deluge continues
summary: US stocks opened higher on Monday, driven by optimism over improving economic conditions. Key reports this week include the April employment report and earnings from General Motors, Pfizer, and others. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index edged up 0.2%. Investors are also monitoring the coronavirus crisis in India and the impact of cost inflation and supply chain problems.

images.alt_text: Wall Street stocks were higher early Monday to open a week that includes key US jobs data and earnings from General Motors, Pfizer and others.

site_title: Aviation, travel groups urge fully reopening US-UK travel market
summary: A coalition of US and European travel, airline, union, business, and airport groups urged the US and UK governments to fully reopen the US-UK air travel market "as soon as safely possible." They called for a joint announcement during a planned meeting between US President Joe Biden and British Prime Minister Boris Johnson in early June. The US has barred nearly all non-US citizens who have recently been in the UK from entering the country since March 2020. The groups aim to lift restrictions, which have severely impacted the travel industry.

site_title: Singapore's April PMI up again for 10th straight month
summary: Singapore's economy showed signs of continued growth in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) reading of 50.9, marking the 10th straight month of expansion. The electronics sector, a crucial component, saw an improved PMI of 50.7, up 0.1 point from March, its 9th consecutive month of growth. This indicates optimism among manufacturers, but no specific conclusions are drawn on the overall economic outlook in the provided article.

site_title: Verizon sells 90% of media division to Apollo for US$5b
summary: Verizon is selling its 90% media division to Apollo Global Management for $5 billion, with the remaining 10% stake retained by Verizon. The media group will be rebranded as Yahoo after the transaction, which is expected in the second half of this year. Guru Gowrappan will remain CEO. This sale follows Verizon's earlier disposal of HuffPost and Tumblr, marking the end of its online advertising foray. Verizon prioritizes its wireless business and 5G network construction.

site_title: AEM Q1 net profit falls 63.1% to S$13.34 million after record year-ago period
summary: AEM Holdings' first-quarter net profit fell 63.1% to S$13.34 million due to a high revenue base in the previous year. Revenue declined 45.4% to S$80.23 million. Despite the decline, the company expects full-year revenue of between S$460 million and S$520 million, driven by the acquisition of contract manufacturer CEI Ltd. The board remains cautiously optimistic about the business, aiming to capture new opportunities in uncertain times.

site_title: Fidelity halves valuation of Ant Group after Chinese crackdown: WSJ
summary: US asset manager Fidelity Investments has halved its valuation of Ant Group to $144 billion, down from $295 billion in August. The move comes after Chinese regulators cancelled Ant's IPO and ordered the company to convert into a financial holding company. Fidelity invested $238 million in Ant in 2018, valuing it at $150 billion at the time. This valuation is significantly lower than the $315 billion Ant claimed for its IPO. The new valuation reflects the impact of the regulatory crackdown on Ant's appeal to investors.

site_title: Rhino poachers are back after South Africa eases lockdown restrictions
summary: Rhino poaching has increased in South Africa since the government eased lockdown restrictions, reversing a year-long lull due to the pandemic. The country reported 30% fewer poachings in 2020 compared to the previous year, but incidents have risen since international travel restrictions were lifted in November 2020. Poaching often involves local and international syndicates, and methods can be cruel, resulting in animal deaths. Reserves have had to cut back on anti-poaching patrols, and some use dehorning as a prevention measure. The environmental ministry is expected to release its 2021 poaching figures at the end of June.

images.alt_text: Rhino poaching is on the rise again in South Africa since the government loosened coronavirus restrictions, following a year-long lull due to the pandemic, wildlife parks say.

site_title: UK on course to ditch social distancing rule in June: PM Johnson
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced that Britain is on track to drop its one-metre social distancing rule by the end of June, as the country's vaccination efforts help suppress Covid-19 infections. The government's lockdown restrictions are set to be lifted in stages, with restrictions on foreign travel easing on May 17. Johnson emphasized the need for caution ahead of the deadline, citing concerns about disease transmission from abroad. The move is seen as a significant step towards easing lockdown restrictions in the country.

site_title: Hong Kong Q1 GDP rises 7.8% y-o-y after six quarters of contraction
summary: Hong Kong's economy grew 7.8% in Q1 after six consecutive quarters of contraction, driven by strong exports and a low base comparison. The trade-reliant city benefited from mainland China's recovery and a loosened coronavirus restriction. The government expects a broader-based improvement later in the year, with exports and services expected to improve. The revised GDP forecast for 2021 is expected to be released on May 14.

site_title: Swee Choon's successor has fresh ambitions
summary: Ernest Ting, the third-generation owner of Swee Choon Tim Sum, has ambitious plans to grow the business, opening more outlets in Singapore and considering international expansion. Ting, 30, has a wealth of experience from his previous startup, Hook Coffee, and brings a modern approach to the family business. He aims to preserve Swee Choon's heritage while introducing new ideas and products, such as a frozen dim sum series, to drive growth. The business is currently profitable, with seven-digit revenues annually, and expects to grow at a rate of 20-25% annually over the next three to five years.

site_title: Facebook oversight board set to rule on Trump ban
summary: Facebook's independent oversight board is set to issue a final ruling on whether to leave in place a ban on former US President Donald Trump, who was removed from the platform for inciting violence. The ruling, expected on Wednesday, follows comments Trump made after the US Capitol riot on January 6. The board's decision will determine the fate of the Trump ban, which has been in place since the incident.

site_title: No Signboard has no idea why shares spiked on Monday, board tells bourse regulator
summary: No Signboard Holdings, a Catalist-listed restaurant company, saw its shares surge 90.32% on Monday after unusual trading activity. The company's board told the Singapore Exchange Regulation that it is unaware of any undisclosed information or reasons for the trading. The unusual price and volume movements were flagged by the regulator, and the board replied that it is in compliance with listing rules. No explanation was given for the sudden spike.

site_title: Singapore PMI hits 28-month high in April
summary: Singapore's Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) hit a 28-month high in April, staying in expansionary territory for the 10th consecutive month. The overall PMI reading rose to 50.9, driven by faster expansion in new orders, new exports, and employment. The electronics sector also saw an improved PMI reading of 50.7, marking its ninth month in expansion. Economists attribute the growth to the support provided by the export sector and expect the labour market to improve further. However, the entry ban on workers from India may pose a near-term drag on recovery.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust signs US$15m loan deal with Chailease
summary: First Ship Lease Trust has signed a US$15 million loan deal with Chailease International Financial Services for refinancing six vessels. The loan, with a 5-year maturity, bears interest of 3.975% per annum and will be repaid in 20 quarterly installments of US$750,000 each. The loan is secured by mortgages, vessel earnings, and insurances.

site_title: Temasek-backed payments firm Flywire makes US IPO filing public
summary: Flywire, a payments firm backed by Temasek Holdings, has made its US IPO filing public, revealing a 38% surge in revenue in the latest quarter. The company, which focuses on payments in education, healthcare, and travel sectors, recorded $44.99 million in revenue for the three months ended March 31, up from $32.71 million a year ago. Flywire is seeking a valuation as high as $3 billion and plans to list on Nasdaq under the symbol "FLYW."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 10.92 points lower at 1,590.73 on Monday, with volume reaching 6.681 billion lots worth RM4.257 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 912 to 301.

site_title: Fourth director resigns from City Developments' board
summary: City Developments' board has accepted the resignation of its fourth director, Lim Yin Nee Jenny, effective immediately. She had fulfilled her responsibilities in various roles but stepped down due to contributions from new independent directors. New appointments include Lee Jee Cheng Philip as lead independent director and chairman of the audit and risk committee, and Carol Fong, Chong Yoon Chou, and Daniel Marie Ghislain Desbaillets as members of the ARC and remuneration committee. This follows the resignations of Kwek Leng Peck, Koh Thiam Hock, and Tan Yee Peng over disagreements on investment in Sincere Property Group in China.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Monday amid Covid-19 fears; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1% on Monday amid growing fears over Covid-19, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,184.76. Investors' concerns were fueled by rising cases in the local community and the tightening of social-distancing measures. Nearly all STI constituents ended in the red, with Wilmar International and Genting Singapore leading the decline. The only gainer was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, which rose 2.8%. The decline followed a similar trend in regional markets, including Hong Kong and South Korea.

site_title: Northern Ireland marks centenary as crises simmer
summary: Northern Ireland marked its 100th anniversary on Monday amidst coronavirus restrictions and simmering post-Brexit unrest. The province has been marred by the worst rioting in years, with at least 88 police officers injured. First Minister Arlene Foster announced her resignation amidst a reported coup in her Democratic Unionist Party, citing the Brexit protocol's impact on the region. The protocol has sparked unionist fears of a united Ireland, a prospect that has led to decades of bloodshed. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson acknowledged the complex history and urged the country to come together, but his approval ratings remain low in Northern Ireland.

images.alt_text: Northern Ireland marked its centenary on Monday with coronavirus restrictions, simmering post-Brexit unrest and a leadership crisis marring the anniversary in the British-ruled province.

site_title: EU executive recommends opening up to non-EU foreign travel
summary: The European Union's executive recommended allowing foreign citizens fully vaccinated against Covid-19 and those from countries with a good epidemiological situation to travel into the bloc without additional restrictions. The proposal also includes expanding the list of countries with permitted travel and raising the threshold for determining a country's eligibility. This move aims to ease travel restrictions and promote economic recovery.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares close sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed sharply lower on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index sinking 1.28% to 28,357.54, following a negative lead from Wall Street and ongoing inflation concerns. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday. The sell-off is part of a broader Asia-wide trend.

site_title: Australia reviewing controversial Chinese lease on Darwin port
summary: Australia is reviewing a 99-year lease on Darwin Port to a Chinese company, Landbridge, amid concerns it poses a strategic liability. Defence Minister Peter Dutton stated the lease is under review and refused to rule out forcing Landbridge to divest due to national security grounds. The review comes after a similar deal was scrapped in Victoria last month, straining relations between Australia and China. A conclusion of the review is expected by the end of the year, with potential options including scrapping the deal or divestment.

site_title: Co-founder of Sabana Reit fined for harassment
summary: Sabana Reit's co-founder, Tay Chiew Sheng, was fined S$8,000 for harassment after pleading guilty to two counts. He sent anonymous letters to multiple organizations, including the Ministry of Finance and Starhub, alleging incompetence of investment professional Ng Shin Ein. The letters also included personal details and caused her distress. Tay initially denied writing the letters but later admitted to sending them after the police seized the letters and found his fingerprints. The court deemed Tay's actions calculated to cause maximum damage.

site_title: OUE C-Reit to redeem S$155 million of convertible units in One Raffles Place deal
summary: OUE Commercial Real Estate Investment Trust (OUE C-Reit) will redeem S$155 million of convertible perpetual preferred units (CPPUs) on June 1, as part of its capital management strategy. The redemption, made in cash, aims to mitigate dilution in distribution per unit and is funded by proceeds from the partial divestment of OUE Bayfront. The remaining 220 million CPPUs will remain outstanding, with a special preferred distribution of 1% per year to CPPU holders. The decision was approved by OUE's audit and risk committee, considering the interests of the trust and minority unitholders.

site_title: Indonesia says finds two cases of Indian Covid-19 variant in Jakarta
summary: Indonesia has reported its first cases of the highly infectious B.1.617 Covid-19 variant first detected in India, with two cases found in Jakarta. The health minister urged people not to travel for the Eid al-Fitr festival to curb transmission. Indonesia has also banned mass gatherings and stopped issuing visas for foreigners who have been in India in the past 14 days. The variant has spread to at least 17 countries, prompting border closures, and Indonesia's positivity rate remains above 12%.

site_title: Gold gains as rising virus cases, pullback in US yields lift demand
summary: Gold prices rose 0.5% to $1,777.67 per ounce, driven by concerns over surging Covid-19 cases in countries like India and Japan, and a retreat in US Treasury yields. Palladium held firm above $3,000 per ounce. The dollar index slipped, making gold more appealing to foreign investors. India reported over 300,000 new coronavirus cases for the 12th straight day, and investors await US economic data this week for clues about the recovery.

site_title: Buffett says Abel is likely successor at Berkshire
summary: Warren Buffett has confirmed Greg Abel, 58, as his likely successor at Berkshire Hathaway, citing his age and experience as key factors. Abel, who oversees non-insurance businesses, was seen as the most likely candidate, and Buffett praised his ability to maintain the company's culture. Ajit Jain, 69, was also considered, but Buffett emphasized Abel's 20-year runway. The announcement comes after Berkshire vice-chairman Charlie Munger's comments suggesting Abel could be the chosen successor, following their promotion in 2018.

site_title: Saudi Arabia names former Aramco dealmaker as economy minister
summary: Saudi Arabia appointed Faisal Alibrahim, a former Aramco deal-maker, as economy and planning minister, aiming to diversify the economy away from oil. The move comes after the kingdom's GDP contracted 4.1% in 2020 due to the coronavirus pandemic and oil price rout. Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman predicts a V-shaped rebound, with unemployment expected to fall below 11% this year. The new minister takes over after a series of royal orders also promoted a woman to vice minister of commerce and replaced Prince Sultan bin Salman as head of the space agency.

site_title: KKR to list Australian majority-owned pub group seeking A$352m: memo
summary: KKR is seeking to raise A$352 million in the initial public offering (IPO) of its majority-owned Australian pub group, Australia Venue Co (AVC), valuing the group at A$903 million. KKR's current 80% ownership will be diluted as the firm does not intend to sell any shares. Shares are being offered at A$2.33 per share, equivalent to 15 times forecast 2022 earnings. The IPO will be managed by KKR, Citigroup, and Goldman Sachs, with proceeds used to repay existing debt and redeem convertible notes.

site_title: Jumbo Group board issues loss guidance for upcoming H1 2021 results amid virus woes
summary: Jumbo Group, a Catalist-listed seafood restaurant operator, has issued a loss guidance for its first half-year results due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, particularly in Singapore. The board cited "persistently muted footfall" at its outlets in Singapore as the main reason for the expected net loss. Despite year-on-year improvements in China, revenue decline in Singapore outweighed the positives.

site_title: Economists stick to forecasts despite Indonesia inflation surprising on downside
summary: Indonesia's inflation figures for April surprised on the downside, falling to 1.42% year-over-year, below the consensus forecast of 1.5%. Despite this, economists maintain their expectations for inflation to pick up in the coming months, with Citi forecasting 1.7-2.5% for the full year. Core inflation, excluding volatile food prices, remained at its record low of 1.2%. Economists attribute the decline to lower-than-expected food price inflation and travel restrictions ahead of the mid-May festive season.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The World Travel and Tourism Council opposes vaccination as a travel requirement due to potential discrimination. Singapore Airlines raised S$2 billion from sale-and-leaseback transactions for 11 aircraft. Sembcorp Marine expects losses for FY2021 and has an S$1.89 billion order book. ERA Network Realty launched a S$10 million support plan for 8,000 agents. The long-stop date for a Myanmar mobile payments joint venture was not extended. Singapore stocks fell 1% amid Covid-19 fears.

site_title: Former Coastal Oil CFO who helped defraud eight banks gets nine years' jail
summary: A former CFO of Coastal Oil was sentenced to 9 years' jail for helping to defraud 8 banks into disbursing approximately $320 million in loans. The former CFO, Ong Ah Huat, caused losses totaling around $10 million to China Merchant Bank. The other 7 banks affected, including Standard Chartered Bank and OCBC Limited, did not disclose their losses.

site_title: Hyflux and Salim-Medco settle lawsuit over deposit; judicial managers ask for more time
summary: Hyflux and Salim-Medco have settled a lawsuit over a $38.9 million deposit, ending a dispute that began after a $530 million rescue deal was cancelled in 2019. The settlement, reached on April 7, does not involve any admission of liability. Judicial managers, who took over Hyflux in 2020, have asked for a 60-day extension of their term, until July 14. Trading in Hyflux securities has been suspended since 2018. The agreement marks a resolution to the dispute without resolving underlying issues, leaving the future of Hyflux uncertain.

site_title: Manchester United fan violence condemned by government and mayor
summary: The UK government's sports minister and the mayor of Greater Manchester have condemned violence by Manchester United fans during a protest against the club's American owners. The fans, who were protesting against the Glazer family, stormed into the stadium, causing clashes with police and throwing a flare. The Premier League game with Liverpool was postponed due to the violence. The government and mayor have expressed strong disapproval of the fan violence, emphasizing the importance of maintaining a safe and respectful environment for all fans and players.

site_title: Deals of the week: GIC funds Brazil fintech; Temasek backs UpGrad
summary: Singapore's GIC led a 300 million reais (S$74.4 million) funding round in Brazilian fintech Warren, aiming to invest in technology and double assets under management. Temasek Holdings invested US$120 million in Indian edtech major UpGrad Education, using capital to strengthen its team and scale global operations. Sunseap Group expanded in Japan with investments from three Japanese corporations after a Series E funding round. EAVision Technologies, a Chinese agricultural drone startup, raised US$30 million in a Series C funding round led by Temasek and Citic for research and development and market expansion.

site_title: Online share of retail sales jumps to 19% amid lockdowns: UN
summary: The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) reported that online sales accounted for 19% of total retail sales in 2020, up from 16% in 2019. This growth was driven by lockdowns to combat the coronavirus pandemic. South Korea led with a 25.9% share, followed by China (24.9%), Britain (23.3%), and the US (14.0%). Global e-commerce sales rose 4% to $26.7 trillion in 2019, equivalent to 30% of global economic output that year.

site_title: ERA launches S$10m support plan to help 8,000 agents with professional development
summary: ERA Realty has launched a S$10 million support plan to aid over 8,000 agents with professional development. The plan includes three grants: digital, training, and career. Each ERA agent will receive approximately S$1,340, comprising a digital grant of S$700, a training grant of S$356, and a career grant of S$283.50. The plan aims to help agents adopt new technologies, upgrade skills, and advance their careers through various benefits, including training courses and business expenses.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall on worries over partial lifting of short-selling ban
summary: South Korean stocks fell on Monday as foreign investors reduced their positions due to worries over the partial lifting of a short-selling ban. The benchmark Kospi closed down 0.66% at 3,127.20, with foreigners selling 441.3 billion won worth of shares. The biopharmaceutical and battery sectors were most affected, with LG Chem and Celltrion dropping 2.83% and 6.20%, respectively. Despite upbeat trade data showing the fastest pace of expansion in over a decade, investors remained cautious due to the resumption of short-selling.

site_title: Australia: Shares end flat as losses in miners offset gains in financials
summary: Australia's shares ended flat on Monday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 0.04% to 7028.80, as losses in miners offset gains in financials. The financial sector rose 1.4%, led by Westpac's strong earnings, while metals and mining index fell 1% due to subdued iron ore and copper prices. Technology stocks dragged 1.9% due to US peers, with Nuix as the biggest loser. Despite a solid increase in Australian home prices and job advertisements, the market remained muted amid broader Asian market trading.

site_title: Nepal halts all domestic, international flights in effort to curb huge spike
summary: Nepal has halted all domestic and international flights due to a surge in coronavirus infections, with public fury targeting travelers from India and the government's handling of the pandemic. The move comes as India's crisis worsens and people from several Indian states have flooded into Nepal via land and air routes. The halt affects flights starting Monday for domestic travel and Wednesday for international flights. The decision aims to curb the spread of the virus.

site_title: Sturgeon: Scottish independence leader eyes key victory
summary: Scotland's National Party (SNP) leader Nicola Sturgeon is poised for a key victory in the upcoming elections, which could set the nation on the road to independence. Sturgeon, 50, has become the dominant force in Scottish politics, earning praise for her management of the coronavirus pandemic and clear communication style. Despite infighting and opposition, the SNP is expected to dominate the ballot box, with one poll showing it on course to win 70 of the 129 seats in the Scottish Parliament. Sturgeon has vowed to push for a second referendum on independence, despite UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's opposition.

site_title: 17 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, eight are linked to TTSH cluster
summary: Singapore reported 17 new COVID-19 cases, including eight linked to the Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) cluster and two to the Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) officer cluster. The TTSH cases include five patients who initially tested negative but later tested positive, while the ICA cases involve a three-year-old boy and his mother. Seven imported cases were also reported, bringing the total number of infected to 61,235. With 20 cases discharged, 60,791 patients have fully recovered, and 131 patients have died from COVID-19 complications.

site_title: New Indonesian low-cost carrier Super Air Jet to focus on millennial travellers
summary: Indonesian low-cost airline Super Air Jet aims to launch with a focus on tech-savvy millennials, targeting domestic routes initially before expanding internationally. Founded by former Lion Air Group general manager Ari Azhari, the airline will operate 180-seat Airbus A320 planes. Super Air Jet's launch is pending a license from Indonesia's transport ministry, with some processes still to be completed. The airline will differentiate itself from Lion Air, also a low-cost carrier, but no further details were provided.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holidays on Monday and Tuesday
summary: Japan's financial markets are closed on Monday and Tuesday for Greenery Day and Children's Day, respectively. This summary does not appear to be relevant to the provided article content.

site_title: Europe: Stocks edge higher on earnings optimism, recovery hopes
summary: European stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, driven by optimism over a quick economic rebound and strong earnings season. The Stoxx 600 index ended April with a 1.8% gain, narrowly missing its all-time highs. German retail sales saw their largest year-on-year increase since the pandemic, while Siemens Healthineers raised its forecast. However, Siemens Gamesa fell 3.5% after warning of reduced earnings. The pan-European index is set to close for a UK bank holiday on Tuesday.

site_title: World travel body opposes vaccination as a travel requirement
summary: The World Travel and Tourism Council opposes vaccination as a travel requirement, citing concerns of discrimination against those who cannot access or afford vaccinations.
