The council's vice-president, Lola Uña Cárdenas, stated that vaccination is not the only solution to safely re-opening borders and that alternative measures should be explored.

site_title: TSMC says can catch up with auto chip demand by end June
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) expects to meet the "minimum requirement" of auto chip demand by the end of June, according to its chairman. The move comes as carmakers worldwide shut assembly lines due to chip shortages, exacerbated by US actions against Chinese chip factories. TSMC, a leading semiconductor manufacturer, has vowed to ramp up capacity to address the issue. The company's efforts aim to resolve the global shortage affecting the automotive industry.

site_title: Hong Kong's economy set to bounce back after long decline
summary: Hong Kong's economy is expected to expand for the first time since 2019, with a 3.7% growth in the first quarter, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. The expansion is driven by strong exports and a low base from a year ago. Financial Secretary Paul Chan forecasts full-year growth of 3.5-5.5% in 2021, reversing a historic run of six straight quarters of declines. However, the pandemic remains a challenge, and a persistently low vaccination rate may hinder the city's efforts to fully rebound.

site_title: 5 new Covid patients had been discharged and sent home, but later found to have virus
summary: Five Covid-19 patients discharged from Singapore's Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) were later found to have the virus, raising concerns about the hospital's outbreak. The hospital has tested all inpatients and staff, with results showing no new cases. Of the 14 community cases reported, 11 are linked to TTSH, including seven patients, a physiotherapist, and three visitors to a ward with multiple infections. The hospital continues to monitor patients closely.

site_title: Apple's App Store draws developer ire and legal challenge
summary: Apple's App Store is under scrutiny from developers, who claim the company's strict rules and 30% commission on transactions amount to "tyranny." Epic Games, maker of Fortnite, filed a lawsuit against Apple, alleging monopolistic behavior and accusing the company of unfairly squeezing out rivals. The US Federal Court is set to hear the case, which has sparked a global backlash, with the European Union and other authorities also investigating Apple's App Store practices.

site_title: Manufacturing powers ahead, even as China PMI cools
summary: Asia's manufacturing activity remained robust in April, with Taiwan's IHS Markit PMI index reaching 62.4, its highest reading since 2010, and South Korea's index at 54.6, its seventh straight month of expansion. Global trade continued to recover, driven by demand for electronics, with shipments from South Korea and Taiwan surging. However, supply crunches worldwide, including at the Port of Los Angeles, are starting to dent manufacturing growth, particularly in Taiwan, with supplier delays and backlogs emerging as concerns.

site_title: Thailand reports new daily record of 31 coronavirus deaths
summary: Thailand reported a new daily record of 31 coronavirus deaths, bringing the total number of fatalities to 276, with 2,041 new cases reported. The country is grappling with a third wave of infections, primarily caused by the B.1.1.7 variant, and is aiming to vaccinate 70% of the population by the end of the year. Mass inoculations are set to begin in June with locally manufactured AstraZeneca doses.

site_title: One in two people globally lost income due to the pandemic: Gallup
summary: A Gallup survey of 300,000 people across 117 countries found that one in two people worldwide, or 1.6 billion adults, experienced a drop in earnings due to the pandemic, with those in low-income countries most affected. The impact varied by country, with 76% in Thailand and 10% in Switzerland reporting earnings drops. The crisis disproportionately affected women, particularly in low-paid sectors, and led to job losses or reduced working hours for 1.7 billion adults and over 1 billion people losing their jobs or businesses globally.

site_title: Australia home prices continue to climb, pace slows a touch in April
summary: Australian home prices rose 1.8% in April, slowing slightly from the 2.8% increase in March, with national prices up 7.8% from last year. Sydney prices surged 2.4%, while Melbourne, Brisbane, and Perth increased 1.3%, 1.7%, and 0.8% respectively. The market has boosted consumer wealth and confidence, but CoreLogic's Tim Lawless warns the pace of gains may slow due to rising inventory levels and affordability constraints.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB, Jefferies raise DBS target price on strong business momentum
summary: Research firms RHB and Jefferies have raised their target prices for DBS, citing strong business momentum and high loan growth guidance. DBS reported a record Q1 net profit of S$2.01 billion, driven by fee income and trading gains. Analysts project strong business momentum, with loan growth expected to be a high single-digit growth. The target price for DBS has been raised to S$34 (RHB) and S$33.50 (Jefferies), maintaining a "buy" call for the bank.

site_title: Schlumberger-backed Arabian Drilling planning Saudi IPO
summary: Arabian Drilling Co., a Saudi oilfield-services company partly owned by Schlumberger, is preparing an initial public offering (IPO) that could value it at around $2 billion. The company, founded in 1964, has asked banks to pitch for a role on the potential share sale and may complete the deal on Riyadh's stock exchange before the end of the year. This comes as Saudi Aramco and other national oil firms in the Middle East plan to raise billions of dollars from foreign investors through asset sales and IPOs.

site_title: Pfizer to supply 4.5m doses of Covid-19 vaccine to South Africa by June
summary: Pfizer has agreed to supply 4.5 million doses of its Covid-19 vaccine to South Africa by June, with the first batch of 325,260 doses arriving in the country on Sunday. The country has secured 30 million doses of the vaccine, and the health regulator has also approved Johnson & Johnson's one-shot vaccine.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares fall at Monday's open
summary: Malaysia's shares fell 2.5 points or 0.2% to 1,599.1 at Monday's open, with 516 losers outnumbering 194 gainers. The country's stock market traded 937.7 million lots worth RM580.8 million.

site_title: Building the Googleplex of the future
summary: Google is redefining its office space with a post-pandemic workplace featuring privacy robots, meeting tents, and balloon walls. The company will encourage remote work with a hybrid model, allowing employees to come into the office on a rotation schedule. New designs include "Team Pods" with flexible furniture and "Campfire" meeting rooms with large displays. Outdoor work areas, like "Camp Charleston," will also be created to accommodate remote workers. Changes include boxed, grab-and-go meals, reduced real estate costs, and the use of fresh air through vents.

site_title: Prices of UK rural homes surge as more move out of the city
summary: UK rural home prices surged by 10% over the past year, outperforming urban areas by nearly twice as much, as the Covid-19 pandemic led to urban flight. Analysis by the Resolution Foundation found that rural areas saw a significant increase in housing prices, while flats fared less well as people sought larger properties. Experts question whether this trend will be long-term, citing overcrowding issues during the pandemic that remain unaddressed.

site_title: Long-stop date for Yoma Strategic, Ant Financial JV in Myanmar not extended
summary: Yoma Strategic, a joint venture between Ant Financial and Yoma Bank, has not had its long-stop date extended for a mobile payments JV in Myanmar and a proposed acquisition of Digital Money Myanmar Limited from Telenor Group. Both parties expect to continue seeking regulatory approvals for the transactions. The acquisition aims to drive financial inclusion in Myanmar, targeting the unbanked and underbanked communities. The long-stop dates were previously set for April 30, 2021, and no extension was announced.

site_title: Covid-19 resurgence could hurt Malaysia's recovery if movement curbs reimposed: report
summary: Malaysia's economic recovery may be threatened by a resurgence in Covid-19 cases, with the government considering reimposition of movement curbs in areas such as Selangor and Kuala Lumpur. The country's vaccination rate remains low, with less than 2% of the population fully inoculated. Daily new cases have breached 3,000, and hospitals in the Klang Valley area face a shortage of intensive care unit beds. The central bank is set to meet on May 6, with market expectations that rates will not be cut, but there is a "small tail risk" of a rate cut to address downside risks.

site_title: Huarong seeks to reassure investors that it can repay debt
summary: China Huarong Asset Management Co has reassured investors that it can repay its debt, citing state backing and no signs of a change in government support. Vice President Xu Yongli stated that recent rating downgrades by international agencies are "too pessimistic" and lack factual basis. The company's financial health has been a concern since its 2020 results delay, but Xu assured there is no evidence of a change in the government's support or shareholding structure. Moody's Investors Service and Fitch Ratings downgraded the firm's credit ratings last week amid concerns over central government support.

site_title: Hot stock: Tuan Sing jumps 16% after news of printed circuit board maker stake sale
summary: Shares of Tuan Sing Holdings jumped 16% after its associated company Gultech China sold 13% of its shares in a printed circuit board supplier for $89 million, valuing the PCB firm at $3.35 billion. The divestment is expected to be completed by July 31, 2021, allowing Tuan Sing to monetize part of its long-standing investment. The transaction price implies a significant increase in Tuan Sing's stake in Gultech, leading to the company's intraday high of 43.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS reinitiates 'buy' on 'emerging logistics play' Cromwell E-Reit
summary: DBS Group Research reinitiated coverage on Cromwell E-Reit with a "buy" rating and a target price of 60 euro cents, implying a target yield of 5.9% and a price to net asset value multiple of 1.18 times. The reinitiation comes as the research team remains excited about the Reit manager's pivot into the logistics sector, which accounts for 35% of assets. Units of Cromwell E-Reit closed flat at 47.5 euro cents on Monday.

site_title: Oil demand in India drops as wave of virus convulses nation
summary: India's Covid-19 crisis has led to a significant drop in oil demand, with April sales of gasoline and diesel reaching their lowest levels since August and October, respectively. Fuel sales fell by about 10% from March levels due to lockdowns and curfews, and are expected to continue to decline until June. Despite this, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) has agreed to relax supply curbs, citing a global recovery in other major economies. India is the third-largest oil importer and a vital energy market, with leading refiners typically sourcing most cargoes from the Middle East and Nigeria.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower on Monday; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) falling 0.1% to 3,216.75. The decline follows Wall Street's end of the day lower, weighed by concerns over rising supply chain and commodity costs. Losers outnumbered gainers 71 to 58, with Sembcorp Marine and Mercurius being the most actively traded counters. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index declined 0.7% and 0.9%, respectively.

site_title: Warren Buffett wants to make you happier, smarter and richer
summary: Warren Buffett, 90, and his business partner Charlie Munger, 97, emphasized the importance of long-term thinking and avoiding emotional decision-making during the Berkshire Hathaway annual meeting. They cautioned against the dangers of mega-cap stock valuations and the appeal of short-term trading, instead advocating for diversified index funds and a more rational approach to investing. Buffett also stressed the importance of self-awareness and humility, admitting mistakes and encouraging investors to cultivate optimism and a long-term perspective.

site_title: CGS-CIMB launches S$150m commercial paper in digital securities on iSTOX
summary: CGS-CIMB Securities (Singapore) has launched a S$150 million commercial paper in digital securities on iSTOX, a platform backed by Singapore Exchange (SGX). The move allows the financial services provider to tap an alternative source of funding and a wider spectrum of investors. The commercial paper, which has a 1% per annum interest rate over three months, will be used to fund operating expenses and near-term obligations. This is the first time CGS-CIMB has issued a commercial paper fully digitally, and iSTOX's automation of issuance, custody, and post-sale management enables fractional ownership and lower fees.

site_title: Thugs-for-hire take investor disputes to extremes in Hong Kong
summary: Thugs-for-hire disrupted a shareholder meeting in Hong Kong, with 18 intruders attempting to force their way in and assaulting company employees. Eight men were arrested, and the incident highlights the challenge authorities face in addressing market misconduct. The use of force is rare in Hong Kong but reminiscent of Japan's yakuza gangster disruptions in the 1980s and 1990s. The incident is part of a long-standing struggle against bad behavior in the markets, with authorities pursuing "nefarious networks" involved in stock manipulation and other market misconduct.

site_title: Halcyon Agri bags three-year syndicated loan facility of up to US$300m
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation secured a three-year syndicated loan facility of up to US$300 million to refinance its existing US$300 million term loan. The loan, worth US$270 million, has a greenshoe option for an additional US$30 million. Proceeds will be used to enhance liquidity and support new business opportunities. The loan was supported by the Singapore branch of China Construction Bank Corporation and is subject to certain conditions. The deal demonstrates continued confidence in Halcyon Agri from financial institutions, following its issuance of US$200 million Sinochem International Corp guaranteed perpetual securities in 2020.

site_title: UOBAM's China-focused funds attract more than S$1b in AUM in less than two years
summary: UOB Asset Management's (UOBAM) two China-focused funds, United China-A Shares Innovation Fund and United China-A Shares Consumption Upgrade Fund, have attracted over S$1 billion in assets under management (AUM) in less than two years. The funds, managed by Ping An Fund Management Company, have drawn strong investor interest from Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand, particularly in the second half of 2020. The funds have achieved significant returns, with the innovation fund returning 143.13% since its inception in 2019 and the consumption fund returning 32.71% since its establishment in 2020.

site_title: Siemens Healthineers raises outlook on demand for rapid Covid tests
summary: Siemens Healthineers raised its full-year sales and profit forecast due to ongoing demand for rapid Covid-19 tests. The company now expects sales to grow 14-17% and adjusted earnings per share to 1.90-2.05 euros. Rapid antigen test revenues are forecasted at 750 million euros in 2021, up from 300-350 million previously estimated. The company reported a 7.6% sales increase in its fiscal second quarter to 3.965 billion euros, with a 8% increase in net income to 447 million euros.

images.alt_text: German health technology company Siemens Healthineers raised its full-year sales and profit forecast on Monday, as the global Covid-19 pandemic continues to drive demand for its rapid antigen tests.

site_title: Sembmarine expects losses to continue for FY2021, posts over S$1.89b order book
summary: SembCorp Marine expects losses for FY2021 due to Covid-19 supply chain constraints and a shortage of skilled workers, primarily affecting foreign workers unable to return to Singapore. Despite this, the company has an existing order book of over S$1.89 billion and is actively tendering for more projects. The company's strategic investments are positioned for the global low-carbon economy transition, and it expects sufficient liquidity to fund operations. Its net debt to equity ratio is 0.74 times, and shares closed at S$0.205, down 2.38%.

site_title: Intel will focus less on buying back company stock: CEO
summary: Intel CEO Pat Gelsinger announced the company will reduce its focus on buying back its own stock, shifting resources to research and development instead. This decision comes after a comparison of Intel's stock buybacks to its investment in R&D. Gelsinger made the statement in an interview on CBS's "60 Minutes."

site_title: FYIstival: A digital festival of overseas opportunities
summary: The Singapore Business Federation is hosting FYIstival, a digital festival offering overseas business opportunities amidst the pandemic. The event features webinars, resources, and a networking platform for firms to meet potential overseas partners. FYIstival aims to provide a digital alternative to in-person business missions.

site_title: Algo trading gains ground as AI grows
summary: Algo trading is gaining popularity in the stock market, with more institutions and investors using artificial intelligence models to make decisions. These programs follow specific instructions based on data such as momentum, interest rates, and market sentiment. However, concerns arise about the potential for these programs to become self-defeating, exacerbating market volatility. Despite this, algo funds have been successful in the past, and their use is expected to continue.

site_title: SBF seeks to build ecosystem that grows stronger via more partnerships
summary: Singapore Business Federation (SBF) CEO Lam Yi Young emphasizes the importance of partnerships in driving growth and recovery for businesses. He aims to build an ecosystem that fosters stronger connections between firms, the government, and trade associations. The SBF will focus on facilitating partnerships between large and small enterprises, encouraging internationalization, and supporting SMEs in areas like digitalization and training. With a renewed emphasis on sustainability, women in the workforce, and fair hiring, Lam seeks to strengthen the SBF's role as a bridge between the government and businesses.

site_title: Battling Covid: The Tokyo conundrum
summary: Tokyo is considering holding the Olympics in July-August 2021 despite COVID-19 risks. Victor Mills, CEO of Singapore International Chamber of Commerce, suggests mitigating risks with venue "bubbles," safe seating, frequent testing, and compulsory vaccination for attendees. Public health considerations should be the primary factor in deciding whether the Games proceed, rather than national pride or athlete frustrations. Mills emphasizes the importance of dealing with the situation as it is, rather than idealizing it. The Olympic Games' safety and feasibility will be crucial in determining their fate.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sembmarine, Great Eastern, Venture Corp, EC World Reit, OUELH

summary: A group of NGOs has urged the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to end loans to the fossil-fuels sector, citing the need for a green economic recovery. summary: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has released its annual Asian Development Outlook report, predicting a regional economic rebound in 2021 and 2022, driven by a "healthy global recovery" and vaccination progress. In the first quarter of 2021, 14 Singapore Reits (S-Reits) reported a 31% year-over-year increase in distributions per unit (DPUs). The top five S-Reits with the highest DPU increments were SPH Reit (+313.3%), Mapletree Commercial Trust (+57.9%), ARA Logos Logistics Trust (+35.7%), Frasers Centrepoint Trust (28.4%), and Keppel DC Reit (18.1%). S-Reits reported strong occupancy rates, with SPH Reit's 98% and Mapletree Commercial Trust's 99.1% portfolio committed occupancy. The S-Reit sector is expected to continue its growth momentum, with more updates expected in May.

site_title: Italy's Mario Draghi drives G-20 post-pandemic agenda
summary: Italy's Prime Minister Mario Draghi is leading the G-20's post-pandemic agenda, focusing on global health and economic recovery. A global health summit co-chaired by Draghi and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen was held on May 21, recommending voluntary actions to boost coronavirus vaccine production and proposing a US$50 billion project to end the pandemic by vaccinating 40% of the world's population by 2021. The summit also announced plans to establish three new manufacturing hubs in Africa to boost vaccine production and provide large supplies of at-cost vaccines to developing nations.

site_title: The great corporate bond binge: Where is all the cash going?
summary: Companies globally are taking advantage of low interest rates to raise record amounts of debt, with global investment-grade corporate debt issuance reaching $2.94 trillion in 2020. Despite low borrowing costs, many companies are not using the funds for operational purposes, with studies showing that a majority of bond proceeds are being used to pay shareholders. Experts expect sectors like technology and online retail to continue borrowing cheaply to expand operations, while others, such as airlines and hospitality, may be more cautious due to debt struggles. However, some companies may be hoarding cash for economic recovery or to prepare for distressed assets. With inflation chatter and potential interest rate hikes on the horizon, investors are watching for signs of a sell-off in corporate debt markets.

site_title: Jack Ma to step down as president of his business school: FT
summary: Chinese billionaire Jack Ma, founder of Alibaba, is stepping down as president of Hupan University, a business school he founded in 2015, amid Beijing's crackdown on tech titans. Ma, who has largely disappeared from public view since Alibaba's fintech arm was investigated, will not hold any high-level title at the restructured organization. The move is part of Beijing's efforts to limit Ma's influence and dismantle his fintech empire, which has been fined a record 18.2 billion yuan by antitrust authorities.

site_title: Chinese regulators warn metal firms to maintain good market order
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) warned metal firms to maintain "normal market order" amid significant gains in metals prices this year. The warning follows a statement from the government to manage "unreasonable" price increases for key commodities, including copper, coal, steel, and iron ore, which China is the world's largest user of. The talks with major domestic companies aim to prevent price manipulation and maintain market stability.

site_title: 21 new Covid-19 cases in community; six unlinked
summary: Singapore reported 30 new COVID-19 cases on May 25, bringing the total to 61,890. Of these, 21 are community cases, with six unlinked to previous cases. There were also three new cases from migrant workers' dormitories and nine imported cases. The Ministry of Health (MOH) has quarantined eight community cases and placed nine on stay-home notices.

site_title: WHO sets new targets for vaccinating world's poorest to end inequity
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has set new targets to vaccinate the world's poorest countries against COVID-19, aiming to inoculate 10% of all populations by September and 30% by year-end. The organization's director-general, Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, warned that a small group of countries controlling most vaccines are perpetuating inequity, with over 75% of all vaccines administered in just 10 countries. He urged countries to donate vaccine doses to Covax and manufacturers to commit 50% of their volumes to Covax this year.

site_title: Yellen pitches budget increase for treasury after Trump-era cuts
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is seeking a budget increase for her agency, citing a 20% budget cut since 2016. The department's annual budget, not accounting for inflation, is the same as in 2010. Yellen argues that the IRS needs more funding to ensure compliance with tax payments from wealthy taxpayers. The Treasury Department has established programs to distribute over $1 trillion in direct payments and aid, but its budget has not grown in tandem. A 10.6% increase in the Treasury Department's discretionary budget is proposed for fiscal year 2022.

site_title: Anger simmers in Malaysia as Covid-19 surge strains healthcare system
summary: Malaysia's Covid-19 surge has strained its healthcare system, with daily infections and deaths hitting a record high. A video of medical workers struggling to resuscitate a patient in a quarantine center sparked public anger, with many blaming the government for its handling of the pandemic. The government has been criticized for not imposing tougher curbs or taking stronger action against lockdown violations. Despite a state of emergency, Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin's government is under pressure to take decisive measures to combat the surge, with health experts warning of a potential collapse of the healthcare system.

site_title: Spain hotel bookings jump in April, but still far from pre-Covid levels
summary: Spain saw a significant surge in hotel bookings in April, reaching 4.05 million nights, a 100% increase from zero in 2020. However, this still represents an 85% decline from pre-Covid levels in April 2019. Despite this, preliminary data suggests bookings are gathering pace in May after the national state of emergency expired. The Spanish government aims to reach 30-40% of pre-pandemic levels this summer and up to 70% by the end of the year, with the relaxation of travel restrictions for fully vaccinated visitors from June 7.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on tech, Wall Street boost
summary: Australian shares ended the week higher, with the benchmark ASX 200 index closing 0.2% higher at 7030.3 points. The gains were driven by a positive Wall Street session, with US job growth signs boosting sentiment. Local tech stocks, such as Kogan.com and EML Payments, were top gainers, while banking stocks were flat. The ASX 200 index delivered a weekly gain of 0.23%.

site_title: 2021 VW Golf swings into Singapore
summary: Volkswagen's eighth-generation Golf has made its Singapore debut, with prices starting at S$125,900 for the Golf Life 1.5 eTSI. The new model features a mild hybrid drivetrain, digital interior with touch-sensitive pads and screens, and connectivity features. Two additional variants, Golf Life Plus and Golf R-Line, are also available, while the Golf GTI offers a 245 horsepower engine. The new Golf continues Volkswagen's strategy of spreading premium features into the mainstream, which has helped the company sell 35 million Golfs. The vehicle is now available for purchase in Singapore.

site_title: Final-day drama in Europe's top football leagues
summary: Top European football teams are set to play their final matches, with several titles and Champions League spots still up for grabs. In Spain, Atletico Madrid needs a win to become Spanish champions, while Real Valladolid must avoid relegation. In Germany, Bayern Munich is expected to win, and Robert Lewandowski is poised to break a record. In the English Premier League, Liverpool needs a win to secure a Champions League spot, while in Italy, Juventus must secure a win to avoid the Europa League.

site_title: Union leaders seeking views on how to improve well-being of healthcare frontliners
summary: Union leaders in Singapore are gathering feedback from healthcare workers to improve their well-being during the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is sharing the feedback with the Ministry of Health and hospitals, aiming to enhance processes and support measures. A joint effort by NTUC, the Hospital Employees' Union, and NTUC FairPrice is also providing 12,000 care packs to healthcare workers, containing essential items such as hand sanitiser and vitamin pastilles.

site_title: Cask strength: Is rare whisky liquid gold or an evaporating asset?
summary: Rare whisky has emerged as a luxury good globally, with its value jumping 478% in the past decade, outpacing the Knight Frank Luxury Investment Index. The market is driven by wealthy individuals, particularly in Asia, where demand is mostly from high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs). Whisky casks have also gained traction, with funds and investment schemes offering provenance and longer-term gains. However, industry watchers caution of a bubble waiting to pop, citing frothy valuations and risks such as forgery and unclear duties. The market may be too niche for a significant impact on investment portfolios, and experts recommend a cautious approach, with some warning of a potential correction in prices.

site_title: Gaza media building owner complains to ICC: lawyer
summary: The owner of Jala Tower, a Gaza building housing international media, has filed a complaint with the International Criminal Court (ICC) alleging that an Israeli airstrike on May 15 was a "war crime". The owner, Jawad Mehdi, claims that Israel could show "no military objective" for the attack, which destroyed the building housing the offices of the Associated Press and Al Jazeera. The ICC has already opened an investigation into possible war crimes in the Palestinian Territories, and the complaint may be considered by the court.

images.alt_text: The owner of a Gaza building housing international media that was destroyed in an Israeli airstrike is lodging a complaint with the International Criminal Court (ICC), his lawyer said.

site_title: Not all SPACs are created equal; not all deals will work out
summary: Investors in Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs) must conduct thorough due diligence, as not all deals will succeed. The US SPAC market raised $100 billion in 2021, accounting for two-thirds of the total raised in the last two decades. A recent study found that SPACs typically experience a 40% price jump during the announcement phase, but disappointing returns in the post-completion phase, with 50% of SPACs experiencing negative returns one month after completion. Key factors contributing to underperformance include dilution effects from warrants and redemptions, as well as the involvement of investors rather than operators in SPACs.

site_title: Lamborghini reveals plans to go electric
summary: Lamborghini plans to invest over 1.5 billion euros to electrify its high-performance car lineup by 2024, aiming for a 50% CO2 reduction. CEO Stephan Winkelmann emphasizes the need to balance performance and efficiency, ensuring the "spirit of Lamborghini" remains intact. The company will launch its first hybrid car in 2023, followed by a full electric car in the second half of the decade, with a focus on everyday usability. Despite electrification, Lamborghini aims to maintain its unique blend of design, handling, and acceleration.

site_title: Watches to make you go green with envy
summary: Patek Philippe has released a limited-edition Nautilus stainless steel timepiece featuring an olive-green sunburst dial, making it one of several luxury watches with green dials released this year. The new model is part of the 5711 series, which will be discontinued after this year. Other brands such as Rolex, Audemars Piguet, Cartier, and TAG Heuer have also introduced green-dialed watches, marking a shift in the colored dial trend from blue to green.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIIC, SIA, ST Engineering, CDL, Unusual, Chip Eng Seng, SingHaiyi, CSE Global
summary: Stocks to watch: Several companies saw new developments on Thursday, including SIIC, which signed a supplementary agreement for a wastewater treatment project in China, and SIA, which announced a record net loss for FY2021. ST Engineering signed a letter of intent to lease Airbus A321 Passenger-to-Freighter aircrafts to Global Crossing Airlines. CDL sold 319 units in the first quarter, while Unusual is expected to record a net loss for FY2021. Chip Eng Seng's wholly-owned subsidiary, CEL Development, incorporated two joint venture companies, and CSE Global reported a 22.3% decrease in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open on Thursday with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell in the opening minutes of trade on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index dropping 0.63% to 28,413.49. The decline follows a global sell-off on Wednesday. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also fell, shedding 0.29% and 0.28% respectively. The losses are attributed to investors playing catch-up after a midweek holiday.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks fell in the opening minutes of trade on Thursday as investors returned from a midweek holiday to play catch-up with the previous day's global sell-off.

site_title: AT&T to merge media assets with Discovery in US$43b deal
summary: AT&T has agreed to spin off its media operations in a $43 billion deal with Discovery, creating a new entertainment company that will include assets such as CNN, HBO, and HGTV. AT&T shareholders will receive 71% of the new company's stock, while Discovery CEO David Zaslav will lead the entity. The deal marks a retreat for AT&T's entertainment-industry ambitions, which have been costly and unsuccessful, and will allow the company to focus on its core telecom business and pay down debt.

site_title: Huawei consumer tech tzar Richard Yu appointed smart-car CEO
summary: Huawei has appointed Richard Yu, 51, as CEO of its smart-car solutions unit, expanding his responsibilities in the auto segment. Yu, who led the company's consumer electronics business, will focus on recreating its success in the smart-car market. The move comes as Huawei's consumer tech unit, its growth engine, has been hampered by US sanctions. Huawei has budgeted $1 billion for the smart-car category this year, competing with rivals like Xiaomi and Baidu in the electric vehicle market. Yu will not relinquish his responsibilities leading the consumer tech division.

site_title: Residents of Hougang block to be tested for Covid-19; man aged 70 dies from virus
summary: Residents of Block 506 Hougang Avenue 8 in Singapore are to be tested for Covid-19 after several cases were found in the area. The Ministry of Health has set up a testing operation at the block's void deck on Friday and Saturday. A 70-year-old man, who had not been vaccinated and had underlying health conditions, died from Covid-19, bringing Singapore's total deaths to 32. There were 27 new community cases and 14 imported cases reported on Thursday, taking the total to 61,730.

site_title: Investment banker at DBS and two-year-old boy among 27 new Covid-19 cases in the community
summary: A total of 27 new COVID-19 cases were reported in Singapore's community on May 18, including an investment banker at DBS and a two-year-old boy. The cases are linked to previous infections, with 16 cases connected to other cases and 11 unlinked cases. The new cases bring Singapore's total to 61,651. Fourteen of the new cases had already been quarantined, and the unlinked cases include a 46-year-old DBS banker, a 57-year-old MHA employee, and a 40-year-old food delivery rider.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 3.20 points lower, or 0.20%, at 1,588.12 on Wednesday. The index saw a volume of 300.91 million lots worth RM126.83 million. Losers outnumbered gainers 221 to 128.

site_title: Back to the future
summary: Oracle Japan and Asia-Pacific president Garrett Ilg sees a post-pandemic Asia ready for a boom, driven by a digital shift and the need for rapid transformation. The pandemic has accelerated the adoption of digital tools, with companies either innovating or going through the motions. Ilg believes those that adapt will scale up and capture new markets, while those that don't will be left behind. He notes that Asia is a hub for digital innovation, with the region's first movers in internet, mobile, and virtual technologies. Oracle is well-positioned to help customers navigate this transformation, and Ilg predicts a massive movement towards consumerism and travel once the pandemic is overcome.

site_title: WarnerMedia and Discovery to merge, forming streaming giant
summary: AT&T to merge WarnerMedia with Discovery, creating a streaming giant. The deal, valued at $43 billion, will form a standalone global entertainment company with a combined portfolio of premium entertainment, sports, and news assets. WarnerMedia owns CNN and HBO, while Discovery owns Eurosport. The merger aims to challenge industry leaders Netflix and Disney+, with AT&T shareholders holding 71% of the new company and Discovery shareholders holding 29%. The deal is expected to create one of the largest global streaming players.

site_title: One size may not fit all
summary: Business leaders are divided on the idea of a global minimum corporate tax rate, with some supporting its implementation and others opposing it. Proponents argue that it would curb base erosion and profit-shifting, while others claim it could lead to a "race to the bottom" in tax rates and increase costs for companies. Some experts suggest that a global minimum rate of 12.5% could be a reasonable starting point, but implementation challenges and differing interests among jurisdictions remain significant hurdles.

site_title: Ferraris for the people: luxury goods now sold in fractions
summary: A growing number of fractional ownership platforms offer shares of luxury items, such as art, cars, and sports memorabilia, starting at a few dollars. These platforms allow anyone to own a piece of a rare item, without the need to physically possess it, and benefit from potential value increases. Examples include Masterworks, which turned a Basquiat painting into 284,420 shares, and Rally, which has seen a surge in interest during the pandemic, with over 200,000 users and $25 million in assets listed. However, the market is still experimental, and concerns about price risks and sharp price swings remain.

site_title: Dogecoin jumps after Musk tweets about 'promising' system improvements
summary: Dogecoin surged 20% after Elon Musk tweeted that he was working to improve the token's transaction efficiency, calling it "potentially promising." The cryptocurrency rose from $0.43 to $0.52 on the Binance exchange. This move comes after dogecoin's market value increased by over a hundredfold this year, making it the fourth-largest cryptocurrency.

site_title: ABN Amro posts Q1 loss as fine hits earnings, loan income falls
summary: ABN Amro Bank NV reported a net loss of 54 million euros in the first quarter due to a slump in lending income and a fine for weak money-laundering controls. The loss was a bigger-than-expected 54 million euros, wiping out gains from releasing 77 million euros from credit loss reserves. The shares slid the most in over five months.

site_title: Fintech companies SDAX and Minterest to merge, build digital asset exchange ecosystem
summary: Fintech companies SDAX and Minterest Holdings have agreed to merge, forming a global digital asset exchange ecosystem. The ecosystem will offer integrated solutions for deal origination, fundraising, and secondary trading. Minterest Holdings, backed by ARA Asset Management, will provide access to alternative investments, while SDAX, backed by RHT Fintech Holdings, offers blockchain-powered trading and settlement. The merger is subject to Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) approval and will constitute part of MAS's review of SDAX's application to operate a digital asset exchange.

site_title: Finance for good
summary: Finastra CEO Simon Paris emphasizes the company's focus on financial inclusion and tackling the SME trade finance gap amidst the global pandemic. Finastra has seen significant growth, with over 200 million bank accounts live on its system globally. Paris believes the pandemic has accelerated the industry's shift towards digital innovation, with more than half of Finastra's customers now on the cloud. The company aims to expand its presence in Asia-Pacific and sub-Saharan Africa, with plans to double business in these regions within the next three years. Finastra also aims to eliminate racial and gender bias from lending through reforms and new technologies.

site_title: Huarong risks could delay stimulus exit by China's central bank
summary: China's central bank may delay exiting pandemic stimulus due to heightened financial stability risks surrounding state-owned financial company Huarong Asset Management. The company, which owes $42 billion to domestic and international bondholders, has not released 2020 financial results, triggering market concerns. Economists say the People's Bank of China will take longer than expected to taper monetary support, citing emerging credit risks and the need to prevent systemic contagion. The central bank has highlighted financing pressures at local governments and pressed for creating a system to hold officials accountable for major financial risks.

site_title: Nissan posts record annual loss due to pandemic, chip shortage
summary: Nissan Motor reported a record annual operating loss of 150.65 billion yen (S$1.84 billion) due to the pandemic and global semiconductor shortage. This marks the worst performance in 12 years, with the company not making a profit since 2019. Despite a forecasted loss of 205 billion yen, Nissan recovered from sales in China and cut costs. The company expects to break even for the new fiscal year, lower than analysts' forecast of a 241.7 billion yen profit.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Wednesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 1.61% at 28,147.51, and the Topix index down 1.47% at 1,877.95. Concerns over the winding down of American monetary easing weighed on the market.

site_title: How Singapore built a startup ecosystem from scratch
summary: Singapore transformed its startup ecosystem from a ghost town to a thriving industry over the past 20 years through visionary planning, openness to foreign talent, and determined effort. The country's success stories, such as billion-dollar unicorns, were once non-starters. Experts and leaders share their insights on how Singapore can maintain its momentum and address gaps in the ecosystem. The country's focus on innovation, risk-taking, and collaboration has enabled it to become a hub for startups and entrepreneurs.

site_title: Twitter lets people leave tips for some tweeters
summary: Twitter has introduced a "Tip Jar" feature, allowing some users to add virtual tip jars to their profiles, supporting creators with money. The feature, available to a limited number of English-language users, includes experts, journalists, and non-profits. Users can send tips to creators through services like Patreon, PayPal, or Venmo, with no cut taken by Twitter. The company aims to expand the feature to more users and languages, following weaker-than-expected earnings and disappointing user growth.

site_title: SGX Web services hit by outage; trading unaffected
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) experienced technical difficulties with its Web services, starting at 4:30 pm on Tuesday, but trading remained unaffected. The issue was attributed to a domain name system (DNS) problem, and SGX stated that there was no indication of a cyber attack or malicious cause. The recovery effort was underway, with SGX advising users to visit brokers' websites for price information and issuer announcements until full restoration was complete.

site_title: UK construction reports biggest rise in workload since 2016
summary: The UK construction sector has reported its biggest rise in workload since 2016, driven by strong demand for housing and resumption of projects as the pandemic eases. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) survey found a balance for workloads rose to +26 in the first quarter of 2021, its highest since early 2016. Profit margins are expected to increase for the first time since 2019, and recruitment and volumes of work are expected to rise over the coming months. A shortage of building materials is now the biggest constraint on construction.

site_title: Madrid voters go to the polls in Covid- influenced crunch election
summary: Voters in Madrid, Spain's wealthiest region, cast ballots in an election that could reshape the nation's political landscape. Isabel Diaz Ayuso, a conservative from the opposition People's Party, is the frontrunner to remain regional leader, having defied the left-wing government's Covid-19 restrictions to prioritize the economy and social life. The Madrid region has a high number of Covid-19 cases, and a convincing PP win could give the party momentum at a national level. Ayuso may need the help of the far-right Vox party to govern, with Ciudadanos facing the prospect of disappearing from the political landscape.

site_title: Evergrande raises HK$10.6b selling shares in EV unit
summary: Evergrande Group raised approximately HK$10.6 billion (S$1.8 billion) by selling shares in its electric vehicle unit, China Evergrande New Energy Vehicle Group Ltd. The sale accounts for 2.7% of outstanding shares and came at a 20% discount. The move aims to repair Evergrande's balance sheet and meet Chinese regulators' efforts to deleverage the property sector. The company plans to use the proceeds for general working capital, aiming to halve its borrowings over the next two years.

site_title: Great Eastern Q1 profit hits S$437.6m on favourable market conditions
summary: Great Eastern posted a net profit of S$437.6 million for its Q1 2021, 12.9 times the S$33.9 million reported for the same quarter last year, driven by favourable market conditions. Operating profit fell 39% to S$182.3 million and non-operating profit increased to S$214.7 million. The group also registered a 28% increase in total weighted net sales to S$383.6 million and a 30% growth in new business embedded value to S$182.2 million.

site_title: The promise and peril of central bank digital currencies
summary: The US Federal Reserve, European Central Bank, and others are assessing the prospects of issuing central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) to improve financial inclusion and reduce cross-border transaction costs. However, CBDCs pose complications, including concerns over privacy, control, and international cooperation. The development of CBDCs may threaten the current international financial system, and experts caution that they should not be introduced until issues are resolved. The US dollar's key role in the system makes it essential for the country to adopt a CBDC to maintain its influence.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on US outlook, iron ore at record high
summary: Asian markets rallied on Friday following a record-breaking finish on Wall Street, driven by a positive US jobs report and iron ore prices hitting a record high. The US jobs figures, which showed claims fell to a pandemic-era low, boosted optimism for a full economic recovery. Iron ore prices reached an all-time high of $200.25 a ton, while copper approached a 10-year high, driven by surging demand for commodities from China. The rally was seen as a sign of the global reflation trade, with concerns about potential inflation and the Federal Reserve's monetary policies.

images.alt_text: Asian markets rallied on Friday following a record-breaking finish on Wall Street as traders keenly await a key US jobs report that is expected to reaffirm the recovery in the world's top economy is blasting ahead.

site_title: A new age for office space: What happens to the office market when offices adapt?
summary: Office rental contracts signed as companies adapt to remote working, with about two-thirds of firms planning to limit remote working to one or two days weekly. Office rents rose 3.3% in Q1 2021, reversing from a 3.5% contraction in Q4 2020, while vacancy rates edged up to 11.9%. Companies such as Google, Facebook, and banks are rationalizing office space, with some planning to reduce their footprints by 20% or more. Tech firms, including Chinese tech giants, are stepping in to fill the gap, supporting demand for office space.

site_title: India's seven-day Covid-19 average at new high; WHO issues warning on strain
summary: India's seven-day average of new COVID-19 cases reached a record high of 390,995, with daily cases rising by 329,942 and deaths by 3,876. The World Health Organization has warned of the strain, classifying India's variant as a "variant of global concern" due to increased transmissibility. The country's medical facilities are struggling with a shortage of oxygen, leading to deaths and hospitalizations. The government has warned of mucormycosis, a rare but potentially fatal infection linked to diabetes, and advised against using cow dung to ward off COVID-19.

images.alt_text: India's coronavirus crisis showed scant sign of easing on Tuesday, with a seven-day average of new cases at a record high and international health authorities warning the country's variant of the virus poses a global concern.

site_title: Partial offer for Procurri lapses, both requisite thresholds unmet
summary: Novo Tellus' partial offer to acquire a 51-per-cent stake in Procurri has lapsed due to both requisite thresholds not being met. The offeror received 8.55% valid acceptances, falling short of the 50% required to get the deal through. Independent shareholders voted 37.2% in favor, while the remaining voted against. Novo Tellus will return shares to shareholders who accepted the partial offer, and the company will continue to hold its 28.83% stake, maintaining its partnership with Procurri's leadership team to build long-term equity value.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group Q1 net profit up 22.2%
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) reported a 22.2% increase in Q1 net profit to S$3.8 million, driven by a surge in demand for its aesthetics, Lasik, and diagnostic imaging services. The group remains cautiously optimistic on its health segment and plans to expand its specialist verticals. Revenue rose 7.6% to a quarterly record of S$24.8 million, with core business operations generating strong positive operating cash flows. SMG's net cash position improved to S$18.4 million, down from S$15.8 million at end-December.

site_title: First Resources Q1 net profit falls by 60.5% on higher export taxes
summary: First Resources reported a 60.5% decline in Q1 net profit to US$8.8 million, despite a 40.3% increase in sales to US$196.9 million. Higher export taxes from Indonesia's new levy structure, which increased levy payable by exporters for every tonne of crude palm oil, impacted the company. Sales rose mainly due to a recovery in production volumes and yields, with an 18.1% increase in CPO production. The company expects overall output growth for the full year, but faces challenges from forward sales and higher export levies.

site_title: Saudi private-sector employment rises for first time this year
summary: Saudi Arabia's non-oil private sector activity grew for an eighth consecutive month in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rising to 55.2, indicating a strengthening of growth across the non-oil economy. This marked the first time private-sector employment rose in the first half of the year. However, business outlook weakened as fewer respondents projected growth in the coming 12 months, citing concerns over a possible Covid-19 wave and issues with foreign travel.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Singapore's NTT DC Reit's public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while US stocks opened lower due to Trump's tariff on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall and operating loss. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detained an employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Meanwhile, Singapore's stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran, and the MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: Tighter Covid-19 curbs could hit retail, office Reits again
summary: Tighter COVID-19 curbs in Singapore are expected to impact retail and office Reits, with analysts predicting a rotation of interest to industrial Reits. Downtown retail and office Reits may see a slowdown in leasing momentum, while hospitality Reits are likely to be less affected due to delayed tourist arrivals. Despite the potential impact, DBS Group Research suggests the overall impact on earnings will be marginal, with some Reits, such as those with a focus on essential trades, showing resilience.

site_title: MC Payment's controlling shareholder seeks place on board along with two ousted directors
summary: MC Payment's controlling shareholder, Ching Chiat Kwong, is seeking a place on the company's board, along with two ousted directors, Shawn Ching and Harry Ng Weng Sui. Kwong, who holds 27.06% of the issued shares, plans to requisition an extraordinary general meeting to make the nominations. The move comes after Ng and Shawn Ching were voted out by 56.69% of eligible voters at the annual general meeting on April 28. MC Payment is seeking legal advice on the letters and will update shareholders on further developments.

site_title: Keppel unit bags Petrobras FPSO contract worth US$2.3b
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine (Keppel O&M) has secured a US$2.3 billion contract from Petrobras to deliver the P-78 FPSO, a floating production storage and offloading vessel, for deployment in Brazil's deepwater Buzios field. The FPSO is expected to have a production capacity of 180,000 barrels of oil per day and will rank among the largest in the global operating fleet. The contract is the latest major FPSO project for Keppel O&M, supporting Petrobras and generating job opportunities in Brazil.

site_title: Grab, Sea and more: How Singapore forged a startup ecosystem
summary: Singapore's startup ecosystem has undergone significant growth and transformation since the early 2000s. In 2014, venture capitalist Anthony Tan convinced Grab's co-founder to move the company's headquarters from Malaysia to Singapore, marking a turning point in the country's startup scene. Since then, Singapore has seen numerous successes, including Grab's record-breaking IPO, Sea's rise as the world's best-performing stock, and the growth of startups like PatSnap, TradeGecko, and 99.co. The government's efforts to build a startup ecosystem, including initiatives such as the National Research Foundation's Early Stage Venture Fund and the Technology Incubation Scheme, have played a crucial role in attracting venture capital, talent, and investment. Today, Singapore is home to around 3,800 startups and 190 incubators and accelerators, with the country's startup scene poised for continued growth in the region.

site_title: Modern Japanese bar food and fun at IKO
summary: IKO Restaurant & Bar in Singapore offers a modern Japanese dining experience with a friendly, easy-going vibe. Despite initial teething problems, including power outages and kitchen issues, the restaurant's service recovery efforts impressed. The menu features a mix of Japanese and Asian-European flavors, with standout dishes including uni, somen, and grilled Japanese corn. While some dishes, such as the tai 'crudo' and scampi donabe, had flaws, the overall experience was enjoyable and well-priced, with a rating of 6.5 out of 10.

site_title: Nine contracts worth S$320m awarded for Singapore-Johor RTS Link systems
summary: Nine contracts worth S$321.7 million have been awarded for system works on the Singapore-Johor RTS Link, a 4km rail line connecting Woodlands North with Bukit Chagar in Johor Baru. The contracts were awarded by RTS Operations, a joint venture between SMRT and Prasarana, and include work on core systems, track work, and power supply systems. The project, which will ease congestion on the Causeway, is expected to be completed in 2026 and will carry up to 10,000 passengers per hour in each direction, reducing travel time to just five minutes.

site_title: SGX securities turnover value down 9% to S$27b from last April
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 9% decline in total market turnover value to S$27 billion in April, down from S$29.63 billion in the same month last year. Despite this, secondary fund-raising rose to its highest amount in six months, reaching S$1.3 billion. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 1.7% month-on-month to 3,218.27, driven by a 2% dividend boost, resulting in a 14% total return over the first four months of 2021.

site_title: European economic outlook upgraded on fiscal fund, vaccines
summary: The European Commission upgraded its growth outlook for the euro-area economy to 4.3% this year, citing a strong global rebound, vaccination campaign, and fiscal support from the EU's 800 billion-euro joint recovery fund. The region is expected to reach its pre-pandemic size by the end of this year, with growth expected to accelerate in 2022. However, the recovery is expected to be uneven, with some economies not reaching pre-pandemic levels until next year.

images.alt_text: EU's Paolo Gentiloni says: "Today, for the first time since the pandemic hit, we see optimism prevailing over uncertainty."

site_title: Marriott eyes posh all-inclusive resorts to draw next-gen travellers amid cautious rebound
summary: Marriott International is shifting its focus to catering to the next generation of travelers amid a cautious travel rebound. The company is expanding its all-inclusive resort offerings, including the acquisition of 19 Blue Diamond Resorts around the Caribbean, which will be converted into luxury brands such as Ritz-Carlton and Westin. This move aims to appeal to travelers seeking seamless, hassle-free experiences, as the industry adapts to changing consumer preferences, including a growing emphasis on sustainability and purposeful travel. Marriott's CEO, Anthony Capuano, has seen the company's shares rise since his appointment, and the company is now poised to capitalize on the growing demand for luxury, all-inclusive resorts.

images.alt_text: Marriott has turned its focus to a new sector - one devoted to rental homes called Marriott Homes and Villas, which debuted in 2019 as a far-cry competitor to Airbnb.

site_title: Copper, iron ore hit records as demand surges
summary: Copper and iron ore prices reached record highs due to a powerful global economic recovery, with copper breaking above $10,200 per tonne and iron ore above $200 a tonne. Demand for key commodities is surging as industries ramp up production, driven by major economies reopening after shutdowns. Analysts predict higher prices in the next few years, citing decarbonization trends and increased demand for metals. The surge in prices has sparked concerns about inflation and potentially forcing central banks to tighten monetary policies.

images.alt_text: Copper and iron ore prices hit record highs on Friday as demand for the key commodities surges on the back of a powerful recovery in the global economy, though Asian equity markets struggled to maintain an early rally ahead of a keenly awaited US jobs report.
